HEADLINE: Pollution Poses Growing Threat To Everglades

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLAMINGO, Fla., Sept. 15

 BODY:
The Everglades, 10,000 square miles of delicate marshland that is home to some of the country's rarest birds and other animals, are caught in a worsening environmental crisis, with thousands of acres already unable to sustain wildlife.
The National Audubon Society estimates that the number of long-legged wading birds, like wood storks and egrets, that nest in the waters of the Everglades has declined 90 percent since the 1920's.
This summer, for the first time, fish in most parts of the Everglades have been declared unsafe for eating, because of mercury contamination. Alligator hunting, in season this month in Florida, has been banned in the Everglades because of high mercury levels in gator meat as well.
 
Unwanted Plant Life
But of even more concern to officials is the runoff from dairy, sugar-cane and other farms. Environmentalists say the runoff, rich in nutrients, has fed an explosion in the growth of plant varieties that clog open waterways, robbing them of oxygen and crowding out animal life. The plants, especially cattails, are spreading at the rate of four acres a day. 
Meanwhile, 110,000 acres of the Everglades was swept this summer by fires that went unchecked because of drought.
''Of all the national parks, it is the one closest to extinction,'' said George T. Frampton, the president of the Wilderness Society. ''We ditched, diked and drained Florida thinking that was progress before we realized we totally changed the whole balance.'' What Should Be Done? Officials have responded with a flurry of proposals. The United States Attorney in Miami, Dexter Lehtinen, has sued the state to compel it to enforce its own water-discharge standards. The Army Corps of Engineers has begun studies on how to control the flow of water so that the dry season stays dry and the wet season wet - an important cycle affecting birds' nesting habits that was disrupted by man-made levees.
Congress is considering a bill that would bring 100,000 more acres under the protection of the Everglades National Park, which encompasses about a fifth of all the Everglades. State water managers have proposed seizing 40,000 acres of private- and state-owned wetlands that would be used as a natural purification system to filter out nutrients before they reach sensitive areas.
But the proposals are bogged down in bitter fighting between environmentalists, who charge that state water managers favor the agriculture industry, and the industry itself, which argues that it is being made a scapegoat for the state's failure to manage growth and that, in any case, the pollution is not so bad as everyone says it is.
State water managers say that the Everglades system may simply not have enough water to meet the demands placed on it and that South Florida is going to have to face up to painful choices: supplying water to the 4.5 million residents of the area, meeting the needs of agriculture or supporting the environment.
This week, for the first time in a decade, the state began pumping water that it knows is laden with nutrients into Lake Okeechobee, the main source of the Everglades' water. Officials said they had to do this so they could draw on the lake, which has been running low, to supply the drought-stricken Miami area, 50 miles to the south.
''We're living on the edge with this system in terms of meeting the water needs for 4.5 million people,'' said John R. Wodraska, executive director of the South Florida Water Management District. ''If man is going to live in South Florida and have enough water to drink, we're going to have to do some things to compromise the environment.''
But Pat Tolle, a spokeswoman for the Everglades National Park, said: ''What makes this park special are the values that are protected here. Other parks were set aside to protect some geographical feature - a forest or river canyon. This was set aside purely to protect a delicate ecological system whose heart, its lifeline, is the water.''
 
A Fateful Decision
The story of the Everglades, environmentalists and water-management officials say, is the story of a well-intentioned but ultimately misguided project that began in 1948.
That was the year the Federal Government, trying to make the central part of southern Florida economically viable, sent in the Army Corps of Engineers to build 1,400 miles of levees and canals south of Lake Okeechobee to drain 700,000 acres of wetland so that it could be used for agriculture. Most of the land was then planted with sugar cane.
The canal network also acts as a link - and, at times, a barrier - between the Everglades' main source of water, Lake Okeechobee, and the Everglades themselves. Once the canals and the levees were complete, the flow of water depended on decisions by engineers, not acts of nature.
In the early 1970's, after a record drought, state officials decided to use the system to even out the extremes of the dry and wet seasons, not realizing at the time that the cycle of extremes was essential to the survival of some animal and plant life. Officials also did not realize at the time that the long-term addition of just a few inches of water to the Everglades' normal level changes the environment drastically, from wetland to pond, thereby endangering some animals and plants.
And then came the start of what may be the worst problem of all. In the late 1970's, Lake Okeechobee began to change dramatically, damaged by blooms of toxic algae and other plant life that sapped its oxygen. Officials concluded that the main problem was phosphorous and that it came partly from the runoff of cow manure at dairy farms surrounding the lake. But they said it also came from the runoff of the 700,000 acres of wetland that had been converted to agricultural use and that was releasing phosphorous naturally as its soil decayed. The state had been pumping that runoff into the lake.
Water-management officials then stopped pumping the nutrient-rich runoff into Okeechobee and pumped it instead into the Everglades, thinking the area was so large that it could absorb the nutrients. It is that decision, environmentalists say, that has led to today's problems, especially the explosion in growth of the cattails that are choking the waterways.
 
Fight Over State Plan
Mr. Wodraska, the Water Management District official, said he would accept as a goal reducing the amount of phosphorous in the water to 30 parts per billion from its current level of as much as 100 to 150. He would do that by establishing a 40,000-acre ribbon between the agricultural areas and the main Everglades that would act as a retention area where, over eight-day periods, water would be held while the phosphorous was absorbed by plants.
But the plan has drawn an outcry from environmentalists and sugar-cane growers alike. Environmentalists argue that the district would in effect be writing off 40,000 acres. As the site became more and more polluted, they say, birds might be subjected to mutation.
The environmentalists maintain that the answer is to cut back dramatically in the amount of agricultural production. ''The farmers always get firsties,'' said Joseph E. Podgor Jr., the Dade County chairman of Friends of the Everglades.
The owners of the sugar plantations say it has not been proved indisputably that the phosphorous has caused the growth of cattails. In any case, they say, the proposed new phosphorous standard is unnecessarily strict. And they say the 40,000 acres would quickly be exhausted as a purification site, leading only to further criticism of the sugar-cane industry.
''It isn't agriculture that's growing and creating the demand for water,'' said Andy Rackley, the general manager of the Florida Sugar Cane League. ''It's the urban areas that are growing. The state needs to control growth.'' Meanwhile, as the phosphorous debate drags on, researchers are testing animals to see how widespread the mercury contamination is. While it has been found in fish and alligators, findings are not complete on the Florida panther. Biologists say they do not know the source of the mercury. It could occur naturally in the soil, or it could come from chemicals, like fungicides, used on farms.
''Obviously, we will never restore the Everglades to what is was,'' said Ms. Tolle, of the Everglades National Park. ''But maybe with management we can improve some of the conditions. I don't think it would be stretching it to say we're on the cutting edge between survival and death.''

HEADLINE: Deng Reappears, Saying China Will Seek Change

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, reappeared today after three months of seclusion to declare that China would continue its reform policies, but he suggested that the country would from here on pay more attention to ideology.
Brief television clips showed Mr. Deng, 85 years old, tanned and animated as he met with an old acquaintance, T. D. Lee, a physics professor at Columbia University. The meeting and television appearance appeared to be intended to scotch rumors that Mr. Deng is ill. Chinese officials and East European diplomats had said that Mr. Deng was suffering from prostate problems, and that doctors were checking for cancer. 
Mr. Deng's hands and feet shook briefly during the broadcast, but he walked unassisted and seemed in relatively good health during the clips shown on television.
''I went swimming in the sea,'' he said. ''I don't like indoor swimming pools, but enjoy swimming in the outdoors.''
Mr. Deng told his guest that China had learned ''a major lesson'' from the events of the spring and early summer.
''Over the years, some of our comrades just immersed themselves in their specific work, did not pay enough attention to ideological and political developments, were not vigilant enough against the serious corruption, and the measures taken to correct it proved to be less than effective,'' he said. ''After the turmoil, all of us have become sober-minded.''
The comments were a criticism of the ousted Communist Party leader, Zhao Ziyang, who is accused of neglecting ideological education and allowing rampant corruption. The point appeared to be that the next generation of leaders should pay more attention to encouraging Marxist culture. Mr. Deng said that the country's new leadership would adhere to Communism, but would also maintain the open-door and economic policies of the last decade.
''Twists and turns and shortcomings are unavoidable,'' he said. ''But we believe those who adhere to these policies will eventually win successes.''
 
Last Seen on June 9
Only small portions of the 70-minute conversation were shown on television, and Professor Lee did not return telephone messages requesting comment on the meeting. A Chinese-American who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1957, Mr. Lee is well-known to the leadership here.
Mr. Deng had been last seen on June 9, congratulating martial troops for crushing the democracy movement five days earlier. He spent most of the summer at the beachside resort of Beidaihe in his villa, and it was there that his prostate problems reportedly suffered a relapse in mid-August.
While Mr. Deng retains only one formal position, chairman of the Central Military Commission, he remains the paramount leader and the ultimate arbiter of policies and careers.
Dressed in a blue-gray Mao suit, brown socks and black shoes, Mr. Deng leaned back in his padded chair in the Great Hall of the People and frequently laughed with his guest today.
He reiterated the view that economic growth should not be too rapid, for fear of aggravating inflation. ''One thing is sure,'' he said. ''China must develop, and China's productive forces must grow at an appropriate pace.''

HEADLINE: Rain and Fines, but Mostly Rain, Slow Burning of Amazon Forest in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAUS, Brazil

 BODY:
Plumes of gray smoke are once again rising over the green sea of Amazonian rain forest surrounding this city. But preliminary survey figures from this year's dry season point to a new trend: a marked drop in burning.
Rain, fines and reversals in public policy are combining to slow deforestation by fire, according to Brazilian and American environmentalists interviewed at a scientific conference here in late August.
''In 1989, there has been a considerable reduction in burning,'' Alberto Setzer told the gathering. Mr. Setzer directs a three-year-old Brazilian project to monitor Amazon forest fires through photographs taken by a satellite of the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration.
 
Smaller, but Still Huge
In June, to the surprise of many Amazon watchers, Mr. Setzer's researchers reported that fires during the 1988 dry season destroyed 37 percent less forest than in 1987. The drop was from 80,000 square miles to 50,000 square miles. 
The downward trend appears to be continuing. During the first half of this year's four-month dry season, the satellite recorded that 59,000 fires destroyed 13,000 square miles of forest.
Although reduced, this area is still large - the equivalent of New Jersey and Connecticut combined.
Fires in the Amazon became a worldwide concern last year after studies showed that the burning produces about one billion tons of carbon dioxide annually. Many climatologists believe that carbon dioxide building up in the atmosphere will trap the earth's heat, producing the greenhouse effect.
 
Rain, the Great Preserver
Despite international protests over the fires, rain - not people - appears to be a major factor in preserving the forest. Last year, the Amazon received little rain during the traditional dry season, mid-June through early October.
This year, preliminary reports indicate that much of the Amazon - a region that covers 1.9 million square miles in Brazil, an area about the size of the United States west of the Mississippi - is undergoing the wettest ''dry season'' in a decade. Generally, a farmer needs five consecutive days without rain before he can burn a stretch of jungle.
''This is going to be an unusually wet year,'' said Paulo Nogueira Neto, an ecology professor at the University of Sao Paulo.
In addition, Brazil has made several policy changes that are believed to be slowing the burning.
 
Government Moves to Slow Fires
This year, Brazil suspended tax incentives that made it artificially profitable for landowners to clear large expanses of jungle for cattle ranches.
Last year, it adopted a Constitution that did not penalize owners of unproductive land. During a constitutional debate in 1987, landowners' fear of losing title to ''unimproved'' lands is believed to have contributed to a record level of burning - 80,000 square miles.
''Every indication is that the burning is going down, because of weather, enforcement and the lack of new project incentives,'' said Thomas E. Lovejoy, assistant secretary for external affairs of the Smithsonian Institution.
This year, in the face of international pressure, Brazil began a highly publicized campaign to slow the burning.
Using 5 helicopters and 60 pickup trucks, forestry agents from the Brazilian Institute of Environment and Renewable Natural Resources have handed out $10 million in fines in the last month to landowners who burn forest lots without a permit from the institute.
''I visited a farm 60 miles from here yesterday where they wanted to burn,'' said Mr. Nogueira, a pioneer in Brazil's environmental movement. ''The farm workers were talking among themselves about whether the helicopter would come.''
 
Forestry Agent Slain
A measure of the institute's success is the growing resistance to those who levy the fines. A hail of bullets greeted a helicopter sent in August to investigate a report of an illegal forest fire in Maraba, in Para state. Elsewhere in the state, which has had 13,500 fires this summer, hired gunmen killed a forestry agent.
After an attempted killing last May, the institute's representative in Acre state, Paulo Beninca de Sales, began leaving his house only under police guard. The president of the agency, Fernando Cesar Mesquita, has started to receive death threats.
''In Rondonia, there are rumors among the settlers that the fines are now so heavy that they will have to sell their land to pay the fines,'' said Philip M. Fearnside, an American ecologist who works here at the National Institute for Research in the Amazon.
Brazil's fire-prevention campaign was strengthened this summer by an $8 million low-interest loan from the World Bank, which was matched by an appropriation from Brazil's Congress. The money was used to rent helicopters, buy pickup trucks and pay salaries for forestry agents.
 
Posters Give Warning
Mr. Mesquita said 500,000 posters and 500,000 pamphlets were distributed throughout the Amazon this year, warning the region's 15 million residents that fire permits must be obtained from the newly created Environment Institute.
''Any requests to clear more than 200 hectares never get farther than my desk drawer,'' Mr. Mesquita said. The cutoff point he referred to is equal to just under 500 acres.
''This year, you are going to have a lot fewer fires than last year,'' Mr. Mesquita said, running his finger down a report of ranchers and farmers fined for burning without a permit.
To help Mr. Mesquita's forestry agents, the National Institute of Space Research in Sao Paulo state sends daily telexes to all Amazonian states. The telexes list the locations of all known fires detected by satellite.
''We can send the information within two hours,'' said Mr. Setzer, who gets his photographs from a satellite of the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration. ''However, there is not always the manpower to follow up. Sometimes a telex to one state can be five meters long.''
 
Incentives Are Opposed
Rather than depending on police action or on the vagaries of rainfall, many environmentalists here argue that forest burning can best be reduced by withdrawing economic incentives. They say that tax incentives should be ended - not just suspended - for farms, cattle ranches, sawmills and pig-iron projects, that higher taxes should be imposed on land sales to cool land speculation, and that road building should be restricted to areas with soils suitable for support agriculture.
''They have to go the whole way from suspending incentives for new projects to ending existing incentives,'' said Mr. Lovejoy, an ecologist with 20 years' experience in the Amazon. ''Around Manaus this week, I have seen at least three fires where ranchers were burning second growth.'' He said they were marginal operations, which would not be viable without the tax incentives.
The environmental meeting here received an unexpected visitor on Aug. 28, its opening day - Amazonino Mendes, Governor of the state of Amazonas.
In June, the Governor angered environmentalists when he announced that he would distribute 4,000 free power saws to local farmers to win support in elections next year. Reacting to an earlier giveaway, some Brazilian legislators tried unsucessfully to give chain saws the same legal status as firearms. In Brazil, guns require ownership permits.
 
Nature Reserves Planned
Making peace with the environmentalists, Mr. Mendes announced plans to convert about 6 percent of Amazonas - 40,000 square miles - into nature reserves for tourism and scientific research. Of seven reserves planned, one has been approved by the state legislature and two others are to be considered within a month, he said.
Nevertheless, many Brazilian Government officials remain sensitive over international concern about the Amazon.
Early in August, Air Force helicopters intercepted a French research balloon that was hovering over the jungle near here. On landing, the nine French researchers, who had entered Brazil on tourist visas, were ordered to pack up their balloon and leave the country.

HEADLINE: Apple Growers Hurt by Loss of Alar

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDINER, N.Y., Sept. 15

 BODY:
Standing beside his packing house, Ted Wright watched a forklift operator pick up a large box filled with McIntosh apples and load it into a trailer truck.
Before the end of the day, 2,800 bushels, or 117,600 pounds of apples, were on their way to a cider mill to be pressed into juice instead of being packed for sale, at a higher price, as fresh fruit.
''We're picking a lot of apples off the ground,'' Mr. Wright said. ''They don't stay on the trees long enough for us to pick them.'' 
For Mr. Wright the fate of his apples was a direct result of not spraying his 300-acre farm here on Route 208 in Ulster County with Alar, the chemical that had been used for years to keep McIntosh apples on trees until they were mature and bright red.
 
More Apples for Cider
The apple harvest that began this week is the first after fruit growers in New York and across the country agreed not to use the chemical, which has been linked to cancer in laboratory animals, and its withdrawal from the market by its manufacturer.
Although the results are not yet in, early reports from some growers indicate that many of the new unsprayed McIntoshes are maturing with a mixed green and red color and dropping to the ground rapidly. Mr. Wright estimated that half of his McIntosh crop might go for cider rather than the more lucrative fresh market sales.
Though a major apple, the McIntosh is only one of a dozen or so varieties grown in New York. Many red apples, like cortlands, empires and ida reds; green apples, like Romes and greenings, and yellow ones, like golden delicious and crispin, mature on trees without the use of a ''stop-drop'' spray like Alar.
For years, though, the McIntosh has been the premier apple of New York State, accounting for about 20 percent of the total production. But faced with the ban on Alar, many growers are planting newer varieties to replace McIntoshes.
 
Could Drop to Third Place
''The standard Mac is a thing of the past,'' Mr. Wright said. ''You just can't grow them in the Hudson Valley.''
This year, the total apple crop in New York is estimated at 990 million pounds, which would drop the state to third place among the apple-growing states in the nation in 1989.
For years, New York has trailed Washington, where the major apple is the red delicious, but this year Michigan's estimated crop is larger, too.
The Agricultural Statistics Service in Albany reported that it expected this year's crop to be slightly more than last year in the western part, but slightly lower in the eastern section, including the Hudson Valley.
 
Big Money Losses
''The loss of Alar is a major, significant contributing factor but it's not the only factor in a low crop this year,'' said Warren Smith, the fruit expert of the Cooperative Extension Service. ''It comes after two years of good crops, which may have contributed to a reduced fruit set and last year's drought had an impact on tree health, leading to reduced fruit this year, too.''
For Mr. Wright, the drop in production directly attributable to the ban on Alar is resulting in a severe economic loss. He has had to hire more pickers, he said, raising his production costs, and he is getting less for his McIntosh apples.
Instead of being able to sell them for fresh apple eating at $10 a bushel, he has been forced, he said, to sell the apples picked off the ground to a cider mill for $2 a bushel.
''It costs about $8 a bushel to produce the apples,'' he said. ''You can see what that means.''
The effect of not using Alar was also apparent at the orchards of W. G. Minard and Sons in Rock Tavern in Orange County, where its 350 acres produce large quantities of apples sold to wholesalers and farm stands in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
 
Half Green and Half Red
Robert Minard, the operator, said he had hired 44 pickers, eight more than usual, to try to pick apples before they dropped to the ground. ''That adds about 20 percent to my cost of picking,'' he said.
Although the empires and red delicious apples are maturing and reddening at the Minard Farm, his McIntoshes remain half green and half red, just as at the Wright Farm.
''We haven't had the drop yet, but I think it is coming,'' Mr. Minard said.
Standing next to a bin of newly picked McIntoshes, Mr. Smith bit into one. ''It tastes good,'' he said, ''but the major question is whether the consumer will buy half green-half red apples even if they are Alar free.''

HEADLINE: In 'Black Rain,' East Meets West With a Bang! Bang!

BYLINE: By DONALD CHASE; Donald Chase is the author of ''Filmmaking: The Collaborative Art'' (Little, Brown).

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
After four grueling months that included location work in Japan and New York, the director Ridley Scott is completing ''Black Rain'' at Paramount Studios, on a hi-tech-with-Deco-accents hostess-bar set that is supposed to be in Osaka. Two scenes, filmed on successive days, seem to underscore the theme of the conflict-of-two-cultures thriller, which opens Friday at Loews Astor Plaza and 34th Street Showplace and casts Michael Douglas and Andy Garcia as New York cops pursuing a capo in the yakuza - or Japanese Mafia - in an uneasy collaboration with the Japanese police.
In one scene, Mr. Douglas, frustrated and angry, tries to extract information from Kate Capshaw, ultra-blond and sequinned to play the American expatriate manager of the club. ''Look,'' she tells him in a tough-shady-lady-adrift manner that recalls Jean Harlow and Rita Hayworth. ''I've been here seven years, and I still can't read the headlines. Yes means no and maybe means never. . . . No one's going to help a gaijin.'' Mr. Douglas is unfamiliar with the Japanese word, which Ms. Capshaw then defines: ''A foreigner. Stranger. Barbarian. Me. You. . . . More you.'' But in the other scene, also set in the club, Andy Garcia coaxes the formerly hostile, now alcohol-soaked Japanese police detective played by Ken Takakura on to the bandstand for a duet of Ray Charles's ''What'd I Say?'' This moment of musical communion soon signals an about-face in Mr. Takakura's character. When Mr. Garcia falls prey to a vicious yakuza attack, Mr. Takakura risks his job and his life to join Mr. Douglas in pursuing the responsible parties. 
It was the opportunity to explore the question raised by these scenes - Is East, East; and West, West, or are we all part of the Family of Man? - that attracted Mr. Scott, producers Stanley Jaffe and Sherry Lansing and Mr. Douglas to Craig Bolotin and Warren Lewis's original screenplay.
''I read a lot of newspapers,'' Mr. Douglas says during a break in filming, ''and the movies I'm drawn to both as an actor and as an actor-producer tend to have a current-events mode. I'm thinking about 'The China Syndrome' and 'Wall Street.' '' The former, which he produced and acted in, was about a nuclear-plant accident that, in fact, prefigured the Three Mile Island crisis of spring 1979. The latter, for which he won the 1987 Academy Award for best actor, but did not produce, focused on the still-controversial mergers-and-acquisitions fever and its effect on the financial community's ethics.
''I felt,'' he continues, ''that there was something between us and Japan that was unresolved, that was a mixture of hostility and admiration on both sides - really confused. It involves Japan's cultural imitation of the United States, followed by its economic supremacy over the United States, all of which is colored by lingering memories of World War II.'' More specifically, by the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: ''You turned the rain black,'' one Japanese character reproaches Mr. Douglas, referring to the combination of ash and precipitation that fell on the devastated cities.
''I thought,'' adds Mr. Douglas, who is also involved in ''Black Rain'' in a production capacity, ''that this particular picture, as a cop-action picture, could explore some of the differences in customs and behavior - explore some of the hostilities that our two cultures and societies have for each other.''
''The way in,'' Mr. Scott says, ''is the conflict between police methods. Michael - as Conklin - is a New York homicide detective with a certain disgruntlement, a certain dissatisfaction with the system and a certain renegade quality. It's even suggested that he's on the take in a minor way. Ken, on the other hand, is a thorough, by-the-book, hardline bureaucrat who is part of what seems to be this wonderful machine in Japan.
''Michael, I think, re-establishes some lost values in himself - traditional values, which somewhere along the line have been lost in the West but which I think still exist in Japan, such as a sense of honor and a sense of family - through his experience with this Japanese character. And Ken - who plays a kind of Japanese Everyman, the salaried man, the bourgeois, what we think of as the automaton - loses his rigidity and opens up through his contact with Michael and Andy Garcia. For Ken Takakura - both as that character and as an actor - to stand up and sing is an incredibly alien and even painful thing.''
Mr. Scott - whose extraordinary eye was evident in ''The Duellists,'' ''Alien'' and, rather ironically, in the Japanized Los Angeles of 2019 that he presented in ''Blade Runner'' - admits that at first he was stumped as to how to visualize Japan in ''Black Rain.''
''Japan is difficult visually, awkward visually,'' the English director says. Looking first at Tokyo and Kyoto as possible filming sites, he concluded that ''it's all this squeaky-clean New Town. Everything is well-kept, with gigantic freeways and a gigantic scale of architecture. . . . But the architecture is really not definitively Japanese, except in pockets and pieces and bits.''
Then the director was taken to Osaka by Alan Poul, the film's resident Japanologist and associate producer, who served Paul Schrader's ''Mishima'' (1985) in the same capacities when it was filmed in Tokyo. Mr. Scott found Osaka, whose population of three million makes it Japan's third-largest city, suitably ''big, but provincial, [with a] European feel because of a lot of parks and also a gentility.'' It is also, on the screen, an industrial center whose streets are dense with pedestrian and motorized traffic and whose skies are dense with pollution.
Though Michael Douglas usually involves himself deeply in the preparation of the films he produces, he did not in this case accompany Mr. Scott, Mr. Poul and Mr. Jaffe on their location-scouting expeditions. ''I wanted to see Japan with fresh eyes, as the character does,'' he explains, ''so I held off going there until the casting sessions for the Japanese actors.''
The casting sessions were the first of a series of life-imitates-art cultural clashes between the film makers and the Japanese.
''As far as we were concerned,'' Mr. Poul says, ''the casting sessions were conducted very civilly, along the lines that you cast a film in America. Which is, you ask a lot of top actors, top talent to come in at 20-minute intervals; you talk to them for a while; they read for you; you get them on videotape, and they go.
''In Japan, though, actors do not audition'' - especially actors of the stature of Mr. Takakura, who enjoys a status comparable to that of Clint Eastwood. ''The idea of putting yourself in a position that's potentially humiliating is very disagreeable - and very alien to the Japanese experience. They spend their lives making each other's lives easy - often that's a priority over honesty, over frugality. . . . But here, we had within the space of a few days many of the nation's top actors coming in and out of the Imperial Hotel, which is the most prominently situated hotel in Tokyo.''
''Each actor would arrive with his manager,'' Ridley Scott recalls with a chuckle, ''the manager being fairly angry at having to be there at all. But because we were so well promoted, they were torn between not coming at all and coming to see what was going on.''
Differences in customs and mentalities were also evident during the six weeks of actual shooting on ''Black Rain'' in Japan.
''If you look at most Japanese movies, contemporary Japanese movies,'' Stanley Jaffe says, ''you will see that they take place mostly on [studio-built] sets, and that what on-street scenes as there are were clearly shot with a hidden camera. You don't see real scenes staged in populated areas, as we would expect them to be staged here in the States.''
This lack of familiarity with shooting in real locations - plus what Alan Poul calls a ''literal-minded and image-conscious'' strain in the Japanese psyche - led to problems in securing shooting sites. ''People,'' Mr. Poul recalls, ''thought that having their store or their house used as a place frequented by yakuza would reflect badly on them. And then we wanted to play a row of shops in a fish market as someone's apartment, we were told, 'But people don't really live here. . .' ''
Lack of familiarity with street shooting also meant that the Japanese police were totally unacquainted with the notion of controlling crowds to accommodate a film unit. When Mr. Scott and Mr. Jaffe wanted to film scenes in the Dotonburi nightclub district of Osaka with police cooperation, they had to agree to do so over a number of days, in the quiet hours between 3 and 6 in the morning, instead of in one dusk-to-dawn sweep.
''It was a bit troublesome,'' admits Mr. Jaffe, ''[but] it meant that we could, during those hours, shoot anything we wanted and shoot it with complete control.''
Mr. Jaffe is perhaps a bit disingenuous, because in fact the control was achieved by a 50-strong private security force hired by the production, while, Alan Poul says, ''the cops stood around and watched. . . . And then the police would come out and say, 'Look, look at the disturbance you're creating.' I don't have a lot of kind things to say about the Japanese police, except that ultimately they let us do it, ultimately we got the shot. . . . And the fact is that, though the Dotonburi is one of the single most famous urban landscapes in Japan, it's never - before this - been adequately captured on film.''
In fact, no matter the difficulties, the principal Westerners involved in ''Black Rain'' returned to the United States feeling that the Japanese experience was a positive one. And just as in the film, it was individuals who broke down cultural or institutional barriers.
Of the 120 Japanese who joined 45 Westerners on the crew, Mr. Scott says: ''We communicated through interpreters, but I found there's an international language in film making. Once they know how you're functioning, they all move very quickly, like an army - they were great.'' And despite being required to work, on the average, two hours more per day than is normal for them, ''they had endless stamina. . . . Once they were for you, they would die - absolutely die - for you.''
Mr. Scott directed the Japanese actors through an interpreter, and in the scenes in which Japanese characters speak Japanese among themselves, he had to rely on the interpreter to evaluate the niceties of their line readings. ''But it's funny,'' he notes, ''when you're dealing with a good actor, you know what's going on. I found the Japanese actors were brilliant. I thought I was going to get Kabuki Theater and I didn't get that at all. I got very good, very balanced, very contemporary, very real performances.''
Mr. Scott cites especially the performance of Ken Takakura, and, like Alan Poul, points to the ''courage'' of the Japanese actor in diverging from his customary strong-silent antihero screen persona to play an establishment figure in his first American film.
''Actually, there's a Japanese banquet of actors in the movie,'' says Andy Garcia (''The Untouchables''), referring, in addition to Mr. Takakura, to Yusaku Matsuda, Tomisaburo Wakayama, Shigeru Koyama, Yuya Uchida, who play yakuza or police types, and Miyuki Ono, who plays a Dotonburi hostess.
''It's been a real joy because you learn that acting is really an international language,'' he adds, echoing Mr. Scott. ''It doesn't matter to me how or where they trained - it hasn't even occurred to me to ask them what their process was. . . . I'm just looking in their eyes. The graciousness and honor these people bestow on themselves and the people they work with is enlightening. If other cultures patterned themselves after the Japanese, as represented by these actors, we'd be be a lot better off - certainly a lot of movies would be better off. There's not a lot of ego that I find.''
Asked for his opinion on the making of ''Black Rain,'' Ken Takakura, whose conversational English is limited, replies: ''It is an experience I will never forget.''

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1705 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
The Demon Seesaw Actors Ride

BYLINE: By FRANK LANGELLA; Frank Langella will appear as Prospero in ''The Tempest,'' scheduled to open at the Roundabout Theater in November.

 BODY:
His hands were trembling so much I thought he was going to break into a hundred pieces like a Tom and Jerry cartoon character. He had been sitting at a nearby table in an L.A. actors' hangout and as he got up to leave, he threw me a ''We've never met, but I know you'' wave. I waved back and asked him to join my table. He hesitated a beat, then came over.
I was having a late supper with an actress friend, keeping a date we'd made in New York earlier that week. We three exchanged perfunctory L.A. versus New York cliches: the requisite ''Love your work'' phrase and avoidance of the ''What are you doing?'' question. The trembling hands continued throughout our 10-minute conversation. I resisted the urge to ask him if he was all right because something inside me understood the tremble and knew the answer. 
This man had once been at the top of our profession. A series of successful films and an Oscar nomination had capped a hot streak lasting some four or five years in the mid-70's. Things turned bad. He was now 50 and forgotten. Facing me was an actor climbing the ladder again. Lightly tanned, clean-shaven, eggshell thin, in a blazer and tie; the hands trembling to hold onto the bottom rungs once more. He excused himself and said he was off to see a midnight movie. ''I want to get lost in the dark of the theater,'' he said.
My friend and I fell silent, wondered if we could have been more solicitous, and decided it was best not to invade a shell that seemed barely held together. But his tremble stayed with me through dinner and after I drove her home. It awoke a fear in me. It became a symbol of the questions I had been asking myself more persistently each year. Why do actors live the lives we do?
Some basic truths about us, some fundamentals: married, single, divorced, rich, broke, breaking in or holding on, the morning after Oscar, Tony or Emmy, or struggling along without recognition; whether we are newcomers, superstars, an enduring light, a flash in the pan, a has-been or a comeback king, from low self-esteem to insufferable arrogance - we are the seesaw kids. Kids who hold on tight and wait, wait for the call, the audition, the part, the review - and then we do it again. Those are the ground rules. You accept them if you are an actor. And you accept the demons.
One veteran character actor told me he is so excited when the job comes to a close. He takes himself and his wife to Martha's Vineyard and for four or five days he is in bliss. ''And then,'' he said, ''every time the phone rings, I am running up the dock like an old fool, thinking 'Oh, God, please don't hang up. I hope it is work.' ''I've got money now,'' he said, ''but that's no comfort.'' Another actor, 34 years old, told me when he's waiting he drives back and forth across the United States calling his agent every few days from phone booths. He has no money and no comfort. And another, convinced each time his illnesses are not hypochondriacal, drives himself to doctors' offices and waits for test results. One actress does health spas, another buys and sells houses, a third designs gardens. ''Dangerous things, gardens,'' she said. ''You never want to come out of them.'' A not unsuccessful man with an Oscar told me that when he is out of work an inertia so great overwhelms him that he is practically catatonic. He could not leave his home during one period for over three months. ''Why?'' I asked. ''Fear,'' he said.
And fear encourages the demons insecurity and uncertainty. An elderly actress was over for dinner. When we sat down she threw back a straight Scotch and said, ''You know what I did today? I did a general get-to-know-you, they call it, at a new agency I've just signed with. Look, I don't expect them to kiss my backside, but I have been at this for 38 years and I sat there as kids younger than my children said things like, 'She'd be great as so-and-so's wife in his new series' or 'How good are your contacts in town? Who do you know personally?' '' She was torn between her insecurity and need to be accepted and her anger at expecting and not receiving the treatment she felt her lifetime of achievement had entitled her to.
An agent once said to me when I mentioned I was in my third month of unemployment, ''How I envy you! You can sleep late; take the kids to the park; go on holiday.'' ''Why don't I take the keys to your office,'' I said, ''lock the doors, send home your staff and let you know when you can come back to work. Wait until I have something for you.'' He laughed, but didn't get it. How could he? How could anyone who has not experienced unemployment several times a year every year of his working life. No matter how often an actor may tell himself that a refusal is not necessarily a rejection, the word ''No'' only deepens his self-doubt.
And, even when employed, the actor is still stalked by uncertainty. A great Broadway star once told me that during the entire rehearsal period of one of her many triumphs, she got out of her taxi 20 blocks before the rehearsal studio and walked the entire way in order to stop shaking. ''I was certain I was going to be fired,'' she said. I recalled that when I was a young actor my famous leading lady asked if I would drive her to the first day of rehearsals out of town. ''Sure,'' I said, too cocky to be nervous myself. She got into my car; we drove three blocks and she promptly vomited. ''Wait until there is more at stake,'' she said. ''You'll know what it's like.'' And, as the seesaw rocked back and forth for me, I remembered her words.
I remembered again when years later a close friend of mine called and said, ''You're back in town. Let's have dinner.'' It had been close to 10 months since we had seen each other. We met at a local restaurant. When last I'd seen him, he and his wife had bought a beautiful Bel Air house, one Mercedes and one Jaguar and put their children in private schools. During our dinner he freely admitted that it had all gone bad for them. As we waited in the garage, he told me the house was sold, so, too, the cars, and they were now living in a two-bedroom apartment in West Hollywood. A wreck of a car was brought up by the attendant. ''Ah, well,'' he said, ''back to coach. Keeps you humble.'' He drove away smiling, with a wave.
In between actors' waves to each other there are months and even years of travel to foreign countries, divorces, awards, clinics, love affairs, feuds, and yet whenever we meet we pick up the thread again.
Though sometimes it's more the needle than the thread. Actors can be immensely cruel to one another. There are times when you meet an actor you don't know and he greets you with hostility or condescension or even dismissal. It can be blown away sometimes - and sometimes it develops into downright hatred. A difference in acting styles, position on a set, or being surrounded by too many assistants, can cause actors to polarize. If your career moves ahead or drops behind a friend, the friendship is jeopardized. Your demons against his.
And those demons themselves are competing with an irrevocable one: aging. One strong, up-from-the-floor fighter of an actress said to me, ''I won't be seeing you for a while, darling. I'm off to play the mother in a TV pilot. Can you imagine? The mother!'' she said again. And then totally without rancor, she said, ''You know, I never dreamed it would turn out like this. I thought it would always be Phaedra or Shaw or working with the great directors. I never dreamed.''
One lunch by a pool a young friend of mine said of a 50-ish actor walking by our table, ''Look at him. A fine figure of a has-been.'' I laughed, but it stung. A sag in your career or a sag in your chin, and you're a party joke. And, if someone else isn't noticing your graying hair or expanding waistline, you are. The actors' anxiety over aging is more acute than most. Part of the product starts to wear out and the consumer wants a new one.
Several years ago, on the set of a film, eight of us between the ages of 35 and 50 sat around the table. I studied my face-lifted, hair-dyed, overtanned, lipo-bellied, toupeed, capped-teeth and skin-peeled colleagues. One friend said, ''I'm making it at last - at 48 - I'm making it. I'm going to dye my hair, pump my muscles and smile my way to stardom.''
That smile can be difficult to maintain. In Paris one early morning, waiting to be fitted for a beard, I noticed in the booth next to me one of the world's great beauties. As she was being fitted for a wig, the man attending her said, when an old film of hers was mentioned, meaning no harm, ''God, you were beautiful then.'' She smiled, looked him in the eye, and said, without a trace of bitterness, ''Ah, well, we all have our moment, don't we.'' When the moment passes, it requires of the older actor a profound dignity. Those who age gracefully before the public do so while struggling privately to let go of that for which they were initially loved.
And deeper inside us, past vanity, past fear, past the waiting, past uncertainty and insecurity, there is a demon I can find no name for.
One early morning I looked out the window of the rented house in the country where I was working. Sitting poolside, wrapped in a fur coat, smoking a cigarette, surrounded by empty champagne bottles, was my leading lady. It was 6 A.M. I went down and sat next to her. A long silence and then she said, ''I can't. I can't any more. I can't go where I have to go inside to be really good and survive. I hate revealing myself and I despise myself for wanting to be liked.''
I fear the demons like every other actor. But more than their existence, I fear their departure from me. I need them. They keep away the nameless one. Actors have a legitimate claim on the word ''survivor.'' But just surviving is a victory with no spoils. I want the spoils, and I'll take the pain that goes with getting them.
With each new role comes a test of heart, mind and spirit. Through the work an actor find his place in society. Up against a task larger than himself, he can transform and overcome. More than suffering, more than success, more than defeat, the work strengthens and illuminates. It calms the tremble. It steadies the seesaw.

GRAPHIC: ''The Actors,'' from a triptych by Max Beckmann (Bettman Newsphotos)

PUB-DATE: September 17, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1597 words

HEADLINE: Driving Down The Dollar

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
These days, it seems that nothing can stop the mighty dollar. A combination of relatively high interest rates, a desire by foreigners to invest in American assets and concerns over political instability elsewhere has turned the dollar into the darling of the currency markets. Last May, a dollar bought 130 yen; today it buys 144 yen. And a dollar is now worth 1.93 West German marks, up from 1.88 last spring.
That is good news for those patriots who believe a strong dollar is a sign of a strong America. But largely out of a fear that a high dollar could weaken the American economy, many policy makers are beginning to ask whether this is the time, once again, to knock down the dollar.
''We're in for big trouble ahead,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a nonprofit economic research group based in Washington. ''I would counsel the Administration to make a major attack on the dollar. If we don't, the consequences will be very, very severe.'' 
Rudiger Dornbusch, an economics professor at the Massuchusetts Institute of Technology, agrees. ''It is clear that the current level of the dollar is absurd.''
So far, the Bush Administration, preoccupied by the savings and loan crisis and the nation's mounting debt, has paid little attention to the dollar - which if left unattended, could cause the price of American goods abroad to soar and hurt the industries that produce them. The Federal Reserve has been reluctant to drive down the dollar by increasing the money supply for fear of triggering inflation. Besides, no matter what happens, many say that unless the nation's budget deficit is finally reduced, no real progress can be made since the deficit props up interest rates which, in turn, keep the dollar strong.
In the short run, the Federal Reserve has intervened in the currency markets with massive purchases and sales of dollars. But this has proved to be only a temporary fix. Even when it sold a record $12 billion this summer, the dollar fell for a few weeks only to resume its upward climb. With foreign exchange markets now estimated to trade nearly $500 billion a day, such intervention is limited.
''The dollar did come down, but not far enough,'' said Kathryn Dominguez, a public policy professor at Harvard University. ''The Government, central banks and the Treasury have a bit of control in the market, but they cannot control it totally.''
Among economists, there is little consensus about what should be done. Some say leave the dollar alone, some argue for the Western trading partners to meet once again to orchestrate another round of dollar-bashing, while some even call for a return to fixed exchange rates.
For instance, Richard Rahn, the chief economist of the Chamber of Commerce and a former economic adviser to President Bush during the 1988 campaign, recommends that the dollar ''be treated with benign neglect'' while the Federal Reserve expands the money supply to steadily reduce interest rates and keep the economy growing - which would helpbring the dollar down.
Others, like Mr. Dornbusch of M.I.T., call for central bank intervention and a session by the Western nations to set up a strategy similar to the 1985 meeting that led to the Plaza accord. This was the first concerted effort by the U.S.'s trading partners to depress the dollar.
Robert Mundell, a Columbia University economist, is one who proposes that the trading nations agree on a fixed and stable level for the dollar - perhaps at its current level - rather than letting it operate on a roller coaster of uncertainty.
One taste of that uncertainty came Friday when the dollar went on a wild ride, rising in the morning to equal 2 marks and 149 yen on news of improved trade statistics. It then fell to 1.93 marks and 144.4 yen on unfounded reports that several banks had run into trouble.
Aside from such daily blips, the big worry is that inaction over a rising dollar could spell economic trouble ahead. Mr. Bergsten, of the Institute for International Economics, estimates that the dollar's rise could cause the current account balance - which measures trade in goods and services - to increase to a $200 billion deficit in two years, up from the current $125 billion deficit. The fall in exports could fuel unemployment: The auto, steel, textile, aluminum and paper industries are all vulnerable to keeping their goods priced competitively in the world marketplace.
Ultimately, a rising dollar, says Mr. Bergsten, could plunge the nation into a recession. It could also reignite protectionist pressures in Congress and discredit the central banks' attempts to manage exchange rates.
''This is the greatest single threat to our continued economic expansion,'' Mr. Bergsten said. ''Such a significant deterioration of our trade could drag down the whole economy.''
Despite these gloomy warnings, a strong dollar isn't all bad. In part, it is a vote of confidence in the American economy, which has remained stable and growing for nearly eight years.
To foreign eyes, America looks like a good bet, for now. Interest rates remain high relative to those in other countries and act as a beacon to foreign investors. And the political disarray in China and Eastern Europe, coupled with the crises in leadership in Japan and West Germany, highlight America's role as a ''safe haven'' for money.
In fact, so much money has flowed into the United States in the last year that the dollar rose despite a recent decline in short-term interest rates. This inflow has invigorated the country's financial markets. It pumped up the stock market after the October 1987 crash, offsetting the flight of retail investors. Foreign investors have also bid up fixed-income securities, which, in turn, has helped moderate interest rates in general on many forms of debt, like mortgages.
And foreign money is behind a steady buying spree of physical assets. Just last week, a Japanese bank bought a primary dealer of Government securities from Kleinwort Benson. Another said it was negotiating to buy the business lending unit of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
Some economists argue that the United States should take advantage of this foreign capital to improve America's productive base. As stock prices rise, for instance, corporations can issue more equity to fund new plants and equipment.
''We should take foreign financial capital and turn it into real physical capital with productive potential,'' said Neil Soss, chief economist at The First Boston Corporation. ''This would build a better base for production and exports, which would be an insurance policy when their willingness to finance us is not as great.''
Despite the trade imbalance, exports have actually been growing by about 20 percent annually over the last few years. This has slightly reducedthe trade deficit. But economists say most of that progress stems from the dramatic fall in the dollar following the intervention orchestrated by the Plaza accord and at a subsequent session at the Louvre in 1987.
''We're seeing the last hurrah of improvement in our competitiveness from when the dollar came down through 1987,'' said William Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics. ''We're seeing a rare period of very misleading signals from the trade data coming in.''
Few economists believe exports will continue to expand significantly without a still lower dollar. And that is unlikely without a cut in the nation's budget deficit. To finance the debt, the Government issues billions in Treasury securities, which pushes up interest rates. As foreigners buy Treasury securities, the trade balance worsens.
But with President Bush's ''read my lips'' campaign promise of no new taxes and with many in Congress unwilling to make sweeping budget cuts, few expect much movement on the deficit. ''The Bush Administration seems unwilling to confront the budget problem seriously,'' said I. M. Destler, an economist at the University of Maryland.
Compounding the problem is the Administration's fear of inflation. With the economy operating at nearly full employment, many fear that any near-term reduction in interest rates would stimulate the economy and lead to wage and price inflation. ''The Federal Reserve is not going to push the dollar down with low interest rates until it sees something on the fiscal front, and he is right,'' said Mr. Dornbusch of M.I.T.
And the Administration cannot count on the nation's trading partners to lend a hand without pressure. Western European countries and Japan, whose economies have been growing reasonably well and where interest rates are rising slightly, are less than eager to push up their domestic interest rates and undercut their own economic health to help make American goods more competitive in their countries.
''They need a domestic case for acting. They don't just change because of foreign exchange pressures in the United States,'' said Scott E. Pardee, vice chairman of Yamaichi International and a former Federal Reserve official.
In contrast to the Treasury officials of the Reagan and Carter Administrations, who were vocal dollar bashers, the Bush Administration has remained mum about its plans for the dollar. A spokesman for the Treasury Department declined to comment on its recent rise. ''This is an unusual situation and one that we stay away from commenting on,'' said Robert Levine, a Treasury spokesman. ''No matter what we say, it has an effect on the market. They look to see how we are breathing and then the market goes haywire.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 17, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 430 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN THE COIN TRADE;
A Rush of Investors Cause Hobbyists to Flee

BYLINE: By MARK HENRICKS; Mark Henricks is a writer based in Irving, Tex.

 BODY:
When George B. Berk opened a rare coin shop in Canton, Ohio, in 1979, the necessary skills for his job included a horse trader's bent for negotiating, an encyclopedic knowledge of coinage and an artist's eye for appraising a coin's quality and esthetic appeal.
But like most of the nation's 2,000 or so coin dealerships, his business has radically changed over the last three years as the industry has moved to cater to a new breed of collector: the investor. During the late 70's, droves of investors bought tangible assets like coins because they rapidly appreciate during high inflationary times. 
While hobbyists hoard their coins, perhaps for a lifetime, investors readily trade them and have driven up prices considerably since their entry. Salomon Brothers Inc. says that, with a compound annual rate of return of 12.9 percent a year for the last 10 years, its index of rare coins has outperformed all other of its investment indexes but those made up of stocks.
To accommodate the new rush of coin trading, dealers have been forced to standardize their practices. Rather than determine the value of coins by haggling with collectors, many dealers rely on third parties to grade and hermetically seal coins in plastic holders, known as slabs. Third-party certification enables coins to trade sight unseen on the American Numismatic Exchange. Formed by a group of dealers in 1986, the exchange provides member dealers with bid and ask quotes electronically and adds liquidity to the market.
Still, some serious collectors have been turned off by the investor mentality of the coin market. Since the early 80's, the American Numismatic Association, a group of collectors based in Colorado Springs, said it has lost a third of its 50,000 members - mostly collectors. In the last year, several thousand new members, mostly investors, have joined the club, said Stephen L. Bobbitt, a spokesman for the group. ''All the mystery has been taken out of collecting,'' Mr. Berk complained. ''In a way, it's taken all the fun out of it.''
Yet the industry fears that without the stability of a large core of collectors and hobbyists, the coin market will grow ever more volatile. Price swings are already more severe than ever. For instance, they spiked sharply this year on the news that big Wall Street brokerages were setting up funds for investing solely in rare coins. Although speculators viewed the move as a vote of confidence in stocks, the brokerage houses' abilities to dump millions of dollars in coins onto the market in a day could add to the market's volatility.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 17, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2770 words

HEADLINE: Now It's Bob Horton's Turn at B.P.

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Listen to Bob Horton talk and you might easily mistake him for a Wall Street trader or a corporate bust-up artist. His eyes light up as he confesses his love for ''active asset trading'' and ''swaps.'' There is joy in his voice as he discusses ''doing an arbitrage'' and ''making money by betting on the difference between your view and somebody else's.''
But don't let the vocabulary fool you. The use of those techniques is one reason why the British Petroleum Company is in its best shape in decades - and why Robert M. Horton in March will become the next chairman and chief executive of the world's third-largest oil company.
The man that he will replace - Sir Peter Walters, who is retiring at age 58 - had to worry about curing B.P.'s ills during much of his eight-year tenure. B.P.'s European refining and petrochemicals operations were plagued by overcapacity and inefficiency. There were problems galore at the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, in which B.P. had long held a majority stake. There was all that diversification out of oil to deal with. And then the Kuwaitis managed to take advantage of the 1987 stock market crash to grab 21.6 percent of B.P. 
Sir Peter gave the 50-year-old Mr. Horton and other members of top management the green light to wheel and deal their way out of the morass. As a result, Mr. Horton now faces the happy prospect of being able to focus for the most part on building upon B.P.'s considerable strengths in its core businesses: oil and gas production, refining and marketing, and petrochemicals.
''B.P. is highly focused and its management is almost obsessed with efficiency,'' said Nicholas J. Clayton, an industry analyst at Smith New Court Securities in London.
Armed with the command from Sir Peter that ''there are no sacred cows'' and employing a type of financial analysis that was foreign to B.P., Sir Peter's team sorted through B.P.'s vast empire and focused the company on what it did best.
In the past three years alone, that exercise resulted in nearly $21 billion worth of acquisitions and divestitures - not including a $1.31 billion sale of oil and gas properties announced last Thursday.
Even before last week's announcements, 1989 had been a busy year for British Petroleum. Its deals included the $3.7 billion sale of most of its minerals business, including the Kennecott Corporation; the sale of 2.5 percent of its Prudhoe Bay production in Alaska for $515 million; the sale of a minority stake in its Magnus Field in the North Sea for $265 million; the divestiture of some specialty chemicals businesses for $160 million, and the $4.2 billion purchase of a large portion of Kuwait's B.P. stake.
Still more deals are pending: the auctioning off of the coal business, which is expected to fetch $600 million to $700 million; the sale of an Australian copper and uranium mine for an estimated $600 million, and the sale of some London real estate for at least $200 million.
Analysts and B.P. insiders also would not be surprised to see the company divest its animal feed business, the only remaining major business outside of oil and chemicals. That could fetch $1 billion or so, analysts say.
To be sure, selling ailing or non-essential businesses and buying ones that complement core businesses is nothing new, either in the oil industry or in industry as a whole. But B.P. executives, with their self-described passion for ''extracting value,'' have demonstrated a remarkable ability to do just that.
 
Good Timing
 The waited, for instance, until metals prices were high before selling most of their minerals business: the deal, which was completed this summer, netted them a $416 million profit. They have shown similar savvy in their acquisitions. Britoil, the North Sea oil company that B.P. bought for $4.2 billion last year, would cost 50 percent more if bought today, according to Paul Spedding, an analyst here at Kleinwort Benson Securities Ltd.
Although these mega-deals have produced the biggest headlines, the smaller deals really capture the management style that Sir Peter created - and which Mr. Horton makes clear will continue. ''I'm all in favor of creative ways of getting to a stronger physical asset base,'' said Mr. Horton, an engineer by training who has spent 32 years at B.P.
If an asset of peripheral importance to B.P. is more valuable to a competitor who has something that B.P. might want, then a trade might be considered. Whether it is swapping gas stations in America with Mobil or forming a refinery joint venture with Texaco in Rotterdam to cut costs or selling a stake in Alaskan or North Sea oil production to someone with a more bullish view of oil prices, B.P. executives are constantly on the lookout for ways to improve their competitive position and profits.
John Browne, B.P.'s exploration and production chief, is considered to be brilliant in spotting such situations. One idea of his that generated envy in the industry was selling units in the production from B.P.'s prized Forties Field that had appealing tax advantages for companies exploring in the British sector of the North Sea. The 1984 sale of the 9.8 percent stake yielded B.P. a handsome profit.
Last May, Mr. Browne struck again: B.P. sold 2.5 percent of its Prudhoe Bay production in the form of royalty trust units. According to company insiders, the deal netted the company $1.50 more a barrel than it could otherwise have got.
''If you look at B.P. and what it's doing, it's acting like a role model'' for others in the oil industry, said Mr. Clayton, the analyst. ''They're all now talking about active-asset trading and extracting value for shareholders.''
For their part, top B.P. executives make it clear that they are no complacent bunch. All talk with envy of the company's archrival, the larger Royal Dutch/Shell. Calling Shell ''an enormously powerful company,'' Sir Peter said: ''We don't rate with Shell's financials over all. We are Avis to their Hertz.''
B.P.'s chemicals business, which had operating profits of $915 million last year on sales of $5.8 billion, has gone from about the worst of the big companies in the industry in 1980 to one of the best in profitability. But the marketing and refining operation, which had an operating profit of less than $1.4 billion on revenues of $29.8 billion in 1988, is not yet up to snuff, B.P. executives say.
And while B.P. has one of the better exploration records in the industry, the company's leaders obviously think there is room for improvement. The announcements on Thursday made that clear.
First, the company unveiled a restructuring of its exploration and production operation. Those changes are aimed at both lowering overhead costs by $150 million a year and making the operation more entrepreneurial so B.P. can find more oil in so-called frontier areas. Clearly, the company that helped discover the vast oil fields of Persia, the North Sea and Alaska has not forgotten its roots.
 
The Latest Deal
 The company also struck a deal the same day to sell exploration and production assets, most in the North Sea, for $1.31 billion to the Dallas-based Oryx Energy Company. Last year's Britoil acquisition made B.P. the dominant player in the British sector of the North Sea. Indeed, B.P.'s holdings there are so vast that it had more than it needed - a main reason for the deal with Oryx.
And because of tax features in the deal, Oryx could afford to pay a relatively high price for the reserves.
Mr. Horton and his lieutenants have plenty of plans for the money from all the sales and the billions that the company could be able to borrow.
They would like to see B.P. increase its presence in Australia and East Asia: a slew of projects, ranging from a new liquid natural gas operation in Australia to chemical plants in East Asia, are either under way or in negotiations.
Given the economic growth rate in that part of the world, ''a successful company ignores it at its peril,'' Mr. Horton said the other day in his office in the Britannic House, B.P.'s London headquarters.
Then there are ambitions to become much bigger in natural gas, where Exxon and Royal Dutch/Shell dwarf B.P. Mr. Horton shares the view of many other industry executives that for both energy-supply and environmental reasons, clean-burning natural gas is about to come into its own.
And many of Mr. Horton's plans involve the United States, where he spent two years turning around the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, now B.P. America - an achievement that undoubtedly helped him win B.P.'s top job.
Alaska in general and the giant Prudhoe Bay field on Alaska's North Slope in particular will continue to be one of B.P.'s most important sources of income for the foreseeable future. Even so, Mr. Horton would like to see the company become a much more important player in the Gulf of Mexico. In recent Government auctions, B.P. was the top bidder for 35 of 46 tracts in the gulf.
Mr. Horton is also talking about greatly expanding B.P.'s presence in refining and marketing on the West Coast. B.P. established a foothold there last year, when it swapped some of its service stations in the Northeast, Michigan and Florida for Mobil stations in the Northwest and bought a Mobil refinery there.
And while B.P. is a leader in the polyethylene business in Europe, ''we're weak in the United States'' in that petrochemical, Mr. Horton lamented. One possibility is waiting a year or two until the cyclical petrochemicals industry - and acquisition prices - comes down, said James H. Ross, president of B.P. America. Another is some ''novel form'' of alliance, Mr. Horton said.
 
Shares for America
 Mr. Horton also would like to see 15 to 20 percent of B.P.'s shares in American hands, up from the current 6 percent. The London Stock Exchange is just too small and acts as a ceiling on B.P.'s share price, he complains. To that end, B.P. has started paying dividends quarterly and issuing its earnings statements when the big American oil companies announce theirs. It would love to have its shares - rather than American depository receipts - trade on the New York Stock Exchange.
And making B.P. a familiar name to American investors is at least an important secondary reason B.P. is currently turning all of its 8,000 gas stations in the United States into B.P.-brand stations. The fact that major brands typically can charge 2 to 4 cents more a gallon is another.
All this interest in the United States is not surprising. Nearly half of B.P.'s assets are in the United States, thanks to its $7.7 billion buyout in 1987 of the minority stake in Sohio that it did not own. To obtain an American partner to develop Prudhoe Bay, B.P. had in 1969 swapped its share of the field for an eventual slim majority of Sohio. It was that deal that brought Mr. Horton to America. As the money poured in from Prudhoe Bay in the early 1980's, Cleveland-based Sohio, which had long been a respected regional refiner and marketer, suddenly found itself in the big leagues.
But its attempts to use the new riches to diversify and build an exploration and production operation worthy of a major oil company were - to be kind - less than impressive.
In 1986, Mr. Horton got the job of cleaning up the mess. He had already proved himself by turning around B.P.'s European chemicals business in the early 1980's. He did that by closing 20 plants, slashing staff and focusing B.P. on commodity chemicals in which it had an edge in technology and market share.
The pattern was repeated in America, with the help of B.P. veterans like John Browne, who overhauled the exploration and production operation, and Colin Webster, who focused on research, chemicals and minerals.
Mr. Horton, who obviously likes Americans, has played a major role in integrating B.P.'s American staff into the rest of B.P. There are 120 Americans working at Britannic House, and Americans are also climbing the ladder. B.P.'s treasurer and its controller are Americans. And in the last round of promotions, an American was named managing director of B.P.'s Australian business.
One way B.P. benefited from the exchange was in marketing, which had never been B.P.'s strong suit. ''Sohio has always been a superb marketing company,'' Mr. Horton said.
But noting that there are also more than 100 non-Americans working at B.P. America in Cleveland, Mr. Horton emphasizes that talent is what matters at B.P. ''What we are trying to create is a truly transnational corporation in which the only qualification for success is experience and merit,'' he said.
Most analysts think highly of Mr. Horton and the rest of B.P.'s management. Still, analysts tend to be up or down on B.P., depending on whether they think oil prices are going to rise or not. That is because B.P., in industry parlance, is ''upstream top-heavy'' - meaning it depends much more on its exploration and production operations for sales and profits than its major competitors do.
Those companies have relatively bigger ''downstream'' operations - petrochemicals, refining and marketing - whose profits rise when oil prices drop.
 
No Apologies
 Last year, B.P.'s upstream business accounted for 47.8 percent of its total operating profit of $5.1 billion, and 22.5 percent of total revenues of $46.1 billion.
Although their ambitions to expand in chemicals and refining and marketing show that B.P.'s leaders would not mind more balance, they certainly are not defensive about being top-heavy. The memory of having B.P.'s vast operations in Iran, Kuwait, Libya and Nigeria nationalized have obviously not faded.
Sir Peter finds it ''a paradox that B.P. has been criticized for being a two-pipeline company,'' referring to its dependence on the North Sea and Alaska's North Slope. ''You can turn that around and say that represents 80 percent of our company's considerable reserves being in the most politically and economically safe environments in the world,'' he said.
Still, B.P.'s problem at the moment is that production at Prudhoe Bay in Alaska and the Forties Field in the North Sea is now declining. That means that B.P.'s total production - now about 1.6 million barrels a day - will slip next year, although it is then expected to turn up again as new fields come on stream in the North Sea. With costs rising, too, that means pressure on margins. That explains the restructuring of the exploration and production unit.
''The danger arises when you think that oil prices are going to get you out of a fix,'' Mr. Browne said.
There are other challenges, too. ''There is still refinery overcapacity in Europe,'' said Russell Seal, the head of refining and marketing. Ray R. Knowland, the head of the chemicals business who will become a B.P. managing director in March, is worried that the European Community might lower tariffs on petrochemicals, opening the door to a flood of cheap petrochemicals from the Persian Gulf states.
In the wake of the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska, tougher environmental measures were implemented that raised B.P.'s productions costs there by $50 million, and the repeal of a tax measure favorable to the oil industry hit it with another $100 million bill. Then there is the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, where B.P., among others, would love to drill. Before the Exxon spill, Mr. Ross, B.P. America's president, had hoped that the industry might gain Federal permission to drill there this year. Now it will be at least several years, he said.
Still, these are minor problems compared with the major ones that buffeted the company throughout much of the 1980's. ''I've left a company with few if any weaknesses and a whole range of options to build the company's strength in the next decade,'' Sir Peter said.
