HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: TOMORROW'S TELEVISION;
It Will Be Hard to Make Money

BYLINE: By J. MICHEL GUITE; J. Michel Guite is a vice president and technology equipment analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.

 BODY:
The high-definition television picture could use some clarification with regard to its likely roll-out schedule and its prospects for strengthening American-owned consumer electronics manufacturers. My view is that HDTV will take longer to become widely available than most people think and that it will not alter the decline of the American consumer electronics industry. HDTV has, however, been helpful in focusing attention on the need for an American industrial policy. I am cautious about HDTV for three reasons: First, HDTV will take longer to become widely available than many people expect. A review of the pace of introduction of color TV as an enhancement of black-and-white TV, or of FM radio as an enhancement of AM radio, shows that these successful technologies took four to five years, from initial commercial availability to about 1 percent penetration. To reach over 50 percent of households, took another 10 years. Video cassette recorders, show a similar pattern.
Successful consumer product revolutions in the United States take 10 to 15 years on average. In my view, HDTV will probably not achieve a 1 percent penetration level before 1995, and will not be widely implemented in a majority of homes until 8 to 10 years later. 
Second, improved TV picture clarity will arrive via several different technologies. I see a reasonable prospect for fully distinct American, Japanese, and European HDTV standards, with American standard-setting delayed until at least 1991. Furthermore, I see existing American conventional TV as a moving and improving target for HDTV to compete against.
Part of the opportunity that HDTV enthusiasts point to - for more video memory, faster digital signal processors and analog/digital converters - will also be driven by enhancements to conventional TV.
Third, HDTV manufacturing will almost certainly continue to be dominated by the existing non-American worldwide consumer electronics leaders. Over the last 40 years, American-owned manufacturers have seen their domestic market share decline from nearly 100 percent to less than 15 percent. There is no reason to believe this decline will be reversed without changes in the way Americans do business and in the way those business are regulated and protected.
HDTV in the United States could enhance some opportunities for the Zenith Electronics Corporation, and it could fuel downstream product development for North American semiconductor, telecommunications equipment and flat-panel display manufacturers. Texas Instruments Inc.'s announcement last week that it will license technology from NHK, Japan's public television company, will enhance Texas Instruments' component sales in Japan and the United States.
But the principal beneficiaries of HDTV will likely be the vertically integrated worldwide consumer electronics leaders - Sony, NEC, Mitsubishi, Philips and others. This outcome results from a condition of open international trade and investment flows, and from worldwide market share expansion won by the most competitive producers.
HDTV has been used in Washington to help focus attention on the need for a stronger industrial policy. A number of groups - including former President Reagan's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness, the M.I.T. Commission on Industrial Competitiveness and more recently the Electronics Industries Association's Advanced Television Committee - have advocated policies to reverse long-term declines in American manufacturing productivity and world trade. These analyses emphasize the need for economy-wide, rather than piecemeal policies. Recommendations include incentives to encourage a longer-term investment focus by managers and shareholders; open world trade with simultaneous reciprocal market access; reduced deficits and increased savings to bring down interest rates and cost of capital; improved translation of basic research into products, and improved efficiency in manufacturing.
Significant enhancements in TV picture clarity, and in larger and more lightweight flat-panel TV displays, lie ahead in the 1990's. These improvements will likely be introduced on several competing products. Some may be implemented in what we now call HDTV and others on conventional TV.
Meanwhile, the current widespread interest in HDTV can help focus attention on the need for an American industrial policy. An industrial policy needs to assist the most productive American manufacturing sectors. This includes semiconductors, telecommunications equipment, instrumentation and computers. Such a policy should help these companies compete on the basis of merit, price, reliability and service for greater worldwide market share.

HEADLINE: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER;
Beware Those Network Failures

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
The number of companies that have tied their personal computers into local area networks, or LAN's, is growing rapidly, and a new study has found that the networks function properly 94 percent of the time. But what about that other 6 percent - those times when the network fails? The study, released at the Networld trade show here last week, found that the LAN failures are a bigger problem than many people think. In fact, they can cost a large corporation an average of $3.48 million in losses each year.
The study by Infonetics Inc., a Santa Clara, Calif., market research and consulting firm that specializes in computer networking issues, is believed to be the first to put a dollar amount on the losses caused by ''downtime'' at the largest users of local area networks. 
''As LAN's become a larger part of the business world, with more companies putting their 'mission critical' applications on networks, the 6 percent failure rate becomes a bigger part of a company's bottom line losses,'' said Stephen A. Spanier, vice president of Infonetics.
As an indication of the growing importance of LAN's, the Networld trade show here attracted more than 20,000 computer professionals, ranging from small-business owners to the information services directors of the largest international corporations. More than 150 companies displayed their networking hardware and software products.
Networking is one of the fastest-growing segments of the computer industry. The International Data Corporation, a consulting company based in Framingham, Mass., estimates that 10.5 million personal computers, or 26 percent of the PC's now in use, are hooked together in LAN's. By 1992, the company forecasts, that percentage should rise to nearly 50 percent, or 28.6 million PC's.
Another research company, Dataquest of San Jose, Calif., estimates that companies spent $4.8 billion last year on network hardware and software, an increase of 88 percent from 1987. Twenty-three of the 100 companies surveyed had annual revenues of more than $1 billion, and all had at least 300 computers or other devices linked directly on a network. The study has implications for small business as well, since networks are spreading so quickly.
Companies rely on networked computers for such critical tasks as inventory management, electronic funds transfer, and electronic data interchange, in which standard business transactions are handled via computer instead of on paper. The networks are seen as strategic weapons that can give a company a competitive edge. But if a company - even a small one - loses the ability to conduct a part of its business, to send out invoices, for instance, the losses can be substantial.
''It's a major revenue maker,'' said Mike Powell, microsystems manager for Telcom USA, the fourth-largest long-distance carrier. ''If we lose it, we lose money.''
But local area networks are relatively fragile things, as anyone who has worked on one will attest. Indeed, an experimental network set up to demonstrate products at the Networld show, crashed the first morning. Nearly 40 companies had hooked up their products in the network. The network's failure underscored another trend that is making network management more difficult.
In the early days of computing, businesses bought all of their computer equipment from a single company, like the International Business Machines Corporation or the Digital Equipment Corporation. Today, businesses buy their networking products from a variety of vendors, and that can lead to conflicts of networking protocols, operating systems and other esoteric functions.
''The trend away from from single-vendor LAN's means there are more rough edges, and more places for things to go wrong,'' said Harry Saal, president of Network General Inc., a company that makes network diagnostic equipment. Network General commissioned the Infonetics study.
Networks can also fail for simple reasons, Mr. Saal said. A worker in one department could accidentally plug the wrong diskette into a PC and bring down the system, or someone could kick out a plug. A software glitch might accidentally tie up the system, causing response times to slow.
Mr. Spanier said the companies in the study, which included 100 of the biggest users of computer networks, had an average of 23.6 network failures a year, with an average downtime of 4.9 hours each.
The Infonetics study determined that even relatively brief network failures at large companies can result in major losses. The losses were calculated for lost revenue, lost productivity, and direct expenses for maintaining and upgrading networks.
Even a slowdown in the network's operation can be costly if highly paid executives and information workers have to wait three hours to do a job that normally takes one hour. Slow response time is the most common network ailment, but it is usually not reported as a network failure.
All too often, the Infonetics study concluded, companies try to fix network problems by adding more horsepower: faster file servers, speedier disks, brawnier software, more nodes. The companies in the Infonetics study spent an average of $650,000 a year for such performance upgrades. Theirsystems became more complex and even more prone to failure. ''A lot of hardware costs are wasteful; they are well-meaning but inappropriate,'' Mr. Saal said.
Beyond network analyzers, like Network General's Sniffer or Novell-Excelan's LANalyzer, which can reduce network failures by nearly half, according to the Infonetics study, there are other strategies.
The study found that although productivity losses at the average company were measured in millions of dollars, the companies spent an average of just $60,000 a year to manage the networks, primarily for hiring consultants or LAN management personnel.
Mr. Saal of Network General and Mr. Spanier of Infonetics stressed developing an adequate staff of trained network managers. ''LAN managers today are overworked, but companies are under tremendous pressure to keep staffing costs down,'' Mr. Saal said. ''Networks are changing and growing very rapidly, but how can you send a guy off for the network training he needs when he's always busy putting out fires?
''With losses already more than $3 million a year, saving money on the network staff is a false economy,'' he said.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 17, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2663 words

HEADLINE: RJR's Brave New World

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Last week was not a happy one in the ''junk bond'' market. As the Campeau Corporation's highly leveraged empire started to crumble, fears - some might even say panic - about the fate of other companies that had gone private through junk bond-financed leveraged buyouts swept Wall Street. Junk bond prices plummeted, dragging down even bonds that analysts had thought safe.
Not surprisingly, a lot of eyes turned to RJR Nabisco Inc., the giant food and tobacco company that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company took private four months ago in the biggest buyout in history. RJR's bonds have moved down along with the rest of the market, raising the big question: Can any company really handle $25 billion in debt?
RJR's early signs have been stellar - increased operating earnings, a flurry of new products, an effective cost-cutting program. But will that make the RJR deal a success? Or are Campeau's problems a harbinger of troubles at RJR? 
Wall Street, apparently, still sees RJR as a good bet - the prices on RJR's bonds have not dropped nearly as sharply as they have on other issues. And Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the 47-year-old former American Express executive who signed on as RJR's new chief in April, exudes confidence. ''Yes, there is life, even excitement, after an LBO,'' he said.
But post-buyout life is not easy for RJR. The sale of its European food businesses, of Chun King and, most recently, of Del Monte has made the company even more dependent on tobacco and baked goods. Yet the tobacco unit, whose cash-gushing ability is one of the cornerstones on which RJR's debt service is built, continues to lose domestic share, particularly to the Philip Morris Companies.
RJR's cookie and cracker business is still dominant in its markets, but some analysts question whether the debt-ridden company will have the resources to keep it growing. And Mr. Gerstner and his new management team have discharged so many people - 300 at Atlanta headquarters, another few hundred at Nabisco Brands and 1,640 people at the tobacco company - that the remaining workers are in shock.
''We're getting a lot of calls from their workers and if ever there was an ideal opportunity to organize them, it is now,'' said Joseph D. Masterson, international vice president of the Bakery, Confectionery and Tobacco Workers International Union, which represents workers at every American tobacco company except RJR's R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company unit.
Cash, of course, remains the biggest question mark. For now, the tobacco company continues to spew forth profit. And RJR got $2.5 billion, considered top dollar, for the five European food businesses it sold in June. But the $2.3 billion or so that RJR will probably get when the recent deals to sell the various chunks of Del Monte are finalized is about $500 million below what the company is said to have expected.
If interest rates soar, if the bond market plunges lower or if tobacco sales decline more, RJR may have to cut a lot further into bone than Kohlberg, Kravis had bargained for.
''I wouldn't be surprised if they have to sell Planter's,'' said one former RJR executive, referring to the RJR nut and snack division that, to date, has not been rumored to be on the chopping block.
Charles E. Hugel, chairman of Combustion Engineering Inc. and RJR's former non-executive chairman, has deeper worries. ''I am concerned about their ability to fund modernization, research, all the future-oriented things,'' he said. ''A lot will depend on what happens to interest rates, and on how well they stem their slide in tobacco.''
 
Different Signals
 Still, it is hard to forecast doom at RJR. ''A lot of people said that RJR, because of its size, would be the LBO that shows the system has gone too far,'' noted Harbir Singh, an associate professor of management at the Wharton School. ''Instead, it is showing clear signs of working out.''
Indeed, while RJR posted a loss in net income in the second quarter because of the huge debt expense, operating income before good will amortization was up 24 percent, to $848 million, from the second quarter of last year, on an increase of just 4 percent in net sales. Management layers have been slashed, and many of the perks are gone: six of the 11 corporate jets have been sold, limousine bills have been halved, the corporate apartment in Manhattan's posh Essex House is no more.
''We are running to the bone,'' said H. John Greeniaus, chief executive of Nabisco Brands Inc. ''Before, we might have lived with 5 percent fat.''
But the austerity efforts have not been indiscriminate. Nabisco Brands, for example, expects to spend $350 million on marketing this year, the same level as in 1988. And although introducing new products means huge marketing costs, RJR has been sending them flying out the door - nine new items from the Planter's division last month, 12 from the Nabisco Biscuit Company this month and a cigarette called Chelsea, which supposedly yields a nice-smelling smoke, now in test markets.
''Everyone assumes our motivation for everything is the LBO, but most of what we're doing needed to be done before,'' said Mr. Gerstner. James W. Johnston, the new Reynolds Tobacco chief, agrees. ''The changes were not driven just by a need to save money but by a need to build a stronger company,'' he said.
To be sure, RJR had a lot going for it to ease the buyout path. More than half its profits come from tobacco, which is traditionally recession-proof and thus can hedge against any worst-case economic scenario.
''That tobacco company has a great enough cash flow to let RJR weather any interest rate turn-ups,'' said Edward J. Robinson, the former chief financial officer who left RJR in March to join Avon Products Inc. Moreover, Edward A. Horrigan Jr., who ran Reynolds Tobacco until he, too, resigned in March, says that since 1980 RJR has pumped close to $2 billion into upgrading its tobacco plants. ''The modernization program was fundamentally complete before the LBO,'' he said.
 
Easier to Dismantle
 Structurally, too, RJR was well positioned for selling assets to pay down debt. It has long been decentralized, which made it easier to lop off businesses without wrenching those that remained. And well-known brands are commanding premiums these days, so it has got good prices for most of its divestitures. ''RJR was never an unwieldy conglomeration of things like Beatrice,'' said Gailen L. Hite, a finance professor at the Columbia Business School.
On Wall Street, cares about whether RJR is typical or unusual among buyouts pale next to two concerns: How well are its bonds faring now? And what will the company look like on May 1, 1993, when holders of its debt securities have the option of converting to equity? On both counts, analysts are optimistic. ''RJR is a very well-positioned food company and a reasonably well-positioned tobacco company generating tremendous growth and profits and cash flow,'' said Kurt A. Feuerman, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Despite last week's troubles in the junk bond market, Mr. Feuerman is sticking with his buy recommendation on the senior converting debentures of the RJR Holdings Corporation - the official name for RJR Nabisco's parent company.
Edward P. Mally, Salomon Brothers' junk bond analyst, is also still recommending RJR paper. ''The cash-generating ability of this company is such that it can both pay debt and support growth,'' he said.
Sustaining the cash flow depends upon the adroitness with which RJR's new management team addresses the company's problems. And on the surface, Mr. Gerstner seems a strange choice to lead the charge.
He has never been a chief executive before. He has had little packaged-goods experience. And his former company, American Express, is a money machine, where a manager can generally count on virtually infinite resources - a luxury that RJR, with its debt load, cannot afford.
But those who know Mr. Gerstner say he is a quick study. ''The pharmaceutical business is pretty far away from financial services, too, but he has made a substantial contribution just by asking the right questions,'' said Richard M. Furlaud, chairman of the Squibb Corporation, on whose board Mr. Gerstner sits. G. Richard Thoman, chief executive of American Express International, calls Mr. Gerstner ''an incredible strategist who, in a roomful of noise and opinion, will say the three sentences that crystallize where we have to go.''
Smart or not, Mr. Gerstner is in for a rough time. Most of RJR's top management team had been cronies of F. Ross Johnson, Mr. Gerstner's predecessor, and many had joined Mr. Johnson in an earlier, abortive attempt to take RJR private. After Mr. Johnson was forced to resign, there was little doubt that the rest of his team would leave, or be pushed.
And so it happened. Just weeks after RJR announced Mr. Gerstner's appointment in March, Mr. Horrigan and Mr. Robinson jumped ship. They were closely followed by the general counsel, the controller, the treasurer and assorted lower-level managers. ''I had to rebuild my entire team at the same time that I was trying to understand a company of gigantic scale,'' Mr. Gerstner recalled.
 
Emotional Chaos
 RJR, meanwhile, was in emotional chaos. It went through enormous upheaval four years ago, when R. J. Reynolds Tobacco merged with Nabisco Brands, and Mr. Johnson, then Nabisco's chief, superimposed a fast-paced culture on what had been a sleepy, Southern company. Now, trauma was upon RJR again. Every RJR employee knew that assets would be sold and jobs eliminated to finance the buyout. But no one knew whose job or division would disappear.
There were more subtle psychological problems, too. Not only had Mr. Johnson tried to take the company private at a fraction of its worth, he had later offered a game plan for a higher bid that would have entailed cutting the benefits of much of the rank-and-file work force. Employees inevitably began to wonder, if their chief executive could betray them so easily, and if Kohlberg, Kravis could earmark billions of dollars of assets as unnecessary and thus saleable, was RJR ever as good as they had thought to begin with?
''This is a company that just a few years ago was ranked ninth on Fortune's most admired list, yet suddenly its whole raison d'etre was called into question,'' Mr. Gerstner said.
Mr. Gerstner was no calming influence. When he took over, there were 650 people on the corporate staff, ''literally hundreds more than fits my management style,'' he said. He dismissed about 300 of them almost immediately. And he announced that those who were left would be moved from Atlanta to New York City.
The speed with which that announcement came sent a new wave of shudders through the shell-shocked company, which Mr. Johnson had moved from Winston-Salem, N.C., to Atlanta just two years before. ''Everyone expected the company to move to New York, and most have accepted job loss as a part of modern corporate life,'' said W. G. Champion Mitchell, the former senior vice president of external affairs who left in March. ''But whenever a bunch of people are let go there is sadness.''
Still, current and former RJR employees say that the sadness did not translate into anger. ''We were treated fantastically well in terms of severance, and RJR provided outplacement,'' said one former executive who, with much of his staff, is out of a job. ''We really can't complain.''
 
Change in Tone
 Remaining employees may find more to gripe about. Anyone used to Mr. Johnson's low-key, affable style may find Mr. Gerstner a bit hard to take. ''Ross is a fun-loving, playful guy, easygoing and charming,'' Mr. Greeniaus said. ''Lou can be charming when he wants to be, but his attitude is, 'Hey, we're mature professionals and I don't have to go around stroking everyone.' ''
With most of the dismissals behind him and his management team rebuilt, Mr. Gerstner may have more chance to show his charming side.
Many of his new hires have experience germane to RJR. Mr. Johnston, the new tobacco chief, had been with Reynolds Tobacco for five years before joining Citibank in 1984. And Karl von der Heyden, the new chief financial officer, comes over from the H. J. Heinz Company, a food company certainly as prominent as Nabisco.
Already, Mr. Gerstner is looking to push more responsibility on all of them. ''Now it's hierarchical, with all the power coming out of me,'' he said. ''I want it to be more like spokes on a wheel, with me at the hub.''
The new team is now tackling the strategic issues facing RJR. For example, they have decided not to go after more share for Nabisco Brands, which already commands an impressive 44 percent of the market for biscuits, but to try to maintain existing share instead. That strategy has been adopted by many consumer products companies - the Colgate-Palmolive Company being a recent example - to general applause: to wit, going for incremental share points is often a profitless exercise.
Far deeper changes are needed at Reynolds Tobacco. The tobacco company is still reeling from last year's $150 million failure of its smokeless cigarette, Premier. Mr. Horrigan, for one, still believes that smokers, who overwhelmingly rejected Premier's taste, would have grown acclimated to the product in time, and that ''there will be a Premier-like product out there again.'' But at this point, no one can guarantee that it will be RJR's.
 
A Dwindling Share
 RJR has a more immediate problem: it continues to lose domestic market share. ''RJR has got to get unit sales up,'' said Roy D. Burry, a Kidder, Peabody & Company analyst.
That will be no easy task. Winston, RJR's flagship brand, has traditionally appealed to older smokers, who are quitting smoking in droves. And while the company hopes to push Camel into the young-adult market, most analysts say that Philip Morris's Marlboro owns that market. ''Philip Morris's sales force has revved up to high, while this takeover business has discombobulated RJR's,'' said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc.
Reynolds Tobacco is trying mightily to get its act back together. Since the buyout, it has consolidated all its domestic operations, and is experimenting with new ways to group workers into more productive teams. And it is phasing out trade loading, a costly but common industry practice of selling distributors more cigarettes than smokers are buying. The practice lets the tobacco companies move inventory, but it gives distributors the benefits of price increases.
Those moves, combined with a spurt in international sales and the plant modernizations, yielded a 16 percent increase in the tobacco company's operating income last quarter, over the same quarter of 1988. And Mr. Gerstner is predicting more of the same. ''We will generate the cash flow needed to bring the debt down enough so that we can again make acquisitions,'' Mr. Gerstner said.
Maybe so - but then again, maybe not. ''I remember the first year after KKR took Beatrice private, everyone said what a great deal it was,'' recalled a high-level executive at a rival buyout firm. ''When the dust settled, the sum of the parts wasn't any greater than the whole. Will RJR be better? It is too soon to tell.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
U.S.-Soviet Issues Are Overshadowed

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THERE is something accidentally symbolic about the fact that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will hold their ministerial meeting this week in a mountaintop lodge in Jackson Hole, Wyo. While this is not the first important diplomatic meeting to be held in an out-of-the-way place, this time the relative obscurity somehow befits the state of United States-Soviet relations.
It is not that the Soviet-American relationship is fading out in its importance to world affairs. Far from it. As long as the Soviet Union and the United States have nuclear arsenals, the state of their relationship will be critical. Moreover, the ideological and strategic competition between them may have abated, but it has not disappeared. 
Nevertheless, the issues that seem to be having the most impact on the world stage today have less to do with the Soviet-American relationship as such than with changes in the Eastern bloc.
''United States-Soviet relations strike me as second order of importance now,'' said Robert W. Tucker, professor of international relations at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
''One is hard put to imagine a step that could be taken at Jackson Hole, on arms control or any other issue, that would have a comparable impact on world affairs as the events in Eastern Europe and the potential disintegration of the Soviet empire,'' he said.
In fact, the changes in the Communist world seem to be influencing the United States-Soviet relationship more than the other way around. Judging from remarks by Soviet and American officials in advance of the Wyoming meeting, their immediate impact has been to throw the United States-Soviet relationship slightly out of step.
The failure of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's perestroika to make a discernible improvement in the Soviet economy, and the explosive nationalist passions it has unleashed, have, in the view of Administration officials, made the Soviet leader in even more of a hurry for foreign policy and arms control achievements. He needs these to build his authority to make more reforms at home, save money and buttress his international standing in case he decides he must crack down in the Baltic republics or elsewhere in the restive Soviet realm, officials say. Mr. Shevardnadze, in an interview last week with the Soviet newspaper Izvestia, complained to Washington that the ''tempo of movement toward new agreements on real nuclear disarmament doesn't satisfy us'' and that ''because of the restrained, indecisive position of the American Administration, both the U.S.A. and the U.S.S.R., as well as the entire world community, have lost a lot.''
At the same time that the Shevardnadze interview was published, the White House was announcing that a date for a Bush-Gorbachev meeting was not likely to be set in Jackson Hole. Indeed, as Mr. Gorbachev's economic and ethnic woes make Moscow more eager for foreign policy successes, those same woes make the Bush Administration more cautious about its dealings with the Kremlin. While Bush policy makers are now much more certain about Mr. Gorbachev's sincerity as a reformer, and want to achieve quickly what agreements they can, they are increasingly wary that his reforms could lead backward to a sort of turn-of-the-century Europe fragmented by nationalist tensions.
In addition, the uncertainties unleashed by perestroika have made Washington more wary about keeping up the momentum for sweeping new arms control accords. In a time of destabilization, they cannot be so certain about the political context -in Moscow or the Warsaw Pact - in which the other side will be implementing such agreements.
So while there are pressures to quickly reach agreements, there are also counter pressures to move at a very deliberate pace. This may explain why Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze are expected to make progress in Wyoming on the ultimately secondary issue of chemical weapons proliferation, and only minimal progress on the more fundamental issue of nuclear arms.
''For all its risks and uncertainties, the Cold War was characterized by a remarkably stable and predictable set of relations among the great powers,'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said last week. He warned of ''the danger that change in the East will prove too destabilizing to be sustained.''
Administration officials say they are increasingly aware how little the West can do to make Mr. Gorbachev's changes succeed. What he needs more than arms control agreements, they say, is a theory and practice of federalism that would let him reform his economy while preventing an unraveling of his empire.
''It is strange,'' an Administration official mused. ''The United States-Soviet relationship is still critical for world affairs, but it is tertiary in determining whether Gorbachev succeeds or not. But whether he succeeds or not will affect our relationship.''
''It is important that we not be complacent,'' the official said. ''We should move where it is in our interest. But let's not fool ourselves. They are the ones in a rush, not us.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 17, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1237 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION: David N. Dinkins;
An Even Temper In the Tempest of Mayoral Politics

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

 BODY:
IT took David N. Dinkins a long time to get to where he is today, replacing the once-indomitable Edward I. Koch at the top of New York City's Democratic ticket. Yet probably the most delicate step in Mr. Dinkins's slow, cautious career will be his next one: in seeking to become mayor, he must convince the voters that he can lead a changing city.
Regardless of what happens Nov. 7, Mr. Dinkins is already a shoo-in for the history books, not just because he is black, but because of his proven ability to reach out well beyond his own base. His healthy margin of victory in the Democratic primary last Tuesday, including the support of 29 percent of white voters and 54 percent of Hispanic voters, according to exit polls, shows he tapped into a citywide yearning for harmony.
If calm is what many New York Democrats were voting for last Tuesday, a motive that some said easily mixed with a desire to be rid of the contentious and voluble Mr. Koch, it would have been difficult to find a more suitable candidate than the 62-year-old Mr. Dinkins. While his race reflects the shift in the city's demographics - now 23 percent black, and 17 percent Hispanic - his even temperament was suited to its mood. 
But now as Mr. Dinkins moves toward the general election, he faces a tough opponent in Rudolph W. Giuliani, a former Federal prosecutor who will have the ammunition of the Republican national party. Both candidates have already signaled a bolder, harsher campaign: Mr. Dinkins has linked Mr. Giuliani to ''reactionary'' Republicanism, while Mr. Giuliani has called Mr. Dinkins a ''clubhouse politician.''
And with Mr. Koch now out of the picture, the focus will be on what exactly the two candidates propose to do to solve some of the city's ills. In the primary, both talked about what they would like to do to combat crime, treat drug addicts and care for the needy; the question now becomes how, and with whose money.
For Mr. Dinkins, another question arises. Having proved in the primary that he can bring together different factions under a banner of harmony, he must now show he can lead this reassembled coalition of labor, liberals and minorities - and not be torn apart, or immobilized by their competing interests.
At the beginning of the primary campaign, Mr. Dinkins seemed to fall into traps he set himself. When he said he would consider supporting changes in the Taylor Law, which bans strikes by public workers, he signaled that his support from the city's public employee unions may have had a price.
His suggestion brought a counterattack from Mr. Koch. Mr. Dinkins quickly dropped any idea of tinkering with the law, and now says he supports it as written.
In some ways, the pace and pressure of the campaign forced Mr. Dinkins to curb his sometimes maddening vagueness and his preference for lengthy deliberations, the criticism most often voiced of his tenure as Manhattan Borough President. ''The campaign has given him broader scope,'' an adviser said. ''And it has made him quicken his decision-making process.''
Still, by the end, Mr. Dinkins was avoiding any surprises. He stuck close to issue papers prepared by his staff, offering for instance, a 42-point plan for economic development.
And in his off-the-cuff remarks, he kept to platitudes about keeping the peace between the city's different groups. After the Aug. 23 murder of a black teen-ager in the white neighborhood of Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, his plea to ''stop the violence, and start the healing'' began to drown out all other messages put forward in the campaign.
With hindsight, supporters said Mr. Dinkins's even temper served him well, even though some of them had urged him to take on a harsher tone against the incumbent Mayor. ''David was very responsible for keeping the campaign within bounds,'' a top adviser said, ''and it is to his credit that in the end, Koch became more like Dinkins, than the other way around.''
The Rev. Herbert Daughtry of the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn said he saw little change in Mr. Dinkins's style in the campaign, except for a tighter, sharper delivery of his message.
''He never lost his Dinkinism,'' said Mr. Daughtry. ''He is still Dave: if somebody drops a pen, he is the first to stoop to pick it up; he is the first to jump up when a lady comes in the room. It is part of his strong suit, and I don't think he is going to change.''
Some friends say that in the beginning Mr. Dinkins was anxious about giving up his safe seat as Manhattan Borough President for the risky prospect of facing Mr. Koch. But publicly, he maintained a surface calm, broken occasionally by flashes of impatience and resentment that he - as the only black candidate running in either party - was being asked to bear a special burden.
From his childhood, which he spent divided between New York City and Trenton, David Dinkins has kept steady control of his emotions, friends and family members say. When he was 6 years old, his mother left his father in Trenton and moved to New York, taking her two children with her. Mr. Dinkins later returned to Trenton, where he attended elementary and high school.
''He never was a loud type of person,'' said his father, William Dinkins, who was a barber, then a realtor and now, at 83, still lives on Spring Street in North Trenton. ''He thought way ahead before he spoke.''
Leaving the Marine Corps in 1946 - where he had twice been denied enlistment because the quota for blacks had been filled - Mr. Dinkins went to Howard University in Washington, graduating cum laude in mathematics.
He moved to New York City for good when he started at Brooklyn Law School, working nights at the liquor store owned by his father-in-law, Danny Burroughs, an Assemblyman from Harlem.
It was through Mr. Burroughs that Mr. Dinkins became involved in Harlem politics, soon linking his fortunes with the legendary J. Raymond Jones, the ''Harlem Fox'' and founder of the Carver Club, the training ground for several generations of black political and business leaders.
''What the Carver Club did was build men and women,'' said Mr. Jones, now 89 and living in the Virgin Islands, ''and when the opportunity came, fit them and support them where they could do the most good.''
That credo - train first, and then wait for the moment - is a good description of Mr. Dinkins's career. Elected to the Assembly in 1965, Mr. Dinkins served only one term before his district was reapportioned.
His elected career then went dormant for two decades, while he practiced law and paid his dues as a Democratic loyalist, climbing rung by rung up the patronage ladder without a lot of fanfare, first at the Board of Elections, then serving as city clerk from 1975 to 1985.
A low point came in 1973, when it was revealed he had not paid income taxes for four years in a row. He had to back out of an offer from Mayor Abraham D. Beame to become Deputy Mayor. Mr. Dinkins said he had been too busy to file the returns but he later paid the back taxes.
Supporters insisted that Mr. Dinkins's unobtrusiveness in those years was not to be confused with passivity. Rather, they note his perseverance -trying three times to run for Manhattan Borough President, before finally winning in 1985.
''Longevity counts for a lot in politics,'' a Dinkins adviser said last week. ''There are always meteoritic stars, but David is not of that ilk. He hung in there.''

GRAPHIC: The candidate outside City Hall (Sygma/Allan Tannenbaum)

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
After Four Terms, Us Versus Them Still Plays in Detroit

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
AT a time when a new class of crossover black politicians is reaching out to whites, Coleman A. Young, the cantankerous, tart-tongued Mayor of Detroit, continues to confound the experts with his popularity.
Mr. Young last week breezed to a nonpartisan primary election victory over a dozen challengers, and he did so without offering the sort of bridge-building appeals that many newer black politicians must make in other places. Instead, he used the same tactics that have infuriated whites and endeared him to his black supporters in his 16 years in office: he blamed racism, the media and white flight for most of the city's troubles; he called his opponents Uncle Toms. He came away with 51 percent of the vote and in November will face the next highest finisher, Tom Barrow, a 40-year-old accountant who Mr. Young beat in the 1985 Mayoral election. Mr. Barrow got 24 percent of the vote last week, and the consensus among local experts is that Mr. Young will, as one put it, ''have him for breakfast.'' 
The 71-year-old Mayor is among the last of a fading breed of black politicians who rose to power in the late 1960's and early 1970's, swept into office by black voters frustrated by decades of white-dominated administrations. They took over city halls with a mission to heal cities torn apart by race riots. They were considered saviors and symbols.
Mr. Young has outlasted most of his peers from that era - Richard Hatcher of Gary, Ind., Carl Stokes of Cleveland, Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark - by deftly playing to his supporters. His us-versus-them approach - city versus suburbs, black versus white, poor versus rich - has fostered deep loyalty.
More than most black mayors, Mr. Young has the numbers on his side. About 70 percent of Detroit's voters are black. Consequently, he seems to revel in the sort of polarization that other politicians dread. ''He embodies all the things that a lot of black people can't be themselves - tough, combative, confrontational,'' said Dr. Wilbur Rich, an associate professor of political science at Wayne State University and author of a biography of Mr. Young. ''He will tell white people off in a minute. That's reassuring to a lot of black people.''
Mr. Young has successfully deflected blame for the city's problems - crime, unemployment, inadequate services - by arguing that they are a result of national conditions. Some of his most loyal supporters live in ramshackle neighborhoods where trash collection is sporadic, the police do not come when called and crack dealers rule the streets. ''You're not downtrodden with Coleman Young fighting for you,'' said Jack Casey, a political analyst who helped run Mr. Young's first campaign.
 
'Coleman Needs Me'
Mr. Young, a former auto worker, insurance salesman, labor leader and state representative who never went to college, knows his constituents well. He is blunt and streetwise, frequently curses at news conferences and rarely shows up at charity balls. His supporters bridle at threats to his standing. ''If they think the race is a close one, they really come out, because they think, 'Coleman needs me now,' '' Dr. Rich said. At the same time, said Mr. Casey, Mr. Young simply ''never bothered to get white votes.''
If he ignores whites in the city, he is almost contemptuous of those in the suburbs. When stiffer gun- control measures were proposed for Detroit a fe years ago, Mr. Young denounced the effort as a racist attack on the city. ''I'll be damned if I'm going to let them collect guns in the city of Detroit, while we're surrounded by hostile suburbs,'' Mr. Young said.
Still, Mr. Young has forged comfortable alliances with white business leaders to bring scattered development along the downtown riverfront. ''He may have the best of both worlds,'' said Mr. Hatcher, the former Mayor of Gary, Ind. ''On the one hand, he's perceived as the champion of the black community, and on the other hand, the white business community sees him as an ally. It's quite a trick if you can do it.''
Still, the primary campaign of United States Representative John Conyers, who served 13 terms in Congress and was widely expected to be the Mayor's strongest opponent, brought Mr. Young some unaccustomed criticism. Mr. Conyers, a 13-term Congressman, got a lot of attention, but only 18 percent of the votes.
Mr. Barrow did better, but the day after the election he began stumping uphill, shaking hands tirelessly across the city. Mr. Young went on vacation.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 570 words

HEADLINE: The Passive President

 BODY:
In conscience and self-interest, the West cannot let the democratic experiment in Poland fail. Then why has the Bush Administration decided against giving immediate, large-scale aid to Poland's collapsing economy?
Given the historic opportunity to buttress the non-Communist alternative in Warsaw, the response reveals a curious passivity among President Bush and his aides. 
This passivity extends to other opportunities abroad besides Poland. The Administration could, but won't, move briskly to conclude the strategic arms treaty with Moscow. It is sitting back and waiting for the terrorists to make the next move on hostages in southern Lebanon. It is avoiding high-level involvement in Middle East peace talks.
The Administration now gives the appearance of helping Poland with the announcement that it will double emergency food aid to $100 million. But that's more in the nature of disaster relief than the structural assistance the new Government needs to start rebuilding its economy. And Mr. Bush took even this step only after pressure from Congress.
Though Poland is Exhibit A of Administration passivity, there are other examples.
In a remarkable speech last week, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger actually took America's West European allies to task for their evident interest in encouraging Mikhail Gorbachev's reform. The correct policy for the West, he suggested, is to act in its own interest rather than basing policy on helping Mr. Gorbachev to succeed.
How can it not be in the Western interest to help a policy succeed that the West has wanted all along? Given Mr. Gorbachev's moderate foreign policy course, it is clearly in the West's interest to act vigorously to strengthen his internal position.
As to the hostages in Lebanon, the President probably fears that any action would entail unacceptable risks. But that turns on a tragic assumption: that the terrorists will simply tire and relent. It's at least as likely that they won't and that he'll be forced to react once again - in crisis.
Correctly, Mr. Bush cannot ignore the odds against an Arab-Israeli peace settlement. Yet failure is guaranteed if the White House and Secretary of State Baker seem disengaged from the process.
Poland is the most clear-cut case of opportunity going wanting. The success of the new Polish Government will contribute to prospects for reform in the Soviet Union and throughout Eastern Europe, and more democratic governments there will strengthen Western security.
A little economic aid could go a very long way. For example, Solidarity is asking for a $1 billion currency stabilization fund; the U.S. share would be a fraction. The currency must be stabilized if the Polish Government is even to start fighting crippling inflation. Solidarity's leader, Lech Walesa, pleads, in addition, for $10 billion in emergency bilateral and multilateral aid. Again, America would put up only a part of the total. If backed by Polish belt-tightening and economic reforms, the request is not excessive - given the stakes.
The President's disposition to let events take their course has not served him badly so far. His popularity has now soared to 70 percent, a near-record in the last decade. But his standing will not survive catastrophe, and catastrophe almost certainly will result if he forgoes the advantages of decisive U.S. action and is compelled to be merely reactive in crisis.

HEADLINE: Ed Koch's New York

 BODY:
As he flew in from Washington one evening during his second term, a contented Edward Koch looked out at the glittering New York skyline and smiled. ''Mine, all mine,'' he said, figuratively, of course, but with unfeigned warmth.
Edward Irving Koch has personalized the mayoralty with such delight that the line between Mayor and city blurred during the 12 years he has led New York. That stubbornly personal style finally backfired. Calm David Dinkins, who says ''we'' or ''one'' instead of ''I,'' trounced Mr. Koch in last Tuesday's Democratic primary. Still, it was the personal approach that brought Ed Koch his successes, got New York through trying times, infused a dispirited city with optimism and gave it sensible leadership. 
It's natural in the aftermath of a passionate campaign to dwell on the Mayor's insensitivities and love of combat, his showmanship and weakness for one-liners. That makes this a good moment to contemplate all of the Age of Koch in perspective.
In a huge, disparate city that must have firm leadership to stay whole, Ed Koch redefined the role of mayor. That legacy of strong leadership can only help as the city contemplates a government reorganized by proposed changes in its charter.
The city was still recovering from its calamitous fiscal crisis when he took office in 1978. Business and development were at a standstill and New Yorkers were already feeling the strain of budget cuts; the police force had lost one officer in six. Before his first term was out, the city had regained access to the credit markets and was borrowing again on its own. Business was growing. By the end of his second term, the police force had risen to 26,000 en route to its present 27,000.
Shifts in the national economy surely contributed to this turnaround. But through the force of his personality, with the facility of a stand-up comic and the sternness of an accountant, Ed Koch got New Yorkers to accept difficult and unpopular fiscal decisions.
He'd call the United Nations a ''cesspool'' one minute, denounce ''wackos'' the next, but made a fractious bureaucracy for the first time conform to ''GAAP'' - generally accepted accounting principles. That was no small accomplishment. Neither was establishing and adhering to a merit system of appointing judges or championing a new program of public campaign financing.
From the start, Mr. Koch could be petty and insulting. He has been accused repeatedly of favoring the middle class over the poor. His insensitivity to blacks earned him bitter enmity. He reacted more than he planned. But he also showed he could learn. Mr. Koch appointed the first black Police Commissioner, Ben Ward. He launched an incredible program to house 250,000 people by 1993. He built a capital program to address the weakening infrastructure. Finally, he began moving families out of squalid welfare hotels.
When the corruption scandal erupted in his third term, it raised grave questions about the Mayor's judgment, about his embrace of machine politicians and whether his ceaseless need for self-promotion had distracted him. Mr. Koch, never personally implicated in the scandals, denied all. But he also made significant reforms.
In the end, Mr. Koch exhausted his beloved city. New Yorkers wanted a change, a respite from his entertaining, often irritating presence. But even Mr. Koch's most acid critics saw, in the gracious, unselfish way he conceded to David Dinkins on primary night, that Ed Koch's ultimate concern is for New York. This is the city he once called ''a stroke of genius.'' He will, no doubt, always consider it his, all his, and in a sense he will be right.

HEADLINE: How Inflation Looks In a Real Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I wonder if the Federal bureaucrats who report ''a moderating inflation rate'' of 5.1 percent (front page, Aug. 30) live in the same world as the rest of us.
In my local supermarket a roll of toilet tissue, which was priced at 39 cents last year, today costs 69 cents. A 32-ounce bottle of mouthwash, which was $3.79 last year, is today priced at $5.99. And a box of 10 steel wool pads, which was 69 cents a year ago, today costs $1.10.
Comparable increases of 30 percent and 40 percent can be seen on dozens of other items, not to mention the exorbitant prices for seasonal fruit and vegetables. For instance, peaches are 99 cents a pound; potatoes, 59 cents; iceberg lettuce, $1.25; green beans, 99 cents. Why such hothouse prices at a time when produce is in peak quantity?
Over-the-counter pharmaceuticals are priced like prescription drugs: 50 trademark analgesic tablets, $6.75.
Isn't it time we learned the truth about inflation? We may not be able to do anything about it, but let's not fool ourselves into believing the ''better off'' malarkey put out by Washington.
 
FRANCES A. KOESTLER
 New York, Sept. 1, 1989

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Disarm, Don't Disengage

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: OSLO

 BODY:
Military people all over are getting the jitters as East and West come to grips for the first time with the idea of really cutting armed forces. Norway is no exception, although there are political advantages.
There was an indecisive election here last week but with no defense or alliance issues. Controversies were on unemployment, environment, foreign workers. 
The once-active anti-nuclear movement scarcely peeped. ''They've been disarmed by disarmament,'' quipped Defense Minister Johan Jorgen Holst. It's obvious, though, that the campaign will be back with noisy vengeance, here and in the rest of Western Europe, if hopes are dashed.
But it's going to be a good deal harder than President Bush advertised at NATO last spring to get a treaty on conventional force reductions in Europe, and experts worry about the loss of momentum in Soviet-American strategic talks. Mr. Bush and his advisers aren't pushing on missile cuts.
There is a built-in ''braking mechanism'' - to borrow the Soviet term for domestic opposition to Mikhail Gorbachev's reform plans - to reducing military forces in the West, despite almost universal budget pressures.
One reason is that military planners and analysts are used to thinking in terms of clear-cut tasks and missions. They've had it all laid out for years. The idea of starting over again, reopening questions that were considered settled, provokes resistance throughout the alliance military establishment, even if it does hold prospects for big cuts in Soviet threat capacity.
But there are also more valid reasons for hesitation in facing changes required in the West. A tour of defense installations well above the Arctic Circle disclosed the concerns on Norwegian officers' minds.
They argue, rightly, that their far north has crucial strategic importance to the whole alliance, as well as to Norway's defense. They look out across the routes that Soviet subs and warships would take to attack the sea lanes between Europe and America, essential for reinforcements. If their bases were to fall into Soviet hands, it would be a disaster for NATO.
But all the emphasis now is on reducing the threat to the central front in Europe. Would that mean their northern flank would be left to face the principal exposure, they ask? They too could only survive by relying on reinforcement in wartime. Would it still be assured? If there are manpower cuts in both blocs, would they also be expected to reduce what is no more than a bare-bones standing army, with mobilization plans?
These and a lot of other questions applying to other NATO areas can be answered. But for now there is uncertainty. There can be no doubt about the commitment to defense, despite some U.S. arguments that the Europeans don't make enough effort for their own security to merit U.S. support.
It was pointed out at the conference here of the International Institute for Strategic Studies that up to now the alliance has lived with a high level of military threat but with political stability. Now the threat of aggression may be reduced, but with mounting political instability.
No one can be confident about what is going to happen in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Mikhail Gorbachev's difficulties are growing dramatically and confidence is seeking in whether he can maneuver his way through the painful transformation he has launched.
That is all the more reason for the West to maintain coherence as it watches, with only marginal ability to influence developments. Talk of NATO losing its importance when arms are reduced and the risk of deliberate confrontation recedes is pernicious.
On the contrary, NATO matters as much as ever as Europe moves into a new era. The problems for Germany are manifest, and the problem of its division is a central issue again for everybody else. The West has won the long ideological conflict, but that doesn't mean clear sailing ahead.
Western Europe and the U.S. remain critical to each other's security. It is the alliance that gives both the sense of safety needed to encourage peaceful changes in the East.
There is an opportunity to move toward demilitarizing the difficult East-West relation and it is important to seize it, for political, social and moral as well as security reasons. But reducing the level of arms and the danger of aggression does not mean the time has come to unravel commitments within the West.
Disarm but don't disengage must be the watchword for the U.S. now. NATO remains vital, and vitally needed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

PUB-DATE: September 17, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2106 words

HEADLINE: GETTING TO THE HEART OF DIXIE

BYLINE: By HOWELL RAINES; Howell Raines, the Washington editor of The New York Times and formerly the paper's Atlanta bureau chief, is the author of ''My Soul Is Rested,'' a book about the civil rights movement.

 BODY:

ENCYCLOPEDIA OF SOUTHERN CULTURE
Edited by Charles Reagan Wilson and William Ferris.
Associate editors, Ann J. Abadie and Mary L. Hart.
Illustrated. 1,634 pp. Chapel Hill:
The University of North Carolina Press.
$49.95; after Jan. 1, $59.95.
Gov. Ross Barnett of Mississippi was unique among the segregationist demagogues of the 1960's in his willingness to say the word ''nigger'' in his speeches. He was also capable of lying or, at least, changing his mind without telling anyone. In 1962, for example, he promised President John F. Kennedy that he would see to the peaceful integration of the University of Mississippi. Later, he turned up at an Ole Miss football game and, inspired by the sight of 40,000 white people waving Confederate flags, decided to renege. Barnett's duplicity led to a bloody riot on the Oxford campus in which two people were killed and Federal marshals resorted to hand-to-hand combat with a mob opposed to the enrollment of James Meredith, a black taxpayer seeking admission to a tax-supported institution in the state of his residence. 
These useful facts are unflinchingly recorded in the ''Encyclopedia of Southern Culture,'' a 1,634-page reference work assembled by the Center for the Study of Southern Culture at the University of Mississippi and published by the University of North Carolina Press. The mere fact of its publication is noteworthy. Ole Miss, which was once Dixie's most reactionary state university, now houses a center that aspires to fill the place in regional scholarship occupied by the University of North Carolina in the 1930's.
The appearance of the book also coincides with the emergence of a Mississippi governor, 40-year-old Ray Mabus, who may be a prototype for the next generation of Southern leaders. Educated outside the South, he has returned to tackle twin demons - property tax reform and education funding - that have made cowards of generations of Southern politicians. Mississippi, through its university and its Government, is bidding to jump ahead of Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and, of course, Alabama as the avatar of Sunbelt progressivism. Such matters are pertinent because they remind us that books, especially those that involve an effort at self-definition, are cultural events. And this book's significance reaches beyond Mississippi. It provides an opportunity to examine how the South thinks of itself as it emerges from a quarter-century of potent change.
This is a big, serious and ambitious book that has the virtue of avoiding what might be called the Southern Living disease, in honor of that relentlessly cheerful magazine devoted to depicting the region as one endless festival of barbecue, boiled shrimp, football Saturdays and good old Nashville music. To be sure, the encyclopedia makes its ritual bows to hog-killing and mamma's biscuits, but there is intellectual spine to this work, as well.
Most important, in their selections on Southern history, the editors, Charles Reagan Wilson and William Ferris, do a nice job of settling a legitimate regional grievance against William A. Dunning, a New Jersey man who inflicted a powerfully bad idea on the South through his teaching at Columbia University. In the first half of this century, the Dunning school of historians nurtured the myth of the lost cause and fed the white South's paranoid vision of Reconstruction as a time of undeserved suffering.
In general, the ''Encyclopedia of Southern Culture'' reflects a total repudiation of the Dunning thesis and many of its moonlight-and-magnolias corollaries. The historical and sociological analysis reflects the new consensus that has emerged in Southern scholarship over the past 40 years: that the Civil War resulted in positive changes and that the tides of change continued to flow in a healing direction up through the civil rights movement of the 60's and the regional economic transformation that followed.
Unfortunately - and perhaps inevitably in a book with more than 800 contributors and consultants - the individual entries do not always measure up to the encyclopedia's thematic promise and aspirations. As always with the South, things circle back around to race and class. In this regard, this book seems to be wrestling with limited success against two towering ghosts of this century in the South: William Faulkner in the realm of literature and Martin Luther King Jr. in the world of politics. It seems unable to throw off the one or to come fully to grips with the other. Fifty-nine lines in the index are required to record all the references to Faulkner and only 17 lines are required for King. As if to fend off a raid by Hemingway scholars, the Faulkner entry flatly pronounces him ''first among 20th-century American writers of prose fiction.'' King gets no superlatives in his main biographical entry, although ''greatest orator of the century'' would seem a pronouncement every bit as easy to defend.
Some element of Mississippi chauvinism may be at work. Through the middle decades of this century, Faulkner's excellence was Mississippi's shield against national ridicule. He was the state icon, held up the way Alabamians held up the Crimson Tide football team, Georgians pointed to Coca-Cola or Tennesseans celebrated the Grand Ole Opry. It was a way of saying no matter whom we elect or how badly we behave, we aren't trash.
It would be unfair to impute deliberate bias to the editors or their contributors. The biographical essay on King, for example, is a sound piece by David J. Garrow, a civil rights scholar who has done pioneering research on King's life. Rather, the fact that this book is more comfortable with the Civil War than the civil rights era demonstrates that Southern scholars have not fully assimilated the experience of the past 25 years or learned to honor black achievement with the ease with which they laud something like the cavalry tactics of Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest. This book - like the South, like the nation as a whole - suffers from having its vision blinkered along racial, gender and generational lines.
Of the 24 consultants chosen to assemble the major sections, only one is black and only two are women. At best, this is a blunder in public relations. At worst, it suggests that this book's vision of the South is essentially that of middle-aged, white, male academics. It is healthy to be blunt on this point: an institution attempting to throw off the chains of error can ill afford such lapses in editorial planning and intellectual balance.
The decision not to devote a section to the civil rights movement is a major lapse that has left big holes in the book. Heroines such as Ella Jo Baker, who helped found the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, and Fannie Lou Hamer, the SNCC warrior from Sunflower County, Mississippi, get their due. But two men of awesome physical courage - the Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, who sparked the Birmingham desegregation movement by offering his body to Klan beatings and police fire hosings, and Amzie Moore, who brought the first SNCC workers into Cleveland, Miss. - do not get the full biographical essays they deserve. The fleeting mentions of Robert Moses, the legendary SNCC leader who organized the Freedom Summer of 1964, is a breathtaking omission in a book that awards a sanitized biographical entry to Brother Dave Gardner, a white comedian specializing in racist jokes.
Again, sloppiness rather than some more conspiratorial impulse seems to be at work. For example, P. D. East and Hazel Brannon Smith, white newspaper owners who rebelled against Mississippi's segregationist ethos, are mentioned. But the much more potent figure of James W. Silver, the Ole Miss professor who shocked the state in 1964 with the publication of ''Mississippi: The Closed Society,'' is missing.
The 24 sections - varying from such predictable categories as ''Agriculture'' to the creatively conceived ''Mythic South'' - are introduced by essays that vary widely in quality. The best of these - including Blaine A. Brownell's ''Urbanization,'' Raymond D. Gastil's ''Violence'' and Numan Bartley's ''Politics'' - provide analysis that rises well above the conventional.
Mr. Bartley, a University of Georgia historian, for example, notes that it was the white middle class, not the much-maligned ''white trash,'' that sustained racist demagogues in office. He also notes that of all the purported populists only Huey Long fully delivered on his promises to make the extractive industries pay a fair share of state taxes.
Some of the same against-the-grain analysis is to be found in the section called ''Social Class,'' and it is here that the volume most clearly exhibits the conflict that signifies a struggle for growth in the way the South thinks about itself and its people. Here we see a real, if not entirely successful attempt to throw off the Faulknerian vision of an aristocracy that retained a core of nobility despite its moral failings and a Snopesian underclass that was contemptible regardless of its achievements. Consider, for example, this admission by F. N. Boney of the University of Georgia, in an excessively charitable discussion of Southern aristocrats: ''The rebel elite had fought well enough, but the real backbone of the Confederacy had been its redneck infantry . . . who slugged it out with a numerically superior enemy who were also farmers.'' But Mr. Boney cannot bring himself to take the next step and record the fact that the plantation aristocrats, on a percentage basis, were probably the most efficient draft dodgers in the Confederacy through the use of the famous ''20-nigger law'' that granted exemptions to planters whose slaves numbered a score or more.
The section on ''Social Class'' would have been strengthened by more attention to the phenomenon of anti-Confederate sentiment among white Southerners. The fact that 2,500 white Alabamians fought in the Union Army and that 44 percent of its voters cast ballots against secession in 1860 is the sort of oddment that ought to be preserved in a book of this sort. Closer attention to such forgotten footnotes would have served to reinforce the editors' accurate assessment that a South that was politically, culturally and racially monolithic existed only as the stuff of legend.
Despite its lapses, the encyclopedia offers some important correctives to accepted history. The editors are to be credited with picking scholars who consistently point up the exploitation of the pre-World War II South as an economic colony by Northern corporations and the later collusion between indigenous corporations and reactionary politicians. And J. Wayne Flynt of Auburn University, a historian of the Southern poor, justly exposes the shameful record of the American Federation of Labor in maintaining segregated unions.
This kind of scholarship represents progress for a region that has always been hostile to the voicing of uncomfortable truths on the campus, in the pulpit or the legislatures. Sometimes, the conflict between clear-eyed scholarship and traditional Southern courtesy surfaces in comical ways. For example, in a single paragraph, we see the aristocratic Episcopalians and Presbyterians condemned for sustaining religious and class discrimination at state universities and then hastily congratulated for founding, respectively, Davidson College and the University of the South.
Alas, the section on ''Literature'' is dated and sometimes wrongheaded. The Nashville Agrarians are praised out of all proportion and let off too easily on the race issue, while the best artist of the lot, Robert Penn Warren, gets too little credit for the magnitude of his achievement in creating the enduring masterwork on Southern politics, ''All the King's Men.''
The entry on journalism is even more dated and thunderously silent on the most obvious analytical questions. What was the role of Northern chain ownership in the failure of Southern newspapers to meet the challenge of desegregation? How is it that the most widely read Southern columnist of the 50's was Ralph McGill, a crusader for social justice, while today that role is filled by Lewis Grizzard, whose humor often reeks of fraternity house bigotry?
This book represents a step forward for Southern scholarship, but not a great leap. The leap will come when the biographical entry in the law section for Atticus Finch, the fictional lawyer in ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' is joined by one for Fred D. Gray, the pioneering black civil rights lawyer who represented Rosa Parks and the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. during the Montgomery bus boycott.

HEADLINE: WHO'S AFRAID OF THE BERLIN WALL?

BYLINE: By DAVID GRESS; David Gress, a fellow of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, is the co-author of a two-volume ''History of West Germany,'' to be published in October.

 BODY:

GERMANY, AMERICA, EUROPE
Forty Years of German Foreign Policy.
By Wolfram F. Hanrieder.
509 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95
 THE TWO GERMAN STATES AND EUROPEAN SECURITY.
Edited by F. Stephen Larrabee.
330 pp. New York:
Institute for
East-West Security Studies/St. Martin's Press. 
Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $15.95.
In his superlative new history of West Germany's foreign policy, Wolfram F. Hanrieder, calling himself a ''herald of future discord,'' warns: ''There is a broad and deep reservoir of goodwill toward the United States in the Federal Republic. . . . But the translation of that goodwill into the practical policies that ultimately determine the nature of German-American relations does not proceed automatically.'' If American policy makers want to maintain American interests, he insists, they must learn to understand and respect West Germany's own power and interests in formulating a European policy for the United States.
''Germany, America, Europe'' is the essential starting point for that task. Drawing on a lifetime's learning and personal experiences as a German-American scholar of international relations, Mr. Hanrieder, a professor of political science at the University of California, Santa Barbara, lucidly chronicles and interprets the four main dimensions of West Germany's foreign relations: strategic security, national division, international economic integration and domestic politics. In all four dimensions, West Germans face choices. These go to the root of their political existence and self-understanding as citizens of a cruelly divided nation and of a state that was intended by its founders to be provisional, but which, since 1949, has developed its own traditions and logic of survival.
From 1949 to the present, Mr. Hanrieder argues, America has practiced ''double containment'' - not only strategic containment of the Soviet Union, but also political and economic containment of West Germany in order to keep the Germans dependent on Washington for their policy choices and strategic options. In the 1950's, America contained Germany to reassure the French that it would not permit a revival of German military power; in the 1980's, containment has been held necessary to prevent a drift of West Germany toward excessive accommodation with the Soviet Union and East Germany. Such a policy is no longer possible, in view of West Germany's economic and political status. Mr. Hanrieder calls for a fundamental rethinking of double containment:
''This demands above all that Washington treat [West Germany] as a full-fledged partner and elevate the German-American relationship to the full measure of maturity that it deserves. It is time to shed attitudes that regard [West Germany] as a junior partner.''
If America begins to take West Germany more seriously, however, Germans and other Western Europeans must themselves learn the responsibilities of power. They ''must ask whether they truly regard themselves as so lacking in common purpose and strength that they cannot establish on their own a sufficiently credible joint deterrent, nuclear and conventional . . . augmenting if not replacing an increasingly shaky American commitment to their defense.'' If they will not, ''they should indeed continue to accept the American diplomatic tutelage they resent and the American nuclear protection they distrust. In that case they should do so not grudgingly and with endless complaints but willingly and openly, as do those who recognize and accept their lack of resolve and are ready to pay the price in loss of power, purpose, and prestige.''
Mr. Hanrieder's book is that rarity in American academic literature, a truly learned work. He understands that a love of poetry and philosophy are essential for the true scholar, whatever his field. An uncultured author may know many facts, but his presentation will be flat, ahistorical, without depth and context. ''Germany, America, Europe'' is not only the definitive account of its subject; it is also, thanks to its vigorous style and humane learning, a joy and a pleasure to read.
The Institute for East-West Security Studies brings together Western and Eastern specialists to discuss the major issues between the two camps. ''The Two German States and European Security,'' edited by F. Stephen Larrabee, the institute's vice president and director of studies, is one result of this effort. The Western contributions are generally sober, informative and useful, providing analyses of present-day issues that complement Mr. Hanrieder's historical overview. Their general tenor is summed up in the conclusion to the essay ''The Origins of a New Inter-German Relationship,'' by A. James McAdams, an assistant professor of politics at Princeton University. The two Germanies, he says, are building a structure of mutual relations that the West ''can hardly afford to underestimate.'' While well short of anything that even remotely resembles federation or reassociation, this relationship has become a permanent fixture of the European geostrategic scene.
The Eastern contributions, by comparison, demonstrate that the cold war is alive and well in East Berlin and Warsaw. Filled with the wooden language of ideology and confrontation, they are in no sense ''a concrete demonstration of the will of both East and West to work together to improve mutual cooperation and understanding,'' as Berthold Beitz, the honorary chairman of the institute, ingenuously claims in his foreword. Nor do they demonstrate any trace of the ''new thinking'' extolled by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. One East German spokesman has the effrontery to claim that ''the people of [East Germany] have exercised their right to self-determination'' in accepting Communist rule. Elsewhere, he tells the bald-faced lie that East Germany ''does not receive any subsidies'' from West Germany, ignoring the annual billion or so marks paid by Bonn to buy out Germans wishing to exercise their right to self-determination by leaving East Germany.
With a Stalinist regard for the truth, a Polish-regime spokesman straight out of George Orwell's Ministry of Truth asserts that the Polish Communist Government was ''guided . . . by humanitarian principles'' when, between 1945 and 1950, it expelled 15 million Germans from their ancestral lands, killing over a million in the process. Among his other lies are that few Germans ever really lived in these areas and that West Germany is dominated by aggressive, revanchist forces wishing to restore the prewar German borders. His article is one long litany of attacks on West Germany's good faith and intentions, with not the slightest indication of remorse or apology for Communist Poland's own very considerable crimes against humanity.
The contrast between the Eastern and Western contributions is glaring and should be a serious embarrassment to an institute devoted to the proposition that East-West dialogue is possible and useful. The proposition may in some cases be true, but this volume is heavy evidence against it.
