HEADLINE: THE BUZZARDS ABOVE, THE CANE BELOW

BYLINE: By RICHARD J. MARGOLIS; Richard J. Margolis, a columnist for The New Leader, is the author of ''Homes of the Brave,'' a study of migrant farm worker housing.

 BODY:
BIG SUGAR Seasons in the Cane Fields of Florida. By Alec Wilkinson. 263 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. By Richard J. Margolis IN 1951, President Harry S. Truman's Commission on Migratory Labor examined farm worker conditions nationwide and concluded that what held the system together was human misfortune. ''We depend on misfortune to build up our force of migratory workers,'' declared the commission, ''and when the supply is low because there is not enough misfortune at home, we rely upon misfortune abroad to replenish the supply.''
The cane cutters of south Florida - more precisely, of the south shore of Lake Okeechobee, some 60 miles west of Palm Beach - are a melancholy case in point. As Alec Wilkinson tells us in ''Big Sugar,'' the growers there at first depended on black men recruited throughout the South to harvest their crops. But during World War II the economic circumstances of Southern blacks inconveniently improved. So the growers looked elsewhere for misfortune, and found an apparently inexhaustible supply in Jamaica and the surrounding islands. In consequence, ''West Indians have cut the sugar cane crop in south Florida for more than forty-five years.'' 
Unlike sugar cane in Louisiana and Texas, most of the Florida crop is harvested by hand (the soil is too soft for machines), and it accounts for more than 40 percent of all the sugar cane grown in the United States. Miserly piecework wages plus generous Federal Government price supports have made many of the Florida growers rich. Mr. Wilkinson speaks of ''the fine, fine, superfine living they have known with sugar.''
A writer for The New Yorker and the author of ''Moonshine: A Life in Pursuit of White Liquor,'' he started visiting the Florida cane fields in 1984, and over the next four years kept going back. From his catch-as-catch-can explorations Mr. Wilkinson has assembled a vivid collage of the cutter's world - the perilous work, the pitiable pay, the enforced isolation that borders on peonage. ''The cutters live in camps maintained by the growers. . . . Some are surrounded by chain-link fences, a number have checkpoints, and all are off limits to outsiders.''
As an outsider himself, Mr. Wilkinson had a rough time piercing the cane curtain. Most of the workers shunned him. The Florida Sugar Cane League, which represents the growers, showed him public-relations films and told him to stay out of the fields.
He is engagingly open about his journalistic difficulties. In desperation, he latched on to a local ex-convict nicknamed Caveman, who took him to a dingy bar and introduced him to a man who possibly was a cutter. ''While Caveman watched the pool players, the man talked, but it was hard for me to hear because of the noise in the bar and because he kept lowering his head and speaking to the floor. The only part I made out clearly was when he looked at me and said, 'And I'll tell you one more thing. . . .' ''
Gradually, Mr. Wilkinson's shrewd eye and sympathetic ear managed to penetrate the mystery and the misery. We see the dangers that lurk in the fields, where ''more than one in every three [workers] cuts himself or is cut by someone who has lost control of his knife, or wrenches his back, or suffers an attack of some kind in the heat, or steps in a rabbit hole and turns an ankle, or is bitten by fire ants, or pierces his eye or his eardrum with a sharp leaf of cane while bending over and grabbing a stalk.''
In Jamaican voices we hear the quiet lilt of despair: ''First camp I go to . . . I see a big man cry from the cold and they had to take him back to the camp. All day we breathing the soot and ash from the fields. Our lives one day shorter for each day we cut cane. . . . We live in captivity, we must obey our master, anything he say we have to do. For we it is rough. We have always a struggle. We are all of us under a sufferation.''
Mr. Wilkinson's sharp vignettes are constructed from the bottom up. ''If you go out to the fields and lie down for a while,'' he says, ''you draw the attention of buzzards. Sometimes one passes so close that you can look him in the eye and see that he is looking at you.''
What we do not get is a top-down view of the human buzzards - the big sugar corporations that reap the wealth in the wake of the whirlwind. Nor do we learn much about the ignoble alliance between Big Sugar and Big Government, which keeps the system going. For not only does our Government protect sugar prices, it also certifies the workers' miserly wages and monitors their execrable conditions.
As Mr. Wilkinson makes clear, the cutters are in no position to get out from under their ''sufferation.'' Our own belated outrage remains their slim but best hope.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The New Commissioner Brings Up the Name Joe Page

BYLINE: By George Vecsey

 BODY:
The Joe DiMaggio of sports columnists, Mr. W. W. (Red) Smith, once tried to pull a swifty on a new baseball commissioner. Not only that, but he did it while the commissioner was buying.
It happened at Toots Shor's, where Bowie Kuhn had held a soiree shortly after his election in 1969. Smith, who was not charmed by Kuhn's history as a counselor to baseball, happened to exit behind Kuhn into the cold night. 
But let Kuhn tell of the sidewalk encounter, in his book, ''Hardball: The Education of a Baseball Commissioner,'' issued in 1987 with help from Marty Appel:
'' 'Commissioner, name two catchers on the 1944 St. Louis Browns,' '' Kuhn quotes Smith as asking him. ''Surprised though I was, I answered directly, 'Mancuso and Hayworth.' 'My God,' he replied, 'you do know something about baseball.' ''
In the same spirit, a journalist from another paper sprang a flash quiz on the new commissioner, Francis T. (Fay) Vincent Jr., the other day, and found him quite able to converse about the Philadelphia Athletics of the post-World War II era.
But Vincent's knowledge of the Joosts and the Fains somehow obscured the fact that he knew them as obstacles, impediments, nay, even victims. The A's were the passion of Vincent's father, a famous Yale athlete of an earlier generation who later became a football official.
''My father was from New Haven, and it is a little-known fact that Connie Mack was from Meriden, Conn.,'' Vincent said the other day.
The new commissioner was, and let us emphasize the ''was,'' a Yankee fan when to be a Yankee fan was to root for major corporations. Which perhaps explains why Fay Vincent became a chief executive officer of Columbia Pictures.
This Yankee thing is no small matter. Baseball loyalties are a Rorschach test of the soul.
The scholar and former president of Yale, A. Bartlett Giamatti, for example, was such a partisan of the Boston Red Sox that he was livid over John McNamara's not replacing Bill Buckner at first base in a certain World Series game, even though said lapse produced a victory for the league for which Giamatti signed the baseballs.
Peter Ueberroth, we think, was a childhood fan of the Malibu Pool-Dunkers, or maybe it was the Laguna Beach Wet-Suiters, of the Pacific Coastline League.
Kuhn was and still is a Washington Senators fan, even though two different Senators teams have vanished to a fatal mix of indifference and avarice. How stuffy can you be if you root for lost causes?
Before that, Gen. William D. Eckert rooted for the Air Force. Ford Frick was a former journalist, and we know they are always totally neutral. Happy Chandler rooted for the University of Kentucky. And Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis rooted for baseball to survive the Black Sox scandal.
Now we have the first known Yankee fan in the commissioner's office, to which he was elected on Wednesday, following the death of his friend and colleague, Bart Giamatti, on Sept. 1. Even in a telephone conversation, Vincent can be heard to sigh audibly when one offers ''congratulations-despite-the-circumstances.''
The two had planned to ride into the sunset, Butch and Sundance, 1 and 1A, but with Giamatti taking the high-profile road of moral suasion, and Vincent taking the low-profile road of bottom lines. They showed potential as a team in carefully banishing Pete Rose, a manager with a gambling problem, and now Fay Vincent is faced with handling both roles himself.
Vincent does not promise to do away with artificial turf or the designated hitter, both of which he deplores. He says he (and Giamatti) was ''concerned that people are concerned'' over CBS's dismantling the NBC game-of-the-week tradition on network television after this season, but he doesn't claim to have a solution.
The new commissioner does strike a civil note about the impending labor negotiations, saying: ''I was really annoyed over the strike in 1981, and so was Bart. I've lived through strikes in other circumstances, and I think it would be a terrible mistake for the players or the owners to view this in moral terms, good vs. evil. Historically, that's a disaster. This is an economic situation, and I hope I can be of some help in settling it.''
After a career in other industries, Vincent agreed to be Giamatti's deputy a year ago. He began seeing baseball from a new angle during the Hall of Fame weekend at Cooperstown, N.Y., this summer. Vincent, who does not play golf because of a serious back injury suffered in college, accompanied some umpires on a golf outing.
''To see dozens of fans in rural America standing along the edge of the course, getting autographs and talking to the umpires, was a very powerful lesson to me,'' Vincent said. ''I always knew baseball was important, but I began to realize, more than ever, the enormous role baseball plays in the culture and life of this country.''
It reminded him of his childhood in Connecticut, tilting toward the Yankees rather than the Red Sox, perhaps rebelling against his father's love of the Athletics. Now Vincent works with Bobby Brown, the American League president, who played for those postwar Yankees.
''There is nothing like going to the Stadium with Bobby and talking about Cliff Mapes, Johnny Lindell, Joe Page, all those great Yankees,'' Vincent said. ''Bobby told me how well the Yankees worked together.''
As Giamatti and Vincent no doubt thrashed out in their middle-aged friendship, Mapes would throw somebody out and Lindell would bash a big hit and Page would stalk in from the bullpen and strike out the last batter. It is probably not by accident that Vincent recites the names of Yankee shock troops rather than front-liners. He seems to know a bit about a good bench. So did the owners.

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Power Is Short-Circuiting Tennis's Appeal

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA WADE: Virginia Wade is a tennis commentator for the BBC and ESPN. She won the United States Open in 1968 and Wimbeldonin 1977.

 BODY:
A three-of-five-set men's singles match certainly gives you time to reflect upon trends in tennis today.
Watching some of these contests, including the Becker-Lendl final at Flushing Meadows last Sunday, has convinced me that what the game needs now is tennis environmentalists to rescue the endangered species of finesse, style and strategy.
Nostalgia is by definition looking back at the past through rose-colored glasses. When I was on the tour, we usually considered ex-players to be out of touch with the current game, but now as an ''ex'' myself, I allow myself the indulgence of evaluating the progress that tennis has made. What I see is a game in danger of becoming one-dimensional with its preoccupation with power and its neglect of strategy and nuances. 
On one level, Boris Becker's United States Open victory was a triumph for the game's traditional values. Of course, first Becker had to show he was strong enough physically to withstand Lendl's relentless force. I believe that once Ivan knew Boris would not be flattened by his big guns, he lost conviction.
For his part, Becker resisted the temptation to try purely to outhit Lendl. Instead, the depth and placement of his shots took priority over brute force. You could determine a game plan in use, and together with his tenacity it made him the champion.
The inherent danger in winning by sheer power is that you have nothing to fall back on if that fails. You are not accustomed to either employing strategy or thinking under pressure. You can only hit harder and take more risks.
Becker showed us the ultimate mental and physical combination of today's game. But he is an individual of great genius and charisma. So, with her dynamic brilliance, is Steffi Graf.
Less-skilled renditions of the power game have none of this appeal. Why? Because they lack dimension. There are no organic interpretations. One match resembles another: two players indistinguishable in style slugging it out with each other from the baseline. Big serves are followed by huge topspin ground strokes with practically no volleys.
The all-court player is virtually extinct. It's easy to trace the demise of the volley. As children start to play, they obviously begin with ground strokes. When the time comes to venture to the net, it's against other youngsters who are relatively experienced at the baseline, probably with strength and not much control. It is too hard to hold their own at the net so they retreat to familiar territory. Plus, they don't see too many superstars any more with a net game. So, the absence of players with volleying instincts or skills will be a self-perpetuating situation in pro tennis, unless some enlightened coach encourages them to persevere.
Tennis has a rich history of on-court improvisers. Now, only Miloslav Mecir stands out as a survivor of this eccentric breed. Gone are the characters from the past who entertained with their idiosyncrasies. There was Beppe Merlo, a minute Italian whose racquet was strung like spaghetti (not even al dente), who enticed his opponents into an intricate web of drop shots and lobs. And Frankie Durr, whose backhand, executed with an upside-down motion, found invisible openings down her opponent's sidelines, while her slow-motion service challenged our timing and concentration.
There was plenty of variety, both in players' personalities and the manner in which they played. Mass-produced tennis players began emerging only in the 70's, when media exposure made the game much more visible. Borg and Evert were the invincible superstars and role models for the next generation. Inevitably, the most obvious aspects of their games - topspin, two hands and patience at the baseline - were reproduced.
Soon after, technology gave us bigger racquets that not only made an awfully difficult game easier, but also generated more power. With the aid of television and slow-motion, technique has become more efficient at the top of the game.
Yet there are a lot of mediocre coaches out there, teaching limited versions of the game. They demand more topspin, however incorrectly produced. They crave more pace as an alternative to tactics. Hence the fascination with the wide-bodied racquet. It's a fabulous weapon if you have economical, well-produced shots, but its innate power is tricky to control.
This headlong pursuit of pace has also produced an unhealthy increase in injuries, especially among youngsters. Determined to out-topspin their idols, they have developed many more chronic tennis elbows, and wrists and shoulders than you ever saw in the past.
In the final analysis, it seems that only those of better natural selection and more compact technique can emerge at the top. This may mean that one must be a physical giant like Lendl or Becker to succeed today. The thought makes one yearn to see more of John McEnroe with his unmuscular, effortless speed and deft racquet handling. Maybe there'll never be another champion like Rod Laver, of small build but explosive strength. He was a complete player from the baseline and the net and he could win on all surfaces. He was instinctive and assured and never wavered mentally.
As we watched the women's final at the United States Open from the past-champions' box, Maria Bueno, the elegant Brazilian champion of the 1950's and 60's, remarked, ''Watch carefully, it may be 20 years before you see another great serve-volleyer.'' For a set and a half, Martina's flawless serve-and-volley game defeated Steffi's speed and power from the baseline. We all recognize Steffi's inordinate talent, but her game was succumbing to Martina's at its highest level of execution. Martina went on to lose the battle of minds, but also pertinent was that Steffi had to utilize the volley herself to win.
Maybe it won't be as long as 20 years for the pendulum to swing back. Maybe the tennis environmentalists will be able to work their magic on the game.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 32, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1107 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
How Schools Can Win Votes At the Polls

BYLINE: By Harold Levine; Harold Levine lives in Westport.

 BODY:
I WAS distressed to read recently that the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education was planning to deal with the rejection of school budgets this year in about half of the state's public school districts by running workshops and conferences with such titles as ''Passing the Budget'' and ''Winning at the Polls.'' What the school boards association must learn is that you must first win the confidence of your constituency before you can win at the polls.
The focus should not be on the budget, but rather, on a broad- based program of information throughout the school year. Too often the educational bureaucracy tends to pay attention to the public only when a budget vote is forthcoming, and then they try to sell the budget, instead of selling the value of the schools to the community. 
This year, school administrators should borrow the telephone company theme and ''reach out and touch someone.'' If public schools wish to regain the confidence and the support of the community they once had, they must not only continue to improv the quality of education, but also open their doors to the community and maintain a constant flow of communication.
Unfortunately, school officials have for years distanced themselves from the public. They often give the impression of not wanting public interference, putting up with the public only when necessary.
All that must change if schools expect to build a constituency of supporters of public education. School administrators must begin to reach out and touch the community. Our public schools must do a better job of informing the public 365 days a year on what is being accomplished in each and every classroom in the state before they can expect support at the polls. This may be difficult, since most educators have had little or no public relations experience. Therefore, as a starter, I would like to suggest an eight-point program for school administrators:
1. Institute a ''Breakfast with the Principal'' program. Each school principal would be required to set aside one hour a week to meet with invited guests. This would allow different community groups to learn firsthand what the school is trying to accomplish, and some problems it is encountering.
The guests could be medical professionals during one week, real estate agents the next week, then the parents of students in each grade level, and so on. This weekly program would give the principal an opportunity to meet with every social, political, economic, racial and religious group in the community.
2. Plan a Grandparents Day in every school. Much has been said about the growing elderly population and the unwillingness of elderly citizens to support public education. Well, here's an opportunity to make friends.
If every school in Connecticut invited the grandparents of its community to spend a day with the children, we would not only make friends for public education, but we would also build a greater support system for the local school. Retirees should be encouraged to volunteer for mentor programs and reading programs, helping with particularly difficult children, or just helping in the classroom.
3. Mail information about the schools to all residents of the community. As a former member of a school board, I am particularly interested in the public schools. I have lived in Westport for more than 10 years and, since we do not have children of school age, we have never received any information from the Westport public schools, except, of course, at school board election time.
It is the school board's responsibility to let everyone in the community know what is happening, and to not depend exclusively on local news reports. Those reports are too impersonal. If a resident is important enough to write to at school election time and budget time, that person should be considered important enough to get reports from the school throughout the year.
4. Develop mentoring programs by enlisting the assistance of the business community. Meet with the lawyers in town and create a mentor-in-the-law program. Do the same with doctors for a special health program, as well as retailers, manufacturers and other local businesses. The New York Alliance for the Public School is now supervising more than 105 mentoring programs in New York City. Information on how a local school system can set up its own mentoring program is available from the alliance.
5. Establish a speaker's bureau that provides a teacher or an administrator to address every local civic group during the school year. Be sure that all grades are represented. Remember, the public is just as interested in what you are accomplishing with preschool students as well as the high school program or the junior high music program.
6. Seek out a public relations professional from the community. Teachers and administrators cannot be expected to know how to write a good release, develop a photo opportunity or edit a school newsletter effectively. But a public relations, advertising or journalism professional within the community could save you time, money and frustration.
7. Prepare a videotape on a day in the life of a student or teacher. Use community resources and student talent for the preparation of the videotape. The tape should be given to the speaker's bureau as a wonderful introduction to its talks. Every group in town needs program material for its meetings. The Rotary, the Chamber of Commerce and garden clubs will probably be willing to book a speaker from the school system and allow the videotape to be shown. The tape would also be shown at all P.T.A. meetings and introduced at a special meeting for journalists.
8. Sponsor a community-wide survey to determine community attitudes toward the schools. Do it in October and use the results as a benchmark to evaluate the success of your public information program. Rerun the survey in October 1991 and again in 1993.
Seek out help from the community in preparing the survey. The School Boards Association could also take this on as a project and provide a questionnaire to each school district, allowing each district to add questions covering areas of their individual concern. A good survey should be able to tell you what you are doing right and what needs to be corrected. .
These are just a few ideas that can be immediately implemented so that next year fewer school districts will face negative attitudes from their communities.
The bottom line is that starting with the first day of school, all school personnel should be involved in bridging the gap between the school and the community - or, in reaching out to touch someone.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Child Care: A Need That Keeps On Growing

BYLINE: By Norman Goldman; Norman Goldman, an educational consultant, lives in Pennington.

 BODY:
AS the number of working mothers increases daily, so does the need for child care.
In New Jersey, some 60 percent of the children between the ages of 6 and 13 have mothers who work. Four out of 10 New Jersey children under 6 have mothers who bring home a paycheck.
There are 1,850 child-care centers and programs with room for 105,000 children in the state. To some that may sound like a great number, until one realizes we have more than three times that number of children with working mothers. By 1990, it is expected there will be 450,000 children with working mothers. 
Unfortunately, the problems in providing child care are not easily solved. What role should Federal and state governments play? Can public schools be expected to cope with the additional burden placed upon them if they are to provide child care? How can agreement on the delivery of services between private vendors and public schools be reached? What is the responsibility of business to assist in this effort? And, finally, who will pay the bill?
The continuing influx of women into the work force may mark the next five to 10 years as the time for increasing the public school's role in providing child-care services. But not everyone agrees that public school programs can handle the problem. Some argue that schools may lack the room and resources to make quality child-care programs feasible.
Nevertheless, the notion of public schools' providing child care is receiving more attention these days. Simply put, schools would have to expand their hours and stay open all year long, while they provide quality day care for preschoolers and care before and after regular school hours for older children.
But there are critical questions. Can the schools, many of which are already overburdened, take on the added responsibility? Should they? Is there a line between a school's educational and care functions?
Child care in public schools is not a new idea. Day-care centers were financed in public schools when women went to work during World War II. Most closed when women returned to the home. Today's demographics may be making such alternatives worth exploring once again.
Experts say schools should be used to some extent to help fill the growing need for child care. Some school finance experts predict, however, that the cost of a publicly subsidized system of full-day child care approaches the magnitude of what we now spend on schools. Public subsidies for such programs, they project, should be concentrated on poor children, with sliding fee scales for middle-income children.
There are also concerns also about linking child care and education in the schools. Early childhood education advocates insist that such programs primarily provide activities that help a child's development, with emphasis on play and socialization. There is fear, however, that as programs multiply, academic pressures will bring about increased regimentation and create problems for young children.
In the business sector, New Jersey has 96 licensed, employer-sponsored or supported day-care centers. Hospitals, banks and insurance companies seem to be in the forefront of private-sector involvement. This is because these businesses are characterized by a short supply of labor and high growth.
Recently, a former Secretary of Labor, Ann McLaughlin, warned New Jersey corporations that too many employers were making too many excuses for not providing child care.
Companies have options to support workers' child-care needs by setting up on-premises facilities, financing centers in their community or issuing vouchers to workers.
No doubt about it, child care pays off for those companies providing it. It reduces employee turnover and rates of absenteeism, lifts employee morale and loyalty to a company and makes recruitment of new personnel easier.
Gov. Thomas H. Kean has advocated increasing private-sector commitment to child care. ''In my view,'' he said, ''the strength of the American family depends on child care. The health and welfare of children depends on child care. And increasingly, the success of American business depends on child care.''
In Washington, diverse proposals approved in June by the Senate and the House Education and Labor Committee and advocated by President Bush are intensifying debate this fall on how the Federal Government should subsidize child care.
The bill passed by the Senate would authorize $1.75 billion a year to increase the supply and enhance the affordability of child care. Federal funds, distributed through states, would be provided through grants, contracts and vouchers. The measure also includes an estimated $3 billion tax credit provision that would expand the existing dependent care tax credit.
The Administration labeled the bill ''a candidate for a veto'' despite compromises to accommodate the President with an expansion of the tax credit. The President opposes the $1.75 billion in direct subsidies to help parents pay for child care and to help states improve services.
Other critics say the legislation is unconstitutional, permitting Federal funds to be used to support sectarian child-care programs, including religious worship. It also does not require national standards for health, safety, quality or nondiscrimination.
The House Education and Labor Committee approved a vastly different bill, which would provide $1.7 billion to expand Head Start, establish school-based early childhood development and child-care programs, increase child-care services from infancy to school age and provide Federal assistance for training and renovations to meet child-care standards.
The House committee adopted an amendment to prohibit sectarian activity in programs. The House measure also prohibits discrimination in programs that accept Federal aid, and it does not use vouchers. It is due for consideration by the full House soon.
Meanwhile, some 80 child-care bills are pending in the New Jersey Legislature.
Governor Kean is credited with creating three child-care centers for government employees, signing into law a measure calling for a survey assessing the child-care needs of all state employees and establishing a child-care component in welfare reform.
Also cited are the state's child-care referral system and a child-care voucher program under way in seven counties as additional state initiatives.
But the Governor warned: ''The supply of child care must keep pace with demand. We are still searching for creative solutions for more child care.''
The need for child care grows, fueled by a demanding economy and changing life styles. An aware citizenry is coming to expect efforts that will provide quality programs and qualified personnel. This is becoming increasingly clear to policy makers at both state and national levels as well as in business and education.

HEADLINE: Keeping the Pitch Where It Should Be

 BODY:
The Lubo Opera Company is to be commended for its efforts to standardize the pitch to which orchestras tune (''As Pitch in Opera Rises, So Does Debate,'' Aug. 13). The relentlessly upward wavering of the ''concert A'' is a deception that jades our perception of performance. It is as unworthy a practice as grade inflation is in the classroom or as anabolic steroids are on the playing field. It is why so many foreign recordings sound tense and, frankly, out of tune.
Musicians who want to sound brilliant should play more brilliantly. They should not resort to the cheap thrills of faux transposition.
 
KEVIN E. VITTING, M.D.
 Glen Rock

HEADLINE: Focus: Mountain View, Calif.;
Retrieving an Identity in a New Downtown

BYLINE: By JOHN McCLOUD

 BODY:
A NEW City Hall and an arts complex rising on the main street of Mountain View, Calif., a suburb of San Jose, represent more than just a demonstration of civic pride. They are evidence of a community's commitment to reversing a decades-long pattern of development in which this city and neighboring Silicon Valley towns lost their identities in suburban sprawl.
Besides a loss of identity, the area has also lost much of the comfort and convenience its residents initially sought in the suburbs. Homes, workplaces and shopping areas are separated by increasingly congested roads. Long-distance commuting has become so common than many suburban towns in the San Francisco Bay area have begun to wonder whether the traditional building of city centers does not make more sense. 
''People are tired of long commutes to work,'' said Dan Murphy, a project manager for the Prometheus Development Company in San Mateo, which is building City Center-Park Place, a $79 million commercial and residential project two blocks west of the new Mountain View Civic Center. ''People are looking for housing opportunities closer to work and the reverse, work opportunities closer to housing.''
Lucille Hise, principal planner for Sunnyvale, this city's neighbor to the south, said:
''The job-housing balance is a big issue for this whole area. People are beginning to recognize that by putting things closer together you might possibly eliminate some of the commute, which in turn would eliminate some of the congestion we deal with.''
In a twist, suburbs in this region are starting to choose to create, sometimes from scratch, traditional downtowns.
''Image is a major concern,'' said Ken Alsman, the acting director of planning in Mountain View. ''Our plan for downtown came from the community. And one thing that came out very strongly was that there should be a clear sense that it is a downtown, that it should look like a downtown.''
''People wanted stores along the street and sidewalks and cafes,'' he continued. ''They wanted parks and businesses and public offices, everything you associate with a traditional downtown. And they wanted it to be a place where you could park your car and walk around. Everybody seems to be really sick of driving.'' Mountain View is investing $50 million in downtown improvements, including building the civic center, a garage and a park and swimming pool and in redesigning and landscaping Castro Street, the main thoroughfare for shops and restaurants, to make it more pleasant for pedestrians.
The city's Downtown Coordinator, Stacey Holden, who helps promote the renewal, said private investment along Castro Street was more than triple what the city has invested.
IN addition to the Prometheus project - two six-story 115,000-square-foot office buildings with ground-floor stores and a separate 370-unit residential rental complex with mainly three- and four-story buildings - four other office-retail buildings have recently gone up on the street, and a second large mixed-use project has been proposed. Ms. Hise said Sunnyvale had also begun to work on its downtown. ''We really don't have what you would call an urban core,'' she said. ''Mountain View is much further along than we are. But it's clear that people want the same thing here. We have a downtown plan under study right now, and one of the most important things we're looking at is increasing the intensity of uses in the downtown area.''
Sunnyvale intends to replace a prospering shopping center with a $150 million complex of offices, condominiums, a hotel, restaurants, shops, a multiscreen cinema and a 950-seat performing-arts theater. The 15-acre project will encompass six city blocks.
Campbell, a town that not too long ago was best known for its prune yards - plum orchards and plants to turn plums into prunes - also hopes to turn a small strip-shopping district into a bona fide downtown. And in Palo Alto, home to Stanford University and one of the few communities in this area that has managed to retain a strong sense of identity, the city is putting finishing touches on an urban-design plan intended to make an already functioning downtown even stronger.
Local boosters point to the recent completion of several residential complexes and the opening of a large supermarket as a sign that downtown Palo Alto is becoming what planners like to call a 24-hour environment.
Even San Jose, a city that many have called a small Los Angeles because of its sprawl and lack of focus, is spending close to $1 billion on redeveloping its faded downtown, included a light-rail system.
Mountain View and Sunnyvale are negotiating to extend the system, a proposal that, Mr. Alsman said, would have been derided a few years ago.
Residential and commercial growth is leaving diminishing vacant land. Not only have land prices escalated steeply, but the remaining open space is also being fought over by a growing caucus of environmentalists seeking park land and wildlife refuges. A local group, the Greenbelt Alliance, recently reversed its policy and fervently endorsed higher-density land use in developed areas.
''IT'S clear that we can't suddenly stop growth from happening,'' said Larry Orman, the director of the group. ''Only by increasing the density of existing cities and towns can we preserve what open space we still have.''
Rising prices for housing also contribute to the trend, said Mr. Murphy, whose company is developing a mixed-use project, Cupertino City Center, nearby.
''Very few people can afford to enter the housing market now,'' he said. ''And we discovered there's a great demand for rental housing close to where residents work. A long commute may be worth it, if it means owning your own home. But nobody wants to drive long distances if he's just renting.''
Mr. Murphy said that by the middle of last month, his company had leased 290 of the 370 apartments approved in Mountain View. The rents range from $875 to $1,500 a month for one- , two- and three-bedroom units. He also said he expected many renters would work in the office buildings, a pattern he has seen in a similar project his company built in nearby Santa Clara.
The desire for community identity, more than convenience and necessity, seems to inspire, at least in part, the renewed interest in old-fashioned downtowns.
''I myself am from the East Coast,'' Ms. Hise said. ''And I have a vision of Main Street as the center of the community, the place where everybody meets. It's something I missed coming to this area. And other people seem to be missing it, too.
''People want to have some civic pride, some community image. They want a place they can point to and say, 'This is where I live. This is my home.' ''

GRAPHIC: photos of new housing and part of City Center, left, under construction on Castro Street in Mountain View, suburb of San Jose, Calif.; the new City Hall and arts complex (NYT/Terrence McCarthy)

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PACIFIC PALISADES, CALIF.;
Renovating Older Homes

BYLINE: By KATHY SHOCKET

 BODY:
THE gutting and razing of older houses for the development of expensive single-family homes is moving forward at an unusually rapid pace in this well-to-do community in the Santa Monica Mountains in the northwestern Los Angeles region.
Longtime residents who do not want to leave and buyers of older homes account for 80 percent of all the activity in new construction or renovation of homes, said Lila Gordon, a real estate agent for Corliss Westside Properties. The remainder is generated by developers who build new homes and renovate old ones on speculation. 
''Many of our existing homes are small and have outlived their economic life,'' Ms. Gordon said. ''People want bigger homes and, moreover, want to maintain the quality of life here.''
Older one-story homes, most with two bedrooms and one bathroom, rarely sell for less than $600,000. They are being replaced by two-story, three- to four-bedroom homes that sell for $1 million and up.
Stephen Love, a homeowner here and a partner in Solnik & Ward & Partners, a real estate concern, buys and replaces or remodels about 10 homes a quarter, making about a 75 percent profit on resales. He said he recently bought a home for $700,000, added about $200,000 in improvements and expects to sell it for more than $1.3 million.
Pacific Palisades has a population of about 36,000, with an average household income of $136,400. Homes are on lots that average 10,000 square feet, and architectural styles range from California bungalows to Mediterranean.
The trend toward razing older homes is spurred by rising land values. Brokers estimate that land makes up 80 percent of a property's value. Lots, which are scarce, start at $500,000, Ms. Gordon said. A lot she sold for $400,000 last year sold for $195,000 five years ago.
The Palisades Civic League Board must approve exterior renovations or replacements of the 4,000 homes in the original tract of land developed as Pacific Palisades.
There are 19 homeowners on the board, elected by members of the Pacific Palisades Civic League, which comprises 200 homeowners, business owners and employees. The board receives 20 applications a month from homeowners and developers.
The village, which is 15 minutes from downtown Los Angeles, dates from 1922, when the Methodist Episcopal Church developed the area as affordable housing for its members.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bridgton, Me.;
Condos Rising On Site of Inn

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
A LAKESIDE condominium project is being developed on the site of a former inn in this little town in Maine's western mountains. The complex, Moose Pond Village, nestled behind birches and evergreens on nine acres on Moose Pond, will include 19 units of 2,700 square feet priced at $275,000.
Seven of the nine units built so far have been sold, said Peg Miller. Mrs. Miller and her husband, Ken, owned the inn, which was built in 1939 near the base of a Pleasant Mountain ski area. They are partners with two others in developing the project, for which the inn was razed. 
Bridgton was a center for the smaller towns in the area, but lost favor in the 1970's, when Windham, to the east, and North Conway, N.H., to the west, began to develop shopping centers and outlet stores. Bridgton then became popular for vacation homes, mostly single-family houses beside the six lakes and ponds in the 80-square-mile town.
''This has created a new economy,'' said Town Manager Philip Tarr. Through this decade, he said, the town has granted about 70 building permits a year for vacation homes, many selling for about $300,000.
In 1985, the first condominium project, an 80-unit development called Lakeside, down the road from Moose Pond Village, was built and sold quickly, said Mr. Tarr. Another lakefront condominium project, Secret Harbor on Long Lake, began about two years ago, and about 10 of the 40 units approved by the town have been built.
NE Properties of Yarmouth is developing its third vacation-home project in Bridgton, an 80-unit condominium beside a nine-hole golf course. The president of NE Properties, Thomas H. Saliba, said six of the 16 units built have been sold. The units, ranging from 1,700 to 2,700 square feet, sell for $199,000 to $240,000.
Mr. Saliba said his father, Jacob, chairman of the Katy Industries conglomerate, bought the golf course and an adjacent 600 acres 30 years ago with the expectation that someday people would want to live beside golf courses. Two years ago, NE Properties began developing the complex, the Highlands, which was designed by Gary Lowe of Boston to blend in with a series of nearby stately Victorian houses.
NE Properties began its first development, Sunny Brook Farm, a 53-lot subdivision on 200 acres, 10 years ago. In 1983, NE built an 85-lot subdivision on a 700-acre tract on Highland Lake. It has 25 lots remaining, at prices from $30,000 to $200,000.
With the decline of the real-estate business in the Northeast, Mr. Saliba has postponed additional construction on the condominiums.

HEADLINE: Live Music Dying Out in Casinos

BYLINE: By OLGA WICKERHAUSER

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
AFTER a year without work, George Hernandez has given up trying to make a living in Atlantic City. He has sold his house, packed up his belongings and bought a one-way plane ticket to Los Angeles, where, at the ag of 58, he hopes to start a new life.
In leaving, he joins hundreds of frustrated and disappointed professional musicians who have abandoned Atlantic City in the last couple of years as one casino after another has replaced live performers with tapes. Today, in this entertainment-oriented town, not even the best musicians can find work.
George Fognano, president of the Atlantic City chapter of the American Federation of Musicians, says only 25 of 750 members work on any given weekend.
''There is nothing here for musicians,'' Mr. Hernandez said. ''This town is so dry.'' 
Five years ago, when he came to Atlantic City from Las Vegas, Mr. Hernandez, a pianist, was riding high. He had played with all the stars at the Tropicana and other Las Vegas casinos, and had been musical director for the Carpenters back in the 1970's. In Atlantic City he got a job right away as musical director at Trump Castle. For three years he led 12 other musicians in the casino's gala revue, ''City Lights.''
Then last summer, he and the other musicians were laid off with two-week's notice. The casino was planning a new revue, ''Glitter,'' which would use only canned music. ''They told us it was a matter of economics,'' Mr. Hernandez said. At the time, Trump Castle was one of the last of Atlantic City's 12 casinos that used live musicians. There was no where for Mr. Hernandez and the orchestra to go.
Several of the younger musicians took jobs substitute teaching or selling auto parts. ''What could I do,'' Mr. Hernandez said. ''I've been a musician for 35 years. I don't know how to do anything else.''
After a year of living off savings, he is moving to Los Angeles where he has a lead on a job arranging soundtracks for television movies.
Mr. Fognano accuses casino owners and politicians of betraying musicians, who helped bring gambling to Atlantic City in the first place.
''When they were trying to get the gambling referendum passed,'' Mr. Fognano said, ''we played rallies all over the state - for nothing, free! Everytime a politician spoke somewhere there was a live band playing behind him. All free.''
Edward Colanzi, a former Atlantic City Commissioner whose job it was to enlist the help of labor in getting the gambling referendum passed, says musicians did more than any other single group to bring legalized gambling to Atlantic City in 1978.
''The musicians put up money - money they didn't really have,'' Mr. Colanzi said. ''For 10, 12, 15 weeks they stood in malls from the moment they opened until 10 at night, talking to people. They traveled all over the state at their own expense. The musicians helped bring casino gambling to Atlantic City with their hard work. These casino owners didn't bring it here. Now because of the greed of casino owners, they're out of work.''
Musicians worked hard, Mr. Colanzi and Mr. Fognano say, because they were promised there would be plenty of jobs for them when the casinos opened. Each casino has at least one Broadway-sized showroom and several lounges.
 
Union Membership Drops
Musicians apparently believed the promise. After the first casinos opened, they flocked to Atlantic City from all over the country. Mr. Fognano notes that membership in the local union rose from 350 in 1978, when gambling was legalized, to 950 a couple of years later. Today he says it is down to 750 and dropping as musicians, like Mr. Hernandez, leave town.
In the beginning, as part of the promise to musicians, casinos were required by law to use live music in showrooms seating 350 or more. In 1981 however, the State Casino Control Commission overturned the law after casinos challenged it.
For the musicians, that was the beginning of the end. Gradually one casino after another replaced orchestras with tapes.
Also, Mr. Fognano says, casinos started reducing the number and size of shows and filling music lounges with slot machines.
It costs about $600,000 a year for a 13-piece orchestra, like the one Mr. Hernandez led, working six days a week, 52 weeks a year, Mr. Fognano said. Trump Castle's total operating expenses for 1987 - the last year they used an orchestra - were $204 million, according to the Casino Association of New Jersey.
But, says David Gardner, a vice president of the association, ''money is not the important issue here.''
''Frequently, tape music is better than live music,'' he said. ''Advances in recording technology in the last 10 years since the casinos opened have been great. We have to use whatever makes the act better.''
Mr. Fognano and his members scoff at that argument. ''Casino people are bottom-line oriented people,'' said Mike Pedicin, a saxophone player who has worked in Atlantic City for eight years. ''They're not patrons of the arts.''
Since 1981, Atlantic City musicians have been trying to bring back the old Live Music Law.
Last December, after failing to get a state law passed, they petitioned the Casino Control Commission to reverse its eight-year-old ruling. But in May the commission turned them down in a 5-to-0 vote. The commission chairman, Walter N. Read, argued that bringing back the old law ''would impose financial hardship on casino licensees without any concomitant benefit to the public at large.''
Mr. Fognano says his union will take their cause back to the State Legislature.
Mr. Gardner of the Casino Association says the musicians are wrong to blame the casinos for their troubles.
''It was the casinos that put entertainment in Atlantic City back on the map,'' Mr. Gardner said. ''Before casinos opened the only entertainment in Atlantic City was dodging seagulls. I don't know how many musicians were working when they were dodging seagulls.
''Besides, people in the entertainment industry should be more flexible. They should be prepared to move.'' Many Atlantic City musicians are doing that just. ''In the last two years,'' Mr. Pedicin said, ''I'd say 85 to 90 percent of the guys have left town or taken day jobs.''
Mr. Pedicin says he considers himself one of the lucky ones because he works about one weekend a month. ''But that's not enough for me to survive, or for anyone else to survive,'' he said.
Ted Greenberg, 29, a drummer and bass player who moved to Atlantic City from New York straight out of music school eight years ago, says he is ready to leave. ''First chance I get,'' he said, ''I'm going to get out.
''In the last three years, I've made less money every year. It's just a shame. The whole point of bringing casinos to New Jersey was to create jobs, and now everybody's forgotten about that.''
Marvin Rose's engagement calendar tells the story for most musicians here. ''In 1986,'' said Mr. Rose, 63, a percussionist, ''I had 26 engagements a year, mostly three-day weekends. In 1987, I had 16 engagements. Last year I had 12, and this year, I've had one in May.''
The point on which musicians and casino owners all agree is that Atlantic City audiences do not care if they hear live music or canned. And, the musicians say privately, as long as audiences do not demand live music, the musicians do not have much chance of winning their fight.
''People come here for one reason - to gamble,'' Mr. Pedicin said. ''They don't know that live music is supposed to be part of the show.'' And that more than anything makes Mr. Hernandez sad. ''It's such a shame,'' he said. ''They are missing so much. There's such a difference between hearing live music - with its excitement, its emotion - and a flat tape. They might as well stay at home and listen to a tape recorder.''

HEADLINE: Japan on $100 a Day - or Less

BYLINE: By EMILY ARNOLD McCULLY; EMILY ARNOLD McCULLY, who lives in New York, is a novelist and writer and illustrator of children's books. Her most recent work is ''Zaza's Big Break'' (Harper & Row).

 BODY:
WHEN you tell people you are going to Japan, they are likely to say they know someone who paid $6 for a cup of coffee there and wonder how you can subject yourself to such an economy. The language and culture are so forbidding, so strange - and those prices are somehow openly hostile. But if you go, you will discover that traveling on a budget in Japan is not only possible but also easy and surprisingly comfortable.
I recently undertook a two-week trip through the islands of Honshu, Kyushu and Shikoku with my 21-year-old son, Nat. We spent less than $100 a day each, which covered food, lodging and transportation and exposed us to Japanese customs with their many amenities as no package tour with Western-styled hostelries could ever have done.
Our strategy was to stay in small, family-run inns called minshukus, which usually provide two meals with a night's rest and a traditional bath. We spent all our waking hours sightseeing on foot or from trains and our second greatest bargain was the Japan Rail Pass, which is sold abroad for periods of one to three weeks and can save hundreds of dollars over regular fares. In 11 days Nat and I visited Takayama, Kanazawa, Kyoto, Hagi, Beppu and Usuki, Hiroshima, Miyajima and Takamatsu. 
The barebones trip, while it hardly acquainted us with the artful graciousness of high Japanese hospitality, insured that very little we experienced was like it is back home. The old ways may be fading, and the artistic, historic and natural monuments often obscured by dreary and dazzling improvements (as is true all over the world), but minshukus preserve traditions of courtesy, care and cleanliness. They differ from the more elegant ryokans in that they do not strive to provide exceptional service or ambience - no maid will lay out your futon or assist you in the bath - but then you are spared the possible clumsiness of being waited on in stark ignorance of the nuances of protocol. Minshukus cost less than half as much as ryokans.
We made our reservations through the English-speaking Minshuku Center in Tokyo. All inns post signs in English stating hours and procedures, but I resorted to mime to determine much else. We had the impression that our hosts and hostesses had long since suffered the worst a gaijin (foreigner) could bring about and were quite prepared to deal with us.
Business was surprisingly slow in mid-May. Some inns were deserted and even in Kyoto, where running shoes in the foyer denoted Westerners within, we could have found rooms at the last minute by inquiring at the Tourist Information Center near the station.
I was afraid that taking our meals in minshukus would restrict us unduly, but all were humble yet savory and beguilingly presented versions of the kaiseki-ryori, or traditional full-course dining, in which seven or eight small dishes are served with rice and soup. Some meals were better than others, but even the most routine were superior to what was available elsewhere for the same price and spared us uncertain searching and guessing.
Nat and I set forth early on a Sunday morning and found the Tokyo train station carpeted with buzzing uniformed schoolchildren on their haunches, all bound for a week of clangorous communion with Old Japan. Everywhere we went we were hailed with greetings and offered hundreds of hands to shake, but somehow this sea of pilgrims never boarded the same trains we did.
We were delighted to find that Japan Railways lived up to its superb reputation for comfort and punctuality. Seats were well upholstered, windows large and clean, personnel helpful and restrooms clean. All kinds of drinks, from Scotch to a high-fiber health tonic and obentos, or lunch boxes, were sold on platforms and trains. A blind choice usually yielded something like rice, meat or fish sausage or cake, pickled vegetables, sweet stewed soybeans and smoked or grilled fish. Sandwiches are usually available, too, the egg salad being the most easily identified. Bentos cost from $5 to $10.
Trains are gaily painted and immaculate and some tracks are lined with flower boxes. Frequent announcements sustain the railroad's reputation as the ''missing mother,'' reminding passengers to remember their umbrellas and so on. Obento vendors, exiting a car, will turn, bow and murmur acknowledgement of the ''interruption.'' We had to stand only once, on a rackety three-car train on Kyushu, which was packed with waggish members of the geriatric Tai Sai Walk Club, in bright orange caps.
Minshukus are regulated but are not all alike. In Beppu we stayed in an eight-story hot-springs resort. In Takamatsu, arriving exhausted in the evening, we found the lobby dismantled for renovation, tarps on the floors and stairs and the air thick with noxious fumes. Our hostess led us, protesting and gagging, up three debris-littered flights and flung open a door to reveal perhaps the only room they had finished - a perfect, specimen hotel suite, with bath and toilet all to ourselves, fresh flowers and a pot of tea.
Our first night out of Tokyo, in Takayama, was one of the best. The 100-year-old Yamashita Inn described itself as a ''guest house with athletic facilities in a village of farmer's market,'' and lay in the foothills among cucumber plots. The meals were superb and included fish, vegetables and fruit from the inn's own gardens and waters. We ate, not in our room, but around an old charcoal roasting pit with iron pot suspended from an ancient fish hinge.
Dining on tatami mats among strangers can induce serious leg cramps and we did a lot of constrained shifting. Another hazard is runny nose and sneezing due to sipping soup from the bowl. It is considered vulgar in the extreme to blow your nose at the table. One can only dab discreetly. Everything was delicious - salt-roasted whole baby carp, sweet pickled beans, potato in mustard, raw white fish, eel, grated daikon, seaweed and spinach, yam, tempura, fiddlehead ferns, broth with soba noodles and quantities of rice. The innkeeper kept the women supplied with beer and sake and these they tried to share with us.
They were already clad in their yukatas (kimonos supplied by the minshuku for lounging and sleeping), having bathed before dinner. It was out of the ordinary for us to take our turn after the meal, but perfectly acceptable. First we retired to our room, took our futons from the cupboard (and replaced them the next morning), changed into yukatas and descended a steep stair passing communal sinks and toilets to the bath. The old-fashioned tub was set into rocks beneath a shrine, some dwarf trees and shrubs and a window to the garden. Three or four people might use it at once, but you would never bathe with strangers in a minshuku.
The routine had already been made perfectly clear: you perch on a little stool on the well-drained floor and douse yourself with water from spigots or showerhead along the wall or with a basin dipped into the tub. Soap is always available and a tiny towel is sometimes supplied. Once you are thoroughly washed and rinsed, you lower yourself into the hot tub (probably 90 to 100 degrees and adjustable) and sit, water to the chin, to be deeply relaxed and purified by a ritual rooted in ancient religion.
The quality of this experience, however, also varied. In Kyoto, where the minshuku specialized in meeting Westerners' needs and offered instant coffee, eggs cooked to order and tasteless white toast for breakfast, a washer-dryer, international telephone and English newspaper, the bath was lukewarm and tinted green. An establishment catering to Japanese will have no need of such denaturing. Some baths were made of molded plastic or stainless steel and held one person, others were tiled and accommodated a nuclear family. In Beppu we bathed outdoors beneath the sun and the stars in belching mud and vaporous sulfur pools.
Japanese breakfasts are involving, filling and nutritious. We were told that eggs and toast could be ordered in advance, but that would be very foolish. Eggs were a staple of every breakfast but either raw or cooked hours earlier (the idea seemed to be that the food was once hot). Much more appetising were the smoked salmon or trout, miso soup, rice and various little dishes. One morning we ate just-picked, superlative strawberries, on another local mikan orange and melon. (An orange bought from a grocer cost $2).
A craving for coffee usually coincided with sore feet and erased the prohibition against the $6 cup. (It was really more like $3.) In an air-conditioned coffee shop with bordello decor you may lounge for as long as you like. Coffee can be had more cheaply at McDonald's or Mr. Donut (the latter with the seldom-seen bottomless cup) and is the only excuse for entering either of these establishments. A great variety of drinks in small bottles can be bought for 70 cents from vending machines. I grew fond of green plum juice.
When we stopped for lunch or dinner, it might be at a restaurant displaying plastic replicas of its set menus so that we got exactly what we pointed at. A typical set, or teishoku, includes rice, soup and a main course of something like curry or stir-fry. Sushi bars were an affordable treat when we contented ourselves with three or four pieces. Both these options were in the $6 to $8 range. Ramen or soba noodle shops offer a lunch of big bowls of rich broth with noodles and meat and vegetable for $3 or $4. Many train stations contain sleek shopping arcades with inexpensive restaurants ($5 to $10 a meal). Nat was visited twice by the devil urge for Western food and ordered fried chicken and barbecued beef. These dishes, though inexpensive at $5 to $7 a serving, proved far more unpleasantly strange than any of the local exotica we tried.
Japan is liberally supplied and immaculate in the matter of public toilets. Every museum, municipal building, garden, park, station, train and temple had restrooms, and sometimes a commode, although there is nothing mystifying about the Japanese version, which is straddled, and looks like a urinal set in the floor. Some toilets supply paper but travelers are advised to pack tissues and a handkerchief to dry their hands.
If there are dollars left over for souvenirs, it is best to make educated purchases in craft shops in prefectural museums or public gardens, such as the ones in Kanazawa and Takamatsu. These are official craft displays and assure authenticity, quality and fair price. Lots of little papier-mache toys and charms, dolls, paper items and packaged foodstuffs can be had for under $10.
Standard rates for minshukus are $35.75 a person with two meals, calculated at a rate of 140 yen to the dollar, but a few charge a little more or less and all offer discounts if you skip one or both meals. We spent roughly $28 to $52 a night on lodging. In Beppu the minshuku cost $46.50 a night and our meals were served in our room. But I found it compromising to be waited on by an old woman on her knees, even though she grinned roguishly and kidded my son.
In Takamatsu, on the island of Shikoku, our pace relaxed. This was the last stop before returning to Tokyo, and the business leg of my trip. We spent the morning strolling the paths through plum orchards and glades and over arching bridges in the classical hill garden called Ritsurin Koen. Later a heart-stopping bus ride that rocked along the rim of a hairpin climb to the top of the Yashima Plain deposited us 400 yards up at one of the 88 sacred pilgrimage temples of the eighth-century monk Kobo-Daishi. Along the summit there was a spectacular view of the Inland Sea. We had already seen it, close up, from a steamer, in the rain. Now it lay far below, the islands silent shadows, the harbor and sprawling city vague and delicate looking. I lost all sense of time. The humps and cones scattered to infinity were dim, feminine, inviting yet aloof. I longed to sail from one mysterious island to the next and indulged this fantasy to the point of sweet regret. A group of young salarymen - junior executives - appeared and boisterously hurled clay discs out over the edge, competing in an old custom. Then a mother and daughter took feeble turns and collapsed in giggles while their handsome guide watched languidly. The water was hammered silver and the receding islands paled until they vanished. We tore ourselves away in time to catch the last express bullet train, from Okayama for Tokyo.
My glimpse of Japan had been on the order of the mini-kaiseki, a nibble here and a nibble there, just suggesting the grandeur of a true banquet.
 
TIPS ON BULLET TRAINS, BUSES, MINSHUKUS AND MONEY
 
Train Travel
Once we had agreed on where we wanted to go during our two weeks, my son performed the daunting task of coordinating train schedules in one of the world's most extensive rail networks. We then verified his work at the Japan Rail Travel Service Center in the Tokyo Station.
Timetables and basic train information are available from the Japan National Tourist Organization in the United States and so are suggested itineraries, but checking at the Travel Service Center in Tokyo insured our course for every leg of the journey.
We got seat reservations at no added cost in no-smoking cars and advice on how to make connections.
All stations have Green Windows offering travel advice, in English in the major cities, and Tourist Information Centers are also equipped to guide rail riders.
 
Rail Pass
The Japan Rail Pass puts a premium on covering lots of ground and taking full advantage of the bullet train routes, which carry a stiff surcharge without it. In some locations the pass can be used for buses and ferries. Passengers must show the pass to board a train and remember to flash it again to get out of the station.
The two-week pass, which can be bought from travel agents or from Japan Airlines, costs $316 in Ordinary Class.
Buses on many buses in Japan a machine spits out a ticket when you board at the rear. When you exit at the front you match the number on your ticket with numbers on a board above the driver. You then pay the amount that corresponds to your number and drop the money and ticket in a box. Most bus lines originate at the local train station and instructions from the Minshuku Center indicated which line we should take. The driver or other passengers alerted us to our stop. We always had names and numbers written down to show people, if we had questions.
 
Getting Help
The Japan National Tourist Organization operates Tourist Information Centers in Tokyo, Kyoto and at Narita Airport, where personnel speak English and are equipped to deal with almost anything. In Tokyo the address is 6-6 Yurakucho 1-Chome, Chiyoda-ku (telephone 502-1461). In Kyoto the center is at Kyoto Tower Building, Higashi-Shiokojicho, Shimogyo-ku; 371-5649. At Narita the center is in the terminal building (32-8711) The Minshuku Center Headquarters is at Kotsu-kaikan 2-10-1, Yurakucho, Chiyo-daku, Tokyo 100; 216-6556. The center will only make reservations with minshukus with which it is associated. Travelers can be sure that those the center recommends meet standards of safety and cleanliness.
A booklet called ''Minshukus in Japan'' listing 270 inns can be obtained free of charge from the Japan National Tourist Organization at 630 Fifth Avenue, Suite 2101, New York, N.Y. 10111; 212-757-5640. The organization also puts out a free booket called ''The Tourist's Handbook: Practical Ways to Relieve Your Language Problems'' that includes a section on dealing with inns and hotels.
 
The Currency
Japan's is a cash society - traveler's checks must be converted at a bank or at special counters in department stores. I cashed mine in stores, where service was courteous and fast (not the case in banks). Money can also be changed at Japanese banks in the United States before you leave. - E. A. McC.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

HEADLINE: Oil Cleanup Brings Sad Prosperity to Village

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENGLISH BAY, Alaska, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Instead of hanging salmon to dry this month, as Aleut natives have done for centuries here on the toe of the Kenai Peninsula, John Kvasnikoff was putting up a $3,000 television satellite dish on the bluff next to his home above the sea.
A few houses away, Jeff Evans, his hair painted green, churned up the road with his new $1,500 ''Fat Cat'' motorbike, portable stereo headphones over his ears. In years past, he would be storing food for the winter.
''Things have gotten really weird around here since the oil spill,'' said Mr. Evans, who is known as the native James Dean in this hidden village of 170 people. ''A lot of people are getting drunk again. There's just too much money and too much stress.'' 
While the Exxon Corporation's $1 billion push to clean beaches fouled by the March 24 oil spill has ended, the social and cultural disruption in villages that have existed for hundreds of years without radical interruption is just being seen. Is More Than Summer Ending? The modern world had been closing in on English Bay and other native villages, but with glacial slowness. The oil spill and the resulting sea of money have accelerated the process, so that English Bay now seems caught on the cusp of history. A visitor has the sense that much of the village's traditional way of life is fading forever with the last days of summer.
Food to get the people through this winter was donated by other native villages, with the cost underwritten by Exxon. But it is not clear what next season, or the season after that, will bring; biologists do not know when the people will be able to harvest fish, seals and shellfish as they did before.
Oil from the 11-million-gallon spill and money from the Exxon corporate coffers has changed life, for better or worse, in a half-dozen villages where people had been living comfortably off nothing more than the land and the sea.
The cleanup that brought money did not create any permanent jobs. If the villagers cannot harvest the sea, they may have to seek work in the cities, once their savings dry up. Those who choose to remain in the villages may end up on welfare.
Binge drinking of alcohol, a consistent problem in native communities, has risen dramatically in some hamlets where it was thought to have been conquered. Emergencies brought about by mental and emotional distress have tripled in native villages on Kodiak Island, health officials say.
''Ever since summer, when we couldn't gather our food because of the oil, there's been a lot of alcohol and drugs, and stress,'' said Roy Evans, the village public safety officer. ''People here are fishermen. They weren't educated to be oil cleaners.''
Money earned cleaning up oil has made life here easier but, many natives say, not better.
''We are starting to see - what do you call them? - couch potatoes,'' said Vincent Kvasnikoff, the chief of English Bay.
Cut off from the rest of the world by a fortress of glaciers, active volcanoes and the big moat of Cook Inlet, English Bay appears at first glance to be a sort of Alaskan version of Shangri-La. Five crystal clear lakes, surrounded by walls of virgin spruce forests, drain the mountains above town.
There are no roads in and out of English Bay, which the Russians stumbled upon in the 1740's. They built a fort here and converted the people to the Russian Orthodox Church, the only religion still practiced by most villagers in their blue onion-domed house of worship.
Only six people have full-time jobs, including three in the school. Before the spill, everybody else in English Bay lived off the bounty of the sea: seals, salmon, halibut, shellfish, octopusesi, seaweed, barnacles and snails. They also picked berries in the late summer, and hunted for moose, deer and bear. Before the cleanup, the only money that came into the village was from sales of surplus salmon at the end of the season.
Most of this state's 65,000 native people - the three major ethnic groups are Eskimos in the North, Indians in the interior and Aleuts along the sSouthern cCoast - do not live off subsistence hunting and harvesting. But in villages such as English Bay it has been the entire economy.
 
Wood Smoke to Satellite Dishes
Until this summer, when nine satellite dishes were bought purchased by villagers flush with Exxon cleanup money, the only thing rising above houses was the blue curl of smoke from wood stoves.
Three weeks after the grounding of the tanker Exxon Valdez, oil washed ashore here on sandy beaches more than 200 miles from the site of the accident. After oil was found in the eggs of salmon and on shellfish plucked from the bay, villagers decided not to harvest their traditional food.
''The whole bay looked sick,'' said Mr. Kvasnikoff, the village chief, who has a mixed Russian-Aleut heritage. ''It came in as sheen, and then tar balls.''
It was the first time in anyone's memory that the villagers had not spent the summer collecting food. ''It's something I learned as a kid, when every day at low tide my stepfather would say, 'Go out there and pick up everything that you can - that's our next meal,' '' said Roy Evans.
 
Harmony With the Harvests
The summer harvests brought food and social harmony to English Bay, villagers say.
''The men would be gone hunting or fishing, and the women would gather snails and seaweed, and we would all get very close,'' said Nancy Yeaton, who moved back to English Bay 12 years ago after living in New Hampshire for a long time. ''It was always a great chance to talk, to renew old ties and teach your children about the tide pools.''
By early summer this year, everybody in the village above the age of 18 was working for Exxon's cleanup contractor at wages of at least $16.69 an hour. Ten-foot skiffs were rented out at $300 a day.
''It was like a typhoon came in and emptied out the village,'' said Ms. Yeaton. ''Everything changed overnight. We gained a lot of money, but we lost a lot of family closeness and our own food.''
 
Money for Cleaning Tar Balls
Roberta Kvasnikoff, the 21-year-old daughter of the chief who was wearing an MTV T-shirt, said she left behind the chores of caring for her infant daughter to work for Exxon. With the money she earned cleaning tar balls from the beach, she plans to buy food for her baby - the kind of food that comes in packages and cans, instead of from the beach and river.
Some villagers worry that even if the bay returns to full health - and most believe it will - it will be hard to make everybody go back to the subsistence life style.
''It's going to be really scary to see what happens to people,'' said Ms. Yeaton. ''Life is not routine anymore.''
Before the oil spill, labor was a community chore. Now, says Roy Evans, when you ask somebody to help you cut wood, they want money for it.
 
Taxes Are Discovered
With the money comes another novelty: taxes. ''I've never had to worry about paying taxes in my life,'' said John Kvasnikoff, who at age 26 is the youngest of Juanita Kvasnikoff's 13 children. Like others in the village, he said he would rather have a beach untouched by oil than the trappings, such as his new satellite dish capable of picking up more than 100 television channels, that cleanup money can buy. ''I gave up a lot more than I got,'' he said.
Mr. Evans, the village police officer, has noticed a sharp rise in sexual abuse and binge drinking. On this day, the talk of the town is a group of men who have been drinking nonstop for several days. Nobody will go near their house.
The village, which has fought the debilitating effects of alcoholism for years, has had a strong sobriety movement in the last six years. But this year, the alcohol counselor is drinking again, according to Mr. Evans said, and dozens of other villagers have also fallen off the wagon.
''There's a lot of healing ahead,'' said Mr. Kvasnikoff, the chief. ''I don't know how long it'll take to get people back to where they were.'' Is Language Being Eroded? The village chief says the influx of television will continue to erode the native language. Until a few years ago, when nobody had a television, English was the second language, he said.
''All the little kids spoke Aleut,'' he said. Now, he worries that Aleut could go the way of the dinosaurs.
Other villagers are talking of leaving town. Jeff Evans earned $22,000 from the Exxon cleanup and is thinking of moving to Anchorage. On a day when he would normally be hanging fish in the smokehouse, he was playing the Sex Pistols, a punk rock 'n roll band, at high volume. Sober for nine months, he is drinking again.
The village, represented by the Chugach Alaska Corporation, one of 13 native corporations formed in the 1970's to manage land and money received from the Government, has sued Exxon for the subsistence loss.
Some salmon, the last of the summer runs, are being harvested and hung to dry. A seal was recently killed and shared by the natives. But as winter approaches, many smokehouses are empty.
