HEADLINE: Salvador Rebel Chief Offers Truce if U.S. Halts Aid to Rightist Government

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The senior military commander of El Salvador's insurgency said in an interview today that his forces would be willing to ''cease hostilities'' if the United States halted military aid to the country's rightist Government.
''There is no doubt that if this aid ended, the fighting would have to end immediately,'' said the commander, Joaquin Villalobos, the chief military strategist of the rebels' Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. ''To a gesture of this scope, our response would have to be immediate.''
Asked if that response meant discontinuing all fighting, he answered ''yes.'' 
More than 70,000 people have been killed and a million have been forced into flight or into exile as a result of the decade-long civil war in El Salvador. The United States has sent more than $1 billion in military aid to El Salvador in the last decade, and $2 billion more in economic assistance.
Mr. Villalobos's statement came five days after the guerrilla front announced a detailed peace proposal here aimed at bringing about a cease-fire in the war by Nov. 15 and a permanent end to hostilities by Jan. 31, 1990. The plan will be discussed in future negotiations with representatives of the Salvadoran President, Alfredo Cristiani. The two sides held talks here last week.
 
Treated as Separate Matters
But the rebel commander was careful to separate his suggestion of a trade-off with the United States - an idea that Washington is almost certain to reject - from longstanding Salvadoran Government demands that the guerrillas lay down their arms.
''To put an emphasis on the handing over of arms is an act of bad faith,'' he said. ''This war has causes, and the problem is not one of handing over arms but of ending the reasons that have led to taking up arms and maintaining the war.''
If these problems, including the sweeping reform of the military, the political system and judiciary mentioned in the new rebel proposal, were resolved, Mr. Villalobos said, there would be no reason for the guerrillas to take up arms. But until such an agreement is reached, he said, demobilizing the rebels is out of the question.
''To put the emphasis on this question is to ask the F.M.L.N. to commit suicide,'' he said of the National Liberation Front. ''It would be an act of political ingenuity.''
Mr. Villalobos also criticized American policy. He complained of what he called a lack of response from Washington to a rebel peace proposal announced in January, and of Washington's support for the Salvadoran Government despite the passage of power in June from the centrist Christian Democratic Party of Jose Napoleon Duarte to Mr. Cristiani and his rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance.
''We had hoped that the change from the Reagan to the Bush Administration would produce more pragmatic positions and attitudes,'' he said. But with a few minor exceptions, he said, ''we have not seen anything substantive.''
''Look, they have increased aid to the security organs at a time of a Government of the extreme right that includes several persons accused of having used those security organs to persistently violate human rights,'' he continued. ''This worries us.'' Operating under the nom de guerre Rene Cruz, Mr. Villalobos, who is about 38 years old, has spent most of the last decade living secretly abroad or in the hills of El Salvador, directing rebel forces against the Salvadoran military and their American military advisers.
But in the last year, he has engaged in diplomatic activity, and last week he led the rebel delegation in three days of talks with the Salvadoran Government.
In the past, Mr. Villalobos, thin and boyish in appearance, has agreed only rarely to interviews. He said one of the reasons for the more visible profile he has adopted is to bring an end to what he called a ''propagandistic confrontation'' with the United States.
''My own person has been the object of a campaign saying he is a hard-liner, a radical, a terrorist, he's oppposed to any peace dialogue,'' he said. ''But I have said on other occasions that we have a greater sense of identification with the United States than with any other nation.''
 
'Yankees Are Weakened'
In a lengthy article published under his name earlier this year in Foreign Policy, Mr. Villalobos came out in favor of political and economic pluralism in El Salvador and peaceful coexistence with the United States. But doubts about him persist in Washington and San Salvador because of another document, a rebel strategy paper called ''Plan Fire,'' captured by the Salvadoran military last year.
''The Yankees are weakened but not beaten, and will only leave the heart of the continent if they are politically and militarily defeated,'' says the document, which has been called authentic by the rebel front. It also refers to negotiations as a means of ''keeping the enemy tied to the table with a view to his strategic weakening,'' and it endorses the notion of mass insurrection as a political and military tactic.
''I think you have to differentiate two things: between the objectives hoped to be achieved and the strategy by which they are reached,'' Mr. Villalobos said when asked about the contradiction between the two documents. ''I don't know much about the history of the United States, but I imagine that at some point during its struggle for independence, the practice of sabotage must have been discussed.''
The ''conditions of war to which we have been submitted have obliged us in certain cases to do this, and in some cases to make mistakes,'' he said. ''We have made some errors, we are aware of that.'' Among those errors, Mr. Villalobos said, was the slaying nearly 15 years ago of Roque Dalton, a poet and rival rebel leader whose death split the insurgency for many years.
 
Loss of Allies
Mr. Villalobos, who has often been accused of killing Mr. Dalton or of ordering the killing, said the slaying was ''a collective decision'' in which he took part and that the decision was costly because ''it was hard for us to win back the support of the intellectuals.''
But he defended the rebel front's effort to sabotage the Salvadoran Presidential elections held earlier this year, even though political allies on the left who were taking part in the vote asked the front's leadership not to launch a campaign of intimidation.
''In El Salvador, elections are an act of war, not a political act, as in the United States or Costa Rica,'' he said.
''Today, the possibilities for peace in El Salvador are greater than ever, in spite of the fact that we have a right-wing Government,'' he said, adding that the front was willing to make concessions on its latest peace plan.
''From the moment we called this a proposal, we have had margins of flexibility,'' Mr. Villalobos said. ''Since it is a proposal, we are prepared to discuss every point,'' he said.

HEADLINE: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 17

 BODY:
One month after the murder of a presidential candidate here unleashed Colombia's attack on cocaine cartels, President Virgilio Barco Vargas appears to be preparing for a long war against the major drug traffickers.
Breaking the pattern of previous, short-lived crackdowns, Colombia's Government has arrayed its weapons for a prolonged fight: seizing ranches and planes, freezing bank accounts, extraditing drug suspects to the United States and placing the headquarters of drug rings under military control.
''Barco has told me, one on one, that he is going to keep this up until he pushes them out of the country,'' a high Government official said of Colombia's President, who is starting his final year in office.
Clara Lopez Obregon, a congressional candidate from the left wing of the ruling Liberal Party, said, ''My sense is that the anti-drug effort is honest and is not going to blow away.''
But many narcotics experts fear that without major successes, public support will begin to drift. Already political figures are sniping at the drug war. 
''The measures adopted in the United States do not satisfy us: educational videos in the United States, bombers for Colombia, persuasive chats in the consuming centers and helicopters for Colombia,'' Senator Ernesto Samper Pizano, a presidential candidate for the Liberal Party, said at a press conference on Thursday. On Drug Dealers' Side Is Their Vast Wealth The outcome is far from certain in a contest that pits a democratically elected Government of a developing nation against drug merchants who are often described as the richest criminals in the world.
The traffickers, the source of 80 percent of the world's cocaine, have on their side vast wealth, private armies and a predilection for terror and bribery that has intimidated or corrupted courts, congress and much of the press.
Against this, President Barco has overwhelming public support and two new allies - the army and the United States. Narcotics experts say they are surprised by the tenacity of this crackdown, the fifth against the cartels here in five years.
''The drug traffickers have been really hurt this time,'' said Guy Gugliotta, who co-authored with Jeff Leen a new history of the Medellin cartel, ''Kings of Cocaine.''
''The cartels have been hurt in the pocket book,'' Mr. Gugliotta continued in a telephone interview. ''The Government has taken away their toys, their land, their ability to be rich and have fun.'' Supplies of Narcotics Are 'Seriously Disrupted'
Indeed, in the four weeks since the murder on Aug. 18 of the popular politician, Luis Carlos Galan, the police and army have seized an impressive inventory: 367 aircraft, 72 boats, 710 vehicles and motorcyles, 4.7 tons of cocaine, 1,279 guns, 25,000 rounds of ammunition, 989 buildings and ranches, and 32,773 farm animals.
In addition, 535 people have been arrested and charged and more than 10,000 others have been detained and later released. For the first time in two years, a drug suspect has been extradited to the United States and two more are awaiting extradition.
''It's put the traffickers off balance,'' an American diplomat said here. ''The supplies of marijuana and cocaine have been seriously disrupted.''
For the first time in five years, the wholesale price for cocaine in Miami is rising. Since the crackdown started, the price has risen to $18,000 a kilogram, from $11,000.
While Colombia grows about 15 percent of the world's coca leaf production, its major role is processing cocaine base made from higher grade leaves grown in Bolivia and Peru.
Police efforts have largely focused on hindering production by seizing chemicals used for refining coca base into cocaine powder. By mid-August, the Colombian police had seized twice as much ether, three times as much acetone and eight times as much ammonia as in all of last year.
The director general of Colombia's police, Miguel Antonio Gomez Padilla, said in an interview published Saturday in El Espectador, ''In the last laboratory destroyed we found a chemical recycling unit, which means two things: one, that they are having problems bringing the chemicals into the country, and, two, that they realized it is cheaper to recycle.''
Government officials have not explained why the security forces have not heavily hit laboratories and plantations in the first month of the current crackdown, although they have burned some coca plantations in the Amazon area and raided some laboratories.
The police have concentrated on seizing real estate, radio and aircraft suspected of being used for smuggling.
Corruption in the police and army may explain why the so-called 12 most wanted traffickers have slipped away and why major laboratories have not been destroyed, American narcotics experts here suggest.
Mr. Gomez, the police director, said in the El Espectador interview:
''Why haven't we captured the principal ringleaders? There are two groundless charges that are not true: the first is that they are not captured because we don't want to capture them. And the other is because the security forces are very infiltrated. In reality, these people are not being caught because they are not walking around openly in the streets. They are fugitivies and move around a lot.
Under attack, the Medellin cartel has fought back with its trademark violence. In the last four weeks, the toll from the cartel's terror action has been 13 dead, 140 injured and millions of dollars in damage. In all, more than 50 bombs have been exploded.
Tonight a homemade rocket was fired at the United States Embassy, The Associated Press reported. The news agency quoted an embassy spokesman as saying that the device struck a corner of the building but caused minimal damage and no injuries.
Three bombs exploded today in Cali, killing a security guard, and three bombings were reported tonight in northern Bogota. On Saturday, Guillermo Gomez Murillo, a reporter for El Espectador, was shot to death by three men who entered his house in Buenaventura.
The targets of the attacks have been carefully chosen.
Colombia's 200,000-man army, which has joined the fray for the first time, has been virtually untouched. The bombers have largely hit banks, restaurants, ranches and shops owned by wealthy and politically influential Colombians.
''The narcos are going after the ruling class - and they are already starting to squeal,'' a European diplomat said, citing calls for discussions from some leaders in Medellin.
Mr. Galan's murder came three weeks before President Bush unveiled his Adminstration's drug policy. Anger over the assassination is partly credited with prompting the American aid that is suddenly pouring into this Andean country.
As recently as 15 years ago, American anti-narcotics aid amounted to $45,000 - some jeeps and some handcuffs. Days after the August 18 assassination, President Bush ordered $65 million in emergency aid to Colombia.
The Bush Administration's anti-drug plan contains an ''Andean strategy'' that calls for increased economic and military aid for Colombia, Peru and Bolivia in addition to the $65 million.
Pete Williams, a Pentagon spokesman, said last week that for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 the Bush plan specifically calls for $90 million in military and economic aid for Colombia, $97.5 million for Bolivia and $73.4 million for Peru. In those three countries, officials said, there now were 50 to 100 American military officers, but that number is expected to grow.
Responding to Colombian and American officials who have complained that the United States has sent military equipment that was not appropriate for fighting drug traffickers, Mr. Williams said: ''We have to best match their needs with what we are limited by law to offer from existing stocks. We believe that the aid that we have offered is appropriate to the circumstances.'' Public's Attitude Shifts To Favor Extradition Some narcotics experts believe that the traffickers have lost some credibility by not following through on threats to wage war on the Government or to kill 10 judges for every Colombian extradited to the United States.
''One good symptom was that the reaction to the first extradition was not as strong as we expected,'' a presidential aide said cautiously.
The traffickers have won few friends with their policy of terrorism. A recent opinion poll indicated that attitudes towards extradition have reversed since March. Six months ago, 63 percent of Colombians polled opposed sending their countrymen to face trial in American courts. In late August, 77 percent of those polled by the newspaper El Tiempo backed extradition.
The traffickers have singled out congress and the courts for bribes or intimidation. Last week, the House of Representatives gave a cold shoulder to President Barco's Cabinet when they arrived at the chamber to brief legislators on the drug war.
In coming weeks, the Supreme Court will be the scene of next battle. By October, the court must rule on the constitutionality of Mr. Barco's decrees. If they are found to be unconstitutional, all property seized from drug dealers since Aug. 18 must be returned.
''If the court strikes down the decrees as unconstitutional, it will be a victory for the mafia and a terrible embarassment for Colombia,'' said Luis Ricardo Paredes, a Harvard-trained Colombian lawyer. ''On the other hand, if they don't strike them down, they are dead people.'' In recent years, the traffickers have killed about a dozen Supreme Court judges. Top 12 Traffickers Remain at Large Four weeks after the crackdown began, the top 12 traffickers wanted for trial in the United States are still at large. ''I think they had hideouts prepared for a long time and are in Colombia,'' Mr. Gugliotta said.
During past crackdowns, the traffickers have turned to Colombia's guerrilla groups to rent extra firepower. In 1985, the traffickers are believed to have hired the M-19 group. Eleven Supreme Court justices died during M-19's seizure of the court that year. But the M-19, which is about to conclude a peace agreement with the Government, is no longer for hire.
Colombia's largest group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, is feuding with the traffickers. In the last four years, paramilitary squads organized by the traffickers are believed to have murdered 750 members of this guerrilla group's political wing.
Of five left-wing guerrilla armies in Colombia, only one, the National Liberation Army, is not conducting peace talks with the Government. ''The word is out that the narcs have said to the E.L.N.: 'Name your price,' '' the European diplomat said, using the Spanish initials of the National Liberation Army.
Last Thursday, the army reported the arrest in Medellin of 28 members of the National Liberation Army ''who worked in the service of drug traffickers.''

HEADLINE: Low Levels of Asbestos Fibers Pose Few Risks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report on the fears in New York City's Gramercy Park neighborhood in the wake of a Consolidated Edison steam-pipe explosion that released mud containing ''high levels of potentially cancer-causing asbestos'' (news article, Aug. 28). Indeed the fear is there, as evidenced by the responses of Con Edison and the residents of the apartment buildings on Gramercy Park. Unfortunately, scientific-medical journals filled with up-to-date articles clearly showing the lack of adverse health effects of low-level exposure to asbestos fibers, especially chrysotile, are being ignored. With our constantly increasing knowledge of asbestos, it is shameful that these people must suffer unnecessary anxiety.
The fear that a few asbestos fibers are deadly or cancer producing is unwarranted, and wholly unsupported by current evidence. The information is readily available for anyone in recent issues of The New England Journal of Medicine, The American Journal of Industrial Medicine, The British Journal of Industrial Medicine, Chest, Journal of Occupational Medicine and others.
All can be obtained at any of New York's medical centers (New York University, Columbia, Albert Einstein, Mount Sinai), as well as the New York Academy of Medicine (one of the finest libraries in the country); and the articles are about as difficult to read as The New York Times.
Of course, part of the blame for the fear must be assumed by the news media, which continue to purvey the nonsense that low levels of airborne fibers are deadly. This erroneous message is needlessly exacting a frightful toll, both mental and economic.
 
MELVIN A. BENARDE
 Philadelphia, Aug. 29, 1989
The writer is professor and associate director of Temple University's Asbestos Abatement Center, Region III.

HEADLINE: Campaign Matters;
Victory Recipe: Labor, Resolve And a Rainbow

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Are New Yorkers better off now than when Edward I. Koch was first elected Mayor?
''Even if it's better, their expectation level has gone up,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo replied last spring. ''I don't think you're going to find many people who say, 'I'm not better off, but the city as a whole is.' My mother would say she doesn't remember this kind of violence. But she likes Koch.'' After months of measuring the alternatives, voters delivered the Democratic mayoral nomination to David N. Dinkins last week. How did Mr. Dinkins win? It was his turn. His very candidacy cleared the potential field of several fellow progressives. Organized labor provided troops and helped stretch campaign spending ceilings. He confounded skeptics by passing every political test to emerge as the antiKoch. His coalition included Hispanic voters who, Herbert J. Gans, a Columbia University sociology professor, said, ''finally decided economic or class interest was more important than their political competition with blacks.'' Did Mr. Dinkins make mistakes? No fatal ones. He handed Mr. Koch nearly two months of unrebutted television time to re-define himself. He never directly addressed fears of some whites about voting for a black. Nor did he make the bold gestures about crime that might have more dramatically cast him in the mainstream to which he now stakes a claim. That he briefly mulled revising the law barring strikes by public employees fueled fears that he was a captive of labor. 
His shortcomings were only gingerly exploited by Mr. Koch, who could not afford to remind voters of his reputation for racial insensitivity. But it's arguable whether Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican candidate, or his surrogates, can defeat Mr. Dinkins without first deflating him.
How was he able to woo a record proportion of whites?
For some, the first priority was to unseat Mr. Koch. Moreover, Manhattanites were already accustomed to seeing Mr. Dinkins's name on the ballot. When he was finally elected borough president in 1985, he was the first black who had not first served in the post by interim appointment. Were those the only reasons he won? No. Winning campaigns need a credible rationale. In 1965, John V. Lindsay promised the dynamic leadership his predecessor lacked; Abraham D. Beame, stability after the go-go Lindsay years; Mr. Koch, the verve to revive the city. Implicit in Mr. Koch's message was ''give me a chance to do in a fourth term what I couldn't accomplish in three'' and ''my rivals are worse than me.'' Mr. Dinkins represented an appealing salve. He campaigned in character as a man of quiet resolve. ''You won it the way you lived,'' Mr. Cuomo told him. So it's going to be Mayor Dinkins, right? Not so fast. Bringing the city together will be more a consequence of Mr. Dinkins's ability to govern, which, as it was for Mr. Koch in 1977, is largely untested, as of his ability to make many New Yorkers feel good about themselves and their city. He recognizes the need to court a broader constituency - including Mr. Koch - than the seemingly narrow rainbow of Democrats in whose glow he basked on primary night. What is Mr. Giuliani's rationale? His reputation as a crime fighter, vigorous innovator and even newer broom than Mr. Dinkins. That he is an enrolled Republican is tempered by his Liberal Party nomination and by relentless criticism from Ronald S. Lauder, the Conservative candidate, that Mr. Giuliani is a nominal Republican, but a real liberal. And Mr. Giuliani's baggage? His evolving public posture on abortion, his ties to the Reagan Administration and a reputation for political opportunism and zealotry that he has not effectively dispelled. ''You don't have to be mean to be strong,'' Mr. Dinkins might say. While Mr. Giuliani is a political neophyte - and no one has become mayor of New York in 95 years without having held prior elective office - the major difference between his mentors and Mr. Dinkins's political sponsors is that the Democrats hold power and the Republicans and Liberals want to. Since 1965, though, no Republican mayoral candidate has received more than half the 34 percent Mr. Lindsay polled that year on the Republican line.
So, for whom did Mr. Cuomo's 87-year-old mother, who favors the death penalty, vote?
She refuses to say that she stuck with Mr. Koch and it's believed that she voted for Mr. Dinkins. She has reserved decision about November, but is said to be skeptical of Mr. Giuliani.

LENGTH: 1459 words

HEADLINE: Voters Facing Stark Choice In New Jersey

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Seven weeks before New Jersey elects a new governor, voters are being confronted with a stark choice on whom they wish to succeed Gov. Thomas H. Kean in a state that was once solidly Democratic but whose heart was won over by Republicans during the Reagan revolution in the 1980's.
With only one other statewide race in the nation this year, Republicans here and in Washington are wagering that New Jerseyans will choose Representative Jim Courter, an advocate of small government, the free market and unabashedly conservative views on social issues.
Supporters of the Democratic candidate, Representative James J. Florio, argue that after eight years of Republican rule in Trenton, voters want to reinvigorate government for an assault on environmental hazards, overdevelopment, urban ills and an automobile insurance system that has left drivers here with the highest premiums in the nation.
 
Widely Different Philosophies
But such serious philosophical differences have so far been obscured by a rat-a-tat assault of negative images fired by the two sides and by growing questions on the competence of Mr. Courter's campaign, which stumbled through the summer and seemed last week to be sputtering out of control. 
''I cannot think of a campaign where the political philosophies of the candidates have been as different,'' said Richard W. Roper, director of the Program for New Jersey Affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University. ''Jim Florio believes that government has a role to play in improving the life of people in need. Jim Courter believes that market forces will cure the problems that beset us.''
The outcome of the New Jersey race is of particular interest to both national parties because it was in New Jersey, a state dominated by voters who had been loyal to the Democratic Party since the New Deal, that the Republicans scored five stunning victories in the 1980's, starting with Ronald Reagan's defeat of Jimmy Carter in 1980 and Mr. Kean's narrow victory over Mr. Florio in 1981.
While voters favored the Democratic Party by 31 percent to 22 percent in 1980 and 1981, voter preferences are nearly equal today, according to studies by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. Mr. Reagan won re-election by a 60 percent majority in the state in 1984, and Mr. Kean won re-election in 1985 by a 70 percent majority, including estimates that a majority of black voters had supported him. President Bush won in New Jersey last year with 57 percent of the vote.
 
Kean May Be a Model
Yet this election may disclose exactly what it was that voters embraced in the Reagan and Kean administrations. Although voters were plainly dissatisfied with economic stagnation and high taxes during the Democratic administrations of President Carter and Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, polls showed that they were not necessarily opposed to the social changes of the 1960's and 1970's.
Moreover, recent studies by the Eagleton Institute show growing dissatisfaction with some of the fruits of unregulated economic boom in the nation's most densely populated state. Many citizens have grown enraged at traffic snarls on their highways and have come to regard environmental protection no longer as an issue put forward by liberals, but as a goal as universally accepted as patriotism.
Since he defeated Mr. Florio by fewer than 1,800 votes in 1981, Governor Kean has practiced an eclectic type of politics that many politicians say has resonated almost perfectly with the sentiments of the era. Although he has championed free-market economics, he also has spoken out forcefully on environmental issues and on behalf of minorities and has hewed a quiet, modest line on social issues like abortion and homosexual rights. Both candidates this year portray themselves as Mr. Kean's logical successor.
 
Courter Looks to Business
Mr. Courter, a six-term Congressman from Warren County, argues that a key to success in governing New Jersey is a continuation of the state's remarkable economic growth over the last six years.
As governor, he said, he would fight to avoid tax increases, limit government growth and maintain New Jersey as an attractive state for businesses. Mr. Courter says the answers to some of the state's most vexing problems can be found in further growth and competition in the marketplace.
To control automobile insurance premiums, which now average $1,000 a car each year, Mr. Courter has proposed deregulating the industry to permit competition, which he says would force down rates. As for rising property taxes, another vexing issue for voters, Mr. Courter proposes a cap on state spending and turning over rising revenues from growth in the economy to municipalities for property tax relief.
Although some of his positions, including his insurance plan, are at odds with Mr. Kean's policies, Mr. Kean has enthusiastically endorsed Mr. Courter.
''He lit the way,'' Mr. Courter said of the incumbent governor. ''He showed us the path. All we have to do is follow that path.''
 
Florio Relies on Government
Mr. Florio, who has served in Congress since 1975 and is the author of the 1980 Superfund legislation to clean up the environment, says he would use state government more aggressively than the Republicans.
He has promised to create a new prosecutor to enforce environmental laws, involve business in the ills of the inner cities and impose stricter regulation of the insurance industry.
''I feel the Department of Insurance should be a state watchdog for the people, not a lap dog,'' Mr. Florio said. ''My opponent wants to take the watchdog out and put a bullet in its head.''
Since their primary victories last June, the two candidates have stumped the state, painting portraits of their opponents as unlikable, unethical and out of step with the centrist inclinations of most people in the state.
Mr. Courter, following a strategy initially mapped by the Washington political consultant Roger Stone, has attempted to portray Mr. Florio as ''corrupt,'' by pointing to improprieties of his allies in Camden County, and as a ''liberal,'' for not supporting a new, stronger death-penalty law.
Mr. Florio has responded by pointing to his opponent's membership in a fraternity that excluded blacks in college, his ownership of a land development project for which he is being sued and his ownership of stocks in defense industry companies while he was a member of the House Armed Services Committee. Mr. Florio hopes that voters will see Mr. Courter as a man of ''situational ethics,'' who believes in little besides his own self-interest.
 
Dissension in G.O.P. Camp
Last week Republican leaders, including Governor Kean, grew highly anxious at divisions within the Courter campaign, which have pitted Washington-based conservative Republicans close to Mr. Courter against more moderate Republicans based in Trenton and supported by Mr. Kean. Kean aides have shuddered at what they consider Mr. Courter's fumbling of major issues.
Mr. Courter, a supporter of the anti-abortion movement, took several days to respond to the Supreme Court decision on abortion this summer. When he announced that as governor he would not ''simply pose my personal views on the women of New Jersey,'' both supporters and opponents of abortion attacked this as vacillation.
When Mr. Florio attacked Mr. Courter earlier this month for a land deal he was involved with, the Courter campaign responded with three different, somewhat contradictory explanations. And on three occasions in three weeks, Mr. Courter appeared to change his original position that he would ban homosexuals for jobs as teachers, camp counselors and foster parents.
On Wednesday night Mr. Kean met with Mr. Courter and reportedly convinced him to dismiss his campaign manager and press secretary and replace them with Kean stalwarts. But the next morning the Kean choice for campaign manager, Roger A. Bodman, a former labor commissioner, said he would not take the position and left the state. Ensuing rumors left campaign workers demoralized.
''We have had problems,'' said Ken Connolly, the Courter campaign manager whose dismissal Mr. Kean had urged. ''But we are going to show over the next seven weeks and two days that we are not demoralized and that we are not disorganized.''
 
Courter Spokesman Resigns
NEWARK, Sept. 17 (AP) - Gordon Hensley, the chief campaign spokesman for Mr. Courter, resigned today.
Mr. Hensley said in resigning, ''Because of recent events involving differences between myself and Kean administration officials, I have concluded that I can no longer serve in my capacity as chief spokesman for the Courter for Governor campaign.''

United's employees and unions will have the final say over major decisions and strategy at UAL, the airline's parent, under the terms of their buyout, the head of the pilots' union says. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Worries May Emerge On Inflation

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
After receding for much of the summer, worries about inflation could well re-emerge this fall, credit market analysts said.
Aided by falling energy and food prices, producer prices, which galloped along at a 9 percent annual rate in the first few months of the year, have eased considerably since then. With the report of a drop of four-tenths of a percentage point in August, producer prices have advanced at a 4.4 percent clip so far this year.
The overall report seemed good, but economists expressed concern over a bigger-than-expected rise of half a percentage point in the price index once food and energy are excluded. The fact that oil prices have moved higher since the start of September, and are once again hovering around $20 a barrel, made last month's upward move in the ''core'' inflation rate a bit more disturbing. 
 
Not an Immediate Concern
''Right now the bond market is not concerned about inflation,'' said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''But with oil at around $20 and core inflation rising, that may not be the case two months from now. Those worries could, over that time span, push long-term interest rates higher.''
Maria Fiorini Ramirez, a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said, ''Unless there is some surprising event that has a positive impact on food and energy prices in the coming months, it seems that the best of the inflation news for the year is behind us, and not ahead.''
That view may not be literally correct, because most analysts are expecting that tomorrow's report on consumer price inflation in August will show another relatively benign increase. 0.2% Price Report Expected Bruce Vertes, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., is forecasting that consumer prices rose by two-tenths of a percent last month, keeping to a pace that began in June. Even with the summerlong moderation, consumer prices through July have risen at a 5.5 percent annual rate.
Although Mr. Vertes said the firm did not expect longer-term acceleration in prices, he writes in the firm's weekly ''Comments on Credit'' that beginning in September there will be seasonal increases ''in apparel prices and higher prices accompanying the introduction of 1990 car and truck lines.''
From a practical short-term perspective, the August increase in producer prices is likely to restrain the Federal Reserve from easing short-term credit conditions further, analysts said.
''There seems to be no basis for a decline of note in interest rates over the next few weeks,'' said Robert M. Giordano, a partner and co-director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
 
Effect of 'Junk' Bonds
Aside from monitoring new reports on the economy and inflation, this week's activity in the market for Government securities is apt to be responsive to developments in the high-yield ''junk'' bond market.
Problems with a number of high-yield issues, especially Allied Stores and Federated Department Stores, two big subsidiaries of the troubled Campeau Corporation, prompted near-panic selling in the high-yield market and a subsequent decline in short-term Treasury yields, as investors sought haven in high-quality securities.
Campeau's problems may continue to reverberate through the high-yield market, particularly if recent developments persuade investors in high-yield mutual funds to sell shares.
But market participants said that the recent sell-off has been so large that professionals are likely to start buying selected issues again soon, perhaps this week.
 
'Interest in Distressed Credits'
''We are seeing more interest in distressed credits than at any time in the past,'' said Robert Long, head of the high-yield research department at the First Boston Corporation. ''We think that investors will start bottom-fishing and buying the market in general.''
Indeed, yields on most junk issues have risen to dizzying, almost record levels. By the end of last week the spread, or difference, between 10-year Treasury notes, which were offered at a price to yield 8.07 percent, and First Boston's index of 280 high-yield issues was just over 6 percentage points.
''The only time the spread has been wider was in 1986, when it got to 6.17 percentage points after Ivan Boesky was indicted,'' Mr. Long said. ''I think we will get a rally.''
In the more tranquil world of high-grade investment issues, activity this week will be highlighted by a $1.5 billion ''global bond'' offering of intermediate-term securities from the World Bank.
 
A World Issue
Befitting its name, the AAA-rated institution will for the first time be issuing the securities simultaneously in the United States and Eurobond markets. The issue is intended to be traded around the clock. As such, it will offer investors better liquidity than outstanding World Bank issues that are traded in the United States or Euromarkets alone.
The move to a globally offered issue underscores the degree of integration that has been realized in world financial markets. But the bank's offering, the first of many, is not likely to be repeated by a slew of other borrowers.
''There are only a handful of large international companies or governments that could do this,'' said William Michaelcheck, a senior managing director at Bear, Stearns & Company and a former World Bank executive. ''Companies like I.B.M. and Citibank could do it, as could a Government agency like Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae. It creates a security which has a worldwide trading market. By definition, that makes it a more valuable security.''

HEADLINE: Effect of I.R.A.'s on Savings

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
A Congressional study indicates that the nation's savings rate fell sharply after Congress slashed tax deductions for most individual retirement accounts in 1986.
The study, prepared by an economist for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, was released Saturday by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Mr. Bentsen, who has called for restoring partial tax deductions on contributions to I.R.A.'s instead of cutting the capital gains tax, said the study shows their effectiveness in promoting savings. 
''Now if we're going to be less dependent on foreign investment and foreign loaning of money to us, then we have to increase the savings rate in this country,'' Mr. Bentsen said.
Mr. Bentsen said the study found that after I.R.A.'s were severely curtailed by cutting back on the tax deductions, ''savings rates dropped substantially in this country - and they were already low - and that in addition the I.R.A.'s themselves were cut almost in half.''
The study said the personal savings rate averaged 5.3 percent of disposable income from 1982-86 and has averaged 3.7 percent since then. The rate fell to 3.2 percent in 1987 and 1988, the lowest in 40 years, the study said. Savers contributed $38 billion to I.R.A.'s in 1986, but the amount fell to almost half that the following year, the study said.
Mr. Bentsen has proposed a deduction of at least 50 percent for all I.R.A. accounts. His plan would allow the withdrawal of I.R.A. funds without penalty at the time of retirement, for a down payment on the purchase of a first home or to finance college costs.

HEADLINE: JAPANESE MAKING BIGGEST DEAL YET WITH A U.S. BANK

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The world's biggest bank, the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, announced plans yesterday to buy control of a unit of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and a portion of the bank's stock.
The investment, totaling $1.4 billion, is the largest yet by a Japanese bank in an American financial company.
The financing will help Manufacturers Hanover to strengthen its financial condition significantly. The New York bank, which is the nation's seventh-largest and has been troubled by its heavy investment in loans to developing countries, also announced that it would add $950 million to its reserves for losses on loans to those countries.
For its money, Dai-Ichi will get 60 percent control of the CIT Group, a finance company with 50 offices around the country. A small portion, about $120 million, of the Japanese bank's investment will go to buy new Manufacturers Hanover stock that will equal about 4.9 percent of all shares outstanding. Dai-Ichi has promised not to increase that holding for 10 years. 
 
Extensive Arrangement
Manufacturers Hanover is the first American banking company to make such an extensive arrangement with a Japanese company. Although several other Japanese insurance and securities concerns have invested in American companies, their purchases have been smaller than that of Dai-Ichi and have not given the Japanese control of such a large company as CIT, which currently has about $10 billion of loans and other assets.
The lending of funds and the financing of equipment leases for medium-sized American companies, which is CIT's business, are among the most profitable parts of the American financial market, and one that Japanese companies have been eager to enter because they can charge higher interest rates.
''Looking at what happened first with automobiles and VCR's, and later with Treasury bonds and real estate, more Japanese investment in American banking is not surprising,'' said James K. McDermott, a banking analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a New York securities firm specializing in bank stocks. ''But I expect that the investments will have more of an evolutionary than a revolutionary flavor, and we are not going to see a wave of Japanese takeovers of American banks.''
The Japanese bank will spend $1.28 billion to buy the 60 percent of CIT, which Manufacturers Hanover acquired from the RCA Corporation in 1985 for $1.5 billion. Because Manufacturers Hanover continues to hold 40 percent of CIT, the two banking companies expect to cooperate in referring customers to CIT.
The sale of control of CIT was part of a four-pronged move by Manufacturers Hanover to strengthen its financial condition. For several years, the bank has been criticized for having too little capital relative to its size and for losses it might face from its $6.8 billion in loans to developing countries.
In addition to the CIT sale, the placement of $120 million of the new stock with Dai-Ichi, and the addition of the $950 million to its loan-loss reserve, Manufacturers Hanover announced yesterday plans to sell another $500 million of common stock by the year's end in a public offering.
 
Quarter Loss of $775 Million
By adding to the loan-loss reserve, John F. McGillicuddy, the chairman of Manufacturers Hanover, said the bank will take a loss in the third quarter of about $775 million, and $475 million for the entire year.
Japanese banks have been active for several years in lending to the world's largest corporations, where profit margins are very thin. But they have had trouble generating business among the smaller companies that pay the higher interest rates.
Albert R. Gamper Jr., CIT's chief executive, said profits could improve following the change of control because the company might expand rapidly in the leasing business. He added that leasing activity was not great under Manufacturers Hanover because the American bank did not need the tax benefits it produced.
Yuko Oana, senior managing director of Dai-Ichi, said there would be no change in the current management of CIT.
 
Daiwa to Buy Lloyds Offices
In another sign of the eagerness of Japanese banks to become lenders to medium-sized businesses, Daiwa Bank Ltd. yesterday agreed to buy the American middle-market lending business of Lloyds Bank P.L.C. for $200 million, plus the $1.46 billion value of the loans accumulated by Lloyds through its network of 15 American offices. Lloyds said that last year the middle-market lending business produced profits of about $11 million, but was not as profitable as it would have liked.
Other recent forays by Japanese companies into the American lending market include the Mitsui Bank's purchase for $100 million earlier this summer of a 5 percent stake in the consumer and commercial credit operations of the Los Angeles-based Security Pacific Corportion. In 1984, the Fuji Bank paid $425 million to buy control of Heller International, a commercial finance company like CIT.
After setting aside the additional funds as a reserve and swallowing the loss, Manufacturers Hanover will have reserves for about 36 percent of its loans to the developing countries, up from 22 percent. At 36 percent, its reserve will be roughly in line with reserves kept by other large New York banks.
In addition, the bank will have equity capital - the shareholder money that serves as a cushion against bad times and is available to finance expansion - equal to about 5.1 percent of assets, also nearer the average of other large banks. After the bank completes its sale of new stock and sells control of CIT, Manufacturers Hanover's capital, adjusted for risk according to a formula set by Federal regulators, will equal 10 percent of its assets, higher than the 8 percent minimum to be imposed in 1992.
 
Mexican Negotiations Cited
Mr. McGillicuddy said results of Mexican debt negotiations suggested that it would be wise to set aside more funds for possible losses. Under the agreement worked out with Mexico to reorganize its debt, banks have the option of accepting a 35 percent reduction in the value of their loans, leading analysts to suggest that Manufacturers Hanover needed a larger reserve for loan losses. Federal regulators did not suggest an increase in the reserves, he added.
Apart from the third-quarter loss from the addition to reserves, Mr. McGillicuddy said, profits from the remaining parts of the company should continue to rise this year.
Last year Manufacturers Hanover sold its consumer finance and investment advisory units, and the sale now of control of CIT leaves the corporation with two remaining business groups. These are a regional banking operation in New York, for consumers and small and medium-sized businesses, and its global banking group, which arranges wholesale type financings for large corporations. Among American banks, Manufacturers Hanover is one of the most active in lending for corporate take-overs.
 
Approach Made Last Winter
Mr. McGillicuddy said Manufacturers Hanover first approached Dai-Ichi with the CIT offer late last winter after he read ''press reports that they were eager to expand into the asset-based business finance market.'' When Dai-Ichi executives described what they were looking for, he added, ''it sounded to us like they were reading from the CIT annual report.''
Investment bankers from Goldman, Sachs & Company made the overtures to Dai-Ichi officials, Mr. McGillicuddy said, ''and we danced around the maypole until about the middle of July.'' Last week, Manufacturers Hanover confirmed that serious discussions were under way.
''We wouldn't have sold CIT except for the fact that we are trying to raise capital,'' Mr. McGillicuddy said. In addition to putting the bank into compliance with bank standards set for 1992, he said, the latest actions might encourage rating agencies to raise Manufacturers Hanover's ratings, which would enable it to borrow at lower interest rates. In recent years, Manufacturers Hanover has operated at a disadvantage to other banks because its weak capital position required it to pay slightly higher rates for borrowed funds than other large American banks.
 
Debt Ratings Affirmed
The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday affirmed Manufacturers Hanover's BBB- senior debt, BBB subordinated debt, BB-plus preferred stock and A-2 commercial paper ratings and also said it might upgrade $8 billion of CIT debt ratings.
Although Mr. McGillicuddy said CIT would not have been sold except for the need to raise additional capital, he contended that the company's earning potential had not been weakened. Besides retaining a 40 percent share of CIT, which will continue to distribute half its profits to its owners, Manufactures Hanover benefits because the sale removes $10 billion of assets from its balance sheet.
Manufacturers Hanover stock rose 87.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $41.75. Last week, when traders first learned of plans to sell control of CIT, the stock rose $2.875 to $42.50. Yesterday's announcement was made after the market closed.
''Manufacturers Hanover has done itself a great favor by squarely addressing its need for more capital,'' said Robert B. Albertson, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs.
Analysts said it would be premature to assume that other banks would follow Manufacturers Hanover in adding to their loan-loss reserves.
 
Japanese Not Aggressive
Mr. Albertson said Japanese banks had not been aggressive buyers into American banks ''because they have plenty of developments in their home market to keep them occupied.'' Besides keeping a wary eye on outside banks like Citibank, which is eager to expand its branch network in Japan, the Japanese banks are in a highly competitive market for consumer loan and deposit products, and are considering ways to expand into the business of distributing stocks and bonds.
Manufacturers Hanover is not the only American bank to seek fresh capital from Japan. In a separate announcement yesterday, the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., announced plans to sell five million shares of common stock to Japanese investors, at $51 a share. It was the second offering in the Japanese market for NCNB, which sold four million shares for $100 million in 1987. Since then, the North Carolina bank's stock price has improved sharply as its earnings rose after a Government-assisted acquisition of the First Republic Bank, once the largest bank in Texas.

HEADLINE: Hungary Restores Ties With Israel

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Hungary today became the first Communist country to restore full diplomatic relations with Israel after having broken them over the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.
The move, which followed a recent warming between Budapest and Jerusalem, was announced at a brief ceremony by Foreign Ministers Moshe Arens of Israel and Gyula Horn of Hungary. Mr. Arens flew here this morning, signed the joint protocol, called briefly on Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth and returned to Israel.
In a brief interview, he said the decision had been reached only two days ago. ''I feel very good about it,'' he said. ''It's a historic occasion.'' Business Accord in the Works In another initiative in redirecting its foreign policy toward closer links with the West, Hungary announced today, jointly with the United States, that the two countries would negotiate ''a comprehensive business and economic agreement.'' 
This move was announced by Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher at a news conference with Trade Minister Tamas Beck. Mr. Mosbacher arrived Sunday night on a two-day visit.
The two steps followed Hungary's action last week opening its border with Austria to East Germans seeking to emigrate to West Germany, against East Berlin's wishes.
That direct defiance of its Warsaw Pact ally East Germany, with whom relations have sunk to their lowest point ever, is seen by Hungarians and foreign diplomats as a watershed in Hungary's rapidly growing assertion of a more independent, West-oriented foreign policy. #14,000 East Germans Flee About 14,000 East Germans have crossed into Austria and continued to West Germany since last Monday, and the border remains open, although the outpouring has slowed markedly.
Until today, Rumania was the only Warsaw Pact member that maintained full diplomatic relations with Israel. It defied the Soviet Union and refused to break ties with Israel in 1967. Poland and Hungary resumed limited diplomatic relations with Israel two years ago, when missions below embassy status were opened in Warsaw, Budapest and Tel Aviv.
A de facto relationship, with an exchange of consular delegations, has also brought the Soviet Union and Israel closer. Mr. Arens expressed hope that these ties, too, would soon be raised to full diplomatic level.
The Israeli Foreign Minister said Hungary expected that Israel would help expand its economic links to the West. He said this was based on ''a realistic evaluation that Israel has some very good contacts with top business people in the world.''
 
Setting Itself Apart
The new relationship with Israel is the second established by Hungary in one year that sets its apart from the Communist world. Last September it became the first Communist country to exchange diplomatic missions with South Korea. This year they were raised to embassy rank.
The proposed comprehensive business and economic agreement was described by Mosbacher aides as an American idea that the Commerce Secretary proposed to Mr. Beck today and found readily accepted. Negotiations will get under way before the end of the year, the aides said.
The idea was devised by the United States to meet the conditions of a Communist country that is seeking to transform its centralized economy by creating a significant private sector.
Ambassador Mark Palmer said at a news conference that American investment in Hungary amounted to half the total Western investment of about $300 million. He contrasted the relatively small Western private-capital flow with Hungary's high indebtedness to the West - $17 billion.
 
FAVORED STATUS FOR BUDAPEST
HELENA, Mont., Sept. 18 (Special to The New York Times) - President Bush said today that he would grant permanent most-favored-nation trading status to Hungary starting next month, as well as free duties on some products.
The Administration said Hungary, which had been getting annual waivers to receive most-favored-nation benefits for the last several years, would become the first country in Eastern Europe to get the reduced tariffs on a continuous basis.
At a news conference here, Mr. Bush said the United States was not yet ready to grant preferred trading status to the Soviet Union, despite the Kremlin's policy of letting more Soviet Jews emigrate.
''There are encouraging signs coming out of the Soviet Union and we're going to continue to look at them closely,'' Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Bush said the shift in trade status was ''in the mix'' before the Hungarian Government allowed East German refugees to go through Hungary to the West.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin in U.S.: Pravda's Ugly Profile

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The visit to America of Boris N. Yeltsin, the critic of the Kremlin, was depicted at length today in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda as a vulgar spree by a hard-drinking demagogue.
After ignoring Mr. Yeltsin's eight-day visit until now, Pravda signaled the party's sensitivity to his overseas popularity by publishing a long, mocking attack on his behavior and character reprinted from La Repubblica, the Italian newspaper.
With scanty direct attribution, the article said Mr. Yeltsin had greeted an unidentified faculty member at one speaking stop, Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, with ''a slobbering drunken kiss and a half-empty bottle of whisky.''
''He leaves behind in his tracks predictions of Soviet catastrophes, crazy spending, interviews and the particular smell of the famous Jack Daniels Kentucky whisky,'' the correspondent, Vittorio Zucconi, reported in the article reprinted in Pravda. 
 
Ousted From Party Job
Mr. Yeltsin, who just completed his eight-day visit to the United States, was ousted as Moscow Communist Party leader in 1987 after making a speech complaining about the slow pace of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic changes. He ran for the new Congress of People's Deputies in the election in March, collecting almost 90 percent of the vote for a citywide seat, and since then has been chosen a leader of the Soviet Union's first independent parliamentary caucus.
In the article, Mr. Zucconi claimed to have ascertained that Mr. Yeltsin, during his trip, consumed two bottles of vodka, four bottles of whisky and an incalculable number of cocktails at official receptions while often staying awake much of the night and drinking alone in his hotel room.
The correspondent offered no indication of his sources in the article. It was widely read and discussed by Soviet citizens who asked Western friends whether it could be true. [Mr. Zucconi said in Washington that his material had come from an article in The Washington Post, from people in the Russian emigre community in Washington and from other sources.] ''For Yeltsin, America was a feast day, a theater stage, a bar 5,000 kilometers long,'' said the newspaper. ''For America, Yeltsin is a wonderful new toy, a doll with a typical Russian face that says things no Russian ever dared to say before.''
 
'It's Garbage,' Yeltsin Says
In the one accusation attributed by name, the correspondent contended that an accountant named Alfred Ross, supposedly employed by the Esalen Institute, sponsor of the Yeltsin visit, reported that Mr. Yeltsin was wasting speaking fees that he had publicly promised to give to Soviet AIDS victims. ''Put it on the account, on the account,'' Mr. Yeltsin was said to have shouted in department stores as he supposedly rushed about buying video recorders and clothes.
In the only other specific reference to an individual, the report said that Mr. Yeltsin, tired from drink and jet lag, fell asleep in front of Pamela Harriman, the widow of Averell Harriman, the former American Ambassador to the Soviet Union. She ''gave a motherly smile,'' according to the dispatch, as Mr. Yeltsin's head dropped ''right on the table.''
The article was published as Mr. Yeltsin was flying home to Moscow.
When he returned to Moscow, The Associated Press reported, he said, ''It's garbage.''
''It's a simple lie, slander, and revenge for the fact that Americans received us with admiration,'' A.P. quoted him as saying.
The 1,500-word article, reprinted without comment, was more significant as a public measure of the Communist hierarchy's deep displeasure with Mr. Yeltsin than as an account of his travels.
''Yeltsin brought carnal smells and the physical vigor of the homeland of Mother Russia to the corridors of American power,'' the report declared.
''He has everything he dreamed about - whisky, dollars, knickknacks and 'Rambo' videocassettes,'' the newspaper asserted, quoting him as surprising even Washingtonians who are ''used to seeing alcoholic senators and debauched deputies every day.''
 
Sponsor Denies Charges
The sponsor of Mr. Yeltsin's trip denied yesterday that the former Moscow party boss was ever drunk during the tour and said he was convinced that the Pravda's account was politically motivated.
''They are looking for some way to denigrate Mr. Yeltsin,'' said Jim Garrison, executive director of the Esalen Institute's Soviet American Exchange Program. ''He knew when he left that the knives would be out and sharpened for him when he got home. But he's a big boy. He can handle it.''
Pamela Harriman, who attended a lunch in Mr. Yeltsin's honor in New York last week, denied the report that he had fallen asleep in front of her. ''He was very much not asleep,'' she said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Garrison, who accompanied Mr. Yeltsin on his trip, said, ''There was no indication at any point along the way that he was drinking heavily.''
Mr. Garrison said that on one evening in Baltimore, Mr. Yeltsin and four members of his entourage went through a quart of Jack Daniels. ''For five grown men to go through a bottle of whisky, that is not heavy drinking,'' Mr. Garrison said. Mr. Garrison said that Mr. Yeltsin never set foot in a department store, although on his last stop, in Miami, he did dispatch an aide to buy gifts - mainly blue jeans and children's clothes -with money from the $100 per diem from the Esalen Institute. They were unable to find a video recorder suited for the Soviet Union, Mr. Garrison said.
He said Mr. Yeltsin's trip would result in at least $100,000 in donations to Soviet AIDS patients.

HEADLINE: Town Agonizes Over Dioxin Levels

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, S.C., Sept. 14

 BODY:
The paper industry was surprised a few years ago when a study showed that paper mills were producing toxic dioxin and releasing it into nearby rivers.
But when a follow-up survey of the nation's paper mills became public this year, nowhere was there more dismay than in this river town. The report by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said dioxin emissions from the giant International Paper Company plant into the murky Sampit River here were the highest of the 104 paper mills studied.
The median for the mills where dioxin was measurable was 0.024 parts per trillion. The International Paper plant here had readings as high as 0.640 parts per trillion. 
Despite steps that the company took to reduce emissions immediately, a combination of confusion and anger has resulted in a town where fishermen have been pulling their dinners from the Sampit River for years. And it left the community trying to grapple with one of the most emotional, but least defined, environmental issues. The Government, in fact, has no standards for the amount of dioxin that may be in effluents measured in the study.
 
Health Effect Is Uncertain
Dioxin, a long-lived byproduct of bleaching paper pulp, has been described as one of the most toxic substances known to man. But despite evidence that it causes cancer in laboratory animals, studies on humans have been inconclusive, and same scientists now say that dioxin, particularly at the levels commonly produced by paper mills and other industrial processes, poses less of a threat to human health than was first thought.
''Dioxin has become sort of a symbol for environmental contamination,'' said Michael Kamrin, an expert on dioxin at the Center for Environmental Toxicology at Michigan State University. ''But all you can say is we have tons of studies on animals, but we don't really have any good data on the effects on humans.''
That is little consolation to this town of more than 10,000 people.
''We're so used to apathy here, but what surprises me is how concerned everyone is about this,'' said Carol Winans, president of the League of Women Voters, who recently organized a forum on dioxin. ''Everywhere I go, it's what people want to talk about. I don't know which group of scientists is right, but why should I take the risk?''
The whole matter arose almost by accident in 1985 when scientists found unexpectedly high levels of dioxin near paper mills that bleach paper pulp with chlorine. Studies of five mills in 1986 and of 104 last year found all but a handful were producing dioxin and releasing it into rivers. But paper mills as a whole account for less than 1 percent of the nation's known production of dioxin; municipal waste incinerators account for 60 percent of the output, largely as a result of the burning of plastics.
National concerns were also raised recently about the presence of trace quantities of dioxin in milk cartons, but Federal officials said on Sept. 1 that there is no indication the dioxin in the cartons poses a health risk. Still, mills have taken steps to reduce the levels.
 
High Dioxin Levels in Fish
Of particular concern for the mills was the concentration of dioxin in fish in nearby rivers. In the Sampit, elevated levels of dioxin were found in fish, particularly white perch and catfish. The Federal Food and Drug Administration, in a warning about dioxin in the Great Lakes, warned residents of the region to reduce consumption of contaminated fish when the levels in them reach 25 to 50 parts per trillion and stop eating fish with levels above that.
White perch in the Sampit have been found to have levels as high as 49 parts per trillion. In June, South Carolina officials posted signs warning fishermen not to eat fish or shellfish from the river, and they have issued a milder warning for white perch, and catfish taken from nearby Winyah Bay.
Dr. Carl Schulz, a toxicologist at the University of South Carolina School of Public Health said that because so many poor people in the area get a sizable amount of their protein by eating fish from the river, the consumption here poses particular risks.
''I'm not a rabid environmentalist in a lot of ways,'' Dr. Schulz said, ''but I felt for this particular group of people in Georgetown, it's a very serious situation.''
Officials with the State Department of Health and Environmental Control are planning closer monitoring of fish and crabs in the Sampit and Winyah Bay to determine if further restrictions, like a ban on commercial fishing, are needed. Winyah Bay is a center for commercial fishing, and any restrictions there would cut further into the community's economic life. Some residents say commercial crabbers are still working the river and selling their wares.
 
Plant Reduces Emissions
Officials at the plant say they have cut dioxin emissions by 83 percent and plan to reduce them further. ''We appreciate the community's concerns,'' said the plant manager, Roger H. Purrington. ''We're not unfeeling; we live here, too. We feel really good about being able to move fast and get the reductions as quickly as we have.''
But critics say the reduction leaves dioxin production well above the average found in the study of 104 paper mills. And they say that since dioxin levels will remain high for years even if new production stops, the reduction is only slowing the rate of growth of the dioxin content.
The Sampit, a narrow muddy river lined with scrawny vegetation, has not been anything close to pristine for a long time. But in a region where fishing is as much a rite as a sport, the situation here, combined with mounting pollution problems on some other Southern rivers, at times evokes sadness as much as concern.
''There was a letter to the editor of the paper the other day that talked about coming down the Waccamaw River and feeling like you were in the Garden of Eden and then coming to the Sampit and finding the signs that the fish weren't safe to eat,'' James Chandler, an environmental lawyer, said as he steered a small boat along the Sampit. ''We've won some cases lately, and you think you're making some progress, then something like this comes along and you realize you didn't even know what the problem really was.''

GRAPHIC: Discharges from the International Paper Company plant in Georgetown, S.C., showed the highest level of dioxin contamination by 104 mills studied by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. (NYT/Wade Spees); map of Georgetown showing location of Sampit River (NYT)

PUB-DATE: September 19, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 442 words

HEADLINE: Hungary's Heart, and America's

 BODY:
Four months ago Hungary ripped a hole in the barbed wire in its section of the Iron Curtain. Now, more dramatically, it gives East Germans safe passage to the West. For that, Hungary deserves America's salute - and more. Yesterday's announcement that the Bush Administration hopes to grant Hungary new trade status is a timely step in the right direction. 
Many of the East Germans fleeing to the West are young skilled workers who went to Hungary on holiday visas issued by the East German Government. They encamped on Hungary's border with Austria, obviously hoping to go on to West Germany. After informing Moscow and Washington, Hungary let them go.
Their arrival in West Germany is reason to rejoice and reflect. In finding a new home they have also breached old boundaries, intellectual and geographic.
For one thing, the exodus challenges East Germany's faith in its own brand of socialism. Enfeebled, insecure, increasingly absorbed in a succession struggle, the East German regime believed its ''economic miracle'' would shelter it against political winds. Why deny some of its most efficient workers well-earned holidays?
The exodus also further undermines the notion of a monolithic East Bloc. When the vacationers took flight, East Germany attacked its ally for treaty violations. Hungary defended itself by invoking not the Warsaw Pact but the Helsinki accords. And when Hungary approached Moscow, it was reassured that letting the workers go was its own internal affair. Moscow's message to East Germany was clear, too: Get in tune with the times.
Finally, the exodus exposed contradictions in the recurrent German dream of reunification. West German employers hurried to the border to hire the new arrivals. But some West German workers expressed fears that their East German brethren would take away jobs.
Nor does the exodus begin the reunification of the German states. It is a reunion of German people - mostly going one way.
The economic attraction of the West has had much to do with the workers' flight and the Hungarians' solicitude. Yet Washington remains anxious about growing economic ties between Eastern and Western Europe, as if economic attraction drew Westerners eastward, not the other way around.
Offering negotiations that would make permanent Hungary's trading status as a most favored nation signals a welcome change in policy. But the Administration could do more, easing restrictions on some high-tech exports, underwriting more private investment and extending emergency refugee aid to Hungary.
The East German Government still yearns for the cold war. There's no cause for Washington to do the same.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Thanks, Boris, but No

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Americans who meet Boris Yeltsin in Moscow sometimes tell him it is a pity he is not American himself. They say he is so charming, so open and candid that he would win an election back home.
That seems to have gone straight to Mr. Yeltsin's heart. When he was in the United States last week, he treated Americans pretty much as American politicians often do - as if we were all a bunch of nincompoops. 
Mr. Yeltsin is a leader of the opposition to Mikhail Gorbachev within the party. It's easy to see why so many Russians love him. He is big and hale and says things they are still getting used to hearing about what a mess the Soviet Union is in.
But in speeches or talks with Americans around the country and to the Bush Administration, Mr. Yeltsin delivered a message that has not been matched for chutzpah since Jackie Mason first took a microphone in hand.
It had two parts: 1. The Soviet Union is in a state of crisis and after one year may fall right into the abyss. Things are much worse than you Americans know. You are much too euphoric about perestroika, which is not working. Mr. Gorbachev is an ineffective compromiser. 2. Therefore join us as we stand on the lip of the abyss, staring down, mired in this mess of Communist failure. Give us loans, credits, technology, build a million apartments for us, provide consumer goods, take the heat off us, and maybe we won't fall in. Hurry.
Mr. Yeltsin also divulged to President Bush, Secretary of State Baker and other officials here the details of the Revolutionary Yeltsin Plan for solving the debacle brought about by a state-controlled economy. If he had the chance to change it, he said, the Soviet economy would be just 85 to 90 percent state-owned and collective and fully 10 to 15 percent private!
Mr. Yeltsin seemed sure he would fascinate the Administration with his mixture of doomsday warnings, demands for help and continued statism.
I do not know whether he knows it because everybody was polite, but within the Bush-Quayle-Baker team, he went down like a lead pirogi.
The Administration wants Mr. Gorbachev and his perestroika to keep afloat because evil days certainly may be possible if he fails.
But the Administration also has healthy doubts that Communism can rescue Communism and no strong inclination yet to take big risks on that gamble.
The Administration's reaction to Mr. Yeltsin - thank you, but no - is particularly important because of the meeting later this week between the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, and Secretary of State Baker. To Europeans, Mr. Shevardnadze has been delivering the heart of the Yeltsin message: Things are getting much worse - help.
The Bush Administration expects him to say something like that to Mr. Baker when they meet in Wyoming this week. The Foreign Minister will get some advice - for instance, put freedom to emigrate into written law so Washington can legally give Moscow all trade advantages any other country gets. But if he is looking for major commitments, the weather in Wyoming may be cool in September, appropriately.
There is no evidence that Mr. Gorbachev's effort to save the Communist system by adjusting it will succeed and plenty that it will fail. If it does, people far worse than Mr. Gorbachev could take over.
But it could also happen that real freedom would come to the Soviet Union, the fruit of the wrenching effort of those who fought it from within and paid with years in cruel prison camps.
The victims and opponents of the Soviet system are the real heroes of their nation. The Yeltsins and the Gorbachevs climbed the Soviet ladder until they thought it was about to fall. Then they shouted alarm, which earns them credit and respect.
But think how much more is due to those who saw what the Yeltsins and Gorbachevs claim they did not until they got high up the ladder - the system was collapsing under its own tyrannical weight. For their wisdom, and in recognition of their years of pain, they deserve a chance for a share of political power and a clear voice heard in the West.
So far they have had little of either. They have ideas far different than Mr. Yeltsin's or Mr. Gorbachev's about how to help the Soviet people, not the Soviet apparatus, and when.
They have earned the right - as Solidarity had before it took office -to be heard in Washington. Only then can the United States make a rational decision on whether to bolster the present Soviet system or a new one that may emerge. Until then, thank you, but no.
