HEADLINE: Nuclear Dump Plan Ignites Rural Protests

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: ANGELICA, N.Y., Sept. 12

 BODY:
Federal Express made an unwelcome delivery the other day to Marilyn Ostrander's farm here in the lush green hills of Allegany County.
The package of brochures and technical information from Albany was sent by the New York State Low-Level Radioactive Waste Siting Commission. Mrs. Ostrander's land, a cover letter explained, was one place where the state was thinking of putting the waste.
''This is crazy,'' said Mrs. Ostrander, a retired teacher, clutching the letter that informed her and her husband, George, that officials would visit their 60-acre property this fall to inspect it and conduct tests. ''Here we are living in absolutely the most beautiful part of the earth. It's clean, it's pristine. Why in the world are they talking about bringing nuclear waste here? ''I think it's wicked. I think it's criminal.'' Two Finalists Picked Like virtually every other state, New York is searching for a dump site because it is under a Federal mandate to find a home by 1993 for low-level nuclear waste that is now shipped to South Carolina and Nevada. It is conducting a contest nobody wants to win. 
Last December Allegany County, in southwestern New York, learned that it was one of 10 counties under consideration. Last weekend it learned that it and Cortland County, near the Finger Lakes, were the two finalists. Fear was already prevalent here; now, with the state sending out letters like the one the Ostranders received, anger has set in.
People not usually given to protest have gathered in force. On Main Street in the village of Almond, nearly every house has a bright orange ''Posted! No Dumping'' sign in the window. On Monday hundreds of people went to a rally in the county seat of Belmont, recited the Pledge of Allegiance and then vowed to do everything they could to block the dump.
''We'll get arrested as often as we can,'' said Sally Campbell, a founder of the Allegany County Non-Violent Action Group.
''We'll throw ourselves in front of bulldozers,'' said Mary Gardner Smith, a day-care worker from Wellsville.
Some went further. ''I'd almost predict - it's a terrible term, I know - but I'd almost say there might be guerrilla warfare if they try to bring this thing in,'' said Larry Deis, a house painter from Almond.
 
No Waste of Its Own
The county, with about 50,000 people, produces no nuclear waste of its own. Almost all of it would come from the New York City area, 300 miles to the east, or from nuclear reactors in Oswego County, 150 miles to the north. Why send it here? State officials say it will come here or go to Cortland County because they best fit the geologic criteria set down in the 1986 law passed by the Legislature to establish a dump.
Low-level radioactive waste includes fluids, resins, tools, machine parts and clothes. It comes from reactors, hospitals and certain companies licensed to handle radioactive materials. Some of the waste that will go to the dump will lose its contamination within months; some will remain radioactive for hundreds of years.
The state expects to send about 100,000 cubic feet of waste a year to the dump, or the equivalent of four tractor-trailer loads a week. High-level radioactive waste, like spent fuel rods or coolant from reactors, will continue to be stored at the reactors for eventual shipment to a storage center the Federal Government is planning to build in Nevada.
 
Efforts in Other States
Every other state is going through a process similar to New York's to find a site for nuclear waste, and in many of them similar protests have greeted officials trying to site a dump.
Only three states - California, Texas and Illinois - have announced decisions on where they plan to put the waste, said Edward L. Helminski, publisher in Washington of The Radioactive Exchange, a newsletter that tracks the efforts. New Jersey and Connecticut have formed a compact to dispose of their waste jointly, but they have been locked in a dispute on which state to put it in; sites in both states are under consideration at present.
In New York, consultants who completed an 11-volume scientific survey cited, among other factors, low water permeability in the clay soil of Allegany and Cortland Counties and drainage patterns that would deter leaching, said Jay D. Dunkleberger, an engineer who is executive director of the state's waste siting commission.
Low population around the site is also required, although officials insist that the dump will be absolutely safe and pose no health risk to people living nearby.
 
Residents See Discrimination
Many Allegany County residents scoffed at the technical data and said there were simpler reasons behind the state's conclusions. ''I think it's because we're very rural, very low population and very far away from Albany,'' said Karen Lorrow, a waitress at Muhleisen's Fine Food and Cocktails in the town of Almond.
''And we're very poor,'' said Carol Muhleisen, the restaurant's owner. Of New York State's 62 counties, Allegany ranks 62d in per-capita income, according to the state's Department of Economic Development.
Some officials in New York said they hoped the waste could continue to be taken out of the state altogether.
''I think we can find a spot elsewhere in the country where somebody wants this stuff,'' said Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., the Republican leader in the State Assembly whose district includes the two Cortland County sites. Mr. Rappleyea said he had spoken with officials in towns in Illinois, Texas and Washington who had expressed interest in taking the waste as a moneymaking project.
There is nothing in the Federal law to prevent New York from shipping its waste to another state if that state is willing to accept it.
 
Out-of-State Solution Doubted
But Mr. Dunkleberger, the New York commission's executive director, said that while that remained a possible option, he believed it was ''highly unlikely'' another state would actually approve of such a plan, even if a community said it was willing to take the waste.
Last weekend the New York siting commission said it had narrowed its search to five areas, each roughly a mile square. Two in Cortland County are both in the town of Taylor. Here in Allegany County, there is a site in the town of Allen, where the Ostrander property extends; another in the towns of Allen and Caneadea, and a third in the town of West Almond.
While protests had been common enough in the last several months, they multiplied with the latest announcement.
 
Radium and Radishes Don't Mix
Richard and Marion Bagley, who live on Main Street in Almond, nailed an orange ''No Dumping'' sign to a tree in their front yard and put another one by their front door.
''We're not great protesters, but this has us really upset,'' Mrs. Bagley said.
''We've never really protested anything before,'' Mr. Bagley said, ''except when the creek overflowed here a few years back.''
In Cortland County, like Allegany a heavily agricultural area, hundreds of people have protested against the dump, with one official telling people at a rally that ''radium and radishes don't make good neighbors.''
Meanwhile, in eight other counties that had been on the commission's original list, there have been expressions of relief. Many of the groups formed to oppose the siting of a dump in their community have vowed to assist the groups that still have the problem on their hands.

HEADLINE: Bush, in a Visit to the West, Prods Congress About Key Bills

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELENA, Mont., Sept. 18

 BODY:
President Bush gave Congress a sharp elbow today, suggesting that it ''move fast'' on his legislation covering crime, drugs and the environment.
''I don't want to be hypercritical,'' Mr. Bush said at a news conference in the Senate chamber of the State Capitol here. ''But I must say there's a certain frustration level when you come out with a sound program and two answers come out: spend more and raise taxes.''
He added, ''I think we ought to try now to move some of these things forward in the last days of this Congress.'' 
The President said that he did not think it was right for Democrats to threaten not to support his budget because the capital gains tax cut he supports was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee last week.
 
Two-Day Western Swing
''I don't think it is right for people who get whipped on an issue in a committee to then start a lot of threats on the other side, saying, 'We'll never deal with the President,' '' he said.
Mr. Bush is on a two-day Western swing for the centennials of South Dakota, Montana and Washington. Originally, the stops in these states were to be added to a trip to Alaska to tour Prince William Sound, where the tanker Exxon Valdez grounded March 24, causing the nation's worst oil spill.
But with fresh controversy over the Exxon Corporation's decision to call off its cleanup at least for the winter, White House officials decided that a Presidential tour of Prince William Sound would only renew questions about the Federal role in the cleanup.
Mr. Bush was asked why he did not go to Alaska or did not mention the oil spill in his speeches today, when he had styled himself as the environmental President.
 
'A Rather Busy Time'
''Please don't associate my not going to Alaska at a rather busy time with a lack of interest in Prince William Sound,'' he replied. He also said he had sent emissaries to Alaska.
Reminded about violent racial incidents that have occurred recently, including the killing of a black youth in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Mr. Bush was asked what it says about the state of race relations in the nation.
''Well, it says something ugly whenever there's an incident of that nature,'' he said. ''I hope there's no trend toward more and more divisiveness along racial lines, and I will do my best to speak out against bigotry wherever it occurs, racism wherever it occurs.''
The President said he had ''no hard intelligence evidence'' that he, his family or other Americans have been targeted by Colombian drug traffickers.
 
'No Hard Evidence'
If drug lords were planning retaliation for the American aid to the Colombian Government, he said: ''I think I take a rather dim view of it. There is no hard intelligence evidence of such targeting.''
Was concerned about security for his children or other members of his family? ''No I'm not afraid. I have great confidence in the selflessness and in the thoroughness of the intelligence community and of the Secret Service.''
Even though his advisers did not want him to go to Alaska, Mr. Bush, whose approval ratings on handling of environmental issues dropped after he declined to visit Alaska immediately after the oil spill, used the centennials to talk about conservation.
In Sioux Falls, S.D., and here in Helena before spending the night in Spokane, Wash., Mr. Bush talked about ''the need to awaken a new spirit of environmentalism across the country.''
 
Role for the Peace Corps
Speaking at the State Capitol here, Mr. Bush announced a new initiative to bring the Environmental Protection Agency and the Peace Corps together ''in a joint venture in the service of the global environment.''
With William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the environmental agency, at his side, the President summarized the new venture: ''Beginning in 1990, as part of their standard preparation for duty, Peace Corps volunteers will be trained by the E.P.A. to deal with a full range of environmental challenges -water pollution prevention, waste disposal, reforestation, pesticide management.
''Armed with greater knowledge about our environment, our Peace Corps volunteers are going to help spread the word in the developing world,'' he continued. ''They'll work to stop pollution before it starts, and insure that economic development and environmental stewardship go hand in hand.''
Setting the stage for an education ''summit conference'' to be held next week in Charlottesville, Va., Mr. Bush said that ''the plain truth is that our educational system is not making the grade.''
He said the education conference ''will be as wide-ranging as the West,'' and added: ''I meant it when I said earlier, 'Washington doesn't know best - the people do.' For I reject the notion of Federal mandates, Federal bullying, in education. Instead, what we need are local ideas, local creativity, and more local autonomy.''
Mr. Bush planted trees, birthday presents from the White House, in South Dakota and Montana. He also talked in a folksy way about the delights of the West, quoting Thoreau and, in his speech here, marveling at Montana's ''big sky'' and 896 ''catchable'' fish per square mile.
Then, in one more jab at Congress, he noted that the Montana State Capitol was just a mile away from Last Chance Gulch and said, ''There's a herd back on Capitol Hill that I'd like to move in my direction.''

HEADLINE: The 'People's Opera' vs. Parity for the Musicians

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The current strike by the New York City Opera orchestra doesn't seem on the surface to make a whole lot of sense - for either side. The two parties appear to be within negotiating distance, and the six-day-old strike threatens the entire fall season, which is scheduled to end Nov. 19. Indeed, Martin J. Oppenheimer, vice chairman of the City Opera and its chief negotiator, said that if the strike began to approach the 54 days of the orchestra's 1983 strike, ''it will last a lot longer than that, because we'll cancel the entire season.''
Yet there is a fundamental issue that separates the parties and that may explain why a strike has come at this juncture. That issue is the continuing contradiction between the orchestra's demands and the City Opera's populist mandate, which entails low ticket prices and harsh economies. In that connection, there is also concern about the departure this year of the charismatic Beverly Sills as the company's general director, and what her loss will mean to the City Opera's ability to raise money. 
Despite Mr. Oppenheimer's cancellation threat, the tone of the negotiations has been mostly conciliatory -even though the last formal proposals, placed on the table in July, staked out widely divergent positions. The City Opera musicians currently earn a weekly minimum of $755.25, with additional hourly wages for rehearsals, and the City Opera's top ticket price is $47. The orchestra has asked for a raise of more than 20 percent, to put it at parity with the orchestras of the San Francisco Opera and the Lyric Opera of Chicago, whose top ticket prices are roughly one and a half times that of the City Opera.
 
Shrinking Season Feared
The company has offered only a 4 percent raise annually over a three-year pact. It also says it wants to rescind a current guarantee of six additional weeks beyond the base season of 23 weeks, wherein the players are now offered either regular employment or supplemental benefits amounting to roughly one-half of their full wages.
There is also a nearly definite plan to import the Bolshoi Ballet next summer to the opera's home, the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, which would reduce the 23-week season to 20 weeks. The orchestra fears that plan is the opening wedge to a shrinking of the City Opera season on a regular basis.
Yet Mr. Oppenheimer has denied that the Bolshoi engagement at the expense of the City Opera is the ''beginning of a trend,'' calling it ''a one-shot'' arrangement by the Nederlander organization.
Few would disagree that the orchestra has been chronically underpaid, in comparison with similar ensembles locally and nationally. But that's part of the traditional City Opera modus operandi, applying to all the performing forces, not just the musicians.
 
A 45-Year Tradition
And it is a situation that seems inseparable from the popularly priced ''people's opera'' tradition that has defined the City Opera since its inception 45 years ago. From an artistic standpoint, it might make sense in the long run for the City Opera to re-examine that tradition and boost ticket prices, raise even more money and begin to pay more not only to its orchestra, chorus and dancers but to its solo singers as well.
As it stands, New York is given infrequent exposure to a whole host of American singers who are stars on the regional opera circuit. They may appear here when they are young and occasionally thereafter to keep up their New York presence. But the City Opera pays too little, and rehearses its repertory productions too hectically, for many of them to make it a habit.
But such a basic change in policy would cost a fortune and flout the City Opera's populist inclinations. In addition, it might set up a more direct competition with the Metropolitan Opera for singers, which the City Opera would lose. It would also require far more planning and preparation, in a more contemplative climate, than the atmosphere of a labor negotiation.
Indeed, unlike the disruptions in 1983, when the City Opera was in truly desperate financial straits and Miss Sills had just unilaterally reshuffled and curtailed the annual work schedule, no profound changes are now in the offing. Christopher Keene, who succeeded Miss Sills as general director, and Robert W. Wilson, the board chairman, have declined to talk during the strike negotiations. But Mr. Oppenheimer has denied any intention of permanently shrinking the City Opera season, altering its schedule, rethinking its repertory policy or moving out of Lincoln Center and back to a more intimate, more acoustically congenial but less glamorous theater.
 
Five-Year Grant Expiring
The company says it cannot guarantee six supplemental weeks because it does not know where it could obtain the money for that work after the expiration next year of the late Lawrence Wien's $5 million grant for five seasons of spring musicals. But in 1983, after similar denials that it could not guarantee work it did not already have funds for, the company did just that.
Attendance for the 1989 summer season was slightly under projections, company spokesmen concede. But the fall season is traditionally stronger at the box office, thus giving the company little incentive to welcome a strike as a means of stemming its deficit.
The key reason for a strike now would seem to be a frustrated orchestra's sense that the company might feel vulnerable at the point of transition from Miss Sills to Mr. Keene, and the company's nervous apprehension that its fund-raising clout may erode with her no longer at the helm.
Miss Sills was a formidable fund raiser, and while she remains in the newly created post of board president, she is likely to play a less active role in the company's future.
The orchestra justifies its demands by pointing to the company's own boast that it raises more money annually than any other American performing-arts organization apart from the Met. ''We've repeated that for a long time,'' Mr. Oppenheimer concedes. ''It's a staggering statement, and I think it's even true. Unlike 1983, we're not going out of business. We're going to be here for the foreseeable future.''
''But,'' he added, ''Beverly was our premier fund raiser, and it's going to be an enormous challenge now.''
Like legendary warriors, condemned by fate to fight the same battle over and over again, the City Opera negotiators don't know any other avenue to compromise except confrontation. Apart from 1986, no City Opera orchestra contract since 1962 has been settled without some sort of work stoppage. It is a sad legacy, and the company's loyal public can only hope both sides can bend enough to resolve their differences quickly.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Dai-Ichi Kangyo will buy control of a Manufacturers Hanover unit and a portion of the bank's stock for $1.4 billion, the largest investment yet by a Japanese bank in a U.S. financial company. The financing will help to strengthen the financial condition of Manufacturers, which said it would add $950 million to its reserves for losses on third-world loans. [Page A1.] First Pennsylvania agreed to a $730 million merger with Corestates Financial. [D19.] First Interstate of Wisconsin said it would merge with Norwest. [D4.] 
 
Burroughs Wellcome cut the price of the AIDS drug AZT by 20 percent. Protests had been mounting over the drug's cost. [A1.]
 
A proposed $250 million loan to Campeau was held up by differences with banks over terms sought by Olympia & York. [D1.]
 
Additional investors are expected to join a Citicorp unit's effort to acquire a division of Del Monte. [D1.] Birmingham Steel agreed to be acquired by Harbert for about $375.6 million. [D4.]
 
A strike is threatening to slow Peugeot's momentum while the French auto maker is preparing to introduce a crucial model. [D1.] Imported cars again dominated the best- and worst-mileage categories in the E.P.A.'s annual survey. [D15.]
 
Delta, Northwest and TWA are considering a merger of their computer reservation systems. [D11.]
 
Six computer companies accused the National Intitutes of Health of awarding data processing contracts to I.B.M. without competition. [D2.] Apple and Microsoft are expected to cooperate on technology for the display and printing of typefaces. [D2.]
 
Sir James Goldsmith has come to America to try to persuade legislators and regulators that his takeover bid for B.A.T. poses no threat to the company's U.S. operations. [D4.]

Companies are aggressively moving to control airline travel expenses, as fares used by business people have jumped. [A1.]
 
U.S. and Japanese executives had unusually blunt exchanges over trade imbalances at a conference on manufacturing. [D1.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The Mexican Government intends to sell its majority stake in Telmex, the unpopular and inefficient telephone monopoly. [D1.]
 
President Bush said he would grant Hungary permanent most-favored-nation status, starting next month. [A3.]
 
The Brady plan to cut global debt could misfire by further shrinking the core of future lenders to the third world, the Institute of International Finance, which represents banks, contends. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Out of Disorder, a Deal: 5 Weeks of UAL Talks

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
When the management of UAL agreed five weeks ago to listen to a proposal to participate with United Airlines' pilots in a buyout, relations between the sides were at a low. After more than a year of negotiations, there was almost no progress on a new contract, and on-the-job slowdowns by the pilots had caused many summer delays on United flights.
Yet less than two weeks later, leaders of the two sides emerged from a crucial meeting confident that they could buy the nation's second-largest airline together.
Interviews with most of the central players disclose that the quick turnaround - which led to a $6.75 billion offer for the UAL Corporation, the airline's parent, that was accepted by the company's independent directors on Thursday - can be attributed to four factors:
* A bid by Marvin Davis, the Los Angeles billionaire, persuaded UAL management that it would have to act in some way.
* Leaders of the pilots' union were well prepared with a proposal for a joint buyout, a plan they had been honing for more than two years. 
* The two sides agreed in many ways on how the power in an employee-owned company should be divided.
* Finally, the concessions on wages and benefits offered by the pilots and the tax advantages of the employee stock ownership plan envisioned in the buyout made a management-labor offer difficult to top.
 
'Davis Was the Catalyst'
The rapid turn of events was begun by a $240-a-share bid for UAL by Mr. Davis, made public on Aug. 7. The offer, later raised to $275, forced management and the UAL board, which had twice refused to consider a buyout proposal by the pilots, to begin to explore such a possibility.
''Davis was the catalyst,'' said Eugene J. Keilin, a general partner at Lazard Freres & Company, who was the leading investment banker to advise the union. ''He forced management to come to grips with our proposal.''
When on Aug. 11 UAL said it was willing to have its investment banker, First Boston, listen to an employee buyout proposal, the pilots were ready.
Within hours of the call from UAL, Frederick C. Dubinsky, the chairman of the governing body of the United pilots' union, was on a plane to New York from Chicago. His briefcase was filled with papers that had been ready since 1987 for such a bid. He did not have time to go home and pack anything else.
At the time of the call, contract talks between United and its pilots had bogged down. And some of the 6,100 pilots were ''flying by the book,'' causing delays. On-time performance had plummeted. United's chairman and chief executive, Stephen M. Wolf, was also seething because the union had decided not to fly two new Boeing 747-400's until it had a new contract, frustrating the company's plans to expand and upgrade its service across the Pacific.
 
'Close to Confrontation'
''We were getting close to confrontation,'' Mr. Dubinsky recalled. Indeed, the pilots were beginning to consider using their ultimate weapon, a strike.
But after meeting with UAL's bankers in New York, Mr. Dubinsky found that the pilots and the management group could agree in some important ways. Both sides were committed to having a board with a majority of independent directors and management that would largely have a free hand in running the company day to day.
The only area in which the pilots' union wanted control was in the broad decisions, like disposing of such major assets as the airline's Pacific routes or diversifying into other businesses. The union was granted that control; under the agreement, such changes would have to be approved both by a majority of the eight independent directors on the new 15-member board and by at least two of the three directors from United's participating unions.
Confidence that agreement could be reached on the delicate issue of the balance of power was largely reaffirmed in a meeting between Mr. Wolf and Mr. Dubinsky on Aug. 24.
 
New Lack of Tension
Mr. Dubinsky recalled that at the meeting, in a conference room at the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, which represented Mr. Wolf, ''it was casual; there was no tension between us.'' This had not been the case in earlier meetings.
Mr. Wolf had concluded that Mr. Davis had put the company ''in play'' and that it could not remain as it was.
Mr. Dubinsky recalled that although Mr. Wolf had been leaning toward a buyout by employees, he wanted reassurance that he and his management team would have the freedom to run the company without undue interference from labor.
''He needed to hear that from me face to face,'' Mr. Dubinsky said.
People close to the meeting said it was a turning point.
The bid by Mr. Davis had forced Mr. Wolf to step off the curb, Mr. Dubinsky said. The meeting between them ''persuaded him to cross the street.''
 
Cementing the Alliance
What finally cemented the alliance between management and labor was the growing realization that an employee stock ownership plan, with its tax advantages, would enable UAL to carry its huge interest costs with less effort and to repay debt faster.
Because the banks that will finance the buyout, led by Citibank and Chase Manhattan, can deduct 50 percent of the interest they earn on the loans in such a plan, they can lend the money at more favorable rates than in a transaction like that proposed by Mr. Davis, where no such tax breaks would be available.
The company can also deduct the money it borrows to buy the 75 percent stake that will be owned by the employees in the stock plan, further reducing the cost of the takeover. The management group, which includes Mr. Wolf, will own 10 percent of the company and British Airways P.L.C. 15 percent.
The pilots have also granted $250 million a year in wage and benefit concessions, which would reduce United's labor costs and provide more cash to pay off its higher debt.
 
Flexibility on Loans
In its negotiations with banks, the buyout group has also won some flexibility to renegotiate its loans if the industry should go into a deep recession.
The banks looked with favor on the transaction, Mr. Keilin said, noting that when the group began to negotiate the expectation was that the lead banks would put up $500 million to $700 million of the $7.2 billion being sought, leaving the rest to be lent by syndicates of banks.
Instead, Citibank and Chase together committed to lending $3 billion.
Mr. Keilin recalled that after the pivotal meeting between Mr. Wolf and Mr. Dubinsky, the rest of the negotiations proceeded fairly smoothly. British Airways came into the buyout the following week with a commitment to put up $750 million in equity. The pilots have promised $200 million in equity and the management group $15 million.
 
The Last Big Hurdle
But one big hurdle remained: approval by the Master Executive Council, the 24-member governing body of the United pilots' union.
Although the council had supported pursuing a buyout for several years, circumstances had changed. The carrier had grown stronger, and interest in a buyout had waned among union leaders.
Mr. Dubinsky recalled that before the Davis bid the union members and leaders had been preoccupied with negotiating a new contract that would provide for pay and benefit increases, rather than the concessions offered in the buyout, like a 10 percent pay cut, less vacation time and extra hours of work.
But the union council members had also become convinced over the last several years that they wanted control of the airline's strategy and direction so that United would not be sidetracked from its core business.
 
Grilled by Pilot Leaders
Mr. Keilin and other advisers were grilled repeatedly by pilot leaders, who wore business suits and were not the more free-wheeling, shirt-sleeves group they are at most meetings.
But Mr. Keilin was reassured after telling the group that British Airways had decided to join the buyout. ''They got up and gave a standing ovation,'' he recalled. After three days of debate and questioning, the group unanimously approved the proposal on Aug. 31.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan Executives Exchange Barbs on Trade

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Tensions over the trade imbalance between the United States and Japan today produced some unusually blunt exchanges between chief executives gathered here for a conference on the outlook for manufacturing industries.
Akio Morita, the co-founder and chairman of the Sony Corporation, said 50 percent of American imports from Japan were now high-technology machinery and devices like microchips. ''The fact that the United States is losing its competitiveness in so many areas of high-tech manufacturing suggests that something is fundamentally amiss in American industry,'' he added. 
Mr. Morita said that because of the emphasis by Americans on short-term financial results, American manufacturers had not made investments that would pay off in the long term. But a top American executive chastised Japanese industry, and Mr. Morita directly, for what he said was Japan's resistance to imports.
''The fact is that Japan remains a virtually impenetrable market for many foreign businesses,'' said Edward L. Hennessy Jr., the chairman of Allied-Signal Inc. Referring to a new book, ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' by Mr. Morita and Shintaro Ishihara, a Liberal Democratic Party politician who was a candidate for Prime Minister in August, Mr. Hennessy added, ''Instead of a Japan that can say 'no,' all of us need a Japan that can say 'yes' to open markets.''
In the book, the authors suggested that Japan could use the United States' dependence on it for high-technology components as leverage in trade disputes.
Mr. Morita and Mr. Hennessy spoke at the International Industrial Conference, a meeting held every four years to assess the outlook for manufacturing industries. It is sponsored by the Conference Board, a business research group, and SRI International, a research and consulting organization.
According to the organizers, it is being attended by executives and Government officials from 31 countries, including the Soviet Union and Hungary.
Judging from questions posed to a panel of experts, the major concerns of executives here appear to be: increasingly stringent environmental standards, the development of trade blocs and changing social patterns.
''Burdens on companies will change in the 1990's,'' said Tore Browaldh, a Swedish banker who is the honorary chairman of Svenska Handelsbanken. ''There will be a shift from economic growth to care of the environment, health and safety for workers and women's rights.''
The participants agreed that environmental issues would become an increasingly contentious issue between industrialized countries and those just beginning their economic development. Saburo Okita, a former Japanese Foreign Minister, said, ''Developing countries are not signing the Montreal Protocol,'' which seeks to reduce the use of chemicals known as chlorofluorocarbons, which damage the earth's ozone layer.
Newly developing countries, he added, felt industrialized nations could afford to use less efficient substances, while they could not until they were economically advanced.
Mr. Okita also said Asian nations were increasing their cooperative efforts in response to the United States-Canadian trade treaty and the European Community's plans for economic integration after 1992. But he added that he doubted that a unified trade bloc would emerge in Asia, where countries were less alike socially and economically than in Europe.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Bank of Tokyo Trust Appoints a Chairman

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
After a 10-year tour of duty in Tokyo and in Jakarta, Indonesia, Kenji Yoshizawa is returning to the United States, this time as chairman of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company in New York and the bank's resident senior managing director.
Mr. Yoshizawa, 57, succeeds Tamotsu Yamaguchi, who has returned to Tokyo to become deputy president of the parent.
The Bank of Tokyo, which grew along with Japan's economy, is the largest foreign bank operating in the United States, Mr. Yoshiwaza said. ''In the United States we employ 9,000 people, he said. ''That, incidentally, is much larger that the number we employ in Japan, where we have a little over 5,000.'' 
The bank, which opened its New York operation in 1955, has worldwide assets of $197 billion and 250 overseas offices.
Mr. Yoshizawa, who was born in Japan, has been with the bank since 1956, a year after he graduated cum laude from Georgetown University. In 1975, he became deputy general manager of the New York agency and a year later was named executive vice president of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company.
He spent some time at the bank's branch in Indonesia, and since 1983 has been assigned to Japan.
In his new post, he will oversee the bank's operation in California as well as the trust company operations in New York. A decade ago, the Bank of Tokyo's California operations became California First Bank. Bank of Tokyo also recently acquired the Union Bank of California. Mr. Yoshiwaza will sit on the Union board, he said, but will not be responsible for day-to-day operations. His predecessor, Mr. Yamaguchi, was chairman of Union Bank in addition to his other roles.
Mr. Yamaguchi became known as an enthusiastic fan of American football. Mr. Yoshiwaza said he didn't share the same fervency, but ''we always support the Hoyas,'' he added, referring to his alma mater's teams.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Fall; Gold Prices Down in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar dropped again yesterday in the aftermath of the panicky decline at the end of last week, hurt by traders' fears that central banks would sell and by the uncertain effect of an upcoming meeting of finance ministers.
Gold prices also fell after gains overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $361.70 a troy ounce, down $2.20 from Friday. 
Money traders said the foreign exchange market was quieter yesterday than last Friday, a day characterized by wild rumors and price swings, but that the rout had convinced other dollar holders to sell yesterday or at least avoid the market until the currency's long-term outlook became clearer.
''The dollar bulls are hanging on the sidelines,'' said Michael Guarino, vice president and chief dealer at the New York branch of Algemene Bank Nederland N.V., the largest Dutch bank. ''The dollar bears are taking over. They have the central banks in their favor. That's going to add fuel to the fire.''
The central banks of the United States and its principal trading allies have repeatedly swooped into the foreign exchange markets recently to sell large amounts of dollars to keep the dollar from rising in value.
A more expensive dollar partly reflects confidence in the United States economy and the relatively high interest rates offered in this country, which attract foreign investors. But as the dollar's value rises, it hurts American manufacturers by making their products more expensive overseas.
 
Group of Seven Meeting
Some traders were awaiting a meeting this weekend of finance ministers from the Group of Seven nations before making dollar commitments.
''At this point I dare say I wouldn't put my neck on the line,'' said Scott Horwitz, senior foreign exchange trader at the Bank of Boston's New York branch. ''My frame of mind is one minute to one hour. I think we'll see the dollar trade in a range until we get new direction from that meeting.''
The Group of Seven members meeting in Washington consist of envoys from Britain, Canada, France, Japan, Italy, the United States and West Germany.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 146.43 Japanese yen, up 0.58 yen. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 145.85 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York the dollar fetched 145.93 yen, down from 146.35 late Friday.

LENGTH: 1104 words

HEADLINE: Baker, Defending Policy, Details 'Creative' Response to Gorbachev

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d moved today to counter charges that the Bush Administration was unresponsive to opportunities presented by changes in the Soviet bloc.
With only a few hours' notice, Mr. Baker decided to hold his first press conference at the State Department since taking office eight months ago to list steps taken by Washington to engage Moscow. He also used the occasion to announce a modest proposal to advance the strategic arms talks, apparently in response to charges by Soviet officials and some critics of the Administration that those talks had become a low priority.
Mr. Baker has held many news conferences overseas and briefings in Washington before trips, but has generally let President Bush lead in articulating foreign policy at home. 
Mr. Baker was asked about a speech Monday by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, who accused the Administration of being so ambivalent about changes in the East bloc that it seemed to be almost ''nostalgic about the cold war.'' The Secretary brushed aside Senator Mitchell's comments, indicating they were motivated by partisan politics.
''When the President of the United States is rocking along with a 70 percent approval rating on his handling of foreign policy, if I were the leader of the opposition, I might have something similar to say,'' Mr. Baker said.
The Secretary began the news conference by ticking off everything the Bush Administration had done to respond ''creatively'' to initiatives by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. He went on to warn critics of the Administration's pace against becoming ''frantic'' and doing something ''dumb.''
He also used the occasion to announce that the United States would drop its insistence on a ban on mobile land-based nuclear missiles if Congress would appropriate money for such new weapons.
 
Proposed by Reagan
Now only the Soviet Union has mobile missiles, and arms experts said the conditional lifting of the American ban would contribute to progress in the strategic arms talks. But the move did not constitute a major breakthrough.
The ban on mobile missiles was proposed by the Reagan Administration and drew sharp criticism then from Brent Scowcroft, then a private consultant and now President Bush's national security adviser, who argued that the United States needed mobile missiles like the single-warhead Midgetman to make its forces less vulnerable to Soviet attack.
Indeed, Mr. Baker's strategic arms proposal seemed to be as much intended to advance the negotiations as to put the Soviets politically on the defensive on the eve of high-level United States-Soviet talks this week. The Bush Administration was stung by the surprise initiative of Mr. Gorbachev that involved a reduction of short-range nuclear weapons in Europe, when Mr. Baker came to Moscow last May.
The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrives in Washington for talks with President Bush on Thursday, then flies to Jackson Hole, Wyo., for talks with Mr. Baker on Friday and Saturday. Mr. Shevardnadze is expected to be carrying a letter from Mr. Gorbachev that Administration officials expect - some would say ''fear'' - will offer dramatic new Soviet proposals for breaking the strategic arms logjam.
 
The Unresolved Issues
With that in mind, Administration officials appeared to be looking for a gesture to show that it is not just reacting to Mr. Gorbachev but continuing to take the initiative. The initiative they chose, however, does not address the more fundamental unresolved strategic arms issues like whether ''Star Wars'' weapons testing should be allowed, whether to limit sea-launched cruise missiles and how to count air-launched cruise missiles on bombers.
Besides the strategic arms talks, Mr. Baker said the Bush Administration and Moscow were now ''fully engaged across an increasingly broadened agenda - broadened, if I may say, so at our suggestion.''
For example, he said, by urging the Soviet Union to ''join us'' in solving regional conflicts and reducing tension the Administration was helping Mr. Gorbachev ''save the Soviets billions of dollars that we still see spent in a disappointing pattern of support for those who fuel the conflicts in Central America, Cambodia, Afghanistan, Cuba, Ethiopia and elsewhere.''
While indicating that he did not envisage any major new financial initiatives for Poland beyond those already announced by President Bush, Mr. Baker said: ''We should take a harder look at the problem,'' since ''we are now dealing with a democratic government seeking to survive, rather than a Communist government seeking to reform itself.''
He then added, though, ''I think its fair to say that we need to help them over the rough spot, but whether they succeed or not is going to depend on their willingness to effect some very fundamental economic reforms.''
In other fields of arms control, the Secretary said the Bush Administration ''could offer the Soviets some real economic savings if they respond positively'' to the conventional arms reduction proposals President Bush presented at the NATO summit last May.
Mr. Baker also said he would propose to Mr. Shevardnadze ways to break the 15-year Soviet-American impasse over verification of underground nuclear tests so the two nuclear testing treaties could be ratified.
In addition, he said, ''We have, I think, a reasonable shot at an agreement to exchange data on chemical stocks, which I think is a first practical step toward achieving real controls and eventually a total ban.''
It was clear from the Secretary of State's remarks, however, that the Bush Administration does not intend to abandon its cautious approach toward Mr. Gorbachev, and that it would not rush to engage him at a summit.
That position was also underlined by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, whose speech on East-West relations last week prompted some of the recent criticism that the Administration was afraid of change in the Eastern bloc. In an interview today Mr. Eagleburger said he was ''in no way nostalgic for the cold war.''
The point he was trying to make, he said, was that ''with all the hopeful reform going on in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe one has to also recognize that these processes will unleash'' some forces that could destabilize the European order that existed for the last 40 years. To point that out is not to hanker for the stability of the cold war, he said, adding that it is now incumbent upon the West to nuture this change in creative ways ''that won't create further instabilities.''

HEADLINE: Vietnamese Leader, Assailing the West, Ignites Fear at Home

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Vietnamese leadership has intensified a crackdown in ideological and intellectual life, warning against Western subversion in the language of the cold war.
Two recent speeches by the Communist Party General Secretary, Nguyen Van Linh, who is regarded as a reformer, profoundly disappointed and depressed some of his allies in this country's intellectual and journalistic elite.
They also raised concern among some prominent economists who have helped to draw up the changes, known here as renovation, that have begun to reduce the economic role of the state and to attract private capital and initiatives.
 
Concern Over Aid and Trade
They worry that in the absence of a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia, which the United States is now making a condition for improved relations with Vietnam, Hanoi's new defensiveness about the intentions of the West will further delay the aid and trade that it needs to salvage a rickety economy and provide jobs for a rapidly growing population. 
Vietnam's withdrawal next week from Cambodia, which it invaded in December 1978, driving out the Government led by Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge, is now believed unlikely to lead to the United States' lifting its embargo on Vietnam. The embargo forestalls signficant investment and trade from other Western countries and has caused bitterness here.
At the same time, radical changes elsewhere in the Communist world - in China, the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary in particular - seem to have shocked the party leadership here and increased a sense of threat, insecurity and isolation.
Conservative voices that were muted during the first two years of Mr. Linh's rule, which began in December 1986, are now dominating debate only a little more than a year before Mr. Linh himself has said he will step down.
Some magazines and newspapers have been closed and some editors in chief, including To Hoa of Saigon Giai Phong, this city's most important paper, have been retired or replaced. Vu Kim Hanh, the 37-year-old editor of the newspaper Tuoi Tre, or Youth, which has written movingly of the country's social problems, is on a list of six editors to be dismissed, Vietnamese officials say privately, though for now she has retained her post.
''I tell you frankly that we writers and poets are facing great difficulties,'' said a novelist who has spoken openly before. ''We do not want to speak of political problems, and please do not mention names, for this is Vietnam.''
An official said: ''The problem now is that there is no clear ideological line. It is very easy now to cross it. Being an editor now is a very dangerous job.''
Mr. Linh spoke to senior journalists here in March, encouraging them to emphasize positive accomplishments as well as ''negative phenomena,'' and he spoke out strongly against ''pluralism'' and multiparty democracy at the end of a party meeting on March 29.
In a speech here on Aug. 24 at the end of another party meeting, devoted to ideological questions, Mr. Linh accused the West, and in particular President Bush, of intervening in the internal affairs of Communist countries and trying to undermine them. He spoke of the ''escalating'' battle between the Communist camp and a fundamentally unchanged capitalist world, ''with its very insidious schemes and tricks.''
While apparently continuing to seek Western investment and encourage private enterprise here, he spoke harshly of an increasing exploitation of workers under capitalism, and said that modern technology, by increasing productivity, was robbing the worker of his ''surplus labor value by tens of time compared with a worker in the previous century.''
He also criticized ''some deviant ideological viewpoints among a handful of cadres and party members,'' which have been breeding amid ''the impact of wrong ideological currents coming from outside.''
''This was a very clumsy speech,'' said a senior journalist here. ''It was the language of 45 years ago, and it depressed many people.''
A Vietnamese official said there had been only one vote against the speech in the Politburo, cast by Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach, a Linh ally who did not attend the August party meeting due to illness.
It was Mr. Thach who had pressed for the early withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia to end Vietnam's economic and political isolation, and if the withdrawal does not produce some results, Mr. Thach's position will be jeopardized, the official said.
In a second speech Sept. 1, for Vietnam's national day on Sept. 2, Mr. Linh took up the same themes. He said Vietnam was prepared ''to broaden our external economic relations with all other countries, foreign companies and international organizations'' without political conditions, but he warned against ''the life style and decadent culture'' of the bourgeoisie and the West.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICES STEADY IN AUGUST

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Consumer prices over all were unchanged in August, making it the first month in more than three years that the Consumer Price Index did not rise, the Labor Department reported today.
Economists regarded the report as somewhat encouraging because it showed that inflation was not as serious a problem as it seemed to be earlier in the year.
But they noted that a central reason why the inflation index remained steady was a large drop in energy prices, particularly a 4.2 percent fall in the price of gasoline. Fuel prices rose significantly early this year, and the lower prices in recent months are regarded as a return to a more normal level. 
 
'Core' Rate Half the July Rise
The ''core'' inflation rate, however, which excludes the categories of food and energy because of their volatility, rose by two-tenths of 1 percent last month, half the rise in July. At an annual rate, the core inflation for the last three months has risen by 3.1 percent, as against a 4.8 percent increase in the first five months of the year.
That indicates an easing of inflation, but it is not nearly so dramatic as the difference in the entire price index, which rose at an annual rate of 6.6 percent in the first five months of the year and by only 1.6 percent in the last three months.
''The bulge in inflation at the start of the year was a spike and not a trend, and this is just a reverse of what we saw then,'' said Gordon Richards, an economist at the National Association of Manufacturers.
In general, economists cautioned against drawing too much significance from the overall figure. ''Most of us believe the good news in energy is behind us, and the underlying inflation isn't coming down,'' said John Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.
Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University, agreed with Mr. Paulus's assessment. ''It's a plus,'' Mr. Ratajczak said of today's report, ''but I wouldn't say, 'Hey, we've solved the inflation problem.' The big picture is that the underlying inflation rate is in the 4 percent to 4.5 percent range it's been in for several years.''
Meanwhile, the Commerce Department reported today that housing construction fell 5 percent last month, the largest decrease in six months. But many analysts viewed the decline, which was attributed to a jump in mortgage rates in August, as only a temporary setback because rates have already begun to moderate.
 
Dow Drops Fractionally
The markets seemed to pay little attention to the news on inflation. The Dow Jones industrial average rose early in the day shortly after the new figures were announced but ended the day down by 0.19 point. In the bond market, the benchmark 30-year bond rose initially but then slipped by the end of the day.
The Federal Reserve has kept interest rates high for the last two years to curb the spending that has led to higher prices. But earlier this year, after evidence emerged that the economy was slowing, the central bank began easing interest rates slightly.
Today's price report from the Labor Department ''strengthens the hand'' of those pressing for lower rates, said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist in the New York office of Lloyds Bank. But he and others who watch monetary policy closely said the Federal Reserve would need much more evidence that inflation had been arrested before further action was taken.
 
Basis for Adjustments
The prevailing view of economists is that the inflation rate for the year as measured by the price index will be 5 percent or perhaps a fraction less. That would exceed the 4.4 percent rate for 1988. The annual rate is important because it is the basis for inflation adjustments in many wage contracts as well as Social Security payments and income taxes.
The index measures the cost of a fixed basket of consumer goods. Each item is weighted to reflect what urban consumers spent on that commodity in 1982-84.
The index for August was 124.6. This means that consumers had to pay $124.60 last month for goods and services that cost $100 in the 1982-84 base period.
The last month when the index did not rise was in April 1986, when it fell by three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Relief Seen as Temporary
Energy prices fell last month largely because of an oversupply of crude oil early in the summer, but the relief is likely to be temporary, economists said. Crude oil prices have begun to rise again, and that will be probably reflected in the price of gasoline and other fuels in the months ahead.
Other than the drop in fuel prices, the main reason inflation seemed to be moderating last month was lower figures for food and apparel. Food prices, which rose sharply early in the year largely because of lingering effects of last year's drought, were up by only two-tenths of 1 percent in August.
Apparel prices altogether fell 1.7 percent, and those for women's and girls' clothes dropped by 3.6 percent. Mr. Chandross noted that a big decline was also shown in August 1988, and he said he suspected a problem existed in the way the apparel data were adjusted to account for seasonal variations.
 
Renters' Costs Down
Housing costs, which account for more than 42 percent of the entire index, rose only two-tenths of 1 percent last month, compared with six-tenths in July. Renters' costs fell four-tenths, while homeowners' costs rose by the same fraction.
The cost of services rose by three-tenths of 1 percent, while commodities fell by four-tenths. Mr. Paulus noted that the price of services had actually risen faster, at a 5.9 percent annual rate, in the last three months than they did in the first five months of year, when the rate was 5.1 percent.

HEADLINE: HURRICANE SPARES BAHAMIAN ISLANDS; HEADS FOR THE U.S.

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
The fiercest hurricane to rake the northeastern Caribbean in a decade sideswiped the Bahamas yesterday and began swirling toward the United States after damaging tens of thousands of homes and causing billions of dollars of damage.
Incomplete reports indicated that 19 people were killed by Hurricane Hugo in Puerto Rico and a string of islands along a 500-mile arc of the Caribbean. But that toll may rise as the cleanup of collapsed structures begins. 
Officials credited early warnings of the storm's approach for keeping the death toll low. ''The people on the islands respect these storms.'' said Lee Grenci, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. ''When they have warnings they take them seriously. People in the United States should do likewise.'' #3 Possible Paths As many as 50,000 people were reported to have been left without homes throughout the Caribbean. Officials in Puerto Rico said the storm left 10,000 people homeless on that island, and the American Red Cross estimated that 25,000 people were staying in its emergency shelters in the eastern part of the island. The Coast Guard said a survey it had done by helicopters had found 80 percent of the roofs blown off houses between San Juan and Sajardo, 25 miles to the east. [Page B9.] And on the tiny British island of Montserrat, officials said 99 percent of the houses were destroyed, along with the island's only hospital. Pilots who flew over Montserrat yesterday reported that the once tree-covered volcanic island ''looked like it had gotten a crew cut,'' said Rolf Stefanson, the local coordinator of a United Nations relief effort.
Although forecasters offered three possible future paths for the hurricane, including one in which it would veer safely to the east and out to sea, the most likely projection was for the storm to strike somewhere from Florida to North Carolina Friday or early Saturday.
 
Bypassing the Bahamas
Yesterday, with winds decreasing to a still-dangerous 105 miles per hour, down from the winds of at least 120 m.p.h. that brought chaos and destruction to dozens of Caribbean islands, the hurricane took a northwestern course along the 700-island chain of the Bahamas, but at least 100 miles out to sea, and was expected to remain on that course for another 24 hours.
The forecasters said a variety of atmospheric factors, some as distant as Canada and the Rocky Mountains, could determine the storm's course. But the most likely impact would come from the combination of a low-pressure system moving west across southern Georgia and a broad high-pressure ridge - the ''Bermuda High'' - to the hurricane's north.
Robert Sheets, the director of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla., urged residents from the Florida Keys to Cape Hatteras in North Carolina to begin preparing. ''We were just looking through a bunch of the old charts,'' Dr. Sheets said. ''They've done loop-the-loops, they've gone into south Florida, they've gone into central Florida, all the way up to the Carolinas.
''Within the next 24 to 48 hours,'' he continued, ''we can narrow the zone where the hurricane is likely to hit.''
 
Preparation at Cape Canaveral
At Cape Canaveral, space agency officials were already making preparations and said they would decide today whether the threat was serious enough to roll the space shuttle Atlantis off its launching pad and back to its giant hangar, delaying an Oct. 12 blastoff. In Miami, where emergency officials were meeting yesterday to prepare evacuation plans should the hurricane turn toward that city, hundreds of residents were inundating insurance companies with last-minute pleas for flood coverage.
And the Navy said yesterday that it had decided to start removing ships from some of its Atlantic Coast naval bases.
Starting at 8 A.M. today, 20 ships were scheduled to sail from the naval base at Charleston, S.C., into the Atlantic out of the expected path of the hurricane. Around noon, 17 ships were to leave the naval station at Mayport, Fla., including the aircraft carriers Forrestal and Saratoga.
Insurance experts, meanwhile, were already assessing the damage that Hugo wrought in Puerto Rico and the rest of the Caribbean, with preliminary losses estimated at up to $2 billion. About $1 billion in losses is expected in Puerto Rico alone. The hurricane has dealt a serious blow to the struggling economies of at least half a dozen islands that rely heavily on tourism and cash crops. And it terrified people. ''We were all huddled together in the corridor when the wind took off the roof of the house,'' said Didier Gacoby-Karoly, 14 years old, of Guadeloupe.
 
Boats Blown Out of Water
On St. Thomas, Terri Lynn Thrush, a 20-year-old American tourist, said, ''I'm scared and anxious,'' after high winds blew out windows in her hotel room. The winds were so strong in St. Thomas that sailboats were blown out of the water and thrown as far as 150 feet on shore; and some waterfront businesses simply disappeared. In Puerto Rico, 50 airplanes were reported destroyed at the airport in Isla Verde.
Many of the worst-hit islands of the northeastern Caribbean remained cut off from normal communication links yesterday, and damage reports were based on eyewitness reports, official statements and amateur radio transmissions.
The storm made a direct hit on Puerto Rico on Monday, with 120 m.p.h. winds ripping roofs off hundreds of homes, heavily damaging hotels, knocking out power, overturning cars and flooding roads. Up to 80 percent of all homes on the offshore islands of Culebra and Vieques were destroyed.
 
Huddled in Hotel Lobbies
Thousands of tourists had to ride out the storm huddled in hotel lobbies or crowded into emergency shelters. Looters stole goods from damaged stores and supermarkets, and at least 10 people were arrested, the authorities said.
After touring the 90-mile wide island, Gov. Rafael Hernandez-Colon was quoted by Puerto Rican radio stations as saying he would ask President Bush to declare the island a Federal disaster area, making it eligible for emergency aid. In the United States Virgin Islands, with a population of about 100,000, up to 80 percent of all structures on St. Thomas were damaged.
Mr. Bush, who was in Spokane, Wash., on a two-day Western trip, said the Federal government is dispatching a team to help in the rescue efforts. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the Government ''stands ready to respond promptly and fully.''
A spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Phil McAde, said a C-141 loaned to the agency by the Air Force carried radio equipment and several of the agency's representatives to St. Croix yesterday. Mr. McAde said the emergency agency has 300 to 400 hundred people waiting to go to the islands.
The agency has had little contact with the Puerto Rican Government, Mr. McAde said, but its representatives in the Virgin Islands plan to meet with Governor Hernandez-Colon as soon as possible.
Radio reports from St. Croix said 300 to 500 inmates had broken out of a heavily damaged prison and had joined a wave of looting on the island.
 
Devastated Banana Crop
The British Virgin Islands were also hit hard. Power and phone service was knocked out and, on the island of Tortola, numerous injuries were reported and scores of homes destroyed. Officials on Dominica, a former British colony with a population of 74,000, reported no deaths, but said Hugo had ripped the heart out of the island's vital banana crop, its main agricultural export.
In the Commonwealth of Antigua and Barbuda, the main business area in the capital of St. John's was reported to be heavily flooded and power lines were down. Two deaths were confirmed and 15 to 30 percent of the islands' 80,000 people were said to be homeless. Extensive damage to agriculture was also reported.
On Nevis, where residents were supposed to be celebrating their independence from Britain yesterday, they were instead surveying the damage to their houses and property. A tour of the island suggested that perhaps 10 percent of the houses were destroyed, with considerably more seriously damaged. And there was extensive damage to beachfronts and the island's agriculture.
Much of the British colony of Montserrat, where 12,000 people live on 40 square miles, was leveled, United Nations officials in the Barbados said yesterday as they began a relief effort.
Officials in Montserrat said that ''at least 99 percent of the housing was destroyed,'' Mr. Stefanson said, along with most of the public buildings, including the hospital. The airport control tower in Pointe-A-Pitre, the commercial center, was among the many buildings destroyed.
And on Guadeloupe, a 700-square mile French territory consisting of seven islands, the authorities said 5 people died and up to 12,000 residents were left homeless out of a total population of about 300,000. An estimated 30 percent of Guadeloupe's roads were impassable. Military planes had already arrived with about 50 tons of emergency supplies and more than 500 relief workers.
 
Aid From the French
In Paris, the French Overseas Affairs Minister, Louis Le Pensec, said the Government would release $5.4 million in immediate help to Guadeloupe. The French Government also said it would freeze interests on loans to residents of that island.
The president of the European Commission, Jacques Delors said the commission will give about $476,000 to Guadeloupe as ''exceptional help.'' The commission handles the day-to-day operations of the European Community. The aid is far from enough to cover damages, and the French Government said it was just in the way of initial help. All 1,500 banana growers, for example, said their plantations have been totally wiped out.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Offers Fractious Nationalists Both Olive Branch and Stick

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 19

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today laid down a policy on growing nationalist agitation in the Soviet Union that invited conciliation but drew the line firmly against the separatist hopes of the nation's restive republics.
''Talk of secession is an irresponsible game,'' he said, addressing a special meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee, called to deal with ethnic and separatist pressures that have been interfering with Mr. Gorbachev's plans for reform. ''Those calling for it are no more than adventurists.''
In particular, he rebuffed the well-organized autonomy movements in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, which the party leadership last month condemned, warning of a ''virus of nationalism'' that could lead to civil conflict. 
 
No Rewriting of Events
''There are no grounds to question the decision by the Baltic republics to join the U.S.S.R. and the choice made by their people,'' Mr. Gorbachev said, rejecting the Baltic republics' assertion that their independence was usurped when they were incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940.
In a long speech to about 500 party and Government leaders, the Soviet President cautioned against ''giving in to the passions and ambitions of the moment'' by repainting ethnic history with ''rosy colors.''
His Kremlin audience offered spirited applause as Mr. Gorbachev, after pleading for harmony and summarizing unrest across the nation, declared:
''I will put it straightforwardly. We will not back away from solving all problems by political methods. But where it is required by the acuteness of the situation, where a threat has arisen to the safety and lives of the people, we will act decisively, using the full force of Soviet laws.''
 
Date of Congress Advanced
In his 90-minute appearance before the full Central Committee, the party's consultative body, Mr. Gorbachev also dealt with growing internal pressures on the Communist leadership by announcing that the next party congress would be held in October 1990, five months sooner than scheduled.
In announcing the rescheduling, which had been viewed as a compromise means of dealing with increasing doubt in the party hierarchy over the stalled economy and the uncertainties of political change, Mr. Gorbachev urged faster reforms to deal with ''panicky sentiments,'' critical consumer needs and ''wider rights'' for party units in the restive republics.
''Real life and perestroika have been proceeding at such a pace that we have often lagged behind,'' the Soviet leader said, urging fresh faces and ideas for the congress. ''Much of what previously seemed correct no longer satisifies us.''
Addressing party leaders and the nation tonight via delayed TV recording, Mr. Gorbachev mixed unqualified endorsement of the supremacy of the party with qualified endorsement of autonomy for the republics.
 
A Galloping Soviet Pluralism
The common element in his remarks was the question of whether one-party rule can somehow be adapted to satisfy the multiple voices and needs now confronting the Soviet nation at an ever-more-demanding pace.
Mr. Gorbachev replied once again with a firm yes, declaring that the party instituted democratization of society and that ''it intends to stick firmly to this path.''
''The party is simply obliged to restructure its own activity on democratic principles and strengthen its ideological unity on the platform of perestroika,'' he said, declaring, without specifying how, that the Communist Party must ''confirm by deeds its right to be the vanguard of society.''
As some East European nations continued to move away from the Soviet Union toward greater political and economic independence, Mr. Gorbachev's own country remains wrenched by separatist pressures. He noted the continuing violence between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in the Caucasus.
''We can not allow anarchy,'' he said. ''even more so bloodshed.'' But he offered no immediate proposals, only warning that ''national enmity has risen to a point when further developments may have unpredictable consequences.''
 
Grievances From Many Places
The nationalist challenge to Mr. Gorbachev encompasses an array of problems - ranging from mass migrations and conflict along the nation's southern border, to Popular Front movements in critical areas like the Ukraine, to the demands for greater autonomy in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.
Mr. Gorbachev conceded that in the Stalin era, the Government committed ''gross violations of the Leninist principles of foreign policy.'' But he flatly rejected the Baltics' cry of usurpation, declaring: ''History cannot be rewritten to suit subjective views and political calculations, or give in to the passions and ambitions of the present.''
Emphasizing the complex economic dependence among the 15 Soviet republics, he added: ''The course of events cannot be reversed. One can go forward, only relying on historical truth and the reality of the modern world.''
The Soviet leader was not specific when he denounced ''attempts by enemies of perestroika to play ''the nationalist card.'' In discussing the Baltics, however, he talked of ''more prosperous republics'' trying to erect ''regional fences'' that would interfere with plans for a ''federal market'' designed for common prosperity.
He said the nation's new policy on nationalism, which is being debated by the Central Committee behind closed doors, should draw a distinction between peaceful demonstrations and what he termed ''extremist rallies that provoke inter-ethnic clashes and terrorize and intimidate people of other nationalities.''
 
No Secession Allowed
Mr. Gorbachev talked of giving substance to republic sovereignty through economic reform and decentralization of decision-making.
Last week, Mr. Gorbachev took a somewhat conciliatory tone in a meeting with party and government leaders from the Baltic republics, urging ''reasonable compromise,'' according to a Government account of the meeting. A summary of the meeting Wednesday with the Latvian, Lithuanian and Estonian leaders said Mr. Gorbachev warned against the ''ruinous'' step of separatist Communist movements but also emphasized the need to work out differences without confrontation.
Baltic separatists have noted that the Soviet Constitution theoretically allows secession. But Mr. Gorbachev once again would not entertain such a possibility.
''To embark now on recarving the country's administrative and territorial map would mean only complicating what is already a difficult situation,'' he said.
Pointing to the tasks of the party congress, the 27th in the nation's history, the Soviet leader appeared concerned that the meeting not be an excuse for further procrastination. In the 13 months before the congress, he said, ''we should insure a turn for the better, especially concerning living standards,'' emphasizing that it is necessary to defuse tension in the nation's consumer marketplaces.
''Society is going through impetuous revolutionary change,'' he said. ''We cannot leave things as they are.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: BALTIC STATES (93%); LITHUANIA (92%); LATVIA (91%); ESTONIA (90%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Journal;
In a Quest For Profit, Beethoven Is Ousted

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The final anguished notes of the symphony still hung in the air as the announcer, Mary Fain, said, ''That was Tchaikovsky's 'Pathetique' Symphony, composed just a few months before his death, and played just a few hours before ours here at KFAC.''
KFAC-FM radio in Los Angeles is not dying. Indeed, its new general manager, James de Castro, sees a booming future for the station, which was recently bought by the Evergreen Media Corporation for $55 million, a price that reflects the robust health of the broadcasting industry.
What is dying is the station's classical music programming, a staple of Los Angeles's cultural life for 58 years but, all concerned agree, not much of a money earner these days for a commercial radio station. 
When KFAC switches to much more profitable rock music programming at lunch time on Wednesday, Los Angeles will be without a commercial classical music station - a sign of the times and perhaps of things to come as American cultural tastes evolve.
''We bought the station with the hope of staying classical,'' Mr. de Castro said, ''but unfortunately it was economically impossible to stay classical, because the advertising base is abandoning us.''
With Wednesday's switch to rock music, he said, ''more listeners will listen and more advertisers will buy advertising.''
''The sad fact is that the audience is not large enough to make classical music viable as a commercial enterprise,'' said Robert Goldfarb, the station's departing program director.
''I think this is part of a general trend where the arts just aren't self-sufficient anymore,'' he said. As with museums or symphony orchestras, ''classical music radio stations are not really a legitimate business that presents a reasonable return to investors.''
David Hostley, the station manager for KQED radio in San Francisco, which switched from classical to all-news programming two years ago, put it bluntly: ''The problem that is happening in the country with classical music audiences is that they are getting smaller and they are getting older.''
As a result, radio stations have abandoned classical music programming in recent years at cities around the nation, including Houston, Milwaukee and Salt Lake City.
In New York City, WNCN has been phasing in a new approach to classical music presentation since 1981, trying, in the words of Mario Mazza, the director of programming, ''to mainstream this radio station as much as possible and try to make classical music appealing to a much wider variety of people.''
Mr. Mazza's strategem is to hire pop music disc jockeys to present classical music, on the principle that ''it's easier to teach them how to say Shostakovich than to train classical people how to do contemporary radio.''
Banishing opera, organ music, the avant-garde and the atonal, WNCN is having success with what Mr. Mazza called ''lighter, peppier'' forms of classical music sprinkled with high-energy talk and comedy bits.
The fading of the classical music audience has spawned several theories, including the decline in music instruction at public schools and the deregulation of radio broadcasting, which has turned it into a more hard-nosed business.
At KUSC, the Los Angeles public radio station that will inherit much of KFAC's classical music audience, Ann Taylor, the director of public relations, blamed the pervasiveness of popular culture.
''When you have Michael Jackson selling tanker trucks full of Coke as part of the fiber of everybody's life,'' she said, ''people are more likely to have heard of Michael Jackson - and to see that he represents an important way of life - than they are to have heard of Beethoven, except that he rolled over.''
In its last days, KFAC has been broadcasting advertisements sponsored by KUSC that invite listeners to switch over after Wednesday. But the reminders that the end is near seemed to rattle Rich Capparela, a KFAC announcer, who said at one point today, ''Well, as always, an exciting time here at KFAC: we have a new weather forecast.''
Explaining his mood to his listeners, he said, ''It's that giddiness coming over the condemned just before they put the blindfold on and yell, 'Fire.' ''

HEADLINE: Our Sugar Protectionism Spurs Coca Growing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Orange Juice, Not Cocaine'' (Editorial Notebook, Sept. 3) observes that our protectionist policy actually protects the raw material for cocaine and proposes that we make oranges a more attractive crop to Bolivian farmers. Protectionist American farm policies have not only damaged the economies of Bolivia, Colombia and Peru, but have also helped fuel America's greatest social problem -drugs. It might be worth thinking about protectionism's human, as well as economic, consequences. 
Your suggestion of oranges as an ideal substitute for coca plants is good. I submit that there is a better one - sugar. In 1983, the United States imported more than 200,000 tons of sugar from Bolivia, Colombia and Peru. Today we import less than 85,000 tons. Because of our sugar subsidy and import quota program, these three countries have seen their sugar exports to the United States slashed. According to the Department of Commerce, Bolivia, Colombia and Peru have lost more than $100 million in revenue between 1983 and 1987 because of our sugar program.
In a Washington Monthly article two years ago, State Department officials warned the Reagan Administration that sugar farmers in tropical countries would practice an ''unfortunate style of crop diversification'' if sugar trade with the United States was cut. Diversify they did. Today, Colombia, Peru and Bolivia produce most of the cocaine coming into the United States.
On Sept. 5, President Bush announced his $8 billion solution to the drug problem, with more than $300 million for military and economic assistance to these countries. The assistance is, no doubt, needed. But it might just be beneficial if we thought about enabling these farmers to make an honest living. If we buy their sugar again, we'd give them a good start. And we'd make sugar cheaper for the American consumer.
Time, however, is running out. If we don't revamp our sugar program soon, Bolivia, Colombia and Peru (not to mention other countries that have traditionally exported sugar to the United States) could be cut out of the American market. Coca plants will be more attractive than ever. Clearly, just saying no to drugs could be a lot more effective if we said no more to the United States sugar program.
 
THOMAS J. DOWNEY
Member of Congress, 2d Dist., N.Y.
 Washington, Sept. 6, 1989
