HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
The Can't-Do Guy

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
President Bush says nothing can be done about these massacres.
It's too bad, they are terrible, he wishes they would stop, but we may as well face it, we are just going to have to put up with them.
Thus the President when pressed to say something about the latest slaughter by gent-with-AK-47, this one in Louisville.
This is Bush at his emptiest. Mass murders by lunatics having commando fantasies are not acts of God like death by lightning storms on summer afternoons. By suggesting that they are, Bush sounds indifferent to the eerie frequency with which acts of violent madness nowadays shatter the domestic tranquillity. 
He also sounds impatient with the idea that this is a problem that ought to engage a President. There is good political reason for him to be a little impatient, of course. He has the usual politician's terror of the gun lobby, and he knows that each new AK-47 slaughter produces a transient public demand for gun-control laws loathsome to the gun people.
Fortunately for politicians, each brief public impulse for controlling automatic combat weapons now fades faster than the one before as AK-47 massacre becomes commonplace. A President can only give one longer shelf life by expressing outrage at the bloodshed.
Better to deflect the enmity of the gun lobby by taking the dispiriting line that falling victim to gent-with-AK-47 is merely to suffer one of humanity's unfortunate random fates, alas. Some are felled by lightning, some by tornadoes, some by onsets of lunatic-with-AK-47. Legislation availeth naught against acts of God.
Maybe there is, in fact, little that the Government can do now to clear the streets of automatic combat weapons. Maybe it's too late, all the lunatics and gangsters and drug soldiers already too inexhaustibly armed.
No President can say so, however; it would make him sound practical. Americans do not want practical talk from Presidents; they want Presidents promising to do the impossible. Since this is precisely the kind of talk that would incense the gun lobby, Bush can only brush off each passing slaughter as a dreadful but natural phenomenon.
''Nothing can be done'' threatens to become the Bush Administration password. This was the first response to Lech Walesa's suggestion that Washington pitch in big dollars that might give Poland's new non-Communist governing majority a chance to rebuild their down-and-out economy.
The American $50 million offer was a way of saying, ''Nothing can be done.'' In Washington $50 million is hardly considered a sum worth picking up off the sidewalk.
Pressure from Congress now has the offer up to $100 million, which is a way of saying, ''Well, maybe a little can be done, but not much.''
So far the position on international arms control isn't much different from the position on domestic AK-47 control: ''Nothing can be done.'' Nothing at least is all that has been done despite strong evidence that the Soviets are eager for the kind of cuts we have wanted for years.
There is the ''war on drugs.'' It is all trumpet and high sentence. ''Plenty will be done,'' proclaim the official noise writers.
But money? Money? Come now, what money? If there is only a trifling $100 million to help Poland achieve what we've hoped for over a whole half-century, where in the world would we get money for our resolute war on drugs? Let the states produce the money, the cities. No new taxes, of course. Read lips. No taxes. Federally speaking, nothing can be done. Except noisewise of course. But stay! What is this? Speaking of taxes, something can be done. In fact, something is being done at this very instant!
Yes, the President is keeping his campaign promise to cut the capital gains tax. Moreover, the Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee are helping him. Both parties, eternally triumphant Republicans and eternally hopeless Democrats, are doing their best to get the limousines drawn up in a circle.
Talk about snouts in the trough, how about both parties conniving in this Treasury heist? Maybe nothing can be done about AK-47 onsets, about helping Poland escape Communism, about getting an arms control deal with the Russians, but when it comes to giving the well-heeled yet another tax break, these are can-do guys.
Their reason: until the rich get another tax break for investing their money in the great engines of American enterprise, capitalism will not have the energy to make America Number One again.
If you believe that, friend, nothing can be done.

HEADLINE: States Using Stiff Methods To Collect Child Support

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
Using strengthened Federal and state laws, New Jersey, Connecticut and New York are tracking down parents who fail to pay court-ordered child support and collecting the money by seizing their wages, intercepting tax refunds or putting the delinquents in jail until they pay.
In New Jersey, ranked as one of the toughest states in enforcing child support, many county sheriffs have taken advantage of Federal financial aid to hire officers exclusively for such cases and have rounded up delinquents in mass sweeps and jailed some.
In one of the more dramatic sweeps, in Monmouth County, Sheriff William Lanzaro dispatched 38 officers last month to serve warrants on 66 delinquent fathers. Thirty-six of them, owing a total of $217,000, were roused from sleep, led away in handcuffs and forced to sit in the county jail until they paid part of their debt. 
''It's called pay or stay, and they pay,'' said Raymond Rainville, chief of child-support enforcement services for New Jersey courts. ''It sounds too simple, but it works.''
 
Speedier Justice Sought
Under the Federal Child Support Enforcement Amendments of 1984, states were required to strengthen their enforcement procedures to qualify for Aid to Dependent Children grants. The amendments suggested speeding hearings through the use of officials other than judges.
In New Jersey these officials are called hearing officers, and they make recommendations to a judge. In Connecticut they are called family-support magistrates, and they recently received authority to incarcerate delinquent fathers.
The Federal Family Support Act of 1988 required states to have uniform child-support guidelines for judges to consider in awarding payments. Income and number of children, for example, would be considered under the guidelines.
Last year the House Ways and Means Committee rated the enforcement programs of the 50 states, and New Jersey officials note that their state ranked No. 2. New Jersey has increased collections from delinquent parents from $183 million in 1984 to $280 million projected for this year.
Only three states besides New Jersey received A ratings from the committee: Michigan, which was ranked first, Delaware, third, and North Dakota, fourth.
A spokeswoman for the New Jersey Department of Human Services, Mary Kay Risi, said: ''New Jersey is among states that are beginning to look at child-support enforcement as a law-enforcement issue and the violation of support orders as a crime. This wasn't the case in the past. One of the states that is using arrests and raids is Massachusetts.''
 
Pressure Through Jailing
In Monmouth County, failure to make child-support payments for two weeks usually leads to a bench warrant for arrest of the parent. After the arrest, each case is handled individually, said Jan Budnik, a principal probation officer for the county. ''If their history indicates they have a pattern of nonpayment, they can be kept in jail in an attempt to make them pay,'' he said.
The probation department gives the court the history of the case, and the judge determines how much partial payment is needed to obtain release from jail, Mr. Budnik said.
Of the 36 men arrested in the Monmouth sweep, 16 managed to pay their way to freedom by the end of the day and eight more did so by the next morning. But seven remained in jail after two weeks, and the last was not released until after three weeks, 'No Civil-Rights Issue'
Edward Martone, executive director of the New Jersey branch of the American Civil Liberties Union, said: ''I don't see any civil liberties implications in these sweeps. There is no civil-rights issue, but a law-enforcement issue, in that there is reasonable suspicion that these men are in violation of legitimate court orders.''
The raids have less to do with punishing delinquent parents than to impress on them that New Jersey is serious about collecting child support, officials said. Sheriff Lanzaro, whose first raid in February netted 22 men, said, ''We find that after we conduct raids, for weeks afterward, delinquent fathers come in voluntarily and the payments escalate.''
Other New Jersey counties that have conducted sweeps are Camden, Cape May, Gloucester, Morris, Ocean and Union, and still others are preparing to do so. Marion Reitz, director of the Division of Economic Assistance of the state's Department of Human Services, said 17 of the 21 counties in the state were now being reimbursed by the Federal Government for seeking collections under warrants.
Sheriff Lanzaro, said that he was able to hire a part-time secretary and two extra officers with the reimbursements and that he planned to hire a third officer.
 
Crackdowns Are Growing
New Jersey, with some 300,000 child-support cases, does not keep figures on the number of arrests for nonpayment of child support, said Mr. Rainville, the courts official. Neither does Connecticut, with 93,000 cases, or New York, with 776,000, so comparisons are difficult.
''We have about 90 arrest warrants a month,'' Sheriff Lanzaro said. ''Of these, we arrest 60 to 70 a month, and of the 20 remaining, about 10 will come in on their own and pay up.''
Neither Connecticut nor New York use the types of sweeps employed by New Jersey, officials in those states said, but they added that they, too, had been taking a harder line on delinquents.
They pointed to upgraded state laws in conformity with Federal standards. And New York was the first and Connecticut the third state to receive Federal certification and money for a computer system that links involved agencies in each state to help track delinquents.
 
Seizure of Funds and Property
In Connecticut, which was rated sixth by the House Ways and Means Committee, child-support collections have risen steadily each year to about $70 million this year, said Anthony DiNallo, director of the Bureau of Child Enforcement in the Connecticut Department of Human Resources.
Over 50 percent of collections come from seizing wages, he said, but in the last five years the interception of tax refunds and liens on property have increased total collections from $4.6 million to $11.8 million.
New York's total collections increased from $188 million in 1984 to $310 million projected for this year. Collections from tax refund intercepts alone have risen from $11.5 million in 1984 to $53 million projected for 1989.
Last spring New York began informing delinquent parents who owed more than $1,000 that they had 90 days to pay up or their debts would be reported to credit bureaus nationwide.

HEADLINE: Campaign Trail;
Giuliani Seeking D'Amato's Support

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
The D'Amato-Giuliani political minuet began yesterday and is likely to end later this week with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato pledging his support to Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose mayoral candidacy he tried to derail by backing Ronald S. Lauder in the Republican primary.
Mr. Giuliani called the Senator in Washington yesterday afternoon asking for his support. The call was timed to immediately precede a meeting between J. Patrick Barrett, the new Republican state chairman and Mr. Giuliani's dove-bearer, and the Senator in Washington.
''It was a very cordial conversation,'' said Mr. Giuliani, who added in response to a question that it was not a difficult task. Is the Senator's support that important? 
''All the support I can get is important,'' said Mr. Giuliani. ''I'm reaching out to a lot of people.''
Mr. Barrett acknowledged that he had urged Mr. Giuliani to call the Senator, and said he had asked the Senator to support Mr. Giuliani ''on the basis of party unity.'' That's a political way of saying you don't have to love him to endorse him.
The Senator told Mr. Barrett that he would talk with Mr. Lauder, who remains on the ballot as the Conservative Party's mayoral candidate, and issue a statement by the end of the week.
 
Lauder's Options
Mr. Lauder, meanwhile, is presumably waiting on Mr. D'Amato. Mr. Lauder's aides are predicting that he will not run a major campaign on the Conservative line, since that would put him in the position of opposing not just Mr. Giuliani but, more importantly, President Bush and national Republicans backing Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Lauder, a former ambassador and at one time a Defense Department official, may want another Federal job.
He cannot get off the Conservative Party line, leaving him the options of running a token campaign or endorsing Mr. Giuliani and running no campaign at all.
 
Panel Reviews Literature
Prodded by Evan Davis, counsel to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the State Commission on Government Integrity is examining campaign literature circulated by Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman in the Democratic primary for Brooklyn district attorney. The literature implied that Charles J. Hynes was a bigot because he has a summer home in Breezy Point, Queens, which is virtually all white. Mr. Hynes, who swamped Mr. Feldman in the primary, lives in an integrated area of Flatbush.
Most politicians believe that Mr. Feldman's literature, which also linked Mr. Hynes with homosexual groups, backfired; the Governor cited the literature as one reason he was breaking his usual neutrality in primaries and endorsing his longtime friend, Mr. Hynes. Religious and community leaders also condemned the literature.
The results in the primary also signaled that the literature did not work. Mr. Hynes won 15 of the 19 Assembly districts in the borough, sweeping predominantly black districts by ratios of as much as 5 to 1. The Democratic nomination virtually assures his election.
A commission press aide, Linda Sachs, acknowledged the commission's interest in the literature. She noted that the panel had in the past looked into campaign literature and called for legislation requiring identification of its sponsor. The commission has power only to make recommendations to the Legislature.
 
Cosby's Lasso
David N. Dinkins posted another first on Monday evening - a major fund-raiser at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. Almost all such events are held in midtown hotels. A mixed audience of about 1,400 people contributed $25 to $1,000 each for a total of at least $200,000 to help finance the Dinkins campaign and hear the comedian Bill Cosby.
Mr. Cosby came up with a humorous version of the show business hook for getting windy politicians off stage. As Mr. Dinkins spoke before the stage curtain, he was interrupted by a disembodied Cosby voice from behind the curtain: ''I'm getting very old back here.'' Mr. Dinkins got the message.
 
Message From Albany
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, not known for his political boldness, had some unsolicited fiscal advice for Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Dinkins yesterday while praising Mayor Edward I. Koch for his fiscal restraints.
Like a father lecturing his offspring on fiscal prudence, Mr. Regan wrote identical letters to both candidates warning them of hard times ahead. Mr. Regan, a Republican who may face a stiff challenge for re-election next year because of investigations of his fund-raising practices, wrote that the city faced budget gaps of $1.3 billion to more than $2 billion during the next mayoral term.
He pointed out that city residents already pay the highest state and municipal taxes in the country and that any more taxes in the city would ''impair its economic development.''
In short, watch those promises of pie in the sky, candidates.

HEADLINE: Methanol Defended as Option

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency responded today to oil and auto industry criticism of an important part of President Bush's clean air legislation by defending methanol as both an economically and environmentally sound fuel alternative to gasoline.
The agency said in a report that methanol prices would be competitive with gasoline at the pump, would not leave the nation more dependent on unreliable sources of imported energy and would reduce harmful auto emissions far more than any other pollution control program. The report also played down safety hazards associated with methanol, saying that all combustible fuels have risks. Methanol comes from various sources, including natural gas and coal, and is now used as a blending agent in gasoline. 
Also today, the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment began debating the Administration's clean air plan, and in its first vote narrowly rejected, 12 to 10, a compromise measure offered by its chairman, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California.
The Environmental Protection Agency's defense of methanol comes as the oil industry is mounting a public relations campaign against the alternative fuels provision in the President's proposed revisions of the Clean Air Act of 1970. Under the plan, one million vehicles powered by cleaner-burning alternative fuels would be introduced each year into the nation's nine most polluted cities after 1997.
 
Regulating Car Travel Rejected
The Administration asserts that expanding the use of alternative fuels, including methanol, is the only realistic way to reduce auto emissions significantly. Tighter auto pollution standards may be too expensive, while regulating the amount of car travel is not feasible, the White House says.
The oil industry supports studying the wider use of alternative fuels. But it contends that too little is known about the environmental effects of fuels like methanol to introduce them as widely as the President proposes. In addition, the industry says the Environmental Protection Agency has dramatically understated the eventual cost of methanol to the consumer.
There is ''no evidence'' methanol can be sold as cheaply as gasoline, Michael Canes, chief economist at the American Petroleum Institute, said today.
The oil industry has acknowledged that methanol produces less hydrocarbons, which contribute to smog. But its said methanol also generates more formaldehyde.
In its report today, the Environmental Protection Agency said more study is needed to determine the health effects of formaldehyde.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: CLEAN AIR ACT

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (89%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: US ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (94%); US ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (94%);

HEADLINE: Budget Roundup;
Senate Votes to Increase Limit On Mortgages Insured by U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Senate approved a measure tonight to raise the ceiling on mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration, making them more available to home buyers in high-cost areas.
The measure had set off sharp debate on the Senate floor, where opponents argued that the housing administration is already financially burdened and does not need additional risks. After several challenges to the original measure that would have eliminated the ceiling on insured mortgages, the Senate approved a compromise by voice vote.
Under current law, F.H.A.-insured mortgages can be obtained for amounts up to 95 percent of the median price of a house in an area. But there is also a flat dollar cap: a maximum of $101,250 in the highest cost areas. The measure approved tonight would raise that cap to $124,875. 
F.H.A.-insured mortgages can carry a number of benefits for home buyers, including lower down-payments and lower interest rates.
''My constituents are in need of this legislation,'' said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who argued on behalf of the original measure.
But those who opposed eliminating the cap asserted the measure benefited the wealthy and was an additional burden for the agency. ''If there ever was a fat-cat provision, this is it,'' said Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.
The Bush Administration also expressed strong opposition, citing ''dramatic increases'' in defaults in recent years.
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, tried to amend the legislation to replace the cap at a level of $118,000, but the Senate voted 50 to 49 to table his amendmement. Mr. Nickles and other opponents of the bill urged the Senate to delay action until the completion this fall of a report on the health of the F.H.A. by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.
Ultimately, however, the $124,875 ceiling was approved.
An Administration spokeswoman said, ''We generally supported the compromise although we still feel it's premature to make any recommendation about the F.H.A. until we've completed an actuarial review.''
The housing provision is part of a $67.2 billion spending bill for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Veterans Administration and other agencies. Like other spending bills, the measure is stalled in the Senate because of the struggle over financing President Bush's drug strategy.
 
Automatic Cuts Loom
House Republican leaders warned today that the deficit reduction package, which Congress has to pass by Oct. 16, had become so laden with contentious measures unrelated to the budget that there was a serious danger the measure would not be approved by the deadline.
If Congress fails to meet that deadline, the 1987 deficit reduction law imposes an automatic, across-the-board spending cut that would take an estimated $8 billion out of military programs and another $8 billion from a variety of such popular domestic programs as education, subsidized housing, space, veterans affairs and environmental protection.
''We now have a real danger of sequestration,'' said Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, using the formal name for the automatic spending cut procedure. ''There is a real danger that we end up with a complicated bill in the House, which then has to go to the Senate, and at just that time, the Senate has scheduled a weeklong recess.''
Among the measures now attached to the deficit-reduction package are proposals for increasing Federal assistance for child care services, modifications for the health insurance law to cover the catastrophic costs of illness. The deficit reduction package also includes the cut in capital gains taxes approved by the House Ways and Means Committee last week.
 
Rostenkowski Is Blamed
Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, reasserted the party's opposition to a cut in the capital gains tax today, describing it as an issue that ''we ought to have a line drawn in the sand about.'' He also laid some fault for its approval by the House Ways and Means Committee at the feet of the powerful committee chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat.
''He has to bear some of the responsibility,'' Mr. Brown said at a breakfast meeting with reporters. ''On this issue, there'll probably be a lot of finger-pointing going on. There already has been.''

HEADLINE: Storm Cut Across the Economic Lines

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R. Sept. 19

 BODY:
The two extremes of San Juan's social spectrum - the shantytowns of the poor and the oceanfront condominiums of the wealthy - appeared to suffer the most from the hurricane that swept across Puerto Rico on Monday.
Most of the roofs were missing in an oceanside cluster of shanties at the base of a steep hill in Old San Juan. Wet mattresses lay on the beach, and in some cases, whole houses were blown hollow.
''I have no clothes, no furniture,'' Ivette Riverso, the mother of two children, aged 2 and 4, said as she stood in what had been her house. ''My children! I don't know what we'll do.'' 
Across town on Condado Beach, an enclave of expensive hotels and apartments and stores that is to San Juan what Fifth Avenue is to New York, damage was among the most extensive in the city.
Whole apartments and shops were blown out. High-rise hotels in Condado and high-rise office buildings in Hato Rey, the financial center, look like checkerboards, with some windows blown out and others intact. In some sections, store owners reported looting.
''The neighbors said they saw the kids hiding and waiting for the storm to get bad so they could break in,'' said Adone Crudeli, who owns a shop on chic Ashford Avenue in Condado. ''But they're not going to do me in. I spent 20 years as a bridge painter in New York; I know how to survive.''
 
No Water or Electricity
In other ways the storm affected nearly all of Puerto Rico's 3.3 million residents. Much of island, for instance, was without water or electricity today.
Some fire hydrants were labeled as sources of drinking water, but the water that came out was brown. Officials broadcast warnings that all water was to be boiled before drinking. While insults about not bathing were the running joke in Puerto Rico, today's joke will soon become a crisis, because it was not clear when or how water would be restored.
''What am I supposed to do with three small kids?'' Carlos Lopez, 38 years old, asked a police officer in Old San Juan. ''What are they going to drink? How long do you think we can go?''
Officials said it would take at least three days to restore electricity. Bright white-and-red tape marked downed wires to make them easier for repair workers to spot. Stores, offices and schools remained closed. Some Areas Unscarred A few neighborhoods of San Juan, a city of 945,000 people that is Puerto Rico's capital, were virtually untouched. But in most, windows of houses, businesses and cars were shattered. In some sections, furniture dangled from floors where walls had been blown away.
Over all, officials said 10,000 people were left homeless, and they estimated damage at hundreds of millions of dollars.
The American Red Cross estimated that 25,000 people were staying in its emergency shelters in the eastern part of the island.
The island's Agriculture Department reported that in the area around Utuado, 80 percent of Puerto Rico's coffee crop was destroyed. In addition, virtually the entire ornamental-plant industry, poinsettias and orchids, for example, was lost.
The Puerto Rican Government appealed to President Bush today for disaster assistance that would provide direct aid to the homeless and loans to businesses.
Many major highways in San Juan were cleared of debris over night with the help of 1,500 National Guardsmen, but many side streets here as well as main roads in the countryside remain blocked by trees, abandoned cars or shards of glass. Many palm trees have lost all their fronds, looking like giant dandelions that had had their white heads blown off.
 
Fishing Villages Damaged
Coast Guard and civilian defense officials said some of the worst damage was on two islands just off Puerto Rico, Vieques and Culebra. They also said some fishing villages on the central and southeastern coast, like Maunabo, had been severely damaged.
Rescuers had not yet able to reach many remote areas, because of roads blocked by water and debris. The Coast Guard said a medical team that arrived on Vieques found that no residents had been killed in the storm but some had been injured. It said virtually all wooden structures have been knocked down.
In Humacao, civil defense officials said, the third, fourth, fifth and sixth floors of the hospital had been destroyed. But no one was injured because the floors had been evacuated.
Still rattled by the hurricane and finding themselves in hotels without electricity and water, tourists clambered to leave Puerto Rico. But officials at the airport here, which suffered damage to its control devices, said it was unlikely to reopen until at least Thursday.
Over all, officials said there had been four deaths in Puerto Rico, the same figures they gave on Monday. Two of the deaths were sailors aboard a research vessel that sank in San Juan Harbor. They said the low number of deaths and apparently low number of injuries was because unlike some tourists in San Juan, residents of rural areas had taken the hurricane warnings very seriously.
''We're not hearing of fatalities or large groups of injuries,'' said Lieut.
Dan Whiting of the Coast Guard. ''I think people were prepared. But we still don't know the full extent of this yet. If they're out there, we may just be starting to hear what's really happened.''

HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
Brecht-Weill 'Mahagonny,' Set in 20's Hollywood

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The Los Angeles Music Center Opera, which in its first three seasons has brought home-grown, big-time opera to this city for the first time, has a penchant for splashy, flashy productions. The opening pair of fall operas consists of a ''Tosca'' with Maria Ewing, conducted by Placido Domingo, and a new staging of the Brecht-Weill ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny'' directed by Dr. Jonathan Miller, designed by Robert Israel and conducted by Kent Nagano.
For the ''Mahagonny,'' Dr. Miller and the company apparently raised a few hackles by announcing that the setting would be Hollywood in the 1920's and that the ''dated'' aspects of the original would be modified. In fact, the Hollywood references were fairly subtle and altogether appropriate, given Brecht's fascination with things mythically American. And while one missed the grim procession of Communist protest signs at the end, as in the Metropolitan Opera's version, the bitterness and anachronisms, if you choose to call them that, of the original conception were left pretty much intact. 
That's not to say that the performance, seen Sunday afternoon, didn't have its flaws. Chief among them was Michael Feingold's English translation. The kindest thing to be said about it is that Mr. Feingold was perhaps attempting to echo Brecht's own pidgin English. But the recurrent awkward slang, curious constructions (''I've eaten two calves head to crupper'') and clumsy prosody, most of it mirrored redundantly in the supertitles, provoked persistent and inadvertent laughter.
Other problems included some of Mr. Nagano's tempos and a curious blankness to Dr. Miller's staging. This operatic inflation of the original ''Mahagonny Songspiel'' (seen last spring at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a Peter Sellars production) fluctuates between cabaret-style spunkiness and grander proclamations. Sometimes, in emphasizing the operatic, Mr. Nagano sounded so slow and grave that the action almost ground to a halt. But elsewhere he was livelier, and achieved a nice grim climax at the end.
The hints of Hollywood came mostly in Mr. Israel's handsome if often cluttered sets, with their intimations of a back lot. But the ''concept'' wasn't rammed home to the point of crudeness. Still, except for a graphic flair in the calf-eating scene (here Dr. Miller's anatomical expertise came in handy), the direction seemed more stiff and dispassionate than involved, which didn't help much with an already formalistic opera.
That said, much of the individual acting was affecting within Brecht's constrained emotional terms, the singing (apart from the unfortunate absence of true low basses among the soloists) was solid, and the playing of the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra was accomplished.
Of the singers, the best was Gary Bachlund as Jimmy - a handsome presence and a real heroic tenor. Anna Steiger, outfitted by Mr. Israel to look like the ingenue Lillian Gish, made a sweet if not very charismatic Jenny, and Marvellee Cariaga, despite an awkward register break, flounced about imperiously as Leocadia Begbick. Other parts were taken by, among others, Michael Gallup, Jonathan Mack and Louis Lebherz.
This production will be seen subsequently at the Kentucky Opera and, most likely, the Geneva Opera and the Lyons Opera, where Mr. Nagano is music director.

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
Consumer prices were unchanged in August, the first time in more than three years that the Consumer Price Index did not rise, the Labor Department reported. Economists regarded the report as somewhat encouraging because it showed that inflation was not as serious a problem as it seemed earlier in the year. [Page A1.] Consumer prices in the New York area rose by two-tenths of 1 percent, with higher prices for apparel, housing, food and beverages said to account for much of the rise. [D5.] 
Housing construction fell by 5 percent in August, depressed by a jump in mortgage rates, the Government reported. [D1.]
The E.P.A. defended methanol as both an economically and environmentally sound alternative to gasoline. The agency was responding to industry criticism of the Bush clean-air plan. [B6.]

Campeau said it had reached agreement for a $250 million loan that will help ease a cash crunch at its nine department store divisions in the U.S. The agreement will also greatly reduce the power of Robert Campeau, its chairman and founder. [D1.]

A bacterial process can reduce PCB's in rivers and lakes by more than 70 percent in four to eight weeks, scientists say. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Campeau Wraps Up Loan Pact

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Resolving a weeklong financial crisis, the Campeau Corporation said yesterday in Toronto that it had reached a definitive agreement for a $250 million loan that would help ease a cash shortage at its nine department store divisions in the United States.
The agreement will also significantly reduce the power of Robert Campeau, the dynamic chairman and founder of the Toronto-based development and retail company who borrowed heavily to take over the United States stores. And it will increase the power of the Reichmann family, owners of Olympia & York Developments, another large Canadian developer that already owns 24.5 percent of Campeau and is providing the loan.
The loan will provide working capital for the Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Stern's stores on the Eastern Seaboard, among others around the country, where fears had risen that suppliers' reluctance to deliver goods would affect business for the fall and Christmas seasons.
 
Release of Supplies Expected
However, various executives said yesterday that the loan agreement, as well as new proposed ''bridge'' financing, would quickly release withheld supplies. 
Two weeks ago, Campeau put its 17-store Bloomingdale's chain up for sale to raise funds for repayment of its debts. The amount of debt, largely in the form of ''junk bonds,'' that Mr. Campeau took on to finance his retailing purchases, has been blamed for his current troubles, and the junk bond market was roiled last week by the news of the cash problems. Yesterday, however, word that the corporation had reached an agreement with creditors contributed to a rally in the junk-bond market, participants said. [Page D14.] 250 Department Stores Involved Campeau announced that as part of the agreement, Mr. Campeau would voluntarily step down as chief executive of the company's American arm and be succeeded by an as-yet-unnamed individual. That person, and a new chief financial officer to be selected, will have the primary responsibility of supervising Campeau's 250 cash-poor American department stores and restructuring them to obtain maximum shareholder value.
Mr. Campeau will retain his title as chairman and chief executive of the parent company but will concentrate his efforts on the real estate business.
The agreement and accompanying changes announced by Campeau came after several days of marathon negotiations in Toronto between it and Olympia & York, Citibank, the Scotia Bank and other lenders.
The cash infusion to Campeau by Olympia & York will keep Campeau solvent and allow it to restructure its own financial affairs and those of its two American retail subsidiaries, Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores. Campeau's crisis began a week ago when it reported that those subsidiaries had insufficient cash for operations and were unable to meet debts coming due last week.
The changes announced yesterday, including a projected increased stake of about 10 percent for Olympia & York in Campeau as a result of its loan, signify a sharply expanded role for the Reichmann brothers, Paul and Albert, whose family owns that company. Olympia & York and Campeau will each have three representatives on a newly appointed 10-member board of Campeau, along with four others representing minority and public shareholders.
The company also announced that a new restructuring committee would be set up to increase shareholder value from existing assets. It will be headed by Lionel G. Dodd, chief operating officer of Olympia & York Enterprises. Mr. Dodd was a member of the previous Campeau board and will be on the new one.
However, in a telephone interview yesterday afternoon from Toronto, Mr. Campeau insisted that both his group and Olympia & York's would be running the company ''50-50'' on the basis of the similar number of seats on the new Campeau board. ''I am delighted that we have decided to bring Olympia & York more prominently into the picture,'' Mr. Campeau said. ''And the loan wil bring about the needed liquidity and enable us to preserve our company.''
 
No Comment From Reichmanns
Neither of the Reichmann brothers could be reached to comment.
Campeau said that the restructuring committee intended to hire Merrill Lynch to assist in the financial restructuring plan and to name McKinsey & Company as retailing consultant. In addition to naming Mr. Dodd chairman, the four-member restructuring committee includes Robert J. Butler, former president of Eaton's department stores in Canada and a director of various companies; G. William Miller, a previous Campeau director and former United States Treasury Secretary, and Ronald E. Tysoe, Campeau president.
The new board consists of three Campeau representatives, Mr. Campeau, Mr. Tysoe and Byron Allumbaugh, the chairman of Ralph's Grocery Company, a supermarket chain in California that Campeau also owns. The three Olympia & York representatives are Mr. Dodd; Albert Reichmann, president of Olympia & York, and Gilbert Newman, an Olympia & York executive. The four representatives of minority shareholders are Mr. Butler; Mr. Miller; Robert Despres, president of DRM Holdings, Quebec, and Conrad Black, principal shareholder in Hollinger Inc., a Canadian communications company.
Reports that pressure was brought to bear on Mr. Campeau to downgrade his role emerged during negotiations between Campeau and Olympia & York and other lenders, such as Citibank. Both Citibank and Olympia & York were said to have insisted on a new chief executive and chief financial officer for the American stores. In addition, the new restructuring committee, while it will report to the directors, will have considerable authority to develop its strategy independent of Mr. Campeau, financial sources in Toronto said.
Mr. Campeau said that he would now concentrate on real estate, where ''my background shows that I have always had a conservative approach to financing.'' In previous interviews, he had said that ''real estate is really my true love.''
 
'Junk Bond Fever' Cited
He said that he had followed that policy in 1986 when he bought Allied Stores, his first American retail acquisition, issuing bonds to pay 10 1/2 percent. But he said that he had got swept up in the ''junk bond fever'' when he acquired Federated Department Stores in May of last year, agreeing to pay 16 1/2 percent on the bonds.
The firm agreement with Olympia & York will loosen up withheld shipments from suppliers who began last Thursday to curtail their deliveries as the cash shortage developed at the Federated/Allied stores, according to Kurt Barnard, publisher of the Barnard Retail Marketing Newsletter.
Already yesterday, the Leslie Fay Company, an apparel maker that had suspended shipments last week to the Campeau stores, began resuming deliveries, said Alan Golub, president of the company's dress division.
Walter F. Loeb, senior analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, said, ''Not only will the agreement restore credibility for the Campeau stores, but it will also tend to remove the threat of heavy markdowns for those stores, and probably others, because it will stabilize sales.''
Under the loan agreement, funds up to $150 million will be furnished to Federated Department Stores, which operates Bloomingdale's, A.&S., Stern's and other stores, and $100 million to Allied Stores, which operates the Bon Marche in Seattle, Jordan Marsh in Miami and Boston and Maas Brothers in Tampa.
 
Olympia & York Gets Warrants
For the loan, Olympia & York will receive warrants entitling it to purchase common shares of Campeau. Up to 15,625,000 such shares may be purchased at a price of $16 (U.S.) per share at any time up until Sept. 18, 1991. And Olympia & York has the right to apply the proceeds from the $250 million loan to the purchase of those shares.
Olympia & York will be able to increase its current 24.5 percent stake to about 35 percent, while Mr. Campeau's holdings will drop to about 46 percent, from 56 percent.
In another move analysts considered significant, Olympia & York agreed to use its ''reasonable best efforts,'' Campeau said, to arrange bridge financing for Campeau of about $800 million. The financing is intended to help the company until it sells Bloomingdale's.
The bridge loan is also conditioned on Campeau's repurchase of 75 percent of its outstanding debt issued by Allied and Federated at prices not above those of last Friday. Olympia & York has also committed to provide a portion of the bridge financing if necessary, Campeau said.
 
New Terms on Debt
In other agreements reported by Campeau, Federated received new terms on some of its debt. Federated defaulted last Friday on $401.3 million in notes held by three investment banks, which thereby obtained 6.96 percent of Federated stock. But Federated has the right to redeem the notes next year and receive the stock.
Some doubts persisted, however, that Campeau's financing problems were over. George Hartman, an analyst for Brown Baldwin Nixer in Toronto, said: ''They have bought themselves some extra time through Christmas. From what I can tell from the details of the loan and the warrants, the Reichmanns may feel that the company has lots of breakup value.''
In the interview, Mr. Campeau denied widespread belief yesterday that the appointment of a restructuring committee meant the company would sell more of its stores.
''The restructuring is necessary, but we plan to sell no other stores,'' he said. ''The Bloomingdale's sale and the bridge loan are sufficient to do the restructuring.''
This, however, contradicts strong reports this week that Campeau directly or through its investment adviser, the First Boston Corporation, had been negotiating to sell its 39 Bon Marche stores on the West Coast to a Japanese company but that the deal fell through.
''All our sources indicate that whatever can be sold at Federated/Allied will be sold, but some of them can't be easily financed because of insufficient cash flow,'' said Edwin J. Berkowitz, division president at Wesley, Brown & Bartle.
Janet Mangano, research director at Josephthal & Company in New York, said, ''I see more asset sales, even though there will be greater access to capital markets now'' where the company can borrow to help raise cash for its operations.

HEADLINE: August Home Construction Dropped 5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Housing construction, depressed by a jump in mortgage rates, fell by 5 percent in August, the Government said today in a report many analysts viewed as only a temporary setback for the housing industry.
The Commerce Department said new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.35 million units last month, down from 1.42 million in July.
It was the first decline since May and the largest setback since a 12.7 percent fall last February. Housing starts had risen 1.3 percent in July and 7.5 percent in June. 
 
Rates Now at 10.05 Percent
Fixed mortgage rates, which peaked at 11.22 percent in March, had fallen to 9.68 percent by Aug. 4, but then rose by about half a percentage point through August. However, in recent weeks they have begun edging down slightly, now standing at 10.05 percent, according to the weekly survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Economists predicted continued small declines for the rest of the year and said this should bolster sales and construction figures.
''The housing starts numbers show builders were waiting out the recent uptick in interest rates'' in August, said John Tuccillo, chief economist of the National Association of Realtors. ''However, the higher rate of building permits is a good sign that the stalled activity in August is only temporary.''
Overall applications for building permits, considered a good barometer of future activity, rose by 3.5 percent after falling by 2.1 percent in July.
David Seiders, chief economist of the National Association of Home Builders, said the drop in construction and another report today showing that consumer prices did not rise in August should persuade the Federal Reserve to stop fighting inflation and resume lowering interest rates to bolster the economy.
However, other economists said they doubted that the weak construction number would prompt action on the part of the Fed, given the fact that other statistics showed that the economy was continuing to grow at a healthy rate.
 
Starts Rebounded in June
Construction starts fell earlier this year for four straight months before rebounding in June, the longest string of declines since activity slowed for five months in a row from February through June 1987. The May level of 1.31 million starts was the slowest pace since the 1.30 million rate in December 1982.
Total housing starts during the first eight months of the year are down 4.7 percent from the corresponding period of 1988.
Construction of single-family homes last month fell 2.5 percent, to an annual rate of one million units. Single-family starts had risen 5.9 percent in July after falling five-tenths of 1 percent in June.
Apartment construction fell 11.4 percent in August, to an annual rate of 350,000 units. It fell by 9 percent in July after rising 31.1 percent in June.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fighting Cocaine, Coffee, Flowers

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
EVEN as President Bush cheers Colombia's brave effort to stamp out exports of cocaine, others in the Administration are making it more difficult for Colombians to profit from exports of coffee and cut flowers.
Colombian farmers, driven from these legal markets, are not likely to turn to cultivating coca. Indeed, they could not: the soil and weather conditions in coffee and flower-growing regions are not right for coca.
But these two crops are crucial sources of export earnings for Colombia. It seems an inopportune moment to make life more difficult for the nation's legitimate farmers and deprive the struggling nation of foreign exchange. 
Colombia does not grow much of the raw material used to make cocaine; it imports most of it from Peru and Bolivia. But the Medellin cartel controls most of the world's cocaine-manufacturing capacity.
Much of the estimated $1.5 billion earned from cocaine is invested abroad and never finds its way back to Colombia, points out Peter Reuter, an economist at the Rand Corporation. But enough certainly does to provide work for tens of thousands in the city of Medellin, and to provide hundreds of millions of dollars to offset the country's bills for imports and foreign debt.
Thus if current attempts to disrupt the cocaine trade are successful, Colombia, with a per capita income just one-fifteenth that of the United States, will be even harder pressed to met basic human needs. That is why American positions on coffee and flowers can make a significant difference.
Colombia and the United States are both members of the International Coffee Agreement, a 74-nation group of producers and consumers that regulates coffee prices by regulating total exports. According to Takamasa Akiyama, an economist at the World Bank, the group has successfully stabilized prices in recent years, But in July the agreement collapsed when the organization refused to meet American demands. There was some reason for the demands, but rather than negotiate further, the United States pulled out.
The United States delegation wanted an increase in export quotas for higher-quality arabica coffees, which Americans consume in disproportionate quantities. And it wanted tougher policing of exporters that cheat on the quotas: Mexico, Guatemala and Indonesia have reportedly been secretly selling their surpluses to Eastern bloc countries at half the price they charge the United States.
But the demands were bitterly opposed by Brazil, the largest coffee producer. And the Bush Administration has chosen to play hard ball, brushing aside pleas from President Virgilio Barco of Colombia for a one-year extension of the current terms. Prices have fallen by one-third, reducing Colombia's expected earnings this year by $400 million.
American moves to block Colombian exports of cut flowers are probably less damaging - but also harder to defend in economic terms.
Colombia is the South Korea of flower exporters, having doubled foreign sales to $200 million in the last decade by producing efficiently and pioneering distribution through supermarkets. American flower growers have not directly suffered because total American demand is up sharply. But the Colombians have grabbed most of the growth in the market. And the American industry is fighting back, charging the Colombians with illegal dumping.
Dumping, or selling below cost in some export markets, seems implausible on its face: Virtually all Colombian flowers are sold in a single market, America. If many of Colombia's 200 private flower exporters are not making money, it is hard to understand why they keep expanding production.
But American trade law gives the Commerce Department broad discretion in defining and measuring dumping. And, stung by accusations during the Reagan years that it blindly favored free trade, the department has been bending over backwards to find ways to support the home team.
Flower importers, who have been paying counter-dumping fees of 4.4 percent since 1987 as a hedge against an adverse final ruling in the case, now fear that the department will force them to pay tens of millions in duties on flowers that were sold over the last year. Were that to happen, the distribution network would probably break up, and dozens of Colombian flower exporters would be ruined.
Colombia does not need cocaine to prosper, but it does need a rapid growth in export earnings. Blocking the country's attempts to expand legal exports may be forcing Colombians to choose between drugs and poverty.

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Questions Foreign Airline Deals

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that the Bush Administration had serious questions about the increasing number of foreign investments in United States airlines, even when the foreign partners buy stakes smaller than the 25 percent legal limit.
''I will keep an eagle eye on these transactions,'' said Mr. Skinner, who is reviewing the recently negotiated European acquisitions of stakes in Northwest Airlines and United Airlines.
British Airways is acquiring a 15 percent stake in United. And KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, which contributed $400 million to the partnership acquiring Northwest, could eventually raise its stake to 20 percent by exercising warrants. Other foreign airlines have also arranged deals with airlines in the United States, including Swissair with Delta Air Lines and Scandinavian Airline System with Texas Air. 
Mr. Skinner, in a speech to international airline officials in Washington, provided the latest sign of the Transportation Department's worries over the changing structure of the airline industry. His aides had billed the speech as a significant policy address, but he raised many questions without providing firm answers to them.
Citing safety considerations and competition, he said he was troubled by the rising debt being accrued by airlines in the recent transactions.
''I will not allow excessive debt in the airline industry to jeopardize the public interest,'' he said. ''Debt-ridden airlines, forced to adopt sweeping austerity measures, may unwittingly threaten the safety of the traveling public.''
At the same time, he said, heavily indebted airlines would be more likely to go bankrupt or to lose market share during an economic recession, reducing the level of competition.
Mr. Skinner said he held ''the very strong presumption that the marketplace knows more about the proper capitalization of business than do government regulators.'' It is widely believed that he will allow the Northwest takeover to proceed. He said he had already made up his mind on the matter but refused to disclose his decision.
His remarks coincided with hearings before committees in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, in which lawmakers are looking into concentration and competition in the airline industry.
On the issue of foreign ownership, Mr. Skinner cited several concerns:
* Might minority investors exercise control over a highly indebted airline that has just been through a leveraged buyout?
* Would American negotiators be compromised in bargaining over international routes, which are agreed to by governments, when a foreign airline is involved on both sides of the talks?
* Would international competition or national security be affected?
Although he said he believed in the principle of open investment, he said, ''To extol the virtues of a free market for the flow of airline capital without reference to the highly restricted market in which international airlines operate would be to ignore reality.''

HEADLINE: Costs in New York Area Rose by 0.2% in August

 BODY:
Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area rose by two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the regional bureau of the Labor Department reported yesterday.
Higher prices for apparel, housing, food and beverages accounted for much of the rise, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commisioner of labor statistics.
Last month's rise, in line with increases of one-tenth of 1 percent in July and two-tenths in June, contrasts with rises that ranged from five-tenths to 1 percent in the first five months of the year. It also contrasts with the national report, which showed the price index unchanged in August. Mr. Ehrenhalt said the difference was a result of the earlier appearance of fashion lines in New York compared to the rest of the country. 
 
Steamroller 'Losing Steam'
The slowdown in the New York area rises indicates that ''the inflation steamroller we saw earlier in the year is rapidly losing steam,'' Mr. Ehrenhalt added.
The rise in apparel prices, which is common in August with the introduction of fall clothing lines, was based on a 4.9 percent increase in women's and girls' clothing prices and a 1.6 percent increase in footwear prices. Boys' and men's apparel prices, however, were down by 1.1 percent.
Housing prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, largely reflecting a five-tenths increase in homeowners' costs.
Reflecting the same trend as in the national report, the largest declines were in energy prices, which were down 1.2 percent. Gasoline prices were down 2.3 percent, the largest drop in three years, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. Combined with a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent in gasoline prices in July, the recent declines constrast sharply with the 13.5 percent increase in the first half of the year.
 
Private Transportation Down
Also reflecting the decline in gasoline prices, private transportation prices dropped by four-tenths of 1 percent. But public transportation was up by three-tenths.
Prices for meats, poultry, fish, eggs and dairy products all increased by six-tenths of 1 percent. Most other food products, including cereals and bakery goods, were up moderately, but fruits and vegetables declined by seven-tenths.
Prices of medical care rose by six-tenths of 1 percent, and entertainment prices increased by eight-tenths.

HEADLINE: Brazil Skips Loan Payment

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Brazil, the third world's biggest debtor, skipped an important interest payment Monday, joining a growing list of Latin American countries in arrears on debt.
Bankers in New York said Brazil had failed to pay $1.6 billion of interest due on loans from commercial banks. The interest bill was due on Monday, and Brazil's Finance Minister, Mailson Nobrega, has said repeatedly that Brazil will not be able to pay unless it receives fresh financing from abroad. Since the minister made his comments, Brazil has not received any new loans.
A Finance Ministry spokesman simply referred to the minister's statements when asked whether Brazil had paid the interest due to banks. ''Any delays do not mean a suspension of payments nor the declaration of a moratorium,'' the spokesman said.
Mr. Nobrega himself was at a Latin American financial meeting at Cancun, Mexico.
Brazil's huge $110 billion foreign debt has served to push up the internal debt, in turn fueling inflation, economists say.

HEADLINE: Angola Is Admitted to the World Bank and I.M.F.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Angola joined the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank today, despite objections by the United States, which earlier this summer cast the only vote against its membership.
Angola said that it would not only seek aid from the two global finance organizations but that it was also reaching out for American investment.
Membership in the two organizations could open the door to hundreds of millions of dollars in loans as well as technical assistance for the African nation, which is ruled by the Marxist People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola, or M.P.L.A.
''Angola is a country that will necessarily need assistance,'' Finance Minister Augusto Teixeira de Matos said at a news conference at the World Bank today shortly after signing membership documents. ''To leave Angola alone and weakened now would be a disaster for the West.'' 
 
Reform Program
He said Angola had embarked on significant market-oriented economic reforms, including freeing prices and revamping the banking system. He indentified oil, fishing, agriculture and transportation as promising areas for investment.
Angola's membership could also strengthen the M.P.L.A.'s hand in the 14-year-old civil war with the forces of Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita.
Treasury and State Department officials declined to comment, but a Republican staff member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee observed that until national reconciliation had been achieved ''it would be crazy for Americans to invest'' in Angola. The United States refuses to recognize the M.P.L.A. Government.
A cease-fire in the civil war, which was negotiated in December, recently broke down. Monday, Mr. Savimbi failed to show up at an eight-nation African peace meeting in Zaire because of what were reported to be wide differences between him and President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola.
At today's news conference Mr. Matos said the first loans his Government would seek would be for rebuilding the county's war-shattered infrastructure.
He also said that Angola, which has a total debt of $6.3 billion, had had trouble meeting debt service payments and had recently entered into rescheduling agreements with both the Soviet Union and Western Governments.
He said the entire $2.5 billion that Angola owes to Moscow has been rescheduled over 15 years and that $400 million of debt to Western Governments was recently rescheduled over 10 years.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Griffin Proposal To Cost Investors

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
LESS than a year after raising $325 million in the ''junk bond'' market, Merv Griffin yesterday proposed a reorganization of Resorts International that will leave bondholders with substantial losses but holding a 25 percent equity stake in the troubled casino company.
The proposal, which is viewed as an attempt to recapitalize Resorts without going into bankruptcy court, got a hostile reception from some analysts. ''If I were the bondholders, I wouldn't accept the recap plan,'' said Lee S. Isgur, an analyst with Paine Webber. ''I'd try to force it into bankruptcy and see what I could get.'' 
Resorts noted grimly that unless the plan was approved by the bondholders and put in place quickly, there was ''a significant likelihood'' that both Resorts and Griffin Resorts, its subsidiary, would be forced into bankruptcy.
The plan, proposed by Resorts and its investment banker, Salomon Brothers, offers bondholders a combination of new subordinated secured debt due in 1999 and some cash and common stock in exchange for Resorts' junior and senior debt.
Mr. Griffin took control of Resorts last fall as part of a complicated deal that left Donald Trump in control of the Taj Mahal, an uncompleted casino.
The proposed reorganization demonstrates just how risky it can be to buy bonds based not on cash flow but on reported asset values. Less than a year ago, when Mr. Griffin was taking over Resorts, his new company, Griffin Resorts, went to the junk bond market to raise $325 million. The company already had $600 million of junk debt on its books.
The pitch for the Griffin Resorts bonds last year was not on the company's cash flow. Resorts has been an poor performer in the Atlantic City casino business and said it would not have enough cash, at least in the first year, to meet its interest obligations. But buyers were assured that the bonds were senior to the previous Resorts debt, meaning they would have first claim on the company's assets, and that no matter what happened, there was clearly enough collateral. By the second year, the company expected business to improve enough to cover the needed interest payments.
The reorganization eliminates the right of Griffin Resorts security owners to get cash interest payments, offers a lower rate of interest to be paid in more paper and raises the possibility of up to a 30 percent capital loss if all does work out.
At that, the holders of Griffin Resorts paper are doing better than holders of the Resorts International paper. But better in this case is still poor.
For those who bought Griffin Resort first mortgage notes at par, with a 13 7/8 percent coupon just a year ago, the plan is to give them an equal face value of new 10 percent notes. The notes pay interest in more notes and, if Resorts can come up with the cash, can be redeemed at 70 percent of par value through the end of next year and at smaller discounts thereafter.
The owners of Griffin Resorts' 13.5 percent senior reset notes, who were supposed to have bonds with an interest rate to be reset to insure the bonds traded above par in October 1990. Instead, they will get the same 10 percent rate and the same possibility of being called at a sharp discount to par value.
If any holders of Griffin Resorts paper choose not to convert, they will lose the collateral backing up those securities, the company said.
For holders of Resorts International bonds, which were outstanding before Mr. Griffin took over, the proposal is to give them new bonds, some cash and some stock in the new company.
Depending on the issue, for each each $1,000 principal amount of the Resorts bonds, holders will get at least $571.64 and as much as $686.85 in new bonds, paying a below-market interest rate of 7 percent for the first three years and 8 percent thereafter. For the first five years, interest could be paid in new bonds, rather than in cash. Such bonds would be expected to trade at sharp discounts to their nominal value. Assuming that all of the bonds are exchanged, the company said it would issue $377.7 million in new bonds.
In addition, the bondholders would be paid from $81.66 to $98.12 in cash per $1,000 old bond, and would get 14 to 16 shares of common stock. Since that stock is not publicly traded, there is no way to estimate its value.
Part of Mr. Griffin's troubles with Resorts is the original assessment of the value of the company's Atlantic City and Bahamas real estate. The plan last year was to sell some of the real estate to reduce debt and increase cash flow through upgrading operations. The real estate has turned out to be worth less than Resorts said it would sell for and operating income has fallen rather than risen, as Mr. Griffin expected. The company's market share in Atlantic City has continued to fall, for reasons that the company said included ''the deterioration of the Resorts Casino Hotel facility and equipment.''
There was no trading reported of bonds in either Griffin Resorts, which have been trading around 60 percent of par, or of Resorts, where the quotes have been about half that level. Ross Haberman, a trader at R. D. Smith & Company, a firm that specializes in distressed issues, said he expected prices to fall today.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday, despite economic reports that were better than expected, while the ''junk bond'' market staged a rally after losing ground last week.
Dealers said a heavy influx of new issues, including a $1.5 billion offering from the World Bank, was the big reason that the latest reports on consumer prices and housing starts did not get a more enthusiastic reception.
The consumer price data were particularly positive, participants and analysts said.
By the numbers, the consumer prices in August were unchanged from a month earlier. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices rose by just two-tenths of 1 percent. 
In addition to the consumer price report, the Government said housing starts fell by 5 percent last month.
''Numbers like that should tend to make people want to do some business,'' one government bond trader said. ''But with the Fed on hold, it seems like we are running out of steam. And the natural thing for the market to do when the Fed is on hold and a lot of new supply comes to market is to retreat.''
Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, said: ''There is a maddening sense that the data we have been getting for the last six weeks aren't telling a different story. The numbers that came out on Tuesday were good, but they merely continue the story of moderation in the economy and an underlying inflation rate that is around 4.5 percent, which is roughly the same as it was a year ago.''
Treasury prices rose by as much as a quarter of a point after the reports were released, but retreated later.
By late in the day, the 8 1/4 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 100 13/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.08 percent.
 
Secondary Treasury Issues
Among secondary Treasury issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 14/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.08 percent. And the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 27/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.03 percent.
Meanwhile, short-term Treasury bill rates rose sharply.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.71 percent, up 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bills were offered at 7.66 percent, up 4 basis points. And one-year bill rates rose by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.53 percent.
In contrast to the Treasury market, the mood in the high-yield market for junk bonds improved markedly yesterday.
News that the Campeau Corporation had reached agreement with creditors prompted a rally in all sectors of the high-yield market, participants said.
Prices of Campeau-related issues like Allied Stores and Federated Department Stores rose by 5 to 7 points, traders said. And higher-quality issues like RJR Nabisco, which began to attract buyers on Monday, rose an additional 1 1/2 to 2 points.
''A lot of what happened today was led by the Street,'' one high-yield trader said, ''but there was substantial business from retail accounts as well.''
Dealers said that volume was fairly heavy, especially considering that many participants were in North Carolina at a high-yield conference sponsored by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Traders of Government agency debt said the $1.5 billion World Bank global bond issue was well received.
The 10-year issue, priced at $99.55, to yield 8.442 percent, or 37.5 basis points over the prevailing yield on 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing, was trading late yesterday at 34 basis points over 10-year Treasuries.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was light yesterday, dealers said. Prices of most issues fell by about an eighth of a point.
Secondary issues of tax-exempt municipal bonds were weighed down by an $874 million, two-part issue from the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York. Prices of most secondary issues fell by about three-eighths of a point, participants said.
The Dormitory Authority offering consisted of $692 million of serial, term and zero-coupon bonds, and $182 million of special obligation bonds.
Serial bonds from the larger of the two issues range in maturity from 1991 to 2005, and were originally priced with coupons from 6.35 percent in 1991 to 7.30 percent in 2005. Coupons on the term bonds offered range from 7 percent on bonds maturing in 2008 to 6 percent in 2017.
The $182 million special obligation issue contained of serial bonds with coupons from 6 percnet in 1990 to 6.70 percent in 1998.
Lazard Freres & Company acted as lead manager for the offering. The larger part of the offering is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The special obligation bonds are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Mixed Results Amid Intervention Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in nervous worldwide trading yesterday amid reports that the Federal Reserve had intervened to keep the currency down.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $361.20 an ounce, down 50 cents from late Monday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $360 an ounce, off 70 cents. 
Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia, said reports that the Fed had sold small amounts of dollars added to the tension of an already nervous market after the declines recently. Last week's downturn followed the release of mixed economic reports and rumors.
''We don't really know what future lies for the dollar,'' Mr. Glamuzina said. ''Today it seems more of a wait-and-see attitude where traders didn't feel comfortable unloading long or short positions.''
A corporate dealer at an American bank in Frankfurt agreed, saying, ''People don't have much of a medium-term view about the dollar now.''
In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.70 yen to close at 145.73 yen. The dollar traded at 145.55 yen in London and at 145.85 yen in New York, down from 145.93 on Monday.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. The pound firmed to $1.5720 in London, compared with $1.5695 late Monday. Sterling fetched $1.5710 in New York, unchanged from late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's quotes, included: 1.9535 West German marks, up from 1.9523; 1.6905 Swiss francs, up from 1.6840; 6.60105 French francs, up from 6.5830; 1.18455 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18335, and 1,406.50 Italian lire, up from 1,404.50.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Monday, were: 1.6870 Swiss francs, up from 1.6850; 6.5875 French francs, down from 6.5890; 2.2000 Dutch guilders, down from 2.2180; 1.1833 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1834, and 1,406.50 Italian lire, down from 1,417.40.
Gold traded in London at $360.50 an ounce late yesterday, down from Monday's $361.65. In Zurich, gold traded at $360.50 an ounce late in the day, down from $361.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Soybeans at 22-Month Low For the September Contract

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Soybeans for spot delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade fell to a 22-month low yesterday on a combination of harvest pressure and position-shifting in the September contract before its expiration today.
Other soybean contracts closed mostly higher, while most corn and wheat futures retreated amid increased corn harvesting and slack export demand for United States grains.
On other markets, energy futures were sharply lower, cocoa futures advanced, livestock and meat futures were mixed and precious metals inched lower. 
Soybean futures settled 9 1/4 cents lower to 3 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in September at $5.63 a bushel, the lowest since Nov. 16, 1987.
Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 2 1/4 cents lower, with September at $3.80 a bushel; corn was 1 1/2 cents lower to 2 cents higher, with September at $2.33 3/4 a bushel, and oats were 1 1/4 cents lower to 1 cent higher, with September at $1.34 a bushel.
Aside from the drop in the September soybean contract, the markets held up well in the face of the advancing harvest and forecasts for continued good growing weather.
 
Crude Oil Down Sharply
Crude oil futures fell steeply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, paced by liquidation in the expiring October contract, which goes off the board today.
Heating oil futures also weakened significantly, partly as a result of mild temperatures in the Northeast.
''Heating oil is not getting any help from seasonal factors and supplies seem to be building,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, vice president of trading and research with the Carson Petroleum Company, a Chicago-area petroleum distributor.
After the close, the American Petroleum Institute reported that United States stocks of petroleum distillates, including heating oil, increased by 1.61 million barrels last week. Gasoline stocks rose by 244,000 barrels while crude oil stocks fell by 9.61 million barrels.
Cocoa futures rebounded modestly on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after tumbling to 14-year lows on Monday following the International Cocoa Organization's failure to repair its price-support mechanism. Cocoa settled $9 to $13 higher, with December at $1,047 a metric ton.
Cattle futures finished mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in the wake of Monday's Agriculture Department report showing lighter-than-expected marketings of cattle off feedlots last month.
Precious-metal futures drifted lower in response to the Labor Department's report of no change in consumer prices last month. Gold and silver perform best during times of rising inflation.
