HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Jamaica Mall Is Renovated After Setback

BYLINE: By Shawn G. Kennedy

 BODY:
THE owners of the shopping mall in the former Gertz department store in Jamaica, Queens, who have seen a third of their retail tenants leave since the mall opened 18 months ago, are trying to infuse new life in the stalled center with a renovation and a new name.
In the last few months they have spent more than $100,000 to upgrade the basement level of the mall, which opened in the spring of 1988 with nearly 60 tenants. Today about 25,000 square feet of space is available for rent in the mall, which occupies the ground floor and basement of the building on Jamaica Avenue between Union Hall Street and Guy R. Brewer Boulevard.
But the owners, Lager Associates and members of the Gertz family, remain confident about the long-term prospects for the retail center. They cite such thriving tenants as Fava Shoes, Sterling Optical, the Albee Dental Center, Flowers by Katina and Nu Tribe Hair Sculptors. 
They attributed the mall's shaky start to the management problems of the mall's main tenant, John Chung, a Chicago-based retailer who specializes in discount merchandising. The retailer, they said, had a marketing plan that failed to recognize the level of sophistication of the area's shoppers.
''Many of the stores have done very well,'' said Ethan Lazar, a general partner of Lager Associates, which spent $10 million constructing the mall two years ago. ''In fact, overall retailing in this area is stronger now than when when we opened.''
Gertz, once a major retailer in Queens, closed in 1981 after struggling to compete with regional shopping centers that started opening in the 1960's.
The plan to turn the department store into an office building and minimall was announced shortly after the store closed. The building's six upper floors were converted to 300,000 square feet of office space. Most of it was leased to the State of New York, which transferred four agencies to the building from the World Trade Center in 1985.
But the owners were not so fortunate in their efforts to find retail tenants. After a two-year campaign resulted in leasing about half the 100,000 square feet there, they signed a lease with Mr. Chung, who took all 53,000 square feet in the basement with the idea of subletting the space.
Many of Mr. Chung's subtenants were discount concerns. But the discount shopping level never took hold with shoppers. Douglas Sugarman, the mall's manager, said one reason was that there were too many of the same types of retailers. At one time, he said, there were 10 jewelery stores or exchanges. But the tenant mix was not the only difficulty.
''There were problems with security, and the basement was not fixed up the way we had been told it would be,'' said Mrs. Shermin Emmanuel, one of the tenants who left.
Mrs. Emmanuel, who with her sister, Yvonne Walker, own Shervonnes, a women's clothing and gift store, believes that the mall is a good location for merchants and will reopen the store this week.
Mr. Chung's Chicago telephone has been disconnected, and he could not be reached for comment.
Last spring the problems reached a crucial stage when Con Edison, because of nonpayment of bills, cut off power to the basement. That forced Lager Associates to close the basement.
Meanwhile, Lager Associates terminated its lease with Mr. Chung and started a renovation. A gray and blue tile floor has been installed, lighting fixtures have been added and the basement has been painted. A food court is also being built. In the next few weeks a sign bearing the mall's new name, Jamaica Plaza Mall, will be installed over the Jamaica Avenue entrance. It had been called the Gertz Mall.
''We are looking for more upscale retailers than were in many of these spaces originally,'' Mr. Sugarman said. ''Demographic studies show that the average household income in the neighborhood is about $32,000 a year. So we want the sort of tenants that can best respond to that economic strength.''
A poll of frequent shoppers in the mall and of the employees in the building's office space showed that a bookstore, drugstore, crafts and hobby store, record shop, sporting goods store and full service restaurant would be welcome.
The mall has a prime location in the middle of the flourishing Jamaica Avenue shopping strip that stretches from Sutphin Boulevard to 175th Street. According to a recent study, the strip is used by 385,000 residents, workers in the area and students.
The mall currently has 33 tenants, Mr. Sugarman said. Twelve retailers who were in the basement have agreed to reopen stores there.
The asking price for available spaces, which range from 350 to 18,000 square feet, is $25 to $45 a square foot, depending on the location and size of the store.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev: Beyond Our Help

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is director of Soviet studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev's troubles are mounting again, and Americans wonder whether and how to help him. This week's events frame the question nicely.
Yesterday, the Communist Party's Central Committee met in Moscow to consider the Soviet Union's growing ethnic turmoil, and heard Mr. Gorbachev draw the line against separatist aspirations in the Baltic republics.
Today, Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze flies to Washington to discuss U.S.-Soviet relations with President Bush and Secretary of State Baker. 
Some U.S. officials reportedly believe that a nice diplomatic boost would help Mr. Gorbachev contend with forces that seem to be closing in on him. Others advise waiting until the dust settles, for he - and perestroika - may soon be gone.
To argue for delay misstates our predicament. The dust is not going to settle for a long time, and the Administration has to conduct policy in the face of uncertainty. But to argue that progress in East-West relations can be a major help to reform is to misstate Mr. Gorbachev's predicament.
The authority of Soviet political institutions is unraveling for reasons that dwarf any foreign policy success. Remember that Mr. Gorbachev's dramatic trip to Beijing last May opened the summer of the worst political chaos since he took office.
Relations with the U.S. are no different. No agreement on chemical weapons or nuclear testing, both high on the Baker-Shevardnadze agenda, will impress the Donbass coal miners, who warned last week that the agreement that ended their strike in July is not being observed.
No breakthrough on strategic arms will appease farmers who were told in August that they would receive hard currency for their harvest but got I.O.U.'s instead. And no summit meeting will solve Mr. Gorbachev's credibility problem in dealing with ethnic conflicts: He has been so tolerant and conciliatory that nationalist groups now disbelieve his warnings. If the prestige of being a giant on the world stage does not allay his internal problems, won't agreements that help him redirect economic resources have a direct impact?
It is argued that large cuts in conventional military forces could contribute to keeping reform alive. But the Soviets will have trouble cashing a ''peace dividend.'' The military-industrial resources to be freed up would be transferred to a civilian economy that is grossly wasteful, has been turned upside-down by successive reorganization schemes and is hit hard by inflation.
Moreover, Mr. Gorbachev's economic advisers insist that, given the huge budget deficit, their top priority has to be cutting spending outright, not just shifting it to other uses. If so, the first result of a smaller defense budget won't be more consumer goods, but unemployment. Not much of a peace dividend here.
Other ideas to be discussed in U.S.-Soviet meetings this week go beyond helping Mr. Gorbachev reallocate resources internally. They could help make available resources from outside.
President Bush speaks of ''integrating'' the Soviet Union into the world community - perhaps to include membership in the International Monetary Fund and General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Yet the short-term impact is negligible. One recent, highly sympathetic study found ''few if any benefits'' for Moscow in early GATT membership, and proposed observer status as a kind of tutorial in free trade.
Generating extra resources is not a real problem for Soviet foreign economic policy. Mr. Gorbachev could in an afternoon borrow the money needed for goods that might convince ordinary citizens that things are improving. He hasn't done so. After a summer of strikes and rioting, his plans to increase imports may come to only $1 billion or $2 billion. His TV speech last week promised austerity measures that will be ''unpopular,'' ''harsh'' and ''painful.'' Many Western economists trace Mr. Gorbachev's peculiar course to a hypercautious fiscal policy. But the real explanation may be his high-wire political radicalism. As rationing goes into effect across the Soviet Union, he replies serenely that the answer is not to buy goods abroad but to acquire the means to produce them. This is the revolutionary strategy Lenin called ''the worse, the better'': To overturn the system, do nothing to ease its crisis.
For Mr. Gorbachev, the path to reform lies through disorder. At home and abroad, he has shown extraordinary confidence that he can survive the chaos his policies create.
Consider his encouragement of centrifugal forces in the Soviet bloc. Soviet support for Hungary against East Germany will jeopardize what Mr. Gorbachev's predecessors saw as a principal bulwark of their security: Western acceptance of the European status quo, especially of East Germany's legitimacy. His actions oblige even West Germans who prefer to ignore the reunification issue to take it seriously - a guarantee of terrible dilemmas for Soviet policy down the road.
In undermining Moscow's international position, Mr. Gorbachev is exploding the long-held idea that, to succeed, perestroika requires foreign policy successes. He is forcing us to reconsider the relationship between his foreign and domestic policies.
Earlier, when his interest in detente first became clear, we used to say that to pursue reform at home he needed a calm international environment. Now, Soviet internal problems are so great that foreign policy has become less important altogether. He is prepared to accept - even to tempt - international instability.
Mr. Gorbachev's flexible, don't-take-no-for-an-answer diplomacy gives us reasons to explore areas of agreement. We can even get our hopes up a little. But we should see that he is pursuing upheaval on a scale that makes it all but impossible for the U.S. to affect the course of events.

HEADLINE: Bush Dispatches Troops to Island In Storm's Wake

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
President Bush ordered more than 1,000 military police to the Virgin Islands last night to help restore calm after two days of looting and sporadic shooting on St. Croix that was set off by the devastation of a major hurricane.
The United States had already sent six Coast Guard cutters to St. Croix to evacuate terrified tourists and residents.
The Pentagon said last night that about 1,100 military police from Fort Bragg, N.C., Fort Hood, Tex., and Fort Leonard Wood, Mo., were scheduled to arrive in St. Croix beginning this morning. A Defense Department memorandum said the troops would arrive aboard 16 Air Force C-141 Starlifter aircraft and would take with them three helicopters, ground vehicles and appropriate medical equipment.
''I have been informed that conditions of domestic violence and disorder exist in and about the Virgin Islands,'' Mr. Bush said in a statement. But the Governor of the Virgin Islands, Alexander Farrelly, told The Associated Press last night that he had not yet asked for Federal troops and that ''there is no near state of anarchy'' in the Virgin Islands. 
The disturbances started soon after Hurricane Hugo devasted much of St. Croix, as it had done to dozens of islands in a 500-mile arc of the Caribbean on Sunday and Monday. But the unrest increased Tuesday and yesterday in what witnesses described as a complete breakdown of civil authority.
Reports from people who fled St. Croix yesterday on a flight to Miami, amateur radio operators and news service accounts indicated that gangs were moving through the streets with rifles. Some witnesses said local police officers and National Guardsmen were among the looters.
 
Path of Hurricane
Hurricane Hugo continued to bear down on the East Coast today, and meteorologists said it was most likely to come ashore in the Carolinas or Georgia late Thursday or early Friday. [Page B19.] In its pass through the Caribbean, the storm left about 50,000 people homeless from Guadeloupe to Puerto Rico and caused billions of dollars in damage. Nineteen people were reported killed.
Mr. Bush officially declared the Virgin Islands a disaster area earlier yesterday, which will entitle hurricane victims there to reconstruction loans and other forms of long-term Federal relief. He was considering extending that designation to Puerto Rico.
With reports yesterday afternoon of widespread disorder continuing on St. Croix, the Coast Guard sent in the cutters with armed men, to rescue civilians.
 
Coast Guard Evacuations
Coast Guard officials in Miami said initial reports from one of the cutters, the Bear, ''indicate that the situation ashore is serious.''
''Looting and civil disturbances are continuing,'' the officials said.
The crew was evacuating ''all people from the island who fear for their safety,'' the Coast Guard said in a statement. A cargo plane was ready to supplement the evacuation, if needed. As of 11 P.M. yesterday, 100 people had been evacuated by the cutters and 77 more had flown out aboard a C-130 that brought in the some of the 100 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and deputy United States marshals sent to the Virgin Islands by Attorney General Dic Thornburgh..
An additional 200 people were evacuated to a National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration research vessel in Christiansted harbor, said Petty Officer James Wentworth, a Coast Guard spokesman.
Governor Farrelly of the Virgin Islands, speaking from his office in Charlotte Amalie on St. Thomas, about 30 miles north of St. Croix, acknowledged, ''There is some looting, no doubt about that.
''But,'' he added, ''there is no near state of anarchy. And I should know. I'm in the streets every day and I'm the Governor of this territory.''
 
Reports on Unrest
People arriving last night at Miami International Airport from St. Croix spoke of widespread unrest on the island.
Jackie Evans, on her way to South Carolina, said: ''Everyone was looting - National Guardsmen in uniform, policemen. There's no law and order.
''They're holding up gas stations,'' she continued. ''They're holding up everything. At the gas station, there's a six-hour wait to get gas, so people are coming in with machetes and guns to get gas.''
Robert Dykes of Los Altos, Calif., another passenger on the flight said there were ''armed guards at all the hotels.'' He also said National Guard troops from Puerto Rico had surrounded the airport.
Defense Department officials said they could not confirm reports that members of the National Guard in the Virgin Islands were participating in the civil disturbances there. But Gary Williams, a San Juan reporter who had flown to the island, said he saw police officers and some of the island's National Guardsmen participating in the looting. ''We saw a National Guard truck filled to capacity with all kinds of stuff in it,'' he told The Associated Press.
''It's very bad, extremely bad,'' Mr. Williams continued. ''When we landed, we were pounced upon by about 15 tourists. They said, 'Please get food! Please get water! Please help us! They're looting. We've seen police looting. We've seen National Guard looting. There's no law and order here.' '' Lieut. David Hume, who is directing the Coast Guard's relief operations in the Caribbean, said his men had seen and videotaped extensive rioting on the island. ''The St. Croix National Guard is nowhere to be found,'' he said.
James Fanjoy, a private helicopter pilot who just returned to San Juan, said residents of St. Croix had told him ''Everyone's gone crazy. Everything is destroyed. Shop owners are standing at the stores with guns.''
 
'Garbage Bags Loaded'
Mr. Williams said his helicopter flew over the Sunny Isle shopping center in Christiansted, and there appeared to be about 1,000 people in the parking lot, many walking in and out of shattered shops with their arms loaded. At one jewelry store, he said, ''We saw three men and a woman walking out with garbage bags loaded with stuff.''
''We did not see one cop in Christiansted, and that's the main town,'' he said. ''We saw a National Guard truck filled to capacity with all kinds of stuff in it.''
Carlos Harrison, a reporter for The Miami Herald, said he also saw a National Guard truck loaded with merchandise. ''They didn't look like they were delivering things,'' Mr. Harrison said.
Federal officials said the hurricane had damaged a territorial prison and that inmates had either escaped or were released by the authorities.
Debbie Huber, a student at Florida State University, said yesterday that she had spoken to her fiance, David Shuman, on St. Croix. She said Mr. Shuman told her: ''People with guns are robbing houses, hotels, restaurants. They're stealing food, clothing, fuel, batteries, candles, anything.''
Mr. Shuman, an employee of a St. Croix FM radio station, WAVI, said three of the island's four radio towers had been toppled, Miss Huber said. He said officials were simply overwhelmed by the extent of the damage and the looting, and were unable to deal with it.
Unofficial reports said that 97 percent of the buildings on St. Croix, which has a population of 53,000, were damaged or destroyed by the hurricane.
There are nine main islands in the Virgin Islands, six of them held by the British. The United States purchased three of them - St. Croix, St. Thomas and St. John - from Denmark in 1917. The population on the islands is about 110,000, and tourism is the principal industry.
 
Electricity Still Interrupted
In Puerto Rico today, most of the eastern end of island was still without electricity. Water service was restored to some parts of San Juan and its suburbs but remained interrupted in most rural areas. In San Juan, the Fire Department was dispensing water in some neighborhoods from its tanker trucks. Schools and most stores and businesses remained closed.
The main airport at San Juan, Luis Munoz Marin International Airport, reopened for a handful of flights. The airport remained open even after a propane gas line exploded in a Delta Air Lines terminal that is under construction. Jose Felix, superintendent of airport security, said two people were overcome by gas fumes and taken away in an ambulance.
Gov. Rafael Hernandez-Colon of Puerto Rico said the houses of at least 50,000 people were either destroyed or severely damaged. Officials said 27,000 people were housed in temporary Government shelters Tuesday.
The Governor said, ''This is a tragedy of major proportions, which has left desolation among the people and a swath of destruction.''
The American Red Cross in Washington said it would send its first relief supplies, including 15,000 tents, to Puerto Rico today on a flight from McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey.
Hotels, businesses and homeowners were cleaning up and doing repairs Tuesday, but it appeared that damage was so extensive that it would be weeks before life would return to normal.
Juan Miguel Domenech, director of Puerto Rico's Department of Tourism, said the government will begin an advertising campaign in the United States to offset any negative effect of the hurricane on local tourism. Nearly 860,000 tourists visited the island last year, spending about $1.1 billion.
 
United States Virgin Islands
 
Geography
The United States Virgin Islands are St. Thomas (32 square miles), St. Croix (84 square miles), St. John (20 square miles) and another 50 smaller islands, most of which are uninhabited. The group lies about 40 miles due east of Puerto Rico.
 
Population
In a 1985 census, the total population of the islands was 110,800, an increase of 15,209, or 16 percent, since 1980. The 1985 population was St. Thomas, 52,660; St. Croix, 55,300, and St. John, 2,800. The official language is English, but Spanish is widely spoken. Black and Hispanic people comprise approximately 85 percent of the islands' population. In 1986, median household income for whites ($17,281) was nearly twice that of black and Hispanic households ($9,908).
 
Government
The islands, first settled by Carib and Arawak Indians, were discovered by Columbus in 1493 and claimed for Spain. They later passed through Dutch, English and French hands. Denmark colonized St. Thomas and St. John after 1670 and purchased St. Croix from France in 1733. The islands were purchased by the United States from Denmark for $25 million in a treaty ratified in 1917. They were administered by the Navy until being transferred to the Department of Interior in 1931. They now form an unincorporated territory of the United States.
Residents of the islands are American citizens with a non-voting representative in Congress; they cannot vote in Presidential elections. Since 1970, executive authority has been given to an elected Governor and Lieutenant Governor. The capital is Charlotte Amalie, on St. Thomas.
 
Economy
The islands are heavily dependent on their links to the American mainland. More than 90 percent of their trade is with the United States and Puerto Rico. Natural resources are scarce, and food production is insufficient to satisfy local demand. The economy is based mostly on the tourist trade. Rum production and oil refining are two other important industries.

HEADLINE: Argentina's Chief to Try Charm on U.S.

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20

 BODY:
In two and a half months in the presidency, Carlos Saul Menem has woven a kind of magic over the Argentines.
He has played soccer in a packed stadium alongside one of the world's greatest players, Diego Maradona. He has kept up his end of a basketball game with men half his age and two feet taller. He has elegantly danced the tango and the zamba, the folk dance of the Argentine gauchos, or cowboys, on prime-time television. 
In his 20-hour days, he has also tamed Argentina's soaring inflation, refilled the Central Bank with dollars and forged an alliance with private enterprise and capitalism that would have troubled the founder of his political party, Juan D. Peron.
Now he hopes to weave some of that magic abroad as he sets out Saturday night for the United States on a mission to convince foreign officials, bankers and investors that Argentina is a serious country and has stopped living, in his words, ''from party to party.''
Mr. Menem said in an interview that on this trip he wants to transmit ''live and direct'' the news that Argentina's finances are improving dramatically, that he is pushing ahead with efforts to sell off or dismantle Government-owned companies and that the doors are open to foreign investors.
 
Inflation Down Sharply
''Fundamentally, what we want to accomplish is a more fluid insertion of Argentina in the international field,'' he said. ''It is well known that we are coming out of a very conflictive situation, with the image of a decadent Argentina, I would say, a chaotic Argentina without future.''
In July, the month in which Mr. Menem succeeded Raul Alfonsin in the presidency, Argentine inflation almost hit 200 percent, just for the month. On an annualized basis, that was equal to any known world record.
The soaring inflation, attributed to huge deficits by state companies and tax evasion in the last months of the Alfonsin presidency, was accompanied by a drop in the foreign reserves to less than $100 million, next to nothing for a country of 32 million people.
Mr. Menem, bringing respected businessmen and free-market economists into his Government, reduced inflation to 38 percent in August through negotiated wage and price accords. It is expected to fall to 7 or 8 percent this month. Reserves have recovered to almost $2 billion, Mr. Menem said today.
But important tests lie ahead in terms of how quickly the Government can move with plans to turn over state companies to private ownership or management and whether it can come out of the unofficial wage and price controls without new inflation or a recession.
The one-week visit, which is to include a meeting with President Bush in Washington on Wednesday, a speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Monday, and meetings with several European foreign ministers in New York, will be the first ever made to the United States by a sitting President from the Justicialist Party, better known as Peronism.
 
Lifting the Shadows
Mr. Menem, who was in the United States several times before he was elected President, said this visit ''will end an old and stupid legend'' about the supposed anti-Americanism of Peronism and ''lift all shadows from relations between the United States and Argentina.''
General Peron, after first coming to power in 1946, created a kind of populist socialism in Argentina, under which the state became the primary motor of the economy and created a vast network of programs and services for the working class that went further than most social welfare systems, including things like direct gifts to children and vacation hotels for laborers and their families.
Mr. Menem, whose partnership with capitalism has pleased many of those who did not vote for him and dismayed many of those who did, denies he is rejecting Peronism's traditional identification with social justice. He now talks of a ''popular free market economy'' as his goal. He says that means ''private enterprise and free trade, with social justice incorporated.''

HEADLINE: Oakland Schools Face Bankruptcy and Scandal

BYLINE: By LOUIS FREEDBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17

 BODY:
The Oakland school system is enmeshed in a scandal involving arrests of school officials and allegations of widespread patronage at a time when it is threatened with bankruptcy.
State legislators, upset at the fiscal deterioration of the system, voted last week to assign a trustee to Oakland, making it the first school district in the state to have a trustee imposed on it.
The trustee's powers will be limited to overseeing the finances of California's fifth-largest school district, but opponents of the move see it as an unwarranted state intrusion.
Amid these troubles, the district has been without a permanent superintendent since Joe Coto resigned last November. He is now superintendent of a high school district in San Jose. The search firm hired by the district to find a new superintendent gave up looking when all the leading candidates withdrew their applications. While the candidates gave no reasons, many appear to have been scared off by the district's problems. 
The district is being overseen by Carolyn Getridge, listed as ''interim deputy superintendent.''
 
Problems With Deficit
The district faces a $10 million deficit in its total budget of $225 million and has just sold $10 million in revenue bonds to try to cover the deficit. But it is unclear whether state officials will agree to using the money for balancing the budget, rather than for the usual construction purposes.
While the school district tries to avoid bankruptcy, eight former or current school employees have been charged with embezzlement of school money, theft of school property and other crimes. The highest official charged is Donald Fennell, director of the district's state and Federal programs. He was indicted on charges of grand theft, falsifying records and misappropriating public money in connection with salary payments to a teacher who was not employed by the district. He has pleaded not guilty. In addition, some school board members and school officials are alleged to have hired friends and relatives in a pattern of patronage.
The Oakland Police Department has set up an 11-member squad to continue investigating the district and has a telephone hot line number to receive tips about wrongdoing. More indictments and arrests are expected.
 
Already Troubled Community
The crisis has touched the soul of an already troubled community that is trying to cope with the ravages of drug use in some neighborhoods, an overburdened health care system and a sluggish local economy.
Of the district's 50,000 students, 59 percent are classified as black, 14 percent as Hispanic, 17 percent as Asian and 9 percent as white. Test scores of high school students are among the lowest in the state. And there is fear that the crisis will accelerate the already considerable flight of whites from the district.
The bill just approved by the Legislature would provide a $10 million bailout loan for the school district, which would meet the deficit without using the revenue bonds. In addition, the bill would impose a trustee to help the district start a financial recovery plan.
Four of the seven Oakland board members, led by Alfreda Abbott, the president, oppose the trustee plan. ''It has been a well-orchestrated and political attack to take over our school district,'' Ms. Abbott said.
 
Local Control at Issue
Ms. Abbott blames California's Education Superintendent, Bill Honig, for what she says is his attempt to subvert local control.
Mr. Honig dismisses those allegations. ''Every day that goes by, it gets worse and worse,'' he said. ''We all like local control, but it's a horrible situation which has to be corrected, and if they won't correct, someone has to help them do it.''
The charged atmosphere has been brushed with racial overtones. Ms. Abbott and the three other board members who oppose the plan are black and contend that attacks on the board are also racially motivated, even though many of the legislators and local officials who have criticized the district are also black.
One prominent black figure, Robert Maynard, publisher of The Oakland Tribune, said in a recent column, ''Unless we learn to throw the rascals out and start over, Oakland's future as a community will be in jeopardy.''
Local private schools say they have been inundated wtih requests from Oakland parents trying to place their children.
In addition, school officials in neighboring communities like Berkeley and Albany say an unusually high number of Oakland students have been trying to enroll in their districts illegally by falsifying their addresses.
 
Recent Loss of Teachers
Students are not the only ones leaving. Close to 100 of the district's almost 2,300 teachers have resigned or retired in the last few months.
One of them is Vivian Jones, who until last year was a music teacher and coach of the Castleleers, a student singing group at Castlemont High School. The group has sung at the White House and is an Oakland institution. Ms. Jones said that when other music teachers were laid off, she felt she had better look for another job.''When I realized that the school district was dying, I began to think about my fate,'' Ms. Jones said, speaking from St. Louis where she now teaches.
Some students say they feel they are being shortchanged, especially in contrast to the city's attempts to bring back the Los Angeles Raiders football team, which abandoned Oakland several years ago.
''I'm a Raider fan,'' said Anthony Polk, 17 years old, a senior at Castlemont. ''But if they don't have any money for the schools, how do they come up with $54 million for the Raiders?''

HEADLINE: Venus May Tell Us How to Escape Its Fate;
The Next Giant Step

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Message From Neptune'' (editorial, Aug. 24) uses a spectacular accomplishment of our space program to support the flawed argument that we should continue to do only what we have shown we know how to do.
Voyager's tour of the outer planets - Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and now Neptune - was truly a triumph of space science and cost only a fraction of the projected investment in our new manned space station. But your concern that investments in manned space activities will squeeze out future opportunities comparable to Voyager's is unfounded. 
The coming months will see major triumphs in space science, beginning with the launch of Galileo to Jupiter in October and continuing with the Hubble Space Telescope early in 1990, exploration of Venus by the Magellan spacecraft launched last spring, a decades-long so-called mission to planet Earth that will help us understand the environmental changes that have begun to take place in recent years, and a host of new scientific spacecraft to be launched in the 1990's to study the Moon, the Sun, the planets and the distant universe.
But a balanced space program must include activities that go beyond what robot spacecraft sensors can tell us. Space is the next major area for human expansion. And the development of new industries that will generate the increased tax revenues to support our desperately needed social and environmental programs will come from research performed on the space station - that can only be performed by people.
True, the expansion of humankind into space is expensive - but compared with what we are willing to spend on health and human services or national defense it is a drop in the bucket. Manned space development absorbs less than half of one percent of the Federal budget, and even if we were to pursue the ambitious goals President Bush called for July 20, the ante would increase to scarcely one percent. Yes, it is risky - but risk taking is unavoidable in the development of new frontiers.
We could continue doing no more than we have done so successfully -study the planets with robot spacecraft. But we have explored virtually the entire solar system, and it would be truly myopic to do nothing further than simply refine the first giant step of data that Voyager and its colleagues have given us. What is needed is to move out on the next giant step: using that best decision-making, action-taking general-purpose computer - the human being -to explore and develop space for the benefit of all humankind, not just for the scientists.
 
JERRY GREY
Washington, Aug. 29, 1989
 The writer is director of science and technology policy, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics.

HEADLINE: L.I. Draws Economic Breath and Looks to a High-Tech Future

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your attempted assessment of Long Island's economy after a decade of expansion (news story, Aug. 24) falls seriously short of the mark.
While it is true that we no longer have the same economic conditions that marked the previous decade, that does not mean we are faced with economic woes. The economic transition we are experiencing means we are moving toward a more intensive high technology-research and development base. This is not even remotely similar to an economic bubble that has burst. 
There is solid evidence to support the transition theory of Long Island's economy. A recent survey of the members of the Association for a Better Long Island showed that an overwhelming number of them believe that the island's overall economic position is good. Several pointed out that even in the face of a potential loss of 10,000 jobs because of defense cutbacks, that figure still represents less than one percent of a work force of more than 1.1 million, a number that doesn't include the more than 200,000 Long Islanders who commute to work in New York City. Long Island is no longer solely dependent on defense contracts for its economic success.
You quote Thomas Conoscenti, one of our well-known economists, as saying that Long Island's economy ''now has an opportunity to breathe.'' As a former planner and chief executive of Suffolk County, I concur with Mr. Conoscenti's view that our economy can best be described as being in a temporary lull and that our local governments should use this time to equate future growth with growing job demands. It is also an opportunity for those governments to pursue intelligent policies that will provide benefits, financially and in the quality of life, for Long Island's most basic economic unit, its families.
Of course, our present economic condition requires that government respond by recognizing and satisfying the persistent needs of business. We can achieve our ultimate goal of creating a stable business environment on Long Island by encouraging the kind of high-tech businesses that are compatible with the concerns of our natural environment and by government that can create predictability in taxes, as well as simple predictability.
You leave an impression that Long Island is on the decline; we are not! I bet that 45 of the 50 governors in this country would give their eyeteeth in exchange for having Long Island's economic future in their own states.
 
MICHAEL A. LOGRANDE
Executive Director
Association for a Better Long Island
 Melville, L.I., Sept. 5, 1989

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
What Are We Waiting For?

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
For Americans it may be the most hopeful development of the last 40 years in world history. Whether it can work is in the balance. And the United States Government, shrugging lackadaisically, says it will do nothing to help.
That is the nature - the astounding nature - of the Bush Administration's response to the embattlement of Mikhail Gorbachev. As he runs into severe problems in his effort to open up the Soviet system, the President and his men seem barely interested. They say there is no hurry. And anyway, what can we do? 
We can do plenty to help Mr. Gorbachev: now, quickly, when he needs help. I am speaking not of massive aid programs but of gestures with symbolic importance to his constituency at home.
First, Mr. Bush can agree to a summit meeting with the Soviet leader. That would give Mr. Gorbachev a political lift, and at no imaginable cost to George Bush. It is the least the President can do. What is he waiting for?
''I feel under no rush on that subject,'' Mr. Bush said when asked about a summit meeting the other day.
''The key point is, does the Soviet Union understand we want to see their perestroika succeed and see them move forward with more liberties? And I think they do understand that. So I don't think there's any chance of a disconnect there.''
Can Mr. Bush conceivably think that is ''the key point''? A summit conference would not just reprint the U.S. position on perestroika. It would signal a continuing American intention to do business with Mikhail Gorbachev. At a time when he is battling economic disaster and conservative Communist opposition, he would gain status and leverage from a meeting with the American President.
A substantive step ready for Mr. Bush to take is to suspend the Jackson-Vanik Amendment and grant the Soviet Union most-favored-nation trading status. Jewish groups are mostly satisfied with Mr. Gorbachev's relaxation of restrictions on Jewish emigration, and would not object to putting aside Jackson-Vanik.
Easing our trading terms would not produce large or immediate economic benefits for the Soviet Union. But in Soviet eyes it would give Mr. Gorbachev something concrete in return for the gestures he has made to the United States. He is often criticized at home for giving way to the Americans and getting nothing in return.
When Secretary of State Baker meets Foreign Minister Shevardnadze in Wyoming, he could be candidly sympathetic about the problems facing Mr. Gorbachev. He could ask, privately and delicately, whether the United States can help on the menacing food situation in the U.S.S.R.
But all of this depends on a simple understanding. That is that the survival of Mr. Gorbachev, and his success, are in this country's profound interest. The point has nothing to do with ideology, right or left. Just about everyone agrees now, as Jeane Kirkpatrick wrote the other day, that Mr. Gorbachev ''seriously seeks broad reform of his own society.'' The changes in the Soviet Union, Hungary and Poland have been breathtaking. Just now, it is said, Mr. Gorbachev approved Hungary's decision to keep its border open as East Germans streamed through.
We have hardly dared dream of such changes in the Soviet system. And their continuation depends heavily on the fate of Mr. Gorbachev. Without him, the Soviet Union could easily slide into dangerous chaos or slip back into tyranny.
Margaret Thatcher has no difficulty understanding the point, and responding to it. She is going to Moscow this weekend to see Mr. Gorbachev: a hurriedly scheduled meeting plainly designed as a show of support for him.
But American understanding matters. To take one large example, only American commitment to arms control, particularly completion of a Start agreement to reduce the number of strategic weapons, can create a domestic political climate in which Mr. Gorbachev can cut military spending.
Why, then, is the point so hard to understand in Washington? In part there is a strange uneasiness about ending the cold war because change is uncomfortable - as if change could be avoided.
Whatever the reason, there will be a heavy responsibility on George Bush if he does nothing to help Mr. Gorbachev. Not many Presidents have such an opportunity. To miss it could be disastrous.

HEADLINE: Bailout Urged For Hospitals With Losses

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20

 BODY:
Foreshadowing what is likely to be a divisive debate in Albany next year, a representative of New York City's private hospitals called today for a $300 million bailout of many financially troubled hospitals.
In requesting the emergency aid, $35 million of which would come from New York State, Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, joined representatives of other health-care providers in denouncing New York's system for determining how much hospitals receive for treating patients.
The $35 million in increased state aid, he said, would provide hospitals with about $300 million in additional revenue because more state funds would lead to higher payments from local governments, private insurers and the Federal Medicare program.
 
To Protect Medical 'Assets'
''We are calling on the state,'' Mr. Raske said, ''to protect New York's medical and social assets through a bailout or to untie the hands of hospital managers, now so tightly bound with regulations and rate control, so that they may efficiently work themselves out of the crisis.'' 
To emphasize the severity of the situation, Mr. Raske called on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to call a special session of the Legislature this fall to address the hospital crisis.
A spokesman for the Governor, however, rejected the call for early state action. The spokesman, Gary Fryer, said, ''We're looking at the problem of hospital reimbursement and have been for several months. The topic will receive attention in the near future, but at the present moment, because we have not concluded on the proper approach, what is the point of having a special session?''
Mr. Raske spoke at a hearing here of the New York State Council on Health Care Financing, which is headed by the leaders of the Legislature's health committees.
 
Operating Losses for Hospitals
His comments came after reports earlier this year that New York State's private hospitals posted operating losses of about $548 million in 1988.
Hospitals and other health-care institutions in the New York metropolitan area reported $359 million of those losses, or 65 percent of the statewide total, Mr. Raske said today. Because the situation in the city, Long Island and Westchester County is so bad, he added, emergency state action is necessary.
Although prompt state action appeared unlikely, today's hearing was clearly the first round of what is expected to be a bitter debate in Albany next year. While most analysts and state officials agree that New York hospitals are in crisis, many in the Cuomo administration and among influential business organizations believe that the growth of health-care costs must be restrained.
The hearing today, the first of two scheduled by the financing council, was held to gather testimony from hospital executives, insurers, business groups, labor unions and others in an effort to evaluate the reimbursement system and prepare legislative recommendations for changing it during the 1990 session. The reimbursement system expires in December 1990.
 
Pledge From Governor
Governor Cuomo has pledged to present several health-care initiatives in his annual State of the State Message in January, and hospital executives are bracing themselves for a long battle over health-care costs and state financing.
One particularly troublesome issue in the battle was discussed today as hospital representatives called for the state to revise its method of calculating costs and reimbursements to hospitals.
The reimbursement system for Medicaid has been a matter of fierce debate since its adoption in 1987. The new system pays hospitals a certain amount for each Medicaid patient, based on the diagnosis, instead of on the length of stay, as had been done previously. Private insurers also base their payments on the state reimbursment plan. Medicaid is the Federal and state health program for the poor, while Medicare is the Federal health program for the elderly.
When it adopted the new reimbursement system, the Legislature approved a plan that used 1985 as a base year for the costs of medical care. But Mr. Cuomo, under the advice of the State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, vetoed the bill, and after protracted negotiations the base year was set as 1981.
At the hearing today, Marjorie A. Geiger, a program research specialist in the Bureau of Health Economics of the Health Department, testified that Dr. Axelrod believed 1981 should continue to be used in determining specific reimbursement rates.
 
To Seek Cost Efficiencies
By not moving the base year, Ms. Geiger said, the Health Department believes it will force hospitals to continue to seek cost efficiencies. When problems are identified, like soaring labor costs, the department would seek to give hospitals more money, as it did last year in providing $193 million to cover increased salaries for nurses.
Dr. Axelrod's position on the base year is likely to further outrage doctors and hospital administrators, who last year began to complain loudly about the Commissioner and the regulatory system he has put into place.
Daniel Sisto, president of the Hospital Association of New York, a lobbying and information gathering organization, testified, for example, that ''every hospital needs a reasonable chance to meet its costs in 1991 terms, not in 1981 terms.''
Beyond the medical problems of AIDS, drug abuse and mental illness, hospitals say they are under pressure from the state's reimbursements, which they contend are unrealistically low. In addition, the Federal Medicare program, which a recent study by Brandeis University found had oversubsidized costs in New York hospitals, has been the target of cutbacks in Washington.
Saying that administrators recognized the need for a restructuring of New York's health-care system to restrain costs, Mr. Sisto complained that the current situation made any planning for the future impossible.
''It is hard to focus on restructuring when you are scrambling to meet payrolls,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Campaign Trail;
A Terrific 'Boring' Speech by Dinkins

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

 BODY:
Even in politics, friends sometimes blurt out the most amazing things. Take Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President and Democratic leader, who rose to the podium at a Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce luncheon yesterday right after David N. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee for New York City mayor, had finished a long speech on economic development.
''It was the most boring speech I have ever heard,'' Mr. Golden declared, ''but it had to be said.''
He went on to explain that Mr. Dinkins had touched on subjects vital to the future of New York City. Later, in a telephone interview, he explained further just what he had meant by boring. 
''I didn't mean that the candidate was boring, but the issues can be boring,'' Mr. Golden said. ''What I meant was that David Dinkins wants people to listen to statistics on homelessness and such - which are critical issues. I think it is great that he doesn't do what his opponent does, which is speak all the time on the glamorous issues, like crime and rape.''
 
'Great City,' Great Flaws
In his first commercial of the general election campaign, to be telecast tonight, Mr. Dinkins is shown standing in a schoolyard, complaining about overcrowded classrooms and drug dealers who lurk in the streets outside. He says the city has been shortchanged in education aid from New York State, and he calls for more discipline in the schools. The message ends with the line: ''A great city and the man who believes in it.''
 
No Tax Rise - Maybe
Mr. Giuliani told the Mortgage Bankers Association yesterday that despite the city's problems, raising taxes would only make them worse. But at a news conference afterward he refused to make an ironclad ''read my lips'' pledge against a tax increase.
''You have got to do all the things you can to avoid a tax increase, but you can't print money,'' Mr. Giuliani told reporters. ''You cannot promise no tax increase under any circumstance. That would be irresponsible.''
Speaking to the bankers, Mr. Giuliani said the city must develop programs to increase revenue and save money through more diligent collection of parking fines, more aggressive prosecution of tax cheats and better monitoring of city contracts through computerization.
A tax increase would only worsen the city's deteriorating state, Mr. Giuliani said, observing, ''You can't force people to live in a city in which there is increasing crime, increasing drugs, deteriorated schools, the worst roads in America, the dirtiest streets in America and one of the highest tax structures and one that promises to be higher.''
 
In Defeat, a Token Race
As expected, Ronald S. Lauder, defeated by Mr. Giuliani in the Republican primary, said in so many words yesterday that he would continue a token campaign as candidate for the Conservative Party - ''as a spokesman for the conservative solutions I've talked about.'' But he said he would not broadcast any television commercials and would refrain from ''discussing personalities and comparing contenders.''
Mr. Lauder formally released his Republican supporters from any obligation to vote for him, although in the news release sent out by his greatly reduced staff, he never mentioned the name of the man who beat him for the party's nomination.
 
The Pencil Campaign
Knocked off the Democratic ballot by a petition challenge, Assemblyman Sal F. Albanese, Democrat of Brooklyn, had to work hard to be nominated in last Tuesday's primary. It cost him 15,000 pencils and forced him to remind voters to spell his name correctly, but yesterday he was declared the winner by the Board of Election, with 6,378 write-in votes.
Actually, that was 6,372 more votes than he really needed, since the write-in candidate with the next highest total - his Republican opponent, Steven Maresca - received only five, and election law says that all you need is one more than your opponent.
To mobilize supporters to do more than pull the lever, Mr. Albanese distributed 15,000 palm cards, with pencils attached, and sent 200 people into his Bay Ridge-Bensonhurst district on Primary Day to make sure people spelled his name right.
Bruce Kaufman, Mr. Albanese's aide, said yesterday that no one had challenged the slight variations on the Assemblyman's name - cases where people dropped one of the e's in his last name or forgot the middle initial. ''They'll count it, as long as it is pretty darn close,'' Mr. Kaufman said.
The Board of Elections, however, did strike out ''Mayor Albanese,'' ruling that it was too far off the mark and more than a spelling error.

HEADLINE: Alaska Ghost Town May Become a Park

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KENNECOTT, Alaska, Sept. 20

 BODY:
A half-century ago, Federal officials made their first pitch to add the bright red buildings of this abandoned copper-mill camp, the country's largest ghost town, to the national park system. Several decades and proposals later, the idea is alive again.
Appraisers have finished poking through 40 or so structures built in 1906 for the Kennecott Mines Company, and a contract will be awarded soon to determine the cost of removing any asbestos and industrial chemicals left behind, said Dick Martin, superintendent of Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve, which surrounds this town about 235 miles east of Anchorage. 
The site comprises about 3,000 acres plus buildings owned by Kennecott Copper Corporation, which still operates in Utah. The mining town once had 800 workers. The cost of acquisition and cleanup could be several million dollars, Mr. Martin said.
The first proposal to fold the town into the national park system was made in 1938, he said.
''It came up again in the 40's, and I believe it was discussed again in the 50's,'' he said. ''There were various proposals, like using the tramways for ski areas and the dormitories for hotels, but nothing has happened.''
Kennecott Mines Company took its name from Kennicott Glacier in 1906. But the company misspelled the name. The company's workers may be gone, but many of their books and papers still lie on desks and most of the machinery that they used to crush and extract ore remains.
From 1911 to 1935, the Kennecott deposit produced 4.6 million tons of ore, which was refined into 591,535 tons of copper and 9 million ounces of silver worth some $300 million.
The discovery of vast copper deposits in Chile and economic dislocations brought by the Depression killed Kennecott, even though millions of tons of high-grade ore may still lie within Bonanza Ridge, which rises several thousand feet behind the processing facilities.
But it is history that makes the site so valuable, Mr. Martin said.
''There's always going to be some great value here for the public, even if some of these buildings fall down,'' he said. ''The more that are standing the better, clearly. But there always will be a great deal of value because of the people who lived here, the scenic value and what they did here.''
It might be possible to make the area safe for visitors to roam outside the buildings, he said, but it would be ''simply beyond our ability'' to restore all the buildings to safe condition.
Only a few tourists now walk or ski the trails leading to mines with names like Bonanza, Mother Lode and Jumbo. Visitors either fly to the 4,000-foot gravel airstrip at McCarthy, five miles down a rutted road, or drive the scenic Edgerton Highway to its terminus at the Kennicott River. There, they pull themselves hand-over-hand on a cable tram that separates the road from the wilderness.
At 13.2 million acres, Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve is the nation's largest national park. It abounds in wildlife - buffalo, caribou, moose, wolves, brown and black bear, among others. It also includes nine of the 16 highest mountains in the United States. Mount Wrangell is an active volcano, with steam and the odor of sulfur wafting near its summit.
Miners still extract gold and silver from the park, which is six times the size of Yellowstone but, because of its remoteness, has fewer visitors in a year than Yellowstone has on a summer weekend.
More than a million acres within the park are privately owned. The Kennicott Glacier Lodge would not be part of the ghost-town purchase, Mr. Martin said.

HEADLINE: Brady Plan Is Forcing Bank Loss

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The wrap-up last week of an accord to provide debt relief to Mexico is forcing a new round of losses at major American banks.
The accord between Mexico and its lending banks was the first under the plan devised by Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady to provide relief to the most indebted of the world's less developed nations.
The losses occur as the banks set aside more funds in preparation for the day when they must accept less than full repayment on their loans to the troubled debtor nations.
 
Plan at Chase Manhattan
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the third-largest banking concern in the country, said yesterday that it expected a loss of $1.12 billion this quarter, largely because it was setting aside $1.15 billion to be held in reserve for possible losses on its $6.2 billion of loans to less developed countries. On Monday, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation added $950 million to its loss reserves, and said it would lose $775 million this quarter. 
Increases in a bank's reserves for losses on its loans are immediately subtracted from its earnings.
Willard C. Butcher, chairman of Chase, said the Brady initiative had resulted in ''increased pressure on banks to reduce their claims'' and, at the same time, had ''increased the resistance on the part of some lesser developed nations to meet their contractual obligations'' to repay their debts.
The Brady plan, which was announced in March, is aimed at reducing the $1.3 trillion in debts of the less developed countries. Earlier, bankers focused their efforts on providing new loans to those nations.
 
Pact With Mexico a Signal
Mr. Butcher and John F. McGillicuddy, chairman of Manufacturers Hanover, both said that the loan agreement with Mexico was a clear signal that they needed to begin setting aside more reserves. The agreement was announced in principle in July, when Mexico had $100 billion in foreign debt, but its final terms were completed last week.
The pact, which the Bush Administration urged the banks to adopt, requires that banks choose between making new loans to Mexico and accepting a 35 percent reduction in the value of their loans. Few banks, however, are likely to accept the option of making new loans because of the increasing risks of loss.
Because there are large debtor countries whose condition is more dire than that of Mexico, many analysts have said banks might have to accept reductions of even more than 35 percent with those nations.
Bank loans to Brazil, for instance, which has $110 million of foreign debt and missed a $1.6 billion interest payment earlier this week, are today trading at about 30 cents on the dollar. Loans to Argentina, which has $60 billion of debt and has not paid interest in nearly 18 months, are trading at about 18 cents on the dollar. Banks and securities firms have begun trading these loans in the last few years as some banks, eager to rid themselves of these loans, become willing to sell at reduced prices.
In June, banks were required to declare a loss on 20 percent of their Argentine loans, and many analysts expect regulators to require additional write-offs in coming months.
 
Talks With Venezuela
Negotiations are now under way with the Philippines and Venezuela to provide debt relief under the Brady plan.
Since 1987, when Citibank added $3 billion to its reserves as pressure to recognize the deteriorating quality of the loans was building, the big banks in New York have set aside funds to cover roughly 30 percent of their loans to less developed countries. But because of the Mexican agreement, bankers are raising their estimates of the amount of reserves they should have to cover future losses. They noted that the Mexican agreement had led to cries for relief from other countries not in the same serious straits as Mexico.
The reserve at Manufacturers Hanover, at 22 percent, was the lowest of those at the large banks until Monday, when the bank announced plans to raise its coverage to 36 percent. Chase, which was at about 30 percent, said yesterday that it planned to raise its reserve fund to 46 percent.
To rebuild its finances after the loss, Chase said it planned to sell $500 million of new stock in coming weeks. Manufacturers Hanover also announced plans for a $500 million stock offering.
 
British Banks at 50% Level
Many analysts expect that other banks will follow suit in raising their reserves. The four leading British banks earlier this year raised their reserves to 50 percent of their troubled foreign loans, a level that is also maintained by many regional American banks.
''Other banks are going to look and say that, if Manufacturers Hanover can do it, we can too,'' said Christopher T. Mahoney, an analyst at Moody's Investors Service. ''Clearly, banks like Morgan Guaranty and Bankers Trust have the financial capacity to make larger reserves.''
Analysts who asked not to be identified said that the Chemical Bank was another candidate for an increase in its reserves. Chemical has reserves covering about 27 percent of its $4.6 billion of outstanding loans to less developed countries. Whether Chemical would also suffer a loss would depend on how much the bank might add to its reserves.
The amount of the loans covered by reserves will vary from bank to bank because some banks lent more to the most troubled countries. But an unusually low level of reserves relative to loans discourages buyers of bank stocks because they worry that some time in the future, when major debt negotiations are completed, the bank will be required to increase the reserves and possibly take a loss.
By increasing the reserves now, banks may be reassuring shareholders that it is less likely they will have to do so in the future.
Because traders and investors had been expecting announcements similar to that of Manufacturers Hanover, Chase stock rose $1 shortly before 3 P.M. when it announced a special 4 P.M. meeting. The stock ended the day up $1.625, to $39.50 a share. Manufacturers Hanover stock, which rose $2.25 on Tuesday, following its announcement, fell 12.5 cents yesterday. $15 Billion Set Aside in 1987 The latest round of increased reserves to cover possible losses is not likely to be as large as in 1987, when banks set aside about $15 billion in reserves, said Robert T. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''Insolvency of major banks is not one of the ramifications of increased reserves,'' Mr. Litan said. ''But there is no question that reserves have been insufficient at many banks.''
Now that the ice has been broken in a new round, Mark Alpert, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, said that ''the market is expecting these moves; it is a good time for banks to act.''
Not all bankers agree additonal reserves are needed. At Citibank, officials have consistently declined to add to the reserve since 1987.
John S. Reed, Citibank's chairman, said at a meeting of investment analysts last week that, ''from a practical business view,'' he was comfortable with the current level of reserves. Citibank's reserves of $2.6 billion, or almost 30 percent, to cover possible losses on nearly $8.9 billion of loans to less developed countries ''adequately cover the economic risk on those loans,'' he said.
 
Chase Stock Up $1.625
Other developments announced by Chase included cutbacks in its securities trading in London and New York and a large loss from the write-off of real estate loans at a troubled subsidiary bank in Phoenix.
By withdrawing completely from the market for British Government bonds, and reducing its activities in the American Treasury and mortgage-backed markets, Chase said it would suffer a one-time loss after taxes of $25 million but would increase 1990 earnings by $40 million. In London and New York, about 40 employees will be laid off, Mr. Butcher said.
The Arizona bank, which Chase bought in 1986 for $75 million, has been a problem almost from the day it was acquired, losing $42 million in 1988 and $30 million in the first six months of this year. Recognizing that the bank's real estate loans are worth only about 50 percent of their original value will result in a one-time after-tax cost to Chase of $85 million. But in the future, the absence of those loans should raise earnings by about $45 million a year.
About $155 million of loans from the Arizona bank will be set aside in a special company, whose sole job will be to sell the assets, while the remaining Chase Bank of Arizona continues with its consumer banking and lending to small businesses.
Chase officials told stock analysts that the package of actions would add about $205 million to their earnings in 1990, not counting the profit to be generated from the additional $500 million of capital to be raised from the stock sale. They said $75 million more of stock would be sold in 1990 through more generous features of a stock dividend and repurchase plan offered to shareholders, such as a 5 percent discount on purchases of new shares.

HEADLINE: Environment Dominates 91-Nation Energy Talks

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTREAL, Sept. 20

 BODY:
In a striking shift of focus, the 3,400 delegates gathered here from 91 countries to discuss the world energy picture have one dominant concern: the environment. Price and supply, the traditional focus of energy suppliers, have almost been squeezed off the agenda.
The delegates represent some of the world's most prominent experts on oil, coal, natural gas, shale oil, hydroelectricity, nuclear power, photovoltaic power, solar thermal power and even peat moss. But in most of the 160 technical papers presented here, the dozens of panel discussions and the major addresses, the worry at this triennial event has shifted from oil embargoes and declining reserves of fossil fuels to urban smog, acid rain and, above all, global warming.
The question, clearly, is no longer where the fuel will come from - one study released here noted a 30 percent increase in estimated oil reserves in the last three years - but how to use it safely. 
The producers have cause for worry. Industrial emissions of carbon dioxide, which scientists believe must be limited to slow global warming, could be 70 percent higher than current levels by 2020, assuming moderate economic growth, according to a major study released today by the World Energy Conference.
 
Changes in the Atmosphere
''It is unambiguous and beyond doubt that we are changing the composition of the atmosphere by a measurable and important amount,'' said Lord Marshall of Goring, chairman of Britain's Central Electric Generating Board,'' in a keynote address. The program includes an outline for a panel discussion on global warming, listing topics for discussion, but begins by saying, ''The existence of a greenhouse effect is not to be debated.''
For such a huge group of energy suppliers to put price, supply and production technology in second place is surprising, many of those present said. John Wakeham, Britain's Secretary of State for Energy, contrasted the concern now with the belief by Western nations in the 1970's that oil and other fuels were dwindling. That, he said, ''has been revealed as a gloomy fantasy and one of the most spectacularly mistaken forecasts of recent history.''
But even after the oil glut of 1986 drowned the talk of shortage, the talk did not shift to the environment. ''You would never have heard this three years ago,'' said Elihu Bergman, executive director of Americans for Energy Independence, a conservation organization based in Washington. ''This conference is symbolically legitimizing what we have known in the States: environmental policy is driving energy policy.''
A speech by Lee M. Thomas, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, reinforced the point. Mr. Thomas detailed decisions ranging from handling of the wastes from oil drilling to requiring anti-pollution equipment on power plants that cast his agency in the role of making energy policy. In another speech, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney made a similar point. ''Environmental sensitivity and economic growth, fueled by energy, go hand in hand,'' he said. ''We no longer have the luxury of trying to have one without the other.''
 
Growth in Energy Use
The carbon dioxide study, assembled by 30 experts from 18 countries and 9 international organizations, assumed only a small increase in each person's energy use over the period, but a near-doubling of the population in the third world, from 3.6 billion in 1985 to 6.3 billion in 2020.
The conference also released a separate study hinting that the reserves of fossil fuels are plentiful. A triennial study of resources found that global recoverable reserves of hard coal are up 80 percent since 1986, oil reserves are up 30 percent and natural gas is up 14 percent.
What was less clear than supply was where energy policy was being driven. Lord Marshall's prescription was nuclear power, a view that did not create a clear consensus here. Another conflict was between delegates from the third world and the developed countries over who would have to improve energy efficiency to minimize releases of carbon dioxide and other gases.
Chauncey Starr, the founder and former president of the Electric Power Research Institute of Palo Alto, Calif., pointed out that each North American uses, on average, seven times as much energy as people of the third world. For ''a huge portion of the world population,'' he said, the primary concerns are ''food supply and enough fuel for cooking and warmth.'' If that population increases its energy consumption only modestly - 2.3 percent a year, Mr. Starr said - the combination of population growth and higher consumption would quadruple world energy demand in 75 years.
Mr. Starr and others suggested investing in efficiency, especially in the third world; for example, Mr. Starr said, the efficiency of cooking over an open stove is 3 percent, versus 20 percent in a clay oven, a percentage increase far greater than that available in the industrial world.
But that focus may be wrong, said another delegate, Jassim al-Gumer, director of the economics department at the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Counties, in Kuwait. ''They have such little to spend on pollution, or energy,'' he said of the nonindustrial countries. India, he said, uses a barrel of oil a year for each person, Brazil 3 and the United States 45. ''How much pollution is coming from the 45 barrels versus the one barrel?''
For the developing countries that aspire to use more energy, limits on use to slow global warming seem unfair. ''Industrialized countries should recognize that they are to carry the lion's share of the total burden because they consume 80 percent of world energy resources,'' said Bong Suh Lee, the South Korean Minister of Energy Resources.
More than unfair, it may be impossible, said the British Secretary of State for Energy, John Wakeham. In any international agreement to cut emissions from burning fossil fuels, he said, ''We have to recognize that some backs are broader than others; that costs that are an inconvenience in the developed countries may make the difference between life and death in the third world.''
 
Allocating the Burden
But allocating the burden, experts said here, would be difficult. Speaking for the United States, W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Secretary of Energy, sounded distinctly unwilling to take too large a role, or to take substantial action before everyone else agreed. ''The good done by one country is offset by the increased damage done by another,'' he said.
But the United States and the rest of the world would feel a substantial effect from third-world energy growth, according to the study on energy growth, ''Global Energy Perspectives 2000-2020.''
Whether the level of carbon dioxide output represents an unrealistic constraint on the scenario painted by the study was not clear to the participants. Klaus Brendow, the director of the energy commission of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, noted that the scenario assumed that fossil fuels would provide about 80 percent of energy in 2020, down from 88 percent in 1985. ''The risks of a global warming resulting from such a bias are obvious,'' he said, calling for more research into renewable energy.
The scenario established in the study predicted that with moderate economic growth, third world use of coal would triple between 1985 and 2020; use of oil would double, and use of natural gas would more than triple. Worldwide, the study said, coal use would be up by 51 percent, oil by 66 percent and natural gas by 58 percent.
It also assumed that the use of nuclear power would more than triple, to account for 7 or 8 percent of energy supplies, compared with 4 now. An estimate by the organization in 1983 had put nuclear at 12 percent by 2020, but it was scaled back because construction has dropped off.
