HEADLINE: World's Fastest Train Makes Debut in France

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 20

 BODY:
A sleek silver and blue train known as the T.G.V. Atlantique sped from Paris to LeMans at 186 miles an hour today, as France introduced the world's fastest train to be put into commercial service. The train is so fast that France's principal domestic airline worries that it will lose passengers to the rail line.
The luxuriously appointed Train a Grande Vitesse, run by France's state-owned railway, connects Paris with cities on France's Atlantic coast, chopping the time for some trips nearly in half. The 125-mile trip to Le Mans, for example, takes 55 minutes, compared with 1 hour 40 minutes on other trains. Next year the T.G.V. will begin service to Tours in the Loire Valley and points south.
''The train has the potential of going 360 kilometers an hour,'' or 223 miles an hour, said Bernard Gondouin, spokesman for Altsthom, a subsidiary of Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, which built the train. ''But it would be unwise to make such a large jump in speed right now because it might scare away a lot of the public.'' 
The 490-ton electric train draws its power from eight 1,500-horsepower three-phase motors that are 40 percent more powerful than those on France's eight-year-old Paris-Lyons train, which has a maximum speed of 167 miles an hour. But, the manufacturer said, the increased speed reflects a refinement of exisiting technology rather than a technological breakthrough, and it is helped by the train's streamlined design, which minimizes wind resistance.
Although some passenger organizations protested because the train's prices will be 5 to 47 percent higher than current train tickets, French officials were crowing about the new train today because high-speed rail service is one of the few sectors in which France is the world's leader. Its trains far outpace the 130-mile-an-hour Tokyo-to-Osaka bullet train.
Prime Minister Michel Rocard, who spoke at the inauguration, hailed the T.G.V. as ''a great technical, commercial and financial success.''
 
Global Contracts Sought
French officials hope the new train will improve the nation's chances to win multibillion-dollar contracts to supply high-speed trains for a Miami-Tampa, Fla., route, a Montreal-Toronto run and a Seoul-Pusan line in South Korea. Transportation experts say high-speed trains can be more efficient than airlines at distances of 175 to 450 miles.
The French also hope their new train will be chosen over a German competitor for the high-speed rail network to be set up in 1993 to link Paris, Frankfurt, Brussels and, with the English Channel tunnel, London.
''Europe, an area that is densely populated and where distances traveled remain moderate, is particularly suited for fast rail links,'' said Jacques Fournier, chairman of France's Societe Nationale des Chemins de Fer, the state railroad company. ''France has taken an important lead in this area.''
His company invested $3 billion in new tracks and trains for the Atlantic route. It hopes to earn back the investment in a decade by attracting 22 million passengers a year on the line.
Atter Le Mans, the train will travel on renovated track to Rennes, the capital of the Brittany region, and to Brest and Nantes, two important coastal ports. The 237-mile trip to Nantes will fall to 1 hour 59 minutes from the current 2 hours 55 minutes.
Jean-Marie Metzler, sales director of the state rail company, estimates that the T.G.V. Atlantique will win over 40 percent of the 450,000 passengers who took planes for the Paris-Nantes trips last year.
''It's a competitor, that's clear,'' agreed a spokesman for Air Inter, France's principal domestic airline. ''We will probably feel a loss of customers between Nantes and Paris.''
A plane ticket costs $90, while a first-class Paris-Nantes ticket on the T.G.V. will cost $49.08 to $61.38, depending on the time of day, and second-class will range from $33.38 to $38.32. A one-way ticket to LeMans will cost $31.84 to $44.15 for first class and $22 to $26.95 for second class.
 
Tunnels for Deer Crossings
French officials say that the T.G.V. is environmentally sound. There are deer crossings built underneath the track in certain places, and there are sound barriers to protect nearby houses. In addition, in Vouvray, near Tours, a tunnel was built, with rubber cushions, to protect that town's vineyards and wine cellars as the T.G.V. rumbles through.
The train officially goes into service on Sunday, but in an inaugural run today for dignitaries and journalists, the train whizzed smoothly and quietly through hayfields and cornfields at 300 kilometers, or 186 miles, an hour. The ride was so smooth that it was easy to write on a note pad - and wine bottles did not rock on lap trays when lunch was served.
Among the train's amenities are telephones, small compartments for business meetings and a nursery with a ledge to change diapers and a machine to warm baby bottles. The train, which has ten cars rather than the eight of the Paris-Lyons train, can carry 485 passengers.
Paralleling the superhighway at some points, the train easily left behind France's speeding drivers, who often drive at 110 miles an hour. The one cause for passenger complaints was the sudden pressure changes when the train sped through tunnels.
 
'Just 2 Hours From Paris'
City and village officials in western France welcome the high-speed train. ''It should mean a lot to us,'' said Christine Angoujard, director of economic development in Rennes, a city of 200,000 people. ''Because we will be just two hours from Paris by train, we hope a lot of companies based in Paris will open branch offices here. We also think it should be a shot in the arm to tourism.''
French rail officials are confident the new line will be profitable. Last year, the Paris-Lyons line had 17 million passengers and net earnings of more than $100 million on $681 million in revenues.
Mr. Metzler, the sales director, said the French National Railway expected similar results from the T.G.V. Atlantique next year - $700 million in revenues with profit margins of 12 percent. Railroad experts say high-speed rail links can be profitable as long as they attract at least 10 million passengers a year.
''High-speed rail is one of the few growth areas in heavy electrical engineering,'' said Stephen Parker, an analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew, a London borkerage.
Despite the train's speed, Air Inter officials are optimistic that they will not lose many Paris-Bordeaux passengers when the T.G.V. begins serving that route next year. The train will cut the time for that 360-mile journey, now 4 hours 8 mintues, to just under 3 hours. The plane takes only an hour.
Transportation experts say that with today's crowded airports, it is hard for airlines to compete with trains when a rail trip takes 2 hours or less, but far easier when the train trip takes 3 hours or more.
 
Double-Decker Planned
For Alsthom, manufacturer of the T.G.V., the biggest contract on the horizon involves South Korea, which is expected to begin seeking official bids to build tracks and supply high-speed engines and trains for a 185-mile link between Seoul and Pusan.
''We're designing a double-decker T.G.V. to serve that route,'' said Alsthom's Mr. Gondouin.
Alsthom's main competitors for the Korean contract are a German consortium led by Siemens A.G. and a Japanese consortium that includes Hitachi and Kawasaki.
Rail officials say that Canada may also seek bids next year for a high-speed train. They see a Florida route as a longer-range project, which state officials are still debating.
Some trains have reached faster speeds in experiments, but are not yet in service. The German Intercontinental Express consortium reached 252 miles an hour in May 1988, while a French train, also built by Alsthom, surpassed that last December, reaching 254 miles an hour. Magnetic levitation trains, which hover above the rails, have reached even higher speeds in tests, but are expensive to build.

HEADLINE: A Film Tweaks G.M. Over Jobless

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Just as the General Motors Corporation was about to forget its public relations headaches of the 1980's, a rookie film maker appears to have scored a highly acclaimed hit with a documentary that tweaks the auto maker for the plight of the unemployed.
Michael Moore, the film's director and a self-described critic of the nation's economic system, has focused his lens on Flint, Mich., his hometown and G.M.'s birthplace. But instead of producing an anti-capitalist screed, which might easily have escaped public notice or been dismissed by critics, Mr. Moore made a parody, mocking G.M., as well as the efforts of President Reagan, the singer Pat Boone, the Rev. Robert Schuller and others to console and uplift the city's unemployed.
 
Stalked by Film Crew
The film's title, ''Roger and Me,'' refers to the chairman of General Motors, Roger B. Smith, who has suffered his share of public trials, contending with the billionaire investor Ross Perot, disgruntled auto dealers and fickle customers. To confront G.M.'s top executive on the company's decision to close plants in Flint, Mr. Moore and his film crew stalked Mr. Smith at the chairman's supposed haunts: the Grosse Pointe yacht club, the Detroit Athletic Club, the 14th floor of the G.M. building. They were turned away. But Mr. Moore cornered Mr. Smith at the company's Christmas gathering. 
A General Motors spokesman said that the company had never received a request for an interview with Mr. Smith, despite Mr. Moore's contention that he sent several letters to the company. In a statement, General Motors conceded that it had realigned operations in many locations to become more competitive, but said the effect of such changes appeared magnified in Flint because the company has its largest operations there. The auto maker also pointed out that by concentrating on ''the negative'' in Flint Mr. Moore failed to mention that G.M. has an annual payroll in that city of $2.5 billion.
Critics who have seen the film describe it as hilarious. It broke attendance records at the Telluride, Colo., film festival, won the top award at the Toronto film festival and is scheduled to be shown at the New York Film Festival on Sept. 27. Susan Stark of The Detroit News and others have predicted it will be nominated for an Oscar.
The film's black humor springs from the contrast between the bleakness of Flint's unemployment problem and what are portrayed as hopelessly superficial attempts to do something about it. In one scene, Miss Michigan glides by on a float and in the background are boarded-up stores. In another, an industrial development official boasts about the salvation offered by a factory that makes a lint-removal device.
 
Reagan's Treat
''Roger and Me'' also contains footage of President Reagan going to Flint to treat a dozen unemployed auto workers to a pizza; one later said on camera that the President had suggested a move to Texas as a cure for unemployment.
Mr. Moore, a counterculture figure who briefly edited the magazine Mother Jones, is the first to acknowledge that ''Roger and Me'' makes no pretense of being fair. It does not make a factual, logical case that General Motors deserves blame for the woes of the unemployed. Instead, he said in an interview, he hopes that when viewers stop laughing they will become angry and demand that corporations and unions accept more responsibility when people are thrown out of work.
From G.M.'s perspective, the film's celebrity comes at a most inconvenient time: In recent weeks, the Buick division, based in Flint, has been basking in some unusual media acclaim because its LeSabre model received high ratings for quality from J. D. Power & Associates. The influential marketing research group also awarded high marks for quality to the Buick City manufacturing complex in Flint.
And General Motors can point to some expanded employment opportunities at its plants in Flint, despite the decline in employment to 49,000 from a peak of 79,000 a decade ago.

HEADLINE: Europe Vows No Bias Against U.S. Chips

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today that the European Community had assured her that it would not discriminate against American manufacturers in setting rules of origin for computer memory chips.
The assurances, related to directives that Brussels is preparing to set up an integrated European market by the end of 1992, calm an issue that had threatened to escalate into a critical trans-Atlantic quarrel.
Mrs. Hills said here that she had received the assurances from European commissioners and officials during a six-nation tour last week.
The Europeans, she said, told her they would now treat semiconductors made in Europe, in the Silicon Valley or elsewhere in California ''as if they were the same.'' 
 
Concerns on TV Code
But Mrs. Hills continued to express concern about another European initiative, primarily sponsored by France, that would discriminate against American television programming on Europe's airwaves.
After postponing action in June because of American pressure, the European Council of Ministers is scheduled to vote next month on the Television Without Frontiers Directive, which would require that a ''majority proportion'' of broadcast time be reserved for European programs.
American chip producers have been caught in the backwash of complaints by European industry against the purported ''dumping'' of Japanese office machines and other products containing semiconductors.
To attack the Japanese, the Europeans altered some customs rules that have had the effect of subjecting American chip producers to a 14 percent duty, while United States chips had entered Europe duty-free.
 
'Fortress Europe'
This touched off protests from American industry, which contended that the Europeans had intended to use market integration as the rationale for creating an economic ''Fortress Europe'' that would discriminate against the rest of the world.
Mrs. Hills said she returned from her tour of the European capitals last weekend convinced that the community ''really doesn't want a resurgence of the view of the notion of Fortress Europe sailing across the U.S.''
The Semiconductor Industry Association, an industry group based in Cupertino, Calif., issued a guarded comment about the assurances. ''If Mrs. Hills feels the assurances will not lead to discrimination, that is great,'' said Jeanne Alford, the organization's director of communications. ''However, we will be following the issues with Europe very closely.''
The Hills trip, the industry officials said, is being followed up by bilateral discussions at the technical level to insure that the principle of nondiscrimination is applied to the specifics of customs procedures.
''The proof of Mrs. Hills's assurances will be in whether the bilateral talks make progress,'' said R. Michael Gadbaw, the Washington counsel for the semiconductor trade association.
 
Another Conflict Solved
Mrs. Hills said the European Community had quietly resolved another conflict threatening the harmony of Atlantic economic relations.
This involved customs rules set earlier this year based on assertions that the Ricoh Company, a Japanese copier maker, was trying to avoid 20 percent European dumping duties by assembling copiers in California and shipping them to Europe.
The community's rules, based on what the United States regarded as a departure from the norm in identifying the country of origin of an imported product, have apparently been quietly shelved, and Ricoh copiers from California are now coming into Europe as before, Mrs. Hills said.
Efforts to resolve trans-Atlantic trade disagreements before they become big confrontations are being given a high priority by the Atlantic partners so attention will not be diverted from the Uruguay Round of global trade talks, which are expected to be completed next year.
Washington and Brussels are hoping for freer trade in financial and other services and for greater protection for patents, copyrights and other intellectual property to emerge from the global liberalization talks.

HEADLINE: Economy Is Expanding Slowly, Fed Says

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The nation's economy is advancing at a slow to modest rate with substantial regional variation, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its ''beige book'' on current economic conditions.
The report, prepared for an Oct. 3 meeting of the Fed's top economic policy makers, said consumer spending, construction and manufacturing activity were mixed, while agricultural conditions continued to improve.
The findings appeared consistent with a number of recent economic indicators that have shown the economy in a holding pattern of modest growth and low inflation - the so-called soft landing favored by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. 12 District Banks Surveyed The current report was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis based on business and economic surveys conducted by the 12 district Fed banks before Sept. 12. 
The Fed gave no overall survey of the nation's inflation outlook, although five of the 12 Fed districts reported that raw material prices had eased for manufacturers, while another district reported higher prices.
Many of the Fed districts said in their separate summaries that growth was modest, sluggish, mixed or soft, with the general direction decidedly unclear.
The 12th district of San Francisco stood alone in a report of healthy growth in the West, supported by robust consumer spending, stable manufacturing, strong exports and good crop yields. Expectations for growth are rising, it added.
Atlanta, the sixth Fed district, said that weakness in business activity had abated and expectations had brightened for the rest of the year. The second district of New York also found recent signs of strength.
 
Sluggish Growth in St. Louis
In contrast, St. Louis reported sluggish growth, with no change in sight, while Philadelphia said that manufacturing continued to soften in a climate of modest growth.
The varied pattern of economic growth was echoed in the summary provided by the Fed in the opening pages of its ''beige book'' report.
''Consumer spending has been mixed, but most districts report strong sales of apparel and cars recently,'' the Fed said. ''Manufacturing conditions are generally satisfactory or improving in the nation's Southern and Western regions, but some weakening was noted in New England and much of the Midwest.''
The 12 districts reported much variation in the strength of construction and real estate, although several districts said falling mortgage rates in the summer stimulated the market.
In a brief summary of the labor market, the Fed said that three districts, Boston, St. Louis and San Francisco, reported a shortage of workers.
The Fed also noted that a surge in auto sales had helped pare auto inventories. Since then, the expiration of financing incentives has caused car sales to drop back, based on the industry's early September figures.

HEADLINE: Stocks Prices Slip, With Dow Falling 3.42

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices slipped yesterday in another cautious and slow trading session.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 3.42 points, to 2,683.89, as the 726 declining stocks outpaced the 697 advances.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 136.6 million shares, from 141.6 million on Tuesday. 
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 0.08, to 346.47, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.01, to 192.45.
''The market was possibly awaiting the outcome of the meeting between the United States and its chief economic allies in Washington this weekend,'' said Robert Ritter, chief technical analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. ''Bonds prices also were down sharply.''
Mr. Ritter said that the market appeared to be consolidating following the summer rally in which it added more than 300 points on the Dow. ''Currently less than 5 percent from its peak, the stock market has reacted very well to the recent junk bond fiasco,'' he said.
Among individual issues, Compaq Computer rose 7/8, to 88 1/8, after a Bear, Stearns analyst, Andrew Neff, repeated a ''buy'' recomendation on the stock because of new product announcements expected in the fourth quarter.
 
The Most Active List
Stocks where investors were apparently trying to capture dividends led the most active list. They included the Southeast Banking Corporation, unchanged at 26 1/2 in the No. 1 spot on a volume of 1.6 million shares and in the runner-up position, Portland General Corporation, up 1/8, to 23 7/8, on a turnover of nearly 1.3 million.
Chase rose 1 5/8, to 39 1/2. After the close, Chase announced that it had raised its reserves for losses on loans to developing countries by $2.9 billion, or about 46 percent of its total $6.2 billion of its medium and long-term debt.
Spain Fund soared 7 points, to 28 3/4, and was the Big Board's biggest percentage gainer in active trading. A representative of the company attributed the sharp rise to growing institutional interest in Spain Fund as well as a strong Spanish stock market. At the same time, First Iberian Fund gained 1 3/8, to 12 3/8.
Other international funds that have attracted attention of late also fared well. Thai Fund jumped 2 1/2, to 21 1/4; Italy Fund 3/4, to 10 7/8; Germany Fund 1/2, to 11.
AMR, whose American Airlines subsidiary has raised fares effective next week, rose 2, to 78 1/2.
Active blue chips included Upjohn, off 1/4, to 36 1/8; Syntex added 7/8, to 45 1/2; A.T.&T. slipped 1/8, to 41 7/8, and Bristol-Myers added 1/2, to 49 3/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index edged up 0.31, to 379.14, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.33, to 466.72.
In over-the-counter trading, Jaguar P.L.C. added 15/32, to 8 9/32. Ford Motor's European unit disclosed on Tuesday that it was interested in buying as much as 15 percent of the British luxury car manufacturer.

HEADLINE: Retailers Seek More Detailed Sales Data

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The International Council of Shopping Centers began issuing new monthly retail sales data yesterday that it said would be more accurate and comprehensive than those reported by the United States Government.
In its first report, on 1989's first half, the 27,000-member council said that the West Coast had taken the lead over the East Coast in percentage gains in retail sales of general merchandise, while gains in the South exceeded those of the North. Both shifts are reversals of previous patterns. 
''The South has especially benefitted from spectacular gains in the 'oil patch,' where pent-up demand is finally breaking loose,'' the report said, referring to oil-industry states, like Texas, that have experienced an economic slowdown in recent years.
 
Longer Lag Time
The monthly reports by the council will be issued two to two and a half months after the month being reported, a longer period than the reports of the Census Bureau of the Commerce Department, which usually reports within weeks.
The trade group said that it would buy certain raw data from the Census Bureau that would help it provide sales data that were ''ultimately more accurate than the Government's,'' Isaac Lagnado, the council's research director, said at a meeting yesterday. Mr. Lagnado said that his organization was paying ''six figures'' for the service from the bureau, which several years ago began accepting private-sector assignments.
''We have asked Census to go into an auditing procedure to provide 100 percent reporting as opposed to much of the bureau's projected data taken from a sampling,'' he said.
 
Problem With Revisions
He noted that one problem encountered with the usual pattern of Census Bureau reporting is that the monthly results that are reported are revised the following month when more data become available. ''We will be avoiding that by coming out later with a much larger data base,'' Mr. Lagnado said.
The report that the council yesterday showed that Western states had a 6.3 percent gain in retail sales for the first six months of 1989, compared with the similar period of 1988, that the South Atlantic states had a growth rate of 1.3 percent and that the New England states ''trailed the country'' with a 2 percent sales decline.
In the South, 14 standard metropolitan statistical areas had a sales increase of 11.2 percent in the first six months.
 
Turnaround in Oil States
''Since the oil-dominated economies have suffered through an extended economic contraction,'' the report said, ''a recent turnaround has apparently been sufficient to usher in a wave of consumer spending. This was by far the largest gain in an otherwise lackluster year, considering that the national, median gain was 4.5 percent.''
In the Middle Atlantic states, New York's metropolitan district had a 1.9 percent decline in June and a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent in the six months. The council said that Newark had the region's worst performance in June, while Jersey City had the best both in June and the six months.
The council said that its report covered 125 of the largest United States markets with data obtained by Census Bureau researchers from 6,000 stores. The retailers surveyed account for sales of $110 billion and included national chains, mass merchants and department stores.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
News of Hurricane Damage Sends Oil and Gasoline Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Reports of hurricane damage to a major Caribbean refinery sent gasoline and heating oil futures prices surging on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday.
Late in the day, the Amerada Hess Corporation confirmed rumors that had circulated in the market that its huge St. Croix refinery had been badly damaged by the storm and would be shut down for about 60 days. The refinery, with a capacity of 545,000 barrels a day, supplies markets in the Eastern United States and the Gulf of Mexico. 
The October contract for unleaded gasoline soared 2.07 cents to close at 59.74 cents a gallon after trading as high as 60.20 cents. Heating oil for October delivery jumped 1.60 cents, to 56.55 cents a gallon. Other contract months also had strong gains.
Traders said the strength in product prices helped buoy crude oil prices. The October contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of United States crude oil, rose 8 cents to close at $19.64 a 42-gallon barrel. November crude rose 29 cents, to $19.68, and December jumped 32 cents, to $19.46 a barrel.
Coffee futures prices surged on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York amid developments that at least momentarily appeared to improve the chances for a resumption of export quotas to support coffee prices.
Coffee futures settled 1.88 cents to 3 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in December at 82.55 cents for a pound of green, unroasted coffee.
The market, which had languished for most of the day, surged late in the session on news that President Bush had offered support to President Virgilio Barco of Colombia for a revival of coffee export quotas.
Coffee prices have fallen by about a third, hurting Colombia's economy, since the International Coffee Organization suspended export quotas in July, largely because of Washington's dissatisfaction with the system.
But the market quickly lost interest in the letter from Mr. Bush after learning the President had not altered the United States' previously stated conditions for rejoining the coffee pact: no more sales of coffee to nonmember nations and greater availability of high-quality arabica coffee beans.
The letter was quickly replaced by another ostensibly bullish factor: a report that Jorge Cardenas, president of the Colombia National Coffee Federation, would meet in Washington tomorrow with a United States trade negotiator, Robert Murphy, before both of them travel to London for a two-week meeting of the International Coffee Organization beginning Monday.
But Kim Badenhop, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc., said the Murphy-Cardenas meeting had been planned for some time and predicted the coffee meeting would produce nothing substantial.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Off Amid Rumors; Gold Prices Move Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slumped in skittish trading yesterday, while gold prices moved higher.
Analysts said the dollar was buffeted by rumors that the Federal Reserve was intervening in the market to push the dollar lower. 
Traders were also troubled by the prospect that the West German central bank, the Bundesbank, would move interest rates higher in that country today. Such a move, unless matched in this country by the Fed, would likely weaken the dollar.
Overseas dealers said Saturday's planned meeting of financial officials from the Group of Seven industrial nations added to traders' qualms. The market was concerned that participants in the meeting might want to see the dollar decline.
In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 145.10 yen, from 145.85 late Tuesday. The British pound was quoted at $1.5835, up from $1.5710.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.93965 West German marks, down from 1.9535; 1.6815 Swiss francs, down from 1.6905; 6.5560 French francs, down from 6.6010; 1,399.00 Italian lire, down from 1,406.50, and 1.18325 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18455.
Gold rose $3.70 an ounce, to $364.90. on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Gold traded late in London at a bid price of $363.25 an ounce, up from $360.50 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the closing bid price was $363.50, up from $360.50 late Tuesday, and in earlier Hong Kong trading, gold fell 34 cents to close at a bid of $361.42 an ounce.
On the Comex, silver rose 5.8 cents, closing at $5.119 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Familiar Partisan Banners Unfurl As Fight Over Taxes Takes Shape

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The lines were drawn in the House today for a bruising fight over taxes, with Democratic leaders scrambling to sell their newly devised plan as a boon to the middle class and Republicans asserting that it was just another tax increase.
Democrats cast the battle as a choice between a Republican capital gains tax cut for the wealthiest people and the Democrats' package of higher taxes on the rich and savings incentives for ''the fellow who carries the lunch bucket,'' in the words of Representative Dan Rostenkowski.
For all the populist oratory, Democrats acknowledged that they faced a tough fight with the Administration and a difficult sales job with their own membership. Republicans, for their part, waded into a familiar fray with an old charge: that Democrats were addicted to taxing.
President Bush said tonight on ABC's ''Prime Time Live'' that he was sticking to his campaign pledges of not raising taxes and cutting the capital gains tax. He said that he would veto the Democratic tax plan, if it passed Congress. 
It was a frenzied, hustling day of political positioning. ''Beginning today, the middle class fights back,'' said Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader. He made the remarks at a news conference with other House Democrats held to promote the Democratic alternative to the capital gains tax cut backed by the Administration.
Both sides were wooing conservative Southern Democrats like Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, a leader of the so-called boll weevils. Behind the anxiety of the party leadership was their recollection of 1981, when many Democrats defected to support the Reagan tax cuts. ''This is 1981 all over again, and I think it's very important for Democrats to stick together,'' said Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn.
The fight on the House floor next week will involve two very different tax plans. The measure passed by the House Ways and Means Committee last week, which has the support of the Administration, would temporarily cut the maximum tax rate on capital gains to 19.6 percent from 33 percent. It passed the committee with the support of six Democrats, and has the backing of many more on the floor of the House.
The Democratic leadership found itself faced with the prospect of political humiliation: watching a cut in the capital gains tax, which Democrats excoriated during the 1988 campaign, become law with the support of Democrats. This week the leadership came up with an alternative, stitched together to try to win enough votes from the left and the right of the Democratic caucus to defeat the capital gains tax cut.
The plan would raise the marginal tax rate for families making more than $155,000 a year and single people making more than $93,000, thus bringing their marginal rates in line with the rate paid by middle-income people. The marginal rate is the tax paid on the last dollar of income.
The plan also restores a tax deduction for contributions to individual retirement accounts and lets I.R.A. savings be used without penalty for educational expenses and first-time home purchases. Money raised by increasing the top marginal tax rate would be applied to reducing the Federal deficit.
Republicans today gleefully seized on one aspect of the Democratic plan: the fact that it included higher taxes. Representative Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip, took the floor today to say he found it ''amazing'' that the Democrats had learned so little ''from the lessons of 1984 and 1988.''
''Walter Mondale carried one state,'' said Mr. Gingrich, who added that Michael Dukakis had also been soundly rejected by the nation's voters. ''It is clear that a tax-increase liberal Democratic Party will remain a minority, and yet what are we going to see on the floor next week? We are going to see a tax increase that would threaten to kill the prosperity, bring on a recession, kill jobs, make America less competitive.''
 
Republicans See Opportunity
John Buckley, spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, asserted that the Democratic plan was ''an absolute bonanza'' for the Republicans.
For their part, the Democrats were casting the fight in class terms. ''Today we Democrats offer the nation a choice: giveaways for the rich, or I.R.A.'s for working people,'' Mr. Gephardt said.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley declared, ''The only people who are going to pay more taxes are people who make over $150,000 a year.''
Mr. Gephardt, whose unsuccessful 1988 Presidential campaign was based on the slogan ''It's your fight, too,'' was striking similar chords today. He asserted that Mr. Bush's plan was ''designed to keep Leona Helmsley's dream alive - that 'only little people pay taxes.' ''
Rich Galen, press secretary to Mr. Gingrich, said, ''Dick Gephardt is going to rerun the election of 1988, and he's going to lose again.''
 
Divided Ranks
The Democratic plan met with mixed reviews from House Democrats today. It was outlined in a party meeting, which participants said was an animated session that included sharp questioning of the plan from the right and the left.
Some Democrats criticize the plan because it leaves the party open to charges of backing a tax increase. Others worry that it involves the party in a bidding war of benefits and cuts that blurs distinctions with the Republicans.
''I'm not real wild about this approach,'' said Byron Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota. ''George Bush is proposing to give very large tax cuts to the rich, and this approach sits us down at the same table trying to negotiate a different deal.''
Still, other Democrats were rallying around the plan. ''If it's going to win the Southern Democrats, who are the fulcrum, over to our side, I support it,'' Mr. Schumer said.
Democratic leaders outlined details of their plan at a news conference. The plan would eliminate an anomaly in the current tax code under which families with incomes between $74,850 and $155,000 or single people with incomes between $45,000 and $93,000 are taxed at the top marginal rate of 33 percent. But taxpayers with incomes above those amounts are taxed at a top marginal rate of 28 percent. The Democrats' plan would end this so-called bubble by making the top rate 33 percent for the wealthiest taxpayers as well.
 
A Democratic Tax Cut
The Democrats also said they had come up with a provision that would amount to a capital gains tax cut for some taxpayers. Capital gains are now taxed at the same rate as other income, but Democrats said they would create a 28 percent maximum capital gains rate so that those affected by the 33 percent rate would pay a lower rate on capital gains.
Another part of the Democratic plan would restore a tax deduction for I.R.A.'s, for couples with incomes above $50,000. The deduction was eliminated in the 1986 overhaul of the tax code. Restoring it would cost the Treasury $15.4 billion over five years, according to the Democrats' figures.
But they said that that revenue loss would be more than offset by the $37 billion raised through increasing the top marginal income tax rate and other changes they propose. The $22 billion left over would be placed in what the Democrats called a ''deficit reduction trust fund,'' a move they hope would encourage budget-conscious Southern Democrats to support the package.
The tax measures are tied into a deficit reduction plan that must be passed to avert automatic spending cuts under the Federal budget-balancing law. ''This is domino politics,'' one Republican leadership aide said. ''We may be here till Christmas, fighting with each other. It's not a very pleasant picture. This sucker's R-rated.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (79%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: PRIME TIME FREEWARE (56%); NATIONAL REPUBLICAN CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEE (58%);

HEADLINE: Peres Plans to Visit Moscow At Peace Group's Invitation

 BODY:
Shimon Peres, the Israeli Labor Party leader, conditionally accepted an invitation from the Soviet Peace Committee to visit Moscow, a spokesman for the Israeli Government said yesterday.
Mr. Peres is visiting the United States and met here yesterday with a Soviet delegation that included Genrikh Borovikh, president of the Peace Committee. 
''On principle, he accepted the invitation, although he would like to make it more tangible,'' said the Israeli spokesman, Baruch Binah. Mr. Borovikh stressed that the invitation was not on behalf of the Soviet Government, Mr. Binah said. No date was discussed.
Mr. Peres would be the highest-ranking Israeli visitor to Moscow since the two countries severed ties during the 1967 Arab-Israeli War.
The hourlong meeting, attended by Yuri Snamensky, deputy chairman of the Foreign Economic Relations Commission, and Yuri Olkhovikov, deputy chairman of Gosplan, the state planning committee, also included plans for expanding trade and business ties between Israel and the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Where the Elk and the Diplomats Roam

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 21

 BODY:
In choosing Grand Teton National Park as a setting to talk about arms control with Soviet diplomats this weekend, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will be showing off one of the most dramatic places in the American West but also an area that is in conflict with itself.
A walk in the woods with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union during the two days of talk that begin here Friday, would lead the superpower diplomats to aspen and cottonwood groves holding a blush of gold amid bugling elks and foraging moose herds.
Cradling a half-dozen glaciers, the Tetons rise up a mile and a half from the floor of Jackson Lake, home of rare trumpeter swans, where the two foreign ministers will talk about chemical warfare and land-based nuclear missiles, among other things.
Mr. Baker, who has a ranch next to a prized trout stream 70 miles south of here, told friends that he chose Jackson Hole because he wanted to share with the Russians one of the garden spots of the earth - where the questions of war and peace might be influenced by nature's theatrics. 
 
'Power and Majesty'
''The power and majesty of those mountains ought to give anyone pause about the tangled events that we've allowed ourselves to get wrapped up in,'' said Senator Alan K. Simpson, the Wyoming Republican, whose father settled in Jackson Hole in 1897.
Jackson Hole, by the reckoning of some visionaries here, may well be on its way to becoming a sort of Geneva of the Rockies. But the fragility of the natural attractions also make some residents of ''the hole,'' as skiers call it, nervous about the attention.
''At the turn of the century people used to herd cattle here, but now they herd tours,'' said Bob Rudd, a historian and director of the Jackson Hole Museum. ''This has become a yuppie paradise. They're even talking about building a recreation center so we can teach people how to walk in a heated room.''
 
More Elk Than People
Mr. Rudd said he was concerned that the abundant wildlife and the crowds who come to ski, hike, hunt, fish and gaze at the scenery might one day be incompatible.
At certain times of the year there are still more elk in this valley, from the largest native herd left in the world, than there are people. The summit spire of Grand Teton, 13,770 feet above sea level, will never be like Central Park on Sunday.
Residents of Jackson Hole, so named by 19th-century fur trappers, like to say that everything America used to have - free roaming antelope, eagles crowding the sky, air you can't see and bison munching on prairie grass - is still here.
But this is also a place where cowboy boots can cost $700 at one of the tony leather boutiques surrounding the square in Jackson, the main town in the area, and a buffalo burger can set you back $8 and change.
 
Wood Planked Sidewalks
Cowboys, authentic and urban, walk the wood planked sidewalks in the occasional company of Harrison Ford, the movie star who has a ranch in this valley, and James G. Watt, the former Secretary of Interior, who is building a home with money earned lecturing against environmentalists and consulting with the Government.
Teton County, which borders the park, is the richest and fastest growing county in Wyoming - America's least populated state with 480,000 people. Now facing the 12,000-barrier, Teton officials are trying to decide whether to allow a huge mall to be built in a field where hay is cut by horse-drawn mowers.
The Russians, whose advance delegation of journalists and diplomats have taken to this valley like a child on his first trip to Disneyland, will not have to look far to find American cowboy kitsch.
 
Russians Tour the Town
Mr. Rudd, the historian, was showing a group of Russians around town earlier this week and said they were overwhelmed by Jackson Hole's connection to its more rowdy past.
''They said that before the visit they thought all Americans were born in front of a TV set,'' Mr. Rudd said.
Senator Simpson believes that the allied nations eventually could hold their economic summit meeting here and that President Bush, who has fished the Snake River for blue ribbon trout, could meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the shadow of the peaks named Les Troi Tetons (the Three Breasts) by French trappers.
 
'Best Hope for Future'
''The recreation counties like Jackson Hole hold the best hope for the future,'' said Philip M. Burgess, president of the Center for the New West, a Denver-based research institution.
''What these emerging areas all have in common is an outstanding environment and some kind of intellectual activity or convention center,'' he said. ''People understand that their natural environment is the best thing they have going for them and they can't afford to foul the nest.''
In Jackson Hole, a valley 6,100 feet above sea level, 97 percent of the land is owned by the state or Federal Government, a condition which conservationists say should guarantee long-term protection.
The transience of humans here is reflected in a poem written by Edith Sargent, a pioneer settler from New York. In her poem, titled ''The Grand Teton,'' she wrote:
 
The ages pass and men die fast
But still the Tetons stood
In stately silence to the last
Wrought by no human hands.

HEADLINE: Politburo Shuffle? Muscovites Shrug

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Out on the streets, where Kremlin-watching is no mere academic exercise, the morning-after view of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, master Politburo purger, was of a man whose political gifts still fail to ease the national torment of fading opportunity.
''I've been waiting in line since May,'' said Aleksandr Y. Daskal, one of the horde of Soviet citizens who every day encircle the American Embassy searching for the chance to apply for a visa to leave the hard times of this country for good.
On Wednesday night, Mr. Daskal heard the news that Mr. Gorbachev had purged five men, most of them regarded as conservatives who have delayed Mr. Gorbachev's program of political and economic change.
Mr. Daskal described the purge as a more or less annual event now in Mr. Gorbachev's attempt to get the nation moving again. 
 
Waiting List of Thousands
Mr. Daskal said he appreciated Mr. Gorbachev's frustration, but he nevertheless kept his place in line. He is No. 2,049 in the initial line organized by the waiting crowd as the means of getting to the real line, the embassy's waiting list for visa applications.
This list is now at scores of thousands and growing, with American officials about to introduce even tighter quotas. Still, it is one of the few bits of hope for more and more Soviet citizens who find themselves less fettered by political repression but freer mainly to cope with economic depression.
''The situation gets more and more tense in our country, and our problems will be solved by either the democratic methods of Gorbachev or by the old methods, the methods of the 1950's,'' Mr. Daskal said. He is a 34-year-old construction worker, a family man whose dark estimate of Mr. Gorbachev's chances prompts him to stand in line for hours every day, looking for a way out of the nation's great subculture of standing and waiting.
 
'Changes Mean Nothing'
For such Muscovites, Mr. Gorbachev, in his latest lightning purge of Politburo members, may as well have been mastering some desk-top executive game in the Kremlin.
''The changes mean nothing,'' said a man holding his daughter's hand and standing angrily outside the latest emporium that is taboo for hard-pressed Soviet shoppers, a new supermarket stocked with delectable Western goods, from bright fresh bananas to thick steaks, unavailable to most Soviet citizens.
''We went in and had a look and had to leave, of course,'' the man said of the store, which is closed to most Muscovites, his eyes glistening from a sense of insult. His daughter tugged at his sleeve, wanting to walk away from the store's masked windows, behind which a checkout counter was laser-reading high-priced goods that spilled along like some fantasy cornucopia.
The store, not far from the Kremlin, was opened by Stockmann's, the Helsinki store that long has discreetly shipped in weekly orders of first-grade food, clothing and furnishings to Western diplomats and journalists here.
 
Credit Cards Only
For a few days after the store was opened, some resourceful Soviet citizens used the store, producing hard-earned dollars normally hidden in mattresses because of the law against ordinary citizens possessing foreign currency. As the authorities showed interest, the store introduced a credit-card only policy. Now, Soviet citizens can must stand outside and wait, this time, however, with noticeable anger.
Before the latest purge, President Gorbachev exhorted his elite Communist hierarchy to find ways to ''defuse tension'' along the long, slow lines of Soviet shoppers with his programs of perestroika, or political and economic change, and glasnost, or increased openness.
Mr. Daskal, waiting at the American Embassy for his number to come up for a chance at getting away, said: ''We've had four years of perestroika and glasnost and things have only gotten worse. the only thing we have is more glasnost and perestroika.''

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Neighborhood Not a Cradle of Racists;
Italy's True Heritage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an Italian-American, I feel deep shame that an Italian neighborhood should again be the site of a brutal racial murder and that the Italian flag should be waved at protesting black marchers as an emblem of bigotry and cultural insularity. Italian philosophers were the first Westerners systematically to develop the concept of a universal humanity united by the rule of law. 
But it was my grandmother, an illiterate landless peasant from the plains of Puglia, who taught me that the human heart speaks a single language of desire and terror. Racism is profoundly alien to both the high-literate and popular traditions of Italian civilization.
When the Pentecostal pastor Herbert Daughtry (Op-Ed, Aug. 29) invokes Carl Jung's unproved notion of a peculiar ''race consciousness'' to explain the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins, he consigns the solution to the problem to the unchangeable regions of the psyche and not to the changeable structures of interaction and communication between ethnic and racial groups.
Nor should black and white leaders forget that it is young men - white and black - poorly educated and economically marginal, who are responsible for most of the violence that threatens to ignite a larger conflagration. We ignore their yearnings and waste their fierce energies at our peril.
 
THOMAS BELMONTE
 Brooklyn, Sept. 1, 1989
The writer, a professor of anthropology at Hofstra University, is author of ''The Broken Fountain,'' a study of the inner-city poor of Naples.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
In a Small Town, One Pharmacist Versus a Chain

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
Neil Norwood has always tried to give his small-town pharmacy a personal touch. He keeps one bottle of Odol imported mouthwash on the shelf for Mrs. Bogyo. ''Mrs. Bogyo's happy when she comes in and sees it,'' Mr. Norwood said. ''The fire chief comes in for Ionil medicated shampoo in the 32-ounce size. Pat Warner just bought her Norell cologne, so I don't have any, but I've reordered and her Norell will be there next time she's in.''
All his life, Mr. Norwood dreamed of owning a pharmacy. He worked as a delivery boy at 14. By 16 he was recommending over-the-counter medications. His father and older brother are also pharmacists, and nine years ago, at 26, Mr. Norwood bought Russell & Lawrie, the village's oldest pharmacy, founded in 1894. 
People expect a lot from a small-town pharmacy. When Jim Beach couldn't reach his pharmacist to fill a prescription one afternoon, Mr. Beach called the man at home that night and yelled at him. ''I said, 'You have violated a public trust.' '' Mr. Beach switched to Russell & Lawrie, and so far, he says, he has not had to yell at Mr. Norwood.
''I love what I do,'' Mr. Norwood said. ''And I think it shows in my work.'' But two weeks ago a pharmaceutical force blew into town that not even Mr. Norwood is sure he has a salve for. The CVS chain (770 stores in 14 states) opened a new pharmacy a few doors away. ''I'm probably more nervous than I should be,'' Mr. Norwood said, ''but I'm nervous.''
His regular customers keep asking what he is going to do. ''It makes you nervous when people keep asking what you're going to do,'' Mr. Norwood said. ''What is he going to do?'' asked Barbara Cohen, a regular.
''I'm worried, of course,'' Mr. Norwood said, ''but I'm self-confident. When I bought the store, I was doing 30 prescriptions a day. I built it up to 100. Monday I did 140; that's a good feeling. I love pharmacy. I love being where I'm needed. I'm sure I am nervous about it. But I feel my customers I've got in, I've earned.''
He paused to get Mrs. Deely's blood pressure pills. ''Neil is very, very nice,'' she said.
''Even if they take away just 10 a day, that's 10 percent of my volume,'' Mr. Norwood said. ''We do everything we can. I'm just afraid people will think that the grass is greener on the other side.''
He got Mrs. Capalbo's antibiotic. ''There isn't anyone who doesn't like Neil,'' she said.
Mr. Norwood knows what goes through people's minds when they think of CVS: a giant, economy life style, tubs of cold cream, industrial drums full of mouthwash.
Russell & Lawrie is just two rows wide, 1,000 square feet. CVS is 9,417 square feet. CVS is constantly running full-page advertisements in the newspapers. Mr. Norwood runs a two-by-three-inch advertisement. ''It costs $35.''
He is bracing for the CVS big guns. Soon, he knows, CVS will make its introductory offer -up to $10 off a prescription. For a few years he has seen this coming: nine new CVS pharmacies in Westchester County in 10 years. ''I was going to be prepared,'' he said. ''I was going to have my store as strong as possible.'' He emphasized service, bolstering home deliveries, taking blood pressure free, joining a cooperative to qualify for bulk-rate purchases.
His assistant, Steve Eckstein, became certified as a fitter of therapeutic braces. ''We do three to four a week,'' Mr. Norwood said. ''I don't want to lose even one customer. I'm probably more nervous than I should be. If I see someone looking dissatisfied, I ask why.''
Meanwhile, down the street at CVS, Lip Quencher was on sale for $1.99; 60 Ziploc bags were 99 cents; Afrin 12-hour nasal spray was $2.88. The CVS pharmacist referred a reporter to the manager behind aisle 14. The manager said talk to the regional pharmacy supervisor, who provided a toll-free number in Rhode Island. Gary Charboneau, a pleasant-sounding vice president, said the CVS philosophy was to open many stores in an area to take advantage of the economy of scale in advertising. ''The strong independents will remain,'' he said. ''You do have some weaker guys going out. It's often that they're not good business people.''
Mr. Norwood believes he will be here when the dust settles, though he doesn't think the village can support its five pharmacies. He is reminded of the need for vigilance every time Jerry Sachs comes in. Mr. Sachs had a health and beauty store in Mamaroneck until CVS moved across the street. ''We owned that store 17 years, but we couldn't match CVS prices,'' Mr. Sachs said. ''Sure, it hurts to close. You see your people walking across the street to CVS, it's heart-wrenching.''
He says he does not hold it against CVS. ''It's just a business thing,'' he said. Mr. Sachs is now a regional salesman for a drug wholesaler. ''I sell to CVS now,'' he said.

HEADLINE: THE LAW;
Coke in Bitter Legal Fight Over Cost of Sweetener

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 21

 BODY:
In the cavernous lobby of the Coca-Cola Company's headquarters here is a crystal globe ringed with delicate glass doves marking the company's 100th anniversary in 1986. It carries the inscription: ''Congratulations from your partners and friends, the bottlers of Coca-Cola 1886-1986.''
But there will be no doves around the Federal courthouse in Wilmington, Del., on Monday, when Coca-Cola and a group of bottlers resume a bitter eight-year-old legal fight whose roots go back almost 70 years.
In three lawsuits, the bottlers are charging that Coca-Cola has failed to live up to a 1921 contract. But what is really at issue is the role of Coca-Cola's independent bottlers, whose history is almost as old and distinctive as the soft drink itself. 
For the plaintiffs, about 30 relatively small bottlers, it is a David and Goliath battle to maintain their historic relationship with the company. They are seeking damages that with interest could come to $100 million by the time the trial ends.
 
'Negotiating With the Russians'
''Negotiating with the Coca-Cola Company is like negotiating with the Russians: what's theirs is theirs and what's yours is negotiable,'' said Emmet J. Bondurant 2d, the chief attorney for the bottlers and a principal of Bondurant, Mixon & Elmore in Atlanta.
For Coca-Cola, it is a struggle with a small band of holdout bottlers unwilling to face economic reality.
''From our standpoint, they're trying to get something no other bottlers are trying to get,'' said Robert Keller, general counsel for Coca-Cola. ''The real quarrel they have is that the economic system has changed.''
The origins of the dispute lie in the original vision for Coca-Cola.
The company's founder, Asa Candler, apparently felt Coca-Cola's future was primarily as a soda fountain beverage, not a bottled soft drink. In 1899 he gave two lawyers in Chattanooga, Tenn., Benjamin F. Thomas and Joseph B. Whitehead, exclusive rights to sell Coca-Cola in ''bottles or other receptacles'' throughout all but eight states. In return, he received $1 and agreed to sell them his syrup at a fixed price.
 
Dispute Over Sugar Prices
That arrangement worked until World War I, when soaring sugar prices made it onerous for the company. When Coca-Cola tried to change the contract it touched off a legal battle with the bottlers that finally resulted in a 1921 settlement that tied any price increases the bottlers would pay for the syrup to increases in the cost of sugar.
In the 1970's, when the inflation rate was soaring, a similar dispute arose as Coke again tried to free itself from what was essentially a fixed-price contract. In 1978 the company proposed an amended contract that split the cost of sweetener from the base ingredient and tied increases for the latter to increases in the Consumer Price Index.
The amendment also provided that if Coca-Cola modified the syrup formula to replace sugar with ''another sweetening ingredient,'' the resulting savings would be passed along to the bottlers who agreed to the amended contract.
All but about 90 of more than 400 bottlers went along with the change. In 1980 the company began switching from sucrose to less expensive high fructose corn syrup as a sweetener. It passed the savings along to bottlers who agreed to the revised contract. But for syrup sold to the bottlers who refused to sign it continued to set syrup prices according to the market price of granulated sugar, as stipulated by its interpretation of the old contract.
 
Contract Violations Charged
That left the other bottlers at times paying substantially higher prices for their syrup. Seventy-three dissident bottlers filed suit in 1981, saying the company had abridged the 1921 contract by changing its formula without their consent and refusing to pass along the cost savings to them.
In 1987, after a court ruling in favor of the bottlers, Coca-Cola reverted to supplying the bottlers who refused to sign with the more expensive sucrose sweetener while giving the other bottlers the fructose syrup.
Since then the two sides have flailed away in litigation that has revolved around details like the definition of sugar and Coca-Cola Bottler's Syrup and the difference between ''market,'' ''list'' and ''quoted'' prices of sugar. Also at issue is whether Diet Coke is covered under the 1921 contract.
The hearings dragged on for so long and in such detail that Federal District Judge Murray S. Schwartz, who presided over the case from its beginning, issued a ruling in 1986 chastising both sides for being unable to settle the case. #17-Week Trial Last Year Undeterred, both sides plowed on, culminating last year in a 17-week trial that produced thousands of pages of transcripts, closing briefs, conclusions and findings. Now they must now do it all over again. After the hearings, Judge Schwartz became too ill to work and has been forced to relinquish the case.
The new judge, Joseph J. Farnan Jr., steps into litigation that has already dragged on for eight years and in which Judge Schwartz has written 12 opinions.
Each side says the other has been unwilling to settle, but both admit the litigation is about more than the price of sugar.
To the bottlers, the suit is part of an effort to maintain the partnership role they have had since 1899. As recently as 30 years ago there were more than 1,000 bottlers in the United States. Now there are about 160, and the 10 largest account for more than 80 percent of the bottled and canned Coke sold in the United States.
The largest bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., 49 percent of which is owned by Coca-Cola, now accounts for almost half the bottled and canned Coke sold in the country.
 
'A Master-Slave Relationship'
The bottlers who are suing say Coca-Cola has used every means at its disposal, from overcharging for syrup to withholding advertising funds and threatening to withhold products, in order to bring them into line as part of an effort to undermine the historic relationship with its bottlers.
''We would like to maintain the relationship we have, that we've always had, where it's a partnership and not a master-slave relationship, which is basically where these businesses have evolved for a lot of bottlers now,'' said William Schmidt, president of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company in Elizabethtown, Ky., whose family has been in the bottling business since 1901. His company is one of the plaintiffs.
The Coca-Cola Company says the plaintiffs are asking for the best of both worlds: the advantages of a clearly outdated old contract and the increased national marketing they say the company is doing as a result of the new contract.
Company officials say the shrinking number of bottlers reflects the competitive environment throughout the bottling industry.
 
'Economic Realities' Cited
''Those are the same economic realities whether you're a Coke bottler, a Pepsi bottler or a Royal Crown bottler,'' said Frank C. Jones, a partner with the Atlanta firm of King & Spalding, who is Coke's lead defense attorney.
To some degree the battle for the small independents has already been lost. The 15 or so active plaintiffs of the 30 bottlers still involved in the case make up more than 10 percent of the nation's soft drink bottlers but account for less than 3 percent of the total volume sold.
Meanwhile, as lawyers prepare for trials that will probably last into next spring, neither side expects any big surprises.
''By this time there's no room left for any kind of ambushes,'' said Mr. Bondurant, the bottlers' lead attorney. ''It's going to be more like a tank attack.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 22, 1989

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 2; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3145 words

HEADLINE: Documentaries Are Hot At the '89 Film Festival

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
HAS the power of the documentary film to bear witness to reality endured in an era saturated by the instantaneous images of television news? Has the documentary been rendered irrelevant - or worse, boring - by the competitive video verite of the Cable News Network and its 24-hour-a-day bulletins in millions of homes? Such concerns, debated by film makers, critics and assorted videologues, are answered definitively by the New York Film Festival in its 27th series, which opens tonight.
This season, in the remarkable ways they transcend cliche, the festival's offerings demonstrate the indomitable perseverance of the art of the documentary.
''Talk of the death of the documentary is as appropriate as talk about the death of the novel,'' said Frederick Wiseman, a master of the documentary who has made the longest movie included in the festival: ''Near Death,'' an unblinking 5-hour-and-48-minute examination of the dance of life in the intensive-care unit of a Boston hospital. ''The images you see on television news are so superficial, they don't begin to touch the mountains of complexities and feelings and ambiguities behind those images. People working in the documentary form are expressing what they mean to say in ways that are certainly unpredictable - and I, for one, think that's great.'' 
The majority of the festival's 33 films from 13 countries are not documentaries, of course. But a remarkable number of this year's fictional offerings do more than accentuate the nonfiction crossover trend. Many offerings clearly demonstrate the film makers' preoccupation with the nature of the real. Several films explore their characters' emotional interaction with video representations of other characters, a la ''Sex, Lies and Videotape.'' The tension between things real and imagined is evident even in lyrical cinematic experiments like Bertrand Blier's ''Too Beautiful for You,'' a hallucinatory exploration of love and passion that opens the festival this evening.
The film, which stars Gerard Depardieu and Carole Bouquet, is the first of six full-length features that will be screened this weekend at Lincoln Center. It is one of the 11 films in the festival already picked up for American distribution. The festival will conclude Oct. 9 with Bill Forsyth's ''Breaking In,'' a caper movie about two small-time thieves, starring Burt Reynolds and Casey Siemaszko.
''Too Beautiful for You,'' Mr. Blier's antic deconstruction of the hoary French menage-a-trois drama of husband, wife and mistress, has an unceasingly reflective quality. Structurally, scenes rooted in reality seem to engender a succession of fantasy sequences as dreamlike as the state of being in love. Real-enough characters talk to the camera, each other and total strangers in a public verbalization of their own interior monologues; fantasy seems to be propelled by the reality of the characters' thoughts.
Film makers' engagement with a documentary esthetic ''seems to be a strong trend,'' said Richard Pena, chairman of the festival's program committee. ''Perhaps the events of the world are achieving a kind of primacy in some artists' minds.''
''Or maybe the escapist fare from Hollywood is so unsatisfying that we're all looking for something with relevance and staying power,'' said Wendy Keys, executive producer of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which presents the festival. But the very word documentary ''carries a burden,'' she added.
''The voice-over, the old film clips, the interviews - all of us absorbed these techniques in grade school watching films called 'The Making of Aluminum,' '' she said. ''This burden is not lost on the documentary makers.''
Some offerings in the festival, she said, ''are a reaction to - or a subversion of - the traditional video white papers that don't seem to stir us anymore.''
 
From Real to Quasi
There are a dozen documentaries, diary films and ''crypto-quasi-documentaries'' - as Ms. Keys put it, with a laugh - at the festival this year. One entry is a documentary made by a film maker who has minimal tolerance for documentaries. The black comedy ''Roger and Me,'' to be shown on Wednesday and Thursday, was written and directed by Michael Moore. It has been eagerly anticipated since becoming a runaway hit at the recent film festivals in Toronto and Telluride, Colo. In Toronto last Sunday, moviegoers voted it the festival's most popular film, the first documentary to win since ''Best Boy'' in 1979, which went on to win an Oscar.
''It's not exactly an anti-documentary,'' said Mr. Moore, interviewed in Toronto, where he received a standing ovation after the screening of his film. ''It's just a documentary made by someone who doesn't like documentaries.''
''Roger and Me'' is a personal essay by Mr. Moore, a 35-year-old former journalist, on the closing of the General Motors factories in Flint, Mich., his hometown. The film depicts the grim realities of the Rust Belt blues in a way that is so elliptical that festival critics in Toronto and Telluride have hailed it as a masterpiece of comedy. That's right, comedy.
''I think it's almost impossible to make a standard documentary now,'' Mr. Moore said. ''Who wants to watch another documentary about a dying steel town? Who wants to see a shot of another unemployment line? The images from TV news have made traditional documentaries obsolete.''
In its abundance of personality, Mr. Moore's film often seems to evoke fictional comedies. ''People at the festivals have the hardest time putting it in a category,'' said Mr. Moore of his film. ''There's no fiction in it, but it usually winds up being screened with the fiction features. I guess it's not your usual documentary.''
 
Reality-Based Fiction
But if documentary films can be confused with fictional offerings, reality-based television itself is flirting with fiction. These days, ''television is playing fast and loose with fiction and reality - you know, every time you turn on the TV, there seems to be a new show fictionally purporting to re-enact a crime or event,'' said Mr. Pena.
Mr. Wiseman said: ''Those kinds of re-creations are disturbing to me. They're playing with illusion to the point that people don't know how to touch base with real events anymore. The idea of it appalls me.'' He added: ''In real life you can get events that are as funny or sad as those in the greatest novels. You just have to be there to stumble across them.''
Mr. Moore, who is a character in his own movie, is one of many directors at the festival who are redefining the concept of auteur, which once described the guiding intelligence that created a film. Now it also seems to mean a person engaged in the action, not only as a witness, but also as a participant. Yet ''Roger and Me,'' narrated by Mr. Moore in a very personal way, is the auteurial anitithesis of Mr. Wiseman's narratorless investigations. In fact, ''Roger and Me'' is so personal a statement about such an impersonal thing as a factory city, that the film seems closely related to several of the ''diary films'' at the festival.
 
Media's Effect
One such work is ''Current Events,'' to be shown Oct. 7, in which the director Ralph Arlyck offers his own intensely personal journal to address the effect of the news media on the townspeople of the global village. ''I sometimes feel that I live suspended with that other world of news drifting out there like a dream, far away,'' he says in the film, then demonstrates just how that other world impinges on his consciousness, his family and his soul.
Also to be shown Oct. 7 is ''Dreams From China.'' This diary film by Fred Marx is a lyrical observation of that country, which is also the setting for Joris Ivens's ''Tale of the Wind,'' to be shown Monday and Tuesday. ''Wind'' is a diary, an essay and a meditation on the life, the work and the art of the Dutch Mr. Ivens, a master of the documentary form, who died in June at the age of 91. His film deals with the elusiveness of his subject - the wind - just as his own lung problems, he says in the film, gave him difficulty in his youth with catching breath itself. The film, co-directed by Mr. Ivens's longtime collaborator Marceline Loridan, includes not only documentary elements, but also fantasy sequences that evoke the work of Georges Melies.
Mr. Wiseman said that he, like Mr. Moore, finds ''the traditional documentary boring, the sort that has run its course since the beginning of television. I responded to that by doing my own films, with no narration.''
Mr. Wiseman's exhaustive study of the presence of death in a Boston hospital takes as its subject the impact of advancing medical technology on the prolongation of the lives of the gravely ill. The film will have its world premiere at Alice Tully Hall on Oct. 7.
Mr. Wiseman said his work grew out of the cinema verite movement in the late 1950's and early 60's, when the advent of hand-held equipment and fast film made it possible for film makers to capture reality directly and unobtrusively.
 
Verite Derivative
Curiously, one of the fictional films at the festival, ''The Plot Against Harry,'' to be shown tomorrow, is also derived from the cinema-verite movement. The gritty story of a small-time numbers satrap just released from jail was shot by the director Michael Roemer in the 1960's. Funds became available only recently to complete the post-production work.
Filmed in black and white, suffused with street noise, ringing phones, barking dogs and settings that have a transcendent 60's authenicity about them, the film emerges in 1989 as if from a time capsule. ''It is an example of a kind of cinema that never came into being,'' said Mr. Pena. ''It uses the language of cinema verite in a fictional context. But that cinema -exemplified by the work of directors like John Cassavetes - was somewhat stillborn.''
Nevertheless, cinema verite is alive and well at this festival, and so is a kind of video verite. Several films probe the interaction of video images with their protagonists' state of mind. One of them, ''The Documentator,'' by Istvan Darday and Gyorgyi Szalai, which will be shown Oct. 1 and 2, chronicles a love triangle set in a video shop. The obsession of the store owner, Raffael, is not only to spy on his girlfriend, but also to compile a video archive of the history of the world. Ultimately, Raffael's ''visual encyclopedia'' serves to make the reality of history itself a kind of packaged commodity, to be play-buttoned, paused, fast-forwarded and ejected.
In another fictional film, Atom Egoyan's ''Speaking Parts,'' to be shown Sept. 29 and 30, a woman rents videotape after videotape searching for the image of a young actor who has worked as a film extra. Her infatuation with his image, as well as a portrait of the actor's own post-electronic disaffection, make this film a meditation on emotional alienation in the era of the microchip.
 
Artists' Portraits
Several of the festival's documentaries are portraits of well-known artists. Charlotte Zwerin's ''Thelonious Monk: Straight, No Chaser,'' a portrait of a brilliant musician and troubled personality, will run on Sept. 30. And Anne Belle and Deborah Dickson's ''Dancing for Mr. B: Six Balanchine Ballerinas'' illuminates the life of the great choreographer by focusing on six dancers who were closely associated with him. The film, to be shown Oct. 7, seems somewhat traditional in form, but in truth it has few images of Balanchine himself. ''It's a very different understanding of Balanchine, because here we see a man totally through his women,'' said Ms. Keys. ''We can see how he changed their life and, indirectly, we can understand how they changed his life. But those who see this film have to work to see him. They must participate themselves.''
For another of the documentaries, ''Confession: A Chronicle of Alienation,'' to be shown Oct. 3, Georgi Gavrilov spent more than two years filming the life of a Moscow drug addict. Although it is a harrowing portrait of the drug demimonde in the Soviet Union, in presentation the film is highly expressionistic. ''If 'Roger and Me' begins to verge on fiction in its presentation,'' said Mr. Pena, ''then 'Confession' verges on the avant-garde in the images that are chosen and in the presentation of the character's inner reality.''
 
An Older Reynolds
Of course, there are many films at the festival that have not a whiff of the documentary about them. ''Breaking In,'' by Mr. Forsyth, is a much-anticipated film by the acclaimed director of ''Local Hero,'' ''Gregory's Girl'' and ''Housekeeping.'' In ''Breaking In,'' Burt Reynolds plays, for the first time in his film career, a character much older than himself.
''A City of Sadness,'' which will be shown Oct. 6 and 8, recently won the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival. The film is Hou Hsiao-Hsien's long-promised epic about Taiwan in the mid-1940's. It is the story of a family in the tumultuous time when the Japanese returned Taiwan to Chinese control, and the Taiwanese rebelled against the Nationalist Government.
Bertrand Tavernier's ''Life and Nothing But,'' to be shown Oct. 3 and 4, tells the story of two women who search for their missing-in-action lovers in the landscape of 1920 France devastated by the First World War. Mr. Tavernier's moody jazz film, '' 'Round Midnight,'' was the hit of the festival three years ago.
Jim Jarmusch's ''Mystery Train,'' set for Sept. 29 and 30, tells three shaggy-dog stories situated in a Memphis hotel, evokinge the mood and look and sound of the city of Graceland and Elvis. ''Jim belongs to that generation of people who know the documentary world very well, but concentrate on fiction and storytelling,'' said Mr. Pena.
Another high point of the festival is the Oct. 2 showing of ''Intolerance,'' D. W. Griffith's 3-hour-and-29-minute silent masterpiece from 1916.
 
First Entries
The worldwide nature of the festival is especially evident this year, and the contributing countries include not only Australia and three Eastern-bloc countries, but also Burkina Faso (formerly Upper Volta), Finland and, for the first time at the festival, New Zealand.
That film, a short, ''Kitchen Sink,'' will be shown Oct. 6. It is the story of a woman who begins uncurling a strand of hair from her kitchen sink and finds herself pulling up an adventure, a companion and an unending mystery. The film was greeted with applause and laughter when screened at the Toronto Film Festival this month.
 
Schedule of Screenings
The 27th New York Film Festival opens tonight at Lincoln Center with two screenings of ''Too Beautiful for You,'' and closes Oct. 9. All films except the late show on opening night, the closing night and D. W. Griffith's ''Intolerance'' are at Alice Tully Hall. Many screenings are sold out. Tickets for most performances, at $8, may be purchased at the Tully Hall box office (362-1911); tickets for ''Intolerance'' are $15 and $20. Screenings for which tickets are available are noted. Some films are scheduled to open commercially in New York City; those dates are noted. Here is a schedule of the festival.
