The Economy
The lines were drawn in the House for a bruising fight over taxes, with Democratic leaders scrambling to sell their plan as a boon to the middle class and Republicans asserting that it is just another tax increase. [Page A1.]
Foreign exchange traders and economists will be looking for a new sign of commitment to a stable dollar policy when the United States and its economic allies meet tomorrow in Washington. [D2.] 
The nation's economy grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the April-June quarter, the Commerce Department said. [D3.]
 
 
 
Companies
Bankers Trust will sell a new issue of ''junk bonds.'' Making quick use of new powers granted by the Fed, it will become the first banking company to manage a public sale of corporate bonds. [D1.]
J. P. Morgan added $2 billion to its reserve against third world loans. It now expects a $1.8 billion quarterly loss. [D1.]
Tiffany's said one of Japan's leading department stores would buy about 10 percent of its public shares. [D1.]
Dow Jones moved to make its ownership of Telerate complete, with an unexpected $576 million offer for the portion of the financial information service now in public hands. [D1.]
Campeau retailing officials denied that three large department stores in their nine retailing chains would soon cut prices. [D2.]
I.B.M. and Baxter Healthcare are forming a partnership to sell software and services to hospitals and physicians. [D4.]
3Com said it earned money after all last quarter. It told analysts last month that it might face a loss. [D4.]
The pilot-management group seeking to buy UAL predicted that the needed debt could be paid off in eight years. [D5.]
Rupert Murdoch will sell his Boston TV station to the group that owns the Boston Celtics. He faced an F.C.C. order to sell either the station or The Boston Herald. [D15.]
An F.T.C. judge ruled that Owens-Illinois violated antitrust laws when it acquired Brockway in April 1988. [D6.]
R. J. Reynolds said it would reduce U.S. cigarette shipments for the rest of the year and eliminate its sales incentives. [D4.]
 
International
Japan's economy is continuing to expand at a robust rate, according to Government figures, adding to a growing labor shortage and increasing inflationary pressures. [D1.]
The head of the I.M.F. said most of the fund's membership supported a substantial increase in the amount it could make available to meet emergency financing needs in the 1990's. [D3.]
 
 
 
Markets
The Chicago Merc will begin an experiment in which some futures trading would take place off the exchange floor. [D1.]
A late burst of program selling depressed stocks, with the Dow losing 3.61 points, to 2,680.28, after being up most of the day. [D6.] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped further. [D12.]
Prices of grain and soybean futures rallied strongly as the markets braced for the first hard freeze in the Midwest. [D13.] The dollar gained ground in quiet trading; gold prices were mixed. [D13.]
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange slipped 1.3 percent in the four-week period that ended Sept. 15. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Japan's Boom Continues, And It's Creating Problems

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Japan's economy is continuing to expand at a robust rate, according to Government figures released today, adding to a growing labor shortage and increasing inflationary pressures.
Japan's gross national product slowed slightly after a first-quarter surge, but compared with the quarter a year earlier it expanded by 4.8 percent, the Economic Planning Agency reported. Economists expect the economy to grow at a booming 5 percent rate this year, which would make it the third consecutive year of such rapid expansion.
The Japanese economy's remarkable strength sends two messages to the Western industrial economies. On the one hand, it is likely to raise imports and keep upward pressure on domestic interest rates and the yen, which the United States in particular has sought. Yet much of the high growth is being fueled by a huge increase in capital investment, which is likely to make Japan an even more formidable economic contender. 
Still, the high growth is also creating problems for the Japanese. To some, including the Bank of Japan, the expansion is causing concern that the economy is overheating, and it is leaving numerous companies scrambling to find workers.
''This is really more than the economy can handle,'' said Eric Rasmussen, an economist at Jardine Fleming Securities. ''Without some restructuring, I don't think they can let it grow at this rate.''
One important factor stimulating the boom is an enormous surge in capital spending by Japanese companies. Capital investment reached nearly 23 percent of the gross national product in the first half of the year, the highest level ever recorded here, according to a study by Deutsche Bank.
Economists said the slowdown from the first three months of the year was not significant because it was attributable to the introduction of a 3 percent consumption tax that took effect on April 1. The tax prompted a shopping spree in advance and then a lull in consumption afterward.
That is expected to right itself in the third quarter. In fact, today's news prompted Taiki Saito, senior economist at the Yamaichi Research Institute, to forecast a year-to-year increase in the gross national product of more than 10 percent during the third quarter.
In one sign of the pressure on prices, the wholesale price index rose by nearly 3 percent in August from the period a year earlier. While not threatening in itself, it followed a decline in the index of nearly 1 percent in the fiscal year 1988, and a fall of 2 percent in 1987.
 
Hints of a Rate Rise
Senior officials at the Bank of Japan have dropped numerous hints in recent days that they may soon raise the official discount rate to cool the economy. It would be the second increase this year, and would follow a steady upswing in market interest rates in the last several months, which the bank has clearly sanctioned.
''We will take suitable actions at suitable times to check excessive activities by corporations and households,'' the Bank of Japan governor, Satoshi Sumita, said yesterday.
The central bankers have also indicated that they would intervene heavily in the currency market to weaken the dollar, because its strength has been adding significantly to inflationary pressures here.
But one of the more telling and potentially troubling features of the economic surge is a severe labor shortage, which the Labor Ministry has estimated at more than two million workers.
The number of want ads is the highest in 15 years and tens of thousands of workers are entering the country illegally. The construction industry, in particular, has been so hard hit that companies are reportedly going to the job sites of competitors and hiring away entire teams.
As a result, the incomes of workers jumped 5.5 percent in the second quarter from the period a year earlier, the Economic Planning Agency said today.
 
A Sensitive Issue
In a country that prizes its ethnic homogeneity, the issue of bringing in foreign workers is sensitive. But companies are so desperate that they have been willing to skirt the laws and social pressures.
One economist said he knew of a textile company that had brought several dozen Thai workers into the country as ''trainees.'' The police detained the operators of a language school today on suspicion that they had supplied forged documents that would allow their ''students'' to work in the country. The Labor Ministry estimates there are some 150,000 illegal workers in Japan.
Some companies have become involved in the issue of whether Japan should repatriate boat people arriving from Southeast Asia.
Earlier this week, in another symbolic response to the problem, the Justice Minister, Masao Goto, said he would consider easing the ministry's traditional opposition to accepting unskilled foreign workers.

HEADLINE: Campeau Denies Rumors of Price Cuts at 3 Chains

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Retailing officials of the Campeau Corporation denied yesterday that three of the largest department stores in their nine retailing chains would soon cut prices to raise money for the troubled company.
Some who follow the industry had expected that the Campeau stores would need to cut prices quickly to build the cash flow. But this was denied by the officials, supply market executives and a merchandise liquidator.
The American retailing arm of Campeau, the Canadian developer that borrowed heavily to buy Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation over the last three years, experienced a serious cash squeeze last week that was only alleviated by a $250 million loan from Olympia & York Developments Ltd., another big Canadian developer. 
 
No Effort Planned
Despite the belief by some suppliers that the loan is inadequate for more than a few weeks' needs, which might have prompted the expectations of price cutting, the senior management of three Campeau retail chains in the East - Abraham & Straus, Bloomingdale's and Stern's -said they had no plans to cut prices beyond promotions that had been planned before the financial crisis. The current sales trend, they said uniformly, is good enough not to require any additional price promotions.
The three chains together account for nearly $3 billion in annual sales.
Their executives said yesterday that they had expected the price-cutting climate through and during Christmas to be normal, changing only if the present favorable sales trend deteriorated. ''There is no pressure to add cash flow at the expense of profit margins, so we are not planning to slash prices,'' said Chaim Y. Edelstein, the chairman of Abraham & Straus, which has 15 stores in New York and New Jersey.
He said that September sales of A.& S. stores that were at least a year old were running ''well into a two-digit gain'' over the same month last year. This does not include the new A.& S. Plaza store at Greeley Square in midtown Manhattan that opened on Sept. 14 and, according to Mr. Edelstein, is ''doing excellently.''
Retail executives close to A.& S. estimated that the new store was faring so well that their estimates of $100 million to $120 million in annual sales were being raised to $140 million.
''I don't think that the events of the last few days dictate any reason for a desperate price-cutting situation,'' Mr. Edelstein said. ''One runs a business according to a sales trend and, if there is pressure, it is to maintain an already-good sales trend.''
Lawrence Stone, the chairman and chief executive of the 24 Stern's stores in New York and New Jersey, said: ''Our business is much better than last year, when women's apparel sales were awful. Now, it is very good, as are men's wear and children's wear.''
 
'No Reason for It'
He said that Stern's, which is already well known for its promotional pricing, did not plan any additional price cuts. ''There's no reason for it. We are producing enough cash flow to accommodate our needs.''
Besides the three Eastern store groups, Campeau also owns Bon Marche in Seattle, Rich's in Atlanta, Jordan Marsh in Boston, Burdine's in Miami, Maas Brothers in Tampa and Lazarus in five Midwestern states.
Separately, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that, after the proposed divestiture of the 17 Bloomingdale's stores owned by Campeau, it might still downgrade the single-B senior debt and CCC subordinated debt ratings of Federated and Allied. The ratings remain unchanged. About $3.2 billion in securities are involved. Standard & Poor's added that Allied's CCC preferred stock rating was affirmed.
Campeau said earlier this month that it would sell Bloomingdale's to help with its cash problems.
 
No Diversions by Suppliers
One fallacy behind the expectation of imminent price cuts at the Campeau stores was the belief that the four-day supplier holdup of shipments during the company's cash squeeze would cause suppliers to divert deliveries to other, non-Campeau stores at cheaper prices. These stores, in turn, would supposedly sell them at drastically reduced prices. But such a diversion did not happen, an executive at Bloomingdale's said. ''Shipments have virtually returned to normal from Seventh Avenue.''
The executive, who asked not to be named, said that meetings yesterday with store buyers representing more than 100 departments found that only one supplier still had not resumed shipping goods. Bloomingdale's has 17 stores in New York, Illinois and Texas.
He added that the chain's business was good enough in most areas such that no additional price slashing beyond what was planned weeks ago was needed.
But the executive and the other Campeau retailers said that some of the stores might advance clearances by several weeks in such areas as swimwear, shoes or domestics, if sales slackened.
 
Pointing to High Debt
Executives familiar with the company said yesterday that the cash squeeze was not caused by inadequate sales or cash receipts in the stores. They said the parent company had found itself facing high interest and principal payments on its $9 billion debt and used the stores' working capital to pay it down.
''Right now, the mood among the Federated or Allied stores is not to dump goods,'' said Victor Ringel, the president of Opportunities Plus in Port Chester, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Stabilizing the Dollar;
Coordination Process of Group of 7 Is Under Pressure as Allies Convene

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Foreign exchange traders and economists will be looking for a new sign of commitment to a stable dollar policy when the United States and its economic allies meet tomorrow in Washington.
In July, at an economic summit meeting in Paris, the dollar was pretty much ignored in the final communique.
Now the allies, known as the Group of Seven, will convene at the gathering of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. And if another meeting of the group comes and goes without a reaffirmation of the group's intent to maintain a stable dollar, the coordination process, already under strain, would be undermined even more. 
On the other hand, a reaffirmation, including some backup dollar selling followed by an interest-rate shift, could restore some punch.
 
Inability to Keep Dollar in Check
This summer, the Group of Seven, which is made up of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, seems to have lost its ability to keep the dollar in a narrow range. Except for a brief respite in July, the dollar has been untamable, roaming outside its ceilings and undermining the credibility of the group's policy of stabilizing the dollar and the effectiveness of its economic coordination.
What has weakened the coordination process is that the domestic economic concerns of the United States and its allies, for at least the moment, have overshadowed worry about the dollar. The Federal Reserve is worried about inflation and a stronger-than-expected economy. The West Germans and the Japanese are on the fence - not wanting to dampen growth but still keeping their eyes on inflation.
This domestic focus makes it more difficult to coordinate the economic policy moves needed to restrain the dollar, like the lowering of interest rates here and increases abraod. David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, acknowledged this difficulty in a speech last week.
 
Intervention Less Effective
Substantial dollar intervention - a record $12 billion in selling by the Federal Reserve alone from May through July - has not been so effective as in the past because it is not backed up with the clear threat of coordinated changes in economic policy.
The dollar, at 1.9439 marks and 145.65 yen yesterday, is above the ceiling of 1.90 marks and 140 yen set by the Group of Seven. It shot past the 2-mark level in May and again in June and the 150-yen level in June. It breached the 2-mark level briefly last Friday but fell sharply on unsubstantiated rumors, including one that the President had been shot. With the market's eye on the Group of Seven meeting, it has yet to recover. But many traders and economists expect the dollar to make another run at 2 marks soon.
Because of the summer's experience, some economists have concluded that the coordination process, which started with the agreement at the Plaza Hotel in 1985 to drive down the value of the dollar, has fallen apart.
''The G-7 coordination process is in a shambles,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, adding that the United States is not providing the needed leadership.
Others argue that cooperation is not dead but more limited in impact now. They say that if the economy slows here and the Fed eases interest rates, the dollar will fall some and it will look as if cooperation is more effective.
''Coordination is not dead,'' said John Lipsky, director of international bond trading for Salomon Brothers in London. ''But this year we have certainly seen the limits of the G-7 process.''
Right now in the United States, the Fed has stopped the easing of interest rates that the central bank began in June. This came in response to revisions in economic data for earlier this summer that showed the economy to be stronger than expected.
 
Policy Tension in West Germany
In West Germany, Mr. Lipsky said, there is tension over policy, but it appears that the Government does not want to raise interest rates now. He said that recent inflation and money supply figures did not justify a tightening of policy by raising interest rates, which could help weaken the dollar. He added, however, that later this year or early next the West Germans might re-evaluate this stance.
Japan has voiced the loudest objections to the stronger dollar, both through central bank dollar selling and comments from officials. Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, said Wednesday that the bank was willing to tolerate market-led interest rate rises. But this could be more jawboning of the market. Mr. Sumita would not say if Japan and West Germany would take the critical step of a coordinated, official increase in interest rates.
Adding to the complexity of policy making, some analysts say, the United States Treasury does not want the West Germans and Japanese to raise interest rates now because that would slow their economies, cut the sales of American exports and slow the decline of the trade deficit.
The resulting policy coordination weakness has been magnified by the fundamental strength of the dollar, which has been supported by relatively high interest rates here, confidence in the American economy that has attracted foreign investment in stocks and bonds and the political instability in Japan, China, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. This underlying strength makes any coordinated policy of intervention and interest rates changes less effective.

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Growth in 2d Quarter Revised to 2.5% From 2.7%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the April-June quarter, slightly lower than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today.
The department said lower domestic spending more than offset gains in trade, causing the modest revision in the second-quarter gross national product figure. The previous estimate had put the quarter's growth rate at 2.7 percent. 
The third and final G.N.P. figure, based on a number of statistical reports and adjusted for inflation, compared with 3.7 percent growth in the first quarter. The second-quarter growth was the lowest since the final quarter of 1986, when the economy grew by 2.3 percent, department officials said.
The economy, growing at a 3.1 percent rate in the first six months of the year, needs to rise at a rate of at least 2.3 percent in the rest of the year for the Bush Administration to reach its target of 2.7 percent growth for 1989.
''They've got it,'' said Donald Ratajczak, an economist at Georgia State University, who predicts about 2.5 percent growth in the second half.
Today's report had little effect on the financial markets. Many investors are awaiting Friday's report on consumer spending in August and Tuesday's report on durable goods to get a better feel for the economy's direction.
On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Board issued an overall review of the economy that said growth continued at a slow to modest rate.
In a report today, the Fed said that corporate profits fell 7.2 percent in the second quarter, compared with the previously estimated drop of 5.4 percent. The decline was the second consecutive quarterly drop and was the biggest since the first quarter of 1986, when profits fell 16.5 percent.
The economy's slower growth has helped keep inflation under control. The G.N.P. implicit price deflator, a broad measure of inflation, rose 4.6 percent during the second quarter after running at 4.0 percent in the first quarter, but inflation has cooled since then, tempered by lower oil prices.

HEADLINE: Most I.M.F. Members Ask Aid Rise

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The head of the International Monetary Fund said today that most of the fund's membership supported a substantial increase in the amount it could make available to meet emergency financing needs in the 1990's. The United States, however, does not. The managing director, Michel Camdessus, said at a news conference that 19 of the executive board's 22 members, representing 70 percent of the weighted vote in the I.M.F., supported an increase of at least two-thirds in the $120 billion pool of gold and currencies that is used to help countries deal with economic crises. 
But to go ahead with the increase, the I.M.F. would need the consensus of all its principal members. The other dissenters are Britain and Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Camdessus's willingness to disclose details of usually confidential board positions was expected to sharpen the growing debate over resources, which are technically known as quotas, as the membership gathers here for the joint annual meeting of the I.M.F. and its sister lending agency, the World Bank.
 
'Unexpected Problems'
''I am comforted by this vote of confidence,'' said the former French central banker who has headed the 152-nation organization for the last two and a half years. He is pressing for a doubling of its resources.
Noting the oil crises of the 1970's and the debt crises of the 1980's, he said he could not predict what the next crisis would be, but added, ''We know we are living in a dangerous and unstable universe and that we will have unexpected problems.''
Mr. Camdessus is hoping to achieve agreement on an increase at the coming meeting. But experts do not rate the chances as high in view of the position of the Bush Administration, worried, among other things, about the rising volume of overdue I.M.F. debt and the prospects of selling a quota increase to Congress. Washington has said it hopes to reach a consensus on the issue before the end of the year.
However, Mr. Camdessus has an unusually powerful ally in Japan, which is anxious to conclude an agreement because it would almost certainly be linked to a change in its voting strength within the organization.
Japan, which has the world's second-highest gross national product and is the world's biggest creditor as well as aid donor, would probably move from fifth to second position behind the United States. Britain is now No. 2, followed by West Germany and France. Japan is already the second-most-influential country in the World Bank.

HEADLINE: 3Com Posts A Profit, After All

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Last month, when the 3Com Corporation told analysts it could not rule out the possibility of a quarterly loss, the widespread perception was that the company had finally hit the wall.
Today, 3Com, the leading maker of microcomputer networks, said it did earn money after all, but its reported profits still represented a sharp decline.
For the quarter that ended on Aug. 31, 3Com earned $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, down by 83 percent from $7.1 million, or 25 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Its sales rose by 8.6 percent, to $89.1 million from $82 million. 
The shares of 3Com, which had fallen from a high of $28 to about $12.50 after the earlier announcement, closed unchanged today at $13.50 in over-the-counter trading.
 
Various Factors in Decline
Factors internal and industrywide account for 3Com's fall from the trajectory that took it from $19 million in sales in 1984 to $386 million in 1989, analysts say. Microcomputer sales are in a slump, which has affected sales of equipment to link those machines in local area networks. 3Com also entered this period lacking vital new products, compounding the problem, the analysts say.
This is partly because 3Com, based in Mountain View, Calif., has been focusing on becoming a company that sells complete computer systems rather than just networking components. While this is a good long-term strategy, it represents a difficult transition. Some of the analysts say that diverting resources toward systems development has left the company vulnerable in core products, like network adaptors, which still account for half its sales.
When the company first said it might have its first loss in five years, L. William Krause, 3Com's chairman, president and chief executive, cited a general economic slowdown, a lack of new products and - with unusual candor - his inattention while busy building a house and serving as the chairman of the American Electronic Association, an industry group.
He now thinks the earnings forecast was a tactical error. ''We're not going to make projections anymore,'' he said. ''We're just going to report results.'' Mr. Krause says this change is one part of the company's growing up; the other is its shift from selling network components to selling complete systems.
 
Established in 1979
Founded in 1979, 3Com began by selling adaptor boards and other equipment that linked personal computers to a network. 3Com has been quick to adopt new standards and to move into new areas of the market.
Companies have a ''huge investment in mainframe architecture, but the economies are in the microprocessor machines,'' like PC's and file servers, Mr. Krause said. 3Com's forte has been linking machines from different manufacturers, providing ''multi-vendor compatibility.''
It is 3Com's intent now to supply the broadest array of the parts itself, while still providing links to other makers' machines. ''Customers are very comfortable buying our client/ server system because it's open,'' he said.
William K. Becklean, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company in Boston, said that 3Com's shift ''is a tough strategy, but they don't have a lot of choice.''
''3Com can't really afford to remain a component supplier because the parts are rapidly becoming commodities,'' he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Executive Quits At First Bank System

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The First Bank System, Minnesota's largest banking company, yesterday announced the resignation of DeWalt H. Ankeny Jr. as chairman, president and chief executive.
The bank, which has reported loan problems and losses on interest-rate gambles, announced plans earlier this week to trim jobs and get out of some riskier businesses.
''Given the challenges the organization faces,'' Mr. Ankeny, 56 years old, said in a statement, ''I've determined that it is in the best interest of shareholders and employees that I resign.'' 
The board named Darrell G. Knudson, 52, the current vice chairman, to the additional post of acting chief executive.
First Bank, the 28th-largest banking company in the United States, on Monday announced a restructuring in which it said it might cut 2,100 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force. It said it was forced to make an early announcement because of rumors about the Minneapolis-based bank.
The bank said the shake-up could result in a charge against third-quarter earnings of up to $40 million and could cut assets by $2 billion.
First Bank plans to concentrate on business in the upper Midwest and Northwest and to eliminate or scale back corporate banking to lower its risk. It has reported problems with loans made to finance leveraged buyouts.
The company's problems began last year after it gambled on the direction of interest rates, losing $300 million after it sold $4.6 billion of bonds from its $8 billion investment portfolio. The loss prompted the resignation of Dennis E. Evans, First Bank's president.
First Bank reported this week that domestic nonperforming loans were expected to increase as a result of problems with a few loans in its $738 million portfolio of leveraged transactions.
''Banks face two major risks,'' Kenneth F. Puglisi, a banking analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., said. ''They are interest-rate risk and credit risk, and First Bank System has been troubled by both of them.''
Neither Mr. Ankeny nor Mr. Knudsen was available yesterday, the bank said. Mr. Ankeny has led the bank for the last four years and has been associated with it since 1967. Earlier, he was a marketing and sales executive with the Theodore Hamm brewery.
Under Mr. Ankeny, First Bank sought to expand in the Northwest but lost out in 1987 in a $1 billion bid to acquire the Rainier Bancorporation of Seattle.
Mr. Knudsen's career with the bank goes back 31 years. He became vice chairman in January.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 3.61 Points, To 2,680.28

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
A late spurt of program selling depressed stocks yesterday in continued moderate trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had hovered between 5 and 10 points higher most of the day, finished 3.61 points lower, at 2,680.28.
The broader market also reversed its daylong trend, with declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering advances, 750 to 677. At the same time, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.77, to 345.70. The other basic barometer of the market's breadth, the New York Stock Exchange composite index, dipped 0.29, to 192.16. 
Volume on the Big Board continued pedestrian, although it rose to 146.9 million shares, from 136.6 million on Wednesday.
There seemed to be little impact from the report by the Commerce Department before the opening of trading that the nation's gross national product rose at an adjusted annual rate of 2.5 percent in the second quarter.
''The Dow made a run at 2,700 but this proved difficult to accomplish in the face of a sluggish bond market and nervousness over the near-term direction of the dollar,'' said Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton. ''These two factors continue to weigh on the stock market and erode traders' confidence.''
 
Transportation Average
The Dow transportation average gained 8.53 points, to 1,465.86, largely on the strength of airline issues like AMR. The parent of American Airlines, which introduced higher fares earlier this week, rose 3 3/8, to 81 7/8. Delta Air Lines, which said yesterday that it planned to match the increases in discount fares introduced by American, gained 1/2, to 73 1/8. UAL, parent of United Airlines, gained 1 1/4, to 286 1/4.
Mr. Grennan said any strength in the market could be attributed to the onset of ''window dressing as the end of the quarter approaches.''
Money center banks showed strength over the possibilities of the successful steps being taken this week in Washington to resolve the problem of loans to third world countries. Citicorp gained 3/4, to 31 3/4, and Chase Manhattan added 1/2, to 40.
Among active blue-chip stocks, A.T.&T. gained 7/8, to 42 3/4, and Burlington Resources rose 1 5/8. to 49 5/8.
 
Most Active Issue
Telerate was the most active issue on the Big Board, soaring 5 1/4, to 20 3/8, on a volume of nearly 2.8 million shares. The company said two independent directors would study the $18-a-share buyout offer by Dow Jones & Company for the third of Telerate it does not already own.
Puerto Rican Cement was the biggest dollar gainer, rising 6 points, to 57 1/2. The gain came in the wake of the devastation to Puerto Rico by Hurricane Hugo.
Kollmorgen fell 5 1/4, to 18 3/8. Vernitron said it no longer wanted to proceed with a $25-a-share takeover of the company.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index tacked on 0.28, to 467.00, while on the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index rose 0.90, to 380.04.
Adobe Systems plunged 4 1/8, to 15 5/8, in heavy over-the-counter trading. Traders said investors feared a severe drop in business because of potential competition from new Apple Computer/Microsoft Corporation computer technology.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225-stock index rebounded after Wednesday's decline, gaining 274.44 points to close at 34,745.02.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Decline Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped further in moderately active trading yesterday as concerns about upcoming auctions of new issues prompted traders to sell securities.
''Two of the themes that encouraged people to buy last week, jitters in the junk bond market and a strong dollar, seem to have receded in importance,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''In the absence of that sort of support, the inclination is to sell in advance of new supply.''
Next week, the Treasury is expected to auction $9.75 billion worth of new two-year notes and $7.75 billion worth of new four-year notes. And yesterday, it auctioned $9.5 billion of new one-year bills. 
Yesterday's auction went about as expected, traders said. The average rate on the new bills sold was 7.61 percent, down slightly from the 7.68 percent average rate at the last one-year bill auction on Aug. 24. 2-Year Notes at 8.24% Late yesterday, the two-year notes to be sold on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.24 percent. Meanwhile, the four-year notes, which will be auctioned Wednesday, were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.20 percent.
Prices of secondary Treasury issues initially moved higher during trading in overseas markets, spurred by buying from Japanese and Middle Eastern investors. But the gains could not be sustained once trading shifted to the United States.
A revised Commerce Department report on economic output in the second quarter, which showed the economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate on an inflation-adjusted basis, somewhat slower than the 2.7 percent rate that had previously been reported, had no impact on the fixed-income market.
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds that mature in 2019 were offered at a price of 99 11/32, down a quarter-point, to yield 8.18 percent.
Among secondary note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 23/32, down 6/32, to yield 8.19 percent. And the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 9/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.17 percent.
 
Bill Rates Up a Bit
Treasury bill rates were marginally higher. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.81 percent, up one basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bills rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.67 percent.
The report on the gross national product offered little to suggest the economy had lost additional momentum as it started the third quarter, according to Mark Green, an economist at MMS International, an economic information services and forecasting concern in Belmont, Calif.
''We think the economy will grow at a 2 percent to 2.5 percent rate for the rest of this year, and slow a bit from that level as 1990 gets under way,'' he said. ''We also think that Fed policy will remain on hold for the balance of the year, even though our surveys show that most people are expecting further easing moves.''
Elsewhere, trading in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate securities was light, dealers said. Prices of most issues dropped by about a quarter-point.
Prices of high-yield ''junk bonds'' were unchanged to off a half-point, market participants said.
Issues of Owens-Illinois Inc. fell by four to five points early in the day, after an official of the Federal Trade Commission announced a potentially adverse ruling against the company on its 1988 acquisition of Brockway Inc., a rival maker of glass containers. But prices recovered later in the session when the company said it would appeal the ruling.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices fell by about a quarter-point in light trading, dealers said.
Late yesterday the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Sept. 11. The report had no impact in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Session; Gold Prices Post Small Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained ground against the major currencies in quiet trading yesterday.
Gold prices were unchanged to slightly higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold finished at $365.50 an ounce, up 60 cents from Wednesday. 
Currency traders continued to adjust their positions ahead of this weekend's meeting in Washington of the Group of Seven finance ministers and central bankers. The Group of Seven is made up of the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada.
Although dealers were divided over whether any new initiatives would result from the meeting, the underlying sentiment toward the dollar remained bullish.
Recent statements by Japanese and West German officials indicated some concern about the dollar's strength. But a regularly scheduled meeting of Bundesbank officials yesterday ended with no increase in West German interest rates, contrary to what some traders had expected.
Some traders are anticipating higher West German and Japanese interest rates in tandem with softer rates in the United States, a scenario that would depress the dollar.
''That would take away the interest-rate differential, which is sustaining the demand for dollars,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
The dollar failed to respond yesterday to the Commerce Department's downward revision in the second-quarter gross national product. The Government put economic growth at a moderate 2.5 percent during the April-June period.
''The technicals are bearish, and you would think the momentum would be on the downside,'' said Linda McLaughlin, a trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group. 'But it looks like we're having real difficulty getting the dollar lower.''
In late New York trading, the dollar closed at 145.65 yen, up from 145.10 yen on Wednesday. And one pound cost $1.5790, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.5835.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.9439 West German marks, up from 1.9397; 1.6835 Swiss francs, up from 1.6815; 6.5740 French francs, up from 6.5560; 1,400.25 Italian lire, up from 1,399.00, and 1.1830 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1833.
On the Comex, silver closed at $5.181 an ounce, up from $5.119 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Third World Debt Woes;
Major U.S. Banks, After Absorbing Losses, Could Lose Their Appetite for New Loans

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company's surprise decision Thursday to drastically increase its financial cushion against bad loans to third world countries raises new questions about how those countries will escape their severe economic problems.
Morgan's action, which increases its reserves to cover 100 percent of its medium- and long-term loans to debtor nations, makes it less likely the bank will participate in any new lending. The latest Mexican financial package, for instance, calls for at least $2 billion in new loans over four years. Since Morgan is a large and prestigious institution, its position on that issue could influence the stance of other banks. 
The move by Morgan poses a challenge to the policies of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who called in March for a combination of debt relief and new loans to deal with the debt crisis. And the challenge comes just as the world's top central bankers, finance ministers and commercial lenders are gathering in Washington for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank.
At the time he announced his bank's $2 billion reserve, Lewis T. Preston, Morgan's chairman, criticized Mr. Brady's initiative, saying it raised unrealistic expectations in third world countries and did not provide enough money to encourage banks to grant debt relief.
Earlier in the week, when the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation also made $1 billion additions to their reserves for third world loans, they displayed a similar unhappiness with the Brady plan.
The increased reserves mean that there will be less of an impact on bank earnings if the loans are not repaid; but even with full protection, a bank continues trying to collect on its loans.
A Morgan spokesman acknowledged yesterday that the increase in loan-loss reserves means that Morgan is less likely to make new loans, although it has not ruled out that possibility. But having decided that 100 percent is an appropriate level of reserves, Morgan would have to set aside an additional dollar for every new dollar it lends. ''It would be rather costly,'' the spokesman said.
Moreover, having 100 percent coverage makes it easier for Morgan to simply get out of the business of third world lending altogether. Indeed, Morgan said it will have sold $500 million of its loans by the end of this month.
One senior lender at a large bank said: ''This allows Morgan to say to the Treasury, 'You cannot tell us what to do.' They have reclaimed their independence.''
By contrast, banks that cannot afford to write off their loans have a greater incentive to continue lending, in hopes that the countries will continue servicing their debt.
 
'An Element of Reality'
A senior Treasury official said yesterday that the Administration welcomed the decision by banks to increase their financial cushion, because it would enable them to afford more loan write-offs. ''The important thing to bear in mind,'' he said, ''is that the Brady plan has introduced an element of reality into the debt process.''
But some bankers and policy analysts said yesterday that there was a distinct possibility that for a country like Mexico the ''reality'' could be the worst possible situation: getting a financial package that does not offer enough debt relief to make a real difference while facing a banking community that has sufficient reserves to turn its back on third world lending.
If Mexico's cash problems grow more severe, there would be an increased likelihood that American taxpayers would eventually have to pay for a rescue.
Morgan's reserve action pits it against Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, who favors both debt relief and new lending. It was Mr. Reed who started the move to increase loan-loss reserves in May 1987 with the announcement that Citicorp was adding $3 billion to its coverage. 2 Chairmen in Conflict At the time, Mr. Preston was said to be bitterly opposed to the Citicorp strategy, because he feared it would encourage debtor countries to forgo their obligations, and would divide the banking community. Since that time, many debtor nations have indeed stopped paying interest. With Morgan's step on Thursday, Mr. Preston seemed to be saying that the things he warned against have come to pass.
''This is a hell of a high-stakes game to be playing,'' said an official of another bank. ''These two guys are battling it out, but the few of us caught in the middle are the ones getting bloodied.''
The issue of new lending is at the heart of the debate over the success or failure of the Brady plan. For years academics have recommended debt reduction as a solution, on the ground that new bank loans were being extended only to insure that third world countries could continue making interest payments to the banks.
 
Breaking With Baker
Debt reduction finally won some official support last March, when Mr. Brady broke with his predecessor, James A. Baker 3d, and gave it an endorsement. Since then, however, Mr. Brady has sent out conflicting signals by stressing that new lending is also important if the cash needs of countries like Mexico are to be met. The countries need the money for a variety of reasons, including paying their interest on old debt and financing economic development.
Of course, if debt reduction occurred on a large-enough scale, new money might not be needed.
''Let's not pretend inadequate debt reduction should be covered up with new lending,'' said Jeffrey Sachs, a professor of economics at Harvard. ''Let's get adequate debt reduction.'' But banks have been unwilling to grant large-scale debt relief because they have demanded some form of guarantee on their remaining loans. And the money that has been made available to provide those guarantees, largely from the I.M.F. and the World Bank, has not been sufficient to cover more than limited relief.
 
Fears of a Cash Shortage
Mexican Government officials have said that their greatest concern about the financial package negotiated this summer is that not enough banks will make new loans available and that they could suffer cash shortages, a point that officials of the Federal Reserve and Citicorp have also privately emphasized to bankers.
While Morgan may not plan to make new loans to the third world, it does see good business opportunities there. It was clear from Morgan's statement on Thursday that it intends to offer itself as an adviser to third world governments and companies and to act as an intermediary in loan sales and swaps. A bank official said that with its 100 percent reserve, Morgan, unlike other major banks, would no longer have a conflict in advising enterprises in third world countries.
''To be an adviser, you have to be disinterested,'' the official said.

HEADLINE: New York Tax Cut Delay Means a Tax Increase

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has in a radio interview finally come out in the open on his proposal to defer implementing the tax-cut package adopted by New York State in 1987 (news story, Aug. 23). In my view, the Governor is dead wrong on this issue. 
When the Governor talks about delaying the next phase of the tax cut, he is actually embracing a tax increase. Delaying the cut will give him more money to spend on favored programs in a year in which he is up for re-election, and it will come out of the pockets of New York's taxpayers.
When the tax-cut package is fully implemented, the top tax rate on personal income will be 7 percent, still high compared with the average top rate in neighboring states, 2.7 percent for paycheck income. If anything, the Governor should be trying to set the stage for further tax reductions.
The Governor speaks of the dire need for more money to combat crime, improve education and attain other goals. The answer is to cut elsewhere to finance these projects, not raise taxes. A tax increase in New York is especially inappropriate because the state has failed to get spending under control. Since Governor Cuomo took office, state spending (excluding Federal money) increased 88.8 percent, compared with inflation of only 28.2 percent. This year, which was supposed to be an austerity year, state spending still increased by 8 percent.
New Yorkers are not undertaxed; New York's government overspends.
 
(State Senator) JOSEPH L. BRUNO
 Albany, Aug. 30, 1989
The writer is chairman, New York State Legislative Commission on Public-Private Cooperation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Same Old Same Old Deficit

 BODY:
The Federal budget taking shape for 1990 will scale new heights of hypocrisy. The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law requires deficit reduction each year and President Bush and Congress are doing their best to make it appear they've complied. In truth, they're still playing games. 
The House has passed all 13 annual money bills, but the Senate has several yet to finish. House and Senate conferees have reconciled their differences on only one bill, for the Energy Department and water projects. But beyond that one, Congress hasn't appropriated one dime for the new fiscal year, which begins in eight days.
Congress may bundle everything into one gigantic bill and shoot it to the White House at the last minute, as it did two years ago. That, in itself, would parody the deliberative process; it would give the President no choice but to sign or veto the entire package. It's also possible that Congress will miss the deadline altogether, forcing the President to order across-the-board spending cuts to conform to the deficit target - but those cuts could be restored later when Congress finally acts.
Mr. Bush set the pattern for this year's obfuscation in his February budget message. He embraced President Reagan's fiction that the Government would reap new billions from asset sales and user fees. And he added a trick or two of his own - like removing the Postal Service deficit from the budget. Even when he and Congressional leaders came to terms on an outline in April, they agreed on $5 billion of new revenue but agreed not at all on how to raise it.
The crucial $5 billion question remains. Mr. Bush still insists that he would veto any new taxes. But he presses the alluring notion of an immediate revenue windfall by cutting the tax on capital gains, now approved by the House Ways and Means Committee. The Democratic leadership rightly remains dead set against cutting the gains tax; it would favor the wealthy and, after the windfall, would actually increase the deficit.
More blatant falsification comes in the ''off-budget'' savings and loan bailout. This Bush proposal avoids the appearance of adding to the deficit but actually adds billions. And then there's the old device of making the deficit look smaller by coloring the economic outlook; this time the Administration wishfully forecasts lower interest rates, which would mean paying less interest on the national debt.
All this horsing around is done in the name of compliance with the mischievous Gramm-Rudman-Hollings anti-deficit law. Theoretically, it requires that the 1990 deficit be cut to $110 billion. Actually, it requires only an official estimate, on Oct. 15, that the target will be met. As far as the law is concerned, what matters is not the results, only the forecast, even though it is made just two weeks into the new year.
It's hard to take seriously a law that ordains such games - or the officials who play them.

HEADLINE: Bogota Justice Chief Was Ousted By President Barco, Aide Reports

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Colombia's Justice Minister was asked to resign because she was ''dragging her feet'' on signing papers to extradite drug suspects for trial in the United States, a presidential aide said today.
The minister, Monica de Greiff, who resignation was reported on Thursday, ''didn't show the resolve required,'' said the aide, who spoke on the condition that he would not be identified. ''Her main concern was her family's safety, not her own.''
President Virgilio Barco Vargas had no public comment on the move. Caracol radio reported tonight that he named Communications Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds as Acting Justice Minister. 
 
New Blow to Drug War
Mr. Lemos was Acting Justice Minister in August and early September while Mrs. de Greiff was in the United States seeking help for the Colombian Government's drug war, and it was during this period that Colombia extradited the only suspected trafficker to be sent to the United States in the last two and a half years.
As President Barco prepares for a trip to New York and Washington next week, the replacement of Mrs. de Greiff, who was internationally known, comes as another blow to his faltering war on the drug traffickers, which he declared a month ago after the assassination of his party's leading presidential candidate.
On the political front, initial bipartisan support for the anti-cartel fight has recently unraveled. This week, Mr. Barco started drawing fire from the opposition Social Conservative party, which accuses the governing Liberal Party of failing to consult it on the anti-drug fight.
On the military front, 10 days of terrorist bombings have caused millions of dollars of damage and have left this capital's population of six million skittish. At the same time, army and police raids on cocaine refining laboratories and the confiscation of airplanes appear to have sharply cut Colombia's cocaine exports to the United States.
 
Dollar Rates Going Up
In Peru and Bolivia, the world's largest growers of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine, black market rates for the United States dollar have jumped in recent weeks. Since the crackdown on cocaine trafficking started in Colombia on August 19, Peru's currency, the inti, has lost 60 percent of its black market value.
''I think a lot of the labs here have been dismantled,'' an American official said today. ''If they can keep the pressure up for a few more months we may see Peru and Bolivia emerging as cocaine producers.''
Mrs. de Greiff, a 32-year-old lawyer, was the eighth person to serve as Colombia's Justice Minister in three years. All her recent predecessors received death threats from Colombia's cocaine traffickers. In 1984, Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla was murdered in the streets of Bogota. In 1987, a former Justice Minister was wounded in Hungary, where he had been sent as Ambassador. Planning Trip to U.S. At a news conference today, Mrs. de Greiff seemed relieved to have been removed from the post after only two months of service.
''I'm going to the States,'' she said with a smile. ''I'm going to be with my family. I have been working here alone. My husband and my child are in the United States. This is a very difficult post. There have been very many threats here.''
She said that out of ''concern for my safety,'' President Barco asked her on Wednesday if she would like to serve as Ambassador to Portugal. She said she refused the offer.
''I understand that he wanted me to leave,'' she said, referring to the President. ''I have no regrets.''
Mrs. de Greiff said she plans to spend two weeks in the United States and then will return to Colombia.
At the news conference she was not asked to respond to the charge of delaying action on extradition requests, and after the appearance she could not be contacted.
 
'She Was Very Brave'
An American Embassy official who has met several times with Mrs. de Greiff declined today to speculate on the circumstances of her resignation.
''She was very brave,'' he said. ''I was struck by her courage, given that it was an incredibly dangerous time.''
Today, Army General Eduardo Niebles announced that four more men have been arrested this week for the murder of the presidential candidate, Senator Luis Carlos Galan.
''They need some results to keep the spirit going,'' the American official said of Colombia's war on the drug barons. ''We have had results against the ranches, farms and laboratories. Now, they need some results against the kingpins.''

HEADLINE: Conservative Figures See 'Bright' Future

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 22

 BODY:
There was more than a trace of self-congratulation in the air today as Vice President Dan Quayle, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and other like-minded political leaders assured each other that Communism and socialism were on the defensive everywhere.
The prospects for ''the heritage and hope of democracy and freedom'' are ''brighter than ever in many parts of the world,'' Mr. Quayle said, referring to changes under way in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, Asia and some parts of Latin America.
But at an unusual three-day meeting of conservative political leaders from 27 countries, there were also signs of disagreement and uncertainty over how to respond to new challenges and possible new threats to the international trading system posed by the economic success of Japan.
For instance, despite speech after speech praising pro-democratic changes under way in Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union, the conservative leaders resisted endorsement of any sweeping aid packages for the Communist bloc. 
 
Thatcher Warnings on Japan
Mr. Quayle said that President Bush's limited package of aid to Poland was ''a very good proposal'' in spite of Congressional criticism that it falls short. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said Tokyo would not provide more aid or investment to the Soviet Union until Moscow returns four disputed islands to Japan.
The conference, which is to end on Saturday, was called by the International Democrat Union, established in 1983 as an international forum for right-of-center political leaders and parties to support their common ideology in each other's countries. It was the group's fourth international session and its first in Asia.
The sharpest warnings on Japan this week were from Mrs. Thatcher, who said the world economy was endangered by protectionist tendencies in the United States, Japan and the European Community. ''We are all offenders in this area,'' the British Prime Minister said.
But Mrs. Thatcher's comments came at the end of a four-day visit to Japan in which she singled out Japan in terms that were more blunt than those used by almost every other Western leader on an increasingly contentious issue.
 
Protectionist 'Tit for Tat'
''Japan's economic miracle was made possible because the rest of us were ready to keep our markets open to you,'' Mrs. Thatcher told businessmen on Thursday. At present, she said, ''it sometimes seems to the rest of us that the benefits of the open trading system have been too much one way.''
Mrs. Thatcher warned that Japanese practices were stirring ''resentment'' that could bring ''an explosion of tit-for-tat bilateral deals'' that might wreck the global economy.
Prime Minister Kaifu, the host of the conference in Japan, reportedly failed to make any major concessions to Mrs. Thatcher on trade matters but he assured the conference of conservatives that Japan understood ''the importance of strengthening the world's free-trade system.''
The Japanese Prime Minister also used the occasion to endorse the conference's several denunciations of socialism as a failed system. But he did not point out that the Japan Socialist Party won the elections to the upper house of Parliament in July.
 
Quayle Adheres to Party Line
For the most part, Mr. Quayle resisted discussion of trade or economic issues. He is to hold substantive talks with Japan's leaders on such topics on Monday as part of his 12-day visit to Asia.
Mr. Quayle arrived in Japan on Thursday after a stop in South Korea, where he reiterated the Bush Administration's opposition to withdrawal of 43,000 American troops stationed there. From here, he is to travel to the Philippines and Malaysia.
At the conservative conference today, the Vice President gave two short speeches and took part in a joint news conference with Mr. Kaifu, Mrs. Thatcher and a dozen other conservative party leaders from Austria, Finland, Australia, Jamaica, Canada and other countries.
Only a handful of questions were asked of Mr. Quayle, who gave short answers reiterating the Bush Administration's position on subjects like Cambodia, China and Poland.
Asked when the United States might resume aid and close ties to China, for example, Mr. Quayle said that ''the ball is clearly in China's court'' and that Washington was waiting for China to ''move once again toward the reforms that they had been heading for for a number of years.''
In a speech, Mr. Quayle called on colleagues to support the opposition parties against the Sandinista Government in the elections in Nicaragua scheduled for February, but few others referred to any problems in Latin America. Asked about that, an American official said the group was very ''European oriented'' now and distracted by the problems of Eastern Europe.

GRAPHIC: Vice President Dan Quayle and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Tokyo yesterday before a meeting of conservative political leaders from 27 countries. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Outside U.S. Embassy, Soviet Extortion

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 22

 BODY:
American officials trying to cope with increasing crowds of Soviet applicants for immigration say the people in long lines outside the United States Embassy are being victimized by an extortion racket involving Soviet police guards assigned to keep order.
''I've been first in line three days in a row, and each day other people were led through by the police,'' said Semyon M. Belostotsky. He said that with American immigration visa standards about to be tightened, the asking price for a bribe to be led to the front of the line was rising to more than 500 rubles.
This is $800 at the official exchange rate, or about two months' salary for an average Soviet worker. Applicants, some of whom report demands for their cars as bribes to buck the line, are enraged at this extra demand for graft as they wait for months in the very shadow of what they view as a symbol of justice and economic opportunity. 
The Soviet police declined to comment on the charges.
American officials said privately that they were aware of the corruption and greatly disturbed about it, but added that they were powerless to police the sidewalks outside the embassy, on the city's main downtown ring road.
 
'We Have No Jurisdiction'
''We know about this,'' an embassy official said. ''It's terrible. Our people get angry and go out and complain to the militia guards, but they tell us to get back inside, we have no jurisdiction.'' The Soviet citizens are in line for the mere chance to submit their application forms and documents to the embassy and obtain a date for an interview on eligibility - another waiting list that extends well into next summer.
Those who clear that hurdle face still one more: the typically cacophonous, chaotic wait to buy an Aeroflot ticket, where some veterans say even bribes fail to guarantee attention.
''All my life I have waited in line, but this is the most valuable line I have ever been in,'' said Mr. Belostotsky, an artist who arrives at 4 A.M. to resume his place in one of two lines outside the embassy. That line is organized by the people themselves under control of the militia in hopes they can finally get on each day's ''real'' line, the one leading to the embassy door.
The number of Soviet citizens admitted to immigrate to the United States has increased fivefold in two years, running close to 50,000 this year because Moscow has greatly relaxed travel restrictions. Of late, embassy personnel have faced perhaps 20,000 applicants a month. The Bush Administration has decided the United States cannot accommodate all of this growing tide, and so has said it will institute new restrictions beginning Oct. 1.
 
End of Long Lines Planned
The embassy has not yet announced precise procedures. But officials say applicants will no longer wait in lines for months at a time, but simply be given a form to fill in and put in a box outside the embassy, theoretically with no interference from militia guards. The form will tell the applicants that notification may eventually be sent to their homes for a time for an interview - ''if ever,'' according to one official. He said the new system will extend less false hope than the present one.
One Soviet citizen involved in seeking a visa, a man long inured to the need to bribe Moscow bureaucrats, obtained an embassy interview date and then routinely asked a friend which American should be bribed next. The man seemed incredulous when told that American Foreign Service personnel have a reputation for integrity.
''There is no Soviet citizen who has not had to pay a bribe in his life,'' Mr. Belostotsky said, noting that the outrageous embassy bribes are fed by panic that the United States is finding it necessary to limit its intake. To pass the time and keep calm, he has been reading ''The Gulag Archipelago,'' Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's epic account of the Stalin regime's imprisonment of throngs of innocent citizens.
Today, his three days as No. 1 in the line ended after a television news crew unexpectedly arrived outside the embassy. Soon the militia let 50 from the line pass to the door of the embassy. Mr. Belostotsky led the way on to the next waiting list.

LENGTH: 718 words

HEADLINE: Bush Calls Courter's Race a Poll on G.O.P.

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 22

 BODY:
President Bush came to New Jersey today to endorse the Republican candidate for governor, Representative Jim Courter, and paint a picture of the race as a nationally significant referendum on Republican policies and values.
Striking some of the themes that have brought victory to Republicans in the state in the last three Presidential campaigns and last two campaigns for governor, Mr. Bush linked Mr. Courter's candidacy with the growth and prosperity experienced here under President Ronald Reagan and Gov. Thomas H. Kean. ''New Jersey's elections are among the most crucial in America,'' Mr. Bush said. ''This election will decide whether New Jersey builds on what you began eight years ago, or whether it risks everything by returning to the past.'' 
Standing between Mr. Courter and Mr. Kean at a fund-raising luncheon at the Ramada Renaissance Hotel, Mr. Bush struck on some themes that Mr. Courter has tried to make the centerpiece of his campaign in recent days, the environment, economic growth, taxes, crime and drugs.
 
Tying Prestige to Candidate
''This election will decide whether New Jersey continues to have the kind of leadership which balances a sound economy and sound ecology, and whether its leadership says no to higher taxes and yes to extending the prosperity of the last eight years,'' Mr. Bush said.
The appearance was seen as a much-needed boost to the campaign of Mr. Courter, who has stumbled badly over the last three months. But the visit also raised the stakes for the national Republican Party, by tying its prestige to a candidate who takes a far more conservative view on abortion than most voters in the state and is widely agreed to be trailing his Democratic opponent, Representative James J. Florio.
In the governor's race, voters are being offered a sharp contrast in the philosophies of the two major candidates. Mr. Florio, generally regarded as a moderate Democrat over the years, says government should take a more active role in solving problems of the environment, overdevelopment and an automobile-insurance system that has left drivers here with the highest premiums in the nation.
Mr. Courter, an advocate of small government and conservative social views, sees as one of his great strengths in the race the popularity of the Reagan and Kean Administrations in the 80's, when the state experienced an economic boom.
Strategists for Mr. Courter say they hope to align their candidate in voters' minds with Mr. Kean, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush, and to play down his previous positions on abortion and banning homosexuals from jobs dealing with children, positions less in accord with moderate Republicans in the state. ''Just the picture of them together, Courter, Tom Kean and the President will remind the voters of what we want to say,'' a strategist, Robert Franks, said.
Mr. Bush described Mr. Courter as a longtime friend, a moral man and a family man, resonating with another theme of Mr. Courter's campaign, which has tried to portray Mr. Florio as tainted by the unsavory political practices of associates in Camden County.
''This November, New Jersey will make the right decision,'' Mr. Bush said. ''A vote, in short, for the new New Jersey.''
The appearance is expected to raise $700,000 for the state party, which charged the several hundred people who attended $500 a plate, or $5,000 for an opportunity to have their picture taken with the President. The money is expected to be used in large part to buy television advertising that will urge voters to vote Republican without mentioning candidates' names.
Mr. Courter's campaign is lagging behind Mr. Florio's in fund raising and is several hundred thousand dollars short of the contributions necessary to receive full public financing under the campaign-financing law. The law allows each campaign to spend no more than $5 million. There is no limit on generic commercials paid for by state parties.
In receiving the President's endorsement, Mr. Courter portrayed himself as a representative of mainstream Republican thinking, and he described Mr. Florio as a liberal in ''left field.'' Mr. Courter also repeated the first words he had uttered, standing next to Mr. Kean, the day after winning the nomination in June, ''If you liked Michael Dukakis, you'll love Jim Florio.''

HEADLINE: Abrupt Oil-Price Shifts Seen As Unlikely Despite Swings

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Prices of crude oil, which have edged higher in recent weeks after being remarkably stable through much of the year, may fluctuate as much as a dollar a barrel in the months ahead, but abrupt changes are not likely, many analysts believe.
The ravages of Hurricane Hugo, which severely damaged four refineries in the Caribbean this week, could push gasoline prices 5 cents a gallon higher within weeks, but that increase would be temporary, the analysts said. The lost refining capacity is expected to be repaired before the Thanksgiving holiday.
The analysts believe that oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will raise its production ceiling to as much as 21 million barrels a day at their meeting in Geneva, which begins on Saturday. 
OPEC's output was set at 19.5 million barrels last June, but experts said the group was currently producing close to 22 million barrels a day. In past years, that output would have produced a worldwide surplus of crude oil and depressed prices.
That did not happen this year. Temporary production problems in the North Sea, Alaska, Colombia and the Soviet Union cut global supplies during the summer, and demand rose beyond projections, said Lawrence Goldstein, executive vice president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
The Soviet Union's crude oil exports are expected to remain depressed because of production troubles, but supplies are increasing in the other regions, he said. ''On balance, I'm not looking for a substantial price erosion,'' he added. ''We think there will be some gentle tugging down on prices during the remainder of the year.''
Antonio M. Szabo, a vice president at Bonner & Moore Associates, a consulting firm in Houston, projected that the OPEC members would produce close to 22 million barrels a day in the fourth quarter. Still, he said, prices should fluctuate only modestly.
West Texas Intermediate crude could exceed $20 a barrel if weather patterns in the United States are normal this autumn, and possibly $21 a barrel if temperatures are abnormally cold, Mr. Szabo said. The price of the West Texas grade has risen gradually since the first week of August, when it was traded at $17.90 a barrel. The November futures contract fell to $19.28 a barrel today.
 
Buoyancy Called Aberration
Analysts said the recent buoyancy in the price of the American benchmark crude oil was an aberration from trends in the global market. Kevin J. Lindemer of Cambridge Energy Research Associates said the premium on West Texas Intermediate will ease back into a more typical range by the end of the year as gasoline supplies in the Midwest and Plains States become more plentiful.
Philip K. Verleger Jr., an oil analyst at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, forecast a price of $18.50 late in the year.
American refiners have bid prices for West Texas Intermediate higher partly because crowded pipelines were unable to ship more imports from Gulf Coast storage tanks and tankers. The West Texas Intermediate crude is sought because it produces more gasoline from a barrel than other crude blends.
 
Less Being Produced
Another reason for the rise in West Texas Intermediate is that less of it is being produced from Southwestern oilfields. Over all, crude oil production in Texas, which includes several other crude oil blends, fell to 1.8 million barrels a day in June, compared with 2.3 million in early 1986.
Oil companies have sharply curtailed spending on domestic exploration since oil prices collapsed from $28 a barrel in early 1986. This year, the nation's drilling activity will be the slowest since 1942, and the average number of active drilling rigs in the United States through last Tuesday was 812, according to Baker Hughes Inc., a Houston oilfield service company, down 13.8 percent in one year.
Moreover, more of the rigs in service are searching for natural gas instead of for oil, said Ike Kerridge, a Baker Hughes economist. This is a reversal of oil's longtime dominance over natural gas as the more desired fuel, he added.
