HEADLINE: Campeau's Foes in Toronto Gloat

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 22

 BODY:
There has been little sympathy for Robert Campeau this week on Bay Street, Toronto's clubby financial district.
When Mr. Campeau completed his $6.6 billion takeover of Federated Department Stores 19 months ago, many of Canada's top business executives held their applause. Now that debt problems arising from the Federated deal have forced the 65-year-old entrepreneur to surrender personal control of his Campeau Corporation, some Canadian executives have been saying, in effect, ''I told you so.''
''The reaction on Bay Street? In a word, glee,'' said one executive who was instrumental in gathering the group of English Canadian investors, known at the time as ''the friends,'' who blocked Mr. Campeau's hostile takeover bid for the Royal Trust Company in 1980. Like others reached who said they did not want to appear to be gloating over Mr. Campeau's misfortunes, the executive asked that his name not be used. 
 
Regarded as an Upstart
Mr. Campeau made many enemies on Bay Street with his abortive bid in 1980 for Royal Trust, one of Canada's most powerful financial companies. It was his first major venture outside the Ottawa and Toronto real estate deals that made his fortune.
Indeed, in the genteel world of Bay Street's major brokerages and banks, Mr. Campeau, a high school dropout who worked as a garage mechanic and a millwright before starting a house-building company, has long been regarded as a brash upstart. So it galled many here when his buyout of Allied Stores in 1986 and the Federated takeover last year gave him a magazine-cover renown in the United States that has rarely been accorded to Canadian entrepreneurs outside their own country.
Mr. Campeau has long contended that it was his humble origins, and French Canadian birth, that caused Bay Street to snub him. But in the wake of the turmoil at the Campeau Corporation, some Canadian executives said they felt that Bay Street's wariness toward Mr. Campeau had been vindicated.
A common verdict among Canadians familiar with Mr. Campeau's business dealings was that a combination of two distinctive traits contributed to his undoing: his taste for challenges that would deter more cautious men and a liking for running his company virtually single-handed. Since the Federated takeover, half a dozen senior executives of Campeau and its department store divisions have quit in disputes with Mr. Campeau, taking with them much of the company's expertise in retailing and debt financing.
 
'Broke All the Rules'
''He's always been a man who broke all the rules, and celebrated doing so,'' said one high-ranking executive. ''Now, he's learning the hard way that there were reasons for those rules.''
Catherine Mulroney, co-author of a new book, ''Campeau, the Building of an Empire,'' to be published next month by Doubleday Canada Ltd., offered a more sympathetic view. ''Campeau's always been a man who's thrived on proving the naysayers wrong,'' Ms. Mulroney said. ''To have the whole business community saying 'I told you so' must really hurt.''
Although he has homes in Manhattan and in Palm Beach, Fla., Mr. Campeau spent much of the last two weeks in Toronto. Reporters outside his chateau-style mansion in Toronto's Bridle Path district saw him leave early and arrive home close to midnight in his chauffeur-driven Mercedes-Benz, usually engrossed in conversation on his car phone.
 
Family Problems
As though he needed more trouble, the Canadian entrepreneur had to face again last week the family squabbles that have dogged him. His son Jacques, 36 years old, made a fresh attempt to break free from court-imposed restraints on his right to sell a block of nearly two million Campeau shares, valued at $35 million.
The younger Campeau argued that the freeze would cause him ''great hardship.'' But the court rejected his plea pending trial of a suit brought by Robert Campeau, who contends that the trust guaranteed him first refusal on the shares and control of their voting rights.
Canadian attitudes toward Mr. Campeau have not been helped by his announced preference for doing business in the United States. After completing the Federated deal last year, he said at a New York news conference that he liked the United States' ''wide-open private enterprise system'' better than the more regulated business milieu in Canada.
 
Felt Poorly Treated
He has also told reporters that he wished he had turned his business energies toward the United States years before he did. And he has said that as a French Canadian, he felt ill treated by Canada's English-speaking business leaders.
Canadians have traditionally been cool toward fellow Canadians who move to bigger opportunities in the United States. The chill has been compounded in Mr. Campeau's case by a perception that although he has criticized the close ties between government and business in Canada, that very closeness was the key to his success as a builder in Ottawa, where he created the fortune that staked his ventures in the United States.
''Bob Campeau's career here had nothing to do with risk,'' said one Bay Street financier who dueled with him at the time of the Royal Trust battle. ''When he says he wished he'd got to the United States sooner, the fact is that without the Government of Canada, he'd never have got there at all.''
Others noted that Mr. Campeau had attributed his troubles to the high interest-paying ''junk bonds'' that financed his Allied and Federated takeovers. In that light, some suggest dryly, Mr. Campeau might well review his attitude toward Canada's caution in financial matters. John Crispo, a professor at the University of Toronto's Faculty of Management, said the lesson of the Campeau Corporation was that junk bonds and kindred investment practices were ''what's killing North American capitalism.''
''Campeau's no better or worse than dozens of others who've been doing the same thing,'' Mr. Crispo said.
Despite his difficulties, some Canadians still admire Mr. Campeau, one of 14 children of a blacksmith. Thomas D'Aquino, president of the National Council on Business Issues, an Ottawa-based lobbying group whose members include many of the country's most powerful companies, said Mr. Campeau had shown a courage that Canada needed as its economy becomes more integrated with that of the United States.
''He's an entrepreneur,'' Mr. D'Aquino said. ''He was prepared to take a run at it. If he had done well, everybody would be applauding.''

HEADLINE: Spending Is Up 0.9% as Incomes Rise 0.4%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
In another sign of continued economic expansion, consumer spending increased by nine-tenths of 1 percent in August even though incomes rose just four-tenths of 1 percent.
The Commerce Department said today that the jump in consumer spending, which followed a gain of six-tenths of 1 percent in July, was the largest since a 1.1 percent advance in April. A number of analysts attributed the increased spending to bargain hunting by consumers. 
Income growth, meanwhile, slowed from a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, largely because of strikes against several large telephone companies. Still, personal incomes have increased for nine consecutive months.
''Consumers are still basically positive in their attitudes, largely based on a favorable job outlook,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey Lanston & Company, a government securities dealer based in New York. ''As long as the job sector holds up, and it certainly seems likely to do so, I think consumers will continue to spend, at least when they're given a bargain.''
 
Bargains in Autos
Mr. Jones said that strong rebate-induced sales of automobiles in August were a major element of the advance in consumer spending.
''In a sense, that's good,'' he said. ''As long as consumers buy only when given a bargain, that will limit the potential for inflation.''
Consumer spending is watched closely as a barometer of economic health because it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Other recent reports show the economy continuing to grow, although at a slower pace as the Federal Reserve keeps short-term interest rates high to contain inflation.
Personal consumption spending, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, rose $31.8 billion in August, compared with an increase of $21.1 billion in July.
Purchases of durable goods, like cars and other expensive items expected to last more than three years, rose $22.9 billion after gaining $3.4 billion in July.
Nondurable goods purchases fell $3.6 billion after increasing $4.8 billion in the previous month.
Purchases of services, which includes housing costs, rose $12.5 billion, compared with a $13 billion increase in July.
Disposable, or after-tax, income rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, down slightly from seven-tenths of 1 percent in July. But the savings rate, savings as a percent of disposable income, fell 6.7 percent after gaining 1.7 percent in the previous month.
Based on a three-month moving average, the savings rate fell to 5.4 percent in August from 5.8 percent in July.
The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, decreased $9.2 billion in August, compared with a $23.5 billion increase in July. Payrolls at manufacturing companies rose by $3.2 billion, up from a July increase of $2.1 billion.
Over all, personal consumption spending came in at an annual rate of $3.51 trillion in August, after reaching $3.48 trillion in July.
Personal incomes totaled $4.47 trillion at an annual rate in August, up from a revised $4.45 trillion in July.

HEADLINE: Campeau May Seek New Mortgages

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The new committee charged with rebuilding the American retailing arm of the Campeau Corporation is expected to give high priority to arranging new mortgages for many of the 125 retail buildings that the company owns outright.
The mortgage debt would help pay the mounting debts from bonds and other loans of the parent company. Earlier this week, after weeklong negotiations, Campeau, the Canadian developer that owns nine American department store chains, including Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus in New York and Burdine's in Miami, received a $250 million loan from Olympia & York Developments. Olympia & York is another large Canadian developer. 
Campeau, which amassed its retailing empire by borrowing heavily to purchase the Allied Stores Corporation in 1986 and Federated Department Stores early last year, has already put Bloomingdale's 17 stores up for sale to help with its cash needs.
 
New Bridge Loan Sought
Any new cash, including that from mortgage debt, would also help pay down an $800 million bridge loan from Citibank and other banks that helped the company buy Federated Department Stores early last year. Olympia & York is trying to arrange a new bridge loan to help replace the old one, which is due soon.
Executives close to Campeau said yesterday that they expected the four-man restructuring committee, set up under the terms of the $250 million loan, to seek mortgage financing for most of the Federated and Allied stores situated on property owned by Campeau. About half of the 250 stores are on such property.
Carole Sanger, spokeswoman for Campeau in the United States, said in Cincinnati that a mortgage financing program ''has been the plan all along'' to help repay the company's other debts, ''but the restructuring committee will have to determine what it wants to do with it.''
 
Will Report to New Board
But financial sources said the mortgage financing and the already announced plan to sell the Bloomingdale's stores would be high-priority recommendations of the committee. The group, headed by Lionel G. Dodd, chief operating officer for Olympia & York Enterprises, will report to the new Campeau board, also set up as part of the loan agreement. That board consists of three representatives from Campeau, three from Olympia & York and four from minority shareholders.
Shortly after Robert Campeau, chairman of the Campeau Corporation, acquired Allied in December 1986, he obtained new mortgages for a large number of the Allied stores. This helped him to keep Allied's debts in line until his May 1988 takeover of Federated Department Stores. But the resulting high interest rates for ''junk bonds'' and other capital needs created a credit squeeze last week that ended only with the $250 million loan.
Any sale of other Federated or Allied store divisions, expected by analysts and other retailers, is now said by several financial sources to be of lesser priority than the mortgage financing plan and the sale of Bloomingdale's.
The restructuring committee, meanwhile, is said to have started the process of selecting a new chief executive and a new chief financial officer for Campeau U.S., the company's American arm. The loan agreement called for the appointment of a new top team.
A clearer picture has begun to emerge on what happened earlier this week when Mr. Campeau vacated his post as chairman of the American subsidiary, also part of the loan deal, and said he would concentrate on real estate, not on retailing. A source close to the Campeau negotiations said: ''The stores were doing better than anyone said, but the Campeau Corporation was placed in a seeming position of tighter liquidity than it had been because Citibank, Sumitomo and the others in the bank group didn't want to fund the company anymore if Bob Campeau still ran it. They were fed up.''

HEADLINE: Treasury Issues Are Little Changed

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury note and bond prices were essentially unchanged yesterday, while bill rates posted moderate gains. Dealers described trading as light and featureless in the absence of any significant news. The fixed-income market largely ignored Government reports of rises of four-tenths of 1 percent in personal income and nine-tenths of 1 percent in spending in August, which were in line with expectations. 
Some analysts said the meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Washington this weekend might also have inhibited some investors from taking market positions. Credit market analysts expect participants to discuss plans either to cap or reduce the value of the dollar, which registered modest gains yesterday but was down slightly for the week.
''There was a brief flurry of selling early in the session when one or two large West Coast savings and loan institutions reportedly asked for bids on $1.2 billion of mortgage-backed securities,'' said Mark A. McCluskey, chief money market trader at Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. ''But when the amount was subsequently reported as $700 million, the market snapped back and the rest of session was extremely quiet.''
 
Bellwether U.S. Bond at 8.19%
Late in the session, the Treasury's bellwether long-term bond, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, was offered at 99 9/32, off 2/32, as the yield rose to 8.19 percent, from 8.18 percent Thursday and 8.07 percent a week ago.
In Chicago, the spot December Treasury bond futures closed unchanged at 96 7/32.
As for next week's scheduled auctions of two- and four-year Treasury notes, Mr. McCluskey said that ''outstanding twos and fours are presently well priced to move and make way for the new paper.''
The outstanding two-year notes, the 8 1/4's of 1991, closed unchanged at 99 29/32, for a yield of 8.29 percent, while the 8 1/8's of 1993 slipped 1/32, at 99 18/32, and a yield of 8.25 percent.
The $9.75 billion of new Treasury two-year notes set for sale on Tuesday traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.27 percent. The $7.75 billion of new four-year notes to be auctioned Wednesday traded to yield 8.23 percent.
 
Group of 7 Meeting Awaited
Norman E. Mains, senior vice president and chief economist at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. in Los Angeles, said: ''The fixed-income market has been marking time as it waits for the Federal Reserve to provide some clues to the direction of interest rates. But the Fed seems to be more preoccupied with the strength of the dollar than it is with interest rates. This is why many market participants will be closely monitoring the Group of Seven meeting in Washington this weekend.''
The Fed did not intervene in the money market and the key Federal funds rate held steady at 8 15/16 percent, which is where many credit market analysts think the central bank now wants it to be.
Meanwhile, the good reception accorded Thursday's auction of one-year Treasury bills improved the tone of the short-term market. The discount rate on the 90-day Treasury bills fell six basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.77 percent, while the six-month bills were unchanged a 7.65 percent. The new one-year bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 7.61 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Thin Trading Before Group of 7 Meeting

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday in thin, erratic trading in advance of a meeting today of finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrialized nations. Gold prices also rose.
The Federal Reserve sold dollars for the fourth straight day, dealers said, but the currency bounced back from the intervention and ended near the highs of the session. 
Dealers said the dollar rose in spite of some speculation that the finance ministers would plan more serious steps at their Washington meeting to push the dollar down to help shrink the United States trade deficit.
The Group of Seven consists of the United States, Britain, Japan, West Germany, France, Italy and Canada.
Most traders went home yesterday without any positions for or against the dollar because of uncertainty about what the meeting would produce, said Kevin Lawrie, senior foreign exchange manager at the Bank of Boston in New York.
''We're approaching this next situation very tentatively,'' he said. ''People have been whipsawed.''
The market showed little reaction to a Commerce Department report that consumer spending rose nine-tenths of a percent and personal income rose four-tenths of a percent in August. The report pointed toward continued economic expansion.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 145.00 Japanese yen, unchanged from Thursday. In London the dollar traded higher at 145.35 yen. At the end of the day in New York, the dollar rose to 146.05 yen, from 145.65 on Thursday.
In London, a pound cost $1.5755 late yesterday, compared with Thursday's $1.5805. In New York the pound fell against the dollar to $1.5715 from $1.5790.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.9530 West German marks, up from 1.9466; 1.6933 Swiss francs, up from 1.6835; 1.1814 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1830; 6.6025 French francs, up from 6.5740, and 1,405.38 Italian lire, up from 1,400.25.
Gold prices were higher in active trading. The late London price was $364.50 an ounce, up from $363.25 late Thursday. The Zurich late price was $365.50, up from $363.50. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose to $366.20 an ounce, compared with $365.50 Thursday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $364.25 an ounce, up from $363.85.

LENGTH: 782 words

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Bronx Cheers Now Stylish In Flushing

 BODY:
At a time when coffee, replays and gratification are often considered either instantaneous or worthless, maybe we have arrived at the point where five years is just too long for a memory to last. It has been almost that long since that early December evening when Met fans made the shocking discovery that propelled them through a winter and legitimized their team.
Have you heard? The Mets just got Gary Carter. Can you believe it? When do the playoff tickets go on sale? 
There will be no playoff tickets this October, and after the final home game this weekend, there may be no Gary Carter around here. He would leave with the recent memories of nasty sounds in his ears from the demanding ones at Shea Stadium.
He has been very well compensated to endure those sounds. If the people in the stands wish to overlook the facts that Carter, now 35, has caught more than 1,800 major league games, that he underwent knee surgery on Memorial Day and could have heeded his doctor's advice to forget about the remainder of this season, their right to those opinions is purchased at the ticket windows. Davey Johnson, for all his troubles as a manager, has not lost his powers of observation. Not long ago, when Carter was hearing those noises again, the manager thought out loud that New York was a very difficult place for an athlete to grow old.
''It's just, 'What have you done for me lately?' '' Johnson said. '' 'That's all we care. I don't care why you're having a problem. If you're having a problem, that's it.'
That's the way it is everywhere, but they're more sophisticated in New York.''
Johnson did not seem to be paying any compliments. By stating their opinions about Carter, forcefully and often, the fans have revealed something about themselves. If the growth of WFAN as an all-sports radio station has served any purpose, it has been to provide more than two years of daily evidence that any notion of the majority of New Yorkers as demanding, fair, and above all, knowledgeable observers of games has become history.
Mickey Mantle was revered at the end, even after his abilities had eroded. Willis Reed was not maligned by Knick fans for playing on oneleg. Y. A. Tittle grew very old very quickly with the Giants, but he was not booed into retirement. Ed Giacomin had garbage thrown at him in his early days as a goaltender with the Rangers, but at the end, when he was suddenly sent away without having won that elusive Stanley Cup, fans wept in the stands and turned on his former team.
Met fans have never been quite as tolerant as their image in the early days. There were even some cheers in July 1965, when the scoreboard delivered the news that a broken hip had ended Casey Stengel's days as manager.
But during the 1973 World Series, after Charles O. Finley, the owner of the Oakland A's, unsuccessfully attempted to banish an infielder named Mike Andrews for the crime of committing an error, the Met fans greeted Andrews's first appearance in New York with an emotional standing ovation.
Nowhere else did followers possess as complete an understanding of failure as they once did at Shea. And nowhere else has an unflattering transformation been so complete. Thirteen years later, in Game 7 of another Series, they stood for Bill Buckner, and jeered. Empathy is in short supply in Flushing, N.Y.
Perhaps the change in attitude is nothing more than the price athletes inevitably had to pay as a result of their staggering economic gains. Maybe George Foster, for all his foibles as a Met in the early years of the Doubleday regime, was on the cutting edge of the new contempt.
''Usually players are assessed by the amount of money that they make,'' Carter said. ''In this case, it's an altogether different story. Being injured, it's totally different.''
Maybe the bad vibes have something to do with the fact that it's difficult for almost everyone to age in and around Shea, what with ticket prices rising, with spontaneity removed by the disappearance of the general admission ticket, with blaring music targeted to a yuppie crowd, and with the added monthly expense of cable television. That is, if one's neighborhood has been plugged in.
You hear athletes say it all the time: New York can be, all at once, the greatest place to play and the worst.
''I don't know if that's what they like to go by, if that's their style, or what it may be,'' Carter said. ''You try to make the best of it. ''The surprising part of it is when somebody has a good career, you would hope that you would get support. But I guess it really doesn't matter.''
If you were Dwight Gooden and you had a choice, what would you think about growing old in Flushing, N.Y.?

LENGTH: 1184 words

HEADLINE: European Minds Who Fled Fascism

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
One of the less appreciated consequences of the rise of fascism in Europe in the 1930's was that it put an end to Europe's cultural and intellectual supremacy. That status was transferred to the United States in part by way of a small but historic emigration of the persecuted and the unwanted.
The exiles from Germany, Austria, Italy and France, many but not all Jews, created a new world in America, helping to make the United States supreme in such fields as nuclear physics, architecture, painting, and probably also in social thought. From Einstein to the political philsopher Hannah Arendt, the psychoanalist Bruno Bettelheim to the film director Billy Wilder, the exiles turned the United States into the country of the boldest and most original discovery and creation. 
This is the subject of ''Exiles,'' a documentary produced and directed by Richard Kaplan that is to be shown on Channel 13 on Sunday night at 7 o'clock. Mr. Kaplan explores two aspects of the intellectual migration. The first traces the escape itself from Europe, the routes that were taken, the reasons for flight, the ways in which groups in the United States provided help to those in danger.
 
Changed Forever
The second hourlong segment of ''Exiles'' shows the manifold ways in which the figures of the anti-fascist exodus raised the level of American intellectual life, changing this country forever.
The film covers one of the earliest and most influential efforts to enable threatened intellectuals in Germany to escape. In 1933, Alvin Johnson, the president of the New School for Social Research, got in touch with Emile Lederer, an economist just dismissed from his teaching post in Heidelberg to tell him that he wanted to establish a ''University in Exile'' at the New School, a university made up of distinguished German academics who could no longer teach in their native country.
The two men met in London, to which Lederer summoned a 28-year-old former student of his, Hans Speier, an anti-Nazi social scientist. Johnson gave Mr. Speier a list of 10 names of persecuted professors that he wanted for the New School. Mr. Speier, who came to a Sept. 18 meeting at the New School to celebrate the completion of Mr. Kaplan's film, traveled throughout Germany to deliver the invitations. The University in Exile, which became an important part of the New School's prominence in New York, was born.
 
An Unsung Hero
Another element of the exodus from fascist Europe described in ''Exiles'' is that of an unsung American hero named Varian Fry, a special emissary of the Emergency Rescue Committee, a group that was set up in the United States after the German invasion of France to help refugees reach safe haven. Many of the anti-Nazi Germans who had fled their country for France in the 1930's found themselves in the southern unoccupied zone of France where they knew it was only a matter of time before the Gestapo caught up with them.
Fry, a journalist with no experience in underground work, went to Marseilles that year and eventually helped some 2,000 refugees to travel to the United States, many of whom would no doubt have been murdered had they remained in Nazi-occupied France.
Three figures closely associated with Fry, including Henry and Claire Ehrmann, both of whom were saved through his efforts, attended the New School celebration. The third figure was Albert O. Hirschman, an economist at the School of Advanced Studies at Princeton University, who helped Fry in France to find the artists, writers, scientists and others on the Emergency Rescue Committee's list.
 
'A Great Adventure'
''I look at this experience as a sort of exciting high point in my life,'' Professor Hirschman said in an interview with several of the exiles. ''It was a great adventure.''
Fry, he said, wrote a book about his activities in France entitled ''Surrender on Demand.'' He was given a Legion of Honor award by the French Government. But his heroic achievement went largely unnoticed in the United States in the years after the war and he died some years ago in obscurity.
Professor Hirschman and Professor and Mrs. Ehrmann well illustrate the exile phenomenon. All three were born in Germany. Professor Hirschman and Professor Ehrmann, who had been classmates at the French lycee in their native Berlin, left Germany in 1933 shortly after Hitler came to power and went to live in France. Mrs. Ehrmann, then 18 years old, came to France in 1937 after the arrest of her father, a journalist.
When the Germans conquered France in 1940, all three went to the unoccupied, southern half of France. When Fry and Professor Hirschmann began their rescue operation, they needed to test the escape route to France via the Pyrenees. Professor and Mrs. Ehrmann, who had met and married in France, were chosen to make the trip.
''Fry said somebody has to try getting out of the country,'' Professor Ehrmann recalled. ''He said the Ehrmanns must go to find out how the border with Spain works.''
There was another reason. ''We knew that we were on the list of people wanted by the Gestapo and we didn't have much time,'' Mrs. Ehrmann said.
 
A Minority Went Back
One striking thing about the exiles is how few of them returned to their native countries when the war was over. Those who did return, like the Nobel Prize-winning author Thomas Mann, were a small minority. ''Exiles'' traces how a number of others, persecuted in this country for supposed ''Communist'' ideas during the McCarthy period, including the film director Fritz Lang, also returned to Germany.
Among those who stayed, for example, were the various exiles whose work made possible the atomic bomb - Einstein, Edward Teller and Hans Bethe, (Teller and Bethe appear in Mr. Kaplan's film) along with Enrico Fermi and Leo Szilard. Architects like Walter Gropius and Mies van der Rohe; psychoanalysts like Dr. Bettelheim, Karen Horney and Erich Fromm; musicians like Erich Leinsdorf; scholars like Arendt, Leo Strauss, the influential philosopher of the University of Chicago, and Herbert Marcuse, the Marxist critic who became an idol of the 1960's generation.
Some of those who gathered in New York for the New School celebration explained why. The sense that Germany had become hostile territory could not be erased by the mere defeat of Hitler.
''When you went back to Germany,'' Professor Hirschman said, ''especially in the early days, you never knew what were the real feelings of those who shook your hand, whether they wanted to be shaking it or not.''
Asked what the experience of having been an exile meant to him, Professor Speier replied:
''It means nothing at all to me. What was important was Hitler, not the fact that I was a refugee. I got very impatient in 1933 with people who left and felt homesick. The only time I felt homesick was when I went back to Germany in 1945 and saw a German travelogue about America. That made me homesick.'' Professor Ehrmann, answering the same question, said: ''If we were all to write our autobiographies, it would be an episode, but not a central fact of our lives.''

LENGTH: 1497 words

HEADLINE: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS END WITH PROGRESS ON ARMS CONTROL

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 23

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union ended two days of talks here today by proclaiming progress on a broad array of arms control issues.
''We have moved from confrontation to dialogue and now to cooperation,'' Mr. Baker said. The Soviet Foreign Minister said that the talks had ''placed Soviet-American relations on a new stage.''
 
Probably in Washington
The two foreign ministers, who spoke in separate news conferences after the talks concluded, announced that President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, would meet next year in late spring or early summer. In Kennebunkport, Me., President Bush said the meeting would probably take place in Washington. 
The announcement came a day after the Soviet side conditionally dropped its demand that the Americans abandon plans for a space-based missile defense - a major obstacle to a strategic arms accord.
Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze today signed agreements on monitoring stocks of chemical weapons and on providing notice of strategic military exercises. They also reached agreement on broad principles for verifying limits on strategic forces and nuclear tests, and they concluded accords on the environment and on allowing Eskimos to traverse the Bering Strait.
 
'Open Skies' Proposal
Moscow also responded positively to an American ''open skies'' proposal that would allow unarmed aircraft from NATO and Warsaw Pact nations to fly over one another's territory.
By themselves, the agreements represented noteworthy but not spectacular accomplishments. But taken together, the agreements and the new Soviet arms control initiative presented here on Friday have restored a sense of momentum in American-Soviet relations.
American officials hailed as a major breakthrough the Soviet offer conditionally dropping the demand that the United States agree to curbs on its ''Star Wars'' space defense program before the signing of a treaty limiting long-range nuclear arms. But Moscow made clear that it would retain its right to abrogate a strategic arms treaty if the United States moved to deploy a space-based defense in violation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which restricts the testing and deployment of anti-missile systems.
Soviet officials also said that Moscow would unconditionally tear down its Krasnoyarsk radar in Siberia, which Washington says violates the ABM treaty. The United States had informed Moscow that it would not sign a strategic arms treaty until the radar was dismantled.
The Soviet Union made a new conventional arms proposal by agreeing to include some types of fighters and bombers in the talks - items it had previously sought to keep off the negotiating table. Mr. Shevardnadze also announced that Moscow wanted to hold a meeting of heads of states in late 1990 to sign a new conventional arms agreement.
 
Bush Eager for Meeting
President Bush, in a statement this evening in Kennebunkport, where he is spending the weekend, said, ''I look forward to meeting with President Gorbachev.''
''Our meeting will afford an opportunity to reaffirm our mutual commitment to moving the U.S.-Soviet relationship forward as underscored by the progress at the Wyoming Ministerial,'' the statement said. ''I commend the efforts of Secretary Baker and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze.''
Earlier, during a break from a golf game in the rain at the Cape Arundel Golf Club, the President commented on the site of the summit meeting, saying, ''Probably Washington would be proper for this one.''
 
A Productive Gathering
The two-day meeting at the Jackson Lake Lodge in Grand Teton National Park, not far from Mr. Baker's ranch, was more productive than most of the meetings between American and Soviet foreign ministers in recent years. More progress was made here on arms control than at the Moscow summit meeting last year between President Ronald Reagan and President Gorbachev.
The sessions came as the Bush Administration was under fire for moving too slowly on American-Soviet relations. It appeared that the meeting this weekend would allow President Bush to more effectively counter such criticism, though most of the arms control initiatives were advanced by Moscow.
At the end of the meeting, Mr. Baker said that President Bush would announce an important initiative on banning chemical weapons in a speech on Monday at the United Nations. Mr. Baker did not provide details.
One result of the two days of talks at Jackson Lake Lodge appears to be the establishment of a more intimate working relationship between Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze.
 
A Full Weekend
Talks here ran well over schedule. The two met one-on-one for almost three hours on Friday, and there were broader discussions on regional confrontations, human rights and international issues like the environment and terrorism.
Friday night, Mr. Baker and his wife, Susan, took the Shevardnadzes for a dinner of trout, tenderloin and salmon at a local restaurant, while tonight the Secretary of State planned a Western-style cookout for the Soviet delegation. On Sunday Mr. Baker plans to take Mr. Shevardnadze fly-fishing before the two men take off in the Secretary of State's Air Force jet to New York and the United Nations.
The encounter here could mark the beginning of a departure from the standard United States-Soviet agenda, which for years has included arms control, human rights, regional problems and relations between the two countries themselves, with transnational issues added only this year. Briefings by both Soviet and American officials suggested how much the question of changes within the Soviet bloc are becoming a prominent feature of the American-Soviet talks.
 
Smaller Human Rights Agenda
With the Soviets having reduced their involvement in Afghanistan and the Americans their role in Central America, and with both sides keeping in the background in the Middle East, there appears to be less of a chance of a Soviet-American confrontation in the third world. And with the Soviets now letting out more Jews than the United States is prepared to accept, and allowing much greater freedom of expression at home, the human rights agenda is smaller as well. Because cooperation on transnational issues like the environment has yet to get off the ground, arms control remains the major unresolved question of the old agenda.
But in a clear sign that the Americans are recognizing that a new agenda may soon be called for, Mr. Baker spent the entire four-hour flight to Wyoming, as well as part of the dinner last night, talking to Mr. Shevardnadze about Mr. Gorbachev's restructuring program and how it will affect Soviet nationalities and the Soviet economy.
In addition, for the first time, Soviet and American officials discussed the state of Soviet economic changes.
At a news conference Saturday evening, Mr. Baker said he and his Soviet counterpart also discussed the question of German reunification and the emigration of thousands of East Germans to West Germany. But Mr. Baker declined to elaborate on the discussion, calling it confidential.
 
The Progress in Arms Control
Nevertheless, until a new agenda takes hold, arms control will remain paramount, a fact reflected in the agreements today.
The two sides signed an ''umbrella agreement'' in which they affirmed their desire in principle to implement a variety of test verification measures for any future strategic arms treaty. The idea, initially suggested by President Bush, is to prove that a treaty can be verified to improve prospects for ratification by Congress. But the two sides will have to work out in Geneva their differences over which verification measures they want to test, like an early exchange of data and establishment of on-site monitoring of each other's missile production installations. Moscow has suggested some highly intrusive forms of inspection that the Pentagon opposes.
As one part of this verification program the two sides agreed that beginning immediately they would notify the other at least two weeks in advance of any major strategic exercises involving heavy bomber aircraft capable of carrying nuclear weapons.
The two sides signed a memorandum of understanding on chemical weapons that provides for verification and data exchanges. Proposed by the United States, the agreement calls for an exchange of ''general data'' on each country's chemical weapons capabilities before the end of this year, as well as visits to each other's chemical weapons plants and storage sites.
In a second stage of the agreement to be negotiated later, the two sides would engage in a detailed data exchange on each other's chemical weapons capabilities and surprise inspections.
The two sides also said they made progress on ways to monitor limits on missiles based on trucks and railroad cars, one of the most difficult technical issues holding up a strategic arms agreement.

HEADLINE: New York Region's Housing: No Signs of Return to Boom

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
More than a year after the great housing boom of the 1980's came to an end in New York City and its suburbs, the inventory of unsold homes has grown, demand remains sluggish and experts see no clear signs of improvement.
The shift, prompted in part by retrenchment in the region's economy and a slowdown in population growth, has come as a painful shock to many people who purchased homes between 1982 and 1988, when prices increased more rapidly than at any other time in 60 years. To some, it seemed that housing values could only continue to rise.
Now, according to economists and real-estate executives, those selling houses, condominiums and cooperative apartments across the New York region are lucky to get as much as they would have in early 1988, and some must accept 10 percent to 20 percent less.
 
Seeking a New Psychology
The result is a psychological standoff. Thousands of hopeful sellers - people who stretched their finances and went deep into debt to own homes in one of the nation's most expensive areas - have been holding out for months, sometimes reluctantly reducing their asking prices, but still frustrated in their search for acceptable bids. And many buyers are hanging back, fearful of paying too much. 
''What happened to all those yuppie families?'' asked Ricky Peled, who has been trying to sell her two-bedroom apartment on West 83d Street for six months. Although she has cut her asking price by $30,000, to $385,000, none of the 25 people who have inspected the co-op have even offered a bid.
Despite the slowdown, hundreds of homes are being sold in the city and suburbs every day. Brokers dealing in expensive Manhattan cooperatives, some priced at more than $500,000, say demand and prices increased during the summer. Developers of new condominiums are finding buyers, though slowly. And anxious sellers in the suburbs are becoming more aggressive.
 
Turning to an Auction
''We are dealing with mass psychology,'' said one suburban developer, Marc Nevas, who began marketing a complex of 16 town house condominiums in Westport, Conn., in early 1987 and has so far sold only five. So he is holding an auction.
''In a market like this everybody is worried about what everybody else is willing to pay, so we are putting people in the same room,'' he added. Opening bids at the Oct. 15 auction will be $135,000, less than half the previous asking price.
While some people are struggling to master the psychology of a housing market gone sour, economists say the downturn rests on forces of supply and demand that will take time to change.
''The New York area is simply tapped out in terms of income and buying power,'' said Rae Rosen, regional economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. She said housing had soared so quickly and so far beyond the financial reach of would-be buyers that even reductions of 10 to 20 percent might not end the slump.
 
Giddiness Is Gone
Ms. Rosen said she did not expect the market to begin a broad-based recovery until 1991, as gradual salary increases bring more housing within the reach of potential buyers. Nor will it resume the giddy rate of appreciation of the middle 1980's, she added, predicting that housing values in the early 1990's would increase at only slightly more than the overall rate of inflation.
In one measure of how housing values soared earlier in the decade, the National Association of Realtors, a trade group, said the median selling price of a single-family house in the New York metropolitan area increased by more than 150 percent between 1982 and the beginning of 1988, to $183,500 from $70,500. The association said the median price reached a peak of $194,000 during the spring of 1988 and slid back to $185,200 by last spring.
 
Manhattan Cooperatives
That meant the median house price in the region was roughly double the median national price of $92,900, the trade organization said.
The sales prices of New York City's cooperative apartments are impossible to track precisely because they are not recorded with the government. But they clearly surged. An analysis by the Corcoran Group, a brokerage that deals in expensive Manhattan neighborhoods, said the average price of a four-room, two-bedroom cooperative it sold in 1982 was $220,200 and had climbed to $475,960 by the end of 1988.
Like the prices of other residential property, the prices of Manhattan cooperatives were level or declined slightly during the first half of 1989, a period when, the brokerage said, its prices fell by 3 percent. But by August, it added, had risen again by 3 percent.
 
'Pendulum Always Swings'
Economists say the New York region's six-year surge in housing values resulted from several powerful forces. New York City's recovery from a fiscal crisis, the rapid growth of its banking and securities industries, a sweeping migration of young professionals into the region, the expansion of its suburban corporate centers and a steep decline in interest rates that had climbed to more than 15 percent on mortgage loans by 1981 all served to create a huge new market of buyers.
''These were very good times for New York, but the pendulum always swings,'' said Louis Winnick, a housing analyst for the Fund for the City of New York, a nonprofit urban-research group. Some of the forces behind the boom are responsible for the slump.
The region's population, which earlier in the decade grew by more than 40,000 people a year, is now expanding much more slowly, gaining only 7,700 residents in 1988, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Where Is Bottom? Corporate expansion has also slowed sharply. Hostile takeovers, decentralization and layoffs of middle-level executives have carved deeply into the corporate ranks of the region's suburban business centers, while the Wall Street job losses that followed the 1987 stock market debacle have yet to be reversed.
No one knows if the housing slump has reached its lowest point.
''We've got too many people trying not to sell into a bad market,'' said George Sternlieb, a professor of urban studies and a housing specialist at Rutgers University. ''If you sit too long, you get selling panic.''
Although the sluggish market is affecting most communities in the New York region - and housing at most price levels - some are faring better than others. Executives say many of the most expensive properties continue to appreciate, including estates and waterfront houses. So do large apartments in fashionable Manhattan neighborhoods. These homes are bringing well in excess of $1 million.
Where they exist, well-kept suburban houses that are priced at less than $180,000, within the reach of young couples and moderate- to middle-income families - those with annual incomes of no more than $70,000 - are also in demand, executives say.
But the segments of the market where inventories are the largest and where sellers are enduring the biggest frustrations include the so-called ''trade up'' suburban house, where buyers must sell another house before they can move. These are typically priced at $300,000 up to $800,000.
A weak part of the market in New York City, experts said, is in studio and one-bedroom cooperatives and condominiums that appeal to single people, where prices have appreciated little, if at all, for more than two years.
Even at its worst, the New York area housing market is robust compared with recent conditions in Texas, Louisiana, Colorado and other states where a glut of new housing was fueled by lavish lending policies of savings and loan associations that have since gone out of business. Experts said the New York area was not experiencing anything resembling the widespread defaults and foreclosures of the Sunbelt.
Nor is the slump in New York so severe as the steep, brief depressions that hit the market twice before in the last three decades. The first came after a 1961 overhaul of the city's building code that led to a glut of new construction; the second came during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, when thousands of homeowners fled to the suburbs and beyond.
 
Sagging in Suburbs
''These periods saw blood in the streets,'' said Mr. Winnick, who said the two prior downturns had been so severe that some owners of cooperative apartments could not sell them at all.
Unlike their counterparts in New York City, longtime homeowners in the suburbs are experiencing a market slump with little precedent over the last 40 years. Except for the period of soaring interest rates in 1980 and 1981, when buyers retreated from the market, experts said, suburban housing values have risen steadily for decades.
In many suburban communities the inventory of unsold houses, already much larger than in the mid-1980's, continues to grow.
 
Buyers Can Be Demanding
On Long Island, the Multiple Listing Service for Nassau County said it had 9,046 homes listed in August, up sharply from 6,958 listings in August 1988. The number of Nassau County sales shrank to 568 in August from 653 in August the prior year.
There is a similar imbalance of supply and demand in Bergen County, N.J., where an analysis by Bill Higgins, a realtor, found 8,934 homes available in the first week of September, compared with 7,594 the same week in 1988. He also found that properties had been on the market longer - from an average of 97 days in 1988 to 107 days in 1989 -and that an average price of $278,264 in September 1988 had declined to $276,588 this month.
And throughout the region buyers have become standoffish.
''For now I'm out of the market,'' said Steve Ewing, a 39-year-old investment banker who has been looking at Manhattan cooperatives and condominiums for nine months. He added that he decided to put off the search this month after making an informal offer on an apartment on the Upper West Side, withdrawing it a week later and finding that the seller was still anxious to bargain.
''There is no pressure to buy,'' he said. ''I think things will get softer.''
But some sellers are finding their way to acceptable compromises. Though disappointed by the prices that their homes have commanded, they say they have been amply compensated when they purchased larger homes in the same sluggish market. ''You've got to sell low, but you can buy low, too,'' said Susan Schweitzer of Huntington Village, L.I., who spent six months struggling to sell a three-bedroom house.
Mrs. Schweitzer ultimately sold the house in August for $210,000, $35,000 less than she had hoped. But now she and her husband and 2-year-old daughter are preparing to move to a bigger house nearby in Melville, which they are buying for $255,000, $30,000 less than the seller originally asked.
''We did fine,'' said Mrs. Schweitzer, 35, who said she had become conditioned to think that housing values would not decline. ''It is just a shock to realize your home is not worth what you thought,'' she said.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Help Warsaw Lure Private Investors

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher told Poland's new Government this week that Washington would help lure private credits and investment here but did not offer more immediate aid than President Bush brought with him when he visited Warsaw in July.
But Mr. Mossbacher's line-holding comments on aid took on added significance at a time when the non-Communist ministers charged with charting Poland's economic future are looking for quick measures to halt accelerating economic decay. Figures made public by the Central Office for Statistics this week revealed an economy saddled with huge debt, low export earnings, deteriorating production and soaring wage and price levels. 
 
Visit Ended on Thursday
Mr. Mosbacher's five-day visit to Poland and Hungary, which ended on Thursday, came as the Bush Administration was struggling with Democrats in Congress who have offered a more generous aid package to the two Eastern-bloc countries that have radically transformed their political systems.
While they are aware that the Democrats are likely to press their assertions that by being too timid with aid, the Administration is missing historic opportunities, officials in both countries appear to understand that there will be no swift and substantial increase in Western aid and they have begun to scale back their expectations.
Marcin Swiecicki, the Minister for Foreign Trade and one of four Communists in the 22-member Solidarity-led Cabinet, told Mr. Mosbacher that Poland was ''determined to carry out a reasonable amount of privatization.'' Speaking at a news conference Wednesday, he said that Poland urgently sought assistance in ''creating favorable conditions for private enterprise,'' from the West. During his stay, the Secretary signed some minor accords, including one on tourism.
His aides let it be known that he would propose a package of further guarantees by Washington to allay concerns of private investors about things like repatriating profits, expropriation, taxation and property rights.
 
Upheaval Seen for Workers
As the Government prepares to meet with International Monetary Fund officials at the Fund's annual meeting later this month in Washington, Leszek Balcerowicz, the Finance Minister and chief architect of economic policy, said the Government would make public in early October a program for reducing Government spending, even at the cost of shutting down major unprofitable enterprises, and opening the economy to private investment.
Witold Trzeciakowski, minister without portfolio for economic affairs, told a French newspaper this week that a third of Polish workers would have to deal with losing or changing their place of work. In the past, such pressures at the workplace have swamped social tranquillity and political stability.
Officials did not conceal the enormous problems they face. Government planners report a burst of entrepreneurial activity, but little of it aimed at producing marketable goods that would satisfy angry consumers.
Instead, profiteers are operatiung back-pocket trading companies, exploiting severe shortages to collect enormous profit margins on their sales of small lots of goods.

HEADLINE: GROUP OF 7 WARNS ON RISE OF DOLLAR

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Economic ministers from the seven largest industrial democracies said today that a further rise in the dollar could undercut efforts to promote a healthy global economy, and they vowed fresh cooperative efforts to try to keep a lid on the dollar.
The ministers also reaffirmed support for further policy coordination, which they said has helped lay the groundwork for the past seven years of economic growth with relatively low inflation.
But in a two-page communique issued after a daylong meeting at Blair House, across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House, the Group of Seven nations left vague how they intended to reimpose authority on the foreign-exchange markets. In recent years, the currency markets have been noted for their ability to defy the intentions of the Group of Seven, which includes the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy. 
 
Warning for World Economy
The communique said they ''considered the rise in recent months of the dollar inconsistent with longer-run economic fundamentals,'' adding that ''a rise of the dollar above current levels or an excessive decline could adversely affect prospects for the world economy.''
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, meeting with reporters after the session, declined to elaborate on the communique.
''I have decided to discontinue my longstanding policy of commenting volubly on the dollar,'' Mr. Brady said, apparently referring to market disturbances that have followed some of his earlier observations on the dollar.
Other ministers also declined to expand on the communique, suggesting a general agreement to keep the markets guessing on any intent.
At a meeting last April, the ministers issued a similar statement, but today's language, officials noted, was stronger, signaling a rise in concern over next year's trade prospects.
In April, the ministers chose the term ''counterproductive'' to describe a further dollar rise or excessive fall, against today's terminology that it could ''adversely affect prospects for the world economy.''
Japan's Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, said after the meeting: ''All in all I believe the meeting was very meaningful and constructive.''
 
Officials Express Concern
The Group of Seven ministers were concerned about a rise in the dollar against the West German mark and the Japanese yen approaching 20 percent so far this year.
Although the United States trade imbalances have narrowed over the past two years, many officials fear that progress could stall or even be reversed because of the higher price tags for American exports and lower prices for foreign goods that result from a stronger dollar.
On Friday, a senior American Treasury official who asked not to be identified said that if the dollar continued to strengthen for a lengthy period of time, ''this obviously is a matter of concern for future adjustment.''
At the April meeting, the ministers also agreed to try to restrain the dollar's advance. One result was heavy intervention in the foreign exchange markets, in which central banks either buy or sell dollars to influence the currency's value. But the dollar continued rising.
A reason for the authorities' difficulties in restraining the dollar is the growth in trading volume. A recent study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York placed foreign exchange trading in the United States alone at $128.9 billion a day, more than twice the volume three years ago.
Another reason is the trouble generally acknowledged by most officials in coordinating economic policies. One private economist, C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington policy research group, has termed policy coordination ''a shambles.''
Conflicting domestic economic policy goals compounds the problems. In the United States, the Federal Reserve, facing an economy that has proved more buoyant than expected, is reluctant to cut interest rates because it continues to worry about inflation. Such cuts, however, could make the dollar less attractive in the markets.
On the other hand, Bonn and Tokyo are not keen on raising their own interest rates, even though this could weaken the dollar, because of the dampening effects on their economic growth.

STATE: PENNSYLVANIA, USA (55%);

HEADLINE: Moscow Sets Aside Big Obstacle to Arms Treaty

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 23

 BODY:
The new strategic arms control initiative put forth by the Soviet Union here on Friday appears to remove the principal obstacle to a treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons.
After years of insisting that the Americans abandon their plans to deploy a ''Star Wars'' space-based anti-missile program so as to conclude a strategic arms treaty, Moscow has conditionally put aside that demand.
The Soviet initiative was the highlight of the arms control meetings here, which saw modest agreements reached on the monitoring of chemicals weapon stocks and the broad principles of verifying limits on strategic weapons and nuclear weapons treaties.
 
An Eye on Congress
But in presenting their strategic arms initiative, Moscow changed its position in a clever way, according to accounts by American officials provided before today's round of meetings. 
The Soviet side apparently designed its concessions to enable the Bush Administration to tell conservatives that it has not sacrificed the ''Star Wars'' program to get a strategic arms accord, while at the same protecting Moscow's security concerns. Conservatives in the Senate, however, may not necessarily see it that way and may seek to derail what they are asked to ratify.
The initiative was presented by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in talks here Friday at a mountaintop lodge at Grand Teton National Park.
 
A Warning From Soviets
The Soviet side told the Americans that they would sign and carry out a strategic arms treaty without securing assurances ahead of time that the United States would not deploy a space-based defense shield. But in the next breath Soviet officials warned Mr. Baker that if the United States ever broke out of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty by moving to deploy ''Star Wars'' defenses, Moscow would reserve the right to abrogate the strategic arms agreement.
In other words, Moscow, apparently recognizing that this was the only way to get the strategic arms reduction talks, or Start, off dead center, agreed to defer but not abandon its objections to ''Star Wars.''
''The linkage between a Start agreement and curbs on 'Star Wars' is still there, but it is moved into the future,'' said an American official involved in the talks here who welcomed the Soviet move while noting that clarifications were being sought.
''Kicking it down the road allows us to get a strategic arms treaty now,'' he said. ''But the Soviets still retain the threat to destroy Start in the longer term if the United States abandones the A.B.M. treaty and moves to deploy space defenses.''
The new Soviet approach, which represents an evolution in Moscow's thinking, appears to reflect the calculation that Congress is not going to give strong support to a space weapons program anyway so there is no reason to hold up a strategic arms agreement. Soviet officials themselves appear to be acknowledging that gone are the days when Reagan Administration officials and their conservative allies in Congress talked boldly of plans to speed up the deployment of anti-missile defenses - irrespective of the A.B.M. Treaty, which sharply restricts testing and deployment of anti-missile systems.
Budgetary pressures have forced delays in ''Star Wars'' research, and major questions remain about the technological feasibility of a space-based defense. And while the Bush Administration has retained President Reagan's rhetorical commitment to such defenses, its true allegiance to them is in doubt.
Moscow may also be calculating that a new strategic arms agreement will in itself further deflate proponents of a space defense by alleviating American concerns over the threat posed by Soviet missiles. Moscow hopes that as the perceived Soviet threat recedes, so will the case for space-based defenses.
Beyond that, Moscow may have concluded that its initiative is the only way to revive the stalled strategic arms talks. Completing a strategic arms treaty has remained a top Soviet goal, but with the superpower deadlock over space weapons, there seemed to be little chance that a treaty could be finished soon.
 
Little Room for Maneuver
Both Washington and Moscow have had little room for maneuver on substance of the issue of space defenses, making deferral of the matter an attractive option for both sides.
Any sign of flexibility on the part of the Administration on the testing and deployment of space defenses was bound to be assailed by conservative Republicans as a breaking of faith with the Reagan vision.
Economic and military considerations have given Moscow every incentive to oppose any agreement that would legitimize a technological race to develop space-based defenses. Such a competition would run counter to Moscow's plans to transfer military resources to its ailing civilian economy.
The Soviet side would also be hard put to engage in a ''Star Wars'' competition that turned on the development of computers and other forms of advanced technology, areas of clear American advantage. It is a race they know they cannot win.
Given these obstacles, deferring a resolution of the space weapons issue may be the way out, though Moscow has indicated that it is still prepared to discuss the issue of what tests can be conducted in space should Washington be interested.
 
Risks for Both Sides
Putting off the ''Star Wars'' dispute, however, carries risks for both sides. It perpetuates the dispute over how to interpret the A.B.M. Treaty's restrictions on space testing, creating the possiblity for misunderstandings further down the road.
When the idea of deferring the Star Wars issue was broached in the Reagan Administration last year, the Joint Chiefs of Staff demurred. They argued that it was difficult to determine what strategic weapons the United States needed without knowing what limits that might apply to the development of Soviet anti-missiles defenses. The Chiefs also worried that Moscow would be able to exploit A.B.M. Treaty ambiguities while Congress would not allow the Pentagon to take similar actions. Confronting these and other objections, the Reagan Administration did not press for the kind of deferral option the Soviets are now offering.
But the Bush Administration has already signaled that it is attracted to such a compromise, calling it a ''positive development'' that requires further study and clarification.

HEADLINE: Pakistanis View U.S. as Friend, Suspiciously

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAHORE, Pakistan, Sept. 21

 BODY:
A year after the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in a plane crash, a public-opinion poll asked Pakistanis if they thought he was the victim of a conspiracy and, if so, who were the likely conspirators.
''The Americans,'' said 31 percent of those who thought that General Zia's death in August 1988 was no accident.
Half of the Pakistanis polled said they believed that there had been a plot. Twenty-five percent said they thought Soviet or Afghan agents were behind a conspiracy. Seventeen percent thought political opponents of General Zia were responsible. Only 5 percent of the respondents blamed Pakistan's traditional enemy, India. 
A year earlier, in a poll taken just after General Zia was killed along with the United States Ambassador, Arnold L. Raphel, and most of Pakistan's top generals, 35 percent blamed Soviet or Afghan agents, 28 percent suspected General Zia's political opponents and 19 percent suspected India. The small number of people who thought that the United States might be involved was statistically insignificant.
A group of editors and writers gathered at the offices of the independent political magazine Viewpoint were unable to explain the turnaround in attitudes. They assumed that Pakistanis were friendlier to the United States over the last year because of Americans' support for the country's democratically elected Government.
The surprising poll result, on this and other questions about foreign friends and foes, reflects the complexity of Pakistani opinion where the United States is concerned. In the same poll, respondents ranked President Bush ahead of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, as the foreign leader whom they liked the most. ''Most Pakistanis think of the United States as a friend, but a friend that cannot be trusted,'' said Ijaz Gilani, the director of Gallup Pakistan, which conducted the poll.
Many Pakistanis, in interviews or informal conversations, say they are concerned about the influence the United States has over the country. In his last poll, Mr. Gilani found that 54 percent of Pakistanis questioned believed that the influence of the United States over Pakistani affairs had increased since the Pakistan People's Party of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto came to power in an election last November. The belief was held by Pakistanis of all political parties.
Mr. Gilani, a political scientist with a doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said this attitude helps explain the view that Americans had a hand in General Zia's death.
''Why would Pakistanis blame the United States?'' he asked. ''The reasoning is that since Benazir Bhutto is believed to have good relations with the United States, and has been a beneficiary of Zia's death, therefore the United States must have been involved.''
 
'Superficial' Relationship
Pakistani attitudes toward the United States are influenced by both political and cultural factors, including the country's natural link with the Islamic world, Mr. Gilani said. Pakistan, despite its return to the forms of Western-style democracy, is not automatically pro-Western. ''The relationship with the United States is a superficial type of relationship,'' Mr. Gilani said. ''It doesn't go very deep, and it is easy to switch from issue to issue.'' On general international policy or economic aid, Pakistanis are likely to be friendly to the United States, he said. But when issues of culture and religion are involved, the view changes.
A certain level of politically inspired anti-Americanism has also been part of Pakistani life since independence in 1947, foreigners and Pakistanis say. A few years ago, Ms. Bhutto put a stop to the burning of American flags at her party's rallies.
Some Pakistanis link new problems of drugs and the spread of sophisticated weapons to American involvement in the war in Afghanistan.
''The United States is running my country through remote control,'' a leftist political leader, Khan Abdul Wali Khan of the Awami National Party, said recently. ''It is responsible for all our problems.''

HEADLINE: Coffee Impasse Imperils Colombia's Drug Fight

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Since an international coffee agreement was suspended two months ago, prices have plunged more than 40 percent on Colombia's leading legal export. Now many Colombians are saying that by allowing the collapse of the agreement, the United States has undercut its effort to encourage Colombia to fight production of its other major export, cocaine.
''We need the coffee income to fight effectively against cocaine,'' said an aide to President Virgilio Barco Vargas.
The International Coffee Organization, which includes the 74 consuming and exporting countries that were part of the agreement, has meetings scheduled for London this week and early next month. The accord had kept up prices by setting quotas on exports. 
Colombian officials said they expected to discuss coffee prices with American officials before the meetings. Their hope, one official said, is that the United States will consider the broader implications of coffee prices and not act strictly on commercial interests.
The National Federation of Coffee Growers, an independent organization that works closely with the Colombian Government, released the text of a letter from Washington on Monday in which President Bush said the United States was prepared to begin talks with Colombia aimed at restoring the agreement.
Although American officials have consistently said they were willing to resume talks with Colombia on the coffee issue, officials here took the Bush letter as an encouraging sign.
 
A Sympathetic View
In the letter, Mr. Bush struck a sympathetic and supportive tone, saying he recognized the importance of coffee to Colombia's economy and noting the Government's commitment to fighting narcotics trafficking.
Coffee is Colombia's main legal source of foreign currency. The coffee business employs three million Colombians and yields taxes that go to the country's armed forces and pay for roads, schools and hospitals in areas where the crop is grown.
Government officials say they worry that rising unemployment and general economic hardship would erode public support for President Barco's new war on drug traffickers. They say sustained coffee losses could also lead to cuts in military spending, which now accounts for 14.5 percent of the national budget.
 
Shift to Coca Crop
The Government and some growers say that as coffee production falls, pickers look for jobs harvesting and processing coca and that in the past some small farmers have shifted into coca growing.
Colombia earned $1.7 billion from coffee last year, compared with an estimated $1.5 billion from cocaine.
The Government does not officially recognize the cocaine income. But many Colombians argue that it is unfair for the United States to urge the country to try to eliminate the cocaine industry at a time when income from its most important legitimate crop is suffering.
As President Bush was preparing to announce his program to fight narcotics, Mr. Barco appealed to him for help in restoring the coffee price support agreement.
In an unusually blunt letter, Mr. Barco said: ''The agreement was not extended due to the lack of political willingness on the part of the United States.''
 
The U.S. Response
A senior American official here said the United States, which is the largest consumer of coffee, did ''not torpedo or destroy'' the price support agreement, which covered trasactions between 74 consuming and producing nations. However, he acknowledged that the United States had two demands that had not been met as the agreement foundered. Coffee experts say the American objections started a walkout that led to the suspension.
The United States wants greater flexibility in quotas so that it can secure a higher percentage of top-quality coffee grades and it wants an end to sales to countries in Eastern Europe, outside the agreement, at prices far below those accepted by members of the pact.
''I think the United States has legitimate concerns,'' a Government official said. ''We have to work it out.''
 
Coffee Price Down 60 Cents
Before the agreement was suspended in July, coffee was bringing about $1.45 a pound. Now the price is 85 cents, which Colombians say is less than it costs them to grow and ship coffee.
Colombia, which produces high-grade coffees, has offered a formula for increasing the quality of the mix that the United States receives. But Brazil, which is the world's largest coffee grower and produces mainly standard grades, has not endorsed Colombia's plan.
The producing countries have been willing to sell to Eastern Europe at below-market prices because they have surpluses that they cannot sell through the quota system. They are willing to take paper losses to increase their income of badly needed hard currency.
 
Roots of Price Supports
Colombian officials recall that the price support agreement came into effect in the mid-1960's as an outgrowth of President John F. Kennedy's Alliance for Progress, which sought to increase the resistance of Latin American countries to leftist insurgencies by improving their economies.
