HEADLINE: Bush Clean Air Plan Called Energy Policy in the Making

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
As members of Congress and interest groups look more closely at President Bush's clean air proposal, many are saying it is not just an anti-pollution plan but a national energy policy in the making.
The measure would dramatically reshape the nation's use of energy in the 1990's and into the next century, promoting greater reliance on natural gas and other clean-burning fuels at the expense of coal and gasoline. And it has broad implications for energy conservation, fuel imports and regional economic development.
The President's legislation, if passed, would have such an important effect on energy policy that it could undercut the national energy strategy the Administration is scheduled to complete in December 1990. Linda G. Stuntz, the Deputy Under Secretary of Energy for Policy, called the clean air measure ''the most profound energy legislation Congress considers this session'' and said it would have been better if the national energy plan had been in place first. But the President, she said, is determined ''to move now'' on environmental legislation. In his campaign, Mr. Bush promised to give the environment a high priority. 
The Bush bill ''is energy policy on a grand scale,'' said Representative Philip R. Sharp, an Indiana Democrat whose House Energy and Commerce energy subcommittee is reviewing the legislation's effects on energy. And William G. Rosenberg, an Environmental Protection Agency official, said energy and environment are ''two sides of the same coin,'' because the burning of oil and coal contributes so heavily to health hazards and environmental damage.
 
The Focus Has Changed
Though cleaner fuels like natural gas and low-sulfur coal may seem a self-evident solution to such problems, Mr. Rosenberg said, the nation has not always followed that path.
In 1978, for example, Congress limited the use of natural gas for generating electricity because of fears of a gas shortage. In 1977, to protect miners' jobs in regions that produced high-sulfur coal, the lawmakers passed an amendment to the Clean Air Act that took away the economic advantages of burning low-sulfur coal. That is one reason many utilities use high-sulfur coal, a major cause of air pollution and acid rain. Mr. Sharp noted that when the Clean Air Act was amended in 1977, the energy subcommittee did not even have hearings on it.
In Montreal this week, the 3,400 delegates to the World Energy Conference focused not on customary concerns like oil and gas reserves, but on environmental problems associated with those fuels: urban smog, acid rain and global warming.
The President's bill, now under consideration in the House Energy and Commerce environment subcommittee, addresses urban smog, acid rain and airborne toxic chemicals. Other legislators are sponsoring measures that would attack other problems and in some cases impose more stringent restrictions.
Proposals to strengthen existing acid rain and smog laws have been sidetracked for more than 10 years by conflicts among regions, industries and interest groups. Congress may try to smooth those differences, but the energy issues will still be crucial.
The Administration says its clean air proposals favor no fuel over any other. But many participants in the debate say natural gas would be a clear winner.
To fight acid rain, which causes widespread damage to forests, lakes and buildings and is suspected of endangering human health, utilities would have to cut sulfur dioxide emissions in half by 2000. About 20 million tons of sulfur dioxide are emitted annually into the skies; three-quarters of that comes from utilities, which would have to reduce their emissions by 10 million tons.
The utilities expect this cutback to force some plants to switch from coal to the natural gas. The American Gas Association estimates a modest sales increase, and gas producers would welcome it. Gas consumption declined 25 percent since 1970, although there have been modest gains in the last two years.
Low-sulfur coal is a another likely winner, since it produces fewer emissions than its high-sulfur cousin.
The cost of reducing emissions creates an incentive for utilities to press their customers to conserve because less demand means less burned coal and lower emissions.
The President's plan includes incentives to encourage utilities to use new anti-pollution devices so they can burn high-sulfur coal, which the nation has in abundance, without emitting large amounts of sulfur into the air.
The Administration says the United States can enhance its national security by developing ways to burn coal cleanly, since it would then rely less on imported fuels.
To reduce smog, the White House bill says that in 1997 manufacturers should be producing one million cars a year running on fuels like methanol that burn more cleanly than gasoline. The cars would be sold in the nine most polluted cities.
 
Nuclear Power Could Benefit
Methanol can be produced from natural gas, but much of what might be needed to supply a new fleet of methanol-powered cars would be imported. Another potential car fuel, ethanol, is made from grain and could open a new market for American farmers. But doubts have been raised by industry and others that the President's ambitious target can be reached.
Nuclear power, now much out of favor, could benefit from the President's bill. The legislation would raise the price of fuel by requiring more anti-pollution equipment and the development of more expensive alternative fuels, and this could make the price of nuclear power more competitive. Nuclear power plants do not emit sulfur dioxide, but they do produce radioactive waste.
Energy choices made in the legislation could affect regional development. A developing ethanol market could benefit the farms of the Middle West. Increased demand for natural gas could be a boon to the energy-rich Southwest, which has suffered hard times through much of the 1980's.
''Between the clean air bill and the deregulation of natural gas, this could be the first good news in energy states in eight years,'' said Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat.
Mr. Synar also said there would be winners and losers among states in industrial development. Businesses that use a great deal of energy would be tempted to move to states that have lower fuel costs, he said. By making some forms of energy more expensive, the clean air legislation could help determine which states they are.

GRAPHIC: Representative Philip R. Sharp, head of the House Energy and Power Subcommittee (Paul Conklin)

HEADLINE: Using Social Security Checks for Greater Need

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
People who do not need their Social Security payments to live on are being asked to give them to charity under a novel fund-raising strategy being introduced by United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.
The philanthropy says it hopes to persuade people who have enough independent retirement income to deposit their monthly Social Security checks in a special endowment fund. The contributions would be allowed to accumulate interest untouched until 2020, when the income would be made available for the philanthropy's use. The U.J.A.-Federation and a network of affiliates help four million people in New York, Israel and 33 other countries. 
The concept was developed by Robert E. Linton, director of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, the New York-based investment firm, who volunteered to become the first contributor to the undertaking, the 21st Century Club.
 
How the Money Will Grow
''There's no gimmick for the rich involved, not a lot of paperwork, just a new way of raising money for people who need it in a Robin Hood kind of way,'' said Mr. Linton. He said his own monthly check of about $900 with compound interest would grow in 10 years to $184,000 and nearly $700,000 in 20 years.
To contribute, a donor signs a single piece of paper, directing payments to be made to the 21st Century Club. And the tax-deductible pledges can be revoked at any time.
The U.J.A.-Federation expects to recruit 200 founding members for the club in the next few months, said Stephen D. Solender, the organization's executive vice president. The fund will grow as the older contributors continue their payments. ''We hope and expect the leaders in our community will be healthy and philanthropic-minded for many, many years to come,'' Mr. Solender said. He estimated that in two decades the club's endowment would total at least $250 million.
 
Fund-Raising Not Keeping Pace
He said the organization's fund raising, which brought in $300 million last year, was not keeping pace with the need for services created by Federal budget cutbacks.
''We're launching the 21st Century Club after testing the idea on some of our supporters and receiving an enthusiastic response,'' said Mr. Solender. He said he expected other charitable organizations to copy the strategy.
Still, the strategy brought misgivings from some who fear that it would create a misconception: that Social Security benefits were going to many people who did not need them.
''I hope such a campaign would not give the mistaken impression that there are large numbers of Social Security beneficiaries who can afford to do without their benefits,'' said Robert M. Ball, Social Security Commissioner under Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon and now a consultant on social insurance. ''Such is not the case,''
 
Question by an Expert
Mr. Ball said Social Security was the major source of income for about 27.2 million retired people. Since 1983, under Federal law, half of the monthly Social Security payment has been taxable if the income exceeds $25,000 for an individual, or $32,000 for a couple.
The strategy of asking individuals to commit their Social Security payments could lead some donors to ''hide behind their pledge'' and be less responsive to other charitable appeals, said George A. Brakeley 3d, board chairman of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel.
Nonetheless, he found the concept intriguing. ''As a fund-raiser, the idea is so simple - you wonder it has not been tried before,'' he said. ''It seems there ought to be something wrong with it, but I can't think what. It's absolutely painless.''

HEADLINE: Veterans Housing Loan Program Feels Pinch

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
A housing loan program for veterans is having financial problems because of high foreclosures and may require more aid than the Veterans Affairs Department has requested, according to a Government audit.
The audit by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, covered the department's financial statements for 1987 and 1988 and made special note of the housing loan program.
''The primary cause of the loan guaranty fund's increased need for funding beyond that generated through normal operations was the weakened financial condition of certain sectors of the economy, particularly energy and agriculture,'' said the report, which was released this week. 
The loan guaranty fund guarantees a portion of private loans made to eligible veterans at special terms. About 13 million veterans have taken advantage of V.A. housing programs.
The fund largely paid its way through the 1970's, but its requirement for appropriations and money transfers ''has increased significantly since 1980,'' the report said. The fund required $900 million in transfers and appropriations in 1988, the G.A.O. said.
Congress and the V.A. are making efforts to address the issue, and the department says the problem is diminishing because of a decline in foreclosures.
The V.A. had 44,693 home loan foreclosures in the fiscal year from Oct. 1, 1986, to Sept. 30, 1987, and 48,963 the next year, the report said. Foreclosures totaled 38,721 in the first 10 months of the current fiscal year, said a V.A. spokeswoman, Donna St. John.
''We expect further improvements,'' she said.
The G.A.O. report says the department will need about $100 million in tranfers from the direct loan fund plus about $453 million in direct appropriations in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The direct loan fund is a separate fund used for direct mortgage loans to severely disabled veterans.
The report noted possible developments that would change the department's estimates. One would be a higher foreclosure rate than the V.A.'s projection. Another would be the continued sale, ''without recourse,'' of loans on properties acquired by the department through defaults.
 
Loans Sold in Packages
When the V.A. finances foreclosed-property sales, it can package several loans for sale to an investor. The sale ''with recourse'' guarantees that the department will make good on any future default. ''Without recourse'' means the investor cannot go against the department. The without-recourse loans, though supposedly providing less liability, provide less cash at time of sale, the G.A.O. said.
A law will prevent the V.A. from making without-recourse sales after Sept. 30, but the department is proposing legislation to give it flexibility in determining which types of loans to sell.

Suzanne Noli, a daughter of Mary Noli of Sayville, L.I., and the late Robert Noli, was married yesterday to Brian Silverman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Silverman of White Plains. Judge Arthur Kellman of White Plains City Court officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Decades of Change: A Look Back At China in Chaos

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD; Fox Butterfield, a former Beijing bureau chief for The New York Times, is the author of ''China: Alive in the Bitter Sea,'' published by Times Books.

 BODY:
It is Shanghai in 1927. Chiang Kaishek is conducting a bloody purge of his erstwhile allies, the Communists. In the old black-and-white film, boyish-looking suspects are interrogated by laughing policemen, then held in a cage by a guard brandishing an executioner's sword and finally dispatched by a shot to the back of the head.
The scene is part of a meticulously researched two-hour documentary, ''China in Revolution, 1911-1949,'' to be shown on PBS stations, including WNET in New York, on Wednesday evening at 9. The program, which grew out of the serendipitious discovery of a cache of rare footage about China in a private New Jersey movie archive, combines original film with interviews with Chinese soldiers, peasants and political leaders. These individual participants in the chaotic period between the overthrow of China's last imperial dynasty in 1911 and the founding of the People's Republic in 1949 tell extraordinary tales: stories of warlords and Japanese atrocities, accounts of small girls sold as child brides and recollections of Mao Zedong as a young revolutionary.
Huang Wei, a former Nationalist general, is shown on newsreel footage from 1949 being captured by Communist troops as they swept to final victory. Then, in a recent interview, Mr. Huang recounts how he was subjected to thought reform by the Communists for 27 years but still remains devoted to his one-time commander, Chiang Kai-shek. 
''This man, I think, was a great man, a hero,'' Mr. Huang says of Chiang. ''But his methods were the old ones of China, so he lost. In the end, I was buried alived for him.''
The broadcast of the program now, shortly after the tumultuous events of the student-led democracy movement in Beijing last spring, is fortuitous. When Sue Williams, the New York-based writer, director and co-producer of ''China in Revolution,'' began work on the project four years ago. ''Everyone told us we were crazy,'' she said recently. ''They said, 'Who cares about China between 1911 and 1949?' ''
''China in Revolution'' does not directly explain the events leading up to the protests in Tiananmen Square. But for the Chinese history is a living force, as real to them as baseball box scores are to American boys, and thus the film helps the American viewer to appreciate the Chinese mind set. It suggests why many older Chinese, who experienced the disastrous division of China before 1949, fear anarchy, and why so many younger Chinese still yearn for the elusive goals of democracy and modernization.
''China in Revolution'' bears many similarities in tone and style to two earlier highly acclaimed documentary series presented by WGBH in Boston: ''Vietnam: A Television History,'' and ''Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years, 1954-1965.'' The resemblance is not coincidental. Judith Vecchione, the executive producer of ''China in Revolution,'' was a key participant in both earlier productions. Ms. Williams was a film researcher for ''Eyes on the Prize,'' and Kathryn Dietz, the co-director and co-producer of ''China in Revolution,'' worked on the Vietnam series. Will Lyman, who narrated the Vietnam programs, also provides the carefully subdued voice for ''China.''
Moreover, the producers also borrowed the concept of assembling a team of academic specialists for guidance from the earlier series. The experts, who included Jonathan Spence, a historian at Yale University, and Andrew Nathan, a political scientist at Columbia University, helped identify unlabeled film and offered advice on historical disputes. The result is a carefully balanced presentation that few scholars would quibble over.
But those familiar with China's history may find that the producers' very attempt at fairness sometimes works against them, regretfully draining some of the passion that the period evoked. To recall the heady atmosphere in the Communists' wartime headquarters in the caves of Yanan, the producers interview John Paton Davies, a brilliant State Department officer who spent time in Yanan. But there is not even a mention that Mr. Davies's favorable reporting on the Communists, compared to the corruption, inflation and incompetence that wracked the Nationalists, would lead to his dismissal by Washington and the ruin of his career in the anti-Communist witch hunt that followed the Communists' victory.
Nor is any reference made to the great debate, in the United States and Taiwan, to which the Nationalists fled in 1949, over ''who lost China.''
Ms. Vecchione insisted that to have mentioned Mr. Davies's fate or the debate over who lost China would have been ahistorical. ''It would have gone beyond our period and would have gotten into the argument in America,'' she said. ''We tried to stay with a Chinese point of view.''
The producers were also constrained by other problems, some beyond their control. For one thing, for many key episodes, there was simply no film available. The Communists did not have a cameraman with them on their epic Long March in 1934-35, in which they journeyed an average of 17 miles a day over mountains and wastelands, while fighting continuous battles and losing 95 percent of their men.
Another difficulty was that because of the time period, many important participants were dead or too ill to be interviewed. Madame Chiang Kai-shek, still living in Taipei, though in poor health, declined all requests. ''She sent us tea and cookies,'' said Ms. Dietz.
Deng Xiaoping, China's current leader and a ranking military commissar in the Red Army before 1949, similarly refused to be interviewed. Mao Zedong's widow, Jiang Qing, imprisoned since his death in 1976 as a leader of the discredited ''Gang of Four,'' not only was unavailable, but because of an order she gave years ago to cover up her early years as an actress in Shanghai, the producers were denied access to a valuable repository of Chinese archival film.
There was also the sheer complexity of modern Chinese history. ''We didn't want to overload viewers with strange names and dates,'' explained Ms. Williams. ''We could really turn the audience off.'' So, the producers had to winnow down the material.
''Many of these people are very colorful, if you are writing about them, but not on film,'' said Ms. Vecchione.
In several cases, the producers' omissions are unfortunate. They discovered some remarkable footage of the student demonstration in Beijing on May 4, 1919, which has assumed almost mystical significance to later generations of youthful Chinese. But while the film is briefly shown, there is no mention of what came to be called the May Fourth Movement. In part, it was the 70th anniversary of this long-ago march that inspired students this past spring in Beijing.
Much of the early film was found in the John E. Allen archive in Park Ridge, in northern New Jersey, the home of a private film collector. For years, Ms. Williams, whose grandfather had gone to China to make his fortune in business and whose mother was born and raised in China, had routinely asked archives if they had any footage on China when she was working on other projects.
Suddenly, she had a treasure. But because it was old, nitrate-based stock, much of it had deteriorated. ''You would open the cans and find this white, slimy mess,'' she said. It also was uncatalogued.
Sometimes participants were able to help identify film. Soong Hsi-lien, a former Nationalist general whom the producers interviewed, was sitting in the cutting room one day watching footage when he pointed at a figure standing on a hill with binoculars in his hand. ''That's me,'' he exclaimed. The producers made some other stunning finds. There is old newsreel film of emaciated conscripts, roped together by the Nationalists, being led off to fight the Japanese or the Communists. One and a half million of them died before ever reaching the front because of misappropriation of the funds intended to feed them.
Juxtaposed with this is newsreel footage of Chiang Kai-shek, whom the American commentator of the time calls ''the lean, keen Generalissimo, the undisputed leader and idol of 450 million Chinese.''
Ms. Williams is now planning a sequel to ''China in Revolution,'' carrying the story from 1949 up to Mao's death in 1976. It will be a very different story, something the close of the current film presages. When the producers were in Beijing, they happened to see a play on television in which Chiang, in an apocryphal conversation, quotes a Chinese proverb to Mao: ''It is easy to seize power, but difficult to maintain it.''

HEADLINE: OPEC Is Back and Feeling Flush

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
OPEC's lean years are over. After nearly a decade of steep falls in revenues, wild price fluctuations, shrinking demand for oil worldwide and confrontation with the West, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seems to be coming into its own once more.
Over the past three years, demand for oil has steadily grown and so have exports of crude by all 13 members of the cartel, bringing in desperately needed money and easing tensions within the group.
At the same time, a new generation of moderates has changed the texture of the organization, taking command from hard-liners who once led a frantic push for ever-higher prices in bruising battles with oil consumers.
Instead, the moderates, led by Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, Hisham M. Nazer, have worked to keep the price of oil stable and relatively low. 
That has taken much of the incentive away from the United States and other Western countries to develop their own new sources of energy. In July, for the first time since 1977, imports accounted for more than half of the petroleum used by the United States, a reflection of growing demand and a falloff in domestic production at Alaska's Prudhoe Bay and other fields.
''In the past, we chose to ignore the facts of economics and neglected to pursue long-term gains,'' said Alirio Parra, managing director of European operations for Petroleos de Venezuela, Venezuela's state-owned oil company, and a senior member of his country's OPEC delegation for years.
''The new ministers are more realistic,'' Mr. Parra said. ''They have greater awareness of the dynamics of world economic changes and the global importance of economic relations.''
Added John Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, ''OPEC's dark years are over, mostly because they have managed to live with lower prices.''
Of course, given OPEC's history of chronic discord, the cartel's era of good feelings could turn out to be short-lived.
Indeed, the usual squabbling over cheating on production quotas was high on the agenda when OPEC ministers began meeting yesterday in Geneva to map strategy.
Saudi Arabia has repeatedly warned it may match the excesses of production by others, saying it will not allow a diminution of its 25 percent share of total OPEC output.
And Iraq is widely expected to ask for a significant increase in its quota, as its expensive network of pipelines to the Red Sea becomes fully operational in the next few weeks. It is also clearing up its port on the Persian Gulf to receive ships and resume oil exports, a year after the war with Iran ended.
But it is a measure of OPEC's new equanimity that few industry experts think the squabbling will escalate to a danger point, at least not through the end of the year. It is widely expected that the ministers in Geneva will agree to keep things as they are or slightly increase the cartel's overall production ceiling from the present level of 19.5 million barrels a day.
''All the problems are not solved but the situation at OPEC has considerably improved,'' said Nordine Ait-Laoussine, an Algerian oil consultant based in Geneva who represented his country as an OPEC delegate for many years. ''Although I do not believe the Geneva meeting will lead to a resolution of the quota problems, I don't think it will be acrimonious.''
 
Crucial Lessons
 Veteran leaders of OPEC say the cartel has finally absorbed three crucial lessons from the trials and tribulations of the past decade, a period that was capped by the collapse of oil prices in 1986 to below $10 a barrel:
* The best way to keep the world dependent on oil is to make it affordable.
* It is essential to avoid price wars.
* To lessen competition from alternative fuels, consumers in the industrialized West must be assured that their oil needs will always be met.
''It is evident that to pursue and preserve our interests we must behave as commercial entities,'' said the 57-year-old Mr. Nazer, a man who in many ways personifies the new OPEC. ''Whether the market is up or down, we are in the middle of it as a commercial entity, which means we must be knowledgeable, responsive and efficient.''
When Mr. Nazer replaced Ahmed Zaki Yamani in 1986 as the oil minister of the world's leading oil-exporting country, the change signaled a turning point in OPEC's strategies. Mr. Nazer and other new leaders of OPEC - including Algeria's Sadek Boussena, Venezuela's Celestino Armas and Iran's Gholamreza Agazadeh - have consistently chosen compromise in situations where their predecessors would have opted for collision.
Last year, for example, Mr. Agazadeh abandoned a longstanding Iranian objection to allowing Iraq a production quota equal to Iran's. The Iranians have had a larger percentage of oil production since the cartel came into existence in 1960.
Teheran's decision was a painful one, coming on the heels of Iran's inability to win its eight-year war with Iraq. But without the compromise, OPEC would have been in serious trouble. Iraq and Iran now have identical quotas.
The new leaders are low-profile technocrats, slightly boring, some critics would say, and not fiery champions of third world struggle or flamboyant bons vivants, as Mr. Yamani was. They mirror OPEC's new priorities: to secure a reliable income for its members from oil and to repair the many bridges to consumer nations that OPEC burned in its decade-long quest to become the dominant arbiter of oil price and production.
 
The New Style
 Mr. Yamani's tenure paralleled OPEC's rise to power, with oil prices shooting up to $40 a barrel, and its subsequent fall into disunity. By contrast, Mr. Nazer and his colleagues have pursued a careful strategy of confidence-building, stability and moderation.
OPEC's new style includes fewer and shorter meetings, so as to diminish market speculation on the price of oil. In the Yamani era, the meetings went on for 15 or even 20 days. Now, they last a maximum of a few days. In addition, the ministers have agreed to say very little about their differences in public.
Clearly, the new attitude within OPEC has been greatly helped by the change in fortune that began about three years ago, when demand for oil started growing again after the bleak conditions that prevailed from 1979 to 1986.
Few within OPEC dared hope for a turnaround so consistent and so strong, with demand rising by 3 percent a year on a global basis ever since the price collapse of 1986.
Demand is much higher in some economies, particularly in the rapidly industrializing Asian Pacific region. In South Korea, for example, demand was up 15 percent in the first six months of this year over the same period in 1988. Japan has said that it would need 6.5 percent more oil in the next six months.
''The optimists in OPEC have been right and they may be right again,'' said Mr. Lichtblau, an OPEC watcher for a quarter of a century.
Compared with averages of $35 to $39 a barrel that predominated in the late 70's and early 80's, OPEC oil today is a bargain, hovering between $16 and $17.
Virtually all OPEC countries, with the possible exception of Libya, agree that prices should stay in that range since experience has shown that this is the ''affordable'' price, one that does not hamper the growth of the vibrant economies of the West and Asia, the largest consumers of oil today.
More important, it is a price that seems to discourage competitive threats directed at OPEC itself, a keystone of the cartel's strategy.
One of the elements that deeply hurt OPEC was a concerted campaign to find substitutes for OPEC oil following the Arab oil embargo in 1973. The campaign was inspired in part by Western governments that were concerned about the dependence of their economies on imported oil. But it was also motivated by the potential for profit, given the soaring oil prices at the time.
As prices were pushed further up by OPEC from 1973 to 1981, the West formed the International Energy Agency to design a counterstrategy. This included research to develop alternative energies, like solar energy and shale oils, and efforts to greatly increase the generation of nuclear power.
 
Spigots on the Frontier
 In addition, oil began to be found in large quantities in ''frontier'' areas like Alaska and the North Sea. Today's production of 2 million barrels a day in Alaska, 3.5 million barrels in the North Sea and 3 million in Mexico, not to mention the oil coming out of Brazil, India, Yemen and other places, did not exist in 1973.
But because of OPEC's deliberate policy now to keep prices relatively low, these new oil-producing areas already have begun to decline. Oil found in the North Sea is expensive to produce. The same is true of Alaskan oil. In general it is more expensive to produce oil in the United States and Europe than to buy the oil at OPEC's current price.
As a result, in the past three years oil production has begun to decline dramatically in the United States while demand for OPEC oil has rebounded.
United States production has dropped by almost a million barrels a day over the past 12 months alone, to 7.5 million barrels, according to the Paris-based International Energy Agency. Meanwhile, OPEC production has gone from 16 million barrels a day in 1985 to close to 22.5 million barrels today, 3 million over the official quota.
As the American economy continues to grow, the difference between production and consumption - the United States now uses about 18 million barrels a day - is made up by drawing down stockpiles and by steadily increasing imports.
''One can say that the United States is responsible in a sense for the OPEC recovery,'' said Mehdi Verzi, an oil analyst with Kleinwort Benson Securities, a London brokerage house.
OPEC's strategy is based on what a number of energy experts consider to be an understanding, forged unofficially, with major consumers.
''There is a tacit consensus, a sort of deal, whereby OPEC countries agree to guarantee a price for oil that does not put at risk the economic growth of major consumers,'' said Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based Petrostrategies. ''In return, consuming countries no longer continue their massive efforts to find energy substitutes for oil.''
At any rate, the natural, and well-publicized, consequence of the fall in oil prices has been the widespread abandonment by most industrialized countries in the past five years of research to find substitutes.
There also has been a noticeable softening in the relationship between OPEC and the major industrialized countries. The International Energy Agency has reverted to a low profile after aggressively leading the effort to find oil substitutes.
And in the United States, the Reagan Administration, which sometimes acted as if it were on the warpath with OPEC, has been replaced by the Bush Administration, which has been trying to forge better ties with a number of OPEC nations.
 
Trouble on the Horizon?
 If there is a limit to how well things can go for OPEC, however, it is framed by the quota problem.
Under present OPEC rules, the cartel parcels out production according to an old formula of percentages. But many OPEC members, including Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Iraq, say they are entitled to larger quotas. They argue that their production capacity and huge reserves - contrasted with limited reserves of other members like Algeria and Indonesia - justify a change in the formula.
The tension surrounding this issue has been considerably eased by the growth in demand for OPEC oil, which has allowed all members to increase output. But what is still lacking is an official agreement that sets new quotas that all 13 members can live with.
For months now, two maverick members, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, have been producing almost double their allotted quota of one million barrels each. Other members, like Nigeria and Saudi Arabia, are exceeding their quotas slightly.
 
The Saudi Factor
 The most serious challenge to OPEC's new peace would occur if Saudi Arabia decided to match the excesses of the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait.
In a recent interview with the Oil Daily, a trade journal, Mr. Nazer pointedly noted that his country has an ''export capacity'' of 14 million barrels a day while its quota stands at 5.5 million barrels. He said Saudi Arabia was working toward increasing its sustained daily production capacity from about 8 million barrels to 10 million. The message, one Arab oil official said, is clear: ''Don't push us around.''
Iraq has been making the same point, saying that it has an export capacity approaching five million barrels a day with a quota that is under three million.
''I don't think they have any interest in blowing things up,'' said Mr. Ait-Laoussine, the Algerian consultant. ''But in OPEC, in the end, all depends on what the Saudi giant finally decides to do.''
 
No Sudden Moves
 Saudi Arabia, however, has always been careful not to spring surprises. Its style has been to warn, and then warn again and then, if it must act, to do so slowly, increasing production in little doses to give adversaries plenty of time to change their minds.
Saudi officials say that, despite their exasperation with cheating, they are not ready to declare a production war inside OPEC.
In fact, Mr. Nazer is not attending the Geneva meeting. Instead, he is recuperating in Los Angeles from a recent operation. Many OPEC officials say the operation came at an opportune time, providing Mr. Nazer with a reason to miss the meeting and avoid a confrontation.

HEADLINE: Some Lessons From Avis for UAL Buyout

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
At 2 P.M. on the first Thursday of every month, thousands of employees at Avis Inc., the nation's No. 2 rental company, walk off their jobs. With their company's blessing they gather for employee-management sessions that are at the heart of Avis's two-year-old experiment with employee ownership. From these meetings, held across the country, have come such innovations as multilingual information cards for international customers at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York and a way to deter car theft in Baltimore.
These ideas have helped to cut costs and increase profits. But they also provide a more important function: letting employees know that as Avis makes money and pays down debt the value of their shares in the company increases. In the two years since Avis's employee stock ownership plan, or ESOP, began - it's anniversary is tomorrow - the value of the workers' shares has increased from $5.22 a share to $15.47.
Now a similar ESOP is being proposed at the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines. And what Avis has learned - often through trial and error - can provide a textbook for the planners at United. 
''UAL can take a leaf from our book,'' said Joseph V. Vittoria, Avis's chairman and chief executive. ''Hopefully, they will be better prepared. When we did our deal, we had no idea how it would work and whether it would be successful.''
By most measures, Avis's success now seems assured and the company is considered an example of what can happen when workers become owners. For instance, when measured against its archrival, the Hertz Corporation, which is the No. 1 car rental company, Avis has reported higher profit margins - 8.5 percent in 1988 compared with Hertz's 5.7 percent - and lower relative operating costs. Customer complaints at Avis have fallen by 35 percent; the rental fleet has been modernized, and Avis has managed to accelerate payment on some $50 million of the $1.75 billion it borrowed to become the biggest American company to be majority-owned by its employees.
 
How UAL Compares
 The UAL buyout, if it goes through as planned, would top Avis's in size. UAL proposes a $6.75 billion buyout to make the company 75 percent owned by its 68,000 employees. Avis is 100 percent owned by its 12,500 employees. The UAL deal also calls for three union representatives to be put on its board, where Avis has none, and UAL employees would have the final say in corporate policy.
But ESOP experts and Avis employees, from the executive suite to the front counter, warn that UAL's success may be judged not by whether employees sit on the board or set major policy, but the extent to which all employees are drawn into decisions, especially at lower levels.
''Our research shows that the only factor associated with making an ESOP successful in terms of corporate performance is the degree to which employees participate in decisions affecting their jobs,'' said Corey M. Rosen, executive director of the National Center for Employee Ownership, an Oakland-based nonprofit group, ''Avis has set up an extensive system of employee participation throughout the organization and that's why they are successful. The lesson for United is straightforward. If they want to succeed, they will need to do the same thing.''
However, this could be more difficult at UAL since only one of United's three main unions, the pilots, is participating in the buyout. The flight attendants may join, but the machinists are opposed to it. This raises questions as to whether all employee groups can pull together as a team and it limits the amount of tax benefits UAL can enjoy, since ESOP-related tax breaks are determined by the company's salary costs. The greater the number of employees in the ESOP, the larger the tax breaks.
''It's critical that everyone get into it,'' said Mr. Vittoria, ''The biggest problem at UAL is if the machinists don't join. That will create antagonisms. You're working with one group that has certain goals and making sacrifices and another that almost wishes it will fail.'' Added Robert Salerno, Avis's chief of operations: ''If you don't give employees a say in their own jobs, then you are doomed to fail. You have to believe in ESOP's and not just let it be a financial transaction.''
The Thursday meetings at Avis, of employee participation groups, are the company's way of giving employees a say. ''The EPG's haven't given us any home runs,'' said Mr. Salerno. ''But they have given us a lot of singles.'' Joe Wiggins, who has worked at JFK airport as a service agent for 20 years cleaning cars, echoes the idea: ''I have something to contribute to the company and now management listens.''
But Avis executives admit that their employee program can help only add so much to the bottom line. Equally important are the tax breaks that reduce the borrowing costs for leveraged ESOP's, like Avis, and general business conditions. For instance, if the economy slows, if air traffic falls, if corporations cut back on travel expenses or if other car rental companies initiate drastic price wars, Avis will suffer.
And that is the situation facing Avis . After watching profits climb since the ESOP started, business has now begun to taper off. Avis has steadily increased its operating profits - from $16 million in 1987, to $79 million in 1988, the first full year of the ESOP, to $94 million last year. But in the first three months this year, operating profit margins fell to 3.6 percent - operating profits were $10 million and revenues were $277 million. The only good news was that Hertz had an operating loss over the same three- month period of $3.2 million on revenues of $475 million.
''We've got a sluggish economy, some price cutting in our industry and fewer travelers because of higher air fares,'' said Mr. Vittoria. ''We've got to dance all around that. We've cut costs to match the slowdown in revenues.''
Charles H. Finnie, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore is pleased. ''Joe Vittoria has grabbed that company by its lapels and shaken it up for the better,'' he said. ''The ESOP has been a true success. My only concern is that it leveraged Avis's balance sheet. But I think Vittoria's team is capable of generating cash flow to reduce leverage.''
ESOP's have become popular over the last decade as Congress enacted many tax breaks to encourage employee ownership. In most cases, employees own a small percentage of the company's stock, and many of these ESOP's were imposed by management as a takeover defense. But by the end of last year, some 1,500 companies with 1.5 million employees were majority-owned by ESOP's.
The track record on such deals is mixed. In the three years since its ESOP, the Weirton Steel Corporation, which became 100 percent employee owned in 1984, was the only major steel maker to turn a profit. And Weirton's extensive employee involvement programs have increased productivity and have become a magnet for academic studies. But at Dan River, a Virginia textile maker that became a 100 percent ESOP in 1983, old employee-management antagonisms remained and the company has struggled.
UAL is considered more like Avis than Weirton or Dan River. Both are in highly competitive service businesses where there is a high degree of customer contact and the attitude of an employee can draw an immediate reaction from the customer.
Both Avis and UAL have operations strewn over thousands of locations, making it difficult to impose central management control, and both have similar financial structures. They have large fixed capital investments in aircraft or cars, which means that a slight reduction in costs or an increase in revenues goes straight to the bottom line. Both have large labor costs that lead to large ESOP-related tax breaks. And both were in fairly solid financial shape when the ESOP's were proposed, so it was not viewed as a last-ditch maneuver to save the company.
 
No Magic Potion
 ''I don't think employee ownership is a magic potion to spread over bad businesses and turn them into gold,'' said Eugene J. Keilin, a general partner at Lazard Freres & Company, who advised both Weirton and UAL workers. ''But it is a tool that can produce certain results. At UAL, it can help produce lower costs and signficant tax benefits to pay down the debt.''
In Mr. Keilin's opinion, however, financial benefits rather than worker involvement are the key to an ESOP's success. These include the tax breaks given the lender in an ESOP deal, which are passed on in the form of lower borrowing costs, and tax laws that allow ESOP's to deduct not only the interest payments on borrowings, but the repayment of principal as well. ''With a leveraged ESOP, there is the risk of a lot of debt,'' said Mr. Keilin. ''But an ESOP is less risky than someone else's LBO'' because of these benefits.
Besides, Mr. Keilin points out, ESOP's are true long-term investments. Unlike traditional LBO's, where the aim is to pay down debt, pull out dividends and clean up the company for sale, the worker-owners at an ESOP are concerned about maximizing the value of their shares, which are part of their pension.
''One of the psychological barriers to ESOP's is that they seem to have this vaguely leftist ideology when, indeed, they are profoundly capitalist,'' said Mr. Keilin.
It was hardly ideology that concerned Avis executives when they agreed to buy the company from the Wesray Capital Corporation, its fifth corporate owner in less then four years. Mr. Vittoria wanted stability and security for the company and Wesray was happy to get cash for its investment. At first, employee motivation took a back seat to financial concerns in structuring the deal. ''We were obviously engrossed in the financing of it and the people aspect was secondary,'' said Mr. Vittoria.
About that time, Mr. Salerno read an article by Mr. Rosen of the National Center for Employee Ownership. The two met and the idea of the employee participation group emerged. At first, it took a sales pitch to get employees interested, both in the ESOP itself and the employee participation groups. And Mr. Salerno said that even now there are many employees who are uninterested and do not express any interest in participating in the groups.
At the beginning, many of the meetings were centered around what Mr. Salerno calls ''toilet paper'' issues, which is how he refers to the general housekeeping questions facing each Avis work station. Once those were settled, sessions turned to questions of productivity - replacing expensive paper towels with cloth towels, putting clearer signs on the airport buses, finding ways to get the buses that pick up customers to patrol the airports more frequently.
None of these ideas saved the corporation great sums of money, but they led to small savings and a sense by employees of being heard by management. Traditional management-worker issues, like discipline, are handled in the same manner as before the ESOP.
At the Avis operation at Kennedy airport, station manager Steve Biondo points to many changes related to the ESOP. For instance, employees are now more careful about turning off lights and come up with new car cleaning procedures. But his talk soon turns to a favorite topic: his Avis stock. ''It gives me a piece of the pie,'' he said. ''And that feels great. Every day, I check my calculator and see how much stock I have. Next to my house, Avis is the biggest investment I've got.''

HEADLINE: Four Health Care Vigilantes

BYLINE: By GLENN KRAMON

 BODY:
Medical costs continue to run wild despite widespread efforts by the nation's employers to contain them. The cost of the typical company medical plan is projected to rise by 20 to 25 percent this year, according to the latest surveys, after increasing by 15 to 20 percent last year.
But a few large companies have successfully restrained medical inflation. Employers like the Southern California Edison Company, Caterpillar Inc. and the Adolph Coors Company are recording increases of less than 10 percent a year, and in some cases, of closer to the 5 percent of the consumer price index.
Rather than taking isolated stabs at cutting their costs, these companies have developed more comprehensive strategies to fight inflation on several fronts. The approaches could serve as models for other employers and dramatically change how health services are delivered, benefits specialists say. 
To reduce the cost and use of medical services, they are negotiating lower prices from certain doctors and hospitals in return for a promise to nudge employees in their direction. They are reviewing the utilization of services in an attempt to eliminate unnecessary tests, operations and days in the hospital. Like most employers, some have also shifted more of the burden to employees by increasing annual deductibles, coinsurance payments and payroll contributions to the health plans.
These possible trend setters have also taken more radical measures. Caterpillar has taken on more than 100 doctors in court to challenge the price of their services and in many cases, has won. The John Breuner Company, another aggressive cost cutter, refuses to pay the medical bills of employees who do not join a health maintenance organization. And a few employers have taken certain health insurance services like the processing of claims into their own hands. Southern California Edison even runs its own pharmacy.
Health care, it seems, is coming to be viewed as a product to be purchased prudently, just like the steel in Caterpillar's heavy equipment. ''The idea is to manage health care like a business and do your best to get your employees to understand the problem,'' said David E. Scherb, director of benefits at Pepsico Inc., whose medical costs will rise by only about 8 percent this year. ''We can't keep shifting costs to employees.''
Indeed, employees do not always welcome the added burden. Proposals to make workers bear more of their medical costs were at the root of the strikes by unionized workers that began in early August at two of the regional Bell companies, Nynex and Bell Atlantic, and continued at Nynex last week.
What is more, the medical community fears that it and its patients will bear the brunt of the higher costs. They further worry that rulings against doctors in billing disputes in court could set a precedent for insurers to dictate medical fees and influence care.
Still others complain that other people could be forced to absorb the costs. ''After companies negotiate discounts, the medical community simply shifts costs to others - to the small company or individuals that can't negotiate a discount,'' said Francis M. Miller, president of the Colorado Business Coalition for Health, a Denver-based employers group.
And even the most aggressive companies may not be able to sustain single-digit cost increases. The reason: According to a survey by Noble Lowndes, a benefits consulting firm in East Orange, N.J., costs should continue to climb because of increases in the use of high-technology treatments like organ transplants and CAT scans rise and in the costs of catastrophic cases like AIDS and cancer, substance-abuse treatment and psychiatric care, and of subsidizing the uninsured and those covered by Medicare and Medicaid.
Still, the following companies might be in a better position than most.
 
Southern California Edison
 While increasing at an average annual rate of 22 percent through much of the 1980's, the medical costs of the nation's second-largest utility should rise by only 5 to 10 percent this year and by 14 percent annually over the next five. The projected savings over that time: $105 million on a total medical bill of $615 million. Over the next 20 years, the company hopes to save $5.6 billion, or 70 percent of its costs had it done nothing.
At the beginning of this year, Edison overhauled its health plan for the first time in 37 years. The Rosemead, Calif.-based company organized a large network of hospitals that agree to offer discounted prices on rooms and a panel of doctors who adhere to a fee schedule for many procedures.
Edison also stopped paying the entire medical bills of its employees and of most of its future retirees. It now pays 90 percent of the bill for those who use the network and 70 percent for those who do not. But employees who go outside the network often pay more than 30 percent of their bills. The company pays 70 percent of the amount accepted by the doctors on its panel.
And many employees are now required to contribute up to $100 a month toward their medical plans. Under the ''flexible'' arrangement, employees can lower their monthly charge and pay a higher deductible. And workers who agree to be tested for smoking, weight, cholesterol, blood pressure and blood sugar - and to participate in remedial programs if needed - can reduce their monthly contributions by a total of $10. As a result, some employees pay no monthly charge and a few even receive a small credit.
Finally, the company reduced by about 35 percent the amount it pays its health maintenance organizations. The company's previous payments had been based on the medical costs of workers in its non-H.M.O. plans, whose expenses were much higher than those of H.M.O. enrollees.
Now, it pays H.M.O.'s based on what it estimates care actually costs. Employees choosing H.M.O.'s that charge more than what the company will pay must make up the difference. The company argues that it can fairly assess the cost of care because, unlike most companies, it is self-insured, processes its own claims and even reviews claims for potential excesses itself rather than hiring an outside utilization review firm.
Edison even hires its own doctors and buys its own pharmaceuticals. Its 10 clinics and first-aid stations, managed by salaried physicians on its staff, handle 15 percent of the primary-care visits of the company's 57,000 employees, retirees and dependents. The doctors provide care at a lower cost, enabling the company and employees to save about 20 cents on the dollar, said Dr. Jacque J. Sokolov, vice president and medical director at the company. By buying drugs at below wholesale prices, Edison's pharmacy, which fills 85 percent of all prescriptions, saves about 40 cents on the dollar.
But some Edison employees are not pleased with the changes. Employees who once paid almost nothing for health care now shell out up to $3,000 annually. Edison imposed the provisions unilaterally after reaching an impasse in bargaining with its unionized workers, who objected to the plan.
Rae Sanborn, a business manager of a unit of Edison's largest union, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, said the changes have caused ''a big drop in morale and productivity.'' And by reducing payments to H.M.O.'s to unrealistically low levels, he added, the company has forced those providers to cut back on their services.
Some argue that the company's role in health care is a conflict of interest. ''You have the same people who are paying the bill evaluating the treatment received,'' said Willie Stewart, another I.B.E.W. official.
 
Caterpillar Inc.
 When it comes to health care, this heavy-equipment manufacturer moves faster than its name implies. The Peoria, Ill.-based company has managed to hold its increases to an average of well below 10 percent a year for five years, after they rose by 16 to 25 percent a year in the late 1970's and early 1980's. Yet Caterpillar's almost 200,000 employees, dependents and retirees still pay virtually nothing for their medical care other than for the visits to the doctor's office.
Caterpillar saves in a number of ways. It contracts with the hospitals used by its employees for concessions on fees and plans to require employees who go to other hospitals to pay for part of the bill.
It also negotiates with many doctors on certain fees. It pays only the price on a bill that it considers fair. Caterpillar often represents patients who have been sued by doctors for the remainder of their bills in court and pays those physicians the balance if it loses cases. It has won most of its 100 battles so far, said Dr. Robert D. Hertenstein, medical director for group insurance at Caterpillar.
Caterpillar saves on drugs by contracting with pharmacies and paying them the wholesale price of drugs plus a dispensing fee. When the prescribing physician does not specify a proprietary drug, Caterpillar encourages the pharmacies to sell generic drugs by sharing the price difference with them. Like Edison, Caterpillar also administers claims itself. ''That gives us a savings of probably 2 to 3 percent just in administrative costs,'' Dr. Hertenstein said.
''Over all, I would say the company has done a very good job,'' said Tony Green, the president of the United Automobile Workers' Peoria unit, Caterpillar's biggest union local.
 
The John Breuner Company
 Most employers give their workers the choice of a health maintenance organization. But since 1987, Breuner has required its nearly 1,200 employees, retirees and their dependents to sign up with an H.M.O. The San Ramon, Calif., furniture-store chain, which is owned by Batus Inc., has since cut its medical-cost inflation rate significantly. Making the change to an H.M.O.-only health plan was easier for Breuner than it might be for others. Most of its employees are in California, where H.M.O.'s are widespread.
The company has tried to give every employee a choice of at least two H.M.O.'s and an incentive to join: Employees pay only a small coinsurance payment and a monthly payroll deduction of $25 to $137. Dental and vision coverage was also improved.
Even so, to continue to receive coverage, some employees had to give up doctors they had used for decades. And the H.M.O. doctors were not always as convenient.
Still, seven employees interviewed at three stores in the San Francisco area were generally pleased. But one employee worried that she would suffer financially because H.M.O.'s do not always cover certain procedures paid for by other insurers, like in-vitro fertilization.
 
Adolph Coors Company
 The Adolph Coors Company provides troubling evidence that even a company that works hard to control medical costs can be humbled by factors beyond its control.
In recent years the Golden, Colo.-based brewer has managed to limit its per-capita increases in health costs to about 5 percent a year. But this year, the figure will probably climb to about 15 percent. A few organ-transplant cases that will total almost $2 million are the main culprits.And Coors managers hope the this year's increase is only a blip.
Like Caterpillar, the company, which covers about 32,000 people, has tried to save money by administering its own claims. Coors also contracts with hospitals, doctors and dentists for reduced rates.It also handles its own review of medical and mental-health cases. As a result, expenses for mental health and substance abuse fell 5 percent last year, after rising 20 percent a year in the two years before it began to manage the cases, said Mark W. Wright, director of health services. But its cost-cutting program also emphasizes good health. For eight years, it has run a wellness center, which now has a gym and indoor track and offers programs on smoking, alcohol abuse, nutrition and weight loss. A separate medical center handles all of the company's workers' compensation cases - helping rehabilitate employees with such ailments as back injuries.
To show employees it means business, Coors pays 90 percent of the health costs of employees and their spouses who undergo health appraisals and are judged healthy or strive to improve their health if they are not. But it pays only 85 percent of the claims of employees who do not cooperate or try to improve their health if they are higher-risk.
David Laughton, a representative of the Teamsters Union, which failed in an attempt to organize Coors workers last year, said he heard no complaints about the plan.

HEADLINE: Airline Debt, Foreign Investors Worry Washington

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Although details of the meeting were not disclosed, when Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner sat down to breakfast on Friday with Alfred Checchi, the leader of the investment group that is buying Northwest Airlines, it is likely Mr. Skinner had some strong things to say. The meeting was described as a private talk about Northwest's fitness to operate under new management, but the transportation secretary doubtlessly expressed concern about recent trends in the airline industry that are worrying many Government officials, both in the Administration and Congress.
Mr. Skinner has been voicing his concerns with increasing urgency in recent weeks. He is worried that an increasingly indebted airline industry could leverage itself into financial ruin. And he is upset that the deal-making in the industry is putting a growing share of control over American aviation in the hands of foreign stockholders.
Officials at the Transportation Department would not say what conditions Mr. Skinner presented to Mr. Checchi as necessary to meet before it will agree to approve the company's operating licenses, which are subject to revocation by the department. Mr. Skinner himself said he only wanted to ''sit down with the principals and give them the thought processes'' behind his review. 
And few people expect the Bush Administration to block the free market's workings in the Northwest deal. But Mr. Skinner's actions are being watched closely - not only because the $3.65 billion acquisition of Northwest is so lucrative, but because it is viewed as a precedent in an industry that is changing with dizzying speed.
 
More Takeovers Expected
 The takeover of Northwest has been followed swiftly by the proposed purchase of United Airlines by its employees and managers; and both deals have involved huge borrowing and big roles for foreign airlines.
''I would be very surprised if these two transactions are the last ones,'' Mr. Skinner said in an interview last week - expressing the preponderant view on Wall Street, in Washington and among airline executives.
Airlines are supremely attractive candidates for financial restructuring in an era of debt financing. Their principal assets, big jet airplanes, can be sold to raise cash and then leased back. If used as collateral for loans, the airplanes have the added advantage of gaining in value rather than depreciating as they get older because demand for airplanes is so strong. The airlines have other hidden assets as well, like their gates, landing rights and international routes.
But leveraged buyouts raise the possibility of a collapse down the road, even though the airlines are booming at the moment.
''Their stability is improving, and has been since the early 1980's,'' said the airline bond analyst Philip A. Baggaley of the Standard & Poor's Corporation. ''But they are still cyclical companies, and we have not seen how well they will perform in the next recession. If you do have a spread of leveraged buyouts to most of the strong airlines, the result will be greater bankruptcy risk, greater consolidation in the industry, and slower progress in modernizing their fleets of planes.''
Adding to the Government's worries is the continuing concentration of the industry, in which 90 percent of the traffic now moves on eight carriers. And of the big airlines, only at American has the percentage of capitalization accounted for by debt declined.
''The significant debt involved in a leveraged buyout can increase the risk that an airline will not be able to meet its financial obligations,'' said Mr. Skinner. ''Given the small number of major U.S. air carriers, the failure of any of these carriers could reduce the level of competition in the industry.''
In both the House of Representatives and the Senate there were hearings last week into airline competition and concentration. Like the Transportation Department, lawmakers are looking not just at takeovers, but at a broad range of competitive issues, such as access to overcrowded airports, barriers to newly established airlines and the rules governing computerized reservation and ticketing services owned by airlines.
 
Strong Skinner Involvement
 And committees in both houses will mark up bills this fall that might alter the role of the Transportation Department in reviewing airline buyouts.
Mr. Skinner's breakfast on Friday was part of the negotiations between the Transportation Department and Northwest's new owners over the conditions the Transportation Department would insist upon before permitting the takeover of NWA, Northwest's parent corporation.
Airline lobbyists say they are surprised - and a little worried - by Mr. Skinner's involvement in the financial maneuverings of the industry. ''There is a reregulatory, interventionist tendency at work. It is scaring people around town,'' said one lobbyist.
But Mr. Skinner says he has no objection to the heavy borrowing, as long as the airlines retain enough cash flow for investments in safety modifications of older aircraft, quieter engines to meet environmental standards and advanced technologies for bomb detection, among the other costs of doing business.
''I start from the very strong presumption that the marketplace knows more about the proper capitalization of business than do government regulators,'' Mr. Skinner said in a speech last week before the International Aviation Club. ''Yet the issues posed by very significant increases in debt and proposed significant foreign investment in the U.S. airline industry are important enough to warrant careful scrutiny.'' But language has been blunt in Congress. ''The Wall Street vultures can take their junk bonds and go elsewhere,'' said Senator Wendell Ford, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Aviation, when he introduced his bill on airline takeovers.
 
The Secretary's Veto Power
 Mr. Ford's bill, and a companion measure being drafted in the House, would require the Transportation Secretary to approve any airline acquisition in which more than 25 percent of the voting power changes hands. But Mr. Skinner has made plain that he will exercise effective veto power over takeovers by reconsidering the ''fitness certificate'' of any airline that is involved in a buyout.
The question is whether the Government's reviews and Mr. Skinner's public pronouncements - which are really nothing other than the tried-and-true tactic known in Washington as jawboning - are as potent as the financial forces at work on the industry. The concern is that there still are plenty of potential takeover candidates among the airlines and that the rush toward more takeovers and mergers has just begun.
At the top of the list, now that United and Northwest have been snapped up, are the healthiest airlines left: American, Delta and USAir. American's shares jumped 13 percent in value on a single day last month on takeover rumors. Delta has engineered a takeover defense based on an employee stock ownership plan.
An investor group headed by the Wall Street money manager Michael Steinhardt told the Securities and Exchange Commission earlier this month that it increased to more than 8 percent the 6 percent stake it took last July in USAir, the nation's seventh-largest airline. Airlines that are less well off also are seeking investors. Texas Air's chairman, Frank Lorenzo, has said the company is considering selling an interest in Continental. Texas Air also owns the bankrupt Eastern Airlines, much of which is being sold off under the bankruptcy procedures. And Texas Air was reported to be discussing sale of part of its computer reservations system to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation.
Thomas G. Plaskett, Pan American World Airway's chairman, has been talking for months about the prospect of a merger involving his airline. The increasing trend toward links between international airlines is also making many officials in Washington nervous. Among the financial links are those between United and British Airways, Northwest and KLM-Royal Dutch Airlines, Delta Airlines and Swissair, Texas Air (parent of Continental and Eastern) and Scandinavian Air Systems, and America West and Australia's Ansett.
 
'Worldwide Megacarrier'
 Pan Am's Mr. Plaskett says that the age of the ''worldwide megacarrier'' is upon us. ''British Airways flights currently cover 17 percent of the world's scheduled air routes, while United's cover 31 percent, with none overlapping,'' he commented. ''Together, British Airways and United will offer passengers nearly half of the world's existing air routes, much more than any other single airline or any alliance of airlines.
''Now, it doesn't take a rocket scientist to know that with $750 million invested in United, British Airways will do everything it possibly can to maximize the return on its investment. I hardly think there will be a strategic decision made by these two megacarriers that isn't carefully coordinated.''
James F. Rill, the assistant U.S. Attorney General for antitrust, said on Wednesday that his department will closely examine the British Airways investment and similar deals. United States laws, like those of many other nations, prevent outright mergers of domestic and foreign airlines.
''More likely is the formation of marketing joint ventures, with or without cross-ownership interests, involving foreign and domestic airlines, particularly for interline travel,'' he said. ''These types of transactions, or any consolidation between foreign and domestic airlines, would be analyzed under the antitrust laws.''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Banks Take Blows On Foreign Debt

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
Some big banks took big steps to deal with their problem third world loans. J. P. Morgan added $2 billion to its loan-loss reserves, a move that is expected to give it a $1.8 billion loss in the quarter and a loss for the year. Chase Manhattan put aside an additional $1.15 billion and forecast a loss of $1.12 billion this quarter. Manufacturers Hanover added $950 million to reserves and said it expected a quarterly loss of $775 million. Executives of the banks said the arrangement worked out earlier this month between Mexico and its creditor banks showed a need to recognize the possibility of greater losses on third world loans. For many banks the agreement will mean accepting a 35 percent reduction in the value of their Mexican loans. American banks took similar actions in 1987, setting aside billions of dollars.
 
*
 Manufacturers Hanover sold control of its CIT Group finance company to Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, the world's largest bank. The deal, at $1.4 billion, is the biggest investment yet by a Japanese bank in an American financial company. The money will help strengthen Manufacturers, which is more troubled than most big American banks by its third world loans. For Dai-Ichi, CIT will provide access to medium-sized American businesses. 
Bankers Trust will handle the sale of a corporate bond issue, becoming the first banking company to take advantage of a Federal Reserve decision in July to relax banking restrictions. Bankers Trust will handle a $150 million issue of ''junk bonds'' by Morningstar Foods, a Dallas maker and distributor of dairy products.
 
*
 The second-quarter growth rate was put at 2.5 percent in the final revision of the gross national product figures for the April- June period. That is down slightly from the previous estimate of 2.7 percent . . . Corporate profits in the quarter were even worse than previously estimated. The Federal Reserve said profits were down 7.2 percent, rather than off 5.4 percent . . . Consumer prices were unchanged in August, the first month in more than three years that the Consumer Price Index did not register an increase . . . Housing construction was down 5 percent in August . . . Personal incomes were up four-tenths of a percent in August, outpaced by consumer spending, which rose nine-tenths of a percent.
 
*
 The ''junk bond'' market had a rebound from its big losses, aided by the Campeau Corporation's arranging $250 million in emergency financing. The cash-flow problems of Campeau, a retailer and real estate company, had helped spook the junk market in the previous week. The stock market showed little direction. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.03 points for the week, closing at 2,681.61. The dollar headed down, as speculation grew that world monetary officials, meeting in Washington this weekend, would move to curb the dollar's months-long rise.
 
*
 Uniroyal Goodrich is being sold to Michelin of France for $690 million. The company, based in Akron, Ohio, is the nation's second-largest tire maker. It is owned by the New York investment firm of Clayton & Dubilier. After the deal, Goodyear, the nation's largest tire company, will be the only American tire maker not owned by foreign interests.
 
 *
 France's top chemical company, Rhone-Poulenc, agreed to buy two specialty chemical operations, paying $480 million for the GAF Corporation's unit and $820 million for a unit of Britain's RTZ Corporation.
 
*
 Ford is buying shares of Jaguar and dropping hints that it might eventually seek control of the British luxury car maker. Jaguar's board said the Ford move was not welcome, even though its chairman has said the ailing company may be forced to link up with a bigger corporation. Jaguar, which produces about 52,000 cars a year, has been hurt by a slump in its American sales.
Chrysler is selling 45 percent of the shares it holds in Mitsubishi Motors for $592 million. The buyers are 25 Japanese financial institutions. Chrysler's Mitsubishi stake will be cut to 12.1 percent, from 21.8 percent.
 
*
 Noxell is being acquired by Procter & Gamble in a $1.3 billion stock-swap deal. Noxell makes Noxzema skin- care products, Cover Girl and Clarion cosmetics and Lestoil household cleaner. Noxell's shares jumped $9.75, to $31, after the announcement.
 
*
 Miscellanea. A 10 percent stake in Tiffany & Company is being acquired by Misukoshi, the Japanese department store chain . . . Lion Nathan Ltd. of New Zealand is buying half the brewing operations of the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond for $1.9 billion. The deal does not include Bond's G. Heileman beer operations in the United States . . . The Boston Celtics L.P., which owns the professional basketball team, is buying WFXT, the Boston television station owned by Rupert Murdoch. Terms were not disclosed.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN FRAGRANCES;
As the Market Becomes Flooded, Sales Sink

BYLINE: By DEBORA TOTH; Debora Toth is a writer based in Long Island.

 BODY:
The American market is soaked in perfume. Manufacturers have been introducing 30 to 40 new fragrances a year - up from only 20 to 25 annually in the early 1980's. But instead of invigorating sales, it has made matters worse. 
Manufacturers already complain that consolidation among department stores has reduced the outlets for selling their wares. And a few in the industry worry that the pall cast over the singles scene by AIDS will weaken demand for fragrances. Worse, many women, overwhelmed by the selection, simply have delayed making a choice.
As a result, perfume sales have plunged. Purchases of women's fragrances in the United States have tumbled by about 34 percent since 1981, to about 1.4 million bottles last year, according to William Fitzgerald, a fragrance economist in Potomac, Md. Retail sales increased over the period at the pace of inflation, but only because manufacturers raised their prices. Fragrances include everything from perfumes, the richest in fragrance oil and the most expensive - averaging $200 an ounce - to the lightest and cheapest colognes and splashes.
The slowdown has inflamed marketing wars. Signing up stars for celebrity scents, the latest marketing gimmick, has helped increase the cost of introducing a fragrance to an average of $50 million, up from about $1 million 12 years ago. Even so, the hottest perfumes are lucky to last five years.
Together, the higher stakes of selling scents and the slowdown in sales have strengthened the positions of the biggest manufacturers. Last year, the top five fragrance makers controlled 62 percent of a $2.6 billion American retail market, up from 46 percent in 1981.
For manufacturers with the greatest distribution economies, fragrances, particularly the most prestigous brands, are still lucrative. And they could become even more so. Manufacturers are eyeing fertile foreign markets, where fragrance sales are growing by up to 20 percent a year. And many are encouraged by the promise of behavioral scents, which purport to remedy restlessness, even stress.
