HEADLINE: BUSINESS FOURM: GETTING TOUGH ON TRADE;
Give Japan a Target and Say 'Import!'

BYLINE: By RUDIGER DORNBUSCH; Rudiger Dornbusch is a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology

 BODY:
Japanese tariff rates are only 6.4 percent, even lower than those of the United States, Canada or the European Community. But even so,, gaining market access in Japan is an experience not unlike attaining justice in Franz Kafka's novel ''The Trial.''
To the charge of a closed market, Japanese officials use one of two responses. Either they assert that Japan is not closed at all - but that Japanese consumers are special. Or they argue that perhaps there were difficulties in the past, but all that has changed and Japan is opening up vigorously. 
Neither is true. Industrialized countries, without exception, show major increases in import penetration over time. But in Japan the ratio of manufactured imports to gross national product has stayed at about 2 percent over the last 20 years.
Japanese officials are quick to claim that Japan has been making strides in market opening. They make much of the fact that manufactured goods already account for more than half of imports, far above the share in the 1970's. But the rising share of manufactured goods is only the mirror image of the fall in oil and commodity prices in the 1980's and not the result of a sharp rise in manufactured imports. Growth of two-way trade in manufactures - common elsewhere because consumers like variety - has not happened in Japan.
It does not really matter for our purposes what causes Japan's imports to be low. There is no question that import discrimination exists. But the resulting cost of protection on Japanese consumers is their own problem, not ours. Even so, their discrimination hurts our export companies and that is unacceptable in an open trading system.
A new American trade policy toward Japan is now required. Where negotiations at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and diplomacy have failed, the Super 301 provision of the 1988 trade law offers a means to force recognition of American trade interests in the world market.
The Super 301 route should be used to increase American market penetration in Japan. A target should be set based on the growth rate of Japanese imports of American manufactured goods. Japan should be required to increase its imports of manufactured goods from the United States at an average rate of at least 15 percent per year, with adjustments for inflation in each country. Assuming a 5 percent growth rate in Japan, the import share of American manufactured goods in the Japanese market would thus rise from 0.7 percent to 1.7 percent over a 10-year period.
There ought to be an effective sanction mechanism, automatic and forceful enough to initiate a timely and complete Japanese understanding that adjustment is now required or else access to the American market will be blocked. A suitable mechanism is an automatic tariff surcharge on Japanese exports to the United States. The surcharge would be triggered automatically in proportion to any shortfall of the Japanese import growth target. Early fulfillment of the target would halt the process.
Such a policy raises a number of issues. Japan might simply shift demand from European to American goods. If so what would be the European response? And what if Europe made the same demands of Japan as the United States? One would hope that Europe would do just that and, in exchange, forgo the growing tendency to discriminate against Japanese goods. Japan would face a multilateral challenge to open its markets that, if met, would lead to freer trade.
Japanese companies might also locate in the United States to produce ''Japanese'' goods for sale in Japan and thus meet the import test. There is no problem with Japanese investment in the United States; we are interested in ''good jobs at good wages'' and American-located production. Whether the employer is an American or Japanese company is almost irrelevant. Of course, trade growth targets have to be based on exports of products with substantial American content.
Japan might consider this American posture unacceptable. The trade problem could then widen to become a national security concern and confrontation would be unavoidable. Japan has grown up and is looking to define a role commensurate with its economic strength. In that search, Japan must choose whether it is willing to be part of an open trading system or is seeking another role.
We are ambivalent about Japan, fearful of Japan bashing and uncertain about triggering trade conflict. Japan is conscious of our lack of resolve and exploits it to the fullest. Where we go wrong is in assuming that the showdown can be avoided. If we do not open up Japan's market, the next recession will inevitably lead to import restrictions here - a much worse outcome for the entire liberal trading system.

HEADLINE: Rapid Rail

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The reasoning of Eric W. Beshers, a former deputy director of the office of economics of the Department of Transportation, goes a long way toward explaining why the American transportation system is such a mess.
His attitude, which seems to be typical for that agency, is myopic: no more direct subsidies for rail, but it is perfectly O.K. to hand over more than half a trillion dollars of indirect subsidies to motor vehicle and air-lane users. The rail industry cannot be ''reaching for your wallet,'' because the airline and highway lobbies already have it firmly in their grasp. 
The motor fuel and air-passage taxes cover only a small portion of the public costs of flying or driving: Air traffic control is paid to a large extent from general funds, and automobile traffic control is funded by local taxes. Highway users are indirectly subsidized at 18 cents per passenger mile. If Amtrak got a similar subsidy, we could all ride free, and if the Pan Am shuttle were made to pay back the indrect subsidies it receives, the one-way fare would indeed be raised to over $150.
Mr. Beshers's arguments against some of the benefits of high-speed rail, like cleaner air and the energy savings, are misleading. A Pan Am shuttle with 70 passengers uses as much fuel moving from its loading gate up to cruising altitude as it takes for a Metroliner to travel all the way from New York to Washington with several hundred people.
And there is no question ''whether high-speed rail results in enough fewer cars or planes to make a difference.'' Just look at France's Train a Grande Vitesse: after its inception, demand for air travel between Paris and Lyons virtually disappeared.
 
ALBERT F. CAFIERO
Chairman
Bergen County Transit Committee
Tenafly, N.J., Sept. 3

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
Time to Take the Financial I.Q. Test

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD; Carole Gould writes about personal finance topics from New York.

 BODY:
Many people pride themselves on how much they know - or think they know - about financial matters. Yet accountants and financial planners say misconceptions are rife among their clients. And when it comes to money, the professionals say, ignorance is definitely not bliss. The following questions and answers on investments and taxes can give you a sense of your financial I.Q. You may find that it is time to sit down and review the A B C's of personal finance.
 
Q. You are looking for the best place to stash your small nest egg. While you want a good return, you are very concerned about the safety of your principal. Your stockbroker tells you a ''Government guaranteed'' mutual fund is your best bet. What does the guarantee mean? 
 
 
 
A. It means only that the Government guarantees the payment of principal when the bonds in the mutual fund's portfolio mature. The portfolio is made up of United States Government or agency bonds. But because the bonds are freely traded, their prices fluctuate and fund shareholders can lose principal, depending on when they sell their shares in the fund.
 

 
Q. Now that interest rates are dropping, you are thinking about refinancing your home mortgage. Your neighbor tells you that a 15-year mortgage is always a better deal than a 30-year mortgage, if you can afford the higher monthly payments. True or false?
 

 
A. False. While you always pay less interest on a shorter-term loan, choosing which mortgage to take is not clear-cut. You must evaluate two factors: the tax savings from the larger interest payments for a 30-year loan and your opportunity cost, or the amount you could earn by investing the difference in monthly payments between the two types of mortgages. Thus you may be able to take out a 30-year mortgage, use part of the difference in monthly payments to pay down the loan early, pay off the loan balance at the end of 15 years with accumulated savings from taxes and monthly payments and still have some cash left over, said Steven Enright, director of financial planning with Seidman Financial Services in New York.
 

 
Q. It is time to review your disability policy and your insurance agent insists that you need more coverage. Keep in mind, the agent says, that the payments are taxable. Are they?
 

 
A. When you purchase your own disability policy, any payments are tax-free. But when you get coverage through your job and your employer picks up the premiums, the payments are fully taxable.
 

 
Q. You are thinking about selling 100 shares of stock that you inherited from your father. Your father bought the shares in 1972 for a total of $200. When he died, the stock was worth $500. If you sell the shares for $1,000, what is your taxable gain?
 

 
A. $500. Your tax basis in the stock, or any inherited property, is the fair market value of the property at the time of death. Had your father made you a gift of the stock on the day before he died, you would have taken his basis - the $200 purchase price - and paid tax on a much larger gain.
 

 
Q. You see an advertisement for a fixed-income mutual fund yielding 12 percent. That looks good compared with the fund that your stockbroker is pushing, which pays only 11 percent. When you show her the ad, your broker still insists that her choice is a better investment. Is this possible?
 

 
A. Yes. Investors must also look at total return, which equals yield plus capital appreciation. The Bull and Bear High Yield Fund, for example, has a current yield of 12.19 percent but an annualized three-year return that amounts to a loss of 1.9 percent, notes Douglas E. Mollin, assistant director of financial planning for Seidman.
 
 
Q. To celebrate the birth of your first grandchild, you would like to deed the child some land that you own in Wyoming. Your real estate agent tells you that since you are giving property, not cash, you won't owe any gift tax. True or false?
 

 
A. False. Except for an annual exclusion, you owe Federal gift tax on the fair market value of any asset that you give as a gift. As for the exclusion, you can make tax-free gifts of up to $10,000 a year per recipient. If you and your spouse make the gift jointly, you can give up to $20,000.
 

 
Q. You've just opened up a gourmet take-out shop. Business is brisk, and you need some extra help. You are thinking about hiring your wife, or asking your 16-year-old son to help out after school, since you won't have to pay any Social Security tax on their wages. True or false?
 

 
A. False. Because of recent changes in the tax law, business owners must now pay Social Security tax on the wages of spouses and children of any age. Still, given the sharp curbs on family income-shifting, hiring young children has become more popular, said Lawrence W. Goldstein, a tax principal with Ernst & Young in New York.
 

 
Q. Your wallet was stolen, and the thief uses your bank card to withdraw cash from your account. Are you on the hook for (a) $50, (b) up to $500 or (c) the entire amount?
 

 
A. Depending on what you do, any of the three. If you notify the bank within two business days after learning of the loss or theft of your card, you are liable for only $50 of the fraudulent withdrawals. If you wait longer, the limit jumps to $500. And if you fail to notify the bank for more than 60 days after you receive your monthly statement, you may be liable for the entire loss.
 

 
Q. You are charged no interest on your credit card if you pay your bills within 30 days. You had a $150 balance outstanding last month. This month, you charge an additional $250. When you get your bill, do you owe interest on (a) $150, (b) $250 or (c) $400?
 

 
A. $400. The grace period does not apply when balances are carried forward on a bank card, said Elgie Holstein, director of the Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer group in Herndon, Va.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 1, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Personal Finance column last week misstated the rule that determines when the wages of children employed by their parents become subject to Social Security tax. Because of recent changes in the law, the tax applies to children 18 years of age or older, not to younger children.

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 289 words

HEADLINE: Rapid Rail

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is not true, as Eric Beshers stated, that the right of way for the T.G.V. must be almost straight and almost flat, which implies that new lines are exorbitantly expensive. While it is true that the route for an electric locomotive must be relatively straight, it does not need to be flat - which is where the high cost in construction is incurred. 
Steam does require almost level grades because the locomotive has an engine, and its capacity to create mechanical power is necessarily limited by size and weight. Also, it must carry its own fuel, an additional weight. Diesel engines have similar constraints.
But with electric trains, practically unlimited amounts of mechanical power are created at the central generating station and converted to electricity. Size is no limitation because a generating station doesn't have to move. Enormous amounts of electric power can be transmitted through a catenary, overhead wire, smaller in diameter than your finger. And the electric motor in the locomotive also has large capacity while being very compact since it is not creating power, merely changing its form. Thus, an electric locomotive is so powerful it can easily handle steep upgrades that would sharply slow a steam or diesel locomotive.
However, on sharp turns, the electric train must slow down, thereby losing its advantages of speed. This is why the French national railroad built a new route for the T.G.V. from Paris to Lyons.
To make the high-speed concept even more economical, dynamic breaking permits the electric locomotive's motor to slow the train on downgrades by functioning as a generator and pumping power back into the catenary.
 
ALBERT SANDERS
West Palm Beach, Fla. Sept. 7

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The U.N., Resuscitated, Feels Like What It Was Meant to Be

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
WHEN President Bush steps up to a green marble podium here Monday to address the United Nations General Assembly, his audience will be listening attentively for signs that the United States now wholeheartedly backs a stronger role for the organization in maintaining peace and resolving problems in the world.
The 44th General Assembly is convening in an atmosphere of optimism, with many delegates saying that the easing in East-West tensions has finally created the conditions needed for the United Nations to become something close to what its founders envisaged.
But peace is expensive, and economic conditions may not be so favorable. An important question will be how firm a commitment President Bush can give that the United States, under severe budgetary restraints, will pay its share of peacekeeping and other operations. 
A major reason for believing the time is ripe for the United Nations to become more effective is the change in Moscow's attitude toward the organization over the last couple of years. In that period, as other members have bowed to Western pressure to resist using conflicts to further their own ideological ends, the Soviet Union has revealed a new willingness to work with the United States and the other permanent Security Council members to resolve conflicts and develop joint approaches to common problems like global warming.
The change has strengthened the ability of the United Nations to help resolve bitter conflicts in Afghanistan, Namibia, the Persian Gulf and Central America. In none of these conflicts is a full settlement in place. But United Nations negotiators played critical roles in helping the Soviet Union withdraw from Afghanistan and in bringing about a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq. They are trying to help Namibia move toward independence and Central America carry out regional peace accords. Efforts are also being made to help extinguish conflicts in Cambodia, the Western Sahara, the Sudan and Ethiopia.
In the last two years, the number of blue-helmeted United Nations peacekeeping soldiers has risen by one-third, to about 14,000, as new forces were dispatched to Afghanistan, the gulf war zone, Namibia and are now planned for Central America. Meanwhile, the cost of such operations has nearly tripled, to an estimated $700 million this year, with the United States being assessed 30 percent of the total.
If forces are sent to Cambodia and other areas in the next few years, the peace bill could be higher still.
''The assistance of the organization is being sought as never before in its history,'' Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said in his latest report on the organization's activities. ''There is weariness of wars and there is recognition of their futility.''
Money is not the only limitation on the peacemaking powers of the United Nations. The organization has had its greatest influence in places where antagonists were looking for a face-saving way out and the great powers could bring influence to bear, as in Afghanistan, Central America and Namibia. Civil wars in Cambodia, Ethiopia, the Sudan and the Western Sahara, where strong ethnic tensions are at play, are proving more difficult to resolve.
When he spoke before the General Assembly last year, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed ways to strengthen the organization in the 1990's, including an increased role in environmental protection and more diplomacy by the Security Council to nip disputes in the bud. Prof. Thomas M. Franck of New York University Law School, an expert on the United Nations, said the Soviet proposals represented ''an exceptional opportunity that could give the United Nations a new lease of life'' if the detente continues.
United Nations delegates hope that President Bush expresses renewed American faith in the United Nations in his speech tomorrow.
In the Reagan years, United States antagonism grew toward the United Nations, viewed as a place where radicals sought to promote their statist views of the world and trample on personal freedoms. By encouraging Congress to withhold financing from the United Nations, the Reagan Administration turned the United States into the organization's biggest debtor, while still seeking to exercise its control.
But now President Bush has signaled a change of tack, asking Congress to pay the full American share this year and start repaying arrears. But while Congress is expected to fulfill his first request, there is little chance it will repay any debt.
Today the United States owes the United Nations $491 million in unpaid regular budget contributions, or two-thirds of all outstanding dues, as well as $254 million for peacekeeping operations to which it gave political support but failed to find the money for when the bills came in. For years, Washington scolded Moscow for its failure to pay, but the Soviet Union is now paying its back dues, furthering pressure on the United States.
There are serious doubts whether the United Nations can begin any new peacekeeping operations without some guarantee of stronger American financial support, even though the need for them is likely to increase. President Bush's speech could give some clues on how likely those prospects are.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Why the U.S. Closed the Door Halfway on Soviet Jews

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR 20 years, the United States and Israel have denounced the Soviet Union for severely restricting the right to emigrate. Now that Moscow is allowing record numbers of Soviet Jews and Pentacostals to leave, it is not clear where they will go.
The Bush Administration announced a momentous change in United States refugee policy this month without fully explaining the reasons. On the advice of State Department and immigration officials, President Bush ordered that all decisions on Soviet refugee claims be made at the American Embassy in Moscow. Beginning next month, Soviet citizens will not be allowed to apply for refugee status in Rome or Vienna, as they have been able to since the early 1970's. The Administration also set a ceiling of 50,000 on the number of Soviet refugees in the coming year. 
Israeli officials welcomed the change and predicted that it will substantially increase the migration of Soviet Jews to Israel, because they will find it harder to get into the United States as refugees. Israel looks forward to resettling thousands of Soviet Jews even though it has had difficulty finding jobs and housing for some recent emigres. The number of Jews leaving the Soviet Union rose from 8,155 in 1987 to 18,965 last year and may exceed 48,000 this year. American officials say that could double next year.
American Jewish groups recognize that limits on the admission of Soviet refugees are inevitable, and some, like the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, say they support the Administration plan to centralize operations in Moscow. But many groups, including the National Association of Evangelicals, say the change is being made too abruptly and that there will be too few immigration officers at the Moscow Embassy.
In explaining their decision, Administration officials cited many humanitarian, financial, political and bureaucratic concerns.
First, said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, there was an ''intolerable and inhumane situation'' for Soviet emigres ''passing through the Rome and Vienna pipeline.'' More than 14,000 Jews who managed to get out of the Soviet Union are in Ladispoli, Italy, outside Rome. Most are waiting for their cases to be adjudicated; some have already been found ineligible for refugee status in the United States. Many feel stranded, even though they left Moscow with Israeli visas and could go to Israel.
 
Embarrassing Situation
The long line of refugees in Italy is embarrassing to American officials. For years, Washington looked upon the Soviet Union's denial of exit visas with concern. But now, by most accounts, the number of Soviet Jews denied admission to the United States as refugees, about 5,000 in the last year, exceeds the number who have been refused exit visas and remain in the Soviet Union. American officials said they feared that their operations in Rome and Vienna might be overwhelmed by a huge outpouring of Soviet emigres in the coming year.
 
State Department officials including Ivan Selin, the
Under Secretary for Management, expressed confidence that with computers and other technology, the American Embassy in Moscow can cope with the flow of refugees. Soviet citizens will apply in Moscow, but much of the paperwork will be done by ''remote control,'' from an office in the Washington area.
Jewel S. Lafontant, the new United States Coordinator for Refugee Affairs, said the Administration wanted to ''get control over the flow'' of emigres from Moscow. ''The situation in Rome is extremely costly and ultimately inhumane under current conditions,'' she said.
Soviet citizens who apply for refugee status in Moscow can return home and keep their jobs while waiting for a decision. The situation is much more awkward when Soviet citizens file applications in Rome, because they are then, in effect, camped out on the doorstep of the American Embassy there.
 
The expense of caring for
Soviet refugees in Italy -$34 million this year - was another factor in the decision to phase out use of the way station in Rome. ''We are short'' of money at a time when the number of refugees worldwide has grown to a record level of 14 million, said Princeton N. Lyman, the new director of refugee programs at the State Department.
But some in Congress argue that fiscal concerns are a poor excuse for the change in policy. Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, ''We have a great American ideal of an open door for refugees, but then we come up against the hard reality of cold cash.'' Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Connecticut, chairman of the Judiciary subcommittee on immigration, said that Democrats would probably acquiesce in the change, but believed the Administration should proceed more slowly.
Israel has long insisted that Soviet Jews carrying Israeli visas should not be regarded as refugees. There is no evidence that President Bush's decision was a response to Israeli pressure, but Administration officials have noted that Soviet Jews can go to Israel, while other refugees often have no place to go.
Israel ardently wants the Soviet Jews to resettle in Israel, seeing their arrival as a fulfillment of Zionism and as a possible counterbalance to the rapid growth of Israel's Arab population. But officials acknowledge that with the country in a recession, Israel cannot provide jobs for large numbers of Soviet Jews.
The debate over Soviet emigration demonstrates how United States refugee policy can be affected by domestic political pressures. Dozens of groups have prodded the Administration to keep the doors open to refugees from the Soviet Union and Indochina; there is much less debate in Congress about the plight of Africa's four million refugees.
Experts say it is conceivable that some Soviet Jews, denied refugee status in America, might choose to stay in the Soviet Union rather than go to Israel. Israeli officials say this is unlikely. But if it happened, it would undermine the contention that Soviet Jews have ''a well-founded fear of persecution,'' justifying their admission to the United States as refugees.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Sudden Support for National Health Care

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PROPOSALS that might once have been denounced as socialized medicine or ignored as too costly are now getting serious consideration in Washington, with various plans for insuring America's health receiving the support of labor, industry and the medical establishment.
The core of the problem is that 31 million uninsured Americans are denied ready access to anything but emergency health care. Possible legislative solutions are being considered by a panel of Congressional members and Presidential appointees that began hearings last week. The Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, which was created by Congress last year to develop a national plan, is to issue recommendations next spring.
While the United States spends 12 percent of its gross national product on a system that provides spotty or no service to millions, Canada spends 8.6 percent of its G.N.P. to provide health care to all its citizens and other Western democracies spend even less, using some form of national health insurance. 
The proposals under consideration include everything from simply requiring all employers to provide health insurance, to proposals that would combine public and private resources to make sure no one is uninsured, to the most sweeping proposal now under study, the Canadian approach, under which the Federal Government would be responsible for virtually all health care expenses. Some proposals also include measures specifically intended to hold down the soaring costs of medical care. A Canadian-style plan in particular would represent a radical change for Americans, but some experts expect changes in that direction eventually.
''It is very unlikely in the near future that we'll have a Canadian-type system,'' said Dr. Arnold Relman, editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, in an interview. ''But by the end of the century, I'd be willing to bet that's where we'll come out.''
In a remarkable shift of the political winds, the pressure for expansion of health care coverage is coming from many directions. But each of the various approaches has its own constituency. The medical establishment, for example, tends to oppose plans that would limit fees or treatment, though some doctors support increased Government control. Employers tend to favor plans that shift more of the cost to Government; but some fiscal conservatives in Congress would limit Government involvement, preferring to let the insured pay more for insurance. Many liberals would increase Government responsibility, but would rather not talk of new taxes.
 
Changing Minds
''Employers are changing their minds about national health insurance because they are losing the advantage in international competition by having to pay for health care, instead of having the Government pay,'' said Melvin A. Glasser, director of the Committee for National Health Insurance, a coalition representing labor groups.
Hospitals see national health insurance as necessary to defray the growing costs they bear in treating the uninsured without compensation. ''There should be universal coverage, a partnership with Federal, state and private components,'' said a spokeswoman for the American Hospitals Association. The American Medical Association generally agrees.
Members of the national health care commission said the need for a national plan is urgent. But even before the hearings began, members of Congress agreed that the prospects for national health insurance have been harmed by the current backlash against the legislation passed last year to protect the elderly against the expense of catastrophic illness. Thousands of older people have protested a surtax that helps finance the program, and the law creating it may be repealed. Now some in Congress question whether Americans are ready to make the sacrifices needed to finance national health insurance.
''The impact of the campaign against the Medicare catastrophic bill has scared a lot of us into feeling that we can't do the things we should do,'' said Senator David Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican who is a member of the health subcommittee of the Finance Committee. Any national health insurance program would require some sacrifices, perhaps restrictions in what services are covered, tax increases or reductions in retirement benefits.
''Nobody seems to want to give up anything for the greater good,'' Senator Durenberger said.
While there is broad support for the basic notion that no American ought to be uninsured, there is strong opposition to achieving that goal through a plan similar to Canada's. The National Association of Manufacturers, in a recent report on the issue, doubted the Government's competence to administer such a plan and said that in any case the change would be ''too radical to be politically feasible.'' And at its annual convention in June, the A.M.A. called on its staff to ''document the deficiencies and problems that characterize Canadian health care.''
Still, Congress, industry and the medical establishment largely agree that the health safety net needs broadening. Representing the Administration's point of view, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, told the panel last week, ''We share your sense of urgency.''
 
GETTING EVERYBODY COVERED
Here are some proposals for national health coverage that exemplify the approaches being considered by a Congressionally mandated panel.
 
The Canadian Example
Proposed by Physicians for a National Health Program, a 2,000-member group based in Cambridge, Mass. The Government would virtually control health care, paying hospitals on a negotiated rate and doctors according to a binding fee schedule. Money now spent on Medicare, Medicaid and state and local health care would finance the plan. In addition, employers and employees would be taxed. Patients could select their own doctors and hospitals without paying additional costs. All doctors would be members of plan, but fee schedules would vary according to the local cost of living. Critics say care would suffer under cumbersome Government control.
 
Encouraging H.M.O.'s
A plan developed by two California researchers would provide minimum health benefits for everyone who is not covered by Medicare, Medicaid or some other public program. Coverage would be purchased through employers or through a public sponsor. The plan would encourage the use of health maintenance organizations by rewarding efficiency, say the authors, Alain Enthoven of Stanford University and Richard Kronick of the University of California, San Diego. The plan, which has gained some support through publication in medical literature, would be financed through new taxes and would not abolish private insurance. It projects savings through more efficient use of medical technology. Many doctors oppose it, saying it would do away with solo practitioners.
 
Minimum Coverage for Al
Proposed by the National Leadership Commission on Health Care, a coalition of 38 corporations, unions and foundations. The commission, whose chairmen are former Presidents Nixon, Carter and Ford, has proposed a plan that would mandate basic health care insurance for everyone, with all employers being required to provide at least minimum coverage. The Government would continue to pay for coverage for the poor and unemployed. Financing for the plan would come from premiums or fees paid by businesses and by employees whose income is more than one and one-half times the poverty level. Some critics say the bare-bones plan is insufficient.
 
Increasing Employer Contributions
A proposal by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, would require employers to provide basic health benefits to employees and their dependents, who would pay 20 percent of medical care costs up to a maximum of $3,000. Coverage would include hospitalization, physician visits, prenatal and baby care, mental health care and diagnostic tests. The 14 million Americans who are uninsured and unemployed would receive similar coverage from the states. Critics of the proposal say that it would create an unfair financial burden for business, which would be required to pay much of the cost.
 
State-Federal Burden Sharing
Backed by organized labor's Committee for National Health Insurance. The Federal Government would mandate basic health care benefits for everyone. The plan would be administered by the states, which could provide added services. The package would include inpatient and outpatient care, drugs, tests, mental health and substance-abuse treatment and long-term care. Payments for services would be made by state agencies. It would be financed through payroll taxes paid by both employers and employees, and by general Federal revenues and private insurance premiums. There would be no free health care, except to children and pregnant women in poor families. Charges would be based on the patient's income. Some say the plan gives too much power to states, leading to possible disparities in care.

HEADLINE: The Education Governors

 BODY:
For only the third time, a President has convened the nation's governors to discuss a single issue. President Bush has the opportunity this week to follow through on his campaign pledge to be the education President.
All 50 governors will gather Wednesday in Charlottesville, Va., for a two-day summit meeting on education. They will be looking to the White House to make this meeting only step one toward higher, measurable national standards of achievement, greater flexibility in the use of Federal funds and more aid for early childhood development. 
Though education is principally a state and local responsibility, the Federal Government plays an important role, particularly in insuring equal educational opportunity. It can also be an effective catalyst.
The 1983 report ''A Nation at Risk'' focused on raising academic standards and teacher competence. Now, with increased global competition and business need for basic skills, governors seek to stress the link between educational improvement and economic survival. The Governors Association is halfway through a five-year reform plan that includes improved curriculums, decentralized decision-making, enhanced roles for teachers, improved facilities and accountability.
Mr. Bush has, thus far, offered little in the way of innovative programs or policies. He says the problem is money. At a time of huge deficits, the White House wants to promote the idea that more can be done with less. Fine. There are at least three initiatives he can sponsor, two that are not very costly and one that is extremely cost-effective.
One is national goals. Educators and policy makers largely agree on the need to define national goals. The goals might include a reduction in the dropout rate and basic information that every high school graduate should know. What's necessary are clear goals that can be measured and for which leaders can be held accountable.
The governors want and deserve more flexibility in using the money. Federal money is tied, often irrationally, into more than 200 programs in various departments.
Repeated evidence shows the importance of intervening early in the lives of disadvantaged children. There are many ways Washington can do so, including with adequate nutrition and health care from before birth to kindergarten.
It's one thing to call a summit meeting on education. It's quite another to follow through with ideas, support and, yes, dollars. Only if this meeting proves to be a gathering of national resolve and not simply a political showcase will Mr. Bush earn the right to be called the education President.

HEADLINE: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Economic Watch article on the high hidden costs of the war on marijuana (Sept. 5) is informative, but like much reporting on the topic, lacks historical perspective. This is most prominent in the discussion of legalization.
''Legal marijuana,'' it is stated, ''could be a major source of tax revenue rather than a $14 billion business for criminals and a billion-dollar cost to the Treasury. But there is little support for such a radical experiment; it is generally agreed that more people would smoke marijuana if it were legal, just as more people began drinking alcohol with the end of Prohibition in 1933.'' 
This paragraph perpetuates the popular misconception that marijuana has been illegal since the beginning of time. Of course, it has not, nor has any drug; indeed, it is the prohibition of marijuana that is, as the prohibition of alcohol was before repeal, an experiment - and to judge from ''Marijuana: Costs of Abuse, Costs of Control,'' the Michael Kleiman report that occasioned your article, and from the collective experience of those charged with enforcing this prohibition, a failed experiment. The same can be said for the criminalization of all recreational drugs.
Also, this paragraph ignores that in recent years, with the public recognition of the health hazards inherent in the consumption of alcohol, and resulting from better public education about these hazards, per capita consumption of all alcohol has declined significantly, with a steeper decline in the category of distilled spirits, which have the highest concentration of alcohol and carry the highest risk. This, despite the constant advertising of these spirits on billboards, in public transportation and in every edition of The New York Times Magazine, among other places.
In other words, an educated market, in the best American tradition, is choosing the safer drug over the more dangerous drug, just as it would were marijuana (and preferably the other recreational drugs as well) legalized, as they were before this failed prohibition began.
The public is beginning to recognize, despite the news media's (and legislators') easy dismissal of the facts, that drug-related crime is really drug-law-related crime, and that our experience with alcohol in the 1920's speaks to our experience with other recreational drugs in the 1980's and 90's. The only way to eliminate drug-law-related crimes is to eliminate the profit of the illicit trade that engenders those crimes.
The police state we are approaching now is no solution (witness the recent bill passed by the Senate that authorizes the Drug Enforcement Agency to shoot down suspected drug smugglers in aircraft, endangering every private pilot who operates near our borders); it is just a greater problem. We need to recognize that economical and sensible solutions exist, and we should concentrate on the best way to implement them, and stop wasting our time on our current futile wars.
 
THOMAS BETZ
 Yonkers, Sept. 5, 1989

HEADLINE: Let Debtor Countries Fill Our Oil Reserves

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With the need to increase strategic long-term storage of oil in our huge salt domes, why wouldn't it be in order to ask Mexico and Venezuela to increase their oil production and ship the excess to us for storage?
Payment could be made by reducing the national debt of the exporting country. There would be no effect on the world price of oil because the oil would, by agreement, be for storage only and not resale. The huge reserves of Mexico and Venezuela would not be so depleted as to impair their resources.
On the contrary, once this debt-oil storage deal is struck, the foreign credit of both those countries would be strengthened immeasurably. There could be a major step in halting the huge local inflation that is impoverishing their wage earners. The United States Government would pay United States banks that are owed billions by these countries and prevent writing off huge loans, which would have an adverse effect on our budgetary income.
We have an increasing import deficit as we incur increased debt to pay for oil from countries that owe us so much. We can accelerate the stocking of United States oil reserves, help the exporting countries and remove from the backs of taxpayers the cost of writing off foreign, nonpaying loans, all without reducing the oil receipts from normal sales by these two countries.
 
JOSEPH D. BLAU
 White Plains, Sept. 2, 1989

HEADLINE: New Kinds of Work and Workers Take Shape

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lester C. Thurow's article on the failure of service industries to be more than a transitional phase between an old and new industrial era makes an admirable case for the economic necessity of manufacturing in our economy (Op-Ed, Sept. 4).
Manufacturing does matter; but it matters in more than economic ways. The production of goods is a complicated form of human activity, in which values and attitudes toward work have always figured large. Historically, values and attitudes about work on the part of American blue-and white-collar workers alike have been important in the acceptance of new technologies and of the new industries in which they are integrated. At the same time, these values constitute standards against which people measure their work experience and the success or failure of these technologies and industries. 
Thus, in addition to the failure of service industries to fill the economic breach, we need to consider the question of the impact that work in the service sector has had on the way Americans think about the work they do, and how changes in their attitudes and expectations about work will affect the reception of any new forms of industrial activity.
For example, many people rushed to embrace the new computerized jobs, drawn by the promise of prestige, of working on the cutting edge, of clean and comfortable offices, rather than factory surroundings, of the greater dignity and respect associated with white-collar work and of a middle-class suburban way of life. Fifteen years later, there is much disappointment and frustration at all levels of industry with service jobs.
The questions to be asked are whether computer-based service jobs that demand little skill and offer low pay have discouraged people from taking the initiative at work, so that they would avoid rather than welcome jobs in any new industry that makes new demands on them. Or has the computer itself come to embody an ideal of effortless work through innovative technology that would draw people to new industries in which the computer is an integral part.
The frustrations of workers are encouraging management and consultants to look for new ways to increase efficiency and productivity in the workplace. Job therapists are employed seeking new ways to motivate work. We might also ask them: How has the vision of service-industry work as clean, pleasant and personally satisfying altered the expectations of people in all ranks of the labor force about quality of life in the workplace?
Or, if we keep in mind the Japanese model, did the experience of work in the service sector help accustom individuals to more hierarchically structured working relationships, in which pride in one's work is not a major source of motivation? Or will this experience encourage workers to find new protection for their jobs in unions? How will workers' disappointments affect their expectations and demands should new opportunities in manufacturing materialize?
Some of the answers are being gathered in innovative community studies combining oral history interviews and archival research. The lives of people in towns and cities where heavy industry and manufacturing once thrived, but are now in decline or defunct, have much to tell us about the changing meaning of work.
In Ohio, in Massachusetts, in Pennsylvania, the shift from manufacturing to service industries has been more or less successful. The longtime residents of Cleveland, of Holyoke, of Pittsburgh can provide us with insights about the complexities of economic change that should prove useful when the next industrial revolution comes along.
 
MIRIAM R. LEVIN
Assistant Professor, History of Technology and Science Program
Case Western Reserve University
 Cleveland, Sept. 4, 1989

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Insisting On Disaster

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
William Bennett, the Bush drug czar, thinks the United States made a mistake when it repealed Prohibition in 1933. We would be better off if it were a crime to buy a drink.
That, at least, is the logic of Mr. Bennett's latest statement on drug policy. It was a response, in The Wall Street Journal, to an open letter from Milton Friedman calling for the decriminalization of drugs. Anyone who wants to know the level of thought behind the Bush-Bennett drug program ought to read it. 
Professor Friedman said that relying on the criminal law to stop drug use - the policy of the last many decades - in fact helped to cause the drug scourge. Illegality created obscene profits, corruption, crime: ''A replay of our experience with the prohibition of alcoholic beverages.''
''The path you propose,'' Mr. Friedman wrote, ''of more police, more jails, use of the military in foreign countries, harsh penalties for drug users and a whole panoply of repressive measures can only make a bad situation worse.'' He added that he was revolted by the idea of ''turning the United States into an armed camp,'' with ''an army of enforcers empowered to invade the liberty of citizens on slight evidence.''
To all this Mr. Bennett gave the back of his hand. Mr. Friedman's argument was ''old and familiar,'' he said. It failed to consider the likelihood that if drugs could be obtained legally, their use would dramatically increase.
''After the repeal of Prohibition,'' Mr. Bennett said, ''consumption of alcohol soared by 350 percent.''
So Mr. Bennett, according to his own logic, must regret repeal. It resulted in an immediate increase in drinking, so it was a bad idea.
But that was not the only result of repeal. It did away with speak-easies and rum-runners, with the whole culture of alcohol crime that had given us Al Capone and a new criminal class in this country.
Of course alcohol abuse remains a serious problem. As Mr. Friedman wrote, ''Alcohol and tobacco cause many more deaths in users than do drugs.'' But we have had some success at dealing with the problem by taxation and regulation. Does anyone think we would have more success by once again criminalizing the use of alcohol?
I do not suppose that Mr. Bennett really wants to bring back Prohibition. He just refuses to open his mind to its compelling lesson. In his reply to Mr. Friedman he passed it off in a phrase, saying the analogy between drug and alcohol prohibition was ''misunderstood by legalization advocates.''
Admitting to ourselves that the law enforcement model has not worked would be no panacea. Willingness to face that reality would be just the beginning of a difficult but at least a sensible path.
The change in policy would have to be made gradually, experimentally, with different ideas in different states. The risks and benefits of such an approach are thoughtfully explored in the Sept. 1 issue of Science magazine by Prof. Ethan Nadelmann of Princeton.
Mr. Bennett did not really argue the issue in his letter to Professor Friedman. He substituted pugilism for argument. Government has to teach right and wrong by the criminal law, he said. Only ''the liberal elites'' disagree. Liberal elites? Those who have spoken out lately for decriminalization include not only Milton Friedman but two eminent conservative British voices, The Economist and The Financial Times. Those conservatives understand that criminalizing drugs creates an enormous economic incentive to distribute them.
The Economist returned to the point in its last issue, coming up with a telling quotation from John D. Rockefeller Jr. He pushed for Prohibition. But after seeing it in action in the 1920's he wrote:
''That a vast array of lawbreakers has been recruited and financed on a colossal scale . . .; that respect for all law has been greatly lessened; that crime has increased to an unprecedented degree - all this I have slowly and reluctantly come to believe.''
It is time for Bill Bennett to open his mind in the same way. He is a student of James Madison, so he knows how crucial it is for public officials to be open to change. And under the bombast he must realize that decriminalizing drugs cannot be honestly dismissed as an ''old'' idea. The trouble is precisely that our leaders have been too spineless to consider it - too afraid of being called ''weak.''
Decriminalization, Professor Nadelmann writes in Science, has been ''dismissed without any attempt to evaluate it openly and objectively. The past 20 years have demonstrated that a drug policy shaped by rhetoric and fear-mongering can only lead to our current disaster.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 25, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1045 words

HEADLINE: Time for Bush to Back Up His Speeches With Action

BYLINE: By Mario M. Cuomo; Mario M. Cuomo, Governor of New York, is completing his second term.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Nearly three-quarters of the way through the first year of the new Administration, extraordinarily little of major significance has been produced in Washington. As a Governor, a citizen and a Democrat, I think we have given an appropriate period of deference to the new Administration. It is time now for a different approach.
At their 1984 Convention in San Francisco, the Democrats said that while President Reagan believed we all lived in one glittering, shining City on a Hill, there was another city where people were struggling. 
For eight years, President Reagan argued that the other city did not exist. And for eight years, the voices of people crying for help went largely unheard. Their conditions grew worse as the resources they needed went, instead, into tax cuts that enriched the already rich and into ever-escalating defense budgets.
Now, our new President has broken with his predecessor: He has conceded the Democrats were right, that there is another city. He has seen it. In speech after speech, he has said that it is a place of broken dreams, disappointed hopes and great pain, and we must help the people there.
But President Bush has done all he can with speeches. Now he has to produce resources that will deliver on his promises or concede to the nation that he is still an unconverted conservative who has simply tried to earn himself some cheap grace by reciting a little Democratic poetry.
It is time for President Bush to decide to use Government - as well as his thousand points of light - to provide the bricks, the stone, the mortar, the resources to build a roadway: a wide and sure and safe roadway -from the other city to the shining City on the Hill.
We must start wth our most serious problem - drugs. President Bush says we are at war. He's right, of course. We've been at war for years. And we are losing. Despite this, he is saying that he can't send any substantial number of troops to the front lines where the lives are being lost, in the cities and suburbs of our nation.
The war, in effect, is to be declared by the President, but financed and waged by the states.
And there's more - much more -than drugs on the national agenda.
We need to declare - and to fund -a national Decade of the Child, a real, targeted, specific commitment to begin a full 10 years of emphasis to fight a disgraceful infant mortality rate, to provide access to adequate health care for every child, to provide child care and Head Start for all of our children who need it, not just one out of five of them.
Recognizing this, when the governors meet with President Bush later this month at the education summit, I will propose that Washington help provide national Liberty Scholarships, like the ones we in New York are so proud of, which guarantee that every child who qualifies for college - no matter how poor - will be afforded the means to achieve a degree from a good college.
Also, we have to do more than decry the terrible spread of AIDS, the contamination of our environment, the deterioration of our roads and bridges, the increase in homelessness. At least, we have to rebuild the Department of Housing and Urban Development and other Federal agencies that have been deliberately dismantled, even corruptly.
If there is doubt about whether we have the resources to meet all these needs, the Administration should forget the new capital gains tax cut. Let's be honest. It would be great for some of us. But long-term, it's just another break for the top of the economic ladder, which that has already done so well, and a loss for everyone else.
Also, it makes a mockery of the tax reform bill that reduced the tax rate on our richest people, partly in return for an increased capital gains rate. Now, President Bush proposes giving the rich people back the price they paid for the lower rate - so they would get both!
There are others who need a break more: the victims of crime, abused children, potential workers desperate for an education and training, millions of sick people without insurance, families struggling to find a home they can afford and to give their children a college education.
There is still more proof that the complaint that the nation cannot afford to meet these needs is disingenuous. After saying we were broke and could find no money for housing or education - or the drug war, President Bush found $166 billion (not million) over 10 years to bail out savings and loan owners and depositors and built a giant new Federal bureaucracy to rival Franklin D. Roosevelt's alphabet agencies.
Where did you get the money, Mr. President? Is it there for banks, but not babies? Do we have $166 billion to fight fiscal problems, but not $16 billion to fight drugs? Do we have $166 billion to protect private treasuries, but not $5 billion to build roads and bridges? Do we have $166 billion to protect investors, but not $20 billion to educate kids and teach them the fundamental values that could save a generation?
In foreign affairs we have adopted a laissez-faire attitude, relying on what we hope will be a benevolent destiny, instead of our own initiatives. We allow arms control negotiations to lag, although agreements could reduce the costs of military preparedness - freeing resources we need to deal with domestic problems.
We have chosen inaction instead of movement as Poland and Hungary struggle toward greater economic and political freedom. And we seem as reluctant to encourage human rights progress in Eastern Europe as we were to denounce China's brutal human rights violations.
Yes, it's been a relatively quiet eight months. But while we were still at rest, our problems were not. They grew. And none of them are being effectively dealt with now by our Federal Government. We're coasting and that's no way to go uphill.
It's time to rouse ourselves from our cordial contentment.
If the Administration cannot, or will not, find the political courage to reinforce democracy abroad, or to make hard judgments about how best to use this nation's wealth at home; if it raises the flag of surrender over the other city, then the Democrats must seize the day - and the flag. Either that, or resign ourselves to the role of unhappy but silent centuries in an army that will not fight.

LENGTH: 1448 words

HEADLINE: On Language;
Drug-War Lingo

BYLINE: BY WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
IN THE >CRACKDOWN on >crack and other drugs, there may be no >magic bullet, but >drug kingpins, narco-terrorists and even >casual users - not to mention >carpers on the sidelines - can expect >zero tolerance.
This is the lingo of drug warfare. The nation is hooked on it (we are all linguistic junkies), and because there is no getting this particular monkey off our backs, let's at least dig up the derivations of the phrases being pushed in the discourse of drug dudgeon.
In the early days, about three generations back, we had >hopheads (''hop'' for >opium) and >dope fiends (''dope'' from the Dutch doop for ''sauce'' or ''dip,'' referring to the sticky opiate). The standard English covering these slang terms is >user, in contrast to >pusher. 
''To the so-called >'casual user' '' was the beginning of a warning by President Bush in March of 1989 to >recreational users, a phrase chosen by some drug users to differentiate themselves from addictive users. >Casual user is not rooted exclusively in the drug culture; the phrase can be found in a 1976 Business Week story about a computer system ''not geared for the casual user''; other early citations also point to popularization by computer whizzes derogating those of us in the nonserious software crowd. Crossover use was natural: Mary Jane Hatcher, the widow of a murdered law officer, said, ''We middle-class suburban Americans, we casual users . . . must accept blame . . . .'' (Curiously, >casual - rooted in the Latin for ''chance'' -has a military sense, first as a clipped form of >casualty, later as a soldier in temporary status on the way to another station. The use of >casual in the 1593 term >casual poor, for those who drift in and out of poverty, has been carried over into >casual labor, used for transient or migratory workers since 1852.) ''American cocaine users need to understand that our nation has >zero tolerance for casual drug use,'' said the President in his Sept. 5 speech outlining what he labeled his ''drug strategy.'' >Zero is from the Arabic >sifr; the first citation for >zero tolerance in the Barnhart Books files is from a 1958 Science Newsletter: ''A good example of the care taken to protect against pesticide poisoning is the minimum tolerance set for milk: zero . . . . Recently, zero tolerance was set for methoxychlor and malathion.'' In the Nixon White House, H. R. (Bob) Haldeman was known for demanding >zero mistakes, and the >zero tolerance phrase was popularized in the drug world by William von Raab, then United States Customs chief, when he sought last year to impound yachts that had even a single marijuana cigarette aboard. Lately, >zero has become an emphatic way to say ''no'': margarine makers promise ''zero cholesterol,'' and economists warn of ''zero growth.'' The word has been booming ever since the atomic age's ''ground zero,'' and one of these days I will zero in on it.
A >narc was long the slang name for a narcotics law enforcement officer, rooted in the Greek >narke, ''numbness, stiffness, stupor,'' but now the first two syllables of ''narcotics'' are frequently found in longer terms. Like >klepto- and >crypto-, >pseudo- and >porno-, >narco- is a combining form, which can now be applied to anything in the illicit drug trade. Nestor K. Ikeda, reporting from Lima for The Associated Press in 1982, attributed the coinage of >narco-terrorism to Fernando Belaunde Terry, at that time Peru's President, who was describing a union of drug dealers and political terrorists. In his Democratic response to President Bush's message, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. lashed out at >narco-terrorism, which had been used on the cover of Newsweek that week. >Kingpin seems to be the only acceptable term for drug bigshots, just as >vice overlord was once the only title journalists permitted for a leader of the prostitution racket. Disagreement rages among etymologists about the metaphoric origin.
One school holds that >kingpin comes from the sport of bowling. In the game of kayles, played with a set of ninepins, the tallest pin was called the >kingpin. In modern bowling, the >kingpin is the pin numbered five and is surrounded by the other pins.
Some dictionaries, even some bowling aficionados, have been using >headpin as a synonym, but this is confusing; the headpin is the pin numbered one, placed at the head of the triangle of pins.
If you are right-handed and hook your ball (thereby causing it to curve slightly to the left), the best place to aim is between the headpin (the No. 1 pin) and the pin to its right facing you (the No. 3 pin); this will allow the bowling ball to crash into the kingpin, directly behind the headpin, perhaps leading to a strike and waking the pin boy if the alley is not automated. (There will be mail on this paragraph from irate expert bowlers, who should be reminded that >bowler was the name for an opium smoker, taken from the bowl of the smoker's pipe. I am not without defenses.) Other lexicographers argue that >kingpin is akin to >kingbolt, which was in use as early as 1825 for the main bolt in a machine. The Oxford English Dictionary holds that this is the sense that led to meanings of ''that which holds together any complex system or arrangement'' and ''the most important or outstanding person in a party, organization, etc.,'' as first used in Harper's Weekly in 1867: ''His best position was as a batter. He was a 'King-pin' there.'' >Crack (originally, the word referred to a noise) is recent. The term for pellet-sized pieces of cocaine prepared for smoking was just becoming popular when the 1986 Slang and Jargon of Drugs and Drink was being printed, and was not included. The author, Richard A. Spears, professor of linguistics at Northwestern University, suggests a clue to the etymology in the entry for >crystal.
''What is now called >crack was known as >crystallized cocaine in the early medical days, and that hard form is still known as >rock. There's no definitive evidence,'' says Professor Spears, ''but it makes sense that >crack comes from the physical cracking of those rocks and crystals - literally, the crackling sound of those rocks as they are broken up.'' >Crackdown, the sudden introduction of severe discipline, is not all that old, either. The noun made its first appearance in a May 18, 1935, Washington Post story about punishment planned for liberals who wanted to abolish public-utility holding companies.
When pledging a crackdown on crack kingpins and narco-terrorists, zero-tolerant drug strategists are careful to refrain from promising a cure-all. ''There is no >magic bullet,'' said William J. Bennett, director of national drug-control policy. (He is called a >czar, and claims he calls his wife the >czarina and his children >czardines.) This was a reference to the German bacteriologist Paul Ehrlich, who was seeking a treatment for the scourge of syphilis and discovered the drug >arsphenamine, better known by its trademark name Salvarsan, or by the number 606, which was its numerical order in a series of experiments.
Dr. Ehrlich, who shared the Nobel Prize in 1908 for his work in immunology, is credited with having first used the term >magic bullet (in German, >Zauberkugel) to mean that ideal therapeutic agent that destroys unhealthy cells while sparing healthy tissues. The phrase was popularized in the United States in the title of the 1940 movie about his life, starring Edward G. Robinson. (A related phrase, >silver bullet, was a talisman thought to ward off werewolves and vampires, and was modified as a kind of trademark by the radio cowboy ''The Lone Ranger.'') Today, a >magic bullet is a cure without side effects, and can be applied to any headaches, from air pollution to the economy. However, the phrase is almost always used in the negative, in cautioning against over-optimism, as in ''This is no magic bullet, but . . . .''
President Bush characterized critics of his program as partisan >carpers who are intent on hiking taxes. That is an old noun now heard infrequently. Robert Browning used it in his 1868 ''The Ring and the Book'': ''>Carpers abound in this misjudging world.''
We are more familiar with the verb >carp, which means ''find fault, complain without reason''; this is from the Old Norse >karpa, ''to boast, brag,'' influenced by the Latin >carpere, ''to pluck, gather,'' which led to the sense of ''to slander'' as one snatches the reputation of another. The have-tux, will-cavil verb is not connected with the freshwater fish of the same name, first reported in the West by the sixth-century Roman statesman Cassiodorus as swimming in the Danube, and best known today for its use in the making of gefilte fish.
