The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Page 43, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3816 words

HEADLINE: TOUGH TIMES FOR MR. LEVITTOWN

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman; Michael T. Kaufman, deputy foreign editor of The Times, was for many years a foreign correspondent for this paper and most recently wrote for its metropolitan section.

 BODY:
THIS IS MOSTLY ABOUT LUCK. SPECIFICALLY IT is about how William J. Levitt, the builder who practically invented the modern suburbs, made his own good luck through a series of astute moves and enjoyed its rewards with gusto for nearly 50 years, and how after conspiring in his own bad luck, he is enduring the turn of fortune with grace in his old age. At 82, he fends off a plague of creditors, but he does not brood as he watches other, younger builders flaunt their wealth as he once did.
Once Levitt raised red Devon cattle and had Renoirs and Monets and Chagalls on his walls. Now his beloved yacht has been sold to an Arabian prince. His imposing mansion on New York's Long Island has gone to pay off back debts. Gone, too, are the Impressionist and Old Master paintings, the indoor tennis court, the large staff of servants, the Rolls-Royces and most of his wife's jewels. Only memory and pride remain. 
When asked about the current legal pressures he faces from the New York State Attorney General's office - the result of a series of soured construction deals that led to the misuse of family foundation funds and claims on unbuilt housing, which will cost him more than $10 million - Levitt becomes politely evasive. Yes, he says, the last decade has been hard, but he is digging his way out of all the problems. The claims against him, he insists, will soon be satisfied, and then something big should be happening.
SINCE HIS TROUBLES BEGAN IN THE 1970's, LEVITT HAS SHIED away from interviews, and though he agreed to talk with me he does not reveal exactly where he is living or working; we meet at the Long Island office of a friend. It occurs to me that he is keeping such details to himself either because his home is too modestly furnished, showing his decline to be greater than he admits, or because it is too lavishly appointed and might arouse the interest of the State Attorney General's office, which has been trying to determine his assets in its efforts to recover deposits paid by New York residents for Florida homes that remain unbuilt. Or, maybe he is simply trying to shield his third wife, Simone, to whom he has been married for 20 years, from intrusive publicity. Whatever, it is his right.
What Levitt prefers to talk about, and what he talks about with relish, is the past. It is clearly so much more pleasant to recall that long string of heady successes, when he built not just houses but entire communities, first on Long Island and then all over the United States. What he did back then, just after World War II, he lets you know, benefited the average person during a severe housing shortage. With those 800-square-feet houses that G.I.'s home from the war could buy for as little as $7,990, no money down and $65 a month, Levitt provided something basic and valuable for thousands of young families in need of shelter.
For the most part, though, his talk stops short of boastfulness. Carefully, Levitt gives credit to others, to his late brother, Alfred, whose designs provided the affordable housing sought by veterans, and to his father, Abraham, a lawyer, who founded the building firm of Levitt & Sons. He says he was lucky in his advisers and his friends, and he modestly claims that he never understood why others did not also build mass-produced communities because, after all, the whole idea was so simple. And yet, punctuating his remarks, he pointedly refers to the accolades he has received.
He notes that in its 50th anniversary issue, in 1983, Esquire magazine cited him among a handful of men and women who made a significant difference in the way American lives are now spent, and that this year The Wall Street Journal did the same as it took a retrospective look at his accomplishments. He is singularly proud that Levittown is mentioned in the Encyclopedia Britannica and that the United States Postal Service has named two post offices after him -Levittown, N.Y., and Levittown, Pa.
WE ARE DRIVING through that first Levittown, the one on Long Island where 17,311 nearly identical homes were built between 1947 and 1951. In the last few years, Levitt says, he comes here every few months just to look at the place. He drives out alone in his small Lincoln with the vanity plates that say ''Sir Wm,'' after an old nickname, but no one recognizes him. Yet in the fall of 1987, on the 40th anniversary of that first Levittown, the whole town turned out to give him a parade.
''I was embarassed, I suppose I even cried. It went on all day,'' he says in a voice that has been raspy ever since cancerous growths were removed from his vocal chords 30 years ago. ''You know,'' he adds as an afterthought, ''the 60,000 people of Levittown are much more my friends than the people of Park Avenue. Oh God, yes, more than most of those I entertained on my yacht.'' He says he learned this only after his troubles began.
As we move through the curved streets, this stocky, ruddy-faced, silver-haired octogenarian walks with the gait of a younger man, setting a steady pace as he explains what was revolutionary about this place. Virtually no housing had been built at all during the war years, and the pent-up demand was enormous. Returning G.I.'s were living in garages, in relatives' living rooms, in cars. Levitt had anticipated the housing shortage, and while he was still in the Seabees, the Navy's construction unit, in the Pacific, he had written to those administering the family building business to buy up as much land as they could from Long Island farmers. Even before the war he had acquired 200 acres from one potato farmer, with an option to buy 200 more each year. The price for the first parcel was $225 an acre, with options calling for increases of 10 percent each year thereafter. The last acreage that was acquired for Levittowns cost $3,500.
Levitt realized that in addition to land, potential buyers would need readily available credit. While the war was still going on, he lobbied Washington to provide mortgage guarantees of the kind eventually offered by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration. Then he turned his attention to the task of building as many houses as possible in the shortest time. Here the firm of Levitt & Sons, which had never built more than 100 houses a year, pioneered as much as Henry Ford did in introducing the assembly line. ''For one thing, we introduced slab construction - building on a concrete slab with embedded radiant heating coils instead of having a cellar,'' says Levitt.
''Even more important,'' he continues, ''was our own assembly-line procedures. One team would lay the slabs, another would do the framing, Another the roofing, and so on. What it amounted to was a reversal of the Detroit assembly line. There, the car moved while the workers stayed at their stations. In the case of our houses, it was the workers who moved, doing the same jobs at different locations. To the best of my knowledge, no one had ever done that before.'' As many as 36 houses were being finished each day, and every one was occupied just as soon as the last workers left.
The selling, one of William Levitts' specialties - ''I wrote the copy for ads'' - was literally being done over the counter. ''People would come and pick the lot and the house color they wanted, and the girls would write up the contracts. I remember one day we closed on 1,100 houses in just five hours.''
We are momentarily lost on a pleasant, tree-shaded street. The man who built the place was trying to get his bearings, but he was more excited than flustered.
''Just look at this, it's incredible,'' he says. ''This is the instant slum that Lewis Mumford predicted.'' Levitt is quite obviously enjoying a last laugh on the social and architectural critic proved wrong, one whose contempt for Levittown as a classless, tasteless center of conformity had hurt its builder years ago.
Mumford was hardly alone in his criticism. For many sociologists and writers, the postwar sprawl of the suburbs was a virulent plague of conformity. To them it seemed ludicrous that people of limited means were invading the green belts that had been the preserves of the settled well-to-do. ''Even while you read this,'' wrote John Keats in ''The Crack in the Picture Window,'' his 1957 critical study of suburban life, ''miles of identical boxes are spreading like gangrene,'' adding that these houses were mistakes certain to corrode all the lives they touched. And when a popular song deplored the monotony of lives lived in ''little boxes made of ticky tacky,'' there was no doubt that the imagery drew from the Levittown idea.
Yet the houses are now different from each other, and it is hard to imagine that they all flowered from virtually identical models. Some have brick facades, some are covered in cedar shingle. Several have been remodeled in (Continued on Page 72) Tudor style. There are a few that show post-modern touches. All are well-maintained, and most have grown wings and ells and upper floors. Some are truly spacious. After some looking, we come upon a few that still resemble the basic Cape Cod model, and Levitt traces the original outline for me.
''The cheapest are now going for $175,000,'' says Levitt, ''and there are quite a number you could not touch for less than $275,000. And look at all the Cadillacs in the driveways.'' Then he points out the shrubs and trees which now shade the community with a green canopy. ''When we started there was nothing growing here that was longer than your thumb, and now look.''
In the first decade of Levittown, Levitt says conformity was the rule, but that was only because the young owners had little time and little money to make changes. ''At first they would finish the upstairs, putting in bedrooms to accommodate their growing families.'' More radical alterations came later. Levitt had always assumed that there would be changes in the look of his houses and that the whole idea had been to stimulate such growth by providing the unfinished and adaptable upper floor, but, he says, no one could have foreseen just how inventive the homeowners would become. ''I am the staunchest admirer of what has been done, and that is an unselfish and impersonal judgment because I had nothing to do with it. They made the alterations; at the most we gave them the opportunity.''
IF LEVITTOWN CHANGED the fortunes of the home buyers, it also changed those of William Levitt. He and his family had been successful builders, mostly on Long Island, before the war. They had purchased the old Vanderbilt estate, on which they built some 300 large homes designed by Alfred Levitt. They also began a shopping center in the same area. During the war, the firm built 750 units of housing in Norfolk, Va., for navy officers and 1,600 more for shipyard workers. When William Levitt came home from his Navy service, he lived in a 12-room apartment on Fifth Avenue. He was rich, (Continued on Page 90) but with the success of Levittown he was to become yet richer, and more powerful.
The profits on the original 17,311 Levittown houses came to about $1,000 each. Other successful projects followed. The Levittown developments in New Jersey and Pennsylvania were even larger than the one on Long Island. In Maryland, the firm acquired the Woodward horse-breeding estate near the town of Bowie and built a line of somewhat more substantial and differentiated houses. Soon after the project was finished, Bowie became the third-largest city in Maryland. Levitt built another community in Bayamon, Puerto Rico. His company also built in Florida, the Chicago suburbs and in Las Vegas. Levitt says he liked to live in New York City but did not want to work there because he knew that, at times, it was impossible to get work certificates there without paying bribes. There were reverses in his personal life. His first two marriages ended in divorce. His father and his brother died. According to family friends, there appears to have been some estrangement between him and his two sons, William and James. Meanwhile, not only his fortune but his influence kept growing. He was president and then chairman of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York. During Israel's Six-Day War, in 1967, he says he called a meeting of 100 prominent Jews and asked each to contribute $1 million anonymously. All of them gave. And he both donated and raised money for North Shore University Hospital where a Levitt Clinic had been established. He counted powerful men, like the late Senator Jacob K. Javits as intimates. He frequently testified in Washington on housing, and he fondly recalls a day when he bucked the construction lobby to support public housing. ''I told those senators that nobody could build any cheaper than I could, but that even I could not build cheaply enough to accommodate poor people and that the Government had to provide subsidized housing.''
Sometime in the late 1960's Levitt began promoting another idea, calling for private industry to initiate the construction of what he calls primary employment towns. ''It was valid then and it's even more valid now,'' he says, explaining that he formed his proposal after he realized the children and grandchildren of the people who had thrived in Levittowns could not now buy comparable shelter. The problem, he says, arose because virtually all accessible land around metropolitan areas has been exploited and the price of whatever may be left has been inflated so high as to make the construction of modestly priced units uneconomical. ''Seventy-five percent of the new housing is being built for the top 25 percent of the market,'' he says.
He points enthusiastically to his original report for private industry to sponsor, in conjunction with Government, the building of complete new cities in remote areas. As he envisions them, these would not be bedroom communities but complete economic entities where people would have a range of work. ''The key is employment,'' he says. ''I think at first they should be planned for populations of 50,000, though of course they would grow to different sizes.'' He has had this idea for many years and in the mid-60's he even considered buying a 30,000-acre tract in Indiana, 200 miles south of Chicago, for such a new city. But he came to realize that only with Government participation could such a scheme succeed.
''Sooner or later it is going to happen. There is no place else to go. People are gregarious and they want to cluster near mama and papa and familiar places, but there we have run out of ground.'' Instead of making ''our big cities bigger, we should be building new cities.'' If the process of metropolitan expansion is not stopped, he adds, ''we cannot hope to create for future generations a decent urban environment where the daily business of living -work, getting to work and leisure - can be simple, easy, pleasant and fun.''
BY THE LATE 1960'S, William Levitt was listed in Forbes magazine as one of the country's wealthiest people. He was building a 30-room mansion on a 68-acre estate in Mill Neck, Long Island, which in its design reflected the split in the way Levitt has tried to live: half the house was designed to be used for public entertaining. It was here that he and his wife, Simone, would hold charity balls and host dinners for as many as 50. The other half of the house was meant for informal family living. He applied the same principle to his yacht, La Belle Simone, named for the Frenchwoman he met in Rome and married in 1969. Mrs. Levitt recently signed on to provide an atmosphere similar to her own yachting parties for four of the Cunard Line's ''Connoisseur'' series of sailings.
The designer John Weitz, an old friend, recalls that in the 60's, Levitt was one of the greatest hosts he has ever known. ''I have been on many boats, but I count my three cruises on La Belle Simone as something incomparable. Bill had such ease and charm. He showed concern for his guests. He could never be accused of the kind of self-involved real-estatery we now have. I have seen him when there were 150 guests on that 240-foot yacht. One of the young Marlboroughs was snapping his fingers to the jazz. Everybody came to Bill.'' Weitz says that he now finds Levitt ''as graceful in adversity as he had been when times were flush.''
Richard M. Wasserman, a real estate investor who has known Levitt for nearly 29 years, many of them working as his right-hand man, says that the man he still regards as his friend and mentor has borne his reversal with characteristic courage and aplomb. ''For Bill, tomorrow is always going to be terrific. It was the same when they diagnosed the cancer and he went for the throat operation. He took it in stride. There was no whining.''
As to what actually led to Levitt's run of losses, Wasserman observed that it happened after Levitt had sold his business to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1968 and started various ventures abroad. ''Bill was always a big-picture man. He did not concern himself too much with details.'' The suggestion, delicately made, was that Levitt had overreached himself.
Levitt himself acknowledges that ambition contributed to the decline, but he claims that what happened to him ''contravened the law of averages,'' in that he heavily backed five losing projects in a row. ''We had nothing but successes from 1929 to about 1972 and then we had one failure after another. You know those sayings, 'Win one, lose one,' and 'You can't lose them all,' well, they turned out to be wrong.''
Under the terms of his agreement with I.T.T. Levitt was barred from building on his own or under his name in the United States for 10 years, but that still left the rest of the world. Using I.T.T. stock as collateral, he raised money for what was to be the first of his new ventures, a housing development in Nigeria. ''I realized pretty soon that it would be impossible to build and I got out.'' The next project was a huge housing development in Teheran. For several years he spent a great deal of time in Teheran overseeing construction. That effort capsized in the upheavals of the Islamic revolution, costing Levitt millions and forcing him to flee from mobs as the Shah was deposed. His next deal, was a project to build a suburban settlement in Venezuela; it was cancelled when dropping oil prices led the Caracas Government to cut back on mortgage guarantees.
Some people who worked with Levitt in the years of prosperity note that many of the close aides who had been able to temper his visionary enthusiasm had, with his blessing, set off on their own. In the old days his dreams had been put through tests by teams of meticulous accountants, architects and surveyors. After his sellout to I.T.T., there were fewer people around to raise questions. But Levitt contends that all of the deals had involved sound planning and that he never suffered a loss of confidence when they soured - ''I have never been depressed.''
IF NOT OBSESSED BY his turn of fortunes, Levitt is fascinated by the streak of ill luck that he traces to when he was persuaded to sell out to I.T.T.
''What happened was that I was approached by Felix Rohatyn of Lazard Freres with a proposal for selling to I.T.T.'' Levitt had known Rohatyn since the financier was a young man. Furthermore, he had known Harold S. Geneen, then head of I.T.T., since Levitt had delivered his advertising copy to him in the 1930's when Geneen was an ad taker for the old New York World Telegram.
''My initial gut feeling was against taking the offer,'' Levitt recalls. ''I remember that I had a meeting with Andre Meyer, the chairman of Lazard Freres, who asked me why did I want to sell. He told me, 'You've got a very fine outfit there.'
''I finally sell myself a bill of goods by saying that the reason I want to do it is that with the vast resources of I.T.T. we will then bring whatever know-how we have all over the world. Instead of doing $200- or $300- or $400-million worth of business a year, we'll do $2 billion, $3 billion, $4 billion, and everybody will benefit. I would be providing houses for working people everywhere.
''Looking back, I may have had delusions of some sort of grandeur about my place in history, except that my place in history seems rather assured since I suppose once you make the Encyclopedia Britannica, there's a permanent record.''
As a result of the sale, Levitt got $90 million in stock. He was 62 years old and he could have retired rich and comfortable. But he says, ''I couldn't retire, I wouldn't know what to do with myself.''
When the price of the I.T.T. stock he was using as collateral dropped, he was left owing more than he could pay. According to legal documents filed by the New York State Attorney General's office, Levitt began dipping into the funds of a family foundation to cover the shortfall. Eventually, as a result of action brought by the State, the foundation board was replaced and Levitt was obliged to repay the $5 million he had taken from the trust. That, apparently, was where much of the proceeds went from the sale of the yacht and of La Colline, the estate now facing subdivision and development by its new owner.
Another portion has gone to pay back people who put down deposits of $500 or more on homes that Levitt had advertised he was building in two projects on Florida's west coast. Some were built, but according to Elizabeth Bradford of the New York State Attorney General's office, 2,500 people had paid deposits and not received homes. Moreover, she says, instead of placing the money in escrow accounts, as his ads had promised, Levitt used the money for business and personal expenses. She says that as a result of a court order, about half of these people had been repaid in full; the remaining 1,200 will shortly be reimbursed for most of their deposits. The Attorney General's office has been awarded a claim on whatever money Levitt may win in a pending lawsuit against a Florida bank involved in selling land he owned at a price he alleges was well below its market value. Beyond that, Ms. Bradford says, Levitt appears to have no significant assets.
In the papers she has filed in the case, Ms. Bradford has regularly noted that the man she is dunning for funds has a great reputation for providing homes for so many ordinary people. But in her office in Mineola, not far from that original Levittown, she notes that the people for whom she is acting to recover the deposits are exactly the same kind of ordinary, hard working people, but in this case, ill-served.
Levitt refuses to discuss these cases in detail. He says simply that they will all be settled. Soon to turn 83, he is looking beyond the troubles of the past.
''You know,'' he tells me, ''I've got some plans for something in the Orlando area. I can't talk about it just yet but it could be very big.''

HEADLINE: A Tune-Up For The Market

BYLINE: By Robert Heilbroner; Robert Heilbroner is the Norman Thomas Professor of Economics at the New School. His latest book, written with Peter Bernstein, is ''The Debt and the Deficit: False Alarms/Real Possibilities.''

 BODY:
THE ECONOMIC MOOD IS CHANGING. We see it in the public reaction to the Exxon Valdez oil spill and the company's initial skirt-lifting response. We find it again in the public and Congressional outrage over the sleaze in the savings and loan industry and the Pentagon scandals, not to mention Wall Street, where Masters of the Universe pull down eight-figure incomes while giving us a meaner and nastier business environment.
It is tempting to characterize all this as just a swing in the cycle of sentiment, a reversion from a pro-business period in which Lee Iacocca was the second most-admired man in the country, back to an old populist tradition in which businessmen were depicted with dollar signs on their vests and venture capitalists were called robber barons. But I see something much more important happening today; namely, a growing dissatisfaction with that tutelary deity of capitalism, the Market. By the Market, with a capital M, I do not mean the stock market, although what I shall have to say applies there with a vengeance. I mean, rather, that great, impersonal mechanism of unhindered supply and demand that we trustingly rely on to yield the best possible outcome for the nation. Unless my eyes and ears deceive, there is today a growing awareness that the Market gives a wide range of results, depending on circumstances. Sometimes its dispensations are very much in the public interest. Sometimes they are not. 
Consider, for example, the current disquiet about the stock market. Much of it clearly reflects a change in the public image of financiers. Twenty years ago, the words ''Wall Street'' conjured up Robert Lehman of Lehman Brothers, or Douglas Dillon of Dillon, Read, the very models of rectitude. Today, mention of Wall Street evokes the names of Ivan Boesky, the inside trader, and Michael Mil-ken, the junk-bond king. From this vantage point, our unease about the Street looks like another sign of our dismay at the decline in business values.
Yet there is another way of looking at the problem. The function of a stock market in a capitalist economy is to serve as a great conduit to direct savings into investment, a purpose it seemed to fulfill very well over much of the last century. But that is not the result that first strikes the eye in recent years. Wall Street has become a kind of casino where corporation shares are poker chips in an immense game of winner take all. Moreover, the game is played in such a way that the winner typically gets up from the table loaded down with i.o.u.'s.
Viewed this way, our concern has little to do with individual misbehavior. It has to do with hostile takeovers, leveraged buyouts and other such institutional convulsions. And it is no longer business ethics that lie at the center of our unease, but the suspicion that the stock market is working not to siphon savings into investment, but to restructure American business in ways we do not like.
Let me take a second case. Last winter, a truculent Frank Lorenzo, whose Texas Air had acquired Eastern Air Lines, was a staple of the front page and the television evening news as he battled with Eastern's unions over proposed pay cuts. Lorenzo's image in this contest was about as far from that of Lee Iacocca as one could get - on the face of it, another example of business misbehavior.
But once again there is another side to the story, reminiscent of the rise of the great trusts in the late 19th century. That was the period when competition became cannibalistic in industries with heavy fixed investments, such as steel, oil refining and railroads. Under the terrific pressure generated by their need to meet the costs of their fixed capital, companies swallowed one another in the hope of eventually achieving a monopolistic position. To avoid that outcome, Congress began to ''regulate'' the workings of the Market in industries susceptible to cannibalism, first the railroads in 1887, eventually the airlines in 1938.
From this perspective, the Eastern Air Lines struggle is exactly what we should have expected. The airlines were deregulated in 1978 to enable competition to shake up a complacent industry. What deregulation brought was a replay of the railroad and steel and oil refinery wars, as competition pushed Pan Am and Braniff, American and United and Delta, into 19th-century-style combat - with 19th-century outcomes. Lacking Government regulation, cutthroat competition over fares and routes led to the strong devouring the weak.
Consider the Exxon Valdez disaster and, since then, the oil spills in the Delaware River and Narragansett Bay. Of course there is reason to criticize the behavior of the oil companies. But it is the Market that drives Exxon and its competitors to ship oil in very large tankers. This is good for consumers, who want the cheapest possible gasoline. But as we have now learned many times, and will no doubt have to learn many more times, it is not good for people who live along the shoreline near oil tanker shipping lanes, or who earn their living from the sea. Thus the Market serves some interests well, but others very badly. BECAUSE WE LIVE AT A TIME when history is tilting so dramatically in favor of market economies over planned economies - witness the Soviet Union and the Eastern European nations - it seems near blasphemy to suggest that free markets do not always bring about the best of all possible worlds, and that regulation, which is after all a form of planning, may sometimes make markets work better.
At the risk of appearing blasphemous, then, let me suggest a few principles about the way markets work. 1. Markets are driven by the self-interest of each participant and policed by competition, buyers and sellers vying with each other. This is obviously not the way of planning, which listens to the voice of government. That is not to say, however, that markets have nothing in common with planning. 2. In fact, both are instruments of social policy. More specifically, they represent ways of coordinating the activities of production and distribution that we call the economy. Each way has its advantages and disadvantages. These days we tend to stress the advantages of the Market, but there are things to be said for planning. We use planning to achieve massive economic rearrangements in a hurry; we wage war by planning; an underdeveloped nation uses planning to get off dead center. 3. Because the Market is a social instrument, it cannot be completely ''free.'' All markets rest on law, which establishes boundaries and restrictions and Do Not Enter signs. The market system is not a license to do with property whatever its owner wishes, nor to go after business in any way that may succeed. The only industry that knows no bounds or rules is the illicit drug trade, where the market process resembles what Thomas Hobbes called the ''Warre of Each Against.'' He described life under those conditions as ''Nasty, Brutish and Short.'' 4. Because markets, unlike plans, are blinkered to follow the arrow of economic advantage, some say their workings should only be judged by that criterion. ''Don't bother me with your corporate restructuring lectures,'' says the market enthusiast. ''The question is, does it pay?'' Ditto on airline competition and tanker transport. I do not raise this criterion to scoff at it. Profitability is the way the Market rewards efficiency, and efficiency makes it possible to avoid much of the bureaucratic sclerosis that has been the fatal illness of planning. 5. But efficiency isn't everything. As economists never weary of telling us, the Market is a marvelous means of coordinating economic activity, but as they tell us less frequently, its triumphs are sometimes bought at the price of social carelessness or even destructiveness. Carelessness (Continued on Page 76) because the Market has a keen ear for private wants, but a deaf ear for public needs; the occasional destructiveness because the Market has no way of judging the consequences of its deafness. Thus the Market gives us magnificent metropolises in which the air cannot be breathed, a menu of television entertainments that caters to the lowest common denominator of our culture, distributions of income from occupation to occupation, as well as from top to bottom, that violate our sense of decency. W HAT TO DO? THE ANSWER, of course, is to plan. I do not mean to abandon self-interest and competition as our economic mainsprings. I do not mean to create a central agency authorized to impose its goals on all branches of the economy. What I do mean is that we should modify the markets' boundaries, restrictions and Do Not Enter signs.
There are many ways of doing this. One of them is by direct government intervention. If oil spills prove one day to be too destructive to the environment, we can outlaw vessels of dangerously large capacity or inadequate design. Whatever we do about oil, it is certain that the fragility of the environment will require direct intervention on many fronts. President Bush's recent proposals for tightening the emissions standards on automobiles are one example.
Is this planning? Of course it is, although one will never read that word on our President's lips. Changing emissions standards impose a political decision on the range of permissible private economic activity. But it is not an infringement on the Market. It does not take away the profit motive or the disciplinary force of competition. It simply redraws the rules within which the Market operates in one particular area, in order to give us transportation but not smog.
Intervention of this direct kind is by no means the only approach. In the case of the stock market, the most likely means of closing down the casino is by revising the tax laws that permit the winner's i.o.u.'s to become the basis for large tax deductions. For takeover artists, that would change the calculus of profitability, discouraging merger mania without altering the essential workings of the stock market itself.
Redesigning the Market to improve its social performance does not only imply a tightening of its boundaries and constraints. Some of the things the Market has given us seem likely to require a loosening of existing rules. Consider the inhibitions under which banking operates. American banks are not to be found among the world's top 10 because our laws forbid nationwide banking establishments. As long as our banks are hobbled by outdated regulations, American finance will be hard put to compete effectively on the world market.
The same kind of reasoning can be applied to the relative performance of the United States economy and that of its two great rivals, Japan and the European Economic Community. By general consent, we are falling behind.
One reason for this sorry performance is that American companies cannot pool their expertise, or their collective strategies, as effectively as their Japanese and European counterparts, largely because of antitrust laws. There was a time when I was in favor of antitrust laws, period. They prevented some of the potential excesses of the Market. I now favor antitrust laws, comma. Some of them clearly need rethinking in the light of the new realities of global competition.
IF I READ THE AMERICAN mood correctly, this is what the present anti-business sentiment is actually about. We are not content with what our market economy is giving us. Some of that unhappiness reflects ill-thought-out, wasteful government programs. But most of the public's discontents seem to be focused on the private sector.
The remedy is not to abandon the Market, with a capital M. It is to seek changes in the structure of many markets with small m's. Such changes, ideally, will assert the essential function of planning - to guide the economy where we want it to go, while still retaining self-interest as the motor of the Market, and competition as its taskmaster.

HEADLINE: The Dutch Find New Treats In America

BYLINE: By Peter Applebome; Peter Applebome is Atlanta bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
Atlanta-based architect who introduced the atrium to the modern hotel. Portman is developing a 100-acre complex of office towers, hotels and shops 18 miles from the hurly-burly of downtown Atlanta and hoped to whet the Dutch investor's appetite.
Escorted through the wooded site as a visiting sultan, Fentener van Vlissingen clucked approvingly while trading real estate shoptalk with his hosts. After sitting through a reverent marketing presentation - ''Our aspiration is to bring the flair of the great European cities to suburban America . . . '' - he took his leave to go to the airport. So far, no deal has materialized.
The next stop on his agenda was Tulsa, Okla., to attend a board meeting of the Memorex-Telex Corporation, in which Noro is a major investor. Then, after a detour to Bermuda to celebrate his 50th birthday, and a layover in Curacao, the Netherlands Antilles, where Noro Group is incorporated, Fentener van Vlissingen headed back to the Netherlands, leaving Noro-U.S. in the care of his American deputies. 
The peregrinations of Fentener van Vlissingen reflect an intriguing, little-noticed aspect of the growing torrent of direct foreign investment in the United States, which last year totaled $329 billion. For the better part of this decade, Dutch investors had been second only to the British in their ownership of American business concerns and real estate. But last year, Japanese investors elbowed the Dutch into third place in the Commerce Department's ranking.
LMOST FROM THEIR BEGINNINGS 400 years ago as a tiny nation partly reclaimed from the sea, the Dutch have been traders, by aptitude and by necessity. In a characteristically prudent bargain struck in 1626, Peter Minuit, director general of the Dutch West India Company, bought Manhattan from its native Indians for trinkets worth $24. Thirty-eight years later, the Dutch were forced to surrender the island to the British.
''I think the Dutch have been trying to buy Manhattan back piece by piece,'' says Vincent J. Everts, a 30-year-old Netherlander who runs Atlanta-based CYCO International, the distribution arm of a Dutch software company.
The pattern of Dutch investment in the United States - which last year stood at $49 billion -evolved over three centuries from initial purchases of agricultural land. The Dutch moved into American petroleum operations and light manufacturing in the early 1900's and then, after World War II, into mining, chemicals, food and banking. During the surge of foreign investment starting in the mid-1970's, the Dutch emphasis tilted toward retailing, insurance and real estate.
''Do you realize what a wealthy country Holland is?'' asks Herman A. Vonhof, president of Atlanta-based Grand Cypress Resort Inc., a real estate development arm of P.G.G.M., the $16 billion pension fund for health care workers in the Netherlands. ''The Dutch pension funds alone have $150 billion in total assets. We have only 15 million people. We have to invest it somewhere.''
Grand Cypress has built a 1,500-acre resort in Orlando, Fla. Nine years ago, Vonhof started buying land near Disney World at what he describes as ''a very attractive price.''
According to the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in the United States, some 750 Dutch-owned businesses are operating in this country. They include such giants as Philips, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and the Anglo-Dutch consortia, Royal Dutch/ Shell Group and Unilever. KLM recently invested $400 million for a 10 percent stake in a leveraged buyout of NWA, the holding company for Northwest Airlines. Unilever has been on a buying binge in the field of personal products, witness its $3.1 billion takeover of Chesebrough-Pond's and its $1.5 billion purchase of Faberge, parent of Elizabeth Arden.
Apart from such visible presences, 61 percent of the Dutch companies have revenues of less than $250 million, and their characteristic style of doing business is to adopt a low profile.
The penchant for anonymity, bolstered by a compulsion to escape onerous tax burdens at home, has long shaped the form of Dutch overseas investment. Prior to the recent wave of tax reforms in the United States, Dutch investors were able to repatriate earnings from their American properties practically intact by taking advantage of separate tax treaties the United States had with the Netherlands and the Netherlands Antilles.
The former Dutch colony in the Caribbean, now federated with the mother country as an independent member of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, has been a tax haven for flight capital from all over the world. No reliable figures exist as to the national origins of the funds deposited there, but the Dutch Government has granted special tax privileges to dividends distributed by Antillean corporations to Netherlands-based holding companies.
Although more than two-thirds of the Dutch-owned companies have their United States headquarters on the East Coast, the last two decades have seen a migration to the Sunbelt: 27 percent have operations in California, Texas and Florida. In the 1980's, the single most popular site for Dutch corporate bases has been Georgia. The availability of a nonunion labor force has been one attraction. Another is the growing importance of Atlanta as a financial hub of the Southeast with its own international airport. KLM's inauguration of direct service between Amsterdam and Atlanta in March 1981 provided a crucial spur for Dutch investors in the region.
''When I looked at developments in the financial and service industries in the Northeast and in Los Angeles, I saw nothing comparable in the South,'' says Fentener van Vlissingen, his fluent English overlaid with the rounded vowels of a Dutch inflection. ''Seeing how the area of the Southeast was growing, the obvious place to be was Atlanta.''
Among the 85 Dutch companies now operating in Atlanta are Algemene Bank Nederland, the largest Dutch bank, and Nationale-Nederlanden, the No. 1 insurance company in the Netherlands, which owns Georgia U. S. Corporation, a $3 billion insurance and financial services company.
The biggest splash the Dutch have made in Atlanta is the $285 million project called 191 Peachtree, a 52-story tower designed by John Burgee and Philip Johnson. The project, which is being developed by the Dutch Institutional Holding Company, another arm of the pension fund for health care workers, is the first office tower to be built in downtown Atlanta in almost a decade.
''We had a lot of people say, 'My God, what are you doing, Atlanta's overbuilt,' '' says Onno Breur, the holding company's vice president for corporate development. ''But if you analyzed the submarkets, there was a very good opportunity. We're cautious, but we're fairly entrepreneurial.''
CALVINIST TRADITION AND A PUNI-tive tax system have made the Dutch inordinately private and modest about their personal finances. The billionaire Fentener van Vlissingen family is less than overjoyed to hear themselves referred to as the Rockefellers of the Netherlands, however apt the comparison may be.
Their fortune derives from SHV Holdings, a Utrecht-based energy and wholesale consumer goods behemoth with 1988 assets of $3.6 billion. It is the second largest private company in the Netherlands.
The family business, trading coal from German mines, originated in Amsterdam in the 18th century and was later fortified by marriage with the van Beuningens, coal traders from Rotterdam.
After World War I, Frederik H. Fentener van Vlissingen, grandfather of John, poured some of SHV's profits from coal into a consortium that helped finance such major industrial projects as the AKZO chemical company, the Fokker aircraft company and KLM.
SHV moved into oil after World War II. Pursuing a strategy of acquiring substantial interests in public companies to be able to tap the equity markets for expansion capital, SHV currently controls Calor, Britain's largest liquid petroleum gas retailer, and Primagaz, the largest L.P.G. company in France.
In the United States, SHV has interests in energy and scrap metal; branches of its Makro chain of warehouse-club supermarkets are operated jointly with K Mart.
Despite its size, SHV is still very much a family enterprise. Paul Fentener van Vlissingen, 48, is president. His two brothers, Frederik, 56, head of Flint Holding, an Amsterdam investment firm, and John, Noro's chairman, are directors. They meet monthly with Paul to plot SHV's course.
''I always had the vision of starting a business, because it's something our family has always done,'' says John Fentener van Vlissingen. ''Maybe it's something that tickles us.'' Rather than simply cast his lot with SHV, he built his own company, Noro, from a base in the United States. But according to family tradition, he first had to prove himself by working for outsiders. After finishing his studies in business administration at the London School of Economics in 1959, he trained at several European investment banks and at Brown Brothers, Harriman in New York, then joined Pierson, Heldring & Pierson, a Dutch merchant bank.
On travels throughout the United States for Pierson starting in 1973, Fentener van Vlissingen spotted what he thought were exceptional values in depressed real estate, particularly in the South. In 1975, when Atlanta was in the midst of its worst business downturn in decades, he tapped 12 Dutch friends to raise $1.2 million to buy the National Data Building, an 81,000-square-foot office building in the heart of the city's commercial corridor. The purchase price was $3.6 million; Noro now values the building at $7.2 million. Thus was born Noro-Sunbelt N.V., a closed-end real estate fund chartered in Curacao, the linchpin of what has become a galaxy of dozens of investment partnerships of Dutch and other European individuals and institutions.
During the next five years, while continuing at Pierson, Heldring as director of its securities and investments division, Fentener van Vlissingen made other real estate acquisitions for Noro in Georgia, Florida, Alabama, South Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, Texas and California.
In 1979, Noro entered into discussions with the Rockefeller family about buying the Celanese and the Time-Life buildings in Manhattan. But Fentener van Vlissingen was unable to raise enough money. ''If we could have afforded it, we would have done it,'' he says. ''It was a very exciting time to get into that market.'' The Celanese building went to another Dutch investor, the Shell Pension Fund. SEATED AT A MAHOGANY conference table in the Atlanta offices of Noro-U.S. one afternoon last winter, Fentener van Vlissingen described the cautious approach that has made him and many other Dutch investors successful in the United States. ''We're not going into areas we would not be familiar with,'' he said, a picture of propriety in a black pinstriped suit, muted crimson-striped shirt and gold watch with two square faces set six hours apart. ''Everything is related to real estate and to the service industry,'' he said.
In 1980, Fentener van Vlissingen left Pierson, Heldring to devote himself wholly to Noro. He opened an office in Atlanta with a staff of six Americans and, while intensifying his commitment to real estate in the Southeast, extended his reach to North Carolina, New Mexico and Colorado. During the last nine years, Noro's United States real estate portfolio has grown to more than $1 billion worth of properties in 12 states, mostly warehouses, office buildings and shopping centers.
Aware of the cyclical swings of the energy business, Fentener van Vlissingen has been leery of being overcommitted in areas dependent on that sector of the economy. Long-term leases on the three Dallas properties in its portfolio gave Noro some protection from the real estate debacle in Texas precipitated by the collapse of oil prices in the mid-80's.
''We didn't see it coming, but the moment we saw it, we went out,'' he says. ''We had a building in Houston. Out. A building in downtown Denver. Out. We've always been good at cutting our losses.'' When the Atlanta market showed signs of cooling down a few years ago, Noro began cashing in on some of its properties. In 1988, Fentener van Vlissingen picked up a bargain in a Fort Worth office building, but he is wary of getting back into Texas too early.
In the last two years, he has sighted opportunity in the District of Columbia. ''I like Washington,'' he says, ''because the limits placed on the height of buildings means there won't be overbuilding, and so competition is limited, too.'' Philadelphia also strikes him as reasonably priced.
The most successful real estate investments for Noro in the United States thus far have been shopping centers and strip malls in suburban locales. But, prodded by its institutional clients, Noro has moved from middle-sized office buildings to larger and larger projects such as the renovation of the Warner Theater Building in Washington and the Wilshire Palisades office building in Santa Monica, Calif. Noro's biggest project to date is a mixed-use development of 450 acres adjacent to Hartsfield International Airport, a joint venture with the Webb Company of Lexington, Ky.
Following a practice typical of other Dutch overseas investors, Fentener van Vlissingen develops close relationships with American partners of proven accomplishment such as Trammell Crow, the wide-ranging Texan with whom Noro developed the Galleria complex in suburban north Atlanta. The Dutch entrepreneur is not concerned with having his name on the buildings. His emphasis is on money, not monuments.
With wealth accumulated over generations, Dutch investment tradition calls for a long-term perspective and conservative financing. Noro real estate funds are structured for 12 to 15 years; properties tend to be only 40 to 50 percent leveraged.
Last year, Noro acquired Park 'n Fly, the largest operator of privately owned parking lots adjacent to air-ports in the United States. ''You're getting a good return on the land you've bought,'' says Fentener van Vlissingen. ''And generally, land near an airport increases in value. So you've got the best of all worlds.'' Waxing enthusiastic about the deal, which represents a new strategy to buy and operate companies rather than simply taking investment positions, he says, ''We plan to double our locations in three years.''
From a real estate core, Noro's activities fanned out to such related financial services as mortgage brokerage, banking and venture capital. In 1986, with disaster looming over the thrift industry, Noro bought the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Atlanta, which remains moderately profitable. Now Fentener van Vlissingen is on the lookout for good buys in other Georgia savings institutions.
Ten years ago, he set up his first venture capital fund for investing in the United States. Currently, Noro has $150 million invested through five specialized funds covering a range of industries from high technology to insurance, retailing and TV and radio stations. Their American managers are given a free rein. ''John likes to pick people he wants to be in business with and then lets them go about their business,'' says Charles D. Moseley Jr., an Atlanta venture capitalist who (Continued on Page 54) manages the two funds that are open to American as well as European investors.
''Where are the borders between risk and nonrisk?'' Fentener van Vlissingen muses. ''We are open for calculated risk, but not unlimited risk. You will not find many major failures among Dutch investors in this country. That is not how they operate.'' S TILL, EVEN THE DUTCH don't bat a thousand. In 1987, Fentener van Vlissingen acquired World Travel Advisors, now the nation's 13th-largest travel agency, with offices in Atlanta, Orlando and Washington.
At a meeting in February, Fentener van Vlissingen listened to World Travel executives describe a plan to expand their client base by entering the travel-club business.
One month later, the program of discounted package tours christened ''Grand Style Vacations'' racked up a whopping loss in the test marketing stage. The wholesale packager had booked the tours on Eastern Air Lines. When a strike was called on March 4, World Travel had nothing to sell. Says Gary E. Coton, president of World Travel Advisors, ''We spent $1.6 million to learn a good lesson.'' The agency has been reviving the idea with another partner.
Six weeks ago, Fentener van Vlissingen returned to the United States for a marathon monthlong tour that saw him crisscrossing the country, with a side excursion to Toronto.
On a steamy August afternoon, he sat in the air-conditioned comfort of the conference room at Noro-U.S., nursing a Coke and chatting with Michael R. Raffety, head of Noro's American real estate ventures, and with H. James Griggs, chairman of F.I.A. Associates of Sacramento. Griggs's firm manages $2.1 billion in public pension funds. Noro is participating in a loan for an office building in Baltimore, which is backed by an F.I.A. client.
Griggs is interested in branching into European ventures. Noro is considering expanding to invest for Americans in Europe. The talk turned into an amiable dance, half attuned to issues of international trade, half to specific Noro projects.
In 1984, sensing that Europe was on the verge of an economic resurgence, Fentener van Vlissingen began investing intensively in real estate, principally commercial buildings in London and Glasgow, residential projects in Belgium and resort properties in France and Spain. He also started several funds that take substantive positions in companies listed on European stock exchanges, principally the Amsterdam bourse.
''We've almost completed a deal that would give us control of 5 to 7 percent of the trading on the Amsterdam exchange,'' Fentener van Vlissingen announced.
''That might make some people nervous,'' said Griggs genially.
''I don't want to make people nervous,'' his Dutch host replied in a matter-of-fact tone. ''Why should I?''
Why indeed? The Dutch can be notoriously tough bargainers, but the sheer predatory zeal of American deal making of the 80's is not their style. Fentener van Vlissingen is convinced that the leveraged buyout craze is about to hit Europe, and he expects to be a major player. But he thinks it will be a more prudent, less leveraged game than the one played in the United States.
''I don't want to buy companies, finance them for 89 percent and sack a lot of people or sell off all the parts,'' he says. ''It's not that I'm a sweet guy. A sweet guy will not survive in business. If we go in for leveraged buyouts, it would be based on a far stronger partnership and a far stronger financial structure.''
Similarly, though he handles investments for some 700 individuals and 60 institutions - he allows that a ''substantial'' amount of the assets under management belong to him and his relatives - Fentener van Vlissingen still insists on interviewing every prospective client.
''I want to make certain an investor thinks along the same lines I do,'' he says. ''If I get a feeling someone is a short-term investor who wants out after one year, or is highly leveraged, we don't want him.''
Fentener van Vlissingen spends half his time traveling to oversee his holdings; he visits Atlanta three or four times a year. Despite his Dutch reserve, he fits well into Atlanta, where he keeps a condominium furnished with fine Dutch porcelains and paintings. His Swiss wife, the former Countess Marine Michelle de Pourtales, often accompanies him on his American trips. The brass dedication plaque in the lobby of Noro headquarters bears the names of their children: Nicole, 25; Robert, 23, a former student at Emory University in Atlanta, and Brigitte, 21.
In 1985 Noro sponsored a major exhibition of Dutch painting at the High Museum of Art. It's all part of the higher profile Fentener van Vlissingen realizes might be advantageous for someone who wants to attract American investors to his funds.
''In America, to show one is a success is very important,'' he says. ''In Holland, it's the last thing people want to do.''
Recently, Fentener van Vlissingen has been scouting in Asia. He has opened a Noro office in Singapore and is planning several real estate and venture capital funds for Japan, Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and Hong Kong.
But the United States remains the single largest investment area for Noro, representing half of its total assets. Of concern, though, are changes in the United States tax codes that, together with the abrogation of the favorable treaty with the Netherlands Antilles in 1987, have whittled away many of the advantages for Dutch investors. And the Treasury Department is looking to tighten up the treaty with the Netherlands.
There has been some speculation that the changes may inhibit future Dutch investment in the United States. Speaking for Noro, Fentener van Vlissingen says he does not expect a dramatic shift other than that caused by more attractive opportunities elsewhere in the world. ''Everyone in Europe with a certain amount of wealth,'' he says, making clear he is talking about millions, ''should have part of it invested in America. It's by far the largest free enterprise country in the world.''
The question for him, he says, ''is how do I structure it in the most tax- efficient way? If they take away Curacao, then I do something else. Start an Inc. - a corporation. Or start whatever. It's not something that bothers me much.''
Over the centuries, the Dutch have learned to adapt. Says Fentener van Vlissingen, ''If the treaty gets changed, we change with the treaty.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 64, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 3718 words

HEADLINE: Everybody Loves Solar Energy, But...

BYLINE: By Michael J. Weiss; Michael J. Weiss, a writer based in Washington, is the author of ''The Clustering of America.''

 BODY:
ON A SUMMER MORNING, just before dawn, the sky turns a coppery gold above the Mojave Desert, a 15,000-square-mile expanse of sand and sagebrush in southern California. In the handful of communities clinging to the two-lane highways crisscrossing the desert, nothing breaks the quiet except for the occasional trucker pulling over at a dusty drive-in.
But at Kramer Junction, 150 miles from Los Angeles, the landscape awakens abruptly. As the first rays of light stretch across the arid plain, 600,000 curved glass mirrors flip over to face the sun. Within moments, the synthetic oil flowing through tubes suspended over the shimmering mirrors reaches 735 degrees Fahrenheit, the heat transforms water to steam and generators are producing 194 megawatts of electricity for Southern California (SoCal) Edison - enough power to serve 270,000 residential customers. So begins another day for Luz International Ltd., whose solar fields generate an estimated 90 percent of the world's solar power.
Luz (rhymes with ''fuse'') has built seven solar electric-generating systems, known as SEGS. While Luz's plants generate only 1 percent of SoCal Edison's power, they provide that electricity when it is most needed: during the hottest part of the day, when air-conditioning demand reaches its peak. 
Since its first SEGS went on line in 1984, Luz's cost for producing a kilowatt hour of electricity has dropped from 24 cents to 12 cents - less than the cost of energy from the newest nuclear plants now in operation. Last April, the company broke ground on a $1.2 billion expansion that is expected to triple Luz's electricity output while dropping the cost to about 8 cents per kilowatt hour, nearly competitive with conventional coal- and oil-fueled plants.
More than a decade after the Arab oil embargo convinced Americans of the need for alternative sources of energy, cost-competitive solar power is finally reaching the marketplace. And not a moment too soon. Acid rain, global warming and this year's plague of oil spills emphasize the dangers of relying on coal- and oil-fueled power plants. In the South Coast Basin, which includes Los Angeles, the ground-level cloud of ozone has become so hazardous that state officials have passed a plan to restrict everything from chemical factories to gas-powered lawn mowers to charcoal lighter fluid.
Yet a cloud also hangs over the future of Luz. The growth of the company -which had revenues of $153 million last year, mostly from the construction and sale of solar plants - has been made possible in large part by an array of Federal and state tax incentives and favorable government regulations. Now the last of the tax breaks is scheduled to run out in December. Given the current, relatively low prices of oil and natural gas, which together in 1988 generated 44 percent of California's electricity, it remains to be seen whether utilities and investors will continue to smile upon Luz.
In 1977, announcing his determination to break the nation's dependence on imported oil, President Carter called for a 20 percent reliance on renewable energy resources by the year 2000. He called it ''the moral equivalent of war.'' His Administration initiated a 40 percent residential energy conservation tax credit and a 15 percent commercial tax credit for renewable energy projects. In a symbolic gesture, Carter even installed solar hot-water panels atop the White House.
The following year, Congress passed the landmark Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act (PURPA), which required utilities to provide a market for qualifying independent producers of electricity. The measure dictated that utilities must buy energy from these producers at a reasonable rate based on ''avoided costs'' - the amount of money the utility would otherwise pay to increase production using fuels such as natural gas or oil and building traditional plants. Independent solar producers were to be exempt from local public utility commission rate regulations as long as they met certain qualifications; plants, for example, could be no more than 30 megawatts in size.
The result of these benevolent policies was a market free-for-all. Solar panels were manufactured for the small-scale heating of water in homes and factories. Companies began producing photovoltaic cells - which convert sunlight directly into electricity by means of silicon wafers - for everything from hand-held calculators to wristwatches. And solar-thermal plants were designed to produce electricity for businesses and utilities.
But the fledgling industry also produced its share of lemons. Large corporations, taking advantage of new Government research funds, produced demonstration pro-jects that ultimately proved unsuccessful. ''A lot of Fortune 500 companies built dishes and windmills that were 10 times larger than the market could bear,'' says Scott Sklar, the executive director of the Solar Energy Industries Association. ''All over the country, they left these idols, these statues of great ideas, that wasted a lot of money.'' IN MORE WAYS THAN one, Luz was an exception. Founded by Arnold Goldman, a 46-year-old, bearded and cerebral electrical engineer, it began life without Government research and development funds, and its research base was in Israel. Raised in Providence, R.I., and the recipient of a master's degree from the University of Southern California, Goldman went to work at Litton Industries in 1967. Two years later, he left to help form Lexitron, which eventually produced one of the first word processors.
In 1977, Raytheon acquired Lexitron, and Goldman dropped out to write a book with a modest topic: the meaning of life. For years, he had been filling notebooks with his thoughts on ''holism,'' which he defines as ''the quest to make everyday life holy.'' With more than a million dollars in proceeds from the sale of his company and Los Angeles home, Goldman moved his family to Israel to finish his work in progress.
Goldman titled his book ''A Working Paper on Project Luz,'' taking the name Luz from the site in the Bible where Jacob dreamed that angels traveled between heaven and earth. In 1979, Goldman founded a company he called Independent Household Products. ''I envisioned the company starting cities which would be energized by solar projects,'' he explains by telephone from his home in Jerusalem. But he soon dropped the idea for lack of converts. ''It was too bold and too broad to explain to people,'' he says. Scaling down his ambitions, he changed his company's name to Luz International, and set about formulating a business plan for the manufacture of solar-power plants.
Then Goldman met Patrick Francois, a soft-spoken Frenchman, now 46, with a remarkable resemblance to the actor Robert Vaughn. Francois, who had operated a textile-manufacturing company in Paris, had moved to Israel in 1970 and launched an apparel-manufacturing company, Magoo Ltd. He eventually built it into a $3 million enterprise, employing up to 150 workers. In 1979, he sold out to become a consultant, advising foreigners on investments in Israel.
Francois at first regarded Goldman as ''a kind of mad scientist,'' he says. ''He started telling me about these hundreds of millions of dollars that we could make selling solar electricity, and my first reaction was, 'Is this guy crazy?' '' But, after reviewing Goldman's business plan, Francois asked to join the company.
Goldman and Francois each put up $100,000, and they raised $950,000 for the first round of equity in the company, much of it from people who had backed Lexitron. Although both founders held Israeli citizenship, and their manufacturing and research operations were based in Jerusalem, in 1979 they incorporated Luz in California, partly because of the receptive regulatory environment but also because of their concern about possible anti-Israeli sentiment. ''Some investors are worried about tax issues and currency flow,'' Goldman explains. ''Others are just sensitive to the Arab boycott.''
At first, Goldman and Francois targeted small American companies such as textile mills that required steam for manufacturing. But most potential customers didn't want to take the risk. ''The market just wasn't there,'' Goldman says. ''We had some very tough times.'' Between 1979 and 1983, Luz racked up losses of $13.5 million, a skid that took a serious toll on Goldman. At age 39, he suffered a heart attack.
Meanwhile, the price of domestic oil had jumped from almost $13 a barrel to over $26, making solar power far more attractive to utilities. Goldman and Francois decided to shift gears. In 1983, they landed Southern California Edison.
Luz received a 30-year contract, under which the price paid for power from its SEGS I was guaranteed for a decade. SoCal Edison also granted the company a long-term lease on property in Daggett, Calif. Luz would manufacture most of the necessary equipment in Israel, find limited partners to invest in building the plant and handle construction. In return for operating the finished facility, the company would receive 1 percent of revenues.
Goldman and Francois were soon splitting their time between Israel, where they were manufacturing Luz's solar designs, and California, where they were looking for potential investors. Luz would hold less than 1 percent equity. They needed $62 million to build SEGS I. Since the plant would be producing power at a cost of 24 cents a kilowatt, and SoCal Edison was obligated to buy it for considerably less (payments for the first five years have averaged 13.9 cents a kilowatt hour), they could hardly ballyhoo profitability. What they had to sell were tax breaks.
In 1983, the Federal Government was offering SEGS backers 25 percent investment and energy tax credits. The state of California allowed a 13.5 percent energy tax credit. Francois explained that because of these credits, which could be written off against income in the first year, and because of accelerated depreciation that could be spread over five years, SEGS I investors could expect a 15 percent annual return on every dollar invested. ''Investors had potential risks if the system did not perform reasonably well,'' says Paul Salvodelli, Luz's assistant general counsel. ''Which is the difference between having a valid tax shelter as opposed to a nonvalid tax shelter.''
But Francois faced skeptical audiences. ''We had a hell of a time convincing people that, in spite of being solar, it was legitimate,'' he says. To reduce the investors' risk, Luz guaranteed the output of the plant for 10 years.
Francois also emphasized the simplicity of the technology chosen for the Luz plant. Basically, the system used a conventional steam turbine attached to solar reflectors whose reliability had been demonstrated at the Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M. Luz's technological twist was its design of the synthetic-oil-filled heat-collection pipes and the computer controls that tilted the mirrors according to the sun's east-west arc. To ensure power at night and on cloudy days, Luz included a natural-gas-fueled heater that, under Federal regulations, could provide up to 25 percent of the plant's daily output. ''It wasn't the fanciest technology,'' says Goldman, ''but it was the quickest and cheapest that would bring solar power to market.''
In 1984, Luz opened SEGS I, a 13.8-megawatt facility. When the second plant started up a year later, it turned out 30 megawatts at 17 cents a kilowatt hour, which SoCal Edison bought for an average of 7 cents a kilowatt hour. The utility tracts for another five plants. ''Unlike some other producers, they were savvy in the business environment,'' says Pamela Easterwood, the utility's qualifying-facility development manager. ''They succeeded because they were small, innovative and aggressive.''
WITH EACH NEW PROJECT, Luz managed to pare down its costs. Improved technology helped. The reflectors have been increased in size, and Goldman has designed new ceramic coatings for the pipes and more accurate computer-control systems. Two years ago, to realize economies of scale, Luz lobbied successfully for a change in the 30-megawatt limit under the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act. SEGS VIII, scheduled for completion by December, is an 80-megawatt solar plant.
The improved efficiency of the Luz plants has helped Francois raise $750 million from investors. To date, backers have included insurance companies such as Prudential and Metropolitan Life as well as utilities like Baltimore Gas and Electric and Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric. Lured by Luz's track record and the tax breaks, Potomac Capital Investment, a venture-capital subsidiary of Potomac Electric, organized a consortium of utilities to invest in five SEGS projects in 1986. P.C.I. put in $63 million of its own money. ''Those investment credits had a big impact on our economic analysis,'' says a vice president at P.C.I., John McConomy.
But the credits have been under siege. California's tax incentives ended in 1988. The Federal investment tax credit ended the same year. The Federal energy tax credit, scheduled to end in 1988, has been extended, but not without opposition. In another sign of the times, the solar panels on top of the White House vanished during the Reagan Administration. ''The Reagan ideologues viewed solar as a granola experience for a lot of crazy liberals,'' says Scott Sklar, the industry lobbyist. ''They seemed to lump together communism and solar energy.''
Today, says Ross Ain, a Luz lobbyist who is a former associate general counsel with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, ''The budget is tighter and tighter and most legislators have other priorities.''
The remaining 10 percent Federal energy tax credit is due to expire on Dec. 31, but Congress is considering a bill that would extend it for five years. Many legislators, however, see the measure as an unnecessary tax break for Luz's power-plant investors. ''I don't know why we have to be loading up a lot of tax benefits for otherwise profitable operations,'' says Rep. Pete Stark (D-Calif.). To the argument that Luz produces clean, nonpolluting energy, Stark responds: ''So do squirrels running a treadmill. It's a question of how much you want to subsidize the squirrel-breeding industry.''
The House has failed to extend the credit, but in the past the Senate has succeeded in keeping it. Senate supporters are once again hopeful. ''All in all, the chances for extension look good,'' says Senator Spark Matsunaga (D-Hawaii), the author of the bill. ''There is increasing support for solar energy because of environmental concerns.''
In fact, President Bush has often expressed his devotion to nonpolluting renewable energy resources, but his position on the extension has yet to be disclosed. ''The jury is still out,'' says Matsunaga.
On the other side of the continent, SoCal Edison has begun to look less lovingly at any new alternate energy producers like Luz. In the beginning, the utility had planned to sign on for 2,000 megawatts of power from renewables, but was forced by PURPA to contract for 6,000 megawatts of costly power. SoCal Edison today must pay about 8 cents per kilowatt hour for solar energy when it can purchase hydroelectric power for about 4 cents. ''Under PURPA, we can't say no,'' says SoCal Edison's Easterwood. ''We have to take the power, which is now more than we need, and for much more than we want to pay.'' In the utility's 1988 annual report, PURPA is described as a ''well-meaning public policy that turned out to be wrong.''
As it now stands, 26 percent of the utility's power is produced from oil and natural gas, 21 percent from nuclear plants, 15 percent from coal and 16 percent from other utilities. The remainder comes from water (4 percent) and from other renewable sources (18 percent).
SoCal Edison has offered Luz a different kind of contract to cover SEGS VIII and succeeding plants. Betting that the price of oil and natural gas will remain stable, or dip, the utility wants to peg what it pays Luz to current traditional fuel prices. That has discouraged some of Luz's backers, including P.C.I., which has shied away from investing in SEGS VIII.
These days Goldman and Francois are selling SEGS plants as a hedge against a rise in oil prices. When he meets venture capitalists, Francois lays out several scenarios: With oil at the August price of $17.50 a barrel, investors in SEGS VIII could expect a return of about 13 percent; at $20, it would be in the 16 percent range. In fact, with oil at $20 or more, Francois insists, Luz's plants would be profitable with or without tax breaks. O N THE TOP FLOOR OF a glass and concrete office tower near the main campus of the University of California at Los Angeles, the scuffed walls at Luz's headquarters are bare but for the occasional SEGS photograph or surveyor's map of the Mojave Desert. In Francois's office, two Israeli trade awards hang; Luz's manufacturing plant is one of Israel's top 10 exporters.
Luz International, the parent company, is directed by what staffers call ''the triumvirate,'' three leaders who are rarely together at any one time. Goldman spends much of the year with Luz's 400 employees in Jerusalem. Francois spends his days with 60 employees at the Los Angeles office, whose main occupation is raising money for future Luz plants.
Last April, Luz named James Bazor as its chief operating officer and the man in charge of the construction division. The crusty, 55-year-old Bazor had been building SEGS projects for Montgomery, Ala.-based Blount Inc. He now labors in the Mojave Desert, overseeing a work force of 1,000 - including 250 technicians who operate the plants and another 60 permanent construction managers. Over the next few months, 200 more employees will be signed on as Luz rushes to complete primary construction on SEGS VIII to qualify for the remaining Federal tax credit.
Luz International has recently benefited from an infusion of cash from C. P. National, a telecommunications company based in Walnut Creek, Calif. ''We knew utilities weren't going to build huge generating plants anymore because of the financial risks,'' says Michael Holmstrom, the company's president. ''And Luz was a perfect match because of its small modular plants that offered peak power when it was needed.'' C. P. National has put up $11 million to become a limited partner in SEGS projects, but it has also invested directly in Luz International. Last year, the firm added $11 million to its $6 million stake in Luz International, becoming the largest shareholder, with 38 percent of the outstanding stock.
Luz International's profit picture has only recently begun to brighten. As opposed to the limited partners who bought into SEGS plants, shareholders in the parent company have watched it consistently lose money between 1979 and 1985. Last year the company reported a $5 million profit on $153 million in revenues; this year Luz expects to make about $5 million to $6 million on revenues of $250 million, mainly from the sale of the SEGS VIII plant. But the profit is to be plowed back into the company.
Its prospects continue to be tied, in large measure, to the public concern about the environment. In California, those concerns have led to a dramatic reduction in the use of oil and natural gas for electricity from 81 percent in 1977 to less than half this year. ''We had a heroin-like dependence on fossil fuels,'' says Charles Imbrecht, the chairman of the California Energy Commission, ''and we've spent the last 10 years trying to kick the habit.''
In fact, a new California Energy Commission rule, which will go into effect in 1990, adds an environmental price tag to the cost of power: among other things, the cost of pollution controls, of rehabilitating strip mines and of decommissioning nuclear facilities. ''Some energy resources have looked artificially better than solar,'' says Imbrecht. The commission is committed to fulfilling 10 percent of the state's needs with solar power by the year 2000. With an optimism born of experience, Luz is plunging ahead. The company recently broke ground on the first of five large-scale SEGS plants in Harper Lake, Calif., about 20 miles from Kramer Junction. Over the next five years, the company plans to spend $60 million on research and development projects, including a storage battery that will save daytime energy for use at night or on cloudy days and double-access tracking devices that will tilt the mirrors not only east and west, but also north and south, to follow the sun through the seasons.
AT THE MOMENT, LUZ faces little competition.
There are no other large-scale solar thermal plants anywhere. Photovoltaics are widely viewed as a promising form of solar energy, but photovoltaic power still costs about 30 cents per kilowatt hour and the largest photovoltaic plant is only 6.5 megawatts. Chronar Corp., of Princeton, N.J., has announced its intention to build a 50-megawatt photovoltaic plant north of Los Angeles, but no contract has yet been signed; it will produce power in the 10-to-12 cents per kilowatt hour range.
Arnold Goldman says that the company's SEGS could one day produce hundreds of thousands of megawatts of solar power for the nation's utilities. He envisions much larger plants owned by utilities and thus not limited by PURPA's 80-megawatt restriction on independent producers. Nevada, Arizona and other Sunbelt states are his natural market in the United States since they possess the cloud-free days, dry air and low-cost land he needs. Solar plants still require four or five acres of land for every megawatt of power produced.
Ironically, Luz has had difficulty selling its wares in Israel, whose climate and terrain appear ideal. ''The engineers at Israel Electric are like those at a lot of American utilities,'' says Goldman. ''They tend to be very conservative.''
Patrick Francois sums up Luz's prospects in these terms: ''We'll have a nice business in the future if you believe that oil and gas are finite resources, if you believe that oil prices will return to $20 a barrel and if you believe that society still cares about getting the cleanest power possible.''
But that's a lot of if's -even for a business built on sunshine.
