The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 21, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 2933 words

HEADLINE: Investors Confront a New Europe

BYLINE: By Madelon DeVoe Talley; Madelon DeVoe Talley, an investment consultant based in New York, is the author of ''The Passionate Investors.''

 BODY:
IMAGINE A EUROPE THAT RESEMBLES the United States, a continent in which people and goods move freely across state borders with nary a customs or immigration officer to interrupt the flow.
Mechanics and doctors, accountants and industrial designers change jobs without regard to geography. Their maroon passports identify them as European; they are paid and they enjoy the fruits of their labor with a single European currency.
The idea of such a Europe - not too long ago deemed a utopian goal - is rife in the international business world. C.E.O.'s and economists pepper their speeches and reports with references to 1992, the deadline the European Community of 12 nations has set for the dismantling of internal economic barriers. Recognizing that the 320 million consumers in a Pan-European grouping will constitute the world's largest market (nearly as big as the United States and Japan combined), corporate strategists are factoring 1992 into their sales and operations planning, and concluding that acquisitions may provide the fastest route to gaining dominant positions. 
For Wall Street, 1992 represents a big idea, a ''theme'' of a magnitude not seen since the oil crisis of the 1970's. Investment managers explore such themes to generate ''concepts'' about specific industries and ''stories'' about individual companies.
But 1992 poses a challenge for investors. The general outline is clear enough, but the details and timing remain frustratingly ambiguous. Almost no one expects to wake up on Jan.1, 1993, and find the transition to a single market completed. Says Michael Lipper of Lipper Analytical Services, ''It's a lot of hype . . . . 1992 makes a lot of sense for 2013.'' While some skeptics scoff at the notion of a protectionist Old World transformed into a free and deregulated environment, others predict that its advent is already being discounted. As one veteran Wall Street broker puts it, ''It'll be overblown by the time it happens.''
In fact, much has already happened. About half of the 279 directives for liberalizing legislation have been effected by the European Council of Ministers in Brussels. The reconciliation of standards for product manufacturing and the removal of restrictions on the sale of financial services are both well under way.
The odds against a European central bank and a unified currency, however, remain high. Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been the most resolute foe of monetary union, though she refrained from blocking steps toward such a system at a summit meeting in Madrid last June.
Meanwhile, anticipation of 1992 has already inspired much of the bullish activity on European stock exchanges during the last 18 months. And it has been a catalyst for a spate of mergers and acquisitions. ''Once a businessman believes he'll be able to sell across borders, the smart ones won't wait,'' says Philip Douglas, a managing director of Alliance International Fund, based in London. Sir James Goldsmith's $21 billion bid to seize Britain's B.A.T. Industries is seen as a harbinger of leveraged buyout warfare to come.
The possibility of a ''Fortress Eu-rope,'' where new trade barriers would block competition from abroad, in particular the United States and Japan, has Washington and Wall Street worried. ''When people become rich, they tend to raise walls around their empires,'' says George Soros, president of Soros Fund Management, a global investment pioneer.
American multinationals are moving to firm up their European footholds before the barriers are erected. At the same time, European companies are stepping up their investments in the United States to safeguard against retaliatory actions by an angry Congress. ''The dual paranoia is creating a gold rush both ways of people wanting to be there for the strike,'' says Rainer Greeven of Greeven & Ercklentz, a New York law firm that specializes in advising clients on trans-Atlantic business activities.
INVESTORS ARE PUTTING their money mainly into European securities - which has become easier for Americans to do these days - but they are also buying shares of American companies that are well positioned to take advantage of the new market.
In the early stages of a theme like 1992, investment managers must rely on certain broad assumptions. First, Europe is a wealthy region that can only grow wealthier when companies become more efficient in a deregulated, more competitive environment. Second, the massive restructuring of European industry will make for lively securities markets. ''Change always creates opportunities for investors,'' says Christian Norgren, chairman of The Bank in Liechtenstein, the largest private bank in that tax-haven nation.
For the most part, money managers are looking for the industries that are likely to benefit from integration and deregulation (the ''concepts'') and then searching for companies within those industries in various countries (the ''stories''). This sector approach is preferred by big investors to hunting for winners and losers country by country.
Starting with the losers, experienced Europe hands point to small and medium-sized companies that will be at a disadvantage against giants, which have the resources to market and distribute their products throughout a Pan-European network. Many pharmaceutical companies are among the handicapped.
European airlines, mostly government-controlled and used to operating as a cartel, are being shunned. ''There could be a mine field out there,'' says Henry de Vismes, president of the Kleinwort Benson International Fund in London. He points to the price warfare, heavy losses and initial drop in stock prices that attended the deregulation of airlines in the United States.
No regulatory changes are in the offing to make the automobile and food industries more attractive; their franchises have already been extended beyond national boundaries. But other factors can be brought to bear on specific companies.
If he were to go to sleep for 10 years, says James Heyworth-Dunne, managing director of HD International, a London-based institutional fund management company, he would want these stocks in his portfolio: Peugeot, the profitable French car maker, which should benefit from the harmonizing of value added taxes (France's V.A.T. is nearly double the British rate); Carrefour, a huge French supermarket chain with growth potential in Spain, and Carnaud, a French packaging company that should reap the benefits of standardized labeling on food and alcohol products.
What's more, losers can be winners when they are candidates for takeover. Some investment managers, who think the merger-betting game may have peaked in the United States, intend to participate in the action as it moves to Europe.
Typical of the many variables surrounding 1992 is Spain, the country that draws special attention from sector strategists because they believe its dynamic economy will grow faster than the rest of Europe in the years to come. Spain is also a beneficiary of the sunbelt phenomenon; many companies are moving their operations to southern Europe in search of lower labor costs. Moreover, once pensions can be drawn anywhere within the European Community, many retired persons are expected to head south.
 
TRANSPORTATION
''Once you focus on the most fragmented industries where there's been the greatest degree of regulation,'' says Sally Whittaker, manager of the Fidelity 1992 European Opportunities Assets Fund in London, ''transportation becomes obvious.''
Next year, physical frontiers between Germany, France and the Benelux countries will be eliminated, a first step toward creating a wide distribution network and unleashing the competitive forces that have transformed the freight-forwarding industry in the United States. Two freight-forwarders favored by money managers are Danzas, a Swiss company, and Frans Maas Beheer, a small Dutch company regarded as a takeover candidate. In addition, Fidelity considers Nedlloyd, a Dutch shipping company, as a potential beneficiary of the changing transport scene.
No investment symbolizes for Europeans the process of economic and political integration as much as Eurotunnel, the transportation consortium that is constructing the tunnel beneath the English Channel. When the tunnel opens in 1993, the train journey between London and Paris will be cut in half to less than three hours. Although the company is not expected to produce earnings until 1993, the stock, listed on the London and Paris stock exchanges, has just about doubled its offering price of November 1987.
 
FINANCIAL SERVICES
The psychological impact of 1992 is being felt in banking as consolidation sets in at a furious pace. But many investment managers say it will be the middle of the decade before they can fathom who the winners will be in a single market for financial services. An American giant, Citicorp, has 800 branches and 18,000 employees in Europe, and has absorbed millions in losses trying to cover more of the continent than anyone else.
For current investment potential, Steven H. Nagourney, chief international strategist at Shearson Lehman Hutton, is picking the strongest banks in various countries: Paribas in France, B. C. I. in Italy and Deutsche Bank in Germany. Apart from Deutsche Bank's growing asset base - in 1986 it bought Bank of America's 100 branches in Italy - the German bank should benefit, Nagourney feels, from its longstanding relationships in Eastern Europe in the wake of perestroika. And the scandals that have tarnished the aura of several Swiss banks can further redound to Deutsche Bank's credit.
The recent push by some of the biggests insurance companies to become one-stop financial shopping centers in a deregulated Europe sends a clear signal to money managers. Appearing on most of their lists of investments are Allianz, Germany's most aggressive insurance company; Nationale-Nederlanden and Aegon, respectively, the first and second largest insurers in the Netherlands, and Groupe Victoire, France's second largest insurance company, which last month became the target of a hostile bid from Compagnie Financiere de Suez, a huge French banking company.
 
TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND MEDIA
Historically, most European countries have had two or three television networks financed mostly through Government subsidies rather than advertising. But in recent years, several nations have followed Italy's lead in adding new commercial channels, paving the way for a thriving system of private television and radio networks. By 1990, the number of channels and hours of broadcasting in Western Europe will have nearly tripled in the space of six years.
When the regulatory lid comes off, says Andrew M. Wallach, media and entertainment analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert, the market for imported television programming will explode. The chief beneficiaries could be American film producers. Wallach recommends the Walt Disney Company, Time Warner Inc., Paramount and Viacom International, which operates a European version of its MTV.
Europe is the biggest market for Capital Cities Corporation's ABC Distribution Company, which sells the network's American-made television products abroad. As part of a strategy to market locally produced European programs after 1992 (and import them as well for American cable), ABC has acquired an interest in Telemunchen, a television producer and program distributor based in Munich, West Germany, to serve as a European foothold.
In addition, News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's Australian-based global media company, is seen by some investment managers as a vehicle for tapping into satellite television. Sky Television, Murdoch's British satellite venture, broadcasts directly to the continent.
A favorite of European money managers is Carlton Communications P.L.C., a British leader in the television-support business. It supplies everything from stage props to digital-signal processing equipment to television and film studios. Last year, Carlton acquired Technicolor Inc., the California-based company that is the world's largest duplicator of videocassettes.
Wallach joins his European colleagues in recommending Canal Plus, a French pay- television service, and Compagnie Generale des Eaux, the world's largest private water utility, which has substantial stakes in cable television (including a 22 percent interest in Canal) and cellular radiotelephone.
As the integration of Europe proceeds, major consumer companies are expected to use television to market their brands across borders. ''It's the key to success for any competitive company after 1992,'' says George Johnston, chairman of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, veteran international fund managers. ''Advertising is a subtle form of distribution.'' Because of their long international experience and acquisitive streaks in recent years, American and British agencies are the ones investment managers consider to be in the best position to cash in on the European advertising boom. In particular, they single out Omnicom Group and the Interpublic Group, based in the United States, and Britain's WPP Group P.L.C. and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.
 
LEISURE
According to Sir David English, deputy chairman of Associated Newspapers, a British company that has conducted extensive market research on the subject, younger people have a more selfish rather than idealistic view of European integration. ''They want better jobs, better travel, they want to be citizens of a superpower,'' he says. ''The Americans have had the Good Life for a long time - it's our turn.''
Those sentiments bode well for companies in the European leisure industry, from hotels to makers of camping equipment. According to Wallach of Drexel Burnham, a major investment in the field should be EuroDisneyland. The first stage of the theme park is scheduled to open in 1992 on the outskirts of Paris. Disney is offering a 51 percent ownership in the project in a Euro-equity issue due out this fall.
The offering is restricted to residents of the European Community, but Wallach recommends the stock of the parent company. He calculates that the value of EuroDisney's land and infrastructure is worth several dollars per share to Walt Disney shareholders.
Nagourney of Shearson Lehman Hutton likes Club Mediterranee, the French tourism company, for its undervalued assets and the likelihood the company will be restructured.
 
REAL ESTATE
When investment managers get together to swap ideas about 1992, the talk inevitably drifts to castles in Spain - and farmhouses in Provence. Almost everyone nurtures the idea that a vacation home in some idyllic corner of Europe will pay off in long-term capital gains.
Sotheby's International Realty has numerous listings of authentic properties with price tags that are geared to the affluent investor. An 18th-century Georgian manor house near Dublin or a palazzo on the outskirts of Venice can be had in the $500,000 to $1.5 million range. William Montgomery, Sotheby's chairman, cites as ''exceptional values'' the farmhouses in Aix, Nimes, Arles and the Luberon mountains of southern France that are going for $300,000 to $500,000, not including substantial costs for rehabilitation.
In a more commercial vein, money managers note that Brussels real estate has started to appreciate, as has property on both sides of the channel near the Eurotunnel.
A Salomon Brothers research report points to opportunities in the Paris real estate market that can be bought at a discount by investing in the stock of companies listed on the Paris Bourse. Lucia, an aggressive development company, specializes in office space, particularly in La Defense, the western business section of the city. Grands Moulins de Paris, a large milling company, has unrealized assets in land in eastern Paris. The diversified property portfolio of Compagnie Fonciere Internationale includes office buildings and shopping centers in Brussels and Madrid.
Stephen J. Dobi, a housing and construction analyst for Salomon Brothers, recommends Kaufman and Broad Home Corporation. The California homebuilder has extensive operations in Paris, including the construction and renovation of major office buildings.
HOW CAN INDIVIDUAL investors avail themselves of the 1992 theme?
Americans are precluded from buying the new investment funds specifically oriented toward 1992 that have been blossoming in Europe. But they can choose among mutual funds that are registered in the United States, including seasoned international funds that have both European and Asian portfolios and strictly European funds developed in the last four years.
Both types of funds have performed better than one-country funds. The single exception is the Spain Fund, created by Alliance Capital last year. This closed-end fund has been trading on the New York Stock Exchange at a 33 percent premium over asset value. Its largest holdings are in manufacturing -companies such as Prosegur (electronic security systems and armored trucks), Tabacalera (cigarettes) and Repsol (petroleum).
It is also increasingly easy to buy securities listed on foreign exchanges directly through one of the large American brokerage houses that have international trading and research capability. Commissions and transaction fees are generally slightly higher, although these vary from country to country. In addition, some 800 foreign securities, principally in the form of American Depositary Receipts, are traded on the New York and American Stock Exchanges and in the over-the-counter market.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 18, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 6009 words

HEADLINE: Counselor To The King

BYLINE: By Liz Roman Gallese; Liz Roman Gallese writes about business from Wellesley, Mass.

 BODY:
THE INVESTIGATION BEGAN IN DECEMBER OF 1986. Officials from Britain's Department of Trade and Industry descended upon the London headquarters of Guinness P.L.C., a huge liquor conglomerate. When the charges were lodged five months later, Ernest W. Saunders, the chairman, and a number of leading British business figures stood accused of stock manipulation in connection with Guinness' $4.1 billion takeover of Distillers Company. At the heart of the case was a letter to a lawyer from Olivier Roux, an executive of the Boston-based management consulting firm of Bain & Company. Roux, on loan to Guinness, had served as controller and financial director of the British company and as a member of its board of directors. In his letter he defended his own actions and implicated Ernest Saunders. Roux was not charged. Saunders, who says Bain's behavior in the case was ''ruthless,'' is scheduled to face trial in January.
The Guinness scandal rocked Britain's financial community, but it also raised a number of interesting questions about Bain, in particular, and the management consulting business in general. Aside from Roux, Bain had as many as 35 staffers at a time consulting for Guinness in Britain, for an annual fee estimated at $20 million. Was this typical of a consulting firm's involvement with a client? To what degree was it appropriate or desirable for consultants to take over the duties of management? 
Jack Brennan, a professor of management at Skidmore College and a former C.E.O., offers one kind of response:
''Consultants are supposed to be advisers rather than executives. They are supposed to be counselors to the king. They are supposed to keep their skirts clean.''
William W. Bain Jr., the 52-year-old founder, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Bain & Company, takes a somewhat different tack. Erect in his chair, speaking, as always, with measured precision, he allows that the scandal might have put off some potential clients: ''You never know who almost picked up a telephone and didn't.'' Permitting Roux to join the Guinness board, he acknowledges, was a mistake: ''I wish we hadn't done it.'' (It was also, says James H. Kennedy, who tracks consulting trends from Fitzwilliam, N.H., ''conflict of interest with a capital C.'') Otherwise, Bain insists that his firm's behavior at Guinness was exemplary and productive. In fact, it was a classic exercise in the Bain way.
The $13.5 billion management consulting industry might be divided into two basic camps. Some firms concentrate on performing specific, case-by-case tasks for a client. Leading the pack are the consulting arms of the largest accounting firms (See box, Page 20). In the other corner are the firms that are known for their strategy consulting, whereby clients are advised on how to integrate new acquisitions or alter their product mix - issues that involve the whole company. The list includes the old-line, broad-based houses, such as McKinsey & Company and Booz-Allen & Hamilton, as well as the so-called strategy houses like the Boston Consulting Group and Bain.
Management consulting thrives on change, and has prospered of late, spurred by the torrent of corporate restructurings, in the United States and abroad, and the effort of American companies to position themselves for the economic unification of Europe in 1992. With an estimated $220 million in revenues last year, Bain is far from the largest of the major firms - McKinsey, for example, racked up $620 million. Within the industry, however, Bain has a force and a presence far beyond its size. The firm pioneered the concept known as implementation, whereby a strategy consultant not only offers a client a grand plan but also, like the man who came to dinner, stays on and on to see that the plan is carried out. Bain is the chief practitioner of ''relationship'' consulting, which calls for a remarkable level of intimacy with its major clients.
Beyond its reputation for innovation, though, Bain is famous for the iron discipline and gung-ho spirit of its troops (who are known throughout the industry as Bainies), and for its extraordinary secrecy. New employees must sign a nondisclosure form, promising never to reveal the names of clients, and everyone who works for the company must adhere to a ''code of confidentiality'' that includes instruction on how to discard sensitive documents.
This article is largely based on interviews with Bill Bain, who rarely speaks to the press, and with Bain employees, past and present, some of whom insisted on anonymity. Part of the reason, a former vice president explained, is loyalty to the firm, but another part ''is that these are bad people to have mad at you, that they are ruthless, hard and unfeeling.'' ONE DAY IN 1984, MARK A. GOTTFREDSON, a Bain vice president, found himself in Detroit, chatting with the director of the large-car division of the Chrysler Corporation, a longtime Bain client. The director wondered whether manufacturing quality might be improved by simplifying the process - for example, by cutting back the options Chrysler offered on its cars. As Gottfredson recalls, the director said he would ''kill'' to know, given the hundreds of choices facing a customer in terms of color, style and equipment, just how many possible combinations of options Chrysler plants had to be ready to provide. ''When a client would 'kill to know,' '' Gottfredson says, ''we're pretty quick to go after it.''
The particular answer was soon delivered: 10 billion. But the conversation led to a remarkable series of assignments for Bain, and a dramatic change, still being effected, in the company's manufacturing procedures. It was a classic case of management consulting a la Bain.
The consultants first explored the possibility of offering customers set packages of options - power windows and power doorlocks, for example, would be part of a package rather than provided as individual options. The Bain team also discovered that most American customers bought their cars directly off the lot without bothering to pick and choose among all the options available. Bain embarked on a six-month exploration of what Gottfredson calls ''the cost of complexity.'' A team of Bainies invaded one of the division's plants to determine the hypothetical savings achieved by manufacturing cars with set packages of options.
''There were 1,500 stations in the plant,'' he says, ''and we looked at every one.'' The savings were estimated at one-third.
Chrysler bought the idea of packaging options. Bain talked to salesmen, dealers and marketing executives and customers and came up with a list of 5,000 packages that would satisfy 99 percent of the company's customers.
The final step was to actually implement the decision on the factory floor. Bain showed how. First, the consultant team paid a visit to six Japanese auto plants and quizzed three Japanese industry consultants. Says Gottfredson, who speaks Japanese: ''We wanted to know how many people worked in each plant, the breakdown between direct and indirect labor, how often cars were pulled off the line. We learned a lot.'' He also found, tucked away in an obscure Japanese journal, an article dealing with plant scheduling; it contained a mathematical formula ''that allowed us to optimize for all of those things.''
The Bain team applied its new-won knowledge on the factory floor at Chrysler, identifying four major categories of systems that could be overhauled, advising on just how that might be accomplished. Bain likes to get down with the troops, Gottfredson says. Describing another Chrysler project, he tells how the Bainies swept into a plant, studying all three shifts, ''No ties, women in pants, on the line in the body shop 24 hours a day. They'd ask questions like, 'Why did this piece of equipment go down?' And a plant manager would say, 'Stick your head into this 20-ton jaw and find out.' ''
The consultants labored in 12 of Chrysler's plants, then trained Chrysler's people to handle the process in the others. ''They're rolling it out now,'' Gottfredson says. According to Chrysler, Bain's labors yielded gratifying results. On the Omni and Horizon models, for example, complexity reduction trimmed money off the sticker price.
IN THE HEADQUARTERS OF Bain & Company, which takes up four floors of an office tower in Boston's Copley Place, 700 staff members are crammed into open bays, 15 desks to a bay. Bill Bain's office is a world apart, a commodious room filled with antiques and fresh-cut flowers. A Boston Celtics basketball sits in a silver bowl near his desk. Bain, a trim 5-feet, 11-inches tall, plays basketball himself and is an avid Celtics fan.
He answers questions carefully and exhaustively, constantly sipping a glass of Dr Pepper. His pale face, a stark contrast to his dark suit and the royal blue walls of the room, registers little emotion.
Unlike almost everyone in the strategy consulting trade, Bill Bain does not possess an M.B.A. Born in Johnson City, Tenn., the son of a food wholesaler, he attended East Tennessee State College for two years, then transferred to Vanderbilt University, where he majored in history. By the time he graduated from college in 1959, he was married and a father; William III, now 30, is a freelance commercial artist in California. (Bain married a second time, in 1973, to Colleen Sullivan; they have three children.) Bain received a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship for an advanced degree in history, but found thesis-writing not to his taste. Instead, he joined a small steel-fabricating company, making sales calls and working up engineering studies. In 1960, he returned to Vanderbilt, as a development officer. It was in the course of soliciting alumni for funds for the university's proposed business school that Bain met Bruce Henderson, the founder of the Boston Consulting Group. Within months, Bain was on the B.C.G. payroll.
Management consulting had its roots in time-and-motion studies of the early 20th century. One of the first to apply these scientific ideas was Arthur D. Little, who incorporated his firm in 1909. Its clients today remain primarily in the world of science and technology. Booz-Allen was founded in 1914, followed by McKinsey in 1926.
A turning point in the history of management consulting arrived in 1963 when Bruce Henderson, an Arthur D. Little veteran, set up a firm dedicated to strategy consulting. Henderson's ''product portfolio'' or ''growth-share'' matrix has become a staple of modern management. In much simplified form, it proposes that managers should look at the parts of their companies under four basic headings and behave accordingly: Milk the slow-growing, cash-yielding ''cows,'' nurture the fast-growing, cash-gobbling ''stars,'' ditch the moribund ''dogs'' and convert the ''question marks.''
Before Henderson, says Patrick Graham, a Bain executive vice president and B.C.G. alumnus, ''Everything was a snapshot versus a movie. There wasn't any sense of the dynamic - that one event leads to another. That's what Bruce added.''
At B.C.G., Bill Bain rose quickly to the rank of group vice president, overseeing with Graham one of four operating groups. Their unit was soon producing an impressive share of the firm's revenues, but Bain was restless. He was convinced that the management consultant's role should extend to implementing strategy - he had tried the approach and achieved what he felt were spectacular results. But B.C.G. was then, and remains to this day, wary of such intrusions. Says John Clarkeson, the firm's current C.E.O., ''It's always risky to dilute management's responsibility for day-to-day operations.''
In 1973, Bain marched into Henderson's office and resigned, announcing his intention to start his own business. Henderson, now 76, recalls the moment well. He had thought Bain would be his successor. ''It was war,'' he says, ''the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor. I felt more betrayed and robbed and desecrated than ever before in my life.'' The parting was bitter, with Henderson accusing Bain of looking for business clients among B.C.G. clients, of stealing B.C.G. employees - even of soliciting financial backing from B.C.G.'s then parent, the Boston Company. Bain denies the charges.
In any event, it was not long before Bain & Company had two former B.C.G. clients, Black & Decker and Texas Instruments, and was joined by six B.C.G. professionals, including Graham. Bain was now free to practice his special brand of consulting. He would accept shorter, less all-encompassing assignments, but he was dedicated to building close, long-term relationships with companies. He would not only devise strategies, he would help carry them out. And, in another departure from the industry norm, he promised that he would represent no more than one such client in any given industry. For so intimate an adviser, almost a part of the company, anything else would be a conflict of interest.
Over the years, Bain's list of major clients grew to encompass some of the leading corporations of the nation, including the likes of Baxter International, Burlington Industries, Dun & Bradstreet, Hughes Tool, Iowa Beef, Monsanto and Wells Fargo. The results have often been impressive. In a March 1989 Price Waterhouse audit, the market value of all of Bain's clients was shown to have increased 456 percent since 1980. The audit was based on the in-house Bain Index. It compares the performance of clients' stocks with that of the Dow Jones industrial average, which was up only 192 percent. Bain claims that, for every dollar it charges clients, they increase their profits by a factor of 5 to 10.
Not everyone, however, is convinced of the value of strategy consultants. Some critics believe their chief function is as corporate lightning rod to draw criticism away from the C.E.O. ''The old saw,'' says Abraham Zaleznik, a professor of leadership at the Harvard Business School, ''was that the consultant came in and listened to what the C.E.O. wanted to do and then wrote it up. This is still a large part of the process. It doesn't take great intellectual powers, and there is a fair amount of psychodrama.'' Of Bain's approach, Zaleznik says, ''If the C.E.O. calls in the consulting firm to, in effect, run the business, it's a statement he doesn't know how to do it.''
THE ANNUAL MEETING OF the Boston staff of Bain & Company, a kind of modified pep rally, opened last May in a suburban Boston hotel. The highlight of the first evening's entertainment came when two vice chairmen of the firm, decked out in dark glasses, stormed into the hall on motorcycles. Then they jumped onto the stage, did a couple of back-flips and burst into a takeoff of ''Soul Man'' titled ''I'm a Ba-y-y-y-y-n Man.'' The musical accompaniment was provided by the Bain Band, composed of employees.
At meetings serious and social, in everyday contacts with senior officers, Bain seeks to steep its staff in the ways of the corporate culture. The firm's new mission statement sets the tone. The objective: ''to help our clients create . . . high levels of economic value.'' The means: ''the Bain community of extraordinary teams.''
For Bill Bain, teamwork is all. ''The great teams,'' he says, ''and I think of ourselves as being in that league, are made up of very powerful individuals. Think of the great Boston Celtics, guys like Bill Russell or Dave Cowens. Obviously the players were not subjugated in some oppressive way by the coach, but he got them to play as an incredibly productive team.''
Mark Nunnelly, a 30-year-old Bain vice president, puts it another way: ''Bain recruits Bruce Springsteens and figures out how to make them very strong first violin players.''
Like its competitors, the firm hunts for ''Springsteens'' who have M.B.A.'s from the leading schools, notably Harvard. The pursuit starts with the hiring of top students as summer interns; those who pass muster are courted in the months before graduation. Bain & Company offers candidates salaries well above $60,000, not counting the signing bonus and the year-end bonus. Only investment banks pay more for M.B.A. graduates.
Most of Bain's M.B.A. hires have some business experience, and they rapidly get more working with clients. ''One of Bill's tricks,'' says a former staffer, ''was to move people very quickly, maybe a little faster than they thought they deserved, to keep them on the edge of feeling grateful.'' But Bill Bain scoffs at the often-heard notion that his young consultants run around telling C.E.O.'s what to do. ''I'm amused,'' he says, ''at the idea of our three-year consultants somehow wresting all of this power from 50-year-old general managers who probably killed a couple of people to get their jobs.''
Under the Bain system, a vice president with five to eight years' tenure manages the client relationship, dealing with senior executives. A manager with four or five years' experience oversees the team, which includes a team leader who has had two or three years with Bain, a number of more junior consultants, a smattering of associate consultants and, in season, summer interns.
In a large conference room at Boston headquarters recently, a seven-person case team briefs Bain vice president Christopher Zook on its plans for a meeting with a client. The mission: to prepare the client's sales force to handle a more sophisticated product line.
Standing at the white board, John Flanigan, the team manager, attired like most Bainies in dark suit, blue shirt and red suspenders, outlines a proposal for having technical specialists accompany salespeople on their rounds. An associate consultant expresses concern - she has accompanied one of the salesmen on his rounds, and found him to be an independent type who would not take kindly to having a specialist tag along. Observes the team leader, ''You have to watch the Karma.''
Zook urges the team to be careful how its proposal is presented. ''Your job,'' he says, ''is to depict objective data objectively and let people look at the facts and migrate toward sensible solutions.''
For Bain vice presidents with five to eight years' experience, salaries range upward from $200,000. According to Kennedy, for the services of a $200,000-a-year consultant, clients pay between $600,000 and $800,000 on an annualized basis.
In matters of salary, and much else, Bill Bain maintains ultimate control. For a portion of its life, the firm operated under a partnership deed, what is referred to by one former partner as ''not a bill of rights, but the rights of Bill.'' When he read the document, he says, he discovered that ''I was signing myself up for unlimited liability, along with Bill. Otherwise, I was just going to be a salaried man. No right for compensation if I were to be fired. No tenure. No vote. It was a sham.'' In 1985, the partnership was replaced by a corporation.
Among consulting companies that do strategy work, most notably McKinsey, associates who fail to rise in the ranks often join client companies. Bain discourages the practice. Michael White, who is now a senior vice president of a division of Avon Inc. - not a Bain client - recalls that while he was still at Bain, he was approached by a client. One of Bain's top executives, he says, contacted the company to stop any further talks.
One of the side benefits of being a partner-vice president at Bain has been the opportunity to invest in Bain Capital, a venture capital fund. The affiliate's first fund, started in 1984, put almost $37 million in some 20 companies and has since been closed. Its annual rate of return has been more than 50 percent. The 1987 fund, still on-going, has a $106 million stake in 13 concerns.
Headed by W. Mitt Romney, son of the former president of American Motors, Bain Venture Capital has managed to steer clear of conflicts of interest by having Bain & Company retain veto power over investments. But it is not an entirely neutral relationship. When Bain & Company temporarily stopped consulting for Firestone in the mid-80's, Bain Capital bought a division of Firestone that made wheel rims. Then it retained a Bain team to help revitalize the company. I N ITS QUEST FOR CLIENTS, Bain & Company offers prospects ''acquaintanceships,'' under which the consultants work without charge for several weeks so that the two parties can look each other over. In some cases, Bain also offers to forego its fee if the consultant cannot live up to its promises. Harry C. Schell, chief executive of Cablec, a $500 million electrical cable company, likes the guarantee: ''We get very, very high return, but if they fall short of performance, they don't get paid. Period.''
In the best of all possible worlds, though, consultants prefer to lure new clients on the basis of their track records. That was the case with Alan P. Hoblitzell Jr., the C.E.O. of MNC Financial, a bank-holding company based in Baltimore, Md. Hoblitzell first retained Bain & Company in the early 1980's after having observed its teams in action at another company on whose board he served. The consulting firm has helped MNC introduce new products, such as so-called affinity credit cards issued in bulk to special-interest groups. It has advised the company on acquisitions. In sum, Hoblitzell says, Bain has been instrumental in lifting MNC's profit into the first quartile in the industry among companies of comparable size.
The specific advantages of using Bain, Hoblitzell says, are several. He wants to keep his in-house staff lean - a common desire in an era of corporate downsizing and restructuring - and the consultants can fill in the gaps, providing strategy and a sounding board. And he makes no bones about the value of consultants in shifting the blame for an unpopular decision to a presumably unbiased outsider. ''I felt that in order to bring about change,'' he says, ''it would be better facilitated by using a third party to help that and move it along.''
Frequently, in hopes of finding a new ''relationship'' client, Bain pursues a camel's-nose-in-the-tent policy. According to Bill Bain, his firm will take on a small assignment when the project has the wholehearted backing of the chief executive and the effort can produce spectacular results. If the C.E.O. is impressed, he will be inclined to welcome Bain into the fold.
In the process of getting acquainted, Bain teams ask a lot of questions. ''They're learning the business,'' says Jim Carey, a senior vice president of Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, ''which is the one thing you have to pay for in resources with a Bain that you wouldn't have to pay for with a B.C.G.'' But, he adds, ''They moved quickly with the learning curve, faster than I could have imagined. I thought they did a phenomenal job for us.''
Ironically, the very effectiveness of the Bain way can pose problems. At Western Digital, an Irvine, Calif., maker of chips and boards for computers, the consultants became so familiar with the company's operations that they sometimes had a better handle on what was going on than Western's own staffers. ''They can centralize information gathering,'' says John R. MacKay, senior vice president for worldwide operations, ''but that becomes bad when our people become dependent on them and stop trying.'' IN 1981, BAIN & COMPANY RE-ceived the kind of assignment that lies closest to its heart. Ernest Saunders, the newly named managing director of Guinness, needed help. After a distinguished career as a marketer, the 46-year-old Saunders had been brought in by Guinness to bring order out of chaos. Over the previous years, the company had gone on a diversification binge, buying some 300 disparate companies. Sales of its flagship product, Guinness stout, were declining. Its stock price was languishing.
Bain moved into action, sending teams of Bainies - including a 30-year-old consultant named Olivier Roux - from the London office to help devise a new strategy. In short order, Roux took on a second function as Guinness' controller; later he became the financial director. The loan of a consultant to a client was nothing new for Bain (according to Bill Bain, it has been done a dozen times), though the practice is shunned by most other firms.
Meanwhile, with Bain's guidance, Guinness was getting out of some 150 unprofitable companies, cutting costs, reviving sales of Guinness stout. Within a few years, pretax profits had doubled, and Guinness once again went hunting. It bought Arthur Bell & Sons, a maker of Scotch whisky, for more than $500 million. And it set its cap for Distillers.
What followed remains to be determined by the British courts. According to the Government, Saunders and his co-defendants arranged for a number of investors to take positions in Guinness, driving up the stock price, an illegal maneuver during a takeover. The bid for Distillers involved an exchange of shares, and a higher Guinness stock price raised the value of its bid - a much desired objective in light of a competing offer from the Argyll Group. Eventually, Guinness won out, paying $4.1 billion in stock and cash. It was, at the time, the biggest takeover in British history.
Today, Saunders faces 49 criminal charges and vehemently denies his guilt. He insists that he knew nothing about any stock-inflation scheme, that the man in charge was Bain's Olivier Roux, in his capacity as financial director. But Roux faces no charges, and will in fact be a witness for the prosecution. He has resigned from both Guinness and Bain and now works for a London investment concern called Talisman, founded by two former Bain consultants.
Roux, who was 36 when the scandal broke, also held a seat on the Guinness board, receiving a stipend of about $9,000 a year while remaining on the Bain payroll. The arrangement has drawn considerable criticism as representing a conflict of interest. Says Jack Brennan, the Skidmore professor: ''They were using their man in a nether world. Was this guy working for Bain or for Guinness?'' That is a question Bain declines to answer, on the grounds that it may be called to testify.
Saunders harbors bitter thoughts about Bain & Company. ''It would appear,'' he says, ''that Bain would do anything to save its own neck. Isn't that, in fact, a hell of a warning both for client companies and other strategy consultants?'' Asked to comment on Saunders' ''warning,'' Bill Bain's pale face momentarily reddens. ''I think that any client we have, or potential client,'' he says, ''understands very well that there are limits to the responsibilities we have to each other, and there are actions that either of us can take that cause the responsibility of the other party to cease.''
Bain & Company says that it has not lost any of its clients as a result of the Guinness scandal. For MNC's Hoblitzell, it's a ''nonissue'' because, he says, his company would never put a consultant on its staff. ''If I had a position to fill,'' he says, ''I would hire somebody internally.'' Kenneth Dawson, managing director of Alpha Publications, a British publishing firm, believes that Bain has held on to its European clients.
But as Bill Bain allows, potential clients may have been affected. One such instance is cited by Brennan - a company on whose board he sits. The company was recently looking for a consultant and ruled out Bain. ''Part of the reason,'' Brennan says, ''is that the board has been negatively influenced by that Guinness affair.'' A former Bain consultant adds, ''The scandal made it easier for McKinsey to tell prospects, 'Better to trust us than those guys.' ''
The scandal had a direct impact on Bain's bottom line as its annual Guinness billings shrank from a high of $20 million to, by one outside estimate, less than $10 million. Bill Bain will not confirm the figure, but he allows, ''Anytime you have a shortfall of a magnitude you're talking about there, there's naturally some reasonable period of time required to replace it.''
In the spring of 1988, Bain & Company discharged 90 professionals and administrators. One erstwhile vice president describes being called into his boss's office, only to be directed by the secretary to a room in the Marriott Hotel near Bain headquarters. There, his boss read from a prepared statement: ''We regret to inform you. . .'' The former officer, who had also been a partner, says, ''No one believed they'd just round up and shoot 90 people - that's the way you treat peons, not partners.'' He and some other Bainies still on staff believe that the targets were chosen at random.
Not so, says Bill Bain, who also points out that the firm hired outplacement consultants to ease the process. ''When you're dealing with something this emotional,'' he adds, ''what's best for all is a very counter-intuitive approach'' - which is to say, unemotional.
BAIN IS GENERALLY PER-ceived as holding its own. Between 1985 and 1987, James Kennedy claims, revenues doubled. According to Kennedy, revenues are now rising at an annual rate of about 10 percent. The fact that the client list has doubled in the last two years, while revenue growth was down, suggests that the firm has not had great success at attracting as many big-ticket, ''relationship'' clients.
One that got away, says a former Bain consultant, was Canadian Pacific. Bain handled projects for several of the company's divisions, but failed to penetrate the core railroad business. According to the Bain alumnus, instead of growing into a client on a par with Dun & Bradstreet, one of the firm's largest and oldest clients, Canadian Pacific ended its relationship after only a few years.
In Europe, where consultants are being deluged with business as companies prepare for economic unification, Bain has apparently been unable to find another client on the scale of Guinness. Still, with offices in London, Milan, Munich, Paris and Tokyo, the firm derives about a third of its revenue overseas.
Bill Bain contemplates the future with outward equanimity. He says all is well; that he would consider buying another firm, though he has nothing particular in mind; that he would consider a merger, though no company at the moment ''would make sense to us right now.'' There have been rumors in the industry that Bain might be bought by one of the big accounting firms. Would he sell his company? He responds, ''I always say never say never,'' but goes on to outline with his usual thoroughness just why it is not likely to happen.
At 9:30 on an August evening, Bill Bain sat in his office, listening patiently to the last question of the last interview, which had begun four hours earlier. Given the firm's obsession with secrecy, its determined public silence, why had he decided now to open up? He spoke of his pride in the firm and its accomplishments. ''What we actually do here,'' said Bill Bain firmly, ''isn't that mysterious.''
 
Enter The Accountants
IN 1971, MARVIN BOWER, A FORMER MANAGING DIRECTOR OF MCKINSEY & COMPANY, resigned as president of the Institute of Management Consultants, a leading professional association, to protest the admission of consultants from accounting firms. Such was the sentiment about letting mere number crunchers into the ranks of the prestige consulting firms.
The accountants ignored the slight and proceeded, in their methodical way, to take over. ''They just didn't pay attention to what the outside world said, and now they're the biggest players,'' says E. Michael Shays, the national director of the consulting practice at New York City-based BDO Seidman. Consulting revenues for the eight largest accounting firms last year totaled $3.9 billion, almost one-third of the consulting revenues tracked by Consultants News, a Fitzwilliam, N.H., publication.
Accounting firms got into consulting in a big way in the 50's with the advent of computerization. Early applications involved inventory control, payroll management and other back-office functions; the auditors were ideal candidates for advice on how to turn streams of data into useful information.
The upstarts were tolerated so long as they did not compete head-on with consultants. Ceding to accounting firms the more tedious tasks and ''cost-reduction studies'' - otherwise known as layoffs - that can leave middle management embittered, the consulting firms hoped to keep larger fields such as dereg-ulation, global competitiveness and mergers to themselves.
Still, all of those little pesky chores added up. ''When a $500 million company becomes a $2.7 billion one,'' says a McKinsey consultant, ''they'll remember Arthur Andersen helped them do it.'' And hire them again.
Indeed, Andersen recently helped the Swiss set up a computerized ''trading floor'' for futures and options. And a group of blue-jean-clad Andersen employees spent the summer videotaping workers on the factory floor of Harley-Davidson in an effort to foolproof a new line of small trucks. Andersen's contribution: color-coordinating the tools and chassis parts to insure proper assembly. Just in case a worker is color-blind, colors are spelled out on each part.
But the accounting firms' consultants have yet to parlay such experience into a reputation for getting big strategy engagements. ''They might have a little corner of the practice or a door with a sign on it that says 'strategic planning' division,'' says James H. Kennedy, publisher of Consultants News, ''but they're not in the same league.''
WITHIN SOME OF THE ACCOUNTING FIRMS, THE roaring success of the consulting operations has proven divisive, with consultants demanding an ever larger share of the firms' resources and profits. The two groups have also clashed over clients.
Two years ago, Andersen's consultants wanted to bid on a NASA contract jointly with Grumman Data Systems, a subsidiary of the Grumman Corporation; Andersen's accountants audit Grumman's books. But Securities and Exchange Commission rules ban auditors from having shared business interests with audit clients. That left Andersen with a choice: withdraw the bid or relinquish the audit. It kept the audit. ''When you're run by auditors, you tend to reach the former conclusion rather quickly,'' comments Gresham Brebach Jr., the former head of Andersen's American consulting practice, who says he left to form Information Consulting Group because of such clashes.
The risk of flare-ups is expected to increase now that a wave of mergers is whittling the Big Eight into a Big Five. But overall, the consulting arms of the accounting firms could emerge from the consolidation more formidable competitors than ever. A merger of Andersen and Price Waterhouse, still far from certain, would catapult the pair far ahead of the pack with $1.5 billion in consulting revenues - more than McKinsey, Booz-Allen & Hamilton, Bain & Company and the Boston Consulting Group combined.
Sheer size should help the accounting firms' consulting arms. Systems integration, a fast-growing niche wherein a consultant takes responsibility for a computer project from start to finish, may require that the consulting company make huge investments in technology. Being big may also yield dividends with managements, who prefer hiring large, established names, and in the recruiting wars, both on campus and in the ranks of the profession.
Touche Ross (which will merge with Deloitte, Haskins & Sells) snared 14 would-be consultants from the first-year class at the Harvard Business School by dangling salaries of $1,500 a week as bait. Coopers & Lybrand recently hired John Neuman, a former McKinsey specialist, while another well-regarded McKinsey consultant, Iain Somerville, joined Andersen.
It will be interesting to see how the accounting firms deal with their mergers. Andersen may seek outside help if it merges its operations with Price Waterhouse, even though Andersen itself counsels clients on consummating mergers. Says Peter H. Fuchs, head of strategic services at Andersen, ''It's often helpful to have an objective and outside perspective.'' ALISON LEIGH COWAN

HEADLINE: Rainmaker: Mario Baeza Of Devevoise

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton; Stephen Labaton covers legal affairs for The New York Times.

 BODY:
MARIO BAEZA LOOKS TROUBLED. IT IS A GRAY Tuesday morning in June and Baeza, a partner at the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton in New York, is sitting with a group of his colleagues in his 22d floor office, a diamond-shaped room with a dramatic view of Third Avenue.
''It's not going to work,'' says Baeza, a trim 38-year-old who stands 5 feet 9 inches tall and sports a mustache and goatee. He shakes his head, looking at a stack of stapled papers analyzing a deal code-named ''TIN MAN.''
''As it's structured, the directors are going to get sued to hell,'' Baeza says, in his calm, measured manner. ''They just can't deliver the company up on a platter. It's a nonstarter.'' 
Baeza's client, the New York-based investment banking firm of Kelso & Company, wants to buy the company. Joseph S. Schuchert, Kelso's chief executive, is convinced that the management team of one of his own companies, could help to increase TIN MAN's earnings. Schuchert also thinks the stock is undervalued, that the market has failed to reflect the true worth of the company's large real estate holdings.
The proposal Schuchert has laid on Baeza's desk calls for Kelso to buy the shares owned by an executive who is interested in cashing in his holdings - shares that, though considerably less than 50 percent, represent a controlling interest in the company. Kelso would pay almost double the price at which the shares are trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The executive and his allies on the board would resign, to be replaced by Kelso representatives. Eventually, TIN MAN could borrow against the company's assets to take the company private, streamline the operation and possibly go public again, a move that could prove highly lucrative.
But Baeza has his doubts. He fears that Kelso's purchase of the executive's block of stock, and the change in the board, would amount to what is known in securities law as a change in control. And any change in control requires an auction of the company to the highest bidder, a process to be avoided because the stock price would soar. Later that afternoon, Baeza conveys the bad news to Schuchert. ''I think we have some restructuring to do,'' Baeza says over his speaker phone.
''That's a diplomatic way of saying I'm screwing up what I want to do,'' Schuchert replies.
Baeza outlines the problem with Schuchert's plan: ''It amounts to a premium for one shareholder and not enough for the others.'' The board members, including the executive, would be ''abdicat-ing their responsibilities.''
''What if we ask him not to resign?'' Schuchert asks.
''That's helpful, but you get no control,'' Baeza responds.
The two continue discussing strategy.
''Twenty years ago, this was uncomplicated. You bought shares and that was that,'' Schuchert says. ''But that was before the Delaware law,'' says Baeza, a reference to the state where the target company, like many of the nation's leading businesses, is incorporated. ''Delaware merger law requires you to get consent of the board. Now the board's got some duties.''
The two men finally agree that Schuchert will meet with the executive to seek a preliminary agreement on the price and terms of the stock sale. Meanwhile, Baeza and his colleagues will try to figure out a way to get the deal done.
Two days later, Schuchert reports a success on his end, and Baeza is ready. His solution: Kelso would set up a holding company as a vehicle through which a Kelso company and the target company would merge; the new entity, with a reconstituted board, would then buy out the executive and pay other shareholders cash and securities. Control would be obtained without a costly auction.
FOR BAEZA, THE TIN man project is only the latest in a string of Kelso transactions. As is true of most buyout firms, fewer than half of the proposed deals reviewed by Kelso ever see the light of day. A competitor may come in with a higher bid. The target company may simply turn down Kelso's offer - the end of the line, since Kelso does not mount hostile takeovers.
Whatever the outcome, Debevoise and Baeza benefit. The Kelso connection has made Baeza (pronounced Buy-ay-sa) a deal maker extraordinaire, bringing high-stakes Wall Street takeovers to the middle-sized firm. The son of a man with a master's degree in economics who had to wait tables at Nedick's because of the color of his skin, Mario L. Baeza last year generated more than $12 million in billings at a firm with gross revenues of $119 million and 84 partners. He was born in Montclair, N.J., in 1951, the oldest of two sons of Marco Antonio and Alma Baeza. The family moved to Havana, Cuba, when he was two-and-a-half years old, then back to Montclair four years later just before the revolution broke out. His father, who was chairman of the department of economics, marketing and research at Seton Hall University, died of congenital heart disease at age 42 in 1965.
''I think about him every day,'' Baeza says. ''My skills as a deals lawyer came from him. He would have a cigar in one hand, and a brandy in the other, and he would throw out hypotheticals all the time.'' His mother is a special- education teacher in the Newark public school system.
In grammar school, Baeza was the only black student. His father's advice: ''Under no circumstances are you to let people call you names. I'd rather see you at the hospital bloodied.'' The first month, he had a fight every day. ''I was small but it didn't matter,'' he says, ''because my father said I could do it.''
At high school, Baeza proved to be gifted in several fields, including the outfield, where he played on the school team, eliciting an offer to join an Atlanta Braves farm team. He turned it down. He was elected president of the junior class and the student council. And he organized a band called Mario and the Immortals - he played guitar - that performed in New York City on weekends. ''We would play gigs on Friday night until past 2 in the morning,'' he remembers, ''go for food afterward and be done at about 4. We'd have to be ready for 8 o'clock baseball, so we would sleep in the car by the ball field to make sure that we didn't miss practice.''
Following in his father's footsteps, Baeza enrolled at Cornell University. His senior thesis traced the origins of Greek philosophy to the Egyptians and then sought to show that the Egyptians were black. He completed Cornell in three years, with a triple major in economics, government and psychology and a near-perfect grade-point average.
Upon arriving at Harvard Law School in the fall of 1971, Baeza says, he was troubled by the Socratic method, which emphasizes a dispassionate precision of analysis of legal procedure and precedent. ''They were teaching you to be enslaved to it,'' he recalls. ''I was afraid that if I got successful at it, I would be able to defend the Dred Scott decision. And I was deathly afraid that I would look at Brown v. Board of Education and say, 'There's a jurisdictional problem here, this isn't the right venue,' or some garbage like that.
''You sit at Harvard Law School with portraits of these huge legends on the wall staring back at you - all white faces - some of whom had argued in such a way that they would not have let me become a member of the bar. White students did not have to deal with that.
''There were 165 students in each section, maybe six other black students, and we all suffered the black tax. A professor calls on a black, and how he answers is a direct reflection on me. One guy answers badly, and everyone turns and looks at me. And I can't stand up and shout and beat my breast and say, 'Hey, I'm not here on some affirmative action. I got a 3.97 average at Cornell.' ''
When it came time to find a job, Baeza narrowed his choices down to Debevoise and Davis Polk & Wardwell. After discovering that John W. Davis had argued on the losing side of Brown v. Board of Education, he picked Debevoise.
FOUNDED IN 1931 BY ELI WHIT-ney Debevoise and William Stevenson, soon to be joined by Francis T. P. Plimpton, the firm is the very model of a white-shoe institution, a pillar of the establishment bar. Its early reputation was built largely on the Government careers of the founding partners. Debevoise became counsel to the High Commissioner for Germany in the early 50's. Plimpton gained national prominence as a delegate to the United Nations for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. Stevenson became ambassador to the Philippines and president of Oberlin College.
The present partners include several former senior Government officials and general counsels to major corporations. Some 49 percent of the lawyers attended Harvard, Columbia or Yale. The firm has nine former Supreme Court clerks, and close to a third of the lawyers have clerked for Federal judges. It also boasts that none of the partners has ever left to join another law firm.
This was the world into which Mario Baeza stepped in 1974. During his first few years, he primarily handled private debt and equity placement for insurance companies and large institutional investors, almost all of which could be done by telephone without meeting clients.
''I've always tried to look past a lot of what was said,'' Baeza recalls. ''My father once told me never to sit idly if someone calls you 'boy' and never to let anyone pat you on the head. I remember after completing some work, an older partner came in and patted me on the head and said, 'That's a good boy.' ''
Debevoise is loosely organized around five practice groups: corporate, litigation, tax, trusts and estates and real estate. Within those groups are ''secondary practice areas'' in which partners and associates specialize, the largest of which are securities and mergers and acquisitions. Lawyers at the firm say there is no rigid system of supervision, though partners are expected to attend a weekly luncheon.
Determined to become a partner, Baeza quickly selected the area in which he would specialize, and during his second year as an associate returned to Harvard to take a summer course in securities law. He then asked George N. Lindsay, a senior Debevoise partner whose brother, John, is the former mayor of New York, to be assigned to work on Cooper Laboratories, a major client involved in dozens of acquisitions. He was made partner in 1982, almost eight years after joining the firm.
Baeza's big break came the following year when Kelso walked in the door. Joseph Schuchert had decided to abandon his law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, which represents many takeover companies, because of recurrent conflicts of interest. The meeting with Baeza had been arranged by Rick Johnson, a Baeza classmate at Harvard, who at the time was a Kelso partner.
The combination seemed unlikely to work. Baeza had no experience with employee stock ownership plans, the vehicle Kelso uses to finance most of its acquisitions. In addition, Debevoise had instituted a freeze on new clients. But a certain chemistry developed between him and the Kelso executives, and Baeza ignored the freeze.
Since then, Kelso has become one of Debevoise's five largest clients. ''We keep going back to the well,'' Schuchert says. ''Mario is a large reason for our successes. He's a guy who pretty much came up on his own and is still humble about himself. I call it quiet power.'' T HE INVESTMENT FIRM WAS founded in 1970 by Joseph Schuchert and Louis O. Kelso. Trained as a lawyer, Kelso, 75, is widely regarded as the father of the employee stock-ownership plan, which was initially hailed as a means of achieving broader ownership of American capital. It was Schuchert, also a California lawyer, who concentrated on peddling ESOP's to corporate America and on Wall Street.
The theory is that by selling shares of a company to its workers, management is able to increase employee interest in the fate of the enterprise, and hence productivity. ESOP's sometimes also make it possible for management to trim costly pension plans. The greatest incentive for corporations to adopt the plans, however, came from Congress. Legislation has been enacted that significantly limits the taxes a company must pay on the proceeds of a stock sale to workers, as opposed to other ways to finance company activities.
Money raised through an ESOP may be used by the company to fund capital expenditures or finance other corporate activities. But in practice, the real profits are likely to come through the use of employee stock plans to finance the buyout of public companies. Once such a company has been revamped, it is typically taken public again, reaping staggering returns. If all goes as planned, the members of the employee stock plan may realize a bonanza. Baeza says he was seduced by ESOP's in an early deal when he learned that a secretary at the company involved had made a profit of $150,000.
In this field, Kelso is preeminent. Since Kelso first invested its own money in an ESOP-financed buyout in 1980, the company has completed more than 30 transactions as a principal, investing nearly $7 billion. Its investment portfolio has had a compound annual rate of return of more than 110 percent.
Critics contend that this use of ESOP's can put corporate retirement plans at risk. They also charge that by increasing the share of a company held by its employees, ESOP's can make a takeover more difficult, leaving a possibly incompetent management firmly in control. But for many a company concerned about being a possible takeover target, the employee stock plans are just what the doctor ordered.
Over the last two years, more than 200 public companies have established ESOP's. Polaroid used the strategy this year to ward off an attack by Shamrock Holdings Inc., an affiliate of Roy E. Disney. The ESOP plan adopted by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich in 1987 to thwart a hostile takeover by Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, was devised by Mario Baeza.
But the use of an employee stock plan is not a foolproof defense. The Department of Labor has recently advised that, under certain conditions, the ESOP trustee, who determines how the shares will be voted, has an obligation to cast his ballot in the best interest of the participants. That could mean a victory for the bidder. ''There will be instances when plans will come back to bite management,'' says Schuchert. KELSO'S $3 BILLION BUYOUT OF American Standard, manufacturer of plumbing fixtures, was the most complex task Baeza ever tackled, and among the largest in Debevoise's history. During a 45-day period in March and April of 1988, the firm billed more than 10,000 lawyer hours. Some 3.25 million copies of documents had to be duplicated.
The first task faced by Baeza and his team was to find a way to fend off a competing offer for American Standard from Black & Decker. Two months after the contest began, at Baeza's suggestion, Kelso offered to pay Black & Decker $25 million for its expenses, and the toolmaker agreed to walk away.
The Debevoise lawyers then devised the means to finance the buyout through a series of asset transfers to new subsidiaries, currency swaps, stock pledges and an ESOP - while avoiding as much tax liability as possible. The deal required supervision of lawyers in more than a dozen other countries where American Standard does business.
''I came away thinking Baeza was thoughtful and reasonably intelligent, serving his client well, while he was cooperative in helping me serve my client,'' says David M. Kies, a partner at Sullivan & Cromwell, which represented American Standard. The shareholders in the American Standard buyout have already seen the stock rise by more than 170 percent.
Beyond Kelso, Debevoise has used its new ESOP expertise to advise institutional clients, often insurance companies, who act as lenders, putting up cash to finance the issuing of new stock. Fifty percent of the interest income from these loans is tax-free, though there are moves in Congress to trim this advantage. Lawyers at the firm say that in the first half of 1989, Debevoise has done some $3.2 billion worth of these private placements.
The American Standard deal, along with several other large transactions, made 1988 the best year ever for Debevoise. The firm had revenue per lawyer of about $435,000 and average profits per partner of $610,000, according to The American Lawyer, ranking the firm as the 17th most profitable in the nation.
Baeza drew about $600,000 from the partnership last year. His hourly billing rate is between $300 and $400 an hour. Senior partners at the firm bill about $400, while the time of junior associates is billed at about $100. Debevoise has adopted, rather belatedly, the practice of premium billing, a growing trend among Wall Street law firms to charge clients a higher hourly rate on the biggest and most taxing deals. O NE MEASURE OF THE DIS-tance Mario Baeza has traveled in his climb to prominence at Debevoise is his close working relationship with Roswell B. Perkins, a senior partner and the quintessential establishment lawyer.
''Mario walks on water in Perkins's view,'' says a Debevoise corporate lawyer, ''and that is ironic. Rod is Fifth Avenue, New York high society and has been for decades. Before Mario made it, the only blacks here were in the mailroom. Now, Rod quotes Mario to others, saying, 'Mario says this and Mario says that.' ''
Perkins regularly refers clients to Baeza. Last summer, for example, Perkins urged executives of the Bessemer Securities Corporation, the investment arm of the Phipps steel fortune, to rely on Baeza to supervise a $300 million tender offer for Core-Mark International, a large distributor of tobacco products.
An indication of the relationship between the two men came last June when a Debevoise team, led by Baeza and Perkins, helped Kelso establish a $500 million war chest to finance leveraged buyouts. A major stumbling block was a requirement laid down by the New York State pension fund, one of the investment fund's largest players. The state insisted that when deals of equal potential arose, the investment fund should pursue the New York deal. That, of course, was not apt to sit well with investors from other states. The New York fund also demanded that the investment fund devise specific guidelines as to what constitutes a hostile takeover - a form of buyout in which the state fund refused to participate.
After considerable negotiation, Baeza told the advisers to the New York fund that no two deals are ever so equal that the question of their location would arise. He also told the state's lawyers that any precise definition of what constitutes a hostile bid was virtually impossible, particularly since so many of the Kelso offers involve management-led buyouts. He proposed that the fund's managers formulate some guidelines on the issue that would satisfy New York's concerns yet be flexible enough to allow Kelso to pursue deals it was interested in. In the end, the pension fund planned to invest $50 million.
Late one night, while Debevoise was still setting up the Kelso fund, Roswell Perkins found himself working at his desk, laboring to meet a tight deadline to close the deal. The senior partner's telephone rang. It was Baeza, the junior partner, checking in to see how Perkins was doing. Baeza had taken time off from a gala dinner he was attending, marking the 20th anniversary of the Dance Theater of Harlem; his wife, Della, is co-chairman.
Perkins smiles benignly when the episode is recounted. ''I enjoy enormously working with Mario,'' he says. ''He's a superb lawyer. He's highly analytical and perceptive, yet extremely pragmatic.''
As the firm's premier dealmaker, Baeza puts in his own share of torturous hours - he is not of the 9-to-5 persuasion. He has too many irons in the fire, professionally and personally. ''He gives us more responsibility than most other partners,'' says an associate at the firm. ''The upside is that unlike some, he's not always looking over your shoulder. He's also not stuffy or pretentious, as some partners are. The downside is that it can be a major effort to find him and sit him down and find out when he has time for you.''
Baeza has taught a course at Harvard Law School on emerging technologies and the law and is a member of the New York State Commission on Life and the Law, which issues recommendations for legislation in such areas as euthanasia and surrogate parenting. Tennis occupies part of his week. He is a composer whose works have been performed by Roberta Flack, a longtime friend. (She compares his composing talent to that of Elton John and Stevie Wonder.) And, as he did in high school, he leads a professional band that performs in New York clubs. Some years ago, the Baeza Connection played at an American Bar Association reception. Rock and jazz were the order of the day, and most of those attending seemed to enjoy the music, seldom heard at gatherings of the tradition-bound profession. A number of the older lawyers, however, visibly uneasy, plugged their ears with their fingers.
Says Kelso's Schuchert, with a grin, ''I hate him because he's good at too many things.''
While Kelso takes up about 60 percent of Baeza's time, his client list includes some major Harlem businesses, enterprises that have historically been eschewed by larger law firms. Says a Debevoise associate, ''He gives them the same service and attention as he does Kelso.'' He also charges his standard hourly fee.
One of Baeza's oldest clients is the Harlem Commonwealth Council, a nonprofit community development organization. Baeza has advised the council on the financing and other legal arrangements for a $21.5 million office tower it is developing next to the Apollo Theater on 125th Street. He is also advising the council on a $500 million hotel and office project in Washington that is a joint venture with the Western Development Corporation. Eugene Jackson, the founder of Mutual Black Network News and owner of several radio and cellular phone operations, has hired Baeza to help shape a bid for construction of the $160 million International Trade Center on Lenox Avenue.
In many of the Harlem deals, Baeza assists clients in formulating proposals for government and private funds and then oversees the complex legal work that accompanies such start-up projects. ''What's fun about this side of work is seeing jobs develop, seeing it happen,'' says Baeza. ''It's nice after doing tender offers. But often the issues are harder. The trade center, which entails funding from the State of New York as well as private sources, is a tougher deal because it is a private-public mix. All-private or all-public deals are usually easier.''
Baeza's office telephone has a direct line to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, where he is a member of the board. He is also a trustee at Cornell University, where he is particularly active in raising funds for minority scholarships.
Young black associates at Debevoise say they see Baeza as their guardian spirit. ''We all look to him,'' says Frank Gonzalez, a fifth-year associate. ''He talks to us regularly about the review process. But there's something special beyond that. I can go into his office, close the door and talk to Mario. It's a brother-to-brother conversation, like two blacks talking on the street.''
WITH HIS WIFE, WHO IS a graduate of Columbia Law School, and their two daughters, Baeza lives in a spacious house in Englewood, N.J. The couple met during the last week in December, 1983, at a contract closing. He was representing Gil Noble, the television journalist who was setting up the National Black Archives of Film and Broadcasting. She was representing ABC Television, which was contributing 13 years of ''Like It Is'' programs.
''I had seen his name on some legal papers and thought, Mario, he must be Italian,'' she recalls. Three days after meeting him, she went to a New Year's Eve party at his house. Within three months they were married. She has since curtailed her practice, spending more of her time with their daughters and with the Dance Theater of Harlem.
As the 1992 economic unification of Europe draws near, Baeza talks about tilting his practice more toward international finance. He says he has turned down offers to join the growing number of deal-making lawyers who have become investment bankers. But one firm that has not tried that tack is Kelso. ''It would be too great a loss if we lost him as our lawyer,'' Schuchert says. Then he adds, ''I would be surprised, but not very surprised, if he left to play music.''

The New York Times
