SECTION: Section 7; Page 44, Column 4; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 871 words

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
ABOUT YOUR BOOK ...

BYLINE: By DANIEL MENAKER; Daniel Menaker is an editor at The New Yorker.

 BODY:

GETTING PUBLISHED
The Acquisition Process at University Presses.
By Paul Parsons.
256 pp. Knoxville:
University of Tennessee Press. Cloth, $29.95.
Paper, $14.95.
In case anyone believes that university presses still operate solely in the dusty backyard of American publishing, he should stop and consider that 20 percent of all the National and American Book Awards since 1950 have gone to university press books. How this large and increasingly influential sector of publishing selects, edits and markets the 4,000 books it produces every year is the subject of Paul Parsons' ''Getting Published: The Acquisition Process at University Presses.'' This book will satisfy one's curiosity about the field, if one has a curiosity about the field. But much of it consists of the sort of careful, masonry-like, maddeningly well-documented writing that one associates with the dustier kind of university press volume:
''Manuscripts judged worthy by scholars in the field then advance to the third and final stage, review by the editorial committee. A group of home-campus faculty members and administrators serves as the final authority in determining whether to publish a work.'' 
How could it be otherwise? One is as likely to take an exhilarating voyage of intellectual discovery in the acquisition process at university presses as in the history of adhesive tape. And what we learn seldom departs from what we would have expected or even guessed:
* Editors at university presses generally see their function as the advancement and dissemination of knowledge.
* A university press usually specializes in certain fields or in certain topics, depending on the scholarly traditions of the institution it is affiliated with, or on regional factors, or on the interests of the editors.
* Very few university press books come in over the transom.
* Acquisition often follows personal contact between editor and writer/scholar or upon the endorsement of a young academic meteor by an older academic star.
* Competition for good books is growing keener.
* A university press's frontlist (new books) must to some degree complement its backlist (older books still in print).
* The decision to publish a book takes into account not only the manuscript's scholarly merit but its financial prospects, writing quality and suitability to the press's list as well.
Etcetera. For the most part, Mr. Parsons goes on in the same lawn-mowing style - ''Overall, competition is viewed positively by editors'' - with a few livelier anecdotes sprinkled in:
''Some editors rebel against main titles so literary or poetic that the reader has no idea what the book is about. One former editor did a spoof on the title Vision and Response, offering a set of possible subtitles:
''Vision and Response: A Study in Optics ''Vision and Response: A Case Study in Urban Renewal ''Vision and Response: The Mormon Trek Westward ''Vision and Response: The Effects of Pinups on Healthy Adolescent Males.''
So the bulk of this book will hold interest primarily for those directly or indirectly involved with the subject - university press editors themselves, editors of popular books, college administrators, fresh Ph.D.'s who want to avoid perishing, and so forth. For them, ''Getting Published'' will provide genuine insight and perhaps even guidance, however stolidly presented.
It is only the last quarter of the book that might take hold of the lay reader. Here Mr. Parsons, who teaches journalism and mass communications at Kansas State University, discusses the expansion of academic publishing into the area of trade books; the presses' new courtship of controversy; the question of whether scholarship is in any way served by the publication of fiction or poetry; the kinds of book series that are springing up all over the academic landscape; the grand projects that only university presses can undertake (such as the University of Chicago Press's publication of ''The Complete Works of Giuseppe Verdi''); the technological advances that hold the prospect of printouts of books on demand - thus eliminating ''brown mountain'' inventories in a warehouse; the ebb and flow of interest in various fields of scholarship; the plowing of new ones, such as historical geography and business history; and editors' fear of topics too hot to handle, like the racial theories of Arthur Jensen, the educational psychologist.
These topics lie a bit to the side of the domain of the acquisition process at university presses, but that's just as well since wandering away from the straight road of getting published appears to lighten Mr. Parsons' prose feet a little:
''At Yale, the papers of Benjamin Franklin have been appearing one volume a year for more than two decades, with at least two more decades to go. Yale also has begun work on the papers of an entire family - the Peales. In a showdown of families, Harvard is planning at least one hundred volumes for the Adams family papers.''
In a word or two, then, Mr. Parsons' book is a helpful and sometimes interesting work. But we should probably begin to worry at the next stage - when some scholar writes a book about books about getting published at university presses.

584 of 722 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2716 words

HEADLINE: FROM THE CAMPUSES: ADVENTURES IN PUBLISHING

BYLINE: By ROY REED; Roy Reed teaches journalism at the University of Arkansas, Fayetteville.

 BODY:
How much simpler this country would be if it had stalled out at 13 states. Most of the complicated mountains, climates and ethnic cultures would lie west of the border, as would all of the intimidating plains and deserts. Visiting the Great Lakes would be a foreignJU adventure.
It is possible to believe in some such abbreviated nation if you study the paperback titles and commercial best sellers at any popular bookstore. An interplanetary intellectual set down at the book stand in O'Hare International Airport would quickly surmise that the United States was an uninterrupted urban mass inhabited by a prosperous race with a taste for mystery, horror, sex and self-indulgence. Except for an occasional western by Louis L'Amour or a Gothic romance set in Dixie, the books would reveal a practically seamless America, free of landscape and geography, with just enough human differences to provide a plot line for a movie. 
Fortunately, book publishing in the United States is not left entirely to the conglomerates that fill the airport book stands. There is a thriving publishing industry among university presses. Traditionally, these enterprises have mainly printed works of scholarship, but in recent generations they have moved into other areas as well. One of their current enthusiasms is regional titles - books that recognize bumps in the American map, books that show the upheavals and extremities, the grizzly bears and jack rabbits, above all the fierce cultural diversity that thrives beyond the constricted coastal ribbon that runs between Boston and Washington.
''American commercial publishing has been dominated by New York and the Northeast. Many areas of the country had no voice,'' Kenneth Cherry, director of the University Press of Kentucky, said recently. ''Many books of regional interest would not be widely disseminated if it were not for state university presses. The university presses are really important as our culture becomes more homogeneous, dominated by groups that control our national communications networks.''
Ben H. Bagdikian, the media critic, recently declared that five corporations dominate the world's communications industry. All five publish books, among other endeavors.
Three are especially interesting for the famous old names they now own. Time Warner, the newest conglomerate in the field, owns not only Warner mass-market paperbacks but also Little, Brown & Company, Scott, Foresman & Company, Time-Life Books and the Book-of-the-Month Club. A German company, Bertelsmann, owns Doubleday, Bantam Books, Dell and the Literary Guild. Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation owns Harper & Row and a big piece of Viking Penguin.
These huge companies compete for proven, risk-free ideas. They want books that make money, that will spin off readily into movies, television shows, paperbacks and T-shirts. That means hugging the beaten path. You will not find regional, small-market books on that path.
Imagine Bertelsmann's Doubleday arranging an appearance on the ''Today'' show for George W. Knepper so that he could talk about his new book, ''Ohio and Its People.'' Mr. Knepper has a sure grasp of Ohio's history and culture, and he shows a certain knack for phrase-making: ''Ohio was a salad bowl of peoples, not a melting pot.'' But would anyone at Doubleday consider ''Ohio and Its People'' a potential best seller? Kent State University Press published the book this year, even though it does not expect to get rich from the sales.
Or imagine Harper & Row publishing the 11-volume ''Journals of the Lewis and Clark Expedition.'' The University of Nebraska Press did not hold its breath waiting. It has already published five volumes, and the sixth is due next spring.
At a cost of several hundred dollars a set, the ''Journals'' will not be a blockbuster best seller. No one at Harper & Row will regret passing them up.
Diane K. Wanek of the marketing department of the University of Nebraska Press put it this way: ''Only a nonprofit scholarly press could have successfully undertaken this ambitious publishing project in this era of 'bottom line' and 'cash flow' that the commercial publishing houses are living in today.''
What bottom-line commercial publisher would risk its cash flow on ''The Common Loon: Spirit of Northern Lakes'' by Judith W. McIntyre (University of Minnesota Press)? Or ''Cutthroat: Native Trout of the West'' by Patrick C. Trotter (Colorado Associated University Press)? Or ''Violence in the Model City,'' a study of the 1967 race riots in Detroit, by Sidney Fine (University of Michigan Press)?
For better or worse, 20th-century America is richly, crankily diverse. We are a nation of tribes and territories. Among the tribal concerns addressed in this year's lists from university presses are the following:
* ''Holding the Line: Women in the Great Arizona Mine Strike of 1983'' by Barbara Kingsolver (ILR Press, a division of the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations).
* ''The Last Resort: Success and Failure in Campaigns for Casinos'' by John Dombrink and William N. Thompson, on campaigns for legalized casino gambling in various regions. The publisher? The University of Nevada Press, of course. The same press has just published the first Basque-English dictionary, a reflection of the Basque influence in the far West.
* ''Thomas Morris Chester, Black Civil War Correspondent: His Dispatches From the Virginia Front'' by R. J. M. Blackett (Louisiana State University Press). Chester was the only black correspondent for a major daily newspaper during the Civil War. As a captain in a black company from Pennsylvania, he sent stories to The Philadelphia Press.
* ''Dark Journey'' by Neil R. McMillen (University of Illinois Press), on how it was being a black person in Mississippi during the time of Jim Crow.
* ''Even Mississippi'' by Melany Neilson (University of Alabama Press), on how it was being a Mississippi belle during the dying of Jim Crow. [Reviewed on page 49.] Nationally - that is, as we see ourselves on the evening news - we seem to be running away from our history, hoping to forget it. But out in the territories, among the tribes, history refuses to die.
The University of Arkansas Press this year republished one of the best histories of the state ever written. ''Arkansas,'' by John Gould Fletcher, was first published in 1947 by the University of North Carolina Press, a pioneer in regional publishing. It was in danger of being forgotten except by academics.
The book is not merely history. Mr. Fletcher, a native of Little Rock, spent much of his life in Europe in the company of people like Ezra Pound and Amy Lowell. He won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 1939. After returning to Arkansas, he became associated with the Agrarian movement and, possibly fired by that interest, he wrote an ode to his agrarian home.
Here is the way his mind saw the mountains of the Ozarks: ''These are divided by steep winding hollows, through which the streams straggle irregularly like the branches of a vine.''
And the empty cotton fields of the delta: ''From November to April here, nothing is to be seen but the frost-blackened ghosts of the plant, with a few white strands dangling, or the naked furrows of brown earth, already headed up for future planting.''
The big publishers have little interest in tribal matters, not even those that become strands of the national memory. One day a couple of years ago, I needed to know the birth date of Orval E. Faubus, the governor of Arkansas who became world-famous in 1957 for provoking the first constitutional crisis over school desegregation. He forced President Dwight D. Eisenhower to send the Army to Little Rock. I opened my desk copy of ''Webster's American Biographies,'' which boasts ''comprehensive, biographical information on more than 3,000 significant Americans, from Hank Aaron to Vladimir Zworykin.'' Mr. Faubus was not listed.
I decided on the spot to write a biography of him. I asked an agent to find a publisher. With some embarrassment, he reported that no one in New York wanted the book. Orval Faubus was no longer salable.
I am at work on the book, anyway. The University of Arkansas Press wants it.
The director of that press is Miller Williams. He has run it since it was founded in 1980 (which makes it one of the youngest of the 100 members and international affiliates of the Association of American University Presses). Like John Gould Fletcher, Mr. Williams is a poet and a man of strong language.
''When Bennett Cerf and Alfred Knopf were making the decisions, the commercial press published some books that they simply thought ought to be published,'' he said. ''They published out of a sense of duty and pride. They saw themselves as gentlemen publishers.
''Families no longer hold those companies. Corporations own them, and acquisitions are made as business decisions, by business people, not editorial people. They look at the profit and loss statement and decide that it would be hurt by publishing poetry or non-genre books or the non-blockbuster novel.''
The non-blockbusters find an increasingly chilly reception in the commercial press. Mr. Williams figures that Flannery O'Connor would have trouble selling ''Wise Blood'' to a commercial publisher today.
Mr. Bagdikian reports that after the German conglomerate bought Doubleday, it pruned the company's trade list by a third. That got rid of a lot of books that could not be spun off into movies, paperbacks or other profitable enterprises.
Beginning writers and those who have not achieved commercial success are further threatened by the quirks of the book distribution system, in which the non-blockbuster is not pushed by either salesmen or bookstores.
Mr. Williams said, ''I would almost say that the First Amendment guarantee is called into question if economic forces make it difficult to appeal to the larger society.''
Then there is the effrontery. Mr. Williams's friend John Ciardi, who died in 1986, was ready to send his selected poems - ''the all-time greatest hits by John Ciardi,'' as Mr. Williams put it - to his publisher, W. W. Norton, when, he told Mr. Williams, he learned that Norton had pulped the remaining copies of his last volume, ''For Instance,'' without notifying him. (Norton still publishes the paperback edition of the book.) The University of Arkansas Press was happy to become his publisher.
That was in 1983. Since then, Arkansas has published six volumes of poetry and prose by Mr. Ciardi. A seventh, a book of essays, will be published this fall.
University presses often resurrect books of national interest that the commercial publishers have dropped.
''Black Elk Speaks,'' the reflections of a holy man of the Sioux, told through the English of John G. Neihardt, was first published by Morrow in 1932. The book languished until the 1960's, when young Americans looking for spiritual reinforcement discovered it. The book was eventually taken up by the University of Nebraska Press, which probably will keep it in print for years to come.
The University of Texas Press last year reprinted ''The Raven,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning biography of Sam Houston by Marquis James. The book was first printed by Bobbs-Merrill in 1929.
In 1935, Houghton Mifflin published ''The Texas Rangers'' by Walter Prescott Webb. The book flourished for a while, then was abandoned. The University of Texas Press picked it up in 1965 and has since run it through 12 printings.
''The Valley of Decision,'' the best-selling novel by Marcia Davenport, was published in 1942 by Charles Scribner's Sons. It faded from sight eventually. The University of Pittsburgh Press brought it out in paperback this year.
Indiana University Press last year published a reprint of one of Gene Stratton-Porter's novels, ''Laddie: A True Blue Story.'' It was originally published by Grosset & Dunlap in 1917.
The University of Arkansas Press picked up the Welsh poet R. S. Thomas when Mr. Williams learned that his commercial publisher, St. Martin's Press, had stopped publishing poetry. Arkansas has also resurrected two out-of-print novels by John E. Williams, ''Stoner'' and ''Butcher's Crossing.''
University presses have carved out other areas that seem not to interest the large commercial houses. Now that E. B. White is dead, for example, the big companies apparently see no future in publishing essays. University presses are printing a lot of them.
Specialty areas covered by university publishers can be quite extensive. No one prints more Southern history than Louisiana State University Press. Notre Dame and Catholic University of America have a lock on Irish and Irish Catholic studies. At least 31 university presses concern themselves with Asian studies, 27 with African studies, six with Judaic studies.
Practically every university press publishes a biography or two a year. Many of the subjects are local heroes and villains. Some are national and international figures. Harvard University Press this fall will publish a newly revised edition of Ernest Samuels' biography of Henry Adams and a new biography of Hector Berlioz by D. Kern Holoman.
Reference works have long been a strength of some of the larger presses. The Columbia Encyclopedia was first published by the Columbia University Press in 1935. The same press published the ''Columbia Literary History of the United States'' last year.
Harvard published in 1985 the first volume (A through C) of the Dictionary of American Regional English, edited by Frederic G. Cassidy. It goes from A, the indefinite article, sometimes pronounced er (''Jones Negro Myths 37 GA coast, Buh Tiger come out in er hurry, and dey graff hold er one anurrer'') to Czarnina (''traditional Polish soup made with duck's blood, pork, prunes, apples, and seasonings'').
For all their recent successes, university presses are not about to take over American publishing. Practically all of them are squeezed for money. Many are subsidized by their universities, and when university revenues suffer, so do the presses. Public universities are especially anxious now because of constricted Government funding. In addition, a large market for university press books, libraries, is shrinking. The libraries are hit by the same cut in public funding and have less money for buying books.
But the presses continue to expand. The 100 members of the Association of American University Presses published 6,964 new titles in 1988. That was almost a 70 percent increase in 10 years.
The presses are selling about $225 million worth of books a year. Euan H. Phillips, executive director of the association, said recently, ''Our statistics indicate that a cross-section of our membership raised their sales 36 percent over the last three years, with the smaller presses recording increases far above the average.''
The university presses are doing well, partly because of built-in economic advantages that the commercial houses do not enjoy. Many pay no rent for offices and warehouses. They get grants, endowments and low-interest loans. They are under little pressure to make a profit, although that advantage recedes a little each year as the host universities tighten their belts.
For tax reasons, commercial publishers do not keep large inventories of slow-selling books. University presses, exempt from this and other tax problems, can leisurely build their backlists. That makes the university publishers attractive to authors who like to see their books available for years after publication.
Some of these advantages are threatened, but not as seriously as the commercial competitors would perhaps like. There is evidence that the commercial houses are taking notice of their country cousins.
Donald Lamm, chairman and president of Norton, a speaker at the June meeting of the association, warned his noncommercial colleagues that they would meet ''stiff resistance'' if they poached trade titles from the commercial press. He also portrayed the university presses as operating from ''a privileged sanctuary: tax-free status, university subsidies, foundation grants, low-cost labor, below-market rents.''
No one had the bad manners to talk about publishing from the privileged sanctuary of a billion-dollar conglomerate.

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
HOW ONE RUSSIAN DREAM WENT AWRY

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER; Bill Keller is the Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:

BEHIND THE URALS
An American Worker in Russia's City of Steel.
By John Scott.
Enlarged edition prepared by Stephen Kotkin.
306 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press.
Cloth, $27.50; Paper, $9.95.
In 1931, John Scott dropped out of the University of Wisconsin, itchy with wanderlust and disenchanted by the misery of the American Depression. He contemplated a motorcycle trip to Alaska, to be followed by a sea crossing in a homemade sailboat to Siberia and China. Instead, he took a welding course and embarked for Russia to help Joseph Stalin build a steel mill in Magnitogorsk, on the frozen eastern slope of the Ural Mountains - to, as he put it, ''lend a hand in the construction of a society which seemed to be at least one step ahead of the American.'' 
He hoped to join a people free from ''the fetishization of material possessions'' that his father, Scott Nearing, a radical economics professor at the University of Pennsylvania's prestigious Wharton School of Business, had taught him was a basic ill of American civilization. ''I was going to be one of many,'' he wrote, ''who cared not to own a second pair of shoes, but who built blast furnaces which were their own.''
Like John Reed, the American journalist who played cheerleader for the Bolshevik Revolution 15 years earlier, Scott kept detailed notes that he turned into a book. While Reed's ''Ten Days That Shook the World'' became a political classic, Scott's memoir, ''Behind the Urals,'' has remained a Russia-watcher's cult book. That is understandable. Scott is no match for Reed as a mythologizer, and his topic, Stalin's first five-year plan, is not the natural stuff of best sellers. Nor are his subjects heroic, like the firebrands of Petrograd; they are underfed and threadbare Russian peasants negotiating icy scaffolding in minus-35-degree Siberian winters to construct the world's largest steel mill.
Nonetheless, of the two memoirs, ''Behind the Urals,'' first published in 1942 and newly reissued with some valuable additions, is the more relevant to the Soviet Union of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The city of steel that Scott helped erect is a microcosm of the problems Mr. Gorbachev has inherited: a crash-built and now collapsing industrial plant, a corrupt command economy, the chronic sacrifice of individual life and dignity and the brutal tradition of the police state. At a time when Americans are again flocking wide-eyed to celebrate seismic change in the Soviet Union, this memoir is a cautionary tale for those inclined to euphoria.
When Scott reached Magnitogorsk in September 1932, Stalin had just completed the forced collectivization of the nation's farmers, Lenin's experiment with a mixed economy had been crushed and a starving countryside had been cruelly pressed into service to feed the workers who would build new industry. ''We are fifty to one hundred years behind advanced countries,'' Stalin declared in a nationalistic exhortation to factory managers in 1931. ''We must cover this distance in ten years. Either we do this or they will crush us.''
Hunkered behind the Urals, 1,000 miles from the nearest hostile border, the ragtag people of Magnitogorsk set about building a defensible industrial stronghold. The work force consisted of Bashkiri sheepherders and displaced peasants, wide-eyed pioneers from the Young Communist League, petty criminals and a large number of foreign mercenaries and idealists.
Stalin, no economist, relied on ruthless administration to carry out his transformation of backward Russia. Central planning, which other countries had used as an expedient during World War I, was adopted as the basis of the entire economy. Scott calculated that about a third of the workers were forced labor, many of them former kulaks stripped of their farms in punishment for being more successful than their neighbors.
Methodically recording the grotesque mismanagement and cruelty, Scott noted that the managers at Magnitogorsk spend about half their time trying to wheedle the rivets to fulfill the impossible plans decreed from Moscow, the other half trying to devise ideologically correct excuses for falling short. Workers tumbled from blast furnaces because the scaffolding had been stripped for firewood. And as Stalin's paranoia played itself out in merciless purges, the few inventive managers disappeared in the company of the secret police. The victims of political repression were stacked atop the victims of cold and deprivation. ''I would wager that Russia's battle of ferrous metallurgy alone involved more casualties than the battle of the Marne,'' Scott writes. Elsewhere, he says that ''money was spent like water, men froze, hungered, and suffered, but the construction work went on with a disregard for individuals and a mass heroism seldom paralleled in history.''
With an attentive eye for detail, he describes exhausted workers assembling in the early morning dark; a foreman thawing an ink jar under a wood-burning stove before taking care of his paperwork; a horrifying visit to the local dentist, who wore a blood-spattered smock; a night at the local theater, where the company performed a propagandistic melodrama about a German school for spies. The prose sometimes reads like a stiff translation from the Russian, and a general reader will find rather too much about the workings of a rolling mill. But it is a rich portrait of daily life under Stalin.
As a foreigner and a gung-ho Communist, Scott was part of the elite, with freedom to travel widely in a region little visited by outsiders. He learned Russian, enrolled in the party university, married a Russian woman. Yet in the end he fell victim to the growing xenophobia. Shunned at the plant, he moved to Moscow, where he waited four years for permission to take his wife out of the country. He accepted this stoically, with the observation that ''Westerners have no place in Russia.''
Scott is at his worst when he stops being a chronicler of events and sets out to analyze, as he does in the book's confused closing chapter, ''What Makes Russia Click.'' Here, his awe at the audacity of the industrial transformation overrides both his moral indignation and his judgment.
Now that even Soviet thinkers are looking back on the 1930's as the period when the Communist dream went horribly awry, it is a little bizarre to read Scott's conclusion that, on balance, Stalin's brutality was justified. He writes, evidently without irony, that the kulaks were liquidated for ''the worthy cause of agricultural collectivization.'' After conveying the absurd horror of the purges and correctly tracing their roots to the Bolshevik intolerance of opposition, he then insists that the casualties of Magnitogorsk were vindicated by the Soviet Union's subsequent victory over Hitler, in which the tanks and guns from the Urals stronghold made a decisive difference.
As Stephen Kotkin, who teaches history at Princeton University and prepared this new edition of Scott's book, points out in his introduction, the notion that Stalin's frenetic version of industrialization was vital to the defeat of fascism is arguable, even leaving aside the moral questions. One can contend, as some Soviet historians now do, that the purges accompanying industrialization, not to mention Stalin's decimation of his officer corps on the eve of the war, weakened the country before the Nazi onslaught. Moreover, the Soviet Union prevailed despite Stalin's willful disregard of the evidence that Hitler was preparing to attack, a blunder that led in large part to the Nazi capture of roughly half of all Soviet industry.
In fact, Scott himself was far more disillusioned by his experience than he let on in his book, which was published when the United States and the Soviet Union were allied against Hitler. Some years after returning home in 1941, he became a devout anti-Communist missionary. Until his death in 1976, he traveled the world as a Time-Life editor and business consultant, preaching that a dangerously inhumane system lurked behind the seeming allures of Communism. Because of restrictions imposed by Scott's family, which did not follow Scott's political path, none of this is mentioned in Mr. Kotkin's introduction.
Scott could not have foreseen the extent to which Stalin failed even on his own terms. Yes, the achievements of industrialization were undeniable. By the late 1930's the Soviet Union had mines and factories approaching the level of Germany's, and the Russian peasantry had been recast as a literate (albeit disorganized and impoverished) blue-collar work force. But it was a country that knew how to move only at a forced march. And when the command center relaxed under Stalin's successors, the country slackened into indolence and corruption.
One wonders what Scott would make of Magnitogorsk today. It is a misbegotten place, a mockery of the utopian dream of an egalitarian workers' state. The vast steel mill is a good 20 years out of date, a wheezing dinosaur. Outside the satanic open-hearth furnaces, a mountain of slag blows about in the summer wind, adding grit to the foul, multicolored discharge from the smokestacks. The ideal socialist city that was to surround the plant was never realized. Most residents live either in domino high-rises of shoddy construction or in communal barracks. Meat, butter and sugar are still rationed, as they were in 1932.
Among the older inhabitants one finds a nostalgia for the boldness and clear purpose of Stalin's ''great change.'' But most of Magnitogorsk, given a chance, would probably succumb happily to the ''fetishization of material possessions'' that Scott in his youth was so determined to flee.

LENGTH: 1158 words

HEADLINE: CRIME

BYLINE: By MARILYN STASIO

 BODY:
Early in Martha Grimes's 10th mystery, THE OLD SILENT (Little, Brown, $18.95), Richard Jury of Scotland Yard finds himself in need of ''a calm book'' - something to stave off one of those bouts of melancholy to which this romantic detective is inclined, and to ease the bleakness of a winter's day in Yorkshire. He notices that an attractive woman stopping at the inn where he's staying is reading Camus's ''Myth of Sisyphus.'' (''Not a calm book at all.'') He also notices when she pulls out a gun in the dining room and shoots her husband dead.
The calm moments in this moody mystery about parental ties and family schisms and relationships thicker than blood are as fine as anything Ms. Grimes has written. Her still, perfectly contained descriptions - of a fruit orchard desolate in winter; of the face of a woman lost in a memory of her dead child; of a sheep hunt on the moor after a snowstorm - concentrate the emotions of a scene without spilling a word. 
The same economy of style serves the author for the prickly-funny Dickensian characterizations that have become her trademark. As Jury trudges through Bronte country, puzzling over the enigmatic murderer and digging out the secrets of her past, he and his aristocrat friend, Melrose Plant, encounter many priceless specimens of local humanity, including a fiercely independent little girl Plant calls ''the Fury'' and another child so neat and clean she looks ''as if she'd been licked clean by cats.'' In one remarkable chase scene across the frozen moor, Ms. Grimes even manages an entirely credible entry into the minds of two dogs.
This American author who dares to write of things British and in a British idiom (each novel takes its title from a local pub that figures in the story) has developed her style well beyond its early, charming ways. But her techniques of plotting and structure take a nose dive here. After establishing a plausible mystery around a long-ago kidnapping of two children, she wanders too far from the Yorkshire moors - all the way to London's hectic rock-music world - to resolve it. The city characters and scenes are interesting enough for a book of their own; but their noisy energy shouts down the atmospheric tone of the original narrative, with its somber country landscape, broody characters and time-bound story.
Not a calm book, after all, to inflict such culture shock.
 
*
 No wonder the folks in Durango call it ''The City That God Forgot.'' Ross Thomas really rubs it in, in THE FOURTH DURANGO (Mysterious Press, $18.95), that Father Serra forgot to build a mission in this tiny California town (pop. 9,861), condemning it to a future without tourists. Sprinkling salt on that unkind cut, the highway engineers forgot to build a decent road through the mountains, and the railroad builders forgot to provide access to the ocean. All of which makes the fourth Durango - it's not in Spain; it's not in Mexico; it's not in Colorado; it's nowhere - the ideal hideout for a man with a price on his life.
For a fee, the shrewd mayor and her loyal chief of police offer sanctuary to a judge who has just done time on a cooked-up bribery charge. The judge and his son-in-law, a disbarred lawyer, move into ''the only money-losing Holiday Inn west of Beirut'' and devise a plan for smoking out the person with the vendetta against the judge. For an even bigger fee, the mayor and her top cop are game to conspire in the scheme - until an extremely ugly man comes to town and starts shooting up the citizenry.
We already know how witty Mr. Thomas can be about entrepreneurial greed and political chicanery, from the sophisticated thrillers he sets in such cities as Singapore, Hong Kong and Washington. But Durango is a revelation. Although the town operates on civic codes of ethics that would have Hammurabi tearing at his beard, its ex-hippie mayor and unorthodox laws keep the place running in its own rather wonderful time warp. Give us a road map and a passport - and keep those tourists out.
 
*
 David Williams's urbane banker-sleuth, Mark Treasure, saunters to the rescue of yet another embattled British institution in HOLY TREASURE! (St. Martin's, $15.95). When a Pastoral Committee declares an Anglican church in North London ''redundant,'' its wealthy patron and a handful of parishioners rally to keep the crumbling edifice open and solvent. But when the vicar's wife is murdered, Treasure's eyebrows elevate at the church's many would-be saviors, his own investment clients among them, who would take over its rich real estate holdings in the name of charity.
Clever sleuthing and genteel social satire provide the pleasure in this light, leisurely whodunit. The local church worthies are an amusing lot, and Mr. Williams gets in some nice digs at an American televangelist group called Investors for Jesus, whose worldly ministry a representative thus rationalizes: ''Some of us have to make up in practical zeal what we lack in spirituality.''
Treasure himself is not nearly as erudite or as all-fired charming as Michael Innes's Sir John Appleby, a gentlemanly detective to whom he bears an obvious resemblance. But he definitely cultivates the dry wit and coolly discerning air of his superior kind - even to the ''mock pomposity'' that, after a dozen outings in this series, has become one of his more endearing traits.
 
*
 Ben Wellman, the sensitive police-detective hero of Thomas H. Cook's STREETS OF FIRE (Putnam, $19.95), feels ''trapped on some bizarre and unforgiving front, a man between the lines'' when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. comes to Birmingham, Ala., to lead the city's black residents in their eventful 1963 civil rights marches. ''I guess you might say I'm trying to stay out of it,'' he says uneasily, when the chief of police calls out the fire hoses and unleashes the dogs. In an effort to sort out his own tangled loyalties and muddled beliefs, and as a way of avoiding the racial bonfires in the city, this decent cop throws himself into a case that nobody else wants - the rape-murder of a 12-year-old black girl, which turns out to have far-reaching racial and political implications.
Mr. Cook writes with powerful poignancy about his hero's struggles of personal conscience. His unsparing accounts of the city's racist climate also carry painful conviction. It is only when he reaches for epochal significance that the author overburdens his story with its historical context. Characters become sentimentalized; all events turn portentous; actions lose their ambiguity of motive; and a tone of overwrought lyricism drenches the narrative in melodrama.
''She was a little girl,'' Sergeant Wellman says of his sad case. ''I don't like what happened to her.'' That simple, admirable sense of human scale is precisely what becomes distorted when the author contrives to turn the child into Iphigenia at Aulis and sacrifices her to a history lesson in race relations.

HEADLINE: A COVENANT WITHTHE SOIL

BYLINE: By MAXINE KUMIN; Maxine Kumin raises horses on a farm in New Hampshire. Her most recent books are ''Nurture,'' a collection of poems, and ''In Deep: Country Essays.''

 BODY:

FARM
A Year in the Life of an American Farmer.
By Richard Rhodes.
Illustrated by Bill Greer. 336 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
Richard Rhodes, whose 1987 ''Making of the Atomic Bomb'' garnered the major book awards, grew up in Missouri. From the age of 12 he lived in a boys' home on a farm near Independence, where he developed a close acquaintance with such labor-intensive practices as mucking out barns and chicken houses, docking lambs and picking tomatoes. In an early, poignant essay in his book ''The Inland Ground: An Evocation of the American Middle West,'' he says of his boyhood that he was called back from despair during this bleak time by ''the land and the animals and the work . . . those daily regularities that insist on the continuation and preservation of the world.'' 
In this earlier work, Mr. Rhodes also reports on a visit to the I-D Packing Company, the only plant that would allow him entry, tape recorder in hand. The screaming of pigs wedged onto the ramp that moves them inexorably to their deaths ''had to remind me,'' Mr. Rhodes writes, ''of things no one wants to be reminded of any more, all mobs, all death marches, all mass murders. . . . We are the most expensive of races, able in our affluence to hire others of our kind to do this terribly necessary work of killing another race of creatures so that we may feed our oxygen-rich brains.''
''Farm'' reminds us. Mr. Rhodes brings empathy and intelligence to his subject, and he projects for the reader that continuing identification with the day-to-day complexities, disappointments and gratifications encountered by his pseudonymous family, the Bauers.
Like those of most independent small farmers hemmed in by agribusinesses, the Bauers' holdings are modest. They farm 337 acres of their own in central Missouri and another 779 acres on shares with three landlords, a far cry from the 6,000- to 20,000-acre spreads that are not uncommon on the still-rich flatlands that were once prairie.
Despite a daily year-round schedule that would make an urban construction worker quail, the Bauers' net return for the year that Mr. Rhodes was in attendance was just about $19,000. Land values plummeted during the Reagan years, reducing the Bauers' net worth by half. Constantly changing Federal regulations regarding crop rotations, percentages of land set aside to lie fallow and fluctuating Government loan rates require scrupulous attention to paper work. Many older farmers, baffled by these bureaucratic procedures, have opted out of programs that might have helped them. ''One rule alone had 1,004 changes in one year,'' Mr. Rhodes tells us. By the end of the year, the Bauers finally decide to give up on Government subsidy programs and take their chances on the open market. According to Mr. Rhodes, thrift, independence, family unity, diversity of crops and animals and a strong dose of native intelligence indicate that this family may indeed prosper while others go bankrupt.
A major portion of ''Farm'' deals with the machinery of modern farming: the tractors, mowers, planters, cultivators, the all-purpose pickups and dump trucks and especially the combines that have taken over the role, for example, of the 40-mule hitch that pulled all 15 tons of the first combine through the wheat fields of California a mere 150 years ago.
The modern combine is almost terrifyingly adroit. It reduces the number of times corn or soybeans or wheat has to be handled to get it from the field into the silo down to an all-in-one operation. It eliminates the need for those immense farm families of the past, where every child from toddler size on up had a serious and exhaustingly repetitive job to perform during the harvesting season. It has reprieved the farm wife, who once not only prepared huge meals for a crew of hungry hands, but also hauled cold drinking water out to the fields during daylight hours.
Intensive farming methods have taken the plod out of plowing, women and children and hired hands out of the fields. At the same time, those methods all too often compact the soil; reduce organic matter; endanger wildlife by plowing, as the former Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz commanded, ''from fence row to fence row''; leave chemical residues on food, and pollute the water supply.
Since World War II, there has been a tenfold increase in the amount of herbicides, insecticides, fungicides and other toxic chemicals used on the land, an alarming progression in view of the fact that, as the writer Verlyn Klinkenborg puts it, ''The oldest black-loam farms of the Midwest have just passed the century mark. Many already suffer from the chronic ills of contemporary tillage. . . . How will they look at 350 years? What will they grow?''
Surprisingly, these matters never come under discussion in ''Farm.'' Nitrate contamination of ground water, although a real and omnipresent threat, receives no mention. Rachel Carson warned us 25 years ago that nature does not operate in isolation, and that pollution of ground water is total pollution.
Anyone hoping for enlightenment here on plant varieties that are resistant to insects and diseases and that require minimal applications of fertilizers will be disappointed. (Tom Bauer's one experiment with hybrid wheat is a disaster, and he plans not to repeat it.) A regenerative farm rotates its crops; 50 percent of today's farmers do not practice rotation. Mr. Bauer rotates his corn and soybeans. He is a minimalist when it comes to synthetic fertilizers, lagooning his pig wastes and redelivering them to his fields. He also spreads whatever cow manure is generated by his small herd. But when it is time to plant corn, the granulated fertilizer truck precedes him down the rows. And earlier, he knifes in nitrogen in the form of anhydrous ammonia, a pressurized liquid. This dangerous but economical procedure is commonplace on the large flat fields that make its application feasible.
Mr. Rhodes prizes his farmer-hero's deep patience, mechanical skill and stamina. He respects this very solid marriage partnership and admires Sally Bauer, who, in addition to keeping the books, can run the combine, handle a grain truck, see to the household and still find time to work with her brother in his ceramics business.
Figuring large as villains are the grain companies, here called the Dirty Five for their alleged practice of adulterating first-quality grain by mixing with ''dirt to bring it down to grade.'' Many of the grain-elevator companies are also chemical fertilizer purveyors. They take powerful advantage of fluctuating storage needs, exacting a 10-month deposit fee to hold space in their elevators, ''charging a man for storage when his beans weren't even out of the field,'' Mr. Bauer grumbles. But he pays.
Squeezed by the chemical companies and by Government regulations that make it mandatory to deliver the highest possible yields per acre in order to show a profit in a good year and be eligible for support payments in a bad year, Mr. Bauer and his fellow farmers are in a very real sense trapped by the technology that now dominates tillage. Diversity enables Mr. Bauer to keep his head above water when crops fail. He runs some calves on land shares with neighbors, but the largest source of his income is hogs.
Mr. Rhodes devotes less than 40 pages to this operation, but this subject elicits the most graphic writing in the book. Unlike cattle, which are turned out to graze, Mr. Bauer's pigs are confined in pens. Because they are not ruminants and cannot efficiently digest cellulose, the financial gains are much greater if they are restrained and fed grain. Birthed in narrow steel crates in which the sow cannot turn around, unable to root in soil, the piglets must receive iron shots, be fed antibiotic-laced feed, have their eyeteeth nipped off and their tails docked, all standard procedures in the American methodology. (In Sweden it is illegal to raise pigs without giving them access to straw and litter.) Mr. Rhodes describes Mr. Bauer's efforts to restore a prolapsed rectum in one of his immature sows: the treatment is excruciating, medieval and rarely successful. Techniques that are more effective require a veterinarian, which is financially unfeasible. The cheapest way to produce pork is in a ''pig factory.'' When more humane, old-fashioned methods are used, the profit margin evaporates. As Mark Kramer puts it in ''Three Farms,'' ''The maximum bearable crowding of the fastest-growing hogs available makes a farmer his living.''
American consumers want cheap pork and don't care how they get it. Their meat is shrink-wrapped in plastic; please do not tell them how it got there. Mr. Rhodes unblinkingly describes the process from birth to the auctioning off for slaughter of pigs and cattle. He walks the reader through the vet's annual visit when the cattle are vaccinated and the males are castrated. A certain uneasiness seems to pervade the male-bonded conversation during this latter procedure; the banter is heavy with testicular jocularity. Mr. Rhodes is a faithful reporter.
It is a bit surprising to learn that Mr. Bauer is feeding his newborn calves a homemade brew of salt, baking soda, pectin and consomme to supplement their mother's colostrum, which he claims is not nourishing.
But it is not surprising that Mr. Bauer is sentimental about his land and his crops. Tears come to his eyes when he observes his son running the combine for the first time. He doubts ''if anyone who wasn't born on a farm could understand how he felt about the land.''
This presents a puzzling contrast with his attitude toward the family's young mongrel bitch. The Bauers do not feed their dogs. They are expected to scavenge or hunt mice and rabbits on their own. When the young female gets pregnant, Mr. Bauer makes the decision to ''thump'' the pups and does so as soon as they are born. Toward the close of the book, the bitch is pregnant again. She is killed by Mr. Bauer after being bested in a presumed encounter with coyotes.
The Bauers have just spent a thousand dollars to send one son to Australia on an educational exchange program, thousands more to build a heated garage attached to the house, but apparently the cost of spaying a family pet is beyond their grasp. All the more startling to find Mr. Rhodes's farmer-hero adopting two coyotes: he ''had dug out the pups the day they were born.''
Mr. Rhodes's chronicle is unvarnished, his vision acute. In ''The Making of the Atomic Bomb,'' he examines the aftermath of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the soul-searching exchanges among scientists and between them and Government officials. He is perhaps at the very top of his form in discussing the post-1945 period and the machinery of rearmament, quoting Robert Oppenheimer's ''Can we make them terribly more terrible?''
The reader will not find much soul-searching in ''Farm.'' Two hundred years ago, Thomas Jefferson wrote in a letter to James Madison that ''the earth belongs in usufruct to the living.'' Jefferson could never have foreseen the perils that ensnare the modern farmer, or our loss of allegiance to that noble concept.
 
THE ENVIABLE LIFE
Missouri has been on Richard Rhodes's mind a lot lately. ''Farm'' was inspired by the six years he spent at the Andrew Drumm Institute in Independence, a self-sufficient boys' home with a 360-acre farm. ''I felt some nostalgia for the farm. I wanted to go back,'' the 52-year-old author said by telephone from his home in Cambridge, Mass. ''I always daydreamed about being a farmer. I was curious about the farm. Things in the press and in film made the picture so dire.''
Mr. Rhodes said that his next book, ''A Hole in the World,'' will be about his childhood in Missouri. The title refers to his mother's death when he was only a year old. When he was 12, a juvenile court moved him and his brother to the boys' home after authorities determined that they were, he said, ''seriously underweight and abused.''
Mr. Rhodes said that researching ''Farm'' was a chance for him to fill his lungs after half a decade spent cloistered in archives writing ''The Making of the Atomic Bomb.''
''I lived with the [Bauer] family on a daily basis'' for much of 1986, he said. ''I took an apartment for $75 a month in a nearby town. I was an unpaid hired hand with a notebook in my pocket. They live a life they deeply enjoy. It's really priceless. This family weathered the worst agricultural crisis since the 1930's. They lost value in their land, but they did not go deeply into debt. It's clear to them that although, if worse came to worse, they might have to give up farming on their own, there is always work out there. They will never have to do what to them would be a fate worse than death - which would be to move to the city.''
 
KEITH SCHNEIDER

HEADLINE: Doldrums Troubling Housing Developers

BYLINE: By MARK McCAIN

 BODY:
WITH birch trees and rhododendrons spread across their lush lawns, seven new town houses at the Racquet Club on Long Island Sound look like the pride of loving homeowners. But a wasteland of mud ponds and hardpan that surrounds this manicured oasis in Centerville, L.I., offers evidence of big plans gone awry.
Bulldozers gouged 20 acres out of an oak forest there, 75 miles east of Manhattan, to make way for more than 200 homes. But after spending more than $12 million on land, site work, roads, construction and advertising, the developers found no buyers. The seven model homes now sit locked and empty.
''We figured we'd capture the yuppie market from Wall Street,'' said Dick Dickler of Jericho, L.I., one of the principals. ''My bank bought the concept, my partners bought the concept, but it simply did not work. After the stock market crash of Oct. 19, the yuppie market died on us. We even put ads in the papers to see what would happen at prices $20,000 below our costs. That didn't generate any sales, either.'' 
Throughout the metropolitan New York area, while some developers continue to start new projects, many others have been thrown into difficult times. No longer are buyers searching out every new project, like the Racquet Club, which Mr. Dickler decided to build two years ago on a 111-acre tract.
''At that point, business was booming for us,'' he said. ''We had all kinds of jobs under way. Sales were very, very good and we had an insatiable appetite for more property.''
But today some developers are choking on past excesses. The most beleaguered ones, burdened by mounting debts, are trying to sell off land they no longer need and speculative houses they never should have built.
''Don't buy that new Cadillac just yet,'' warned Builder, a trade magazine for residential developers, in a recent forecast. ''There's an industry shakeout coming and many of you won't make it.''
Actually, the shakeout has already begun. Strong builders like Heritage Development Group of Southbury, Conn., are analyzing opportunities to buy aborted projects at distressed prices.
''Banks are inheriting certain projects,'' said Henry J. Paparazzo, president of Heritage, which expects to sell about 100 homes this year - down nearly 50 percent from 1988. ''Basically, some developers don't have the wherewithal to carry their jobs the extra distance. They can't make bank payments.''
Even without any houses languishing on the market, a developer can slip into financial distress. Land represents about one-quarter of the cost of new homes, and developers usually operate with other people's money, so too many building lots can rapidly translate into too much debt.
''In the mid-1980's, builders were looking out toward some very prosperous years, so they were happy to have large inventories of land,'' said Robert Ritter, vice president of Robert-Mark Real Estate, a brokerage in Hopewell Junction, N.Y., near Poughkeepsie. ''But now they're trying to liquidate inventory.''
Savvy developers are adjusting to this leaner era, with its reduced profit margins and reduced sales activity. They are sharpening market strategies - knowing that buyers have become more selective since the mid-1980's, when inferior design and inferior location did not rule out success.
''What we're going through is a perfectly healthy process of weeding out bad builders,'' said Michael Barile, president of Lynlil Builders of Mahopac, N.Y., which expects to sell about 50 houses this year. ''Three years ago, anyone with some cash saved up wanted to be a builder. I was selling house lots to owners of pizza parlors and to people who worked for I.B.M. And basically, most of the spec homes still stuck on the market were built by inexperienced people.''
Mr. Barile has cut back sharply on ''spec houses'' - which are built on speculation before lining up buyers - and has pared down his average price.
''IN my market, the resistance point of buyers used to be around $450,000,'' he said. ''Now it's more like $350,000.''
Shrinking pocketbooks have become a common phenomenon in nearly every market niche. Gerald Kreisberg has a 120-unit subdivision called Wedgewood in Newburgh, N.Y., on the Hudson River 25 miles north of the New Jersey border, where his first 75 houses sold rapidly in the $150,000 range.
''But now the tight market has even caught up with us in Orange County,'' Mr. Kreisberg said. ''People priced out of Rockland and Dutchess Counties used to come here, but now even we're too expensive. So we have to lower our sights to meet the market.'' Early last month, he began advertising a raised-ranch model for $130,000. That has generated some interest, but sales are still slow.
''While I closed about 50 sales last year, I may close 20 or so this year,'' he said. ''And if I achieve that volume, I'll probably be doing much better than most of my peers.''
Clearly, buyers have revolted against rising prices. For about five years, demand for housing was so strong that anyone with a piece of the action - developers, land owners, tradespeople - could expect their fortunes to improve with each passing month. But now buyers are refusing to play along, and that has thrown the new-home industry into turmoil.
''The market is terrible for a lot of builders, even though underlying demand for housing has remained strong,'' said Ara K. Hovnanian, president of K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., a major builder of moderate-priced homes.
''The problem within this market,'' he said, ''is that both homeowners and developers have set their sights on excessively high prices.''
Hovnanian developments attract first-time home buyers, who are good prospects in today's sluggish market because they do not need to sell before they can buy. And with its reputation for good value, Hovnanian is maintaining a sales volume of about 2,500 homes a year in New Jersey.
One recent weekend, the company sold out 130 houses in a subdivision under construction in Piscataway. Next month the company will open the sales office for a 1,200-unit condominium and town-house project in Jersey City, with prices starting around $100,000.
''We haven't begun any advertising yet,'' Mr. Hovnanian said, ''but we're already receiving about 200 calls a week at our main office.''
FOR Hovnanian and other active builders, a side benefit of the soft market is that contractors and landowners are chasing less money.
''Now the trades are hungry to get work - just to break even,'' Mr. Hovnanian said. ''And in the last few months we've begun to see land deals that make sense.
''Throughout 1987 and 1988, we weren't able to acquire land because sellers were demanding top, top prices that we couldn't justify,'' he said. ''We were getting nervous as we depleted our land inventory at the rate of about 2,500 housing units a year. But now we're in the process of signing contracts for land that can accommodate about 2,000 more units.''
Occasionally, there are heartening signs for residential developers. The Federal Commerce Department reported recently that new home sales in the Northeast soared by 55.8 percent in July. The seasonally adjusted volume of 120,000 units for July was more than double June's volume.
''Interest rates dropped briefly in July and I think many people found a window of affordability,'' said Rae Rosen, an economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.
Unfortunately, many analysts consider the July activity to be an anomaly, rather than a sign that hard times are over. Home prices are stagnating or declining modestly throughout most of the New York metropolitan region, and home buyers are biding their time.
''Right now there are too many houses on the market, so lots of developers have stopped developing,'' said Rae Molinelli, a real estate broker in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. ''And subdivisions have been caught in the crunch, with third and fourth phases not selling nearly as fast as the first few phases.''
Some developers are still trying to sell off speculative units left over from optimistic days; other developers have trimmed their inventories low enough to be able to resume construction at a modest pace.
''We've slowed down considerably in Somers,'' said Mr. Paparazzo of Heritage, which is developing Heritage Hills, a 14-year-old project in the Westchester community that is now about halfway to its projected total of 3,100 condominium units.
''We really had a great sellers' market for four or five years in the Northeast,'' he said. ''But the combined costs of developing new housing rose so high that we outdistanced the capabilities of buyers - and they backed off.''
Like any manufacturer forced to cut back production as it sits on too much inventory, residential developers have introduced sales incentives. Among these are discounts, extra features, free trips and below-market financing.
The sweeteners help lure some home buyers into the market, but alone they cannot turn a troubled project into a winner.
''We are now discounting units, which is something we haven't done for a long time,'' said Ross Wishnick, a senior vice president of Union Valley Corporation, a major developer based in Howell, N.J., which operates in the $100,000 to $200,000 range. ''We went through a very painful thought process before arriving at the decision to discount, but we felt it was an appropriate response to the times.
''We're more flexible in our sales today, and I think everyone else is, too,'' said Mr. Wishnick, who expects Union Valley will sell about 20 percent fewer units this year than in 1988, when it sold about 800 homes.
Throughout the New York region, most statistical information points to a continuing decline in residential construction. On Long Island, for instance, building permits this year are running about 25 percent below last year's level. The Town of Lewisboro is typical of Westchester County: Its building permits peaked at 285 in 1986, dropped to 122 in 1987, 39 in 1988, and this year the pace is slightly slower yet.
''HOME buyers have really fallen off - and the ones out looking are trying to find the best bargains they can,'' said John Sims, president of Weichert New Homes and Land Company, a brokerage in Morris Plains, N.J., now marketing 26 residential projects within the region.
''A few years ago we were converting five out of every 100 people who came into new-home communities,'' said Mr. Sims, referring to people who decided to buy. ''Today it's more like one out of 100.''
Although the ingredients of successful residential projects in today's market vary widely, in almost every case, the development team has analyzed and dissected its target audience extensively.
''There are some builders who haven't done any research, who haven't merchandised wisely, and they're laying dead in the water,'' Mr. Sims said. ''Other builders are responding week by week to the market, and they're selling homes.''
For a few years it seemed that a key element of successful real estate development - location - was losing its stature as buyers snatched up new homes almost anywhere within an expanding ring around New York City.
But as the market has cooled, so has the appeal of less desirable locations.
''Almost every project is cutting prices and discounting units, but we didn't feel that was an appropriate strategy for us because our sales are strong,'' said James Harvie, the developer of Half Moon Bay, a condominium project on the Hudson River in the Westchester County village of Croton. Its prices range from $250,000 to $450,000.
''WHILE the difficulties of obtaining approvals are enormous for a project like ours, living right on the water, next to your own marina, is something that almost everyone would enjoy,'' Mr. Harvie said.
''The uniqueness of our site gives us a major advantage over other developments. We had 40 or 50 people through our sales office in a week near the end of August, which is normally a slow period. There are other developers who have not seen that many people in six months.''
At the Racquet Club on the Sound in Centerville, L.I., the sales office is locked, the blinds are pulled and the potted palms have turned brown from neglect. The developers figured that for less than $200,000 young couples would eagerly buy into a complex offering 12 tennis courts, a pool, a clubhouse and walking trails.
But the location - 50 miles from the eastern tip of Long Island, amid sod farms, greenhouses and cornfields - worked against the concept.
''We figure we'll try again when times are better,'' said Mr. Dickler. ''Who knows when that will be. But for now, there's no sense beating our heads against the wall.''

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
A $300 Million Downtown Bridgeport Plan

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
FOR more than 20 years, Bridgeport - known to its detractors as the ''gritty city'' - has been struggling to redevelop its business district, but it has never taken the big step.
Now, for the first time, a comprehensive rather than piecemeal plan for restoring its entire downtown core of 171 buildings in 19 blocks - a $300 million, six-year project - is ready to run the gantlet of zoning and financing approvals that could start the reconstruction within 60 days.
The proposal, by Joel Schiavone of New Haven, is based on his successful rehabilitation of his home city's downtown, relying on the reuse of 19th- and early 20th-century buildings instead of demolition and new construction. He regards Bridgeport's large stock of old buildings in three historic districts as a blessing bestowed unwittingly ''by unsuccessful mayors in the 50's who never got Federal funds for urban renewal.'' 
A man of many interests, Mr. Schiavone graduated from Yale University in 1958 and Harvard Business School in 1961 and then set about diversifying his grandfather's New Haven scrap-metal business.
His holdings include the Schiavone Realty & Development Corporation, the New Haven Night Hawks hockey team, Connecticut Limousine Service and a succession of more than a dozen other companies bought and sold. An accomplished banjoist with the Galvanized Jazz Band, he is currently seeking the Republican Party's nomination for Governor.
His plan is favored by the government, banking and corporate communities in Bridgeport, the state's most populous city. It is expected that his application for changes in zoning - now limiting setbacks, heights and lot sizes and requiring 1,500 feet between establishments selling liquor, a parking space for every residential unit and a ban on sidewalk cafes - will be approved this month.
''Without the changes, the plan is not economically feasible,'' said James G. Kimball, a partner in the Kimball Group, a Bridgeport real estate company and partner in the Schiavone project. ''We need an entertainment core of restaurants and nightclubs. Parking for up to 2,000 rental apartments must be as it is in other cities, where people park in garages, parking lots or on the street.''
Residential rents would start around $450 for a studio and commercial space would be about $15 a square foot. An outdoor cafe is planned by closing Wall Street to traffic and enveloping it in glass.
''We are not creating a city for blue-eyed WASP's with median incomes of $45,000 a year, nor are we putting a sign out saying 'city for rent,' '' said Mr. Kimball. ''We want diners, shoeshine parlors and laundromats, dry cleaners and ice cream parlors, Laura Ashley and low-priced clothing, quality restaurants, landscaped parking lots, parks and theaters.''
''The best element of Joel's plan is getting 35 buildings done at one time in the first year,'' said Philip Kuchma, president of P. J. Kuchma Construction Company, owner of several properties in the area. ''We need to have that immediate an impact.''
Mr. Kuchma has restored some of his own buildings and will build a 456-car parking garage on Golden Hill Street near the Golden Hill Apartments that Mr. Schiavone plans to renovate and rent for $1,200 a month.
Financing of $54 million for the first phase, bounded by State, Broad, Golden Hill and Main Streets, would restore some 600,000 square feet of buildings that include the vacant Read's Department Store.
Future phases would expand the project to Harrison Street on the west, to the junction of Housatonic and East Washington Avenues to the north, and east to Water Street, where a new marina would be built. A total of 1.8 million square feet are involved, much of it currently rented. Some 300,000 square feet would be office space.
''WE are trying to come up with a venture in which local and nonlocal banks will participate at different levels as general partners,'' said Peter M. Brestovan, first vice president of People's Bank of Bridgeport, one of 10 institutions in a consortium formed to finance the project. He added that the eight months of negotiations were ''longer than any of us wanted.''
Other members of the consortium are Mechanics & Farmers, Bankmart, Lafayette and Citytrust of Bridgeport; Connecticut National Bank and Connecticut Bank & Trust of Hartford; Union Trust of Stamford and U.S. Trust of Boston and the Bank of Boston.
Since the 60's, such widely divergent projects as the unsuccessful conversion of an old ferryboat into a floating restaurant and the construction of a Hilton Hotel six years ago were perceived as generators of further development that never materialized. Spotty demolition produced parking lots and vacant lots. The city averted bankruptcy in 1988 when a state-mandated financial review board forced a balanced budget to be passed last May with the aid of $58 million in bonds to cover debts and working capital.
With one of the state's highest tax rates - $57.2 per $1,000 of assessed value - the city has granted tax credits and abatements for a $30 million, 222,000-square-foot office tower under construction by Robert Scinto of Fairfield on Lafayette Boulevard; the conversion of a vacant Gimbels store into a handsome Mechanics & Farmers Bank on Broad Street and of a coat factory into Lafayette Square offices and pub by the Lindmark Group of Suffern, N.Y., and the construction of the spectacular $100 million, 500,000-square foot People's Bank building designed by Richard Meier next door to the restored 1893 P. T. Barnum Museum.
MR. SCHIAVONE cannot acquire the properties he needs until the financial package is completed and the city's Common Council authorizes property purchases by eminent domain when necessary through the local Economic Development Corporation, which would resell them to Mr. Schiavone. Current owners may also sell to Mr. Schiavone directly, invest their buildings in the project and become limited partners.
According to Scott Brown, president of the Schavione Corporation, ''certain moneys will be reserved for assisting individual residents to relocate.'' But someone like Vino Sakakimi, owner of the Subway Sandwich Shop franchise at John and Main Streets since June, wonders what will happen to his thriving new business. He invested $125,000 in renovations and has a five-year lease at $3,000 a month.
''You have to take a chance in life,'' he said.

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 20, Column 5; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1121 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education

BYLINE: By Irving Gerber; Irving Gerber of Oceanside, a retired New York City principal, is founder of No More, a group opposed to school tax increases.

 BODY:
THE 1989 school board budgets are history. The pros and cons have been hashed and rehashed. The anti-tax groups have been heaped with calumny. They have been called demagogues for daring to suggest that schools are not akin to motherhood.
They have been blamed for forcing children to walk miles to school, for lowering property values in districts on ''austerity,'' for depriving youngsters of their God-given right to high school sports. 
Despite all the rhetoric, nobody has been able to explain adequately why schools today, with half the number of students of 10 years ago, need twice the amount of money and considerably more administrators.
The answer does not require a long investigation. Fat, frills and waste pervade Long Island school districts. School boards have been running amok, building empires; more administrators, more supervisors.
Where before, a few rooms were sufficient, now entire buildings are needed to service a considerably reduced school population. Where before, a superintendent and one assistant with some ancillary help from key personnel were sufficient, now an army of coordinators, supervisors and directors fill district headquarters to overflowing.
The offending districts are ubiquitous Island-wide. Valley Stream sent its entire school board to Orlando, Fla., for a school board convention. So convenient, finding a convention next to Disneyworld. And, with thousands of teacher candidates available in the East, one wonders why this same district found it necessary to send recruiters to California, all expenses paid.
Oceanside used to have 10,000 children and one assistant superintendent. Now it has 5,000 children and three assistant superintendents.
Hicksville has three superintendents and four directors for 4,600 children. Bayport, with only 2,100 children, has the same number, three superintendents and four directors.
Merrick closed schools to save money, but kept the principals on the payroll. School districts are now employment agencies as well.
West Islip had 10,000 children and 10 schools. Now, with 5,000 children, they still seem to need the same 10 schools. Administrators in West Islip have been granted a 46 percent increase in their salaries over the last four years. Why not? When it's somebody else's money, the sky's the limit.
Bayport lost 1,400 pupils, going down to 2,000 in 10 years, but doubled its budget.
Baldwin said it had the tightest budget possible, but somehow managed to include two newly created administrative positions plus funds for carpeting, new lawn decorations and parking lots. This, after taxpayers voted down the budget.
Syosset tried to pass a bond issue to include new rooms for its elementary schools even though the schools are only 70 percent utilized and the school population is declining.
South Haven in Suffolk County was reported to have given its teachers a 12 percent raise per year for three years. The school board simply gave away the store.
The increased costs brought on by this school board profligacy are phenomenal. Island Park, for example, spent $7,300 per pupil in 1986. In 1988, it topped Long Island's districts with an obscene cost of $14,119 per pupil, practically a 100 percent increase.
And what did the people of this small village get for their money? Island Park, based on the New York State Education Department report for 1988, ranked among the lowest in Nassau County in social studies and writing skills, and is among the lower 50 percent in reading.
But, take heart Island Park, Manhasset and Oyster Bay are even lower in writing skills, while their teachers are among the highest paid in the entire county. On the other hand, Rockville Centre and New Hyde Park, where teachers are among the lowest paid, produced some of the finest results in reading, writing and arithmetic in 1988.
Obviously, we are paying for a pig in a poke. We think we are getting better schools for our money, but we are not. We think we've elected responsible trustees but we have not.
School boards are telling us we must spend more to give our children the finest education. The results indicate we are not spending for a finer education, we are spending to satisfy the power lust and prestige needs of school superintendents and school boards.
The evidence of overspending cannot be denied. But what are the solutions? Where does the answer lie?
First and foremost, we must get rid of the fat. We all want excellence in education, but to equate that with burgeoning offices and paper-pushing administrators is absurd.
Why do school districts need public-relations people who turn out self-serving newsletters informing the public of the excellent job being done? Why are there so many more nonteaching teachers today compared with a decade ago? Oceanside has a teacher now to organize training programs for teachers. With fringe benefits, the cost of this position comes to $75,000 per year.
Class size has an enormous effect on school budgets and taxes. Yet many districts continue to go to the taxpayer before they will consider the huge savings to be realized by a slight increase in the number of children per teacher.
The cry that larger class size will result in poorer education can easily be refuted. The January 1989 New York State Education Department Report shows districts with a relatively high pupil-per-teacher ratio, such as East Meadow, Herricks, Massapequa and Wantagh, doing as well as or better in reading and math as Great Neck, Island Park and Manhasset, which have much lower pupil-per-teacher ratios.
The item with the most profound effect on taxes is, of course, teacher salaries. At one time in our history, teaching was equated with poverty. Teachers rightly deserve the raises they have been granted over the past 10 years, to bring them up to a professional level. Now, however, with teacher salaries in the $40,000 to $50,000 range, our pedagogues can hardly cry poverty.
Yes, they should continue to advance with an annual 4 or 5 percent raise based on the cost of living, but why, when the taxpayers are hurting so badly, do school boards grant 8 and 10 percent raises per year?
The decrease in student population has resulted in districts being half the size they were. Why not combine services? Why not purchase and contract collectively and hire education specialists to coordinate and supervise in more than one district?
Is it pride or apathy that prevents an examination into such a possibility? In any case, we must bury the canard trumpeted loudly by school boards that 95 percent of expenses are mandated. True enough, health benefits, pensions, debt payment and so on are mandated, but there are many areas for economy, if the desire is there.
