LENGTH: 700 words

HEADLINE: Additional Alternatives To the Shoreham Plant

 BODY:
Regarding the article ''Despite Shoreham's Closing, Energy Alternatives Exist'' (Aug. 13) by Thomas A. Twomey Jr.:
Of course, energy alternatives exist; Shoreham opponents have said that for years. But instead of five, there are at least six.
The article omits the best alternative of all: the New York State hydropower that we all paid for (it is equal to 2.5 Shorehams and was built by a Long Islander, Robert Moses) and the huge amount of hydropower for sale next door in Quebec.
Even with a long transmission line, the hydropower would be cheaper, safer and more reliable than a nuclear Shoreham ever could be. Look at the figures for the new (not very high-tech) Marcy South transmission line from Canada nearly to Long Island:
 
* 2,000 megawatts vs. 810 for Shoreham.
* Cost of $800 million vs. $15 billion (maybe $20 billion) for Shoreham.
* On line virtually 100 percent of the time vs. 60 percent for the average United States nuclear plant (and you can bet Shoreham would be worse.)
* As for safety, the transmission line is insurable. Shoreham is not at any price. As a matter of fact, one of the finest Congresses money can buy passed legislation limiting liability in the event of a ''nuclear incident.'' (How's that for blaming the victims?) Instead of being 10 years late and 20 times over cost like Shoreham (that's 20 times, not 20 percent), Marcy South was built nearly on time and close to the original figures. Estimates were exceeded because of some rerouting for esthetic purposes.
In California, the people of Los Angeles overcame intense opposition from powerful utilities to build a high-tech line that saves them more than $1 million a day.
Yet, we on Long Island, the most hydro-rich area in the country and with shorter transmission distances, get the highest rates among the 800 United States electric companies. The rates will double again within 10 years under Governor Cuomo's deal.
The Long Island Lighting Company does not make enough money from ''imported power,'' and so it has opposed and lobbied against it for years, but we paid for our share and we have been denied for the last 20 years.
Wouldn't you rather buy almost ready-made power from a triple A-rated company like Hydro-Quebec (the largest electric utility in North America) instead of the clowns at Lilco?
Since Shoreham exists, it will probably go to natural gas, as people have been suggesting for years, especially since the Canadians have lots of it that they are willing to sell and our (United States) reserves are rated at better than 125 years.
It is relatively benign and very reliable. But notice how the nuclear industry never mentions gas? Gas is certainly a good choice for a local plant, even though in this hydro-rich area we should have few local plants.
Natural gas raises another issue. Unlike its electric service, Lilco's gas service is relatively good. But in a country devoted to free enterprise and economic competition, doesn't the combination of two competing energy sources in one monopoly violate the Sherman Antitrust Act?
For technical reasons, local electric and local gas companies must be monopolies, but there is no reason to combine the two, especially since they are competing energy sources.
If a well-respected company like A.T.&T., with a national treasure like Bell Labs, can be broken up, why couldn't a nearly bankrupt and despised company like Lilco, with a national disgrace like Shoreham, be touched? Or didn't our Governor even want to try?
The article mentions the Long Island Power Authority as doing great things for the Isand, but wasn't it supposed to purchase Lilco? Or was it just created as a sop to an outraged public before the election?
Now what will it be: A ''watchdog'' (the Governor's words) to do the job that the state's Public Service Commission was supposed to be doing all along, or just another useless state agency grinding out high payroll checks?
 
JOHN HURLEY

HEADLINE: Drug Abuse To Be Focus Of Hearing

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY, whose turnpike the authorities say has become a major channel for illegal drugs flowing into New York and whose cities are home to some 200,000 cocaine and heroin users, will convene a Congressional field hearing tomorrow in which local experts will testify on the narcotics problem in the northern part of the state.
The hearing, which will be held at St. Peter's College in Jersey City, is the first of three or four that are scheduled around the country to inform Congressional debate on the $7.9 billion anti-drug plan that President Bush announced on Sept. 5.
''When you go out in the neighborhoods, you find there are many people who are willing to step forth and tell it like it is and give you their opinions and advice,'' said Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Jersey City, who is a member of House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control.
Beginning at 9 A.M., committee members will hear testimony from 14 witnesses, including law-enforcement officials, health and drug-treatment specialists and community organizers. ''We want that input from the communities so we can carry it to the debate on the floor of Congress and use it to reshape and improve the President's plan,'' Mr. Guarini said. 
Among other provisions, the plan calls for increased penalties for drug use and more money for treatment, education, law enforcement and prisons. The witnesses in tomorrow's hearing will focus on drug education and prevention, rehabilitation and the spread of drug-related AIDS cases as well as narcotics-dealing in the state.
''Many aspects of New Jersey's economy, geography and location combine to make the state extremely conducive to the successful importation, manufacture, transportation and distribution of narcotics,'' wrote Samuel A. Alito Jr., United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey, in a recent Justice Department report.
''New Jersey is the most convenient land route for any cargo entering the New York area from almost everywhere in the country, especially Florida,'' Mr. Alito wrote.
So common are drug shipments along New Jersey's highways that the stretch of road entering Gloucester County over the Delaware Memorial Bridge is dubbed ''cocaine alley'' by law-enforcement officials.
Cocaine - the ''drug of choice'' in New Jersey, Mr. Alito said in his report - also comes in from Florida and Colombia through the busy ports of Elizabeth and Newark and the state's 79 airports. ''New Jersey then serves as the focus of distribution of the drug throughout the region, including Pennsylvania, Delaware, Rhode Island, Connecticut and, of course, within New Jersey itself,'' he wrote.
But cocaine consumption in New Jersey, most of it in the northeastern part of the state, is rivaled by heroin use in cities like Atlantic City, Trenton, Camden, Newark and Paterson. And southern New Jersey sees more widespread use of methamphetamine - speed - than other parts of the state.
''There is some crack use, but nowhere near the extent of the problem they have in New York or other places,'' said Michael J. Tobin, who is the special agent in charge of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration's Newark field division and who is scheduled to testify at the hearing. ''The place we're not seeing it as much as we thought we'd see it is in the Newark area.''
But crack, the potent smokable cocaine derivative that has plagued cities throughout the country, has nevertheless made inroads in New Jersey. State health officials estimate there are 57,000 crack users and 93,000 cocaine abusers in New Jersey. They estimate there are 50,000 intravenous drug users in the state, most of them heroin addicts.
Mr. Tobin said it was ''absolutely not'' possible for law-enforcement officials to intercept most of the drugs coming into New Jersey. ''Go down and look at the turnpike,'' he said. ''Go down and look at the seaport. Newark and Port Elizabeth represent one-third of the containers coming into the country. If you don't have information, it's like a raffle.''
The Rev. Willard W. Z. Ashley, a leader of the Interfaith Community Organization, a group of 40 Hudson County religious institutions that work together on social issues, said that while law-enforcement agencies needed more money, they also needed to be held more accountable for ridding the streets of dealers.
''We need to mount a systematic enforcement of the law,'' said Mr. Ashley, who will also testify at the hearing. ''This so-called drug war is not even a skirmish at this point. We have a law enforcement that's outmanned and outgunned, so it's not a surprise that it's failing. Even greater than that, we're talking accountability. You can pump money into stuff, but if no one's accountable, you're just going to be pumping money into stuff.''
 
Cocaine Found in Chocolate
Occasionally the police or Federal agents do confiscate huge shipments at the ports or on the highways. In July 1988, for example, the authorities found 6,000 pounds of cocaine in blocks of chocolate in Port Newark, the largest single seizure outside of Florida, Mr. Tobin said.
Trafficking is only one focus of tomorrow's hearing, however. Drug-treatment experts will present statistics showing that New Jersey has only a fraction of the resources it needs to treat abusers who want to quit.
''Our current drug-treatment system is bursting at the seams, despite some recent increases in both Federal and state money,'' said Christine M. Grant, a deputy commissioner of health in New Jersey.
Ms. Grant said state and Federal spending on treatment and prevention now totaled $22 million annually, enough to rehabilitate 16,000 to 18,000 people a year. She estimated that there were as many as 100,000 heroin and cocaine users in the state who needed treatment, and that 50 to 60 percent of those would be willing to enter programs if there were space available.
 
Concerns on Pregnant Women
''We certainly recognize an unprecedented increase in the number of people using particularly crack and cocaine,'' said Ms. Grant, whose assistant commissioner, Richard J. Russo, is scheduled to testify at the Congressional hearing. ''We are particularly concerned with the fact that an unprecedented number of pregnant women are delivering without any prenatal care or are found to be active drug users.''
At one prenatal clinic in Jersey City, for example, some 20 percent of patients have traces of illegal narcotics in their urine, she said.
State health officials hope the President's plan will allocate $6 million in Federal money for treatment and prevention programs in New Jersey. They also hope Federal lawmakers will use their influence to persuade local residents to permit drug-treatment clinics to open in their communities.
''We just can't treat new people in the now-aging facilities that are available - aging and crowded,'' Ms. Grant said.
 
Link to AIDS Cited
Health officials at the hearing also plan to address the link between intravenous drug use and AIDS. Some 60 percent of the state's 7,177 AIDS cases reported as of Aug. 31 were linked to intravenous drug use, health officials say. Perhaps 70,000 state residents are infected with the AIDS virus and are expected to eventually show symptoms of the disease.
''You have to resolve intravenous drug abuse before you can stop the spread of the epidemic,'' Ms. Grant said.
''You not only learn from what's going on in the community,'' Mr. Guarini said of the hearing. ''But you can also spotlight problem areas, and Hudson County is a problem area.''
Expected to join Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, the committee chairman, and other committee members at the hearing are Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, and Representative Donald M. Payne, Democrat of Newark.
Witnesses scheduled to testify include the New Jersey Attorney General, Peter N. Perretti Jr., Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark and Joseph P. Miele, chairman of the Governor's Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

 BODY:

 
VISIT BY 'GISELLE'
The Connecticut Ballet Theater of Stamford will pay a visit to the county this week when it presents ''Giselle'' at the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase. The full-length production staged by Brett Raphael, artistic director of the company, will feature Cynthia Gregory and Fernando Bujones in the leading roles. Miss Gregory will appear as guest artist with the company throughout the season. She and Mr. Bujones have been principal dancers with the American Ballet Theater for two decades.
Performances are at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday, and 2 P.M. next Sunday. Tickets, at $15, $25 and $40, may be ordered with major credit cards by calling the State University box office at 253-5900. 
 
TALKS ON CHINA
Judith Whitbeck's group of Marymount College students and friends had to cut short its travels through China last May. When political unrest turned violent in Beijing, the tour returned home, but not before witnessing a demonstration in Xi'an, a city of three million people and the capital of Shaanxi Province.
Dr. Whitbeck, assistant professor of history at Marymount, speaks Mandarin Chinese fluently and will give two lectures based on her recent experience and its context in the Chinese movement toward democracy in the last decade.
Her first talk begins at 7:30 P.M. Thursday, focusing on Xi'an's 2,000-year history. The second program, dealing with political protest, will be held at 1:30 P.M. on Oct. 7. Both lectures will be accompanied by Dr. Whitbeck's slides of the trip, and are to take place at the Nyack Public Library. There is no charge for admission but reservations may be made by calling 358-3370.
 
CARTOON HALL
A new, permanent Hall of Fame Gallery opens today at the the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook. Twenty-four members have been elected to the elite group of artists every few years since the practice began 14 years ago. A jury of cartoonists, scholars and editors in the field, independent of the museum, makes the selection, and as testimony to their impartiality, Mort Walker, creator of ''Beetle Bailey,'' was just elected this year, 15 years after he founded the museum and became an active participant in its operations.
Also elected this year were the recently deceased Dik Browne for his ''Hagar the Horrible'' and Will Eisner, who draws ''The Spirit.''
The new gallery contains original drawings from the first published strips of all the Hall of Fame cartoonists, including ''Blondie'' by Chic Young, 1930; ''Terry and the Pirates'' by Milton Caniff, 1936; ''The Yellow Kid'' by Richard Outcault, 1897; ''Bringing Up Father'' by George McManus, and early originals ranging from Charles Dana Gibson's ''Gibson Girl'' to Charles Schulz's ''Peanuts,'' plus ''Flash Gordon,'' ''Little Orphan Annie,'' ''Krazy Kat,'' and political cartoons by Thomas Nast among others.
Viewing hours are from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays. The museum is on Comly Avenue and admission is $3 for adults, $2 for students and the elderly, and $1 for children. For more information, call 939-0234.
 
COFFEE CONCERTS
The Philharmonia Virtuosi introduces a new series of four Sunday ''Coffee Concerts'' today at the Westchester Community College in Valhalla. Recalling the leisurely conviviality of old Vienna, a coffee hour at 12:30 P.M. will precede the 2 o'clock concert, warming up the audience with gourmet coffees and an elaborate selection of pastries.
Today's concert is a ''Back to Bach'' affair featuring Sandra Ruggles, soprano; Thomas Young, tenor; and Paul Peabody, violinist, performing arias, cantatas and concertos, with the ensemble conducted by Richard Kapp. All seats are $14, and there is a $5 charge for the coffee hour. Subscriptions for the series, continuing on Nov. 12, April 8 and May 13 cost $42. Call 693-5595 for reservations and more information.
 
SLOW MOTION
Tai chi, that mysterious, slow and flowing version of physical excercises that the Chinese perform at the start of the day, may be learned at Wainwright House in Rye. Yosef Pollack, an expert who has studied with two Chinese masters over 13 years, will teach two classes of six sessions each from 7:30 to 9 P.M. Tuesdays or from 12:30 to 2 P.M. Wednesdays, both beginning this week. The fee is $90.
The profound slowness, absolute continuity of movement and heightened concentration required in the classical Yang style of t'ai chi ch'uan is purported to promote relaxation, general health and a sense of exhilaration. Call 967-6080 for additional information or to enroll. The Wainwright House is at 260 Stuyvesant Avenue.
 
COUNTY ECONOMY
A formidable array of Westchester bankers and businessmen and -women will participate in the yearly fall economic symposium sponsored by the Westchester County Association and the Westchester County Bankers Association from 8 A.M. to noon Tuesday at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza in White Plains.
''Westchester Economy at the Crossroads'' is the general subject, divided into four topics to be discussed by individual speakers. Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, will talk about ''Paying for Mobility,'' and Kenneth H. Militzer, chief economist at American Telephone and Telegraph, will tackle ''The National Outlook: Hard Landing or Soft?''
''The Westchester Economy: Recession and Beyond'' will be forecast by Thomas J. Spitznas, president of T. J. Spitznas and Associates, a county-based economic consulting firm; the fourth speaker is Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority, whose subject is ''Westchester and the Region: What's Happening? What's Ahead?''
A $40 fee includes breakfast. For reservations and additional details, call 948-6444.
 
DAYS OF VISION
The College of New Rochelle's three-day event called ''Visions of the Future: Imagining the 21st Century'' is planned for Saturday through Oct. 2, exploring prospects for the arts, space, architecture, sociological concerns and the world of work.
A free discussion about ''One Marriage: Two Careers'' opens the program at 2:30 P.M. Saturday, with Jerry Carr, commander of Skylab 4, and his wife, Patricia Musick, an artist whose work will be on exhibition under the title ''Exploring the Caverns of the Mind.''
Ms. Musick will give a gallery talk at 1 P.M. next Sunday, while her husband is to conduct a program with films and photographs called ''Ventures Into Space'' at 7 P.M., for which there will be a charge of $5, or $2.50 for children and the elderly. A free Saks Fifth Avenue fashion show will be held at 3 P.M. Sunday, followed by a presentation on careers by the H. W. Taylor Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies of the College of New Rochelle at 4 P.M.
''Alternate Futures'' will be discussed at 1:30 P.M. Oct. 2 by a panel including Anthony Pucillo, an architect; Jean Bonney, a computer scientist; Phillip Johnson, a Westchester 2000 analyst, and Dr. Kathleen Cravero, a United Nations health advocate. Admission is $5; the elderly $2.50. A group of Presidential Arts Scholars of the National Foundation for the Advancement of the Arts will perform free of charge at 4 P.M. Monday. Inexpensive meals will be available in the dining hall. For more information, call 654-5840. $90ELEANOR CHARLES

Sept. 24, 1989, Sunday, National Edition

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1256 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS: BOSTON;
Around Boston, Condo Sellers Try Creative Marketing

BYLINE: By GAIL BRACCIDIFERRO

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
With sales listless in the suburban condominium market, developers are offering a variety of incentives to buy - including below-market mortgage rates and lease-to-buy options. In at least one case, the developers will even purchase buyers' homes.
All this follows several years of soaring prices and easy availability of financing to build new projects, many of which are in multifamily buildings in suburbs where the most familiar housing remains the single-family detached home.
Since the mid-80's, the condominium market has sagged even more than that of single-family homes here. This has led some banks and developers to offer financing packages to bring buyers into the market. It also has put private individuals who bought condominiums, lived in them for a few years and now want to sell, in direct competition with developers. 
Jerry Levin, president of First New Hampshire Condominium Associates of Nashua, N.H., which manages more than 2,500 condominium units in the Boston suburbs as well as southern New Hampshire, said individual sellers were also offering incentives to buy, such as rebates on closing costs.
Seth Emmer, a Boston lawyer who represents more than 150 condominium associations in the Boston area, said people who must move from condominiums, because of job relocation for example, also are choosing to rent rather than suffer a loss by selling.
People should buy for the traditional reasons, he said. Traditionally, people who plan to move soon rent, rather than buy. But the price appreciations of the recent past led many to expect substantial gains from a resale, which encouraged purchases.
The median price of a single-family home in the Boston area rose from $80,800 in 1982 to $178,500 in the first quarter of this year, according to the Boston Realtors' Board. In the second quarter of 1989, the median condominium price was $187,000 in Middlesex County, a suburban area just west of Boston.
The rate of home price increases has slowed considerably - from a high of 34 percent from 1985 to 1986 to slightly less than 1 percent from 1988 to the present. The area's median home price nevertheless remains nearly double the national median of $91,700.
Some banks continue to hold extensive amounts of construction debt. The First American Bank for Savings of Boston, which went public in 1986, is one savings institution using financial incentive programs to try to get out of debt.
Cathleen Maloney, First American's director of corporate communications, said the bank has $132 million in outstanding construction loans. No interest is being earned on 30 percent of its assets - $195 million worth, she said, part of which is in construction loans. In some cases, loans are being rolled over. In May and June, the bank introduced two financial incentive programs designed to retire some debt and begin selling condominiums. Several developers with First American loans who had more than 400 condominiums and several new single-family homes to sell were persuaded to take part.
First American's programs are aimed at two categories of buyers where the market seems to be weakest.
* For first-time home buyers who have been unable to save enough for a down payment in the Boston area's high-priced market, there is the Equitrak, Ms. Maloney said, which offers below-market mortgage rates of 8 percent and lease-to-buy options, under which all rent goes toward the down payment. The developer makes up the difference for the bank between the variable low mortgage interest rate and market rate until the former equals the latter.
* For buyers who are trading up, the Qualifier program offers below-market, 7.95 percent fixed-rate mortgages on higher-priced condominiums.
About $7 million worth of housing has been sold through the two programs.
''With the Qualifier,'' Ms. Maloney said, ''we do book a loss. But what we are getting is payment on loans. That is something.''
Merrill H. Diamond and his partner, Gordon I. Hurwitz, of the Parencorp development company of Brookline, are using the bank's incentives at the St. George on Revere Beach, a 240-unit, 13-story building for which ground was broken in July 1986. When the market softened, they began renting units and offering short-term price reductions on some condominiums.
''In a good market, people buy condominiums,'' Mr. Diamond said. ''In a bad market, people are sold condominiums.'' The partners have sold 124 units priced at $100,000 to $350,000, he said, and rentals created not only a cash flow, but also a pool of potential buyers.
Another tack, Mr. Diamond said, was taken at James Landing, a 50-unit Parencorp condominium town-house complex in the small South Shore town of Scituate where prices range from about $300,000 to more than $500,000. The complex is aimed at retired people seeking a more relaxed life style.
''They had to sell to buy there, so we came up with a home-swap program,'' Mr. Diamond said. For example, the developer would take a house appraised at $250,000 plus $75,000 in cash in exchange for a $350,000 condominium, he said. Parencorp sold five James Landing units through the program and has sold three of the homes they took in exchange.
Franklin W. Simon, president of the Simon Companies of Braintree, said that the lease-to-buy program of First American had brought in 16 buyers at his project in Mansfield, a 36-unit condominium called the Courtyard at Webb Place. Prices range from $90,000 to $125,000.
''The first-time buyers who wanted the units didn't have the down payment,'' he said. ''Basically, they are getting free rent for the first five to nine months.''
The purchasing market also has been hurt by the 1986 Tax Reform Act, which curbed the practice of allowing passive investors to apply real estate losses to other forms of income. Investor purchases had been a major factor in spurring condominium development and prices. Sales of all residences dipped about 25 percent between 1986 and 1988 in Suffolk County, an area that includes Boston, according to the business publication Banker and Tradesman. But in the suburbs, the picture is bleaker for condominium sellers.
In Middlesex County, which includes the wealthy town of Cambridge, residential sales, not including condominiums, for the first six months of this year are down 5.4 percent from the same period last year. But condominium sales are down 18 percent.
In Revere, the blue-collar suburb just north of Boston, town officials hoped the real estate boom would erase its deteriorating honky-tonk shoreline. That work was well under way two years ago, when 163 beachfront condominium units were complete and 870 more were under construction or planned. But residential sales declined 18 percent this year, with condominium sales plummeting 66 percent.
Some say part of the problem was that easy money led to overdevelopment. As banks went public during the 80's, stock sales produced the easier availability of loans.
''Condominiums were becoming more popular, and anyone with a pickup truck called themselves a developer,'' said Nora Moran of the Moran Company Realtors of Back Bay, Boston. ''It produced a glut of condos on the market and then with the change in the tax laws, you had people dumping condos.''
Hendrik Holmes, a Boston developer, said developers seeking to get the most return from land sometimes overbuilt, exacerbating a situation of too many condominiums chasing too few buyers. ''One hundred or 200 units at a clip went up,'' he said. ''The market couldn't absorb this.''

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CEDAR KEY, FLA.;
State Approves Island Marina

BYLINE: By TIM O'REILEY

 BODY:
OVERRIDING the objections of environmentalists and many residents here, the state has approved construction of a marina on the nearby 160-acre island of Atsena Otie, which will make possible its development.
For three years, protesting groups had blocked the building plans of Rex Andrews, who with his sister, Vern Woodlief, inherited the island a mile south of here in 1984. Last month, the Governor and state cabinet granted them a lease on state-controlled submerged land for their slips. 
The lease is critical to the future of Atsena Otie (pronounced at-SEE-nah OH-tee), which is 80 miles north of Tampa on Florida's west coast. It is accessible only by boat and state law prohibits governmental financing of a causeway or bridge to a private island.
Work on the marina can begin Nov. 1, according to the lease. Mr. Andrews, who has a water-treatment company in central Florida, already has retained Pelican Realty of Cedar Key to sell the 36 lots covering the 23 usable acres on the island. Lot prices range from $65,000 to $95,000.
In return for permission to build the marina, Mr. Andrews agreed to cut the number of slips from 43 to 25 and to preserve Indian burial mounds, a manatee habitat and the remains, mostly foundations, of a community that once thrived on the island.
Since granting the lease, the state imposed an indefinite building moratorium on all of 200 islands off the coast pending the drafting by the Department of Natural Resources of a new policy governing their use. The Conservancy, an environmental group based in Naples, counts 112 of the islands as privately owned, and several are under consideration as resort sites. And all but 12 of the islands are off the west coast.
Several cabinet officers who voted for the Atsena Otie marina indicated their support of a ban on the island's development to protect its fragile environments and maintain it as an uninhabited first line of defense against hurricanes.
Now covered by oak and palm trees, Atsena Otie has not had any residents since a turn-of-the-century hurricane destroyed a pencil factory and a dock. The people who survived the storm moved away because the plant, the island's economic base, was not rebuilt. The Andrews family bought the island in the 20's.
Because of the natural threat, all homes will have to be built to Federal Emergency Management Act standards, which include the ability to withstand 19-foot seas and 120 mile-an-hour winds. These rules are in effect throughout coastal Florida.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LITTLE ROCK, ARK.;
Pedestrian Mall Proves a Failure

BYLINE: By DAVE WANNEMACHER

 BODY:
A 17-YEAR experiment in revitalizing downtown Little Rock with a new and fashionable pedestrian mall called MetroCentre apparently has failed. By next January, the city will begin widening the sidewalks and repaving the bricked streets to open to traffic five of its six blocks. The remaining block will be a pedestrian plaza. What was deemed necessary in 1972 for the downtown's economic health - setting up a traffic-free shopping area - has nearly strangled it, and for the last 11 years three buildings at the center of the mall have remained empty. After 5 P.M., the area is all but deserted. 
Little Rock is following the lead of many other cities in removing its pedestrian mall to allow for more vehicular traffic. Opening five blocks of the mall - now four blocks on Main Street and two blocks on Capitol Avenue - will provide two traffic lanes and two parking lanes.
Two years ago local investors raised $13.5 million to convert several empty rundown buildings along Main Street on the mall into a glitzy retail and office center called MainStreet. The addition of 110,000 square feet of renovated space was a much-needed boost, but a lack of enthusiasm among the 40,000 or so downtown office workers has contributed to a high business turnover rate at MainStreet.
The next steps in renovating the downtown area have already begun several blocks to the south, in the historic Quapaw quarter, the original subdivision of Little Rock.
There, $1.2 million will be spent adding landscaping and replacing streetlights, sidewalks, curbs and gutters. The work will take place on Main between 12th and 17th Streets, a strip bouncing back from several years of neglect.
The project, to be completed by March, is being paid for by $300,000 in city bonds and the rest in bonds issued by the Quapaw Quarter Business Improvement District.
The mall is to be reopened to traffic on Main Street from Third to Seventh Streets and on one block of Capital Avenue. Critics say the mall has lost much of its open-air feeling because trees planted for it are now too large. And other obstructions, like an on again, off again, half-block-long water fountain, block views toward the center of the mall.
The winning bid for tearing up the mall came in at $1.8 million, about $700,000 more than expected, but negotiations are under way to reduce the amount. Sterling Cockrill, executive director of the Metrocentre Improvement District, said traffic should be flowing up and down Main Street in a year.

GRAPHIC: photo of A section of MetroCentre in downtown Little Rock, Ark. (NYT/Clay Carson)

HEADLINE: Golf's Appeal Brings New Courses

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
TO meet what they say is a surging demand in the state for golf, developers are planning to build four new courses, in Columbia, East Lyme, Franklin and Middlefield. At the same time, many golf courses are planning expansions and renovations, from the well-known Tournament Players Club in Cromwell to the municipal course in Manchester.
''It's the fastest growing leisure sport in the country and probably in the world,'' ''It's the fastest growing leisure sport in the country and probably in the world,'' said Cliff W. Cable, general manager of the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich. He said the golf industry estimated that if one new course were built every day between now and the turn of the century, it would not be enough to keep up with demand.
Amy J. Starensier, a spokeswoman for Golf Digest magazine, said that there are 162 public, private and municipal golf courses in Connecticut and that almost 11 percent of the state population plays golf, the highest participation rate in New England. 
Mr. Cable said that at his club there is ''a lot of younger interest in the sport, and in club membership.''
''We deter a lot of people from even applying for membership because our waiting list is so long,'' he added. Mr. Cable said someone signing up for membership today could expect to wait at least five years for golf and a year or two for tennis and paddle, two other sports offered at the club.
While the popularity of the sport has been building in Connecticut for several years, Mr. Cable and others in the golf business attribute the waiting lists and the surge in interest to having another golf-playing President in the White House. ''Leaders always tend to affect the public's interests,'' he said.
Nathan Shippee of Old Lyme, who is developing the golf course in East Lyme, said, ''Certainly when the President and Vice President are on the front pages of golf magazines, it gives the sport a lot of prominence.''
Mr. Shippee and the family of George Bush attended the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich. Mr. Shippee left for Texas, to make his fortune in the oil fields, after World War II, about the same time that Mr. Bush left. ''He went into politics and I stayed in oil,'' Mr. Shippee said.
James W. FitzGerald, president of Golf Digest/Tennis Inc. in Trumbull, said the last time golf got such a boost was when Dwight D. Eisenhower was President.
As more players compete for limited playing space in the state, membership fees at some top country clubs are rising. Some players say fees have gone up 50 to 100 percent in five years.
''A membership fee of $25,000 or $30,000 was absolutely unheard of five years ago, but there's several of them around today,'' Mr. FitzGerald said. Private clubs charge $5,000 to $30,000 for an initiation fee, bond and membership for the first year, he said.
Stuart B. Popper, the senior planner in Manchester, where expansion of the municipal course is under way, said golf's growing popularity was a good thing for preservationists.
''It's a nice way to maintain open space,'' Mr. Popper said. But, he said, Manchester lost a private golf course to developers several years ago, and in Glastonbury a private course has been purchased for a housing development where a smaller course will be maintained for residents.
Many courses are being built with luxury housing compleses, and in some cases housing will be built around existing courses.
''A developer sees a golf course as either something to build on or as an amenity for a very exclusive community,'' Mr. Popper said.
''It could be the only way the public will get to play is if municipalities build their own, and in this era of public belt-tightening and fiscal restraint, that's not going to be very likely,'' Mr. Popper said. ''What politician wants to ask taxpayers to spent a few million dollars on a golf course?''
Where they are being developed, though, Connecticut has attracted some of the sport's top names. Ben Crenshaw is designing the East Lyme course. Gary Player has designed another planned for Middlefield.
 
Finding the Land
Golf course developers are also seeking land outside Fairfield County, where most courses in Connecticut are located. Courses are being planned in the towns of Franklin in New London County and Columbia in Tolland County. Besides the popularity of golf, economics has played a part in decisions to find the 130 to 300 acres needed for a golf course in other areas of the state, Mr. FitzGerald said.
''You can't find that much land in Fairfield County at a price that would give you a decent return, using it as a golf course,'' he explained.
Even without the Presidential influence, the new courses make good business sense, said Jerry D. Mobley, general manager of the Cromwell course.
''People have a little more money to spend on recreation, and they're choosing to play golf,'' Mr. Mobley said.
Ms. Starensier of Golf Digest said that the mean household income of golfers in Connecticut is $53,000 and that 24 percent of the golfers here are women, compared with 22 percent nationally.
 
The Sport of Business
Ms. Starensier said Connecticut's growing white-collar work force was another reason for the increase in the sport's popularity. ''Golf plays a significant role in the business arena,'' she said. She said that last weekend she was at a tournament for students at Cornell University. ''The theory behind the tournament is that a good golf swing or good drive is just as important as marketing skills when you get out into the business world,'' Ms. Starensier explained.
Mr. Shippee said he was positive that his $30 million country club on 230 acres in East Lyme, just north of Interstate 95, would be a success. He has already had more offers to buy memberships than are available.
 
Waiting List
''We expect to have a waiting list even before the club opens,'' Mr. Shippee said. He will sell 400 individual and 40 corporate memberships. Members are being drawn from as far as New York, Springfield and Providence.
The course is expected to open in early 1991. Many of the greens are already in place. The property was used by the J. C. Penney Company as a test site for grass seeds and lawnmowers, so it was impeccably maintained before the company moved the operation to Dallas.
Mr. Mobley said the Tournament Players Club course in Cromwell would be completely reconstructed to accommodate 268 luxury townhouses next to the course.
The club purchased 53 adjacent acres on the Connecticut River for the project. The re-design is expected to speed up play by reducing the walk between tees and greens, improving grade levels and creating more space for more golfers.
''It'll be a gorgeous place to live, with all the open space of a golf course,'' Mr. Mobley said, ''and statistics show golf course property retains its value and appreciates quicker than most other properties, except maybe a business property in a good downtown area.''
Others apparently agree with him. So far, 400 people want to buy units, he said, although formal marketing has not begun and construction plans will not even go before the town's Planning and Zoning Commission until next week.

LENGTH: 1725 words

HEADLINE: Impending U.S. Jobs 'Disaster': Work Force Unqualified to Work

SERIES: Skills vs. Jobs; The Classroom Mismatch - First of three articles.

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
David T. Kearns, chairman of the Xerox Corporation, calls it ''the makings of a national disaster.''
Brad M. Butler, former chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company, fears the creation of ''a third world within our own country.''
James E. Burke, chief executive officer of Johnson & Johnson, says it is ''the American dream turned nightmare.''
Corporate America has seen what the nation's schools are producing and it is alarmed.
And many of the students who are most at risk are children from minority groups, the same youngsters who the Labor Department says will fill 56 percent of the new jobs that will open up between 1986 and the year 2000. 
 
Unready for Now or Future
As President Bush prepares to discuss education Wednesday with the nation's governors, population statistics and newly compiled research suggest that American schools are graduating students who lack even the skills needed to fill existing assembly line jobs, let alone the sophisticated new jobs that increasingly dominate the economy.
Research and corporate experience also show that an increasing number of job applicants are among the population groups that are least well served by the nation's schools. ''More than a third of tomorrow's work force will be minorities,'' Mr. Kearns said, ''and half of those are kids growing up poor. A fourth drop out and another fourth don't come close to having the skills to survive in an advanced economy.''
Evidence suggests that they are unlikely to get those skills, since corporations tend to train the workers who already have mastered basic reading and math.
 
Devastating Effects Seen
The result, say leaders in government, business and education, is that America is developing into a nation of educational haves and have-nots, who are fast becoming employment haves and have-nots; that this polarization follows racial lines, and that the effect on the economy and the country could be devastating.
''If we continue to let children who are born in poverty fail to get the kind of education that will allow them to participate in our economy and our society productively,'' Mr. Butler said, ''then some time in the 21st century this nation will cease to be a peaceful, prosperous democracy.''
It is not that America's children are not being educated, researchers say. The problem is that they are not being educated fast enough and at sophisticated enough levels to keep pace with the advances and upgrading in jobs.
''Even the telephone operator job is now computerized,'' said John L. Clendenin, chairman of the board of the BellSouth Corporation in Atlanta. ''Directory assistance operators search a huge electronic data base to retrieve and deliver information to customers. Similarly, most of our clerical jobs require word processing, computer skills or both,'' as do craft jobs and both sales and service positions.
But Mr. Clendenin added: ''In 1987, fewer than 30 percent of employment candidates met our skill and ability requirements for sales, service and technical jobs. Only 15 percent scored at the proficient level on our typing test, and almost 50 percent of those tested were not qualified for jobs requiring even light typing. Over all, we estimate that fewer than 1 in 10 applicants meets all our qualification standards.''
 
Greater Demands in the Future
And the situation is getting worse. ''A recent study found that our jobs will require even more technical knowledge and problem-solving abilities, as more and more rote tasks are performed by computers,'' Mr. Clendenin said. ''With technological change coming more rapidly, even craft employees in the year 2000 will have to adapt and acquire new technical skills rapidly. Most craft employees will also have to be better equipped to interact with customers.''
At the MCI Communications Corporation in Boston, Joanne M. Ramsey, the residential sales manager, said telephone sales jobs paying $7.10 an hour plus incentives are going begging because the company cannot find enough qualified candidates to fill them. ''Now, we have 52 job slots, but only 38 employees,'' she said.
Diane Capstaff, vice president for corporate services and human resources at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston, reports similar hiring problems. ''Some applicants don't have the writing skills to prepare a brief letter to a policy holder or simple math and computer skills,'' she said.
Thomas Bailey, a senior research associate at Columbia University, calls the trend now under way the ''upskilling'' of American jobs, meaning a change from learning based on observation to learning acquired through symbols, both verbal and mathematical.
''Semiliterate textile workers used to be able to function because they saw how their machines worked,'' Mr. Bailey said. ''Now, new machines have invisible microprocessors and other electronic components. Technicians have to repair by decoding complicated manuals, diagrams and updates from manufacturers.''
 
New Kinds of Assembly Lines
Literacy requirements have thus risen sharply, he said. So have mathematics requirements, a result of assembly line innovations in which workers must read gauges, printouts and graphs to monitor quality.
''New opportunities for workers with no more than a high school degree are falling sharply,'' Mr. Bailey said. ''In 1987, 54.6 percent of employed workers were in this category; by 2000 it will be down to 46.5 percent.''
The shift from low- to high-skill jobs and the widespread increase in skill requirements of existing jobs have been documented by the Hudson Institute, a research organization, in a Labor Department study titled ''Workforce 2000: Work and Workers for the 21st Century.''
In a subsequent study, not yet published, the authors of ''Workforce 2000,'' William B. Johnston and Arnold H. Packer, have for the first time correlated data on job skill requirements with data on students' educational achievement. Only tests of verbal skills lent themselves to this kind of analysis, but even on this scale, the results were alarming, they said.
They found that average young adults, 21 to 25 years old, are reading at a level significantly below that demanded by the average job available in 1984 and are even further below the requirements of jobs expected to be created between 1984 and the year 2000.
The researchers used the standard Labor Department scale of 1 to 6 ranking the language skills required for various jobs. Scientists, lawyers and engineers operate at the highest level, 6, signifying the ability to read scientific and technical journals and write speeches. Manual labor jobs fall into the bottom category, 1, signifying rudimentary reading and communication.
 
'A Major Mismatch'
The researchers calculated that the 105 million nonmilitary jobs existing in 1984 required an average language proficiency of 3.0, typical of retail salespeople or skilled construction workers. By contrast, the 26 million jobs expected to be created between 1984 and 2000 will require an average level of 3.6.
These figures were then compared with data on literacy among 3,600 young adults compiled by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a federally supported project that regularly administers tests to national sample groups. Results showed that the average young adult in this country is reading only at a 2.6 level.
''You're talking about a major mismatch of workers and jobs,'' Mr. Packer said.
The mismatch is particularly serious among new, rather than current, jobs. In the Hudson Institute study, Labor Department analysts ranked 87 percent of new jobs at the 3 and 4 levels of reading skills, equivalent to the requirements of sales and marketing positions, but concluded that 97 percent of young adults have skills at the 2 and 3 levels, the needs of farming and transportation work.
 
The Unskilled Will Be Trapped
Evidence strongly indicates that these young workers, who are entering the labor force with inadequate skills, will find themselves in an employment backwater.
''Well educated people are not only the most likely to find employment,'' Mr. Bailey explained, ''but also are the most likely to receive training from their employers. Once trained, their greater productivity earns them more. They switch jobs less frequently and are rarely unemployed. If they change jobs, they find another easily and are more likely to receive further training from new employers.''
But those who start without adequate academic and problem-solving skills fall further behind, he said.
''The well educated face a future of expanding job opportunities and rising wages,'' said Sue E. Berryman, director of the Institute on Education and the Economy at Columbia University's Teachers College, ''while those not well educated face a future of contracting opportunities and poverty.''
The National Assessment of Educational Progress has found some recent improvements in the reading ability of students still in school. But those gains have come primarily in the lower grades, in the most basic reading tasks and among youngsters from low-income families. Thus, millions of students are still underequipped to participate in the emerging job market.
 
Investment in Education Urged
''Our least advantaged students are now drowning in 10 feet of water instead of 15 feet of water, but they're still drowning,'' said Ms. Berryman. ''Lots more are drowning in five feet.' Many business executives, like Mr. Kearns of Xerox, have urged the investment of as much economic and political capital as is needed to overhaul and improve American public education, and thus produce a more highly skilled work force.
''We cannot compete in a world-class economy without a world-class work force,'' Mr. Kearns said, ''and we cannot have a world-class work force without world-class schools.''
In the absence of improved schools, said Mr. Packer of the Hudson Institute, the alternatives are limited: Industry can send skilled jobs overseas, it can automate to accommodate a low-skilled domestic labor force or it can decide against upgrading its operations and the concommitant skill levels of employees.
''Jobs will get filled,'' Mr. Packer said, ''but you're talking about lower productivity and thus a lower standard of living for everyone.''
Next: Basic learning on the job.
